title: Rating the Red Bulls vs. the Houston Dynamo
description: The Red Bulls (3-3-3, 12 points) came into Saturday nights game after their worst performance of the season, last weeks 5-1 loss to the Chicago Fire. This week, the Red Bulls are in Houston to play the two-time defending Major League Soccer champion Dynamo (3-5-3, 14 points).

title: Porter: Appropriate Time Is Derby
description: Rick Porter, the owner of Eight Belles, has decided to not pursue a tribute to the filly before the Belmont Stakes, despite initially supporting a petition to do so.

title: A Tribute to Jim Gray: Sometimes Nice Guys Do Finish First
description: For a half-decade, the San Francisco bureau of The New York Times had a remarkable resource. Just five floors above us were the offices of Microsofts Bay Area Research Center and more specifically, Gordon Bell and Jim Gray, two of the worlds legendary computer scientists. I would have coffee with Jim on occasion, and from time to time, we would head down the alleyway to have lunch at Yank Sing, the local dim sum restaurant.

title: If Presidents Faced Question Time
description: After years of watching President Bush ignore Congress, at best, or disdain it, at worst, there is relief in listening to the British prime minister face questions in Parliament. As seen on C-Span, these events feature literate parries and thrusts, complete sentences, artful arguments, all to a chorus of noisy yeas and brays.

title: Cluster Bombs, Made in America
description: On Friday, 111 nations, including major NATO allies, adopted a treaty that sets an eight-year deadline to eliminate stockpiles of cluster arms  pernicious weapons that scatter thousands of small bombs across a wide area, where they pose a long-term deadly threat to innocents. The Bush administration not only failed to sign the treaty but vigorously opposed it.

title: The Lawyers Crusade
description: In April, on the highway outside the little Punjabi town of Renala Khurd, Aitzaz Ahsan was waylaid by a crowd of seemingly deranged lawyers. The advocates, who wore black suits, white shirts and black ties, were not actually insane; they just seemed that way because they were so overcome with excitement at greeting the mastermind of Pakistans lawyers movement, perhaps the most consequential outpouring of liberal, democratic energy in the Islamic world in recent years. The 62-year-old Ahsan was on his way to address the bar association of Okara, 10 miles away, but the lawyers, and the farmers and shopkeepers gathered with them, were not about to let him leave. They boiled around the car, shouting slogans. Who should our leaders be like? they cried. Like Aitzaz! And, How many are prepared to die for you? Countless! Countless!

title: Boekie Woekie
description: Amsterdam is the antithesis of one-stop shopping.

title: Swallow This
description: From the perspective of an athlete, few things top the virtuous satisfaction that comes from a hard workout. That 10-mile run, that 1,500-meter pool sprint, that hour with the free weights. Makes you feel great, right? Youll do it again tomorrow, for sure. But then it hits  the aftermath.

title: Datebook
description: LOS ANGELES

title: A New Web Site for Students Abroad
description: Exchange students and young United States citizens now have a Web site to use as a resource for international travel. Created and maintained by the State Departments Bureau of Consular Affairs, the site, studentsabroad.state.gov, is part of a larger campaign to promote smart, safe travel by students.

title: Coffee Mated to Chocolate
description: The Quick Bite article last Sunday, about the Kent Coffee & Chocolate Company in Kent, gave an incorrect phone number for the shop. It is (860) 927-1445.

title: In a Girlhood Memoir, Not a Happy Camper
description: THE first time Stephanie Klein heard herself called moose, it was in a school hallway, chanted by a group of older boys while she stood at her locker. She was 13, and had been visiting a nutritionist since she was 8.

title: One-Stop Shopping for Tracking Criminals
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Correction: Edging Closer in Cypruss Divided Capital
description: A map with an article on May 18 about Nicosia, Cyprus, incorrectly described the Republic of Cyprus, the political division on the southern side of the island. While its residents are primarily ethnically Greek, it is an independent country, not part of Greece. The map has been corrected online.

title: Downsizing to 5,000 Square Feet
description: GREENWICH

title: Shes in a Battle to the Very End
description: With no makeup, straggly gray hair framing her face, a shapeless gray cardigan pulled around her shoulders and a stooped gait, Olympia Dukakis looks weak and battered when she comes onstage in The Milk Train Doesnt Stop Here Anymore. Dont you believe it. Her Flora Goforth is far from done for.

title: McCains McClellan Nightmare
description: THEY thought they were being so slick. When the McCain campaign abruptly moved last Tuesdays fund-raiser with President Bush from the Phoenix Convention Center to a private home, it was the next best thing to sending the loathed lame duck into the witness protection program. John McCain and Mr. Bush were caught on camera together for a mere 26 seconds, and at 9 p.m. Eastern time, safely after the networks evening newscasts. The two mens furtive encounter on the Phoenix airport tarmac, as captured by a shaky, inaudible long shot on FoxNews.com, could have been culled from a surveillance video.

title: Talking to Graduates in South Carolina, Bush Calls for Culture of Responsibility
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  President Bush called Saturday for a new culture of responsibility, and he told students they would never find fulfillment in alcohol, drugs or promiscuity.

title: In Love With Fishing at 8, Shes Now a Charter Captain at 22
description: Port Jefferson

title: Dr. Seuss How the Grinch Stole Christmas!
description: A case could be made that the best show on Broadway this past season was not on Broadway at all, but in Justice Helen E. Freedmans courtroom at the State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The show ran for one morning: the day before Thanksgiving, the 11th day of a 19-day strike by the stagehands union. The central character was a man named James Sanna, a producer of the perennial Broadway musical Dr. Seuss How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical. He had cut a side deal with the union, which agreed to stop striking against the St. James Theater, where Grinch was playing (the symbolism of the Grinchs stealing Christmas from Whoville, pounced upon by the news media, was too much even for the powerful union).

title: Baghdad Jews Have Become a Fearful Few
description: BAGHDAD  I have no future here to stay.

title: Kristen Kennedy, John Koecheler
description: Kristen Patricia Kennedy, a daughter of Roseanne C. Kennedy and Robert E. Kennedy of Vero Beach, Fla., was married there on Saturday to John Edward Koecheler, a son of Maureen D. Koecheler of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Gary E. Koecheler. The Rev. Kevin W. Wildes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bullfighting Is Dead! Long Live the Bullfight!
description: It was the time of Las Fallas, the annual spring festival in Valencia. Giant papier-mch cartoon floats of Sinbad and Snow White and troupes of amateur dancers with lacquered hair and sequined outfits jammed the old city squares. Spanish matrons and women in evening dresses joined the teenagers and the men in business suits thronging the plaza de toros. The matador Jos Toms had come to fight.

title: The Burgers Are Back
description: After a fire closed it for winter repairs, the Blazer Pub in Purdys is back in business. Scrubbed and repainted, this casual roadhouse has rarely missed a beat in its 30 years of operation, the last 15 under the OLeary family. Little has changed over the years, and thats the way Blazer customers like it.

title: A Hush-Hush Plan for a Not-So-Secret Garden
description: THE trustees of New York Marble Cemetery, in the East Village, like to think of their half-acre as a secret garden. The cemetery sits within the block bounded by Second Avenue, the Bowery, and Second and Third Streets, and the sole, gated entrance, on Second Avenue, is opened only on the fourth Sunday of every month.

title: Hall of Famer
description: He wasnt a sportswriter. No insult implied, but sportswriters tend to fall into two categories: stylists attempting to turn sport into literature in glossy magazines, and reporters serving it up as news in daily papers. By the evidence of the 44 pieces in this occasionally satisfying collection  spanning his career, from 1955 to 2006  David Halberstam was a different animal.

title: Jamaican Sets World Record in 100 Meters at 9.72
description: The Reebok Grand Prix meet took place at Randalls Island on Saturday night, but it was a home crowd for Jamaicas newest sprint star at 100 meters, Usain Bolt.

title: The Backstage Sights, the Locker Room Scents
description: THE behind-the-scenes tour is a staple of the pamphlet-driven tourist routine, promising a glimpse beyond the glitzy sites where shows and sporting events are put on in this city.

title: Passing Strange
description: Its particularly satisfying because it doesnt happen every night. Sometimes during Keys, a climactic number in the first act of Passing Strange, Stew (left) thrusts a microphone into the audience so his listeners can sing along. Playing the narrator (he also wrote the book, the lyrics and part of the music), he sings about the sexual and intellectual liberation that the American protagonist, played by Daniel Breaker, has found in Europe. Stew works himself into a gospel-rock lather as he repeats the words Its all right, and when he lies down on the stage, stretching across it so that the front row can shout the chorus with him, he transforms the spectators into full participants. Instead of just observing it, the crowd helps create the moment.

title: New Hampshire Hoedown
description: Boozing and brawling and country music might not be the first things that come to mind when you think of New Hampshire; presidential primary is more like it. But after reading Sing Me Back Home, youre likely to agree with Dana Jennings, a native of one of the rougher regions of that state, that the feel-bad songs of Hank Williams and George Jones and Loretta Lynn are the soundtrack for the lives we all live.

title: Correction: Making Sense of Money for Those Who Cant
description: The introduction to a chart last Sunday showing artists proposals for currency that would help the visually impaired differentiate among denominations referred incorrectly to one proposal. Two of the icons that the designer called for punching into each bill represented the founding fathers Hamilton (a pistol for the $10 bill) and Franklin (a kite for the $100 bill). The icons were not all representing former presidents.

title: Setting Politics Aside to Help Victims of China Earthquake
description: In the three weeks since the earthquake ravaged Chinas Sichuan Province, the Chinese-American community that stretches from Chinatown in Lower Manhattan to the large enclaves on the West Coast has contributed millions of dollars to relief efforts, dwarfing past fund-raising campaigns.

title: Let Them Count the Ways
description: Carl Ballenas

title: My Dropout Boyfriend Kept Dropping In
description: IN April of my freshman year, my boyfriend, Terry, decided he wanted to be homeless. Among the decisions I expected a college-age boyfriend to make (changing cellphone plans, or maybe going vegan), homelessness was not one of them.

title: Connie Ng, Paul Hess
description: Dr. Connie May Ng and Dr. Paul Laurence Hess were married on Saturday evening at the Memorial Church of Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Mark D. W. Edington, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Texas Carny and His Coney Island Gal
description: THE Tornado roller coaster, precursor and rival to the world-famous Cyclone, stood on the east side of Stillwell Avenue in Coney Island from 1926 until 1977, when it perished in a fire. More recently, that block, between Bowery Street and the Boardwalk, was home to a go-cart track and a cluster of batting cages. Then last spring, in preparation for a planned revitalization that has yet to arrive, the lands owner, Thor Equities, cleared it of everything but rocks and dirt, and it sat empty, all summer long.

title: Put a Little Science in Your Life
description: A COUPLE of years ago I received a letter from an American soldier in Iraq. The letter began by saying that, as weve all become painfully aware, serving on the front lines is physically exhausting and emotionally debilitating. But the reason for his writing was to tell me that in that hostile and lonely environment, a book Id written had become a kind of lifeline. As the book is about science  one that traces physicists search for natures deepest laws  the soldiers letter might strike you as, well, odd.

title: Claudia DeSimio and Alexander Gil
description: Claudia Marie DeSimio, a daughter of Sheila E. DeSimio and Christopher J. DeSimio of Cincinnati, was married on Saturday to Alexander Guillermo Gil, the son of Christine E. Argento of Miami and the late Guillermo A. Gil. Lea J. Goldman, who became an associate pastor of Rose Ministries for this event, officiated at the Caneel Bay resort on St. John, Virgin Islands.

title: Letters: The Hillary Lesson
description: Peggy Orenstein (May 18) is correct: all is not quite well for women today. Clintons bid for the presidency has unleashed the dormant monster of sexism that our mothers and grandmothers recognize all too well. Misogyny is alive, and post-feminism is my generations delusion.

title: City of Eclectics
description: If the romance of Paris is a cultural commonplace, so too is its reputation for depths that can never be plumbed, a code that cannot be deciphered. You might know every street in Paris, observed Henry Miller, one of the citys best-known expatriates, and not know Paris. Cole Porter likewise cautioned that you may know Paris, but you dont know Paree. Yet clichs (if youll pardon the clich) ring true for a reason; accordingly, Mtro Stop Paris: An Underground History of the City of Light confirms the notion that there is always something more to learn about Frances capital. Written by Gregor Dallas, this thinkers guide to Paris attempts to probe unexplored or underappreciated aspects of the citys history. To this end, Dallas, whose books include a study of the Loire peasantry and a biography of Georges Clemenceau, offers a dozen vignettes from different historical eras, each tale at least ostensibly associated with a specific Parisian neighborhood.

title: A Studio, Priced Just Right
description: JEFF SIEBERT grew up in a small farming town near Fresno, Calif., watching movie musicals and yearning for a life in the big city. He got it when he moved to New York 24 years ago, beginning a successful career as a Broadway dancer with parts in Miss Saigon, Cabaret and Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, among others.

title: Sex and the City (Circa 1840)
description: On April 9, 1842, The Whip, a weekly New York newspaper that pledged to keep a watchful eye on all brothels and their frail inmates, carried an article about chambermaids. Chambermaids were women of flesh and blood, according to the article, with the same instinctive desires as their masters, and much of their time is necessarily passed alone, in remote apartments, which usually contain beds. Accompanying the article was a drawing: a chambermaid gripped the long wooden handle of a warming pan that projected rudely from between a tailcoated gentlemans legs.

title: Two Different Developers Gave Block Its Character
description: Q I live at 632 West End Avenue. Why are there two nearly identical corner buildings flanking a row of nearly identical brownstones? ... George Moran, Manhattan

title: A Very Dirty Movie
description: Documentarians dont get much burlier than Chris Bell. The 35-year-old was a competitive powerlifter before geneticshe stands 5-foot-6 on a good dayforced a career change and sent him off to the University of Southern Californias film school. Bells two brothers, Mad Dog and Smelly, werent so quick to give up their athletic dreams and turned to steroids to further their pursuits of glory. Bells debut film, Bigger Stronger Faster, uses his family as a starting point to probe the sports world obsession with sports-enhancing drugs. It had its premiere at Sundance in January and went into limited release in New York and Los Angeles on May 30. Wider release will follow. He spoke to Play about juicing, family style

title: Think the Economy Is Bad? Wait Till the States Cut Back
description: Struggling as we are with the housing bust, the credit crunch, shrinking consumption, rising unemployment and faltering business investment, we can be forgiven for thinking that all the big shoes have dropped. There is another one up there, however, and it is about to come down.

title: When Thumbs Up Is No Comfort
description: OVER the Memorial Day weekend, the actor Patrick Swayze, who is being treated for pancreatic cancer, made a pointedly public appearance at a Los Angeles Lakers game, looking strong-jawed and bright-eyed. He released a statement about his lively schedule and good response to therapy. Meanwhile, Senator Ted Kennedy, who had recently left Massachusetts General Hospital with a diagnosis of brain cancer, flashing crowds a thumbs up, competed in a sailing race. International headlines cheered, Fight, Ted, Fight!

title: Pulling No Punches, Brawler Wins His Prime-Time Debut
description: NEWARK  At 9 p.m. on a wet Saturday, mixed martial arts opened its case to join the mainstream. The CBS announcer Gus Johnson looked into the camera and proclaimed the evening  the sports live debut on network television  the dawn of an era in American sports.

title: High-End Hotels Are Still Opening in Beijing
description: The hotel boom in Beijing continues as the Summer Olympics draw near. The stylish Hotel G Beijing will open this month in the Chaoyang District, where bars and restaurants like the Green T. House abound. The design of the 110-room hotel (www.avantgardehotels.com) seems to be inspired by the retro-chic sensibility of the Austin Powers movie series, and guests have a choice of three restaurants: 25 Degrees (upscale burgers and cocktails), Gilt (Mediterranean cuisine) and Morio (Japanese fine dining). There is also a spa. Nightly rates start at about 2,010 yuan, or $289 at 7 yuan to the dollar, through the end of the month, after which the rates will increase to about 2,369 yuan, or $334 at the same exchange rate. For those who prefer a corporate ambience  and to stay high above the city  there is the Park Hyatt Beijing (www.beijing.park.hyatt.com), scheduled to open next month in the business district. There will be 237 rooms on floors 37 to 49 in the Park Tower (part of the Beijing Yintai Center). Rates are expected to start at 3,500 yuan.

title: Lindsey Dickinson, Ernest Baynard IV
description: Lindsey Putnam Dickinson and Ernest Cornish Baynard IV were married on Saturday in Ludlow, Vt. The Rev. Michael E. Augustinowitz officiated at Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Al Green: Neo-Souls Not Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Humanitarian Vanities
description: Ours is an age in which the responsibility for protecting people when their physical survival is at stake has become an increasingly accepted principle in international relations. It is even enshrined in a United Nations-approved covenant as the responsibility to protect  the idea being that a state that engages in criminal behavior toward its own people has forfeited not just its moral but also its legal right to sovereignty.

title: Relief Helicopter Crashes in China
description: SHANGHAI  A Chinese military helicopter involved in relief operations crashed in heavy fog near the town of Yingxiu on Saturday with 14 people on board, according to Chinas official news agency, Xinhua, which provided no details about casualties.

title: Roberta Finke, Alan Franklin
description: Roberta Sue Finke and Alan Marc Franklin were married Thursday evening at Cipriani 23rd Street in New York. Rabbi Marcelo R. Bronstein officiated.

title: Darcy Bentley, Daniel Frisch
description: Darcy Virginia Bentley and Daniel Frisch were married on Friday evening in Manhattan. Justice Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the New Leaf Caf in Fort Tryon Park.

title: Triway to Hell
description: Because a triathlon requires a swim, a bike ride and a run, a staple of most training schedules is the dreaded brick workout: two or more disciplines back to back. The theory is that the brick familiarizes you with the feeling of running on legs whose freshness has long since expired. For most people, a brick is a run immediately following a ride, but really, whats the difference? Work is work is work.

title: Theyre Grants to Some, Pork Barrel to Others
description: WITH $9.8 million in taxpayer money to spend at their discretion, Nassau Countys 19 legislators are in an enviable position as they look to do good and win friends.

title: Technology Stocks Are the Weeks Stars
description: The overall stock market managed a small gain for the week, and technology stocks propelled the Nasdaq composite index to a hefty advance.

title: Connecticut Lobstermen Hope for a Reprieve
description: HARTFORD

title: Its All About Leverage
description: Barack Obama is getting painfully close to tying himself in knots with all his explanations of the conditions under which he would unconditionally talk with Americas foes, like Iran. His latest clarification was that there is a difference between preparations and preconditions for negotiations with bad guys. Such hair-splitting word games do not inspire confidence, and they play right into the arms of his critics. The last place he wants to look uncertain is on national security.

title: Officials Look at Equipment, Not Cranes Operators
description: This article was reported by Charles V. Bagli, Ken Belson and William Neuman, and written by Mr. Neuman.

title: Its Good to Be Immortal
description: 1. HE HAD SHARPIE ALL OVER HIM.

title: Working the Reunion
description: You always knew when, at the end of the spring semester, reunion week approached. They would drape a three-story-tall blue banner over Commons; emblazoned on it were gigantic white letters: YALE. When I was in school there, I always worked reunions. You could score about two thousand bucks in a few weeks doing custodial work, waiting on tables, making up rooms and Y-ing the beds. To Y a bed, youd make it up with a Yale blue blanket, then arrange three white towels on top into a Y, for Yale. Actually, everything had to be in a Y  the soaps, the extra blankets, any spare change left on the dresser.

title: 60s Legacy, Personal Histories
description: LESLIE HEWITT was not yet a glimmer in her parents eye when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his I Have a Dream speech at the March on Washington. Still, whenever Ms. Hewitt, a 30-year-old artist, sees images of the crowds at this 1963 event, she searches the more than 200,000 faces for her mother.

title: When a Landlord Wont Return a Security Deposit
description: Q I moved into an apartment on a one-year lease. Thirty days before the end of my lease, I gave notice to vacate and requested, in writing, the return of my security deposit and interest.

title: A Union President Presses for Growth Amid a New Round of Criticisms
description: As 2,000 convention delegates gather in Puerto Rico, the Service Employees International Union is about to jettison a time-honored union tradition  having members go to their union representatives with their questions and grievances.

title: Large Fire Strikes Universal Studio Lot
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  A massive fire erupted early Sunday at NBC Universals studio lot here, destroying a vault full of video and television images and parts of a popular studio tour, including the studios King Kong attraction.

title: Marriage Partners
description: The recent California Supreme Court decision granting gays the right to marry creates a novel predicament. In November, California voters will quite likely have to decide whether to take marriage away from gay couples rather than whether to grant it to them. If Golden State voters decide to preserve that right, the freedom to marry will no longer be the product of activist judges but will acquire a democratic imprimatur. This high-stakes vote squarely poses the question of whether and how gays can get the support of straights on this issue.

title: Shuttle Discovery Heads Toward the Space Station
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Discovery blasted its way into orbit on Saturday through wispy clouds against blue skies on its way to deliver a bus-size laboratory to the International Space Station.

title: What to Watch
description: Consider the following definition: I know what madness is. Its not knowing how another man feels. And this corollary: A madmans never been in another mans shoes.

title: Come Back, Little Sheba
description: Its the morning after in the life of Lola Delaney. The last time she saw her husband, he called her a fat slut and a whoremonger, screamed that she had ruined his life, and as a coup de grce, lunged at her with a butcher knife.

title: Road Maps to Automotive Adventures
description: SPRING and summer have traditionally been the time for piling into the car and heading out for an adventure, whether in the next county or on the next continent. Some recent books document just such drives on the wild side. Other current titles take the reader on a different sort of ride: an armchair tour of dream garages or a journey down the long and winding road traversed by Henry Fords Model T. Here are some road maps for whatever trip you choose.

title: Emily Ryan Lerner, Evan Kindley
description: Emily Ryan Lerner, the daughter of Margaret R. Ryan and Steven P. Lerner of Manhattan, was married last Monday to Evan Sinnard Kindley, a son of Louise S. Kindley and Jeffrey B. Kindley, also of Manhattan. Magistrate Judge Ronald L. Ellis, of Federal District Court in Manhattan, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: From Clay to Bronze to the Hall
description: TRYON, N.C.  The door to the sculptors studio in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains swung open, and there stood Buck ONeil, the Negro leagues legend, in red clay, 6 feet tall, nearly ready to be bronzed.

title: Jennifer Baker, Samuel Taylor
description: Jennifer Marie Baker was married on Saturday to Dr. Samuel Arthur Taylor in Cleveland. The Rev. John L. Viall, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. John Cantius Church, with the Rev. Donald H. Dunson, also a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: The Supper Club
description: When I think of home, I think of the index-card reminder that arrives in the mailbox each month with the words FIRST WEDNESDAY scribbled in Magic Marker. If we lived in a small town in Iowa, or in Pennsylvania Dutch country, the freewheeling potluck dinner that has been held on our block on the first Wednesday of every month for the past 18 years might not seem like such big a deal. But this is Oakland, Calif.

title: High Pants Forever
description: Why did the nerd button the top button of his shirt? Thats not the setup to a riddle. Its one of the mysteries solved in American Nerd: The Story of My People, by Benjamin Nugent.

title: Who Has the Horse Tranquilizers?
description: The Olympics in Beijing are nearly upon us, and if the previous Summer Gamesnot to mention the events of the intervening four yearsare any indication, drug scandals will be part of the festivities. In March, 11 of 14 weight lifters on the Greek Olympic team tested positive for steroid use, and the Greek coach, in turn, blamed a Chinese manufacturer for providing them with tainted supplements. And so it begins. There will always be someone who tests positive at the Olympics, says Gary Wadler, a New York University medical professor and the chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agencys Prohibited List and Methods Committee. Somebody will do a dumb thing, thinking they can get away with it. To some athletes, apparently, doping remains an unofficial Olympic sport. Time for a tutorial on the drugs of summer.

title: City to Explore a Way to Add Organ Donors
description: New York City is pioneering a potential solution to a supply-and-demand problem that has long vexed doctors the world over: how to meet a desperate need for donated organs without trampling on sensitivity surrounding the sanctity of death.

title: Personalize This
description: By VIRGINIA HEFFERNAN

title: Hannah Means, Russell Shannon
description: Hannah Elizabeth Means and Russell Andrew Shannon were married on Saturday in Lahaska, Pa. The Rev. William Peterson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Anna Stancioff, Frederick Bierman
description: Anna Marion Stancioff and Frederick Carrington Bierman were married on Saturday evening at Woodend Sanctuary in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Beth Humphrey, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Meeting Set to Discuss Future of Maple Bats
description: Representatives from the commissioners office, the players union and major league teams will meet June 24 in New York to discuss the future of maple bats.

title: Swing Science: The Fine Points
description: THE MOST DIFFICULT FEAT IN SPORTS, DEMYSTIFIED. HALL OF FAMER AND THREE-TIME BATTING CHAMPION GEORGE BRETT DISCUSSES THE CRAFT OF HITTING: HOW TO IDENTIFY A PITCH THAT IS TRAVELING AT MORE THAN 90 MILES AN HOUR AND THEN MAKE CONTACT WITH ITALL IN LESS THAN A SECOND.

title: Again, for the First Time
description: WHEN your high school English teachers talked about the rewards of revisiting the classics, they probably didnt mean musicals. Most likely they were referring to fat, dense novels (Middlemarch, Anna Karenina) and long, lofty plays (Hamlet, Long Days Journey Into Night): works of weight, they liked to tell us, dragging out a favorite dog-eared phrase, with universal human truth.

title: Prison Puppies
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y.

title: History, Revised
description: To the Editor:

title: Events in Westchester
description: Film

title: Editors Choice
description: BLACK FLIES, by Shannon Burke. (Soft Skull, paper, $14.95.) A rookie paramedic in New York City is overwhelmed by the horrors of his job in this arresting, confrontational novel, informed by Burkes five years of experience on city ambulances.

title: With Few Policy Differences, Little to Argue in Senate Race
description: TRENTON

title: Sacrificing Space for Scenery
description: ITS a view with an apartment, said Mark Del Vecchio of his home on the 42nd floor of a beige brick behemoth near Lincoln Center.

title: Beyond Harry & David
description: The coconut is technically a fruit, and every now and then it grows a pearl. The pearl-bearing coconut is one of some 30 surprising fruits that caused me to pencil an exclamation mark in the margins of The Fruit Hunters: A Story of Nature, Adventure, Commerce and Obsession. Though I did not rank them, I would place the coconut more or less equidistant between the orange that tastes like chicken noodle soup and the exploding variety of pomegranate (grenade means pomegranate in French), but some distance below the miracle fruit, which makes everything eaten afterward taste sweet, including boyfriends. Adam Leith Gollner possesses a talent as rare and exotic as a coconut pearl. I opened this book, Gollners first, expecting the standard nutmeat of competent nonfiction and found instead something lustrous and exhilarating. Gollners is not the sort of talent one can develop. It is genetic, physical  an exquisite sensitivity of tongue, nose and eye. He describes one variety of the stinking durian fruit as tasting like undercooked peanut butter-mint omelets in body-odor sauce; langsats are tangy-sweet detonations of citric perfection; biting into a monkey tamarind is like eating cloud. Here is the Kuching market in Borneo, through the prism of Gollners gifts: Balmy effluvia rising off the sidewalk clamp down on your sinus cavity. ... Writhing, roiling masses of fat sago worms are sold out of tree trunks. Men shout death threats at one another over corridors littered with squid tentacles.

title: Surf and Turf
description: The United States Open, normally a grueling challenge that pays homage to even par, may well undergo a personality change when play begins on June 12 at the Torrey Pines South course in San Diego. It will be

title: Crane Collapses Prompt Questions on the Mayors Oversight
description: It has become the signature image of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs transformation of the economically fragile city he inherited in 2002: the towers that punch skyward throughout New York, gleaming testaments to the billionaire businessmans management of an unwieldy urban bureaucracy.

title: Letter: Wall Streets Agony
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: Ireland and Progress
description: To the Editor: Regarding Dan Barrys search for the real Ireland in his article, Does the Real Ireland Still Exist? (May 18): The issue lies in what he is searching for. If you believe the real Ireland to be the one portrayed in The Quiet Man or more recently in Far and Away, you are searching for something that exists primarily in the minds of movie producers or those nostalgic for a past no longer widely seen.

title: Out for Blood, Right There on the Net
description: HE what? He was killed by Indians in Massachusetts? I lean forward. Was it a scalping?

title: Where Change Is Underfoot, and Overhead
description: The following article was reported and written before the East 91st Street crane collapse on May 30.

title: French Toast
description: Many culturally hungry Americans dream about moving to France. Weve Always Had Paris ... and Provence is the story of two who did so and have lived happily ever after. Patricia Wells, known best for her seminal Food Lovers Guide to Paris, and Walter Wells, a high-ranking editor of The International Herald Tribune from 1980 to 2005, have written a he-said, she-said memoir, volleying back and forth to tell how a girl from Wisconsin and a boy from South Carolina met while working at The New York Times and went to France in 1980 on what they assumed would be temporary journalistic assignments. They found their lives calling as expatriates, transcending prejudice to be accepted and even revered by the foreign culture they embraced. Walter was awarded the French Legion of Honor. Patricia recounts with no small measure of self-amazement the time she showed the Frenchman Jol Robuchon, the greatest chef in the world, how to make her special bouillabaisse.

title: Patrolling the Streets, and Dissing the Rivals
description: IN mid-April, a young black man in Crown Heights was struck with a baton and sprayed with Mace by two white men, according to the police, and ever since, tensions have run high in the Brooklyn neighborhood. Jews and blacks who live there eye one another warily, and police patrols and surveillance have intensified.

title: Save the Shade

title: First Comes the Swap. Then Its the Knives.

(Remember, these are the same instruments that played such a pivotal role in the collapse of Bear Stearns.)

title: Hope You Like Jamming Too

So a Jamaica Tourist Board ad campaign stated in the 1970s, as tourism became the bread and butter of the Caribbean and Bob Marley secured international fame. Promoting the radical notion that there was  gasp!  culture in resortland proved a smart strategy; today Jamaica is to the Caribbean as Starbucks is to coffee: the brand name that inspires fervent fidelity and chronic visits. To cite the current Jamaica Tourist Board motto, which has cult written all over it, Once you go, you know.

title: Its Where You Live That Matters
description: Q. I have lived in my rent-stabilized two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan for more than 12 years. Recently, title to my mother's condominium in New Jersey was transferred to my name for estate planning purposes. She resides there and pays me a nominal rent. My apartment in New York is my legal mailing address and is where I actually live. Have I put myself in a situation whereby my landlord could challenge my right to continue to live in my apartment?

title: Democrats Approve Deal on Michigan and Florida
description: WASHINGTON  To jeers and boos that showcased deep party divisions, Democratic Party officials agreed Saturday to seat delegates from the disputed Florida and Michigan primaries at the partys convention in August but give them only half a vote each, dealing a setback to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: And Now, the Biggest Entertainer in Entertainment
description: Floyd Mayweather Jr., the welterweight widely regarded as pound for pound the best boxer in the world, is about as rich and famous as a 147-pound fighter can get these days. People who dont know anything about boxing beyond Mike Tyson and Muhammad Ali recognize him on the street (Whos that little guy with all the bodyguards?), although sometimes it takes an extra second or two. (Its that boxer who was on Dancing with the Stars.) Mayweather, who used to be known as Pretty Boy and now answers to Money, is famous, but hes not famous famous. He wont settle for that. He wants to be bigger than boxing today can make him.

title: Triple Play
description: The sun is shining, the school year is winding down and librarians everywhere are promoting summer reading. Promoting? Cheerleading, browbeating and nagging is more like it. Every public library childrens room is gearing up. Reading records? Check. Book lists? Check. Giveaway prizes, stickers, bookmarks? Check, check, check.

title: In the Pacific, a New Kind of Monument Is Proposed
description: The Bush administration is taking steps to create a new kind of national monument encompassing Pearl Harbor and other World War II sites in the Pacific.

title: Bro Knows Football
description: Only one sports fan has managed to go the entirety of the N.B.A. playoffs while ignoring Charles Barkleys television commercials. His name is Charles Barkley. It is not that Sir Charles is embarrassed by his commercial work, past and present: the famous I Am Not a Role Model ad for Nike; his battle against Godzilla; the opera buffa Barkley of Seville; and, most recently, the series of T-Mobile ads co-starring Dwyane Wade that seem to appear at least 90 times during any N.B.A. telecast. No, its that for Barkley, there is something unnerving about being confronted with his commercial self. I try to always look away or something like that, Barkley told me recently. I dont want anyone to think Im an egomaniac.

title: August: Osage County and Macbeth
description: Its a tough call this season about what constituted the worse invitation: dinner at the Westons or at the Macbeths. Ones immediate response is: The Macbeths of course. The head of the households a murderer, after all. But while the onstage supper table in August: Osage County (left), Tracy Lettss three-act drama of mounting family turmoil, is not haunted by any bloodied ghosts, there are plenty of place settings for skeletons of the closet variety. And though Violet Weston (Deanna Dunagan), the soul-flaying matriarch of the plays Oklahoma clan, doesnt actually kill anybody during the searing dinner scene, she has assassins skills to match anything the Thane of Cawdor can muster. Venom tongued and gimlet eyed, she seasons her broods repast with cutting remarks, knocking off relations like so many targets in a sideshow shooting gallery.

title: Water Proof
description: Fiji Water

title: Taking Their Faith, but Not Their Politics, to the People
description: ST. LOUIS  Southern Baptists, as a rule, do not drink. But once a month, young congregants of the Journey, a Baptist church here, and their friends get together in the back room of a sprawling brew pub called the Schlafly Bottleworks to talk about the big questions: President Bush, faith and war, the meaning of life, and whats wrong with religion.

title: Following Months of Criticism, Obama Quits His Church
description: ABERDEEN, S.D.  Senator Barack Obama has resigned his membership in Chicagos Trinity United Church of Christ, which he attended for nearly two decades, following months of controversy about pastors and their political views.

title: No Road Map for Democrats as Race Ends
description: The big drama now facing the Democratic Party in the presidential contest is how, when and even whether Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will depart the race.

title: A Century of Vistas: Depicting Natures Glory
description: Out of the approximately 55,000 objects at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, 45,000 of them are prints and works on paper. The same is true of many other regional art museums, which tend to specialize in collecting works in so-called minor art media.

title: As Seen on YouTube (and Pretty Much Only on YouTube)
description: When Vova Galchenko juggles, he often dresses in a red tank top and black track pants  no clown suit, no mime makeup, nothing that comes off as circusy, French or gay, as he puts it.

title: These Games Brought to You by . . .
description: In Beijing this spring, I was halfway through a tour of the spacious new headquarters of Li-Ning, Chinas leading athletic-wear company, when a poster stopped me short. Li-Nings offices, like those of every other sporting goods company, starting with Nike and Adidas, are dominated by huge advertisements of athletes who wear its shoes and clothes, including Shaquille ONeal.

title: R.F.K., R.I.P., Revisited
description: June 8, 1968

title: Going Nowhere
description: Dear American Airlines, Jonathan Miless fine first novel, takes the form of a letter to the titular air carrier, which has stranded Benjamin R. Ford, the books middle-aged protagonist, in OHare Airport on the way to his estranged daughters wedding. One doesnt take this premise literally, of course. As Bennie waits to be put on another flight, he has a lot of time on his hands, enough to miss first the rehearsal dinner and then the wedding itself (quotation marks courtesy of Benjamin, whos just found out that his daughter is marrying a woman), but not enough to write a novel. The premise works though, because, as anyone whos ever been stalled in an airport knows, time crawls. It feels like eternity,

title: Four's a Charm
description: WHAT do you wear to your own relaunching? That was the question on Ashantis mind on a recent Thursday evening as she prepped and primped in a suite at the Four Seasons.

title: 36 Hours in Lima, Peru
description: LIMA has long been a cosmopolitan city hesitant to embrace its diversity. A capital founded by Spanish conquistadors that subsequently exploded with influxes from Asia and then from Perus own Andean highlands, it has remained a city of fairly segregated neighborhoods. But led by Limas cuisine  which is rapidly gaining worldwide renown for its freshness and creativity  that is changing. Sushi and ceviche chefs are learning from one another. The most popular street food is five flavors a rice and pasta dish with Italian, Chinese, Andean, Japanese and African influences. Restaurants that once hid their existence from all but the in the know are now advertising their presence with Web sites and  gasp  signs out front. For the tourist, it means days of exploring neighborhoods and attractions with distinct cultures and histories, interspersed with the spicy, sweet, and subtle gastronomic experience of how it all comes together.

title: Imported Plays? Small World
description: IN the last year I have seen shows in Off Broadway theaters from, among other places, Argentina, Canada, England, Ireland, Israel, Korea, Poland, Russia and Scotland. New York is as much a global theater capital as ever, so why doesnt it always seem that way?

title: Chile and Peru Vie in Spat Over Spud
description: LIMA, Peru  They have quarreled over the 1880s pillaging of Perus national library by Chilean troops. They have squabbled over who has the naming rights to pisco, the fiery grape brandy. Now, Peru and Chile are arguing over another hot-button issue: the origins of the potato.

title: At a Beloved Bookstore, an Ending With a Twist
description: A LARGE yellow sign in the window of Paperbacks Plus in Riverdale bore the news, but Mary Kelleher, an 88-year-old neighbor who left the bookstore slowly, leaning on a cane and carrying a Mary Higgins Clark novel, hadnt seen it.

description: Sacha Zimmerman and J. Peter Scoblic were married on Saturday evening at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington. Smith Glover, a Universal Life minister, officiated, and Brother Dietrich Reinhart, a Benedictine monk, took part in the ceremony.

title: Prospective Buyers on Board
description: IT seemed somehow fitting that a recent tour of foreclosed homes in Nassau County was held on a bus that, with leopard-print sofas, a wood- and mirror-paneled ceiling and a wet bar, looked as if it was headed for Atlantic City rather than for New Hyde Park.

title: Swiss to Decide on Secret Votes by Public on Citizenship Candidates
description: ADLISWIL, Switzerland  Milikije Arifi has lived in Switzerland for more than 30 years, since she was 18, and raised a family here. She is fluent in German  the principal language here in the north of the country  and speaks it with the same Swiss accent as her neighbors. She passed an examination on Swiss and local history and government.

title: Criminal Inquiry Is Opened in New York Crane Collapse
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office has opened a criminal investigation into a fatal crane accident on the East Side, focusing on whether a part of the crane had been seriously damaged last year and then inappropriately put back into service, an official involved in the investigation said on Saturday.

title: Bomb Kills Man in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide car bomber rammed his vehicle into a NATO military convoy in the eastern city of Jalalabad at midday on Saturday, killing one NATO soldier and wounding six others.

title: Correction: She Just Might Be President Someday
description: An article on May 18 exploring the question of who might be the first female president of the United States referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for candidates. In a brief reference to Maria Shriver, the article noted that her husband (Arnold Schwarzenegger) cant run because he was not born in this country. The Constitution says only that the president must be a natural-born citizen, not that the president must have been born in the United States.

title: What You Need to Know to Get a Mortgage
description: GETTING a mortgage used to be as easy as choosing the right color paint for a new home. Dont have stellar credit? No problem. No verified income? Step right over here. High debt-to-income ratio? Sign on the dotted line anyway.

title: Sticking to What It Knows: Chinese
description: ALTHOUGH Zongs Shanghai in Bethpage is less than a year old, it is a throwback. It is solely Chinese: not fusion, not Pan-Asian. There are no tempuras, teriyakis, pad Thai noodles or Vietnamese summer rolls on the menu. Nor is there a sushi bar tucked in a corner.

description: John Weber, an art dealer known for his early advocacy of Conceptual Art, Post-Minimalist sculpture and Italian Arte Povera, died on May 23 at his home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 75.

Mr. Lettss blistering family drama August: Osage County has already received several significant awards, notably the Pulitzer Prize and the New York Drama Critics Circle award. The top Tony, should it arrive on cue, will crown a remarkable season for Mr. Letts and his colleagues from the Steppenwolf Theater Company, the Chicago troupe that created this electrifying production.

title: Jumbo Lit

The Previa is a fantastic vehicle, requiring virtually no upkeep, but The Man Without Qualities is even more fantastic, despite being 1,774 pages long, which is why hardly anybody has finished it.

description: Sheila Yvonne Samuels and Gerard Darryl Graddy were married on Saturday in New Rochelle, N.Y. Canon Franklin L. Reid, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Greentree Country Club.

title: Time Presses the Gardener, if Not the Garden
description: LOOKING out the window to see who was at the bird feeder, I noticed buds on the Carolina jessamine. It was one of the first things I had planted in the garden; when I found it at the nursery, I was transported back to an island off the Georgia coast where it climbed high into the trees, perfuming the air and showering me with golden petals. That was eight years ago, and it had never bloomed.

title: Good Housing News, and From a Banker
description: Under Ed Clark, its chief executive, the Toronto-Dominion Bank has emerged largely unscathed by the current subprime credit trouble. That, in turn, has left Mr. Clark with some very valuable stock options, which he must exercise soon.

title: Safe at Home
description: As a junior in high school in 1984 I studied Russell Bakers Pulitzer Prize-winning 1982 memoir, Growing Up, in which he recounted his childhood after his father died when Baker was 5. He grew up in rural, Depression-era Virginia, without plumbing or electricity, and later in Baltimore. Baker demonstrated that ordinary tales told plainly could rise to the level of art, and the book stuck with me over the years, through the rise of the memoir industry, as a premier example of writing about boyhood.

title: Finding Hope for 08 Holidays, on the Web
description: As summer approaches, its a good time to be thinking about winter  if youre a retailer. Thats because more data is available about the last holiday shopping season just as strategies must be sharpened for the next one.

title: Nicole St. Clair, Kevin Knobloch
description: Nicole Kathryn St. Clair and Kevin Timothy Knobloch were married on Saturday. The Rev. Dr. Linda Fisher Privitera, an Anglican priest, officiated at Race Brook Lodge, an inn in Sheffield, Mass.

description: Melissa Beth Kuba and Jeffrey Lester Lederer were married by Rabbi Jeremy Kalmanofsky on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Cantor Natasha Hirschhorn also participated in the ceremony.
