title: Kicked Out of the Play Group
description: My daughters play group consists of children ranging in age from infancy to 4 years old. One mother revealed that she does not vaccinate her son. After much frank but cordial discussion and opinions from pediatricians  some thought she endangered our vaccinated kids; others did not  she felt pressured to leave the group. Did the group behave ethically? J.G., PASADENA

title: With Tony Pea
description: The Kansas City Royals travel to Yankee Stadium on Friday, a complicated proposition for the Yankees first-base coach, Tony Pea. His son, Tony Pea Jr., is the Royals shortstop. He has a way to go to match his father for longevity: Tony Sr., who turns 51 on Wednesday, caught 1,950 games from 1980 to 1997. Athletic talent runs in the family. Tony Sr.s mother, Rosalia, is a former softball player. TYLER KEPNER

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Metro

title: Paperback Row
description: LEGACY OF ASHES: The History of the CIA, by Tim Weiner. (Anchor, $16.95.) This National Book Award-winning history of the Central Intelligence Agencys first 60 years describes how the most powerful country in the history of Western civilization has failed to create a first-rate spy service, Weiner, a reporter for The Times, writes. Using tens of thousands of declassified documents and on-the-record recollections of former officials, Weiner presents the agencys ineptitude with embarrassing detail (when the Berlin Wall fell, the leader of the Soviet division had to rely on CNN for his information). Scheming or feckless directors and misguided orders from presidents explain some of the problems, Weiner says, and he warns that this nation may not long endure as a great power unless it finds the eyes to see things as they are in the world.

title: South Pacific
description: The defining moment of Lincoln Center Theaters lavishly praised revival of Rodgers & Hammersteins South Pacific arguably comes before the show has actually begun, when not a single actor is onstage. This nonprofit theater has made much of its decision to employ a full complement of orchestra musicians at a time when pits are being pared down to the core. And Lincoln Center makes it clear at each performance in the most dramatic way possible. At the beginning of the overture, just as the violins introduce the lushly melodic lines of Bali Hai, the stage floor above the musicians heads begins to recede, drawing back to reveal every one of the pits 30 members.

title: The Livin Is . . .
description: Im standing on a Maui beach, surfboard under my arm, lip split and bleeding from a wipeout. Im trying not to smile, because it opens the cut even more, but I cant help myself. Ive just learned how to turn on a wave.

title: Calls for Daly to Reform Dont Come From Within
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Amid the soft sands and mild island breezes of Hawaii, some hard career decisions occurred to Pat Perez at the start of the 2008 season. He would hire a trainer to continue the workouts he had begun in the off-season. He would cut out beer during tournament weeks. The practice tee, a place he visited with the same enthusiasm he might have for the proctologists office, would become a regular haunt.

title: Mindy Sprung, Evan Fox
description: Mindy Pamela Sprung, a daughter of Susan Sprung and Dr. Craig Sprung of Wayside, N.J., was married on Monday to Evan David Fox, the son of Dinah Fox and Dr. Bruce Fox of Randolph, N.J. Rabbi Joel E. Soffin officiated at the Wilshire Grand Hotel in West Orange, N.J.

title: Making Noise Behind the Scenes
description: BACK in 1961 who would have guessed that Show Girl was making history? Yet by listing Jack Mann in its program, that lightweight musical revue became the first Broadway show to acknowledge a sound designer. It took a few decades, but now the Tony Awards are following suit.

title: Coldplay Tries a Few New Things
description: WITH its frescoed walls and waiters in white jackets, the Caf Carlyle is like a Hollywood version of old-school New York sophistication.

title: Albert Brooks Gives Himself the Business
description: ALBERT BROOKS, who turns 61 in July, hasnt had a recurring part on a television series since 1970, when he played a guy named Rudy in two episodes of The Odd Couple. He mostly made movies after that: his own movies, written and directed by Albert Brooks and starring Albert Brooks as a less aware, less competent, more easily flustered versions of Albert Brooks. The Woody Allen of the West Coast, a critic once called him.

title: Social Lions
Above the City, Juggling Patience, Precision and Danger
description: They sit in cubicles in the sky, at the controls inside an operators cab 20 or 30 stories above the streets of New York City. They spend their days hooking and hoisting  even when off-duty, since a number of them unwind by going fishing. They have withstood sudden wind gusts, irate contractors and even lightning strikes, all in a days work, for a maximum salary of about $60 an hour.

title: Jordan Wright, 50, Political Archivist, Dies
description: Jordan M. Wright, who at 10 was thrilled to learn that politicians hand out self-promotional baubles, then collected more than a million bumper stickers and other campaign artifacts  from the time of George Washington to that of George W. Bush  died on May 11 at his home in Atlantic Beach, N.Y. He was 50.

title: County Presses Proposal for Bike Trail
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Northern Composure
description: According to Harry Boyd, one of the main characters in Elizabeth Hays new novel, radio is like poetry, and television is like a blockbuster novel. A radio program, Harry continues, is about one person learning something interesting and telling it to somebody else. In Late Nights on Air, which was awarded Canadas Giller Prize in 2007, many people tell other people many things  and many of them are very interesting.

title: Letter: Toronto Bargains
description: To the Editor: Matt Grosss recent visit to Toronto as the Frugal Traveler would have benefited from more research and/or a longer stay. His article O Canada, Where Have Your Bargains Gone? (May 18) paints a rather shallow and limited picture of the many modestly priced attractions in this cosmopolitan, accessible, largely peaceful city, whose metropolitan population is more than 2.7 million, and which harbors communities drawn from nearly every other country.

title: New Tastes of Bohemia
description: Rent, which was originally scheduled to close this weekend after 12 years on Broadway, has extended its lease through Sept. 7. And there lies a poignant irony: The musicals struggling artists surely could no longer afford even one more day in Alphabet City. But these restaurants seem poised for long runs there.

title: Tatis Plays the Star in Another Comeback
description: Any elation the Mets derived from learning that Chad Billingsley, the Dodgers right-hander, would be leaving after throwing seven shutout innings Saturday vanished as soon as Jonathan Broxton, the hulking set-up man, loped in from the bullpen. Due up first for the Mets in the eighth, David Wright. After him, Carlos Beltrn. Their career success against Broxton: no hits in eight at-bats with six strikeouts.

title: A Player Destined for the Majors Chose First to Play for Himself
description: NASHVILLE  A high school senior named Pedro Alvarez went to bat during a major league draft showcase at Yankee Stadium three springs ago.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 38 of the Magazine today about the talk-show host Tyra Banks misspells, in one reference, the middle name of the president of Telepictures Productions, which produces Bankss show. She is Hilary Estey McLoughlin, not Estes.

title: Cult of Deception
description: WASHINGTON

title: From a Leisurely Trot to a Showdown at Belmont
description: Each morning, Casino Drive is saddled up and ridden along the backside of Belmont Park. For an hour, he darts between barns, sends puffs of dirt in the air as he clip-clops down shady paths and garners admiring stares from the most hard-bitten of horsemen. When Casino Drive, a chestnut colt, finally hits the racetrack for a gallop, he swallows the ground with his giant strides.

title: A Novels Twists Immerse a Writer in the World of Addiction
description: Falls Village

title: 10 Years Later, Carrie Coordinated
description: TEN years of watching Sex and the City, including the sanitized reruns on TBS, has trained a generation of label- and love-addled romantics not to raise an eyebrow, presuming Botox hasnt yet made that impossible, when Carrie Bradshaw dons a black Burberry coat and a trilby to go shopping, film noir style, at Duane Reade. Or when Carrie wears a four-figure Nina Ricci sweater trimmed with hundreds of feathers while typing on a laptop in the privacy of her own home. Or when Carrie crawls into Bigs big bed, wearing makeup and a single strand of pearls.

title: Letters: General Vang Paos Last War
description: As a professor of Hmong/Southeast history, in particular the Vietnam War era, I am troubled by the continued portrayal of Hmong people as an ancient tribe who were diehard American allies (Tim Weiner, May 11). There were Hmong fighting on both sides, supported by both East and West. Many were neutral, struggling just to stay alive in the most bombed region in world history to date. Hmong expatriates relationships with Laos are widely varied, and thousands return from abroad annually to visit relatives, establish businesses or even to set up residence. Actual Hmong returns to Laos are neither unrealistic nor simply a military fantasy, but part and parcel of globalization.

title: On the Trail of a Sustainable Feast in Sonoma
description: THE psychedelic, hand-painted, Mushroom Man pickup truck parked at the New Carpati Farm in Sonoma County, Calif., just outside the town of Sebastopol, was the first sign that this vacation was going to be a little out of the ordinary.

title: Using It Before Losing It
description: Secession movements are an American instinct, and Andrew D. Blechman sees one afoot in the migration of young, well-off retirees to the land of golf and sunshine. I could feel it, he writes, watching his sprightly New England neighbors pack up for Florida. I suspected that the Andersons were in the vanguard of a significant cultural shift.

title: Blythe Pittman and Aris Winger
description: Blythe Harriet Pittman and Aris Benjamin Winger are to be married on Sunday on the grounds of Tobias Smyth Cabin at Emory & Henry College in Emory, Va. The Rev. Timothy Kobler, a United Methodist minister, is to officiate.

title: Rachael Degenshein, Alen Lapidis
description: Rachael Lynn Degenshein, a daughter of Jane R. Degenshein and Larry C. Degenshein of West Orange, N.J., is to marry Alen Lapidis, the son of Mila Lapidis and Felix Lapidis of Costa Mesa, Calif., on Sunday. Rabbi Steven Kushner is to officiate at the Manor, an event space in West Orange.

title: A Co-op Superintendent Casts a Lot of Votes
description: Q The superintendent in our co-op also owns shares and occupies the unit related to those shares.

title: Correction: Now Hes Only Hunted by Cameras
description: An article last Sunday about Salman Rushdie misstated the way in which he learned of the end of his marriage with Padma Lakshmi. She discussed the matter in person; she did not tell him via e-mail.

title: Smoke Clears, Dust Does Not in Beijing
description: THESE pre-Olympic mornings, when the air is thick with the scent of jasmine and roses, I gaze out the window of my high-rise apartment in northwest Beijing and see  alas, not much. Thats because the air is also thick with oxides of many colors and complex carbon chains yet unclassified.

title: Mozarts Rivals: A Neglected Contemporary
description: To the Editor:

title: Grace Lockhart, Marko Djuranovic
description: Grace Strahan Lockhart, the daughter of Carolyn S. Lockhart and James B. Lockhart III of Greenwich, Conn., was married on Saturday evening to Marko Djuranovic, the son of Gordana and Mirko Djuranovic of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Greenwich. The couple met at Duke, from which they graduated.

title: Democrats See Cuba Travel Limits as a Campaign Issue in Florida
description: MIAMI  Baltasar Martin Garrote desperately wants to see his mother turn 86 in August at her home in Cuba. But an American law will not let him.

title: Correction: Resistance Is Futile
description: A caption with an article last Sunday about the Nintendo video-game designer Shigeru Miyamoto misidentified the character from the Zelda series shown. It is Link, not Zelda.

title: Where Nerds Rule the Night
description: PINWORMS. Flatworms. Roundworms. Fish tapeworms tens of meters long, inside someones intestine. Worm cysts in the brain. Gross-out pictures of worm extractions.

title: Jennifer Brosnahan, Kevin McIntyre
description: Jennifer Ru-chiao Brosnahan and Kevin Joseph McIntyre were married on Saturday at St. Josephs on Capitol Hill, a Roman Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Peter J. Vaghi performed the ceremony.

title: Da Vinci, Retrofitted for the Modern Age
description: WHEN Thomas Alva Edison was starting in business, his first patent was for an automated vote-tallying machine to let legislators know instantly which measures had passed and which had been voted down. He sold not a one. It seems that legislators, accustomed to schmoozing and politicking right through a votes tally, didnt want to speed the process.

title: The Trouble in Housing Trickles Up
description: Greensboro, N.C.

title: Laura Wareham, Mark Tortorella
description: Laura Stewart Wareham, a daughter of C. Lee Wareham and Raymond N. Wareham of New York, was married on Saturday evening to Mark Philip Tortorella, a son of Deborah J. Tortorella and Philip J. Tortorella Jr. of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall officiated at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, where he is pastor.

title: Banksable
description: Tyra Banks has 275 smiles. Like a star athlete who has perfected a jump shot or a curveball, Banks has studied, honed and mastered the smile. In her arsenal are the surprise smile, the angry but still smiling smile, the flirting with boyfriend smile and the commercial smile, which, like the rest of Tyras smiles, was designed and perfected when Banks, who is now 34, began modeling at 15. From the start of her career, when she was virtually plucked from an all-girl Catholic high school in Los Angeles and whisked off to Paris, to her days as a mass-market first-name-only supermodel strutting the catwalk in her underwear for Victorias Secret, Banks always treated modeling as a kind of beautiful science. Then, and now, the smiles were her secret weapons: they could compel, manipulate, seduce. Banks did not become a model to be a muse to designers or because she loved fashion. Modeling  and smiling  was a skill that could, if engineered and managed carefully, change the course of your life.

title: A Nod to the Insiders
description: As John McCain was purging Washington lobbyists from his campaign last month, Barack Obama fired up a withering put-down.

title: Shovelware
description: Naming-day in our electronic Eden.

title: Beauty and the Beasts
description: Insofar as the Gilded Age model Evelyn Nesbit  arguably the most famous face of the early 20th century  is remembered today, its as a tease and a gold digger. She has long been held vicariously responsible for the 1906 murder of the architect Stanford White, who was shot by Nesbits jealous husband during a performance at what was then Madison Square Garden.

title: Royal Care for Some of Indias Patients, Neglect for Others
description: BANGALORE, India  To get the best care, Robin Steeles said gamely, you gotta pay for it.

title: For People With Down Syndrome, Longer Life Has Complications
description: His Superman T-shirt was bold and bright, but his face was creased with confusion. Gerry Thomas was stumped by a question most men can answer in an instant.

title: Beauty, Brutality and Three Tough Mothers
description: FOR nearly 40 years Dario Argento, the so-called Italian Hitchcock, has had blood on his hands: deliberately, unashamedly, darn near literally. When a deranged killer stabs, slashes, throttles, garrotes or otherwise violates the corporal integrity of a screaming victim in one of Mr. Argentos films  this happens with some frequency  the hands inside the black gloves have traditionally been those of the director himself. (Its his version of the Hitchcock cameo.)

title: Sugar High
description: The Australian artist Timothy Horn has a fondness for taking historical objects out of context and altering their scale and materials. He made a Chippendale-inspired sconce in rubber, and has enlarged 18th-century jewelry in scale to create large wall pieces. But he has outdone himself with Timothy Horn: Bitter Suite, an exhibition that opens June 14 at the de Young Museum in San Francisco. The three large-scale works that make up the show were inspired by objects in the decorative-arts collections of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco (which include the de Young and the California Palace of the Legion of Honor), and by the rags-to-riches story of Alma Spreckels, the colorful collector whose sugar fortune was used to found the Legion of Honor museum, which opened in 1924.

title: A Drug Is Credited With Slight Gains for Patients Who Have Lung Cancer
description: CHICAGO  The drug Erbitux lengthened the survival of patients with advanced lung cancer by about five weeks, researchers are reporting here this weekend.

title: More School Districts Look to Hire Teachers of Chinese
description: MOUNT VERNON

title: Iraqi Military Extends Control in Northern City
description: MOSUL, Iraq  The recent successes in quieting violence in Basra and Sadr City appear to be stretching to the long-rebellious Sunni Arab district here in Mosul, raising hopes that the Iraqi Army may soon have tenuous control over all three of Iraqs major cities.

title: Contributor Biography: Gary Leib
description: Gary Leib is an animator and cartoonist.

title: Never Satisfied, American Vaulter Edges Upward
description: Sixteen years ago, when track and field authorities concluded that women could pole-vault without breaking their necks, Jenn Stuczynski was a 10-year-old in Fredonia, N.Y., participating in softball, volleyball, basketball and golf.

title: Lone Star Superstar
description: It was 1975, and Willie Nelson was about to begin a national tour of hockey arenas and other massive concrete venues. Country music had seldom been heard in spaces of that scale. His first album for Columbia Records, Red Headed Stranger, was about to be released, and its sound was so spare and stark that the labels president introduced it to his executives by saying, Its probably not commercial and might not be made for country radio.

title: Its Back: The Minimum Stay
description: AFTER eight years, the airlines Saturday-night-stay rule has risen zombielike from the grave, and Peter Greenberg, for one, wants to rally a mob with torches.

title: Travel
description: Travel is often a means of escape, and this years travel books offer plenty of it. Failed relationships, dead-end jobs and other disappointments infest the current crop like bedbugs in a youth hostel, driving their authors around the globe in search of transformation. The seekers range from bored young drifters to anxiety-stricken middle-agers, motivated by the quixotic hope that cutting loose will stimulate the mind and heal the soul.

title: Actress Stone and Dior Differ Over Apology
description: THERE is no denying that the high-heeled foot in Sharon Stones mouth at the Cannes Film Festival belongs to the actress herself. She admitted that her comments suggesting that karmic retribution may have caused the devastating earthquakes in China were blithering.

title: Black Watch
description: Its unlike any red carpet, as are the fashion statements. Unfurled the length of a battlefield  and three centuries  across the concrete floor of St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn, where moments before the contemporary warfare of the play Black Watch had raged, it lets an actor (Paul Rattray, above) and a lightning series of costume changes tell the 300-year history of the Royal Highland Regiment through all of its wars. The most recent is in Iraq, the setting for much of this National Theater of Scotland production, which returns to St. Anns in the fall.

title: Big-Top Gala Will Mark Gunn Librarys Centennial
description: Washington

title: Try the Appetizers, Along With Thai Beer
description: WITH its muted color scheme, delicate tile flooring and dark wood wainscoting, Fairfields King and I is as elegant as it welcoming. The accommodating service at this small Thai restaurant on the Post Road (sister restaurant to one of the same name in Bridgeport) is diner-friendly, as are the prices. And some of the food is more than satisfactory, especially the appetizers, although there is a lack of consistency in quality and preparation.

title: A Timely Way to Go Back in Time
description: AS temperatures, gas prices, carbon-emission anxieties and airfares continue their stealthy creep, one cannot help but gripe anew at the measly network of passenger trains in the United States.

title: Look Whos Tough on Iran Now
description: In the annals of role reversal, the switch by the United Nations atomic sleuths in Vienna and the American intelligence community has been striking. Having long taken a back seat to the Bush administration in publicly challenging Irans nuclear program, the global inspectors last week moved into the drivers seat, demanding that Tehran come clean on any progress it has made toward building a bomb.

title: Young Frankenstein
description: Tragedy next season, comedy tonight.

title: Continuing to Heal After Returning to Work
description: Q. You are on medical leave after learning that you have cancer, and you plan to return to work after your treatment. Should you return full time or part time?

title: Clintons Next Campaign
description: RACISM. Sexism. Say what you will about the Democratic primaries, they have at the very least provoked a national dialogue about those two shameful scourges of American society. Just as the furor over the Rev. Jeremiah Wright drove Senator Barack Obama to make a widely admired speech on race, the growing outrage on the part of her supporters offers an opportunity for Senator Hillary Clinton to speak out on sexism in American life.

title: The Watch List
description: Jos Contreras walked eight batters in six starts in May, or one more than he did in his first two starts of the year. That accuracy has helped him win his last three decisions and lower his earned run average to 2.89. In his last three starts, he has struck out 19 and walked 3.

title: A Baton for the Youth of the Americas
description: AS a child in Mexico City, Alondra de la Parra felt mixed emotions when she attended symphonic concerts with her parents, both ardent music lovers. It was frustrating to be sitting in the audience, she said recently in New York, where she lives now. I wanted to be onstage, with the sound.

title: Entitled to Their Opinions, Yes. But Their Facts?
description: ON May 12, The Times published an Op-Ed article by Edward N. Luttwak, a military historian, who argued that any hopes that a President Barack Obama might improve relations with the Muslim world were unrealistic because Muslims would be horrified once they learned that Obama had abandoned the Islam of his father and embraced Christianity as a young adult.

title: Im Forever Drinking Bubbles
description: THE current housing variety aside, Americans love bubbles.

title: Entrepreneurs Act of Faith Bred on the Gridiron
description: Newark

title: Taming the Falls
description: The scenic attributes of Niagara Falls are well known, but if the pilot points them out to you in a plane at 30,000 feet, the falls can look more problematic than sublime, as if theres a leak in the Great Lakes  it makes you want to call someone. On the ground, theres a long list of things the falls have made people want to do, including but not limited to the following: kill people to own the falls for navigational purposes; cross the falls on a tightrope while making an omelet; pay people off to own the falls for power-production purposes; pay people off to own them for scenic-enrichment purposes, covertly affiliated with the power purposes; inflict electrical consumption on a nation that first thought electricity was deadly but then, when it saw all the gadgets that could be bought, said, Electrify me!; use the falls to make chemicals to help make said gadgets, dumping the leftovers all over the place, especially in the infamous Love Canal; make more chemicals in the name of war  arsenic trichloride, for instance, which makes a gas called lewisite, now on terrorism watch lists; stay overnight in a hotel adjacent to the falls to inaugurate a long marriage (Every American bride is taken there, Oscar Wilde said, in the days before Niagara rhymed with Viagra); bury nuclear waste in and around workers neighborhoods and not mention it; depopulate the city named after Niagara Falls by building a highway through it; attempt to repopulate the city by building a big mall (the Rainbow Center); attempt again with a casino; and, most recently, write a book that is wild and sometimes thrilling, as far as local history goes  like a ride over the falls in a barrel that turns out O.K., from which you emerge with a new view of Niagara as well as what we call nature.

title: Do You Love the Job, or Just the Paycheck?
description: AFTER 12 years climbing the corporate ladder to the upper reaches of middle management, I found myself facing a surprising career conundrum: My big paycheck was making me miserable. In short, I hated my job, but I was afraid to give up my hard-earned six-figure salary for what I really wanted: a career as an entrepreneur.

title: Starwood Starts a Chain for the Electronic Era
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts is scheduled to start a new chain next month with a high-design/low-cost concept called Aloft. Starwood hopes to have as many as 500 Aloft hotels worldwide by 2012.

title: The Artist in Search of a Patron
description: THE only bright spot on the Bowery at Great Jones Street that rainy evening was a halogen-lit storefront packed floor to ceiling with ink studies of jazz musicians, dancers and slinky nudes.

title: Big Brown, Big Hype, Big Payday, Bad Drama
description: Not everybody in thoroughbred racing is giddy over the prospect of a Big Brown Triple Crown.

title: The House on Fortune Street
description: The letter came, deceptively, in the kind of envelope a businesslike friend, or his supervisor, might use. It was typed on rather heavy white paper and signed with the pleasing name of Beth Giardini. Sean read the brief paragraphs twice, admiring the mixture of courtesy and menace. Perhaps it had escaped his notice that he was overdrawn by one hundred and twenty-eight pounds? As he doubtless recalled, the bank had waived the penalty last time; this time, regretfully, they must impose their normal fee. Would he kindly telephone to discuss the matter at his earliest convenience?

title: A Bit of Unpleasantness Wont Deter Hamptonites
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

title: Modern Kitchens, Set to a Broadway Beat
description: YES, GE Appliances sells most of its $7 billion a year in refrigerators, dishwashers and other home products around the world through retail chains. But recently, the business, the major appliance division of General Electric, decided to market its GE Monogram line for kitchens directly to design professionals as well as to consumers, something it had never really done before.

title: Inside the List
description: FREYS RETURN: James Freys Bright Shiny Morning isnt his first work of fiction, but its his first book to be billed as such, and it crashes into the fiction list at No. 9.

title: Truth to Power
description: The Book Review asked a handful of writers to recommend books for the presidential candidates. Their suggestions are below.

title: Dangerous Catch
description: If you are one of the millions of Americans who have been seduced by Deadliest Catch, the Discovery Channels testosterone-fueled show about king crab fishermen in the Bering Sea, then you know that commercial fishing is dangerous work  and irresistible to watch. Every year, boats sink, fishermen drown and captains clash with the elements, all of which result in huge ratings. In Bill Carters Red Summer, his account of four summers working as a set-net fisherman in a rough town in southwestern Alaska, the fishing and the weather are less extreme, but the danger level is tantalizingly high. Death, we are reminded, is always one mistake away  a shoelace caught in a net, a skiff overloaded with salmon. Fall into the 42-degree water and youll be dead in minutes. But if you live in a town as tough as Egegik, its the lifestyle thats going to kill you, not the fishing.

title: Lottery Numbers
Properly Soused
description: There has never been a more charming, erudite, eager, generous and devoted lover of drink  to judge by his writing  than Kingsley Amis, who was also, by his own admission, frighteningly authoritative. But too much of a good thing generally leaves one cranky, and reading straight through Everyday Drinking: The Distilled Kingsley Amis classifies as a binge. The book is actually a compilation of three books, written first as columns between 1971 and 1984 by the author of Lucky Jim. Under no circumstance should it be read in one go. Not even with a pitcher of dry martinis at hand. Youll do Amiss work proper justice, as even he suggests, by reading it at the rate of, say, one chapter a night. You may even try reading it out loud at bedtime. Or not.

title: On Venices Grand Canal in a Kayak
description: THEY helped fleeing Romans evade Attila the Hun and held a glittering city aloft for more than 1,500 years. But the wooden pilings rising out of the Grand Canal in Venice are so decayed that as we clung to them one afternoon it wasnt at all clear whether they would be sturdy enough to prevent us from capsizing into its murky waters.

title: A Party to Forget
description: A Party to Forget

title: Roads to Recognition That Were Really Short
description: BROADWAY debuts aint what they used to be. Oh, theyre nice and all, but consider this: On each of the four shows nominated for a Tony Award for best musical, at least one major creative player is doing this whole professional theater thing for the first time. Not just Broadway debuts; theater debuts. Were talking people who have no experience in their field, no years on the regional circuit, no rsum of Off Broadway shows, no Playbill credits that cause an expectant theatergoer to point and whisper: Ech. I saw that. I can only assume hes improved. Like, none (O.K., with a little fudging in places).

title: Feta Accompli
description: Six kinds of feta cheese are on display in the refrigerator at New Bakaliko, a Greek market in Hicksville, where choosing one is a part of the fun. Everybody gets a taste so they can decide, said Chrystalla Miglis.

title: Venture Capital, Before High Tech
description: THE United States military  credited with spawning the Internet  also helped in the genesis of venture capital. So reveals Spencer E. Ante in Creative Capital (Harvard Business School Press, $35), a sometimes slow but ultimately satisfying biography of Georges F. Doriot, the transplanted Frenchman who is often called the father of V.C.

title: Correction: A Fiery Theology Under Fire
description: An article on May 4 about black liberation theology and the debate surrounding the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr, Senator Barack Obamas former minister, erroneously confirmed a statement by Mr. Wright that the United States has used biological weapons against other countries. There is no evidence that the United States ever did so.

title: Comics
description: In 1970, Superman went down a rabbit hole: a secret tunnel on the outskirts of Metropolis leading to a bizarre underground world inhabited by hippies, drop-outs and mutant creatures.

title: Libertarians Dream of Being the Tie-Breaker
description: So maybe it isnt very live and let live for libertarians to assemble en masse in the hopes of exerting power. But some libertarians, feeling a little heady after their partys national convention last weekend, are making a bold claim: this is the year their voting bloc will hold some serious sway in American politics.

title: Letter: Energy Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Sur, Calif.: Post Ranch Inn
description: THE BASICS

title: Sarah Thomas, Jason Donehue
description: Sarah Megan Thomas, a daughter of Regina OBrien Thomas and Frank M. Thomas Jr. of Haverford, Pa., was married on Saturday to Jason Steven Donehue, the son of Mary J. Donehue and Alan M. Donehue of Enid, Okla. The Rev. William T. McCandless performed the ceremony at Old St. Marys Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Lets Make Help for Female Veterans a Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dormant City Farm Is Taking Bloom Again
description: NORWALK

title: When I Paint My Masterpiece
description: These days the word artist is pretty tired. Its one-size-fits-all like no other word in the English language, maybe apart from god and pronouns. It describes Isadora Duncan, Spike Lee, Picasso and Q-Tip, all in a days work. And just when it thinks it can take a breather, it has to account for that kid living on the Bowery praying his orgy Polaroids make it into the Whitney and that writer in Starbucks taking trippy liberties with linear structure in a screenplay called Mama. Even the man on 42nd Street who believes the world could always use a few more faces of Leonardo DiCaprio in Titanic spray-painted onto felt, even he has a claim on the word.

title: Broadway, Before It Was Their Job
description: Erik Piepenburg asked several Tony Award winners to recall the first Broadway show they ever saw and to describe the impact it had on them. Excerpts from their responses are below.

title: Every Thursday Night, Liberal Politics and Pints
description: On Thursday night in Hells Kitchen, an impassioned discussion of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons remarks about the Bobby Kennedy assassination as a reason for her staying in the presidential race took place in the backyard of Rudys Bar and Grill. Across the yard, Rachel Maddow, a host on Air America Radio, poured glasses of beer for a table of friends and debated Senator John McCains war record.

title: At 80, Protesting a War, and Winning Fame
description: Bethpage

title: Cooking
description: It is an immutable truth of the food world, right up there with watched pots never boiling: most cookbooks are failures. You can cook with joy and distraction or follow the instructions to the letter, like a terrified parent responding to a detailed kidnappers note. Too often the result is mediocrity, food that just sits there on the plate, undercooked, overcooked, not rich enough, broken or, worse, boring.

title: Recipe: Mint-and-Mustard-Marinated Lamb
description: 1 white onion, chopped

title: Dateline: Baghdad
description: To the Editor:

title: Quickly Drawing Attention
description: IT wasnt the daffodils or the robins song or even the slowly lengthening days that best brought spring in for me this year. It was biting into Bedford Post Inns grilled octopus with fresh chickpeas.

title: At a Soggy Memorial, a New Face in the Lead
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Mathew Goggin of Tasmania, seeking his first PGA Tour victory, clung tenaciously to the lead after the third round of the Memorial on Saturday. Patiently waiting out a two-and-a-half-hour rain delay and holding off a horde of challengers with a one-under-par 71, Goggin took a three-stroke lead over Kenny Perry, Mike Weir, Justin Rose, Matt Kuchar and Jerry Kelly.

title: Autograph Seekers Create a Subculture of Sharpies
description: They were clustered beneath an awning at Mickey Mantles restaurant, as persistent as the heavy rain falling on a raw day last month in Manhattan.

title: Tree Proud

title: Mrs. Corbetts Request
description: The girlfriend of the late Roger Corbett, Eliska Sedlacek, finally phoned me at my office the next morning. But I was on a call. It was yet another case of a desperate middle-aged man. Why is America so full of them? The claimant owned a large boatyard and marina in Pensacola, Fla. This location, it may be remembered, was flattened in 2005 by Hurricane Dennis. In this case the insured, a man named Otto Planck, had filed a complete-loss claim for his $2.238-million, 85-foot sailboat, the Beckys Best Boy, which, he said, he desperately tried to tow out of harms way and failed, resulting in his rescue in a life raft by the Coast Guard and utter destruction of the boat, which he claimed he saw sink with his two own salt-stung eyes. Our local insurance investigator was disturbed by the condition of a piece of the teak hull of the Beckys Best Boy that was found washed up on a local beach. The piece had been broken outward, against the curvature of the hull, seemingly from a great force, and the investigator also noted that Otto Planck had training as a Navy Seal years earlier. He knew how to blow things up, and he also knew how to survive in extreme conditions. The boat, built in 1923 for a minor British industrialist (and no doubt christened with a more stately name), was valuable but would have been tough to resell, given the extensive restoration it needed.

Oh, Mildred replies wryly, they stay at home with an aged parent and do the flowers, or they used to, but now perhaps they have jobs and careers.

She told me she had discovered that she was grinding her teeth in her sleep. It wasnt every night, she went on. The grinding happened only after her favorite baseball team, the Boston Red Sox, lost a game. Since even good baseball teams, like the Red Sox, lose nearly as often as they win, this meant that my friends bicuspids were getting a fairly regular workout.

The 20-year-old Ivanovic has shot up to No. 2 in the world rankings in part because she has transformed her serve into a multifaceted stroke that overwhelms opponents with its unpredictable speed and spin. Here, a closer look at one of the most dangerous shots on the womens tour.

title: Visuals
description: In 1937, Joseph Goebbels asked the German graphic designer Will Burtin (1908-72) to become design director for the Ministry of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda. Burtin was not flattered and had no intention of accepting the offer. He stalled for about a year until Hitler himself demanded Burtin take the post (even though his wife was Jewish). This prompted a hasty escape to the United States, R. Roger Remington and Robert S. P. Fripp write in DESIGN AND SCIENCE: The Life and Work of Will Burtin (Lund Humphries, $70), where he was hired by his wifes cousin Max Munk, the inventor of the wind tunnel, to design the logo for his aeronautics company. During the war, Burtin worked at the O.S.S., creating, among other things, graphically sophisticated gunnery-training manuals for the Army Air Forces. Goebbels could not have been pleased.

title: Amazon Ambassador
description: Although John Hemming has long been a widely respected scholar of the Amazon  its forests, rivers and people  the roots of his knowledge are much more than academic. When Hemming was just 26, his first full-scale expedition into the Amazon was cut short when the expeditions leader, a friend of Hemmings from Oxford, was ambushed by a group of Panar tribesmen. The Indians riddled the young man with eight arrows and crushed his skull with a handmade club. Hemming helped carry the embalmed and canvas-wrapped body out of the rain forest so that it could be buried in a British cemetery in Brazil. Before he returned home, however, he left gifts for the Panar at the site where his friends body had been found.

Never mind those three packs a day; he has wind to spare. His liver, astoundingly, is still holding up. He has survived not only Fleming but Kingsley Amis and John Gardner, who, among others, kept on publishing Bond novels in Flemings stead. The greatest quote of all time.To those of us who covered Game 4 of the division series in Minneapolis in 2004, this required no explanation.Thats the game where Rincon, then a dominant Twins setup reliever, blew a 5-1 lead in the eighth for Johan Santana.It was 5-2 when Rincon hung a slider that Ruben Sierra sent clattering into the retractable seats above the baggie in right-center for the game-tying three-run homer. The Yankees went on to win, 6-5, and clinch the series, and afterward Rincon, a Venezuelan whose English wasnt the greatest, said, Nobody wants to be in my pants right now.This mornings news: With the bullpen overworked the last few days, the Yankees summoned Scott Patterson from Scranton/Wilkes-Barre and designated Morgan Ensberg for assignment. Ensberg got the news shortly after he arrived at the Metrodome this morning, and was back out the door within minutes. title: Norms and Deviations: Whos to Say?
description: A letter published in the May 26 issue of Time magazine protests the inclusion, in Times list of the worlds 100 most influential people, of two researchers allied with the organization Cure Autism Now (a name that speaks for itself). The letter writer declares himself to be outraged because, in his view, Autistic spectrum disorders are not diseases, but rather markers of genetic difference in the same vein as skin color [and] gender. He equates the search for a cure with genocide  its part of a campaign to wipe out ASDs [autism spectrum disorder]  and he wants the world to know that those to whom the cure would be offered neither need it nor desire it: I speak for many when I say we are happy the way we are.A genetic difference is often adaptive and can be regarded as an advance in the evolutionary process; it is well-known that autism sometimes brings with it remarkable powers in the areas of music, art and mathematics. In the 2006 movie X-Men: The Last Stand, the augmented powers of those known as mutants are even more remarkable and include the ability to walk through walls, to move metal objects as large as Californias Golden Gate Bridge, to auto-generate fire or ice, to be in seven places at the same time, to read minds, to assume any identity, to kill with a touch, to fly like Icarus, to change the weather. These abilities are seen by many normal human beings, and a few mutants, as disabilities, as an indication that the person who possesses one of them is a freak.

Tuesday, the new double CD set, Annie: The 30th Anniversary Cast Recording, will go on sale, and on Wednesday Mr. Strouse will sign copies at the Virgin Megastore in Times Square starting at 4 p.m. Former cast members featured on the newly recorded disc  including Kathie Lee Gifford, Shelly Burch and Andrea McArdle   will join him and other Annie creators. Details of these and other events, including the release of Mr. Strouses memoir, Put On a Happy Face, are at charlesstrouse.com. ... Original cast recordings for In the Heights (Ghostlight) and Adding Machine (PS Classics), will also be on sale starting Tuesday.

On the ground, hundreds of people scrambled excitedly for the 100 million rupiah (about $10,700) that showered down, Reuters reported. His initial hope had been to fly over Jakarta, but police denied permission amid concerns that large crowds would gather and chaos might ensue in a country where millions live on the equivalent of less than $2 a day. This was not the first time that this author, 42, has pulled an odd publicity stunt: he pushed his first book, Financial Revolution, by riding through Jakarta on a white horse. The book became a best seller in 2005. His new book is, appropriately, titled Marketing Revolution.

In the Raconteurs, he works in a double singer-songwriter front line with an actual rock formalist, Brendan Benson. In the more Benson-like of the Raconteurs songs, studied homages to 1970s album-oriented rock, Mr. White can use the context to be as truant as he wants, setting himself loose in places where in the White Stripes he would rein himself in.

Gowda, a City Council candidate from Staten Island who called the temple a true blessing for our community. Mr. Gowdas home country, India, is in South Asia  not Southeast Asia.

title: Oliver Has His Nancy
description: After 12 weeks of competition, the future London production of Oliver! has found its Nancy. Jodie Prenger, 28, won Britains Id Do Anything television talent contest on Saturday night, beating first the runner up, Jessie Buckley, 18, in a decision determined by public call-in voting, the BBC and The Daily Mail reported. For Ms. Prenger, right, of Blackpool, this is the second television competition victory in two years: she also won the British version of The Biggest Loser in 2006. Oliver!, to be produced by Cameron Mackintosh, also found its title character  or rather characters  on Id Do Anything. Three young actors, Harry Stott, 12, and Gwion Jones and Laurence Jeffcoate, both 11, will rotate in the title role. Rowan Atkinson will star as Fagin. The show will be directed by Rupert Goold, currently represented on Broadway by Macbeth, with Matthew Bourne (Mary Poppins) as co-director and choreographer. Previews begin on Dec. 12 for a Jan. 14 opening.

title: In at the Birth of Death

The sudden events  like the death of a star in an explosion called a supernova  are usually detected well after they begin, and, of course, millions of years after they actually occurred, given the great distances their light has to travel.

Of course, there is no rule that a new ballet cant be avant-garde; it just almost never is. And sadly, it wasnt on Thursday night, when Christopher Caines presented Exquisite Hour as part of An Evening of Dance Works, the final program, in the Annex, of the La MaMa Moves! dance festival.

What I really like about that paper is the concreteness: economists often talk about how expectations of inflation get embedded in price- and wage-setting, but dont offer direct evidence that this is happening. Taylor, however, had the goods: you can actually see the wage settlements, and you can even see the difference between settlements with and without escalator clauses.

Kids dont really smoke fake weed like this, Mr. Rogen, above with glasses, told the crowd at the Gibson Amphitheater in Los Angeles, where they were presenting the award for the best summer movie so far. Before television viewers could get a closer look at what was real and what was not, the camera moved to a wide angle and stayed that way until Mr. Rogen and Mr. Franco, above in white T-shirt, left the stage, The Associated Press reported. It was an awkward moment that made some in the audience laugh. Backstage, Mr. Franco told The Associated Press that MTV had put them up to the joke  supplying the script as well as the fake pot and joint  and then had a last-second change of heart.

title: Godard Cancels Visit to Film Festival in Israel
description: The French filmmaker Jean-Luc Godard has dropped plans to attend a film festival in Tel Aviv after a Palestinian group urged him to boycott Israel, Reuters reported. Mr. Godard, one of the founders of the French New Wave of the 1960s, canceled the trip to the Tel Aviv International Student Film Festival, citing circumstances beyond his control, festival organizers said Monday. The Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel urged Mr. Godard in an open letter last week to take a courageous stand and cancel your trip to Israel. The letter asked: Did you ever go to an Afrikaner film festival in apartheid South Africa? Why Israel, then? Reuters said a source in Mr. Godards office declined to comment but said he had canceled his visit for political reasons. Festival organizers said they were disappointed but respected Mr. Godards decision. Pro-Palestinian groups frequently call on prominent cultural and academic figures to boycott Israel because of its occupation of the West Bank and its blockade of the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip.

You cant picture him head-butting, or breaking someones nose with his elbow.
