description: CHICAGO  The priest whose mocking of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton stirred more racially tinged controversy in the presidential campaign was effectively placed on leave from his pastoral work Tuesday at the Roman Catholic parish he has led since 1983.

title: Next on Agenda Is Clintons Role
description: Senator Barack Obama heads into the general election with obvious advantages: He is a Democratic candidate running in a sour atmosphere for Republicans, in a contest where voters are hungry for change and coming out of a campaign in which he filled arena after arena with supporters.

title: Parody and Innuendo Are Out, Artistry Is in for a Music Channel
description: WHEN it comes to music-oriented television networks, MTV and VH1 are the mainstream Hertz-and-Avis, Coke-and-Pepsi pairing that comes to mind.

title: MSN Looks to Hollywood for New Site
description: Can two of Hollywoods most innovative executives help MSN become a player in advertiser-supported entertainment on the Web? MSN, the Microsoft portal, is betting millions of dollars that the answer is yes.

title: Chinas Grief, Unearthed
description: London

title: Mexican Olive Oil: Ensenada to Fairway
description: This extra virgin olive oil, Fairways house brand Mexican Mission, made entirely from Mission olives on a small estate near Ensenada in Baja California, is about as subtle as a mariachi band. It is sunny, fairly viscous and green, with substantial olive and sage flavors.

title: Laboratory Module Attached to Side of the Space Station
description: The International Space Station has a new room.

title: Impact of Earthquake on the Chinese Economy Is Seen as Minimal
description: HONG KONG  The powerful earthquake that devastated southwestern China three weeks ago seems to have had only a limited effect on Chinas overall economy.

title: A Dolls House With a Spice Rack
description: IF a hope chest bloomed into a restaurant, Elettaria might be the outcome.

title: Vote Lets Grand Prix Boss Keep Job, Despite Scandal
description: LONDON  Despite the scandal touched off by his participation two months ago in a videotaped sex session with five prostitutes that a British tabloid newspaper described as having Nazi overtones, Max Mosley, the overseer of grand prix motor racing, won a vote of confidence on Tuesday to keep his job.

title: Toasting the Joys of Imbibing Properly
description: Got a hangover? Search Google, and youll find a thousand home remedies, from mild palliatives (buttermilk, honey, bananas) to shock therapy (pickle juice, kudzu extract, raw cabbage). If you can drag yourself into Walgreens or Rite Aid, theres usually a potion or two that promises relief.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about a trove of Weegee photographs found at a yard sale misstated the date of the photograph Viewing News Report of a Yankee Game, Times Square. It was Oct. 6, 1943, not Dec. 6.

title: Thousands Arrested in Bangladesh Anti-Crime Sweep
description: NEW DELHI  The army-backed caretaker government in Bangladesh that has netted hundreds of politicians and business people in a year-long anti-corruption drive has now rounded up nearly 12,000 people in what it calls a crusade against crime.

title: Mexico at the Brink
description: The War on Drugs may be fading from memory north of the Rio Grande, but south of the river, bloody battles are threatening to overwhelm Mexicos democratically elected government. The timid assistance package proposed by the Bush administration and pared down by Congress suggests that Washington doesnt grasp either the scale of the danger or its own responsibilities.

title: French Rotisserie Joins the Midtown Takeout Rotation
description: Midtown options for lunch and takeout just improved with the opening of a rotisserie and boulangerie on one side of the new Brasserie Cognac de Monsieur Ballon, 1740 Broadway (55th Street). Organic chicken stuffed with herbs and lemon, $13.95 whole or $7.95 half, was satisfying, well flavored and moist. It comes with a little green salad. The shops other items, all made in-house, include breads and croissants, $1.95 to $9; sandwiches, $5.95 to $6.95; a proper salade nioise, $6.99; and pastries like fruit and lemon meringue tartlets, $4.95. The store opens at 7:30 a.m. Monday through Friday and 8 a.m. Saturday and Sunday, and closes at 10 every night; (212) 757-3600.

title: New Life, New Name and a New Chef for Montrachet
description: IT hasnt been the best kept secret, but it has kept the New York restaurant world wondering for two years: What is Drew Nieporent going to do with to Montrachet, the restaurant that helped recast dining in the city?

title: Prado Gets to Play the Spoiler Once Again
description: Edgar Prado is pretty good at preventing history from being made. Twice he has been the winning rider aboard horses that thwarted Triple Crown bids; first when Sarava beat War Emblem in 2002, and two years later when Birdstone defeated Smarty Jones. He will try to do the same Saturday, and this time he will have some extra motivation.

title: Red, White, Sultry: The Wines of India
description: NASIK, India

title: Pavliks the Ghost Who Didnt Disappear
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  Dubbed The Ghost early in his career for his ability to make opponents swing and miss, this citys favorite son has developed into a relentless power puncher with an iron chin. But still, he cannot shake the nickname, which now applies more to his complexion than to the straight-ahead, proficient fighter he has become.

title: Alton Kelley, 67, Artist of the 1960s Rock Counterculture, Dies
description: Alton Kelley, whose psychedelic concert posters for artists like the Grateful Dead, Jimi Hendrix, and Big Brother and the Holding Company helped define the visual style of the 1960s counterculture, died on Sunday at his home in Petaluma, Calif. He was 67.

title: At School, Sins a-Poppin and Cherubs Are Singing
description: Text messages are zipping this way and that, suffusing the suburban airwaves with digital indignation.

title: Senator Warns of a Crisis in Pentagon Cost Overruns
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday declared that cost overruns for Defense Department weapons had reached crisis proportions, after government auditors reported that the projected final cost of the Pentagons major programs had ballooned $295 billion over initial budget estimates.

title: Little Artichokes, Provenal Style
description: Time: 40 minutes

title: At Play in a World of Savagery, but Not This One
description: In May 1934, two years before he killed himself in the driveway of his home in Cross Plains, Tex., Robert E. Howard published one of the finest adventures of his most famous character: the warrior, thief, swashbuckler and king called Conan the Cimmerian.

title: Burgundy Learns to Bottle Consistency
description: POMMARD, France

title: Show Under Pressure in Jolie Birth Story
description: Five days after Entertainment Tonight reported that Angelina Jolie had given birth to twins, it is starting to look more and more as if the syndicated show  which is on every weeknight, primarily on CBS affiliates  made a serious mistake.

title: Western Saharas Conflict Traps Refugees in Limbo
description: The refugees eyes burned as they recounted terrible tales, culled, they said, from decades of hard living in camps in an unforgiving desert, half a world away.

title: The I.A.E.A. Report on Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Artichoke, Some New Helpers
description: A LESSON I learned this spring: if you have artichokes in your kitchen, you will find new ways to cook them.

title: G.M. Shifts Focus to Small Cars in Sign of Sport Utility Demise
description: DETROIT  Even General Motors, the steadfast champion of big sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, is thinking small now.

title: Former Referee Cooperated, Prosecutors Say in Letter
description: Federal prosecutors tacitly vouched for the credibility and candor of Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, in a letter filed in federal court last month. The government also stated explicitly, for the first time, that Donaghy did not intentionally make calls to affect the outcome of games.

title: Museums Set Stricter Guidelines for Acquiring Antiquities
description: After a year and half of deliberations, the directors of the countrys largest art museums will announce new guidelines on Wednesday for how their institutions should collect antiquities, a volatile issue that has led in recent years to international cultural skirmishes and several highly publicized art restitution cases.

title: Maryland: Threats on Immigrant Group
description: A well-known immigrant advocacy organization based in Silver Spring said it had received a string of anonymous telephone messages threatening violence. The Rev. Simn Bautista, vice president of the board of the group, CASA de Maryland, said a message was left Sunday, May 18, on an office phone warning that he could have a bullet in the back of his brain, while a bomb threat was left the same day on the cellphone of Mario Quiroz, the groups spokesman. The group, which runs several centers for immigrant day laborers in Maryland, frequently receives hostile calls and e-mail, Mr. Quiroz said, but threats of violence are unusual. Maryland police and the F.B.I. said they were investigating the calls.

title: Celebrated Rivalry Has Its Roots in 62 Finals
description: Before the confetti fell at Staples Center last Thursday, a chant swept through the arena: We want Boston! One night later, 2,986 miles to the east, the response came booming back: Beat L.A.!

title: Fledgling Dancers, Already Fluent in Two Languages: Balanchine and Robbins
description: In 1941, just seven years after he helped found the School of American Ballet with Lincoln Kirstein, George Balanchine choreographed a work whose opening position and opening step seem to delineate specifically American qualities of ballet schooling. When the school danced this classic over the weekend, it was performed with a freshness that made it look as if nobody had ever danced it before.

title: Defense to Have a Turn in R. Kelly Trial
description: The defense begins presenting its case on Wednesday in the R. Kelly child pornography trial in Chicago, after testimony by a woman who said she had had several three-way sexual encounters with Mr. Kelly and an allegedly under-age victim. The prosecution witness, Lisa Van Allen, 27, told jurors on Monday that Mr. Kelly, the R&B star, offered her $250,000 last year to recover a tape of one of the trysts, The Associated Press reported. She denied a defense lawyers accusation that she was trying to extort money, but admitted stealing his $20,000 diamond-studded watch. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to charges of videotaping himself having sex with a girl who prosecutors say was as young as 13. On Tuesday, the judge, Vincent Gaughan, issued a new order for a Chicago Sun-Times reporter to appear in court. The reporter, Jim DeRogatis, who was sent the tape in question, has argued that his actions are protected under the First Amendment.

title: Sampling Imported Fare (and a Bit of Badminton)
description: When Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was founded in 2003, the company, financed by the Wal-Mart heiress Nancy Laurie, was a punch line: Which troupe has all the money and no artistic reason for being?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary on Saturday about the film and television composer Alexander Courage, who wrote the Star Trek theme, misidentified the studios that produced two of the movies for which he orchestrated and arranged music. Guys and Dolls was a Samuel Goldwyn production distributed by MGM; it was not an MGM production. Funny Face was made by Paramount, not MGM.

title: No Films Appear Permanently Lost in Fire at Universal Lot
description: LOS ANGELES  The flames at Universal Studios last weekend may disrupt viewing plans for some film buffs in the coming weeks, though no movies appear to have been lost forever, studio executives said in response to queries on Wednesday.

title: Protests Strain Thai Coalition and Put Focus on Deadlock
description: BANGKOK  Only five months after national elections ended military rule here, a week of street protests has weakened the coalition government and highlighted Thailands failure to move beyond the stalemate that has frozen politics for more than two years.

title: Opponents of Evolution Adopting a New Strategy
description: DALLAS  Opponents of teaching evolution, in a natural selection of sorts, have gradually shed those strategies that have not survived the courts. Over the last decade, creationism has given rise to creation science, which became intelligent design, which in 2005 was banned from the public school curriculum in Pennsylvania by a federal judge.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about plans by the Alliance Defense Fund, a conservative Christian group, to sue Gov. David A. Paterson to block his directive to New York State agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere used an erroneous title for James C. Dobson, one of the founders of the group. Dr. Dobson holds a doctorate in child development but is not an ordained minister, and so he is not the Rev. James Dobson.

title: Emotion-Tinged Testimony Against Union Officials
description: The tears flowing from Sean J. Richards eyes in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday seemed hardly indicative of the man he once was.

title: Spice-Roasted Cornish Hens With Spring Garlic Jus
description: Adapted from Fabienne Escoffier, Ma Cuisine, Beaune, France

title: DNA Test Offers Inmate a Chance at Freedom After 16  Years
description: Ten feet away, Everton Wagstaffe stopped. He was on his way to a meeting, but first, everything in his possession would be searched. This is life behind bars on Monday morning at the Greene Correctional Center in Coxsackie, N.Y. He handed a mesh sack of papers to a correction officer, then waited without a blink of impatience.

title: Surviving Colon Cancer Is Tied to Family History of It
description: People with a family history of colon cancer carry the emotional burden of knowing they have twice the risk of developing the disease themselves. But a new study may ease some of their anxiety. Patients with a family history of colon cancer, the researchers found, are also more likely to survive it.

title: Big Vehicles Stagger Under the Weight of $4 Gas
description: A fully loaded Ford F-250 pickup truck is a whole lot of vehicle. It can tow a horse trailer with multiple horses. It comes with a DVD-based navigation system for the driver as well as a DVD player for passengers who are sitting in the extended cab.

title: Obama Looks to Recruit Clintons Top Fund-Raisers
description: As Senator Barack Obama edges closer to the Democratic presidential nomination, his campaign is gearing up to recruit many of Senator Hillary Clintons top fund-raisers, a move that could provide him with a huge infusion of cash if he wins the partys nod and the two camps can get past the rancor of the primary season.

title: Union Takes Anti-Buyout Campaign Worldwide
description: It started with faux billionaires in the Hamptons and a fat-cat tycoon (or at least an actor wearing a cat mask) in Washington. Now, a union-led campaign against wealthy private equity firms is going global.

title: Cigarette Tax Arrives Amid Grumbling and Vows
description: Fear of a dreaded disease has been part of the bargain for years. Shame came slower, as smokers were cast from offices, restaurants and even bars. Now, in New York City, there is yet another scary side effect to smoking: empty pockets.

title: Nadal Gets a Cakewalk on His 22nd Birthday
description: PARIS  With the matches turning into mismatches on a clammy, dreary day at the French Open, the consolation was the future.

title: Long Island Publisher Buys the Riverdale Press
description: The Riverdale Press, the small Bronx weekly with an outsize reputation for serious journalism, was sold on Tuesday to a Long Island publisher after 58 years as the personal project of two generations of one family.

title: Contractors Consider Ways to Make Cranes Safer
description: In the wake of last weeks deadly crane collapse, some of the citys largest general contractors are considering whether to hire their own third-party inspectors to ensure the safety of the tower cranes used at their construction sites.

title: Nuclear Cleanup Could Derail an Experimental Cancer Treatment, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  A cleanup of nuclear waste from the cold war era threatens to eliminate the supply of an obscure isotope that shows great promise in cancer treatments, according to a report by the Energy Departments inspector general.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about William P. Ford, who spent decades pursuing justice after his sister and three other American churchwomen were murdered in El Salvador, misidentified the religious order of one of the slain women, Dorothy Kazel. She was an Ursuline sister, not a Maryknoll sister.

title: A Reality Competition Shows a Few Wrinkles
description: Shes Got the Look demonstrates a lack of progress on two fronts: feminism and, more crucial to the shows future, development of the reality-competition format.

title: In Charting Its Future, City Opera Chooses an Adventurous Path
description: The most vibrant performing arts institutions strive to find a balance between hewing to a historic mission and branching into new territory. If done right, which usually means gradually, adventurous initiatives and dynamic change can be not just artistically enriching but smart business as well.

title: A.M.D. Set to Introduce a New Chip for Laptops
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Eager to declare its troubles behind it, the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices is ready for a new turf war with its rival, Intel.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 3, 2008

title: Time for Radical Pragmatism
description: Ramallah, West Bank

title: Museum Acquires Modernist House
description: The nonprofit MAK Center for Art and Architecture in Los Angeles has acquired R. M. Schindlers renowned Modernist Fitzpatrick-Leland House, shown above when it was built in 1936, perched on a cliff near the intersection of Laurel Canyon Boulevard and Mulholland Drive, the center said. The three-level L-shaped house, with its interlocking volumes, was a gift from Russ Leland, who bought it in 1990 and spent years restoring it to its original design. The MAK Center said the house would be used for its new Urban Future Initiative program, which grants two-month residencies to researchers from around the world exploring urban issues like sustainability, immigration and social justice.

title: Chief Cleric Says Iran Doesnt Seek Nuclear Arms
description: TEHRAN  Irans supreme religious leader vowed Tuesday that his country would pursue a peaceful atomic energy program and had no interest in nuclear weapons, calling them expensive and useless.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary on Monday about the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent misspelled the name of a company that at one point owned his haute couture house, the House of Saint Laurent. It is Squibb-Beechnut, not Squibb-Beach Nut.

title: Mourners Gather to Honor a Crane Operators Life, Full but All Too Brief
description: The embraces thumped and cracked with slaps on the back instead of words, and then it was time.

title: Her Killer Meatballs Are the Stuff of Fiction
description: CANNED peas and boiled bologna, Lara Vapnyar says, is a dish she has missed since arriving in Brooklyn from Moscow in 1994. We also ate a lot of black caviar, she said last week. But I dont feel nostalgic for that.

title: Sexual Assault of Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rice Calls Dialogue With Iran Pointless
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice escalated the Bush administrations anti-Iran rhetoric on Tuesday, accusing its government of pursuing nuclear weapons and calling any dialogue with its leaders pointless until they suspend the countrys enrichment of uranium.

title: Myanmar: Navy Aid Ships to Leave
description: The Pentagons Pacific Command announced that Navy ships off the coast of Myanmar ready to offer assistance for cyclone victims would leave Thursday because the ruling junta had not approved. Over the past three weeks we have made at least 15 attempts to convince the Burmese government to allow our ships, helicopters and landing craft to provide additional disaster relief for the people of Burma, but they have refused us each and every time, said Adm. Timothy J. Keating, commander of American forces in the Pacific. The four-ship Essex group can produce fresh water from seawater, has medical facilities on board and landing craft and helicopters that can ferry personnel and supplies to remote locations. Admiral Keating said the ships and marines on board could still offer assistance should the Burmese rulers have a change of heart.

title: Beijing Suspends Licenses of 2 Lawyers Who Offered to Defend Tibetans in Court
description: BEIJING  Two prominent human rights lawyers have lost their licenses after volunteering to defend Tibetans charged in the violent anti-China protests that erupted in March. The decision comes as Chinese authorities are tightening scrutiny over dissidents in advance of the Olympics in August.

title: Bo Diddleys Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Science of Denial
description: The Bush administration has worked overtime to manipulate or conceal scientific evidence  and muzzled at least one prominent scientist  to justify its failure to address climate change.

title: Newest Yankee Just Tries to Blend In
description: Dan Giese had never been to Yankee Stadium before Tuesday, when he showed up five and a half hours before game time. Giese wanted to see the sights, and he noticed a group taking a tour of the ballpark. He tagged along a few feet behind, careful not to step out of line.

title: Rating Firms Seem Near Legal Deal on Reforms
description: Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general to reform some of their core business practices, according to people briefed on the investigation.

title: Clinton Donor Base Is Obamas Next Prize
description: As Senator Barack Obama claims the Democratic presidential nomination, his campaign is gearing up to recruit many of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons top fund-raisers, a move that could provide him with a huge infusion of cash if the two camps can get past the rancor of the primary season.

title: New Job at Met Opera
description: Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Operas general manager, has added a member to his brain trust. Lesley Koenig will become assistant manager for production starting Aug. 1. She will oversee all resident designers and directors, who handle revivals, and coordinate the activities of the creative types who make new productions. Ms. Koenig spent the 1980s and most of the 1990s at the Met, mainly working on the directing staff. She was the rare resident director to create a new production, a 1996 Cos Fan Tutte. Her job is new. Joe Clark, the technical director, had encompassed much of the work, but he is retiring at the end of the summer. His replacement, John Sellars, will take on purely technical duties. Its sort of like separating church and state, Mr. Gelb said. For the last six years Ms. Koenig was general manager of the San Francisco Ballet.

title: Courting Donors, Finding Freedom
description: BADEN-BADEN, Germany  A decade ago, during a speech in Vienna, the mild-mannered director of a German art museum lit into the Guggenheim for carpetbagging, siphoning money from European companies like Deutsche Bank. The audience ritually nodded.

title: Woman Admits Role in Ring Tied to Spitzer
description: A 23-year-old New Jersey woman pleaded guilty on Tuesday to running the daily operations of a high-priced escort service linked to Eliot Spitzer.

title: Russia: President Fires Top General
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev dismissed the militarys top general, Yuri N. Baluyevsky, amid reports of conflict between military leaders and the civilian defense minister over spending and administrative priorities and replaced him with Gen. Nikolai Makarov, above. General Makarov was most recently the militarys armaments chief and, earlier, commander of forces in Siberia. General Baluyevsky had been the militarys chief of general staff since 2004 and a strong critic of the United States, particularly of American plans to build a missile defense system in Eastern Europe. He will now be deputy director of the Russian Security Council.

title: Anne dHarnoncourt: Discerning Enthusiasm for Art
description: By any measure, Anne dHarnoncourts tenure as director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, cut short by her sudden death on Sunday at 64, was distinguished. It shone forth in major acquisitions, successful fund drives, vast gallery renovations, a marvelous rehang of the collection and, above all, her refusal to let the museum become a three-ring circus.

title: 'House' Leads the Night
description: Repeats on Fox lifted that network to No. 1 in the ratings on Monday, as House at 9 p.m. attracted the nights largest audience, 9.4 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. While Foxs Bones was the most-watched show during the 8 p.m. hour, with 6.7 million viewers, it trailed in its time slot among adults 18 to 49. Fox ranked third for the night in that demographic, just behind CBS and NBC, which tied for first. CBS earned second place in total viewers thanks to solid ratings for repeats of its comedy lineup followed by a rerun of CSI: Miami at 10 (8.8 million). Meanwhile, NBCs live coverage of Game 5 of the N.H.L. Stanley Cup finals averaged about 6 million viewers, on a par with ABCs schedule for the night. ABC broadcast a two-hour edition of The Bachelorette (6.5 million), followed by the season premiere of The Mole at 10 (4.7 million). ABC finished fourth over all among the 18-to-49 set.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Benefit, With Wine

title: Pennsylvania: Gun Ordinances Voided
description: A judge ruled that the City of Philadelphia could not enforce new ordinances that would ban assault weapons and limit handgun purchases to one per person per month. The judge, Jane Cutler Greenspan of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas, ruled in favor of the National Rifle Association, which argued that only the legislature had the right to make gun laws. But Judge Greenspan denied on procedural grounds the associations request to overturn three other gun ordinances. One would allow guns to be removed from people who were declared to be a risk to themselves or others, and another would do the same for those under a protection-from-abuse order. The third would require the reporting of lost or stolen guns.

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: Groton, Conn.

title: Final Workout for Big Brown as Trainers Chatter Gallops On
description: Rick Dutrow talks trash. He cannot help it. He believes Big Brown, the colt he trains, will be the next Triple Crown champion. Dutrow may not have the lyricism of the trainer Buddy Delp, who referred to Spectacular Bid as the greatest horse to ever look through a bridle, but he speaks with great conviction.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Sunday about Big Browns place in history as a contender for the Triple Crown misstated the year in which a past winner, Seattle Slew, was named the horse of the year. It was 1977, not 1978.

title: A Court for Veterans
description: There is a small bright spot on the normally bleak terrain for military veterans who return home and fall into addiction, mental illness and crime. Buffalo has established a specialized court to give veterans and their family members, mainly those accused of nonviolent crimes, a chance to avoid jail and rebuild their lives.

title: Palmers Legend, Good and Bad, Lives On
description: Far Hills, N.J.

title: Massachusetts: Kennedy Is Recuperating
description: One day after undergoing surgery on a malignant brain tumor in North Carolina, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts was walking around and recuperating well, according to a statement from his office. Mr. Kennedy, 76, had the surgery Monday at Duke University Medical Center. The statement said he was experiencing no complications and was walking the hallways and spending time with family. Mr. Kennedy is expected to return to his home in Hyannis, Mass., in about a week.

title: Barack Obama: Calm in the Swirl of History
description: He gives the appearance of a strikingly laid-back victor, this presumptive Democratic presidential nominee.

title: Obama Claims Nomination; First Black Candidate to Lead a Major Party Ticket
description: Senator Barack Obama claimed the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday night, prevailing through an epic battle with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters from every corner of America to demand change in Washington.

title: Chamberlain Hits Pitch Count, Not Plate
description: It felt like a graduation ceremony on Tuesday night in the Bronx, with everyone applauding a student who stays on stage for an instant. Joba Chamberlain reached another level in his baseball education, and the fans stood and cheered for him before the first of his precious few innings.

title: An English Barn With American Flourishes
description: BUNWELL, Norfolk

title: Yankees Find Effective if Not Electrifying Arm
description: Joba Chamberlain is a rookie celebrity, cheered in Yankee Stadium even before he made his first major league start Tuesday night, and again when he left the game before sundown in Torontos 9-3 victory.

title: Buildup Lasts Longer Than the Start
description: One day we will look back at Joba Chamberlains first Yankee start Tuesday and ask ourselves, How did this turn into the biggest thing since Hideki Irabus debut?

title: Expertise Called Crucial to China Deals
description: Expertise can be more important than cash when it comes to winning investments in China, managers of four of the worlds biggest buyout firms said on Tuesday.

title: Education Stories, Inspiring or Otherwise
description: In the season of sheepskin and mortarboard, report card and honor roll, I have reached my own commencement. After four years, this is my last education column, as I move on to other journalistic endeavors.

title: Steel Price Is Latest Setback for European Pipeline
description: BERLIN  Nabucco, the European Unions natural gas pipeline project, intended to reduce the blocs dependence on Russian natural gas, has been dealt another setback  and this one could hit European consumers in the wallet.

title: Once a Pride of the Yankees, Irabu Slipped Out of Sight
description: LOS ANGELES  As Joba Chamberlain stepped into the maelstrom Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium, there was one person who could probably relate to making his first major league start in such extraordinary circumstances. That would be Hideki Irabu, who with a Steinbrenner as a benefactor and with the citys full attention, turned a midweek, midseason game into a late October night.

title: Whats the Peppery Note in Those Shirazes?
description: HOW far wrong can you go with mashed potatoes? I had no idea until last month, when I tasted the worst of my life in a new Midtown restaurant whose French pedigree had led me to expect some of the best. They were smooth and buttery, but the flavor was strangely harsh, with a chemical aftertaste. Like Band-Aids, my companion said.

title: Good Deed, Unscripted Consequences
description: Sometimes, if youre a documentary filmmaker, you can search years looking for the right subject. At other times the subject will walk right up to your camera, which is pretty much what happened with Operation Filmmaker, an absorbing story about the best intentions gone terribly and comically awry.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on May 24 about Frances obsession with the life of President Nicolas Sarkozy misspelled the surname of the editor in chief of Le Canard Enchan, a weekly newspaper, who said the obsession had turned negative like a bad love affair. He is Eric Emptaz, not Empatz.

title: The Primary Seasons Final Debate
description: Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton spoke past their cheering, chanting supporters and directly to each other on Tuesday in what was one of the most intimate, tense moments of the campaign, like parents arguing in French at the dinner table so the children wont get upset.

title: Last Seasons Success Hard to Duplicate for Mets Prez
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Oliver Prez and John Maine began this season as interchangeable parts in the Mets rotation. Each won 15 games last year while posting comparable earned run averages, and the Mets hoped  check that, expected  that they would join the ranks of the National Leagues elite.

title: Would Stonehenge Be Built Today?
description: At least part of the mystery of Stonehenge may have now been solved: It was from the beginning a monument to the dead.

title: Shes Still Here!
description: He thought a little thing like winning would stop her?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music review on Saturday about Jeff Harnar, at the Metropolitan Room, referred incorrectly to a song he performed, At Long Last Love, in his tribute to Cole Porter. It is from the 1938 musical You Never Know. It is not a 1938 movie song.

title: St. Vincents Says It Will Close if It Cant Build Tower
description: St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan will have to shut its doors if it cannot build a medical tower in Greenwich Village, representatives of the hospital said Tuesday at a hearing of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Icahn Wants New Chief for Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the companys board with his own slate of directors.

title: Obama Clinches Nomination; First Black Candidate to Lead a Major Party Ticket
description: Senator Barack Obama claimed the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday evening, prevailing through an epic battle with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters from every corner of America to demand change in Washington.

title: Garlicky Spinach Salad With Pine Nuts and Raisins
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: Clinton Discusses What She Wants, but Not What She Will Do
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took the stage before supporters Tuesday night and finally asked the question that so many people had been posing: What does Hillary want?

title: Clinic Treats Mental Illness by Enlisting the Family
description: It was hard to tell just who was the patient, as the Cunanan siblings  Jennifer, Adrian and Anthony  sat in a row on three chairs in a sparsely decorated therapists office at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: In South Florida, Eviction Spares Few
description: MIAMI  In a decade handling evictions for the Miami-Dade County Police Department, Albert Fernandez has run across a middle-class father bankrupted by his daughters cancer treatment; an old woman scammed by a gambling husband; and countless families perpetually on the edge of poverty.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Friday about a report released by the Bush administration describing the effects of climate change on the United States described the time frame for the last such assessment incorrectly. The report undertaken in the Clinton administration was published in 2000, during the last year of the Clinton presidency, not in the early days of the Bush presidency.

title: In Hiring, Europeans Go Global
description: PARIS  When Jos Luis Duran came from Spain in 1994 to work at Carrefour, the big French retailer, he spoke no French. It was total immersion from the first day, he said. It was shocking, but you learn fast.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary headline on Tuesday about Anne dHarnoncourt, the director and chief executive of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, attributed an erroneous distinction to her. She succeeded Jean Sutherland Boggs as director; she was not the first woman to lead a major museum.

title: McCain Distances Himself From Bush and Jabs Obama
description: KENNER, La.  Senator John McCain marked the unofficial beginning of the general election with a speech here Tuesday in which he sought to distance himself from President Bush and to argue that he has stronger credentials as an independent agent of change than his all-but-certain Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama.

title: New Hints Seen That Red Wine May Slow Aging
description: Red wine may be much more potent than was thought in extending human lifespan, researchers say in a new report that is likely to give impetus to the rapidly growing search for longevity drugs.

title: Bargain Seeking
description: FEW Burgundies are cheap, but good values nonetheless abound.

title: A Sidekick No More, Ashanti Tries Some New Poses for the Spotlight
description: Ashanti has never needed to be great, and so she never has been. Or is it that Ashanti has never been thought to be great, so no one has ever asked much of her?

title: Asparagus With Chardonnay Sabayon
description: Adapted from Fabienne Escoffier, Ma Cuisine, Beaune, France

title: Lehman Battles an Insurgent Investor
description: David Einhorn thinks another big Wall Street bank is headed for trouble  and he is not being quiet about it.

title: Martnez Gives Mets Lift, and Some Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After throwing his 57th pitch of the game Tuesday, Pedro Martnez did not grab his leg or buckle over in pain. No flashbulbs went off and no balloons were set free to commemorate the occasion, but already Martnez had done better, pitched longer, than in his first  and last  start of the season, on April 1 in Miami, when he felt a pop in his left hamstring.

title: Inside the Nfl Lands on Showtime
description: Inside the NFL, which HBO Sports canceled in February after a 31-year run, was picked up by Showtime. It will be produced by CBS Sports, a corporate sister of Showtime, and NFL Films, and be shown Wednesday nights. HBO dropped the program, saying that it had lost its uniqueness amid the proliferation of N.F.L.-oriented studio programs on television.

title: In a First, Asian Autos Outsold Detroits in May
description: The three Detroit automakers were outsold for the first time ever by their Asian rivals in May, and a sedan was the top-selling vehicle in the United States for the first time in 16 years.

title: Former Prosecutor Leading in Council Race in Queens
description: Anthony Como, a former Queens prosecutor and longtime aide to State Senator Serphin R. Maltese, was leading a special election Tuesday night for a City Council seat in Queens that was vacated by Dennis P. Gallagher, a Queens Republican.

title: Revealing the Wonder in the Why
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pizzas Secret? Whole-Wheat Crust
description: It may dismay the Neapolitan pizza police, but whole-wheat pizza is showing up more often. Last week the Papa Johns chain introduced pizzas with whole-wheat crusts and five grams of fiber per slice, $11.99 for a large plain pizza. Toppings like pesto and peppers are good with the tender, earthy crust.

title: Suit Seeks to Block State Policy on Same-Sex Unions
description: ALBANY  Five state lawmakers, backed by a conservative Christian policy group, sued Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday, seeking to block the governors order directing state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed outside New York. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in the Bronx, came as the Senate Republican conference all but ruled out taking any action to try to challenge the governor.

title: U.N. Says Food Plan Could Cost $30 Billion a Year
description: ROME  Faced with an immediate hunger crisis and the need to double food production in the next 30 years, world leaders meeting Tuesday to discuss soaring food prices were mostly in agreement on how the problem could be resolved. The questions were how to get there and who was going to pay for it.

title: Stalled Sale Seeks Power From Wind
description: ALBANY  One of the worlds largest energy companies proposed on Tuesday to build hundreds of wind turbines in New York, significantly raising the stakes in a nine-month battle with state regulators over its intended purchase of a power company.

title: Prado Has Chance to Beat the Horse He Never Rode
description: Edgar Prado is pretty good at preventing history from being made. Twice, he has been the winning rider aboard horses that thwarted Triple Crown bids; first when Sarava beat War Emblem in 2002, and two years later when Birdstone defeated Smarty Jones. He will try to do the same Saturday, and this time he will have some extra motivation.

title: Everyday Drinking
description: Anthropologists assure us that wherever we find man he speaks. Chimpanzee-lovers notwithstanding, no animal other than man is capable of laughter. And, although some undiscovered tribe in the Brazilian jungle might conceivably prove an exception tomorrow, every present-day society uses alcohol, as have the majority of those of the past. I am not denying that we share other important pleasures with the brute creation, merely stating the basic fact that conversation, hilarity and drink are connected in a profoundly human, peculiarly intimate way.

title: Daughter of Sect Leader Gets Additional Protection
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  A 16-year-old girl who, her lawyers said, was sexually abused in a West Texas polygamist group led by her father, Warren S. Jeffs, was given added legal protections on Tuesday by a district court judge who barred any contact between her and Mr. Jeffs.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Regulators Move to Tighten Oversight of Commodities
description: Regulators of the nations commodity markets on Tuesday announced steps to demand more information about investors to determine whether they are evading market limits on speculation and artificially driving up world food prices.

title: Chinese Stifle Grieving Parents Protest of Shoddy School Construction
description: DUJIANGYAN, China  Police officers here on Tuesday surrounded more than 100 parents protesting shoddy school construction and mourning the deaths of thousands of children during the recent earthquake.

title: Tori Amos Drops Her Label
description: The singer-songwriter Tori Amos has left Epic Records after six years to become independent and urged her fellow artists to stop being dependent, dependent on any system that has become undependable, Reuters reported. In a statement on her Web site (toriamos.com), Ms. Amos, 44, said she looked forward to crossing into the new uncharted music frontier. She released three albums on Epic, most recently American Doll Posse in 2007, which hit No. 5 on the Billboard 500. Before that she was with Atlantic from 1992 to 2001, when she, along with Rod Stewart, Poe, Collective Soul and other artists, left that label.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a contentious race for a House seat in Northern California misstated the number of terms served by the incumbent, John T. Doolittle, who is stepping down. He is serving his 9th term, not his 10th.

title: Same-Sex Marriages Performed in Greece
description: ATHENS  Defying governmental wrath, the mayor of a remote Greek island performed the countrys first same-sex marriages on Tuesday, wedding two men and two women.

title: Pakistan Calls Embassy Blast Suicide Attack
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The car-bomb attack on the Danish Embassy that killed eight people appears to have been carried out by a suicide bomber, Pakistani investigators and diplomats at Western embassies in Islamabad said Tuesday.

title: Correction
description: Bob Herberts column on Saturday misspelled the surname of a Philadelphia woman whose son died in the Iraq war. She is Celeste Zappala, not Zappa.

title: Toll Brothers Reports a Loss, but Not as Deep as Expected
description: Toll Brothers, the builder of luxury homes, reported a second-quarter loss on Tuesday, still hurt by plunging home prices and a weakened economy. But the results were better than expected, and the companys shares were up more than 4 percent in midday trading.

title: Awaiting Springs Exotic Greens With an Old Family Friend
description: IN the days before spicy mizuna mix, delicate mche, and resplendent heads of purple radicchio were available at every corner greengrocer, spinach was about as exotic as salad greens got  at least in my childhood Brooklyn kitchen.

title: Sun, Sherry, Castanets: Musical Postcards From Spain
description: The French composer Paul Dukas accused the Spanish composer and virtuoso pianist Isaac Albniz of handling his colors as lavishly as his money. Albniz indeed illustrates the scorching colors of Andalucia with Technicolor brilliance in Iberia, described by Messiaen as the masterpiece of Spanish music.

title: Impish Writer on the Edge of Tomorrow
description: In Dreams With Sharp Teeth, the writer Harlan Ellison is variously described by friends and colleagues as a hurricane, performance art, an alternately impish and furious 11-year-old boy, a cranky old Jew and, most memorably by his buddy Robin Williams, as a skin graft on a leper.

title: A New Emerald Is Fashioned for Bostons Necklace
description: BOSTON  On the long-neglected site of a state mental hospital that closed more than two decades ago, a mixed-income community is under construction.

title: Lautenberg Easily Wins Spirited Primary Race, Despite a Tepid Turnout
description: TRENTON  In a barbed contest that focused as much on his age as on his accomplishments, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg easily swatted away a challenge from Representative Robert E. Andrews in the Democratic primary on Tuesday and will seek his fifth term in the Senate in November.

title: Global Trade Negotiations Are Dealt Another Setback
description: BRUSSELS  Global trade talks have stumbled again after a frustrated mediator suspended negotiations over industrial goods, complaining that it was pointless to continue because diplomats were refusing to negotiate.

title: The Healing Power of Classical Music
description: From the classical music world come two stories of coping. The Philharmonie, home of the Berlin Philharmonic, reopened for concerts and tours on Monday, less than two weeks after a fire, and the Philadelphia Orchestra turned its Beijing concert into a benefit for rebuilding after the earthquake that devastated parts of Sichuan Province, China, last month. The German Symphony Orchestra was the first to perform in the Philharmonies main concert hall after a May 20 fire forced rescue crews to tear down a quarter of the roof, The Associated Press reported. The Berlin Philharmonic is scheduled to return Thursday to perform works by Shostakovich and Ravel. Meanwhile on Tuesday, the Philadelphia Orchestras concert, with the pianist Lang Lang and the conductor Christoph Eschenbach, was to be recorded and broadcast by CCTV, Chinas largest television network, and fed to Phoenix TV in Hong Kong for broadcast, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. Negotiations are under way with PBS for an American broadcast, according to the report. The proceeds will help rebuild the Sichuan school system. The orchestra, which is near the end of a three-week tour of Asia, is waiving its broadcast fee and will make a donation to the China Youth Development Foundation. The broadcasts will solicit individual donations.

title: Start-Up Releases Smaller Version of Flip Camcorder
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the last year, Pure Digital, a small San Francisco start-up, has shown the worlds consumer electronics companies how to build a camcorder that regular people actually use.

title: Suit Opposes Elk Feeding in Wyoming
description: Environmentalists filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in an effort to stop a federal wildlife refuge in Wyoming from continuing its longtime practice of feeding wild elk. They say such feeding could lead to or worsen an outbreak of chronic wasting disease in the large wildlife populations around Yellowstone National Park.

title: The Long Goodbye
description: Maybe it was her night after all: Hillary Clinton decided not to withdraw from the presidential campaign tonight, and the liberals in blogville are not happy about it, to put it mildly. Matthew Yglesias of The Atlantic begins his blog post on Clintons speech by writing, I probably shouldnt write any more about this woman and her staff. Suffice it to say that Ive found her behavior over the past couple of months to be utterly unconscionable and this speech is no different. He continues,  I think if I were to try to express how I really feel about the people whove been enabling her behavior, Id say something deeply unwise. Suffice it to say, that for quite a while now all of John McCains most effective allies have been on Hillary Clintons payroll.

title: Its a Process, and a Painful One for the Yankees
description: My friend Tim was visiting from Washington, D.C., on Tuesday. He said he got off the train and it seemed as if the city had exploded with all things Joba. And it was true  everywhere, it seemed, people were buzzing about the first start for Joba Chamberlain.

title: McCain Marks General Election
description: Senator John McCain speaks to supporters after the final primaries of the season. (Video: MSNBC)

title: In Harlem, Its a Wonderful Day
description: Lester Cousey, 74, a retired postal supervisor, gazed up at a television inside Amy Ruths, a soul food restaurant on 116th Street in Harlem, as Senator Barack Obama stepped on stage Tuesday night to deliver a speech declaring himself the Democratic Partys presidential nominee, defeating Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York. Im mind-boggled; I really never thought that I would live to see a black candidate, Mr. Cousey said. Knowing this country, its rather difficult for a black man to attain the level hes gotten to so far; it was indeed surprising.Read More at The Caucus

description: Images from the art fair in Switzerland.

description: Senator Barack Obama speaks to supporters after the final primaries of the season. (Video: MSNBC)

description: Location: Ames, Iowa

description: Looking back at where Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton found their greatest support in the nominating contests.

Remembering Alton Kelley
description: Alton Kelley, whose psychedelic concert posters for artists like the Grateful Dead and Jimi Hendrix helped define the visual style of the 1960s counterculture, has died.

description: The boxer Kelly Pavlik has quietly and suddenly amassed two of the four middleweight belts.

description: The Frugal Traveler works for his keep on a farm in southwestern France.

title: Unions Buyout Protests Go Global
description: It started with faux billionaires in the Hamptons and a fat-cat tycoon (or at least an actor wearing a cat mask) in Washington. Now, a union-led campaign against wealthy private equity firms is going global.

title: First Day Success for Indian Companies May Signal Revived Investor Interest
description: Anus Laboratories and Gokul Refoils & Solvent gained on their first day of trading in Mumbai, following the slowest month for initial share sales in two years, Bloomberg News reported.

title: BSNL Considers I.P.O.
description: Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited  is considering offering shares to government employees along with a considerable reservation for BSNL staff. Should the proposal go through, it would be the first such I.P.O., RTT News reported.

title: Kirin, Warrnambool Try to Gulp Down Dairy Farmers
description: Kirin Holdings and Warrnambool Cheese & Butter Factory will partner to bid for Dairy Farmers, the Australian producer of Bornhoffen yogurt and the Coon and Cracker Barrel cheeses, Bloomberg reported.

title: Sinosteel Lifts Midwest Stake
description: Sinosteel has lifted its stake in Midwest to 28.4 percent from just under 20 percent in its tussle for control of the miner with Australian bidder Murchison Metals.

title: Novartis Nabs Protez for $400 Million
description: Novartis has bought U.S.-based Protez Pharmaceuticals in a deal worth up to $400 million, Reuters reported. The deal would give Novartis rights to an antibiotic which could be used to fight superbugs such as MRSA, the Swiss drugmaker said.

title: Exchange Pays $625 Million For Creditex
description: Securities exchange IntercontinentalExchange has entered into an agreement to buy credit processor Creditex Group in a cash and stock deal valued at $625 million, The Associated Press reported.

title: China Telecom in Talks to Sell Stake to Strategic Investor
description: China Telecom said it is in talks to sell a stake to a strategic investor to help it expand after acquiring mobile-phone assets, Bloomberg reported.

title: Carlyle Closes $3.4 Billion European Property Fund
description: The Carlyle Group has announced the closing of its third European property fund at 2.2 billion euros ($3.4 billion), far above its initial fundraising target of 1.5 billion euros, and an indication of the continued strength of European demand, The Daily Deal reported.

title: Shareholders Advised to Back Restoration Buyout
description: Restoration Hardware said earlier this week that two proxy advisories had recommended shareholders vote in favor of a proposed buyout by a Catterton Partners-led group valued at $4.50 per share.

title: Veoh Raises An Extra $30 Million
description: Online video site Veoh has received a further $30 million in financing from such new backers as Intel and Adobe Systems.

title: Texas Oil Companies Consolidate
description: Smith International has agreed to acquire W-H Energy Services for $3.2 billion, The Daily Deal reported.

title: Third Suit Filed Against San Jose Investor
description: The third time may not be the charm for San Jose investor William Boots Del Biaggio III. A new lawsuit accuses Mr. Del Biaggio of scamming Modern Bank of New York out of a $10 million loan so he could buy an interest in the Nashville Predators hockey team.

title: Polygon Investment Chief Is Gone
description: Polygon Investment Partners chief investment officer, Alexander Jackson, is the latest casualty of the ongoing credit cruch.

title: Bidding War Continues for Herald Resources
description: In what is quickly turning into a heated bidding war, a consortium of Antam and Shenzhen Zhongjin have offered up to A$524 million ($500 million) for Australian mineral exploration and development company Herald Resources, trumping an earlier offer made by Bumi Resources.

title: Stalled Sale Seeks Power From Wind
description: Iberdrola, one of the worlds largest energy companies, proposed on Tuesday to build hundreds of wind turbines in New York. The move significantly raises the stakes in its nine-month battle with state regulators over its intended purchase of Energy East, a power company.

title: Rally Software Raises Nearly $17 Million
description: Rally Software Development, based in Boulder, Colo., was expected to announce that it raised $16.85 million in venture funding in a Series C round led by Mohr Davidow Ventures.

title: European Banks May Need Additional Capital to Stem Losses
description: BNP Paribas and European rivals including Societe Generale and Barclays may need to raise additional capital as their finances weaken, Bloomberg reported citing statements made by a Fitch Ratings executive.

title: Smucker Shines to Folgers Crystals
description: J.M. Smucker Company said Wednesday it would buy the Folgers coffee business from Procter & Gamble in a stock deal it valued at about $3.3 billion, including the assumption of about $350 million of Folgers debt.

title: Lehman Battles an Insurgent Investor
description: David Einhorn thinks another big Wall Street bank is headed for trouble  and he is not being quiet about it.

title: TPG to Continue Stake Building in Banks
description: Texas Pacific Group plans to use its investment in Bradford & Bingley as a springboard for stake-building in other banks. The Telegraph reported that such a move could trigger a wave of private equity investments in Britains distressed financial services sector.

title: Senate Panel to Examine Underwriting Practices
description: The Senate Banking Committee is planning to hold a hearing next Tuesday to examine underwriting practices at some of the top investment banks, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters.

title: This Reds for You
description: New research hints red wine may slow aging, but youd have to drink like four glasses a day, at least. Four glasses? Maybe its time to start marketing wine like beer:

title: Icahn Wants New Chief for Yahoo
description: The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the companys board with his own slate of directors.

title: Rating Firms Seem Near Legal Deal on Reforms
description: Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general to reform some of their core business practices, The New York Times reported citing people briefed on the investigation.

title: Sandras Sources | Willer
description: (Bill Batten)

title: Reliance Said to Consider Buyout Partners in MTN Bid
description: Anil Ambani, the billionaire Indian industrialist, is considering linking up with private equity groups on his bid to gain a powerful foothold in South African mobile operator MTN, The Financial Times reported citing unnamed sources close to the matter.

title: Should Google Buy Salesforce.com?
description: If Google is serious about selling business applications, it may need to make a major acquisition to catalyze that effort. Two analysts at The 451 Group present their point of view on why Salesforce.com would be one of the better targets  though an expensive one.

title: The Early Word: Obamas Record-Breaking Journey
description: What we know after Tuesdays final primary contests is that Senator Barack Obama has clinched the Democratic nomination, becoming the first black candidate to lead a major political party into the general election. Under a history-making banner headline, The Timess Jeff Zeleny writes that Mr. Obamas showing in the South Dakota and Montana primaries as well as a last-minute rush of Democratic superdelegates allowed him to claim victory over his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton:

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Dana Jennings
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: To the Swift: Red Smith on Affirmed
description: The following column, Man Here Loves His Horse, by Red Smith, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist, appeared in The New York Times on June 10, 1978, and is from To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory (St. Martins Press), edited by Joe Drape.

title: Bloomberg Might Try to Stay in Public Life
description: As the end of his term nears, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his senior advisers have been exploring strategies that would allow him to remain in political life, including the undertaking a campaign to overturn the citys term limits law or making a bid for governor, Raymond Hernandez reports.

title: Canceled By HBO, Inside the NFL Lands On Showtime
description: Inside the NFL, which HBO Sports canceled in February after a 31-year run, was picked up by Showtime, Richard Sandomir reports.

title: Art Basel Unlimited | The All-Day Schmooze
description: On the schmooze: Swiss collector Maja Hoffmann, artist Ugo Rondinone, film producer Stanley Buchthal, collector Peter Soros, collector Randy Slifka, artist Doug Aitken (on Slifkas shoulder), New Museum curator Masimilliano Gioni and Gagosian Gallerys Beijing director Nick Simunovic.

title: CBS And Yahoo In Web Video Sharing Deal
description: Reuters reports: CBS Corp. said on Wednesday it reached a deal to allow its Web videos to be carried by Yahoo Inc., part of a broader plan by the media company to add new outlets for its television shows.

title: Entertainment Tonight Sticking With Report on Angelina Jolies Twins
description: Five days after Entertainment Tonight reported that Angelina Jolie had given birth to twins, it is starting to look more and more as if the syndicated show  which is on every weeknight, primarily on CBS affiliates  made a serious mistake.

title: Geometries | Water Tunnel No. 3
description: At the junction of three sections of Water Tunnel No. 3 under construction beneath Manhattan  at this point, 580 feet beneath Manhattan. This section of the tunnel is 10 feet in diameter. The project, to bring more drinking water to New York City, was authorized in 1954 and started in 1970; several stages remain to be built.

title: How will the campaign be covered?
description: The Democratic nomination fight has been hog heaven for the celebrity-journalism style of campaign reporting: with two candidates not too different on the issues (despite the health care divide), plus a special dispensation (under the Clinton rules) to invent scandals when needed, it was all personalities  make that all personas, because the way politicians are portrayed generally has little or nothing to do with what theyre really like  all the way.

title: Will eBay Go Shopping?
description: Who knows whether or not Microsoft and Yahoo will ever merge. In the meantime, investment bankers might consider cruising eBay for their next assignment. The online auction site has money in the bank, a unit it may want to sell and a track record of growing through acquisitions.

title: Hondas Live TV Commercial
description: Last week, 19 skydivers successfully jumped out of an airplane in the skies above Madrid to spell the word Honda live on British television.

title: Yahoos Potential Scheduling Conflict
description: On Tuesday Yahoo finally set an Aug. 1 date for its annual shareholder meeting. Why they picked this date over any other in this time period, including the July 3 one originally scheduled, I have no idea.

title: Lost Brother Is Found at a Dominoes Game
description: It had been almost 30 years since Ana Mojica last saw her half brother, Ruben ,on Fordham Road. In the intervening decades, she moved to Reading, Pa., started a family and eventually her own housecleaning business. Comfortable and far away from the Bronx, she still prayed to find her brother.

title: How Much Nature Is Enough?
description: I asked and answered a provocative, and rhetorical, question the other day, and it engendered some strong responses. Heres what I wrote about a marine denizen that is among the worlds largest, and most venerable, reptiles: Does the world need leatherback turtles? Most likely not.

title: Will There Be a Roar, or Silence?
description: The oldest of the baby boom generation were infants when Assault won the Triple Crown in 1946, and toddlers when Citation swept the series in 1948. They were adults scarred by the war in Vietnam and aghast at Watergate by the time Secretariat became the first in a quarter century to win the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes in 1973, and enamored of Big Reds charisma, many had embraced the sport by the time Seattle Slew and Affirmed earned racing immortality during the 1970s.

title: India Plans a New Colossus of Its Own
description: When a proposal emerged to build an immense statue on an island off the coast of one of Indias largest cities, there was no point in denying a nod to New York: It is true that the Statue of Liberty was perhaps an inspiration a little bit, one official told Reuters.

title: Hit Science Show Renewed for 2009
description: I asked Monday if there should be another science festival in New York next year. I now have the answer from the organizers of the first World Science Festival: The show must go on!

title: We Have a Democratic Nominee
description: Aired Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: It looks like we have a Democratic nominee for president, Barack Obama. And now, Hillary Clinton is indicating privately to friends, who then blab it to the cable news channels, that she would be open to the vice presidency. That would mean the chain of command would be Hillary as vice president, Obama as president, and then Oprah on top of them.

title: The Starting Line: The Tiananmen Square Protests, 19 Years Later
description: Today is the 19th anniversary of the crackdown on the Tiananmen Square pro-democracy protests. In an op-ed piece in todays Washington Post, Wang Dan, a student organizer who was sent to prison for his role in the 1989 pro-democracy protests at Tiananmen Square, calls for the Chinese government to declare an Olympic amnesty for what he says are the thousands of Chinese who are serving long prison terms for activities that are normal political engagement in most of the world and to allow those of us who are in exile to at last return home.

title: Hillary May Be Dropping Out
description: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Our Vice President, our old friend Dick Cheney, apologized for a joke he made about West Virginia. Nothing yet on the Iraqi war.

title: Assassination Artist Is Questioned and Released
description: Updated, 3:30 p.m. | This morning, a Boston-born performance artist, Yazmany Arboleda, tried to set up a provocative art exhibition in a vacant storefront on West 40th Street in Midtown Manhattan with the title, The Assassination of Hillary Clinton/The Assassination of Barack Obama, in neatly stenciled letters on the plate glass windows at street level.By 9:30 a.m., New York City police detectives and Secret Service agents had shut down the exhibition, and building workers had quickly covered over the inflammatory title with large sheets of brown paper and blue masking tape. The gallery is across the street from the southern entrance to The New York Times building.

title: Bruce Wasserstein on Oil, Lehman and His Own Pay
description: The smart money is buying land in Kazakhstan.

title: Bill Clinton May Have Had an Affair
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The Associated Press reported today that Barack Obama has won enough delegates to clinch the Democratic presidential nomination. As a result, Hillary Clinton will concede sometime in the next 30 years.

title: Miles: Give the Kids a Shot at the Big Time
description: The requisite chants of Come on Inger-land! which usually course through a game at Wembley are only echoes a week after the Euro 2008 exiles defeated a stale United States mens national team 2-0.

title: Recipe of the Day: Crispy Baby Artichokes, Capers and Spaghetti
description: Todays Minimalist column could be my last story and post about artichokes this year; then again maybe not. Meanwhile, David Latt, frequent Bitten contributor (and host of www.menwholiketocook.com), has filed an artichoke piece of his own MB

title: Well Remember Always
description: The S.U.V. is on the way out. Graduation parties will never be the same:

title: Long Shot Enters; Big Brown Draws No. 1 Post
description: The field for the 140th Belmont Stakes grew by one Wednesday, when Guadalcanal, who is owned and trained by Fred Seitz, was entered in the race.

title: Looking for Donors
description: Aired Tuesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: John McCain is campaigning, out traveling around the country, looking for donors, mostly organ donors.

title: On Your Mark
description: The workers behind the horses' starting gate at Belmont Park talk about the importance of their jobs. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

title: A New Face for Fuse
description: Fuse, a lesser known version of MTV and VH1, has endured a revolving door of top executives and rebranding campaigns over the past five years, Claire Atkinson reports.

title: Mind the Bagpiper
description: Meet Paul Rutgersen, a bagpiper who practices by the West Side Highway. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

title: Max attack  and what comes next?
description: I was on the airplane flying over from Paris to Canada when the news of Max Mosleys victory in the FIA vote broke. Formula One-related FIA pronouncements are a moving target, and I was never sure whether the results would be announced on Tuesday or on Wednesday. In any case, for months  or was it only weeks?  I had been saying to anyone who asked my opinion, that the vote was foregone conclusion, Max would win. So what did I care? Best get on with business and wait for the real stories to break, those of the votes aftermath.

title: Electoral Enchantment
description: SANTA FE, N.M. -- He is bamboo-thin, relies on a pair of walking sticks to help him up a canyon trail, and has lost most of his vision. But at age 88, Stewart Udall, patriarch of the first family of the American West, politics division, has seen enough history to recognize a Big Moment when it's staring back at him.   "I think we're moving into a new era," he said. "There's something very pleasing and hopeful going on, a resurgence after a long drought of positive conservation sentiment."  (Photo: Stewart Udall at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. (Credit: AP Photo/Jeff Geissler)) He was talking about love of land and passion for place, and how it can crystallize in a political shift once every generation or so. For Udall, one of only two surviving members of President John F. Kennedy's original cabinet, that time first came with the 1960 election.  Doors opened. Fresh ideas were aired. And from Udall's long tenure as secretary of the interior for both Kennedy and President Lyndon Johnson came a legacy of public land protection responsible in large part for so many wilderness areas just outside Western cities.   Now, the son also rises. And so does the nephew.   Udall's next-door neighbor in the 400-year-old city of Santa Fe, his son Tom, a Democratic congressman, has a huge lead in the polling on who will become New Mexico's next United States senator, in the seat being vacated by the Republican Pete Domenici. Udall's nephew Mark, a Democratic congressman from Colorado, is a slight favorite in the open senate race in that state, for the seat opened by the retirement of Republican Wayne Allard.   Two new Democratic senators  first cousins from a family that dates to early Mormon settlers in the Southwest  does not an earthquake make. But New Mexico also has three open Congressional seats, and the presidential campaigns will spend a lot of time here in the Land of Enchantment as well.  If the West does prove to be the gateway to the presidency this year  with at least three purple states in play  the campaigns could do no better than to look at polyglot New Mexico.   Urban and wild define the New West  fast-growing cities nestled in Wallace Stegner's "geography of hope." The art, the history and the food of New Mexico have been commoditized, for obvious reasons. But many of its special places are intact, and owned by every American because of the Wilderness Act, which dates to the fertile years of Stewart Udall's reign as the emperor of the outdoors.  Mark Udall has climbed every one of Colorado's 54 peaks over 14,000 feet (and has come within 3,000 feet of the summit of Everest). Tom Udall is the driving force behind legislation that saved the spectacular Valle Vidal in northern New Mexico from the predations of Dick Cheney and his allies.   Not so long ago, when Western Democrats wanted to caucus, "it was sometimes my cousin Tom and I having a beer," Mark Udall told Outside Magazine. Now Democrats are poised to own the West, or so goes the heady talk here at 7,000 feet.   Mountain Democrats found their way in part by rejecting the excesses of coastal Democrats, and by looking at what worked for their elders, like Stewart Udall and his brother, the late Morris Udall. The Udall name is written deep into the salmon-colored canyons and mesas of the Southwest, as prominent as a petroglyph. The family traces its lineage to John D. Lee, who was shot by a firing squad as a scapegoat for the slaughter of 120 settlers by a Mormon militia in 1857.   The leaders of the Mountain Meadows massacre were never held to account. Instead, John Lee, who was treated like a son by the Mormon patriarch Brigham Young, was offered up to the government for his role in the execution-style killings of men, women and children.   "I have been sacrificed in a cowardly, dastardly manner," said Lee, just before the blindfold was slipped over his eyes. His last words were: "Center my heart, boys. Don't mangle the body."  From Lee, who married 11 women, came the Udall dynasty, which also includes the current Republican senator from Oregon, Gordon Smith, a distant cousin of Tom and Mark.   "I don't like the term dynasty," said Stew Udall in our interview. "We're Westerners and small-town people."   The bolo-tied elder in the adobe house is modest about his influence. "The Bush Administration has all by itself created a backlash," he said. "They've been anti-science, and anti-environment." That backlash, plus a longing for a clean break with the energy policies of the past, are what make him think Democrats can ride an ascendancy of ideas into office in the fall.  Republican opponents of the Udall cousins, by contrast, show how that party has faltered. The nominee in Colorado, Rep. Bob Schaffer, has been trying to explain a junket to the Mariana Islands partly arranged by the firm of the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff. Pictures show him parasailing while supposedly investigating labor practices. In New Mexico, Republicans just chose as their senate candidate Rep. Steve Pearce, whose hard-right rigidity is a poor fit for this year and this state.   Stewart Udall was a child in the still-frontier West of the 1920s; he struggled through the Great Depression, and fought the Nazis in World War II. Reflecting on his long life recently, he wrote a message to his grandchildren.  "The lifetime crusade of your days must be to develop a new energy ethic to sustain life on earth," he wrote. "Cherish sunsets, wild creatures and wild places. Have a love affair with the wonder and beauty of the earth."  His intention was to give the kids something to outlive him. He didn't need to worry. The legacy is already there, in the land and the love affair that brought him to it.

title: Training the Mind for Resiliency
description: Karen Salmansohn has written 29 books and, in the process, created her own mini genre that she calls self-help for people who wouldnt be caught dead reading self-help. The ingredients for a Salmansohn book include bold graphics, advice distilled to digestible nuggets and lots of humor. The levity does not preclude her from tackling weighty subjects, and her latest, The Bounceback Book, looks at the psychology behind resiliency and offers 75 tips on how to bounce back after both minor setbacks or major trauma. The tips are brief and punchy (Walk yourself out of a bad mood, If you ask depressing questions, you will 100 percent get depressing answers. Change your body. Change your mind.) and the text that follows offers scientific backing or quotes from the likes of Aristotle, Deepak Chopra or Martin Seligman, a leader in the field of positive psychology.
