description: A writer for The Chicago Sun-Times refused to answer questions on Wednesday at R. Kellys child pornography trial, The Associated Press reported. In his refusal, the writer, Jim DeRogatis, cited an Illinois law that governs reporters rights, as well as the First and Fifth Amendments to the Constitution. Mr. DeRogatis read a statement more than a dozen times in response to questions, including whether he had once made a copy of a sex tape that is at the center of the trial. Defense lawyers have said that copying the tape  which is said to show Mr. Kelly having sex with a minor  would have been a crime. Mr. Kelly has said that he was not the man in the tape. After Mr. DeRogatiss 10 minutes on the stand, Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court said reporters privileges did not apply. But the judge ruled that Mr. De Rogatis did not have to testify, citing his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

title: Red Cross in New Dispute Over Disaster Relief Funds
description: The American Red Cross has again found itself at the center of a dispute over its fund-raising, this time in the backyard of a major Congressional critic, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa.

title: Cell Services Keep It Easy, and Free
description: You hear it all the time: These cellphones are too complicated, by cracky! I dont want to play music or surf the Internet. I just want to make phone calls!

title: Lights, Camera, Tax Credit: Massachusetts Lures Filmmakers With Generous Rebate
description: Angela Peri was shepherding the more than 200 extras she had sent to the set of a new movie, Paul Blart: Mall Cop, being filmed in an upscale mall near Boston. So Ms. Peri, who runs a small casting agency, Boston Casting, hardly had a moment to talk about the impact of the new tax credits going to filmmakers in Massachusetts.

title: Latino Immigrants Hit by Jobs Shortage
description: Latino immigrants were especially hard hit over the last year by the slump in the construction industry, reaching 7.5 percent unemployment in the first three months of 2008, according to a report released Wednesday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: Court Wont Delay Same-Sex Marriages
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The California Supreme Court on Wednesday refused to stay its landmark decision allowing same-sex marriage, clearing the way for gay weddings to begin statewide later this month.

title: Immigration Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Waiting for Triple Crown: Whats the Rush?
description: How many times can one person commit? My horse was Charismatic. I actually drove down to the airport with a photographer buddy of mine in 1999 to see Charismatic get off the transport from Louisville.

title: Senate Panel Accuses Bush of Iraq Exaggerations
description: WASHINGTON  A long-delayed Senate report endorsed by Democrats and some Republicans has concluded that President Bush and his aides built the public case for war against Iraq by exaggerating available intelligence and by ignoring disagreements among spy agencies about Iraqs weapons programs and Saddam Husseins links to Al Qaeda.

title: Is Art Furniture Growing Up?
description: LONDON

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press game report on Wednesday in some editions of the baseball roundup misstated the score of Philadelphias victory against Cincinnati. It was 3-2, not 6-3.

title: Its Over. Now It Begins.
description: The Democratic Party has chosen Barack Obama, and that left Hillary Rodham Clinton with a choice.

title: Mets and Reyes Changing Attitudes and Getting Results
description: SAN FRANCISCO  No words were exchanged, no eye contact made when the Jos Reyes Home Run Celebratory Tour reached John Maine. He just tapped Maine on the shoulder, and off he went. Maine appreciated the gesture, which, in the wake of the Mets 5-3 victory against the San Francisco Giants on Wednesday afternoon, carried more than a trace of symbolism.

title: The Touch of a Ten-Spot
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping for Old Furniture With Michele Spadaro
description: MICHELE SPADARO once made a sofa from garbage, not because she was enamored of refuse, but because as a set designer on a small budget, she needed one for a play. She had to buy only tubing for the frame; the foam, fabric and plywood were all found on the street.

title: Thomas A. Johnson, Pioneering Black Journalist, Dies at 79
description: Thomas A. Johnson, the first black reporter at Newsday and later, at The New York Times, one of the first black journalists to work as a foreign correspondent for a major daily newspaper, died on Monday in Queens. He was 79.

title: $50 Million More to Physics Institute
description: The ubiquitous Blackberry has been good for Canadian physics. Mike Lazaridis, founder and co-chairman of the Blackberrys maker, Research in Motion, announced Wednesday night that he was donating an additional $50 million to the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in Waterloo, Ontario. Mr. Lazaridis attended college in Waterloo before dropping out in 1984 to start RIM. In 2000 he founded the physics institute, which has done pioneering work in quantum information and quantum gravity. His new gift brings his total contributions to $150 million.

title: Tip of the Week: Let Your iPhone Do the Walking
description: Got an iPhone and need to quickly find pizza, coffee, cash or Thai food nearby? Tap the Maps icon on the Home screen, then tap the small locator button in the bottom left corner to pinpoint your position. Tap the Search button and type in a keyword like ATM or Thai in the box at the top of the screen with the onscreen keyboard. Tap the keyboards blue Search button to see all the banks and restaurants near you pop up as red pins on the map.

title: Wal-Marts Detractors Come In From the Cold
description: Over the last several months, a confidential report has circulated within the headquarters of Wal-Mart Stores, proposing sweeping changes to its employee health care plans.

title: A Boom in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Is Gold, So Billions Invested in Farming
description: Huge investment funds have already poured hundreds of billions of dollars into booming financial markets for commodities like wheat, corn and soybeans.

title: Opposition to Menthol Cigarettes Grows
description: Seven former federal health secretaries joined on Wednesday to protest menthols special treatment in a tobacco bill pending in Congress.

title: Awaiting Clintons Return to Home on Old House Lane
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: Bearing Witness to the Fallen and the Grieving
description: The scenes in this book are true, Jim Sheeler writes of Final Salute, his book about fallen military personnel. I witnessed most of them firsthand, and have the tear-smeared notebook to prove it. Nobody who reads Mr. Sheelers account of just how the families of the dead are notified, the lost loved ones enshrined and their memories preserved and honored will have any question about where those tears came from.

title: A One-Day, Two-Way Sale
description: Modernica, a store that sells reproductions of midcentury modern furniture and lighting, will hold a one-day warehouse sale on Saturday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Biscuit Company Lofts at 1820 Industrial Street in downtown Los Angeles. The company also will have an online sale of 10 pieces from 6 a.m. to midnight. They include a Case Study daybed ($1,116.50), a Noguchi coffee table ($486.50), a Noguchi dining table ($556.50) and a fiberglass rocker ($262.50). Information: (323) 933-0383 or modernica.net.

title: Tomato Catch-Up
description: GROWING great tomatoes is like having a baby. You either start your own from seed, or adopt little ones through an organization you have seriously investigated.

title: U.S. Not Seeking Permanent Iraq Bases, Ambassador Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to Iraq on Thursday dismissed any suggestion that the Bush administration is maneuvering to set up permanent military bases in Iraq.

title: Guards Charged in Smuggling
description: SAN DIEGO  Two men working as security guards for a company under contract to the Border Patrol were arraigned Wednesday in federal court here on charges that they had agreed to accept a bribe to smuggle two illegal immigrants into Los Angeles instead of returning them to Mexico.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the home of J. Morgan Puett, a fashion designer and artist, described her affiliation with the School of the Art Institute of Chicago incorrectly. She is an instructor there, not an adjunct professor.

title: Borrowing a Cup of Sugar (and Maybe a Spouse)
description: Each generation looks back at its parents youth with pity and envy: people were so nave back then, and life was so easy.

title: 9/11 Suspects Arraigned at Guantnamo Hearing
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  Five detainees who the government says were high-level coordinators of the Sept. 11 terror attacks were arraigned in a military courtroom here on Thursday morning.

title: Explosions and Shootings Disrupt Relative Calm in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Insurgents preparing to attack an American military base in Baghdad accidentally killed themselves and more than a dozen civilians on Wednesday when their rocket-loaded truck exploded in a residential area.

title: The Revolutionary
description: FASHION, they say, is ephemeral. But in the case of Yves Saint Laurent, that adage holds little weight. During much of his 45-year career, Saint Laurent, who died in Paris on Sunday at the age of 71, held the style world in his thrall, wielding an influence that dominated the runways and exerts a fascination to this day.

title: Penalties Sought From Utilities Over Untrimmed Trees
description: WASHINGTON  Almost five years after overgrown trees helped set off a blackout that left 50 million people in the dark, a reliability enforcement group announced on Wednesday that it had lowered the boom on two electric utilities that were still not trimming their trees properly, and demanded $225,000 in civil penalties from them.

title: Shifting Ground on Recovery
description: How'd we get from icing and Advil to drinking chocolate milk for muscle recovery? Gretchen Reynolds, who wrote about recovery from workouts in the latest issue of PLAY, says that until recently, no one actually tested the conventional strategies. Rather, many athletes just trusted the advice passed down by a friend or relative. But now, she says, we have some solid evidence, in the form of legitimate medical studies, about what works and doesn't work. If you want to see real benefits, studies show, you'll need the right mix of proteins and carbohydrates to replenish stressed muscles, and the sooner they're taken after a workout, the better. That's where the chocolate milk comes in (and the multitude of protein drinks now available).

title: Footnotes
description: The revival of A Chorus Line, playing at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Broadway, will close on Aug. 17. The critically praised production opened in October 2006 and will have played 18 previews and 759 regular performances when it closes. It recouped its $8 million investment in less than five months. ... Sharon Stone is not welcome at the Shanghai International Film Festival, as the backlash in China against her continued on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Stone stirred outrage in China after suggesting that the recent earthquake had been the result of bad karma. Meanwhile, the Black Eyed Peas helped raise nearly $870,000 for victims of the earthquake at a private charity concert in Shanghai, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Van Morrison and Patti Smith will be among the 30 acts at this years four-day Stockholm Jazz Festival, which is to start on July 16, organizers said.

title: Inquiry Opens Into Northern Rock Bailout
description: BRUSSELS  Northern Rock may be getting government aid for longer than necessary, according to an official European Commission document that suggests that the nationalization of the troubled British lender faces tough scrutiny from regulators.

title: Research Finds Wide Disparities in Health Care by Race and Region
description: Race and place of residence can have a staggering impact on the course and quality of the medical treatment a patient receives, according to new research showing that blacks with diabetes or vascular disease are nearly five times more likely than whites to have a leg amputated and that women in Mississippi are far less likely to have mammograms than those in Maine.

title: Still Swinging, Still Hungry, Keely Smith Keeps the Passion
description: Id kill right now for a meatball sandwich, Keely Smith declared from the stage of Birdland on Tuesday evening. Ms. Smith, who has recently acquired the nickname Queen of Swing, has expressed the same craving for meatballs on New York nightclub stages before. Performing clearly stimulates her appetites.

title: Klaus Perls, Art Dealer Who Gave Picassos to the Met, Dies at 96
description: Klaus G. Perls, who sold art for more than 60 years at the Perls Galleries and donated an important collection of African royal art from Benin and modern works by Picasso and Modigliani valued at more than $60 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Monday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 96 and lived in Armonk, N.Y.

title: A Pageant of Early Aileys on a Journey to Posterity
description: New York audiences are so used to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters annual winter appearances at City Center that the idea of finding the company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in June is positively disconcerting. But it was resident at the Brooklyn Academy from 1969 to 1971, and the fit seems natural  or so thought the Joyce Theater directors who are presenting the Ailey companys short run this week.

title: The Joy of Insects
description: WHEN summer comes, and flowers and windows open, insects follow. They in turn are often followed, swiftly, by a fly swatter. But if you cant beat them, why not let them join the party? This season, jewelry designers, perhaps recalling the imaginative little girl whose surreal interactions with insects brought a dreamy beauty to Pans Labyrinth, have shone a spotlight on the Insecta class, finding glamour and chic in all manner of creepy-crawlies.

title: Mortgage Fraud Is Found During Fire Investigation
description: An investigation into a rash of arsons two years ago in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, helped prosecutors uncover a different crime in the neighborhood: mortgage fraud.

title: Real Thought for Food for Long Workouts
description: DR. MARK TARNOPOLSKY, a muscle physiology researcher at McMaster University in Canada and a physician, knows all about the exhortations by supplement makers and many nutritionists on what to eat and when to eat it for optimal performance.

title: At Harvard, They Hail a Fed Chief
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Ben S. Bernanke spoke about the economic pressures created by high oil prices and inflation at his alma mater on Wednesday.

title: A City Where Hospitals Are as Ill as the Patients
description: LOS ANGELES  The patients line up at 6:30 a.m. outside the tidy clinic. Two hours later, when it opens, they will sit and wait some more.

title: Like the Water, Grand Plans Buoy Spirits at a Vacation Spot From a Bygone Era
description: SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y.  The Vanderbilts and the Macys were regulars. Oscar Wilde held readings of his latest works here. Ulysses S. Grant and Theodore Roosevelt came for brief respites.

title: Spanish Soccer Team Strikes Deal for Altidore
description: The Spanish club Villarreal reached an agreement in principle with Major League Soccer and the Red Bulls to sign Jozy Altidore, an 18-year-old striker, a team official said on Wednesday. Ivan Gazidis, the leagues deputy commissioner, confirmed the agreement.

title: Ochoa Stars on Screen as Well as Green, in Documentary Charting Her Rapid Rise
description: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.  Documentary filmmakers often spend years tailing their subjects, trying to capture the money shot. Lorena Ochoa of Mexico made it easy for the two men who followed her around with a handheld camera for 11 months. What they caught on film was a great comet: Ochoa supplanting Annika Sorenstam as the world No. 1 and winning her first major, on the hallowed grounds of St. Andrews.

title: Correction: Critical Shopper - Catherine Malandrino
description: The Critical Shopper column last Thursday, about the Catherine Malandrino boutique at 652 Hudson Street, misstated the location of Vento, a nearby restaurant. It is across Hudson Street from the store, on the next block north; it is not next door.

title: Getty Adds to Antiquities With Third-Century Work
description: LOS ANGELES  The J. Paul Getty Museum announced Wednesday that it had acquired a third-century Roman marble sarcophagus that includes a detailed relief carving of a Dionysiac vintage festival. It is the museums second antiquities purchase since it adopted a new, stricter policy on buying ancient objects in 2006.

title: Producing Substitute Natural Gas From Coal
description: To the Editor:

title: Less-Is-More Notebook Makes Its Bid for a Little Space on the Desktop
description: The laptops assault on the desktop PC continues. Asus has announced it is repacking its ultra-light, ultra-cheap notebook PC, the Eee, into a slim box for the office.

title: O.E.C.D. Cuts Its Growth Forecast
description: PARIS  Growth among the leading industrialized countries will slip this year and next, with activity flat in the United States, but a serious recession or inflation spiral should be avoided, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Wednesday.

title: Clinton Ready to End Bid and Endorse Obama
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will endorse Senator Barack Obama on Saturday, bringing a close to her 17-month campaign for the White House, aides said. Her decision came after Democrats urged her Wednesday to leave the race and allow the party to coalesce around Mr. Obama.

title: Film Spotlights City Life Often Overlooked
description: The directors of Take Out, a feature film about a Chinese deliveryman who must pay off his debt to immigrant-smugglers, do not claim that their movie is based on a true story. But it has more than a passing resemblance to a documentary, so much so that after a screening, one of the audience members asked where the man was now, and whether he was doing all right.

title: Malaysia and India Increase Price of Subsidized Fuel
description: India and Malaysia risked the wrath of voters by raising the price of subsidized fuel, measures that could further weaken the governments of both countries, already made fragile by recent electoral setbacks.

title: A Households Wounds Are Raw, but No One Is Willing to Ease the Tensions
description: The beseeching smile flickers and then widens. The eyes crinkle nervously, glinting with hope. The voice is a soothing, silky purr. Joyce, the unofficial family negotiator played by JoBeth Williams in Body Awareness, always seems to be apologizing for something or somebody.

title: Horror Shows Life Lessons ...Er, Maybe Death Lessons
description: You know things are not going to work out well for a petty criminal when, stranded in a fortlike compound occupied by three young women who look like American Girl versions of 19th-century psychiatric nurses and talk like the weird sisters in Macbeth, he innocently inquires about Internet access. You dont even have any dial-up, or anything? the crook (Jesse Plemons) asks. Are you Amish?

title: Secret Service Detains Artist Over Assassination Exhibit
description: New York City police detectives and Secret Service agents briefly detained and questioned an artist on Wednesday morning as he installed an exhibition with the title, The Assassination of Hillary Clinton/The Assassination of Barack Obama.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A Man in the News article on Wednesday about Senator Barack Obama misstated the name of a club in Chicago where he played basketball on Tuesday. It is the East Bank Club, not the Back Bay Club.

title: A Town-Hall Summer
description: John McCain wants to recreate the old Mickey Rooney-Judy Garland movies about a couple of kids putting on a show in the barn. Him and Barack, barnstorming around the country. They could fly together on the same plane!

title: A Way to Solve Crosswords Without Pencil (or Eraser)
description: When should Grandma get a Nintendo DS? When it lets her work an endless supply of crossword puzzles, thats when.

title: Many Blacks Find Joy in Unexpected Breakthrough
description: Kwabena Sam-Brew, a 38-year-old immigrant from Ghana, doubted that Nana, his 5-year-old American-born daughter, would remember the rally that effectively crowned Senator Barack Obama as the Democratic nominee Tuesday night.

title: Venezuela: Killing of Executive Might Have Been a Mistake
description: The police in Caracas said that the killing of a newspaper executive on Monday might have been a case of mistaken identity. Pierre Fould Gerges, 48, the vice president of Reporte de la Economa, a business newspaper, was killed by a gunman on a motorcycle who followed him after he left the newspapers headquarters in a car that belonged to his brother, Tanous Gerges, the newspapers president.

title: Monsanto Seeks Big Increase in Crop Yields
description: Monsanto, the leader in agricultural biotechnology, pledged Wednesday to develop seeds that would double the yields of corn, soybeans and cotton by 2030 and would require 30 percent less water, land and energy to grow.

title: Ex-Obama Fund-Raiser Is Convicted of Fraud
description: CHICAGO  Antoin Rezko, a once-powerful fund-raiser who helped propel the career of Senator Barack Obama, was found guilty on Wednesday by a federal jury of 16 counts, including fraud, money laundering and bribery in an influence-peddling scheme that touched the highest levels of the administration of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois.

title: Two Sides of the Cape
description: "Why can't The New York Times write about the SAVAGERY and BRUTALITY" of bullfighting, ended one letter from a reader in Chicago. It was a sentiment echoed by a New Jersey reader who wrote, "This kind of gory spectacle deserves to die. To glorify it is disgusting."

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Tuesday about efforts by some Harvard alumni to persuade the university to use its wealth in new ways, like supporting colleges in Africa, misstated the graduation year of Tamara Rogers, an alumna who is vice president for university development. It was 1974, not 1981.

title: Smucker to Pay $3 Billion for Folgers Coffee
description: The J. M. Smucker Company, the maker of jams and jellies, announced Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the Folgers coffee business from Procter & Gamble for $2.95 billion in stock.

title: U.S. Pushes to Rely More on Remotely Piloted Craft
description: WASHINGTON  Early last year, the Air Force was able to keep no more than 11 of the remotely piloted, armed Predator surveillance aircraft flying over Iraq and Afghanistan at any one time.

title: A Historic Night, an American Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Bryant Park Braces for a Tidal Wave of Traffic
description: Bryant Park in Midtown may soon confront a fate that only Yogi Berra could have described: It will be so crowded, nobody will go there anymore.

title: Governor Declares Drought in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Its reservoir levels receding and its grounds parched, California has fallen officially into drought, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Wednesday, warning that the state might be forced to ration water to cities and regions if conservation efforts did not improve.

title: France: Paintings Retrieved
description: Four paintings stolen from an art museum in Nice in August were recovered undamaged in a car in Marseille. The paintings  Claude Monets Cliffs Near Dieppe, Alfred Sisleys Lane of Poplars at Moret-sur-Loing, above, and Jan Brueghel the Elders Allegory of Water and Allegory of Earth  were taken from the Museum of Fine Arts on Aug. 5 by masked gunmen who held visitors and staff members hostage. The police said they had arrested more than 10 people in connection with the theft.

title: Hollywoods Snakes and Assassins Squeeze Into a Video Game Console
description: With the release of the action adventure game Lego Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures, Harrison Ford has become the first actor to be turned into a Lego video game character twice. That may not be the first thing he lists on his rsum, but its got to rank above starring in Six Days, Seven Nights.

title: TV Host Is in His Prime With a Morning Audience
description: When MSNBC awarded Don Imuss old morning-show slot to Joe Scarborough last summer, it did so with little enthusiasm and few expectations. Mr. Scarborough, a former Republican congressman from Florida, had never quite seemed comfortable on his prime-time show, Scarborough Country, nor did he seem to mesh ideologically with this cable news channels more liberal-leaning stars, Keith Olbermann and Chris Matthews.

title: Afghan Borders Concern NATO Force Leader
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As the new commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan expressed fresh concern over rising activity by militants in Pakistans tribal areas, two powerful suicide bombs killed two people and wounded several others near the Pakistani border on Wednesday.

title: Big Brown Free of Steroids, Trainer Says
description: Big Brown will begin the Belmont Stakes from the No. 1 post position. The big bay colt is a prohibitive 2-5 favorite to win the 140th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday and become only the 12th Triple Crown champion in history. Big Brown will also attempt to remain undefeated and gain immortality without his monthly steroid injection.

title: Bro Knows You
description: The power of the sports commercial is that it conveys the illusion of intimacy with an athlete, Bryan Curtis writes in the June issue of PLAY. It was from a commercial that we learned that Michael Jordan was jolly; that LeBron James could inhabit multiple characters with the aplomb of Alec Guinness in Kind Hearts and Coronets (or at least Eddie Murphy in The Nutty Professor); that Peyton Manning was a hipster ironist. In the span of a 30-second ad, the gulf between athlete and fan seems to close, at least a bit. Against all evidence to the contrary, Charles and Michael and Peyton and LeBron begin to feel like our old pals.

title: Detroit Automakers Compete for a Vanishing Truck Market
description: DETROIT  Ford Motor and Chrysler expected to find themselves in a hard-fought showdown when they rolled out bigger, brasher pickup trucks this fall, hoping to enlarge their shares of a segment that has brought them huge profits.

title: An Award for Floral Arrangement
description: IN a spring season of graphic wallpaper patterns and hothouse floral prints, those of the Belgian designer Dries Van Noten stand out as particularly vivid. A single dress was made up of irises, roses and tulips in such a way as to suggest that its wearer was the fashion opposite of a shrinking violet.

title: Spanish Club to Pay Record Sum for an M.L.S. Star, Altidore
description: The Spanish club Villarreal reached an agreement in principle with Major League Soccer and the New York Red Bulls to sign Jozy Altidore, an 18-year-old striker, a team official said on Wednesday and Ivan Gazidis, the leagues deputy commissioner, confirmed.

title: Poppies and Dill
Injury Throws a Snag into Home Run Derby Plans
description: David Ortizs wrist injury is forcing Major League Baseball to look at alternatives to him trying to hit a home run to a specific area of Yankee Stadium designated by a fan at the Home Run Derby on the night before the All-Star Game.

title: In Rare Study, Cubans Put Money Worries First
description: MEXICO CITY  A rare study conducted surreptitiously in Cuba found that more than half of those interviewed considered their economic woes to be their chief concern while less than 10 percent listed lack of political freedom as the main problem facing the country.

title: Clinton to End Bid and Endorse Obama
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will endorse Senator Barack Obama on Saturday, bringing a close to her 17-month campaign for the White House, aides said. Her decision came after Democrats urged her on Wednesday to leave the race and allow the party to coalesce around Mr. Obama.

title: Verizon in Talks to Buy Alltel
description: Verizon Communications is near a deal to buy Alltel for about $27 billion, including the assumption of debt. Vodafone, Verizons partner in its wireless business, confirmed the talks in a short statement Thursday, which said Verizon Wireless was in advanced discussions regarding the potential acquisition of Alltel.

title: From $15 Per Diem in Albany to N.B.A. Riches
description: Coach Phil Jackson once had to complain that his road per diem wasnt enough for a decent meal. He once had to lobby for a raise to $30,000 after winning his first championship on the bench.

title: Manager of Rogue Trader Calls Himself Unqualified
description: PARIS  The former boss of Jrme Kerviel, the trader whose hidden bets cost Socit Gnrale nearly 5 billion euros or $7.2 billion, suggested Wednesday that the bank should not have put him in that supervisory job because he was not qualified.

title: Two Early Trump Tricks Prove to Be One Too Many
description: At the trial in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., to select the United States open team for the next world championship in Beijing in October, the two-day, 120-board final starts on Thursday.

title: Salad Days for the Internet
description: THE other afternoon, my husband and I were drinking beer on the front porch and already feeling a little dirty about what we planned to do later  grill a big fat steak brushed with butter. Then a terrible thing happened.

title: Palestinian Leader Urges Talks With Hamas
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, called unexpectedly late Wednesday for a resumption of dialogue with the Islamic militant group Hamas, a move that could herald a breakdown of his peace talks with Israel.

title: Standing Up for Sales
description: Usher, below, has made the second-biggest splash of the year on the Billboard chart. His new album, Here I Stand (LaFace/Zomba), sold 433,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan; so far only Mariah Carey has had a bigger entrance, with E=MC2 (Island) moving 463,000 in April. In an otherwise slow week, Ushers album sold more than the rest of the Top 10 put together. The soundtrack to Sex and the City (New Line) bowed at No. 2 with 66,000. Last weeks top seller, the self-titled record on Universal Republic by 3 Doors Down, dropped to No. 3 with 63,000, and Bun Bs II Trill (Rap-A-Lot/Asylum) fell two spots to No. 4, with 40,000. Leona Lewis, a 23-year-old British singer who has been a steady presence in the Top 10 for two months, moved up one to No. 5, with 39,000 sales of Spirit (Syco/J). Down the chart, Al Green scored the highest opening-week chart position of his career: his acclaimed new album, Lay It Down (Blue Note), moved 34,000 copes to reach No. 9.

title: Ikeas Brooklyn Beachhead
description: Soon, New York City residents in need of a new sofa or Swedish meatballs wont have to visit Long Island or New Jersey to get an Ikea fix. Ikea Brooklyn is to open June 18 at 1 Beard Street on the Erie Basin in Red Hook. Although the new location will sell the same products as the 34 other Ikea stores in the United States, it will have a cafeteria with views of the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline, and a 6 -acre waterfront esplanade that will be open to the public.

title: Iran: Bahai Arrests Confirmed
description: A government spokesman confirmed that a group of Bahai religious leaders had been arrested, but said that the charges against them related to security and not religion. The spokesman, Gholam Hossein Elham, said the group had acted against the countrys interests and had links with Israelis, according to the state-run news agency, IRNA.

title: Philadelphia Will Try to Reduce Foreclosures
description: PHILADELPHIA  Philadelphia announced a program on Wednesday to reduce the number of people who are forced from their homes because they cannot afford the payments on an adjustable-rate subprime mortgage.

title: With Opponent in Place, McCain Adapts Strategy
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Now that there is a presumptive Democratic nominee, the presumptive Republican nominee, Senator John McCain, began to show some inklings on Wednesday of what his complicated general election strategy might look like.

title: Paramount Vantage Takes a Trim
description: The division of Paramount Pictures that helped produce the Oscar-winning films No Country for Old Men and There Will Be Blood has been cut back, The Hollywood Reporter said. The two-year-old Paramount Vantage will continue as a production label under its president, Nick Meyer, but its marketing, distribution and physical production departments will be taken over by Paramount Pictures. Three senior positions are being cut, the report said, including that of Vantages executive vice president, Rob Schulze. Paramount Vantage became partners with Miramax on both No Country for Old Men and There Will Be Blood. Other notable films it has released include Into the Wild and An Inconvenient Truth.

title: More Space for TiVo
Nearly 12,000 Are Arrested in Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI  The army-backed caretaker government in Bangladesh that has netted hundreds of politicians and businesspeople in a yearlong anticorruption drive has now rounded up nearly 12,000 people in what it calls a crusade against crime.

title: Zapping Teenage Torment
description: ADOLESCENCE is an awkward time to grow a mustache. Especially if youre a girl.

title: Employee Stock Plans
description: To the Editor

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The Big City column in some editions on May 19, about a reunion of 14 women who were in the same sixth-grade class at Public School 87 on the Upper West Side in 1956, referred incompletely to the occupation of the reunion organizer, Jessica Weber. In addition to her work as a graphic designer, she owns her own graphic design company.

title: More Talking Than Listening in the Senate Debate About Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  About a day into the debate over legislation to combat global warming but before Republicans brought the discourse to a stop on Wednesday by insisting that the clerk read every word of the 492-page bill, Senator James M. Inhofe decided to get a few things off his chest.

title: Player Caught in a Web Not of His Spinning
description: Few opponents have been able to slow Bol Kong on the basketball court.

title: Man Falls to Death Fleeing Drug Raid in the Bronx
description: A man fleeing a drug raid in a Bronx apartment on Wednesday afternoon fell three stories to his death, while two women making the same escape attempt survived and were hospitalized, the authorities said.

title: Senate Approves Framework for Spending in Coming Year
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday gave final approval to a $3 trillion budget blueprint that calls for more spending than President Bush requested for education, highway construction and other domestic programs.

title: Surf Channels, or the Web, With a Remote
description: ESPN the Ultimate Remote, a bright-red home theater remote control from tvCompass, is the first in what one can only hope will be a long line of TV-channel-branded electronics.

title: Slates Editor Will Head a New Unit at the Washington Post Co.
description: The editor of Slate will oversee a new unit of the Washington Post Company and look to broaden the pioneering Internet magazines portfolio.

title: Slashed Womans Ex-Boyfriend Is Held on Harassment Charges
description: A former boyfriend of a woman slashed in the face by two attackers in a condominium lobby in Chinatown last week has been arrested in New Jersey on charges that he had previously harassed her, the police said on Wednesday.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The Big City column in some editions on May 5, about Nancy Weiser, a lifestyle coach who teaches Westchester County mothers how to simplify their lives and eat more healthful food, overstated her academic work at Teachers College at Columbia University. She has a certificate in health counseling from a continuing education program formerly offered in conjunction with Teachers College; she does not have a degree from the college.

title: More Cuts as United Grounds Its Low-Cost Carrier
description: The closet with the Kate Spade flight attendant uniforms just got some company: teddy bears.

title: Step Right Up: A Playful, Complex Whirl, According to Tharp
description: While I was watching Tuesday nights world premiere of Rabbit and Rogue, Twyla Tharps new work for American Ballet Theater, I was unaware of any particular audience excitement. Almost the reverse: though the dancers performed some spectacular feats, seldom could you hear any of the responsive noises usually elicited by the companys virtuoso stunts. An ovation, however, ensued. And you could tell by what some in the audience were saying on the way out  wonderful, exciting, surprising, beautiful  that many people sincerely admired it.

title: Foreclosure Possible for Ed McMahon
description: Ed McMahon, below, Johnny Carsons former sidekick on The Tonight Show and the former host of Star Search, is said to face foreclosure on his multimillion-dollar Beverly Hills house, above, because he is $644,000 behind in payments. The Associated Press reported that Mr. McMahon had fallen behind in payments on $4.8 million in mortgage loans. A unit of the Countrywide Financial Corporation filed a default notice on Feb. 28 with the Los Angeles County Recorders Office, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. Beyond his decades of work with Carson, Mr. McMahon, 85, has also been a spokesman for the American Family Publishers sweepstakes. But Howard Bragman, his spokesman, said Mr. McMahon had not been able to work as a spokesman for various products since he broke his neck 18 months ago. He added that Mr. McMahon had been in very fruitful discussions with the lender to resolve the situation. It is unclear whether Mr. McMahon and his wife, Pamela, will remain in the six-bedroom, five-bathroom house, in a hilltop gated community overlooking Mulholland Drive. It is listed for sale at $6.25 million and has been on the market for two years, said a real estate agent, Alex Davis.

title: Sharks Strike Panic Along Mexicos Pacific Coast
description: IXTAPA, Mexico  Tiburn! a little boy cried out, jumping up and down in the sand with his finger outstretched toward the ocean. Everyone around followed the youngsters panicky gaze out past the waves and into the Pacific, where they spotted not a sharks fin but a buoy.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,081 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: Zimbabwean Opposition Leaders Held by Police
description: JOHANNESBURG  Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader who placed first in Zimbabwes March elections and now faces a runoff with President Robert Mugabe, was detained by the police for nine hours on Wednesday and charged with drawing a big crowd, his party said. He was released late in the evening.

title: Charles Moskos, Policy Adviser, Dies at 74
description: Charles Moskos, a sociologist who regularly advised policy makers, senators and generals on military matters, including coming up with the armed services dont ask, dont tell policy on gay personnel, died on May 31 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 74.

title: Martnez Feels Fine but Keeps Outlook Day to Day
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The morning after making his first major league start in two months, Pedro Martnez said he did not feel sore. Not yet, at least. After finishing a hearty breakfast and autographing a box of baseballs, he turned to his personal trainer, Chris Correnti, who nodded back. Workout time.

title: 3rd Minnesota Bridge Is Closed as Special Inspections Continue
description: ST. PAUL  State officials have closed a bridge over the Mississippi River after finding problems similar to those suspected of contributing to the fatal collapse of the Interstate 35W bridge in downtown Minneapolis last Aug. 1.

title: Vigil for Tiananmen Dead Draws Fewer in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  A somewhat smaller crowd than in previous years turned out here on Wednesday evening for the annual candlelight vigil commemorating the 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square, the participation depressed by a growing reluctance among many Hong Kong residents to confront Beijing officials on human rights issues.

title: Old Music Online
description: Lynyrd Skynyrd, Bob Marley and Jimi Hendrix are among the performers whose vintage concerts will become part of the nearly 500 recordings available for download purchase at Wolfgangs Vault, the music and memorabilia site (wolfgangsvault.com). The additions came through a deal between Universal Music Group and the founder of Wolfgangs Vault, Bill Sagan, Reuters reported. Of the 1,434 concerts on the site, 488 can be downloaded now, Mr. Sagan told Billboard.com, adding that some very major artists will be downloading within the next 30 to 60 days.

title: Taking No for an Answer
description: Boston

title: Revived Paper Mill Brings a Town Back With It
description: NEWTON FALLS, N.Y.  Eight years ago, a paper mill closed in this remote corner of the western Adirondacks, taking with it more than 100 jobs. Most of the 75 houses in this speck of a hamlet a two-hour drive from Canada soon fell into disrepair, their frames thrashed by weather and hardship.

title: Moving Beyond the Kitchen
description: New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Refinishing Floors With Less Mess
description: REFINISHING a hardwood floor is dirty and disruptive work. Dust-removal systems can reduce the mess, but the job will still take days and require moving furniture, corralling the cat and enduring the fumes.

title: To Adopt, Please Press Hold
description: JOHN AND JULIE CASSERLY, both lawyers in St. Paul, have been waiting 11 months to complete the adoption of a Guatemalan girl whom they have named Ruby Rosario. But they say they are afraid to check e-mail messages or answer the phone. Its always some update from their adoption agency regarding the latest suspension of the process or some other bad news.

title: Carefully Planned Jazz, Fit for a 50s Soundtrack
description: The bassist Ben Wolfe has some very tight ideas about composition, an interest in combining a small jazz band with strings and an admiration for jazz of the late 1950s. Where that leads him, inevitably, is to music that sounds as if its made for a film: noirs, thrillers, movies shot at night with rain-slicked streets reflecting the lights, that kind of thing.

title: Proposals Would Curtail Power of Pakistan Leader
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In its first substantial move since taking power, the main political party in Pakistan has proposed sweeping constitutional changes intended to limit the authority of President Pervez Musharraf.

title: Obama Offers Assurances at Pro-Israel Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama, in his first day as the Democrats presumptive presidential nominee, plunged into the thicket of Middle East politics on Wednesday with comments on the status of Jerusalem and deterrence of Irans nuclear ambitions.

title: Indonesia Cracks Down on Extremists
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Hundreds of police officers swept through a Jakarta neighborhood Wednesday morning, arresting about 60 members of a hard-line Islamic group blamed for a violent attack last Sunday at an interfaith rally in the capital.

title: The Delta in Our Home
description: Baltimore

title: Touring Wonderland With Guides Who Sing
description: Peter Westergaard had five operas under his belt when he began work on Alice in Wonderland, a straightforward if mildly quirky setting of the Lewis Carroll fantasy. Two years ago the Center for Contemporary Opera, which often presents workshop productions, staged the first half of the work, and on Tuesday evening the center and Princeton Universitys music department, where Mr. Westergaard is a professor emeritus, presented the complete opera at Symphony Space.

title: Yahoo Tries to Move Past Takeover Status
description: YAHOO has been very much in the headlines these days, much to its chagrin. But on Wednesday the company set out to make news of its own, describing a menu of deals in the online advertising realm.

title: Thunder, Rain and Crickets as a Prelude to Ravels Swirl
description: Pascal Rioult is presenting works choreographed to Bach and Ravel for his companys current Skirball Center stint, which began Tuesday. This is not to his advantage. He is a creator of decorative modern dances that do not gain in strength when set to The Art of Fugue or Bolero.

title: Obscure Labels of a Boldface Kind
description: I RECOMMEND visiting the new hipster high-end clothing store Aloha Rag as soon as possible, because its in the dead center of a freshly gentrified neighborhood that is about to become the citys next overhyped fashion and night life destination.

title: PBS Gains Sponsors
description: After a four-year absence,ExxonMobil will resume sponsorships of PBS programs this month, PBS announced. ExxonMobil will partly underwrite the news program Nightly Business Report and the science program Nova through the end of 2008. The company had sponsored Masterpiece Theater and other PBS programs for three decades but decided to withdraw its support in 2004. The new sponsorship fills a significant gap for Nightly Business Report, a half-hour daily broadcast. One of the shows two sponsors, A. G. Edwards, ended its support in January, citing budget restraints. The other sponsor, Franklin Templeton, renewed its deal in January. The program still has room for two more sponsors. Nova is also underwritten by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and David H. Koch, an owner of Koch Industries. That program is seeking another sponsor as well.

title: Experts Warned of Quake Risk in China
description: SHANGHAI  Chinese scientists say that even before a final accounting can be made in last months earthquake in Sichuan Province, one thing is painfully evident: The huge death toll stems partly from a failure to heed clear warnings of a devastating earthquake in the area.

title: 42 Statues of Liberty Will Start All-Star Hype
description: When 42 eight-and-a-half-foot replicas of the Statue of Liberty crop up across the city in the coming weeks, it will mark the beginning of Major League Baseballs campaign to generate hype for the 79th All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium on July 15.

description: Jorge Posada returned to the Yankees roster Wednesday, with his sore right shoulder feeling better, and said he expected to start at catcher Thursday afternoon in the finale of a three-game series against the Toronto Blue Jays.

description: LUGGING around a big-screen MacBook Pro or other large laptop to the local Starbucks may give you a great visual experience on the road, but at close to seven pounds, it could also give you a bad back.

title: Former Nicaraguan Official Wins U.N. Assembly Presidency
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Rev. Miguel dEscoto Brockmann, an outspoken leftist critic of the United States and a former foreign minister in Nicaraguas Sandinista government, was elected president of the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday.

title: China: Japanese Ship to Visit
description: The first Japanese vessel to visit China since the Communist takeover in 1949 will call at an unidentified port this month, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said. The Takanami, a guided missile destroyer, will make the visit under an agreement reached during the recent trip to Japan by President Hu Jintao of China.

title: Groups Seeking Reforms Assail Paterson
description: ALBANY  The government reform groups were already angry enough with Gov. David A. Paterson. At a news conference on Wednesday, they accused him of abandoning the reform platform on which he had campaigned alongside Eliot Spitzer, in 2006.

title: Penguins Raise Scare, but Red Wings Raise Cup
description: PITTSBURGH  The Penguins last-gasp shot skidded along the goal line, carrying their Stanley Cup fate in the final seconds of Game 6. The puck finally wobbled past the net as the clock ticked to zero.

title: Space Station Toilet Is Working Again
description: The troublesome toilet aboard the International Space Station appears to be working again, thanks to a replacement pump taken to the station by the shuttle Discovery.

title: Foreign Reaction to Obamas Claim Is Favorable
description: LONDON  Across the globe, pundits and politicians of all stripes competed for hyperbole on Wednesday to applaud Senator Barack Obamas claim of victory in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, almost as if he had already been elected to the White House.

title: Marine Is Acquitted in Iraq Killings
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif.  A Marine intelligence officer has been acquitted of charges that he tried to help cover up the killings of 24 Iraqi men, women and children.

title: Energy Lessons
description: Perhaps theres something to treadmill wisdom. Were all so narrow-band these days, using the vast resources of broadband to direct ourselves into a chosen news and ideological tunnel. Polarized pluralism defines us.

title: Euro Opener to Be Shown in Central Park
description: Saturday in the park will offer New Yorkers a new experience  the opportunity to see the opening game of the 2008 European Championship on a big screen at the Central Park Bandshell, between 66th and 72nd Streets. ESPN is sponsoring the public viewing, which it said it believed would be the first time a soccer game has been shown outdoors in New York.

title: A Public Job Still Appeals to Bloomberg
description: As his political team considers strategies that would allow him to remain in public life, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged with rare candor on Wednesday that he was unsure about what to do next, and whether it would be as satisfying as being mayor.

title: At Art Basel, Old Names and Few Showstoppers
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Twenty-four hours before Art Basels invitation-only opening on Tuesday, scores of the art elite gathered, sheeplike, on a wooden ramp at a related event in a cavernous installation space. Word had spread that there was something exciting to see: a dusty old train car whose windows flashed black-and-white images of troubled moments from Chinas past.

title: Cellphone Tracking Study Shows Were Creatures of Habit
description: News flash: were boring.

title: Mussina Puts Yanks Back on Winning Track
description: At the age of 39, after 18 seasons in the major leagues, the Yankees Mike Mussina has nine victories in 2008, tied for the most in the American League. The latest was his best of the season, a 5-1 win against the Toronto Blue Jays that raised his record to 9-4.

title: India and Malaysia Risk Voters Wrath by Raising Fuel Prices
description: BANGKOK  With no end in sight to high world oil prices, India and Malaysia on Wednesday became the latest Asian countries to risk the wrath of voters by raising the price of subsidized fuel, a highly unpopular measure that could further weaken the governments of both countries made fragile by recent electoral setbacks.

title: Peter Rabbit Must Die
description: THE homeowner, a city-boy artist and illustrator who had moved to rural Pennsylvania, never wanted to kill the woodchucks. Sure, they were ruining the garden and digging up the foundations of outbuildings, but it was a moral issue: the artist, who is still so uncomfortable about what transpired  and so concerned about how his New York clients would feel about it that he is not willing to be identified  did not want to take a life.

title: Lessons of the Magnolia Tree
description: MY father sat upstairs in his study, working in the one room of our sprawling house that we children could not storm into unless it was a matter of utmost urgency. I now know that the big brown desk was where he wrote his books and often drafted important speeches or new legislation. On the day etched in my memory, all I knew was that I needed his immediate attention.

title: In N.B.A. Finals, Defenses Hone a Battle Cry: Help!
description: BOSTON  On the eve of his N.B.A. finals debut, the long and lanky Lamar Odom considered the task of guarding the longer and lankier Kevin Garnett and arrived at a simple conclusion.

title: Remembering Our Father
description: Forty years ago, as he was celebrating his victory in Californias Democratic presidential primary, Senator Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated. To mark the occasion, Op-Ed editors invited his children to share their memories of him.

title: Sneaking Into History
description: It was spring 1968. I was a teenager and had just gotten my drivers license when I decided to take my parents Chevy Impala from Paramount, the suburb where we lived, into downtown Los Angeles. I had heard that Robert F. Kennedy would be giving a speech on Olvera Street, near Union Station, and I wanted to shake his hand.

title: Safina Turns the Tables Again to Reach Semifinals
description: PARIS  A sign of impending doom to most tennis players who confront it, match point has been a guarantee of nothing but sunshine ahead for Dinara Safina at this rainy French Open.

title: Surrounded by Water, and Sights to Shoot
description: Camera makers have found they need to differentiate their new products by appealing to niche markets. Pentax is taking its compact Optio W60, an update of its waterproof cameras, even deeper underwater to find customers.

title: Rejoicing in Kenya at U.S. Triumph of a Sort of Native Son
description: NAIROBI, Kenya The banner headline across The Kenya Times on Wednesday seemed to say it all, Obama makes history, beats odds.

title: Best Ever? Cast Your Vote
description: On Sunday PLAY presented readers an online video debate over whether Tiger Woods was the greatest athletic performer of all time. Readers were allowed to cast their own vote and share their opinion, and the result was a mixture of outrage, rumination, praise and detailed analysis. As of mid-day Thursday, almost 4,700 readers had cast votes, with 72 percent saying Woods is not the best ever, and 28 percent saying he is. More than 500 people posted comments, ranging from "He has good aim, does that make him an athlete?" to "without Tiger, Obama would not be possible."

title: Chicago Stays in Running After Early Vote to Decide Host of 2016 Olympics
description: Chicago joined three cities Wednesday in moving a step closer to becoming the host of the 2016 Olympics, setting up a final, fierce race to see which one will hold those Summer Games.

title: Chateau: The Condensed Version
description: While James Westwater, an artist, and his partner, Naomi Sachs, were renovating an old gymnasium in Beacon, N.Y., into a home in 2005, they lived in a 120-square-foot shed for six months with three dogs and a king-size bed  and it was great, Mr. Westwater said. It was in this small space that he conceived the idea for his Plywood Chateaux. It occurred to me that people could live in much smaller houses. All you need is a 4-foot cube, and its a room within a room, a mini-retreat within a house. To decorate his 4-by-4-foot boxes, he lined the walls with adhesive-backed vinyl printed with photos of French chateaux, and covered the floors with flokati wool rugs. Mr. Westwaters two Plywood Chateaux prototypes ($12,000 each) will be shown Saturday to July 7, along with 10 of his paintings, at Van Brunt Gallery, 460 Main Street, Beacon, N.Y. (845) 838-2995.

title: Take Me Out to the Ballgame
description: Imagine having to swipe your credit card to debate whether Justin Verlander or Rich Harden has the better fastball? Or flip cards with a pal on the sidewalk? Or endure another of Grandpas stories about the glory days of the Brooklyn Dodgers?

title: India Mahdavi Introduces Furniture to the United States
description: India Mahdavi , an Iranian-born, Parisian designer and architect, recently introduced her line of furniture to the United States. The 18-piece collection of tables, chairs, stools, desks and lighting, is a sculptural mix of lacquer, wood and ceramics. Some of it was used to furnish her projects, like the new Coburg Bar and Hlne Darroze restaurant at the Connaught hotel in London.

title: Because Its a Jungle Under There
description: The CableBox is large enough 16 inches long, 6 1/4 inches wide and 5  inches tall  to conceal most surge protectors, with enough room left over for the tangle of wires surrounding them. Made of fire-retardant plastic, it has openings at either end so cords can run in and out, above, and generously sized rubber feet to keep it from sliding across the floor. Dominic Symons, the designer, describes it as the absolute simplest way of organizing cables. Basically, you can take the mess under your desk, he said, fit it in the box without even unplugging any of the cables, and put the lid on it. Available later this month for about $30. Information: bluelounge.com.

title: High Fidelity On the Go
description: Q. I dont like the sound quality of MP3 files used by portable music players. Is there a way to play CD-quality music on one of these things?

title: City Unveils Plan to Improve Safety at Construction Sites
description: Plagued by a rash of fatal construction accidents and widespread concern about public safety, the Bloomberg administration and the City Council unveiled a 13-point legislative package on Wednesday to broaden oversight of building sites, increase fines for violations and register all key contractors.

description: Jane Friedman, the president and chief executive of HarperCollins Publishers Worldwide, is stepping down from her post, becoming the second high-profile publishing executive to leave the top slot in the last month.

title: Red Wings Lidstrom Skates Into History
description: It was no secret that the Red Wings leaned on their unflappable captain, defenseman Nicklas Lidstrom, in bouncing back from crushing defeats in these playoffs. After taking big leads on Nashville (two games to none) and Dallas (3-0), the Wings kept making things interesting. They had to put away the Stars in a huge Game 6 in Dallas. On Wednesday, they had to face a rejuvenated Penguins team that stole Game 5 from the Wings in their building when they were seconds from hoisting the Cup.

title: Health Care Struggles in South L.A.
description: Ten months after Martin Luther King Jr.-Harbor Hospital closed, local clinics strain from the weight of long lines of patients who are in need of affordable, quality care.

title: Canada: Union Protests G.M. Plant Closing
description: A blockade forced General Motors of Canada to close its head office in Oshawa, Ontario. The Canadian Auto Workers union has charged that a decision by the automaker to close a truck plant in Oshawa violates a labor agreement reached last month. Under the contract's terms, the union contends that G.M. is obliged to find another product to replace the pickup trucks now assembled in the factory, which employees about 2,600 unionized workers. The province of Ontario has also said that G.M. may have to repay hundreds of millions of dollars in incentives it received because of the plant closing. About 100 people blocked roads leading to the head office and demanded a meeting with the company. G.M. has agreed to meet with the union in Detroit on Friday. The union has not indicated when it will lift the blockade.

title: Getting to Know  Edgar Prado
description: Edgar Prado will ride perhaps Big Browns toughest foe, Casino Drive, in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday. And he is not intimidated. After all, he has been nicknamed the Triple Crown killer, stopping attempts by War Emblem in 2002 with the 70-1 shot Sarava and Smarty Jones in 2004 with the 36-1 shot Birdstone. Asked if Casino Drive, at 7-2, can win, he said simply, I hope so. Here we see another side of the Hall of Famer.

title: California: Conservative Wins Primary
description: Republicans chose State Senator Tom McClintock, a conservative, in a heated primary race for the Fourth Congressional District seat. By 54 percent to 39 percent, Mr. McClintock, 51, defeated Doug Ose, 52, a former congressman who is considered a moderate. Mr. McClintock will face Charlie Brown, a Democrat, in November. The seat, in northeastern California, is being vacated by Representative John T. Doolittle, a nine-term Republican, after an F.B.I. investigation tied him to the corrupt lobbyist Jack Abramoff, accusations Mr. Doolittle denies.

title: Space Stations Toilet Repair Is Success
description: The troublesome toilet aboard the International Space Station appears to be working again, thanks to a replacement pump delivered by the shuttle Discovery. The single toilet on the station has separate systems for solid and liquid waste. The solid-waste system was operating properly, but the liquid system began malfunctioning more than a week before the shuttle's arrival on Monday. Oleg Kononenko, the cosmonaut who did the repair work, replaced a balky pump for the urine collection system with one delivered by the shuttle.

title: Man Scales Times Building and Is Arrested
description: Video   Listen to an interview with Alain Robert    Updated, 6:30 p.m. | Alain Robert, a French stuntman known for climbing tall buildings, scaled the north face of the New York Times building on Thursday, ascending 52 stories to the roof and clutching a bright green banner, before police officers arrested him around 12:22 p.m. (Update: Hours later, a second man was arrested after climbing to the roof on another part of the building. For a complete account of the day's events, see the article prepared for Friday print editions.)  Police and security officials cordoned off the sidewalk below, on West 41st Street, as a crowd assembled. The words on the banner were illegible from the sidewalk, but from office windows inside the tower the slogan on the banner could be clearly read: "Global warming kills more people than 9/11 every week."   The man later confirmed, moments after being arrested on the roof of the tower, that he was Alain Robert, a 46-year-old stuntman famous for scaling structures like the National Bank of Abu Dhabi, the Sydney Opera House in Australia and the Eiffel Tower and Montparnasse Tower in Paris.  He wore a T-shirt with his name and the address of a Web site (thesolutionissimple.org), exercise pants and climbing shoes. He had long blond hair. He used no rope, harness or parachute.    Police officers blocked off the sidewalk at the base of the building and asked members of the crowd to move along. Construction workers on a building directly across West 41st Street, facing the northern face of the building, looked on with expressions of astonishment and amusement. A crowd gathered on the sidewalk, pointing, gawking and capturing pictures and images with cellphones, digital cameras and video cameras.   "This is a publicity stunt, it looks like," Janet L. Robinson, the chief executive of The New York Times Company, said as she entered the building. "There is definitely going to be an arrest."   Wearing a backpack slung over one shoulder, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., the chairman of The Times Company and publisher of The Times, who is himself an avid climber, ducked under the police tape and examined the spectacle. He declined to comment.  Alain Robert, a stuntman, climbed the 52-story New York Times building on Thursday before he was arrested. His banner read, Global warming kills more people than 9/11 every week. (Photo: Sewell Chan/The New York Times)  Inside the building, reporters and editors pressed their faces to the glass windows to catch a glimpse of the climber. He weaved in and out of the ceramic rod facade, seeming to rest on the building's exterior beams every few floors before swinging himself back out the face of the rods to resume his climb. He stopped occasionally to wave to the crowd, which included construction workers on a building across the street and others in front of the Port Authority.   Each time he took his hand away to wave, there were gasps from observers who feared he might fall.  As Mr. Robert climbed the building, police officers from the Emergency Services Unit, using a freight elevator, assembled on the roof. "He's up to 30-something," one police officer radioed another. "No, he's up to 45," another officer radioed back.   A security guard remarked, "Apparently, he's a professional climber," and a police officer replied: "To be honest, looking at this building, you don't have to be a professional. This building is like a ladder." (Designed to be environmentally sensitive, the tower is sheathed in distinctive horizontal ceramic rods that are intended to diffuse sunlight, allowing natural light to enter the building while keeping out heat and increasing the building's energy efficiency.)  Around a dozen police officers were on the roof when Mr. Robert arrived there. One of them put on a hard hat, harnessed himself to the building and sat out on a beam, a couple of feet from the building, as Mr. Robert reached the top. When he got to the top, he calmly perched himself on the same beam, beside the officer, and raised his hands. The pair began talking.   Mr. Robert was placed in handcuffs and led across the roof and into a service elevator. The police officers had evidently made preparations in case he resisted, but he submitted peacefully. A Times reporter asked, "Where are you from and why are you doing this?" Mr. Robert said, "France. Paris."   Mr. Robert was taken down through the service elevator to an underground service area of the building. A reporter asked why he had chosen The Times's building. His reply: "This is a green building, which is a fantastic step." He proceeded to talk about global warming as the police led him away. He said he believed the news media would give more prominence to coverage of global warming if a man climbed a prominent building.  (Photo: A view of Alain Robert from inside the Times building, as he climbed it. (Photo: Matthew Orr/The New York Times))  Asked about the difficulty of the climb, he replied: "No, the building was easy. It was just a statement. Plus, I'm a professional climber."  He added: "My name is Alain Robert. I did climb about 80 buildings around the world and I climbed even the five tallest."  Then he was moved into a squad car and driven away, east on West 40th Street. He was taken to the Midtown South police precinct.   New York's skyscrapers have long been sites for death-defying stunts. In 1974, a French stunt artist, Philippe Petit, famously walked a high-wire strung between the twin towers of the World Trade Center. (Mr. Petit's feat is the subject of a new documentary, "Man on a Wire," which has received critical acclaim.)  More recently, in 2006, another stuntman, Jeb Corliss, was arrested after trying to jump off the observation deck of the Empire State Building. (Mr. Corliss challenged his indictment in court. A trial judge ruled last year that as a professional jumper, he was experienced and careful enough to jump off a building without endangering his own life or anyone elses. But this year, an appellate court overturned the ruling, although it reduced the charge in the indictment from a felony charge of reckless endangerment with depraved indifference to life, to a misdemeanor charge of reckless endangerment.)  Mr. Robert is a practitioner of free-soloing, a kind of climbing done without ropes, harnesses or other external supports. ("Free climbing," another kind of climbing, involves no equipment to aid in the climb, but does include ropes for protection in the event of a fall.)  (Photo: Alain Robert stands on a ledge outside the building. (Photo: Matthew Orr/The New York Times))   "Climbing is my passion, my philosophy of life," Mr. Robert states on his Web site, adding, "Although I suffer from vertigo, although my accidents left me disabled up to 60 percent, I have become the best solo climber." The Web site states that in eight years, Mr. Robert has climbed more than "70 skyscrapers and mythical monuments around the world."  The 52-story steel-and-glass Times building, at 620 Eighth Avenue, between West 40th and 41st Streets, was designed by Renzo Piano and opened last year. A personal assistant at Mr. Piano's architectural studio in Paris said he was traveling and not immediately available for comment.   Along with The Times, it is occupied by several law firms, including Covington & Burling, Seyfarth Shaw and Goodwin Procter. Before The Times moved last year, it had previously occupied a neo-Renaissance building at 229 West 43rd Street since 1913.  Inspector James McCarthy, the commanding officer of the Midtown South police precinct, said Mr. Robert would likely face several criminal charges, including, at the least, reckless endangerment.   Reporting was contributed by Corey Kilgannon, Eric Konigsberg, Jennifer 8. Lee, Conrad Mulcahy and Allen Salkin.

title: The Webs Walled Gardens

The best are like little walled gardens: safe spots for delicate specimens where everything from the paper stock to the kerning has received careful attention from the editors. The online offerings at n+1 and McSweeneys are fun for a quick break, but the sites dont invite an easy-chair reverie  at least not from me. title: Woman in Charge, Women Who Charge
description: Is it a coincidence that the bubbling idiocy of "Sex and the City," the movie, exploded upon the cultural scene at the exact same time that Hillary Clinton's candidacy imploded?  Literally, of course, it is. Figuratively, I'm not so sure.  And before I set off an avalanche of e-mails explaining why Hillary deserved to lose, I want to make one point clear: I am talking here not about the outcome of her candidacy  mistakes were made, and she faced a formidable opponent in Barack Obama  but rather about the climate in which her campaign was conducted. The zeitgeist in which Hillary floundered and "Sex" is now flourishing.  It's a cultural moment that Andrew Stephen, writing with an outsider's eye for the British magazine the New Statesman last month, characterized as a time of "gloating, unshackled sexism of the ugliest kind." A moment in which things like the formation of a Hillary-bashing political action group, "Citizens United Not Timid," a "South Park" episode featuring a nuclear weapon hidden in Clinton's vagina, and Internet sales of a Hillary Clinton nutcracker with shark-like teeth between her legs, passed largely without mainstream media notice, largely, perhaps, because some of the key gatekeepers of mainstream opinion were so busy coming up with various iterations of the nutcracker theme themselves. (Tucker Carlson on Hillary: "When she comes on television, I involuntarily cross my legs." For a good cry, watch this incredible montage from the Women's Media Center.)  Stephen is not the first commentator to note that if similarly hateful racial remarks had been made about Obama, our nation would have turned itself inside out in a paroxysm of soul-searching and shame. Had mainstream commentators in 2000 speculated, say, that Joe Lieberman had a nose for dough, or made funny Shylock references, heads would have rolled  and rightfully so.  But 16 months of sustained misogyny? Hey -- she asked for it. With that voice, ("When Hillary Clinton speaks, men hear, 'Take out the garbage' " Fox News regular Marc Rudov, author of "Under the Clitoral Hood: How to Crank Her Engine Without Cash, Booze, or Jumper Cables," said in January). With that ambition, and that dogged determination ("like everyone's first wife standing outside a probate court," according to MSNBC commentator Mike Barnicle) and, of course, that husband (Chris Matthews: "The reason she's a U.S. Senator, the reason she's a candidate for president, the reason she may be a front-runner is her husband messed around."). Clearly, in an age when the dangers and indignities of Driving While Black are well-acknowledged, and properly condemned, Striving While Female  if it goes too far and looks too real -- is still held to be a crime.  In a culture that's reached such a level of ostensible enlightenment as ours, calling a powerful woman "castrating"  however you choose to put it  ought to be seen as just as offensive as rubbing your fingers together to convey a love of gold coinage when you talk about a Jew. It's nothing other than an expression of woman-hate -- and the degree to which such expressions have flourished, in the mainstream media and in the loonier reaches of cyberspace this year, has added up to be a real national shame.   Which brings me back to "Sex and the City."   How antithetical Hillary's earnest, electric blue pants-suited whole being is to the frothy cheer of that film, which has women now turning out in droves, a song in their hearts, unified in popcorn-clutching sisterhood to a degree I haven't seen since the ugly, angry days of Anita Hill and  the first incarnation of Hillary Clinton. How times have changed. How yucky, how baby boomerish, how frowningly pre-Botox were the early 1990s. How brilliantly does "Sex"  however atrocious it may be  surf our current zeitgeist, sugar-coating it all in Blahniks and Westwood, and yummy men and yummier real estate, and squeakingly desperate girl cheer.  Take Miranda: a working mother archetype for an anti-woman age. She's so callous now that she won't let her nanny eat a decent meal, and so defiantly sexless that she's let her pubic hair grow in. Take Charlotte: the Good Mommy, with an angel's face and no employment, a seemingly limitless credit line and an adoring troglodyte of a husband (so short, so bald, and yet so good with the gelt). And then  please  take Samantha. At 50, she's the one girlfriend aged enough to bear the baggage of old-time, Clinton-era feminist sentiment. She's a self-centered heart-breaker, a real man-eater -- you should see how she rejects a drooping roll of sushi -- her corruption made manifest by the fact that, at film's end, she develops (gasp!) a gut.  Yes, a gut, girls, like yours and mine and that of virtually any real woman who's over 35, or has had children, or has something more important to do than full-time Pilates.  "Sex and the City" is the perfect movie for our allegedly ever-so-promising post-feminist era, when "angry" is out and Restalyne is in, and virtually all our country's most powerful women look younger now than they did 20 years ago.   Oh, lighten up, I can hear you say. Don't get your knickers in a twist.  Earnestness is so unattractive (in a woman).

title: Euro 2008: Group D, Spains Time to Shine
description: Four years ago, Greece shocked Europe, and probably itself, by winning the European Championship in Portugal. It may not have been pretty, but in soccer it is often only about getting the proverbial result. And that is exactly what Greece did  three straight 1-0 wins to claim the title against the hosts in the final in Lisbon. But can anyone remember a champion returning to defend its title being so disrespected and dismissed?

description: The Red Bulls (4-3-3, 15 points) started the season losing only one of their first seven games, and they allowed just six goals over that period. Heading into the match Thursday night against visiting Chivas USA (4-5-2, 14 points), the Red Bulls had lost two straight games, allowing six goals in the process. Chivas was trying to extend its unbeaten streak to four games, but failed. Red Bulls won 1-0.

title: As Usual, Elbow Issue Doesnt Scare Yankees on Draft Day
description: It was no surprise Thursday that with the 44th overall pick in the draft (their second selection, as compensation for the loss of Luis Vizcaino as a free agent) the Yankees took a pitcher who had an elbow injury this season  the Stanford lefty Jeremy Bleich. The Yankees have been undeterred in taking such risks, selecting Mark Melancon, Alan Horne and Andrew Brackman in recent years despite elbow issues with all three.

description: Its all over  a tremendous Stanley Cup final is in the books. Well, not quite, not until the HNIB bloggers have had their say. First, our independent blogger for the proud finalists from Pittsburgh.

title: Dance Draws a Crowd
description: Foxs So You Think You Can Dance earned Wednesday nights highest ratings, as an average of 9.3 million viewers tuned in to the show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Fox led the night over all, but CBS ranked a close second with repeats of Criminal Minds at 9 (8.2 million) and CSI: NY at 10 (9.2 million). CBSs prime-time edition of The Price is Right attracted 7 million viewers at 8 p.m. But in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, CBS tied for third with ABC, which was the least-watched of the four major networks, with repeats of "Wife Swap" at 8 (5.1 million), "Supernanny" at 9 (6 million) and "Men in Trees" at 10 (5.2 million). NBC earned the nights second-highest ratings in the 18-to-49 set with a live broadcast of Game 6, the conclusion of this years National Hockey League championship, attracting approximately 7 million total viewers.

title: Oscar Ratnoff, 91, Expert on Blood Clots, Is Dead
