description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments ethics office is reviewing a decision in 2002 by department officials to send a Canadian citizen to Syria, where he was tortured, American officials said Thursday.

title: The Uncertain Art
description: There is wisdom in the acceptance of uncertainty. Well used, it can make a philosopher of an ordinary man. To the intuitive mind of the twenty-two-year-old John Keats, that precious insight appeared in a flash of understanding one day in 1817, while he was deep in conversation on a long walk with two friends: [S]everal things dove-tailed in my mind, and at once it struck me what quality went to form a man of achievement, he later wrote in a letter to his brothers. I mean negative capability, that is, when a man is capable of being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts. To become comfortable with uncertainty is one of the primary goals in the training of a physician.

title: Tough Workouts Are Now as Rare as the Crown Itself
description: Secretariat, Seattle Slew and Affirmed were as fit as a horse could be when they pulled into the Belmont Stakes and captured their Triple Crown championships. Each sported a series of workouts that rarely, if ever, are seen these days, when top horses do not race very much or stick around very long.

title: After a Stunning Collapse, Gustafson Stumbles Yet Again
description: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.  Bulle Rock golf course was a soaked green sponge. It had been doused a day earlier with more than an inch of rain in less than two hours. On Thursday, the sun broke through the low ceiling of pewter clouds, and the previous afternoons freakish storm, which resulted in tornado watches and power outages, receded into the distance.

title: Festival Highlights
description: The Vision Festival presents a rich bounty of music, rewarding the intrepidness and patience of its audiences. Here are some especially promising sets scheduled for this years edition, at the Clemente Soto Vlez Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street, at Rivington Street, Lower East Side; (212) 696-6681, visionfestival.org. Tickets are $35 per night, $30 in advance, $20 for students; brownpapertickets.com/event/30125.

title: One Bus, Many Plot Twists
description: A love quadrangle, a soup-slurping subplot and concern about global warming are the incongruous ingredients of Polar Bears. The fourth Naked Brothers movie, which will be shown on Nickelodeon Friday night, is clumsy but criticproof.

title: UBS Plans to Close Its Municipal Bond Business
description: UBS said Thursday it would close its municipal bond business after failing to find a buyer for what was the third-largest underwriter of American state and local government debt last year.

title: A Tall Order
description: Take Out tracks, with nimble attention and fine curiosity, a day in the life of an illegal Chinese immigrant as he darts around Upper Manhattan on a cheap bicycle laden with MSG-soaked delicacies. Theres a lot at stake on this particular day, which begins as Ming Ding (Charles Jang) is rudely awakened by a pair of thuggish debt collectors demanding a full $800 payment by nights end.

title: 2 Men Scale New York Times Building Hours Apart
description: Two men, one a practiced French stuntman known for climbing tall buildings, the other a New Yorker who said he wanted to raise awareness of the dangers of malaria, scaled the 52-story New York Times Building in Times Square on Thursday just hours apart. Each was arrested when he stepped safely onto the roof.

title: Seafaring Puppets Rock on a Trip to Party Island
description: Pay no attention to this review, because nothing in it will adequately convey the demented brilliance of Jollyship the Whiz-Bang, a puppet show within a rock show (or perhaps its the other way around) now occupying Ars Nova.

title: Germany: A Newspaper Provokes
description: A leftist German newspaper provoked outrage and condemnation for printing what many readers called a racial slur about Senator Barack Obama. The newspaper, Die Tageszeitung, printed a front-page article about Mr. Obamas becoming the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee and used a photograph of the White House and the headline Uncle Baracks Cabin, in German, a reference to the antislavery novel Uncle Toms Cabin by Harriet Beecher Stowe, which contains negative racial stereotypes. Editors at the newspaper said the headline was satirical and intended to provoke a discussion of race and politics, according to the online version of the leading German magazine Spiegel. The paper is known for standing up for foreigners, but also for crossing the line with articles critics say are in bad taste.

title: New Yorks Big Backyard
description: GOING to our local playground in Brooklyn can be painful. When friends are there, its great. But its hard to make small talk with people I barely know about high-tech strollers, whose kid is taking French lessons (mine are not), the pros and cons of gifted-and-talented programs  the usual nightmare urban-mommy conversation.

title: Forge a Unity of Purpose, Then Conquer the World
description: Mongol  or, as I prefer to think of it, Genghis Khan: The Early Years  is a big, ponderous epic, its beautifully composed landscape shots punctuated by thundering hooves and bloody, slow-motion battle sequences.

title: He Set Tongues Wagging With His Music and Muses
description: Speculation was rife during and after Vivaldis life about possible improprieties committed with the girls he taught at the Ospedale Della Piet, an orphanage in Venice. Several young women were certainly his muses, although scholars continue to debate the precise nature of the inspiration they provided. At Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening the Little Orchestra Society, conducted by Dino Anagnost, offered insights on the matter in a lively program called The Two Annas: Vivaldis Muses.

title: 2 Leaders Ousted From Air Force in Atomic Errors
description: WASHINGTON  The Air Forces senior civilian official and its highest-ranking general were ousted by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday after an inquiry into the mishandling of nuclear weapons and components found systemic problems in the Air Force.

title: Trails of the South
description: THOUSANDS of hikers invade the Appalachian Mountains south of the Mason-Dixon line when the weather turns warm, eager to buck the daily grind  not to mention the heat and haze  by tackling trails that cross rivers, pass refreshing waterfalls and often lead to breathtaking vistas shrouded in mist. These escapes are cool, literally.

title: About 1 in 11 Mortgageholders Face Loan Problems
description: About 1 in 11 American mortgages were past due or in foreclosure at the end of March, according to a report released on Thursday, a figure that is rising fast as home prices fall and the job market weakens.

title: Giambis Home Run Is a Pain Reliever
description: After Jason Giambis titanic home run landed in the third deck to give the Yankees a 9-8 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Thursday afternoon at Yankee Stadium, he hopped, skipped and jumped around the bases, ignoring the pain in his sore left foot that had kept him out of the starting lineup for two games.

title: A Media History Site
description: The Museum of the Moving Image has started a new Web site devoted to the history of film, television and digital media, Rochelle Slovin, the museums director, said. The site, movingimagesource.us, will feature articles by scholars, critics and authors, a calendar highlighting major gallery festivals, exhibitions and retrospectives around the world, and a guide to research resources online.

title: Bush Overstated Iraq Evidence, Senators Report
description: WASHINGTON  A long-delayed Senate committee report endorsed by Democrats and some Republicans concluded that President Bush and his aides built the public case for war against Iraq by exaggerating available intelligence and by ignoring disagreements among spy agencies about Iraqs weapons programs and Saddam Husseins links to Al Qaeda.

title: 50 Years of NASAs Home Movies
description: ABOUT midway through When We Left Earth, a sweeping new video history of the American space program, the former NASA flight director Eugene F. Kranz looks into the camera with an intensity that is almost frightening.

title: Blanket Coverage of Big Browns Bid
description: If you watch the 1978 Belmont Stakes (go to YouTube), youll see what CBS Sports lacked: cameras in the starting gate and in a blimp, cameras isolated on several horses, close-ups of the field or running graphics to show what places the horses were in.

title: Trail of Bad Loans Leads to the Couple Next Door
description: This is a tale of sex, lies and foreclosures.

title: France Salutes the Ultimate Couturier
description: PARIS  Two shopgirls in their uniform red jackets and black blouses stared down from the windows above the Elena Miro shop on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honor on Thursday, as the fashion world gathered below to mourn Yves Saint Laurent.

title: For Jazzs Avant-Garde, an Annual Gathering and a Little Competition
description: During his youth, the New Orleans tenor saxophonist Kidd Jordan worked with some of the brightest lights of soul and R&B, like Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin and Stevie Wonder. And thats just for starters. You name the genre, Ive done it, Mr. Jordan, 73, said this week from Baton Rouge, La., his temporary home since shortly after Hurricane Katrina hit in 2005. But when I was playing in all those other genres, I wasnt satisfied with what I was doing. I always was one of them who would search, and keep searching.

title: $21.5 Million Is a Record for McCain
description: Senator John McCains presidential campaign raised at least $21.5 million in May  its best fund-raising month yet  in a sign that its effort to draw donations in tandem with the Republican National Committee is yielding dividends.

title: Israel to Loosen Limits on Gaza Scholars
description: TEL AVIV  Senior Israeli officials said Thursday that they would no longer stop all Palestinians who had foreign study grants from leaving Gaza and would look favorably upon their applications for exit permits. The move departs from the near total Israeli ban on movement out of Gaza, the Hamas-controlled coastal strip, since late 2007.

title: Year Later, Another Jets Player Is Unhappy
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Tight end Chris Baker ripped Jets management Thursday, bringing an air of familiarity to the first minicamp practice.

title: Two Fed Bank Presidents Warn About Lending to Securities Firms
description: Two Federal Reserve Bank presidents warned in separate speeches on Thursday that the central banks decision in March to lend to securities firms might sow the seeds of further financial crises.

title: 2 Central Banks in Europe Keep Rates Unchanged
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank, alarmed by soaring prices for food and fuel, warned unexpectedly Thursday that it might raise interest rates next month to counter an inflationary spiral.

title: Big Airlines in a Rush to Go Small
description: In the three decades since deregulation, the nations major airlines have operated with a simple strategy that bigger was better, and that the way to win the industry dogfight was to fly more planes on more routes to attract the most passengers.

title: Qaeda Group Says It Bombed Embassy
description: FRANKFURT  A Qaeda operative based in Afghanistan claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing outside the Danish Embassy in Islamabad, according to a posting on jihadist Web sites, saying the attack was in revenge for the publication of cartoons caricaturing the Prophet Muhammad in Danish newspapers.

description: Brian Carty would like to be Tiger Woods when he grows up. Better, actually, if that is humanly possible.

title: Steroid Dealer Who Cooperated With N.F.L. Is Found Dead

She produced a best-selling memoir, Tough Choices, but for the most part spent the years after her ouster in relative self-imposed exile from public life.

title: Vijay Tendulkar, Indian Theater Innovator, Dies at 80
description: Vijay Dhondopat Tendulkar, one of the most important and influential Indian playwrights of the last six decades and the writer for some critically acclaimed Hindi films, died on May 19 in Pune, India. He was 80.

title: BP Says It Is Committed to Russian Venture
description: MOSCOW  The chief executive of BP, Tony Hayward, said Thursday that the company was committed to staying in Russia, even as its joint venture, TNK-BP, came under fresh pressure from the authorities investigating accusations of tax evasion.

title: 2 Top Leaders of Air Force Pushed Out After Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The Air Forces senior civilian official and its highest-ranking general were ousted by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday following an official inquiry into the mishandling of nuclear weapons and components, an episode that Mr. Gates called an indication of systemic problems in the Air Force.

title: Fuzzy Outsider, Kicking His Way Toward His Dream
description: At once fuzzy-wuzzy and industrial strength, the tacky-sounding Kung Fu Panda is high concept with a heart. Even better, this animated feature from DreamWorks is so consistently diverting and visually arresting that it succeeds in transcending its storybook clichs. The tale has the consistency of baby pablum  its nutritious and easy on the gums  but theres enough beauty and pictorial wit here from opening to end credits, enough feeling for the art and for the freedom of animation, that you may not care.

title: The Art of Growing Up
description: In January 1841, Abraham Lincoln seems to have at least vaguely thought of suicide. His friend Joshua Speed found him one day thrashing about in his room. Lincoln went Crazy, Speed wrote. I had to remove razors from his room  take away all Knives and other such dangerous things  it was terrible.

title: Myanmar Detains Activist Comedian
description: YANGON, Myanmar  A popular comedian here who had been carrying out a private campaign to help the victims of last months cyclone has been detained by the police, his friends said Thursday.

title: Riverss Sleight of Hand: Making Three Stars Think as One
description: BOSTON  Doc Rivers has a trophy that bears Red Auerbachs likeness and the words Coach of the Year  an award that has nothing to do with Riverss success with the Celtics, but perhaps foreshadowed it.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: As a Father Nears Death, a Son Grows No Closer
description: A gentle tale gently told, When Did You Last See Your Father? is grown-up, civilized fare. If that sounds like a compliment, it is, even though the whole thing might have been improved with a bit of messiness, a little vulgarity to leaven its tastefulness and tact. This isnt a groundbreaking work; just a smartly played story, enlivened by drama and spiked with passion, the very thing that thinking audiences pine for, especially during the summer spectacle season when theaters are clogged with sticky kids stuff and television reruns.

title: Wonder Tour, Yes; Yes Tour, No
description: Stevie Wonder, below, is set to perform a series of concerts in Europe for the first time in a decade, BBC News reported. Mr. Wonder will begin his tour in Britain on Sept. 8 in Birmingham, followed by dates in Manchester and at Londons 02 arena. He is to perform in seven other countries, ending with a concert in Paris on Sept. 28. Tickets for the concert will go on sale on June 13. ... The classic progressive-rock band Yes canceled its 40th anniversary tour after its singer, Jon Anderson, suffered a severe asthma attack, The Associated Press reported. The band was to start a 26-city summer tour in Quebec on July 12.

title: Vote by Numbers
description: IT appears that Hillary Clinton is going to suspend her presidential campaign this weekend, at the urging of Democratic Party leaders and superdelegates. Before that happens, Mrs. Clinton and the superdelegates might want to know this: if the general election were held today, Barack Obama would lose to John McCain, while Mr. McCain would lose to Mrs. Clinton.

title: Security Council Members Push to Condemn Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS  The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court presented a grim portrait of conditions in the Darfur region of Sudan to the Security Council on Thursday, as a majority of Council members pushed for what would be the first statement in three years condemning the Sudanese government.

title: For Young Penguins, Loss Hurts, but Theres Hope
description: PITTSBURGH  When Sidney Crosbys first shot at a Stanley Cup championship fell short by the smallest of margins Wednesday night, he looked every bit like a 20-year-old who had just had his dream snatched away. He sat at his locker in full uniform, his eyes red, his voice wavering. Finally, he got up and walked away, passing his hero and landlord  the Penguins owner, Mario Lemieux  and headed down a hallway without a word.

title: Portraits of Divas
description: Francesco Clementes exhibition of eight portraits called The Sopranos opened at Gallery Met at Lincoln Center on Thursday. Created in collaboration with the Metropolitan Opera, the exhibition features portraits of eight divas who are to figure prominently in the Mets 2008-9 season. The oil-on-linen portraits, on display until Sept. 26, depict in their coming roles Diana Damrau, Natalie Dessay, Rene Fleming, Angela Gheorghiu, Susan Graham, Karita Mattila, Anna Netrebko and Deborah Voigt, above as the title character of La Gioconda. Mr. Clemente began his association with the Met earlier this year when he created the front-of-house banner for the Philip Glass opera Satyagraha, in April.

title: A Live Promotion, at 14,000 Feet
description: THIS is live, at 14,000 feet, over Spain, a man shouted over the roar of the wind as he and a group of fellow skydivers plunged toward the earth near Madrid.

title: You Mean Outerbridge Isnt Far Away?
description: The Robert F. Kennedy Bridge needs no explanation, but people honored by some other local bridges might need introductions:

title: Rooms With a Viewfinder
description: WHEN Catherine Chalmers was preparing to film her video Safari, which documents the journey of a cockroach through a mini-tropical landscape, she turned to animal breeders to buy her exotic cast of creatures, which included a poison dart frog and a pygmy chameleon. Even the cockroach came from a lab. But there was something missing, she felt  she wanted more bright color.

title: Mahlers Haunting Ruminations at the Abyss
description: Many Mahler devotees demand the ultimate in intensity and transcendence from performances of that composers symphonies. Lorin Maazel would not be the conductor of choice for those who feel this way. Mr. Maazel conducts Mahler with cool expressivity, exacting execution and musical integrity, a refreshing break from Mahler performances that strive to express the inexpressible.

title: To Save a Life: Mosquito Nets, and More
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: JESS

title: Leaders of 4 F Schools Are Now Up for Bonuses
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released stark new report cards last fall, grading all schools on a scale of A through F, the Acorn High School for Social Justice, in Brooklyn, was branded with an F. Later on, its principal, Joseph Parker, resigned under pressure.

title: Europe Warns Germany About Shielding VW
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission threatened on Thursday to take Germany to court for failing to revoke a law shielding Volkswagen from a hostile takeover in the latest round in a furious legal battle over the future ownership of the car giant.

title: Watch Out, Hes Packing a Blow-Dryer
description: Let me be blunt: You Dont Mess With the Zohan is the finest post-Zionist action-hairdressing sex comedy I have ever seen. That it is the only one I have ever seen  and why is that? what cultural deficiency or ideological conspiracy has prevented this genre from flourishing?  does not much detract from my judgment.

title: Clinton May Come Home to Find a Little Fence-Mending Is Needed
description: Do not get Antoine Njeim or Jaye Griffith started about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: More People Undergoing Colonoscopy in New York
description: The number of New York City residents 50 and older who have undergone a colonoscopy has risen by about 50 percent in five years, city officials announced on Thursday.

title: Giving Voice to Poetry in a Concert of Choral Works
description: In its heyday the American Composers Alliance fostered several important institutions, most notably CRI (Composers Recordings Inc.), a label that specialized in new American music, and the American Composers Orchestra. But that was midway through the last century. These days the alliance works mostly behind the scenes, publishing, archiving and advocating for American music. In a way it has been hobbled by its success: American music just isnt as hard to sell now as it was in 1937, when Aaron Copland helped found the organization. Some of it is downright popular.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Clinton Says Running Mate Choice Is Obamas
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday disavowed a campaign by some of her supporters to press Senator Barack Obama into selecting her as the Democratic partys vice presidential candidate. Mrs. Clinton said the supporters were acting on their own, and that the choice of a running mate was Senator Obamas, and his alone.

title: How About Slaughterhouse Tour Before Supper, Food Lover?
description: For New Yorkers, Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the bucolic counterpart to Washington Square Parks Blue Hill restaurant, is a locavores idyll. About 30 miles from the city, the restaurant, on the grounds of the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture near Tarrytown, is set among green pastures dotted with the chickens, turkeys and pigs that will eventually show up on the menu for both Blue Hill restaurants.

title: Former Chief of Broadcom Is Indicted
description: Henry T. Nicholas III, the flamboyant co-founder and former chief executive of the chip maker Broadcom, was indicted Thursday in California on fraud, conspiracy and drug charges, including allegations that he spiked the drinks of other executives with ecstasy.

title: Jets Elam Perseveres With Faith in the Face of Tragedy
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Abram Elam leaned forward, covered his face with his hands and clenched his body to stop the shaking. He wiped the tears running down both cheeks with tissues. Through the silence came the occasional muffled sob.

title: Scratching and Clawing Their Way to the Middle
description: The Promotion tells you everything you might want to know but were too uninterested to ask about working as an assistant manager in a supermarket. As this sweet, ineffectual comedy follows two sad sacks competing for the job of manager at a new branch of a Chicago grocery chain, it pointedly avoids the raucous bad-boy clowning of the typical Everyguy farce. Think of it as a polite, tightly muzzled Clerks.

title: Soft Shoe With Stamina and a Smile for the Ladies
description: They were there  fewer than in recent years because his television talk show was canceled  but the ladies with their digital cameras still turned out on Wednesday evening for Tony Danzas new act, I Could Have Danced All Night, at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. As cameras flashed, the trim, grinning 57-year-old star with short salt-and-pepper hair struck poses and radiated cocky charm.

title: Germany Abuzz at Racy Novel of Sex and Hygiene
description: TEGERNHEIM, Germany  Not many literary readings are restricted to an over-18 audience. Fewer still take place under circus tents. Yet nothing could be more appropriate for the scandalous German best-seller Wetlands, by a television personality and author, Charlotte Roche.

title: Big Brown vs. Curlin? A Track May Offer $5 Million
description: If Big Brown wins the Triple Crown and he and the 2007 Breeders Cup Classic winner, Curlin, remain unbeaten in 2008, Suffolk Downs in East Boston will offer a $5 million purse for them to face each other in this years Massachusetts Handicap.

title: Stravinsky on His Mind; Barbra Streisand and the Sex Pistols, Too
description: What is it about choreographers and Stravinsky? Like moths to a flame they keep coming, along with the inevitable immolations.

title: Continental Cuts Jobs and Grounds Jets
description: Continental Airlines said Thursday that it would cut 3,000 jobs and retire 67 Boeing aircraft, becoming the latest airline to announce capacity reductions in the face of high prices for jet fuel.

title: Corrections
description: Front Page

title: Verizon Agrees to Buy Alltel for $28.1 Billion
description: Verizon Communications agreed on Thursday to buy Alltel for about $28.1 billion, including the assumption of debt, creating the nations largest cellular telephone provider.

title: In Upper Manhattan, Cheers for the No. 2 Pick
description: Pedro Alvarez sat on the couch between his parents in their cramped Upper Manhattan apartment Thursday afternoon. Twenty-eight people had packed themselves into the sweltering living room to watch Major League Baseballs amateur draft. With the television volume turned all the way up, no one paid any attention when Alvarez answered his cellphone.

title: A Sects Families Reunite, and Start to Come Home
description: ELDORADO, Tex.  The cows still get milked each day by machine here at the Yearning for Zion ranch, although the raw-milk cheese is stacking up uneaten. The onions in the garden are as big as grapefruits, ready for harvest, with few people to pick them.

title: No Bed of Roses for a Sudden First Lady
description: ASKED to identify which items in the generic East Side office designated for the spouse of the governor of New York actually radiate her personal decorative karma, Michelle Paige Paterson, 47, takes a cursory assessment. She then shrugs her slim shoulders in a silent yet succinct expression of negativity.

title: The Clues and Conspiracies of an Assassination
description: Heads talk and reason walks in the documentary RFK Must Die: The Assassination of Bobby Kennedy, a conspiracy-addled trudge through the Ambassador Hotels most fateful event.

title: The Truth About the War
description: It took just a few months after the United States invasion of Iraq for the world to find out that Saddam Hussein had long abandoned his nuclear, biological and chemical weapons programs. He was not training terrorists or colluding with Al Qaeda. The only real threat he posed was to his own countrymen.

title: Fresh Produce for Ratatouille, Please, but No Attitude
description: The rolling countryside of Provence may be a dream vacation spot, but it is the last place in the world that Antoine (Nicolas Cazal), the sullen 30-year-old protagonist of The Grocers Son, would like to be. In this French variation of the fable of the prodigal son, Antoine reluctantly returns to his rural hometown after 10 years in the big city when his father (Daniel Duval) has a heart attack.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about free cellphone information services, gave an incorrect phone number for the reQall service, which allows users to dictate reminders to themselves. It is 888-9REQALL.

title: Zagat Family Says Company Is No Longer for Sale
description: Zagat Survey, publisher of the popular user-generated reviews of restaurants, hotels and other leisure businesses, has ended its effort to sell itself, the company said Thursday.

title: With Yelp, Ivanovic Is in French Final
description: PARIS  As the service breaks and momentum shifts piled up late in the third set Thursday, it was exceedingly difficult to know which Serbian tennis player was going to end up No. 1 on the day and No. 1 in the world.

title: Fierce Swing, Deep Grooves and Even a Little Singing
description: Growing up in a jazz family in New Orleans, the trumpeter Nicholas Payton absorbed a host of lessons about melody, rhythm and the implicit arrangement between an artist and his audience. And over the last decade or so he has weighed those lessons against the modernist imperative of open-ended abstraction. Now, in his mid-30s, Mr. Payton still seems to be seeking an arable middle ground, the zone where post-bop evasiveness mingles with soulful reassurance.

title: Tranghese, Commissioner of Big East, to Step Down in 2009
description: Mike Tranghese, the commissioner of the Big East, who has been with the league from its inception through its revival, announced Thursday that he would step down in June 2009.

title: Lessons of the Road, With Phone
description: The long and winding road traveled by Mercer White (Lou Taylor Pucci), the ingenuous 19-year-old protagonist of Martin Hyness wispy but appealing film The Go-Getter, leads from Eugene, Ore., to Reno, Nev.; Mojave, Calif.; Los Angeles; Ensenada, Mexico; and back, with many stops along the way. Mercers vehicle is a well-traveled Volvo station wagon he impulsively steals at a car wash and drives off into the unknown.

title: Its So Much Nicer on K Street
description: The more the presidential candidates promise to rein in the rich Washington culture of influence-peddling, the more voters need a reality check.

title: Norway: A Crime-Fighting Duo
description: The Norwegian Supreme Court ruled that assaulting a police dog was equivalent to assaulting an officer. The suspect in an attempted burglary last year in the city of Bergen is accused of hitting and kicking Vera, a Belgian Shepherd police dog, after she chased him down, will now face a charge of assaulting a civil servant. Two lower courts had dismissed the assault charge, which carries a maximum penalty of three years in prison, but a panel of Supreme Court judges ruled that a police officer and dog are to be treated as a single unit.

title: Whats Really in the Well?
description: YOUVE found the perfect summer cottage in the country. You can bicycle into town. There are a couple of good restaurants. The shops are cute, and your friends are eager to visit. The house passed the usual presale inspection, the closing was a snap, and now youre moving in and reaching for the kitchen tap to get a glass of water.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Remembering Too Well Back When Rock Mattered
description: Picture Michael Douglas in the film Wonder Boys, unkempt and used up, though once brilliant and vital. Then imagine (or remember) Goldie Hawn 40 years ago, in her young and kooky mode, possibly kooky to the point of danger.

title: The Views Are the Selling Point
description: PEOPLE from away have been summering in north coastal Maine for generations. And in parts of Hancock County, there is ample evidence of the grandeur and wealth that characterized many of earliest summer populations. But a large part of Hancock County and bordering Washington County remains affordable.

title: China Reports Declines in 3 Major Pollutants, Reversing Trend
description: HONG KONG  After rising steeply for many years, emissions of three important pollutants began to decline last year, Chinas Ministry of Environmental Protection announced Thursday as part of an annual report.

title: Germany: Russian President Visits
description: On his first official visit to Germany, President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia cited the same issues for which his predecessor, Vladimir V. Putin, had repeatedly taken Europe and the United States to task. I wont hide the fact that we are concerned by the tendency toward a narrowing of our mutual understanding within Euro-Atlantic politics, Mr. Medvedev said after meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel. Addressing a German-Russian economic forum, he reiterated his criticism of NATOs plan to offer eventual membership to Ukraine and Georgia.

title: A Sons Initiation in the Fraternity of the Lawn
description: THE 6.5-horsepower lawn mower roared to life on the first pull, just as I knew it would. I was late opening up my Charlestown, R.I., beach house after the winter, and the grass  crab grass, weeds and dandelions actually  was out of control. Out of habit, I thought to thank my dad for his help, forgetting for a moment that he was gone. The first summer after I bought the cottage, Id begged the misnamed Toro GTS (Guaranteed to Start) engine to turn over before phoning the expert.

title: A Gulf Retreat for the Upscale but Unfussy
description: WHEN Mike Ford was in college, he became acquainted with the Florida Panhandles coast on spring-break jaunts that lured him to its developed, party-hearty beach towns like Panama City and Fort Walton Beach. So when his future wife introduced him to the small and far-removed Grayton Beach, a low-key spit of sand that offers nothing but houses and beach, where she had spent summers all her life, he didnt quite know what to make of it.

title: Obama Moves to Next Phase as Clinton Douses Talk of Ticket
description: BRISTOL, Va.  Senator Barack Obama moved forcefully into the general election on Thursday, placing his stamp on the Democratic Party apparatus and holding a private nighttime meeting with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in an effort to unify Democrats.

title: Turkeys High Court Overturns Headscarf Rule
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys highest court dealt a stinging slap to the governing party of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Thursday, ruling that a legal change allowing women attending universities to wear head scarves was unconstitutional.

title: Bits, Bands and Books
description: Do you remember what it was like back in the old days when we had a New Economy? In the 1990s, jobs were abundant, oil was cheap and information technology was about to change everything.

title: The Mets Choose Power With Top 2 Draft Picks
description: SAN DIEGO  The upper levels of the Mets farm system, depleted by their trade for Johan Santana and recent free-agent signings that forfeited draft picks, received a major boost during Thursdays amateur draft when they used their two first-round picks on power-hitting college infielders.

title: Combating Illegal Guns
description: Mayor Michael Bloombergs campaign against illegal guns won a notable victory this week when a Georgia gun dealer decided to default rather than go to trial in a civil lawsuit that accused him of illegally selling handguns that were later used to commit crimes in New York.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: U.S. Not Seeking Permanent Iraq Bases, Ambassador Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to Iraq dismissed any suggestion on Thursday that the Bush administration was maneuvering to set up permanent military bases in Iraq.

title: Retailers Post Surprising Sales
description: Retailers fears that their customers would keep their pocketbooks shut proved to be unfounded last month.

title: Bosses May Have Hastened Chiefs Departure at HarperCollins
description: One day after Jane Friedman, the charismatic chief executive of HarperCollins Publishers Worldwide, stunned colleagues and the publishing industry with her abrupt exit, it appeared that she had been nudged out from the top spot at the News Corporation books unit that she had ruled for more than a decade.

title: Arraigned, 9/11 Defendants Talk of Martyrdom
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  When at last he got the chance to speak, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed planner of the Sept. 11 attacks, on Thursday called President Bush a crusader and ridiculed the trial system here as an inquisition.

title: Ellsworth Kelly, Basking in Basel
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Unlike most dealers at the Art Basel fair, who are showing a smorgasbord of the artists they represent, the New York dealer Matthew Marks has mounted an exhibition honoring one artist, Ellsworth Kelly, who turned 85 last month.

title: Museums and Antiquities
description: To the Editor:

title: Pierces Return Fuels Celtics and a Rivalry
description: BOSTON  A brilliant rivalry was renewed Thursday night, with all the attendant tension, drama, ill will and ear-splitting volume.

title: Zimbabwe Tells All Aid Groups to Halt Efforts
description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwes government has ordered all humanitarian aid groups to suspend their operations in the deeply impoverished nation, a prohibition that relief agencies estimate will deprive two million people of food aid and other basic assistance.

title: Sales Double for Game Maker
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A bid by Electronic Arts to take over Take-Two Interactive is facing mounting challenges, including possible concerns of federal antitrust regulators and strong game sales that have raised Take-Two shares above the asking price.

title: After 84 Years, WNYC Cuts a Cord With the City as It Moves
description: Hell miss his view, Brian Lehrer said, and who can blame him? From his 24th-floor office in the Municipal Building, where he has presided for nearly two decades over a talk show on radio station WNYC, he looks north and west across a cityscape that never fails to make the heart skip a beat.

title: Matthew J. Bruccoli, 76, Scholar, Dies; Academias Fitzgerald Record Keeper
description: Matthew J. Bruccoli, whose biography of F. Scott Fitzgerald and outpouring of scholarly essays and critical editions made him the dean of Fitzgerald studies in the United States, died at his home in Columbia, S.C., on Wednesday. He was 76.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 5, 2008

title: Resurrecting an Artists Greatest Creation: Herself
description: Louise Nevelson hasnt let death go to her head. As reincarnated with disarming casualness and unimpeachable conviction by Mercedes Ruehl in Edward Albees Occupant, this imposingly flamboyant, Russian-born New York sculptor returns to the land of the living without a wisp of the oracular mysticism you might expect from someone who has spent two decades on the Other Side.

title: In Juneau, Firm Resistance to a Road Out of Isolation
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  The proposed 51-mile Juneau Access Road would provide something this remote capital city has never had: an overland route to the rest of North America. No longer would people have to take a ferry or a flight.

title: British Writer Wins Fiction Prize
description: The Orange Broadband Prize for Fiction has been awarded to the British author Rose Tremain for her 10th novel, The Road Home. The prize, awarded annually for the best novel written by a woman in English and published in Britain in the previous year, was presented at a ceremony Wednesday night in London. Ms. Tremain, who writes novels, short stories and screenplays, received 30,000, or nearly $59,000, for the novel, which tells the story of Lev, a shy Eastern European widower who comes to Britain in search of work and experiences the dissonance of the immigrant diaspora. Recent Orange Prize winners include Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie for Half of a Yellow Sun in 2007 and Zadie Smith for On Beauty in 2006.

title: Surge in Shipping Benefits a Tiny Exchange
description: LONDON  The prices of wheat, soybeans and iron ore have surged in the last two years, but that is nothing next to the surging cost of shipping goods like these.

title: The Ailey Company Exults in the Sheer Thrill of Putting on a Show
description: Watching the second program of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters weeklong run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music amplified just how good these dancers are at the theatrical presentation of their material.

title: A Doctor Finds Miracles in Medicine
description: The celebrated writer-physician Sherwin B. Nuland  a clinical professor of surgery at Yale, the author of nine previous books, the winner of the National Book Award  is a believer in miracles. Not the parting-of-the-Red-Sea kind of miracles that suspend physical laws, but phenomena and events that cant be explained by current scientific knowledge, and perhaps never will be.

title: Another Cant-Miss Prospect May Help Yankees Bullpen
description: NORWICH, Conn.  The ballpark here sits at the end of a winding industrial road, surrounded by trees, with no sense of place. It rained all day Wednesday, and most of the 1,353 paying fans stayed home. Kids were disappointed if they left with only one foul ball.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Dickens Desk and Chair Sold
description: The mahogany desk and walnut chair, left, at which Charles Dickens wrote a number of his novels and short stories, including Great Expectations, was sold on Wednesday for 433,250, about $848,000, at an auction at Christies in London. The desk and chair were recent gifts to Great Ormond Street Childrens Hospital from Jeanne-Marie Dickens (the widow of the writers great-great grandson Christopher) and were sold to raise money for the hospital. Charles Dickens was a close friend of the hospitals founder and spoke at its first fund-raising dinner, in 1858. The buyer was a private Irish collector.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on May 26 about police corruption and Mexicos war on drugs misidentified the academic affiliation of Bruce Bagley, a professor of international studies who is an expert on Latin American narcotics trafficking. He teaches at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla.  not Miami University in Oxford, Ohio.

title: U.N. Food Meeting Ends With a Call for Urgent Action
description: ROME  A three-day United Nations conference on spiraling food costs concluded late on Thursday with the delegates calling on countries and financial institutions to provide more food for the worlds poor and increase agriculture production to ensure adequate supplies in the future.

title: Parents Find Frustration With Process at Schools
description: Kate Yourke does not have the heart to tell her daughter Coral she was rejected from the prekindergarten program at Public School 132 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where her sister goes, even though siblings were supposed to get priority.

title: Doubts About Clean Coal
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: South Carolina to Offer Cross on Car Plates
description: South Carolina drivers will be the first in the nation to be offered license plates that carry the phrase I Believe and a Christian cross over a stained-glass window under a law that took effect on Thursday.

title: When Sons Die, Hard-Hat Pride Becomes Grief
description: They worked hard for decades, scaling miles of scaffolding or sitting long hours behind the levers of a high crane. It was hard and dangerous work, but when their sons were old enough to follow in their footsteps, the fathers watched with pride. When the fathers retired, the sons were their link to the job, their dinner conversations threaded with stories of projects in the works and newer, bigger machines.

title: Songs of Africa
description: You dont have to be a fan of African tunes to appreciate On the Rumba River, Jacques Sarasins heartfelt ode to Congolese music and its resilient practitioners.

title: British Judge Sets Hearing on Evidence for Detainee
description: LONDON  A British judge has ordered a hearing into whether the British government must turn over evidence bearing on accusations by a prisoner at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, that he was tortured during interrogation in Morocco.

title: Adviser Says McCain Backs Bush Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON  A top adviser to Senator John McCain says Mr. McCain believes that President Bushs program of wiretapping without warrants was lawful, a position that appears to bring him into closer alignment with the sweeping theories of executive authority pushed by the Bush administration legal team.

title: Prosecutor Details Rape That Lasted 19 Hours
description: The time crept by so slowly and painfully that the 23-year-old Columbia University journalism student had decided it was time to end her life.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,083 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: $42 Billion French Bid for TeliaSonera
description: BERLIN  France Telecom on Thursday offered $42 billion in cash and stock for TeliaSonera, the Swedish-Finnish phone company with holdings across the former Soviet Union, in the latest bid by a European operator to enter faster-growing emerging markets.

title: Bush in the Background
description: WASHINGTON  Scenes from the quiet life of George W. Bush, master of ceremonies and president of the United States:

title: Los Angeles Sues Time Warner Cable
description: In the two years since becoming the major cable provider in the Los Angeles area, Time Warner Cable has drawn sometimes colorful criticism from its subscribers.

title: Footnotes
description: The actor Kelsey Grammer is resting comfortably at his home in Hawaii, four days after being hospitalized because of a mild heart attack, The Associated Press reported. A publicist for Mr. Grammer, who starred in Cheers and Frasier, said that he sent thanks to those who called and wrote expressing concern. ... Ozzy Osbourne has won libel damages from the Daily Star, the British newspaper, over allegations that he suffered a health scare which jeopardized this years Brit Awards, according to reports from BBC News and The Associated Press. Mr. Osborne, 59, the rock singer and former frontman for Black Sabbath, has indicated that he would donate the damages, the amount of which was undisclosed, to the colon cancer charity set up by his wife, Sharon Osbourne.

title: Yanks First Draft Pick Is a Pitcher
description: The struggles of the Yankees young pitching prospects this season have been well documented. Ian Kennedy and Phil Hughes have yet live up to their potential, and Joba Chamberlains conversion to the rotation is a work in progress. Only Darrell Rasner has provided any consistency this year.

title: Cool, Hot and Finnish, With a Dose of Mythic Imagination
description: Its title notwithstanding, nothing in Arctic Hysteria: New Art From Finland betrays pathological overexcitement. On the surface, at least, all the works in this 16-artist show at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center are coolly controlled. Nevertheless, something hot runs through them: urgent emotions and irrational fantasies. Whether or not this cool-hot dichotomy reflects a split between the flinty and the mystical in the Finnish sensibility, it makes for a transporting show. The most striking instances of emotional tension are in film and video works. title: Raise a Glass to the Ex-Bar Owners Memory

Four months after saying goodbye to the rickety refuge on the Hudson that he helped to define, theyll say goodbye to John Guinan today and Saturday, and in the process say goodbye to a bit of the rivers soul as well. From 1959 to the beginning of this year, Guinans  between the Garrison railroad station and the east bank of the Hudson  was a combination deli, general store and pub with a tiny barroom with green walls and an alarmingly sloping floor that had Irish Music Nights the first Thursday after each full moon. Run first by his father, Jim, it evolved over time into one of those rare places that transcends its own myth  a time capsule, a home away from home, a place to hide out, and in the richest way a community.

title: Respond to Todays Column: What Hillary Won

title: California: A New Hearing in V.A. Case
description: A federal judge presiding over a lawsuit alleging mistreatment of veterans has ordered a hearing regarding new evidence in the case. The judge, Samuel Conti of Federal District Court in San Francisco, ordered the hearing, scheduled for Tuesday, after the emergence of an internal e-mail message that appears to urge Veterans Affairs clinicians to avoid making a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder to save money. The message was written by a V.A. psychologist in Texas, but it did not surface until after the trial concluded in April, prompting the plaintiffs to request that the case be reopened. Its part of a systemic pattern where theres a divergence between the pristine world of the V.A.s central office and what goes on around the country, said Gordon Erspamer, a lawyer for the plaintiffs. On Wednesday, a lawyer with the Justice Department wrote to Judge Conti contending that the e-mail message in question did not represent V.A.-wide practice or policy. Also on Wednesday, Norma Perez, the psychologist who wrote the message, told members of Congress that it was poorly worded and was meant only to suggest diagnostic options for doctors. The lawsuit was filed last year by veterans groups.

title: Smiles All Around at Wal-Marts Annual Meeting

title: Audit Faults an Education Nonprofit
description: A federal audit of Teach for America, a nonprofit that recruits college graduates to teach in low-income schools, has found that the organization did not properly account for $775,000 in government money it says it spent for summer training sessions and related purposes.

title: Microsoft Is Closing a Classified Ad Site
description: Microsoft is closing Windows Live Expo, the classified advertising Web site that was initially seen as a potential competitor to Craigslist, the San Francisco-based online classified service. The service, started in February 2006, will close on July 31, a post on the site said Friday. Live Expo was one of a series of services Microsoft started to beef up its online presence.

title: CBS Swings on Thursday

The new series, set among suburban libertines in the 1970s, has drawn scrutiny for its depictions of sex and drug use. Among adults 18 to 49, it was far from the nights highest-rated show, but Swingtown did improve on CBSs performance in that demographic earlier in the night. In the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, the network broadcast two repeats of CSI, which, despite low ratings among the 18-to-49 set, fared well in total viewers, with 8.2 million and 9.4 million respectively. CBS ranked third for the night over all, just behind Fox and its two-hour installment of So You Think You Can Dance from 8 to 10 (9.1 million). ABC led over all with live coverage of the first game of the N.B.A. finals, which averaged approximately 10 million viewers from 9 to 11.

That number does not, however, include the legally blind population, which the American Foundation for the Blind puts at 1.3 million.

description: The rise in oil prices turned into a stampede on Friday with futures jumping a staggering $11 a barrel to set a record above $138 a barrel. The unprecedented surge came as the dollar fell sharply against the euro and a senior Israeli politician once again raised the possibility of an attack against Iran.

title: For Movement Research, a Time to Cast a Wide Net Over Disciplines and Countries
description: Its that time of year when Europe is flooded with festivals that dwell on more than new choreography and try, through theoretical discussion, to relate dance to larger issues about the body and the art forms place in the world. The spring festival of Movement Research is a scrappier version of that model; organized by artists, it gives those in the New York dance world a chance to stop complaining about the lack of discourse and do something about it.

title: Where Hollywoods Stars Are Interred, but Live Forever on Screen
description: LOS ANGELES  A few hundred people poured through the gates of Hollywood Forever Cemetery last Saturday, carrying picnics, blankets and folding chairs. They moved along a path toward the sound of a Jimi Hendrix song coming from the foot of a high marble mausoleum.

title: Remembering a Master Drummer as Bandleader
description: When Max Roach died last August at 83, he was remembered for a number of things: his stature as a patriarch of bebop; his role in quickening the pulse of jazz drumming; his intelligent ambitions as a conceptualist and composer; his commitment to social justice and equality. What was sometimes buried in the mix was Mr. Roachs track record as a bandleader, which began in earnest in the 1950s.

title: Pelfrey Throws More Pitches, Learning More
description: SAN DIEGO  Manager Willie Randolph had about 97 reasons he could have pulled Mike Pelfrey after five innings in the Mets 2-1 loss to the San Diego Padres on Thursday night, reasons he could have brought in the already warmed-up Claudio Vargas to pitch the sixth. But, Randolph said, You learn a lot from going out there and grinding it out and going through some ups and downs and adversity.

title: Moving Money, Not Telegrams, Across Borders
description: MENTION the name Western Union and most people probably think of one thing: telegrams. But the company sent its last dispatch in 2006.

title: While Rasner Goes Deep, Yankees Dont
description: The Yankees have gotten the fewest innings from their starting pitchers in the American League. It has placed a burden on their bullpen and eventually could threaten the teams streak of 13 consecutive playoff appearances.

title: Zimbabwe Blocks Oppositions Rallies and Again Detains Its Leader
description: JOHANNESBURG  With only three weeks to go before Zimbabwes presidential runoff, the police briefly detained the oppositions standard-bearer, Morgan Tsvangirai, on Friday for the second time this week and directed his party to cancel political rallies, effectively preventing him from addressing voters.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Metro

title: Belmont Is Goal for Ailing Casino Drive
description: Casino Drive, considered the main threat to Big Browns Triple Crown bid, has sustained an injury to his left hind foot, but a spokesman for the owner Hidetoshi Yamamoto said late Friday afternoon that the colt was expected to start in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: Mistakes Mar Close Game as Mets Slip Back to .500
description: SAN DIEGO  Baseball purists would have delighted in the first five innings of the Mets game Friday night, which featured a total of five hits and zero runs, the product of an entrancing pitchers duel between Johan Santana and the Padres Randy Wolf. They might have walked out of Petco Park altogether after watching the sixth, which included Santanas failure to field a bunt and put one down, and a Padres being hit by a batted ball for the second consecutive night.

title: Putting Talent First, Yanks Will Deal With Boras Later
description: For much of baseball, an important factor in the draft is a players willingness to sign. Of course, the Yankees do not operate like most of their peers, generally ignoring the bonus recommendations of the commissioners office.

title: Virgin America Protests Rivals Bid to Protect Slots
description: Virgin America opposes an effort by six rivals to protect takeoff and landing slots they may not use in New York, Chicago and Washington this winter because of high fuel costs. The request by AMRs American Airlines, UALs United Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines, the US Airways Group and AirTran Holdings is anticonsumer, Virgin Americas lawyer told regulators in Washington. Under federal law, carriers must use slots at restricted airports or risk giving them up to rivals. The six want to waive the requirement so they can trim flights without later losing the access.

title: Raising the Bar at the Pentagon
description: Its not often in American politics or government that officials are held accountable these days, so Defense Secretary Robert Gatess decision to fire the top two Air Force leaders on Thursday was as surprising as it was commendable.

title: Tournament Opens With No Shortage of Favorites
description: The 13th European soccer championship begins Saturday and will last 23 days, with games in Austria and Switzerland. The quadrennial 16-team tournament, played in even-number years between World Cups, has emerged as one of the most popular sporting events among TV viewers around the world.

title: Afghan Tribal Leader Killed
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  A powerful tribal leader was gunned down outside his home in the southern city of Kandahar by suspected Taliban Friday morning, Afghan officials said. Muhammad Akbar Khakrezwal, a former commander and supporter of the government, was shot by two men on a motorbike, a preferred tactic by Taliban gunmen. He died before he reached the hospital.

title: Hollywood Is Burning
description: Los Angeles

title: The Cons of Creationism
description: When it comes to science, creationists tend to struggle with reality. They believe, after all, that evolution by means of natural selection is false and that Earth is only a few thousand years old. They also believe that students who are taught a creationist view of biology  or who are taught to disregard the Darwinist view  are not being disadvantaged.

title: Candidates Forgo Soft Money, but Conventions Rake It In
description: One of Senator Barack Obamas first acts after claiming the Democratic nomination was declaring he would not take special-interest money for his presidential bid, even going so far as to bar lobbyists from donating to the Democratic National Committee.

title: Fingers Pointed as Climate Bill Dies for the Year
description: WASHINGTON  Before the anticlimactic demise on Friday of legislation to combat global warming, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, called climate change the most important issue facing the world today. Senator George Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, a critic of the bill, nonetheless called it the most significant piece of legislation to ever come out of the Environment and Public Works Committee.

title: Myanmar Junta Begins Evicting Cyclone Victims From Shelters
description: LABUTTA, Myanmar  Within a week of the storm that flooded the delta here last month with waves as high as 20 feet, the monasteries in this village were swarming with 14,000 people who had lost their families, homes and livelihoods.

title: Nadal Rolls On to French Open Final and Federer
description: PARIS  The manner and methods were certainly different as Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer secured their latest rendezvous in the French Open final.

title: After Verbal Fire, Senate Effectively Kills Climate Change Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Before the anticlimactic demise on Friday of legislation to combat global warming, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, called climate change the most important issue facing the world today. Senator George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, a critic of the bill, nonetheless called it the most significant piece of legislation to ever come out of the Environment and Public Works Committee.

title: Panel Upholds Sprinters Suspension
description: The sprinter Justin Gatlins appeal of his four-year drug suspension was rejected by the Court of Arbitration for Sport on Friday, ensuring that he will not be able to defend his Olympic gold medal in the 100 meters at the Beijing Games this summer.

title: A U.S. Olympic Marathoner and Her Coach
description: Four years ago, Blake Russells stunning tumble from first place to fourth at the Olympic womens marathon trials provoked whispers of pity from the running community and tears from Russell and her coach, Bob Sevene.

title: Rape Victim Recounts 19 Hours of Terror
description: She entered the courtroom on Friday afternoon wearing a tan dress, red flats and thick-framed glasses. She was petite  about five feet tall and weighing 130 pounds  with brown hair hanging halfway down her neck.

title: Two Teenagers and Their Murderous Spree, Evoked in Gesture and Movement
description: The brutal murders committed in Nebraska in 1958 by the 19-year old Charles Starkweather and his 14-year-old girlfriend, Caril Ann Fugate, have inspired a number of books, songs and films, including Badlands and Natural Born Killers. Now there is a dance-theater piece, too: Brendan McCalls Stark Weather, which opened Thursday night at Danspace Project.

title: Fall Wave in Brooklyn
description: The 26th Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will open on Sept. 30 with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, as part of a season packed with dance, the academy announced. The troupe, above in rehearsal with Mr. Jones, will perform the New York premiere of A Quarreling Pair, based on a puppet play by Jane Bowles. Other dance presentations include La La La Human Steps, from Montreal; the French nouveau cirque group Compagnie 111; and return engagements from two Brooklyn Academy regulars, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and Pina Bausch. The Vesturport Theater of Iceland will offer a new production of Georg Bchners Woyzeck with music by Nick Cave and Warren Ellis, and Ivo van Hove brings his Toneelgroep Amsterdam for a stage adaptation of John Cassavetess 1977 film Opening Night. Music bookings include Red Hot + Rio 2, a two-night Brazilian concert with Bebel Gilberto, Jos Gonzlez, Cu and others; the avant-garde string quartet Ethel; Arjunas Dilemma, a chamber opera based on the Bhagavad-Gita by the New York composer Douglas J. Cuomo; and a multimedia interpretation of Emily Dickinsons poems by the Bang on a Can composer Michael Gordon, with the Ridge Theater and the filmmaker Bill Morrison. Information and tickets: (718) 636-4100, bam.org.

title: Virgin Wears a Mustache (Its Spring)
description: The Scottish choreographer Michael Clark continued his Stravinsky Project odyssey on Thursday evening at the Rose Theater with productions of Le Sacre du Printemps and Les Noces, both American premieres.

title: Conditions on U.S. Aid in Drug Fight Anger Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Few slights irk Mexican politicians so much as when Washington treats Mexico like a backward country in need of outside guidance, and that anger raged full throttle this week as top Mexican officials threatened to walk away from a major United States aid package to help defeat drug traffickers.

title: Where Housing Prices Go, Views of the President Follow
description: HOME prices in the United States are plunging, and the presidents economic policies are unpopular.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Inside Art column on Friday about art in the piazza outside the Art Basel fair in Switzerland referred incorrectly to an artist who has a work on view there. The artist, Roxy Paine, is a man.

title: Martial Art of Chess, Promoted by a Rapper
description: The rapper RZA, a founder of the Wu-Tang Clan, sat in a suite on the 48th floor of the Mandarin Oriental hotel overlooking Central Park, staring at a chess game through a pair of sunglasses. His hand was frozen a few inches above the board as he looked for a strategy to thwart his opponent.

title: Billboards and Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Problem With Being Preordained
description: It seemed that the gods were finally smiling on the Chicago Cubs. After coming from Florida with a 3-games-to-2 lead in the best-of-seven National League Championship Series, the odds were in our favor. Not only were we returning home to play the final two games of the series in front of the Wrigley Field faithful, but we had our two top guns pitching for us. Mark Prior and Kerry Wood had been dominant for the last three months of the season, and they were primed for these two final tests. More importantly, all we needed to do was win one of these games to propel us into the World Series.

title: Life at the Starting Gate at Belmont Park
description: Belmont Park will be packed on Saturday as Big Brown, who has won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, tries to win the Belmont Stakes to become the first Triple Crown winner in 30 years. Thousands of spectators will try to get as close as they can to the finish line. But what happens at the beginning of the race might be just as important, and that is where the workers at the starting gate come into play.

title: Roadside Oddities
description: EVER since Model Ts first roamed the earth, attention-grabbing roadside curiosities  giant concrete dinosaurs, house-size artichokes and the like  have been luring drivers off the asphalt to enrich community coffers, Mike Stevens notes in Endless Vacation.

title: In Turnabout, Antitrust Unit Looks at Intel
description: WASHINGTON  A global legal battle between the two largest makers of computer processors took an abrupt turn this week when the Federal Trade Commission opened a formal antitrust investigation of the Intel Corporation.

title: Two Rivals Sneak Away to Meet, and the Hunt Is On
description: WASHINGTON  For 17 months, they tracked one anothers movements like prey.

title: One Less Obstacle in Big Browns Path
description: When the 140th edition of Belmont Stakes is run Saturday afternoon, the favorite Big Brown will have one less obstacle between him and the Triple Crown. His main rival, Casino Drive, was scratched Saturday morning because of a stone bruise to his left hind hoof.

title: California Teachers Challenge Proposed Cuts
description: LOS ANGELES  Tens of thousands of teachers formed picket lines outside nearly 900 schools here Friday morning to protest cuts to education financing proposed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to help close Californias projected $17 billion budget gap.

title: The People Who Aspire to Great Heights, Literally, Hand Over Hand
description: The urge to climb came early to Timmy ONeill, when there was nothing around him but concrete and steel. To the teenage Timmy, during a visit to New York from Philadelphia, the cables on the Brooklyn Bridge were as alluring as any playground jungle gym, but his short vertical clamber ended the same way some of his climbs do today: with a visit from the police.

title: In Shift for Japan, Salarymen Blow the Whistle
description: TOKYO  A car company that hid dangerous flaws to avoid embarrassing recalls. A meat processor that sold ground pig hearts as beef. A fancy restaurant chain that served customers leftover sashimi from other diners.

title: What Hillary Won
description: As the sun was sinking on Hillary Clintons presidential campaign, the nations wounded feminists were burning up the Internet.

title: Bondss Trial Set to Start in March
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Barry Bondss trial is scheduled to begin March 2 now that he has pleaded not guilty to 14 charges of making false statements under oath about whether he used performance-enhancing drugs and to one charge of obstruction of justice.

title: What Paintings?
description: Vladimir Voronin, the president of Moldova, made a wonderful announcement on Friday, saying that two paintings stolen from the State Hermitage Museum in Russia had been found in Moldova and would soon be returned, The Associated Press reported. Theres just one problem: He did not say what the works were, and the Hermitages press office said it had no idea what paintings he was talking about. In Russia for talks with President Dmitri A. Medvedev, Mr. Voronin said the paintings had been recovered three days earlier after a long police investigation. The Interior Ministry of Moldova said that the investigation was under way and that details would not be revealed until Tuesday, but the Russian news service Itar-Tass, citing an unidentified law enforcement source in Moldova, said the paintings were believed to be by the 19th-century landscape artist Vasily Polenov and the Soviet-era social realist Boris Ioganson. The Hermitage, in St. Petersburg, said in July 2006 that 221 items had been stolen, but did not report any missing paintings.

title: Europe Fears a Post-Bush Unilateralism, This Time on Trade
description: The Democrats vocal hostility to trade is starting to scare many of Americas best friends. As Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton have bashed China and a variety of free trade agreements, allies who have been yearning for an end to President Bushs in-your-face unilateralism are worried that a Democratic president may be just as undiplomatic, and unreasonable, when it comes to economic protectionism.

title: Surgery for Ulcerative Colitis Is a Difficult Choice
description: When, or whether, to have surgery may be the most difficult decision facing a patient with ulcerative colitis.

title: Chinese Buddhist Treasures, Written in Stone
description: The script is familiar but irresistible. A cache of art is stored, unexamined, in the bowels of an esteemed institution. Scholars become intrigued. Cataloging begins. The quality is unexpectedly high, and soon an exhibition materializes, accompanied by a catalog that illuminates the tale of neglect, renewed interest and diligent scholarship as well as the splendors of the art.

title: Olmert Warns of a Major Military Thrust in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, warned on Friday that Israel could soon opt for a major military operation in Gaza to try to stop rocket and mortar fire from that area, which has killed three Israelis in recent weeks.

title: He Still Loves New Orleans, and Now Hes Mad
description: NEW ORLEANS  Mac Rebennack, the 67-year-old New Orleans pianist, guitarist and songwriter better known as Dr. John, carries the citys lore in his fingers, his scratchy voice and his memory. He has lived in New York City and on Long Island since the 1980s, but when he revisits his birthplace its as if he never left. New Orleans culture, he said in his ever-surprising vocabulary, has wacknosity  things only New Orleanians do.

title: Tax Laws Popularize the Small Foundation
description: When John Lane III assumed the investment responsibilities for the Edward H. Lane Foundation in 2004, he took on a lot of headaches.

title: S.E.C. Closes Inquiry of Overstock.com
description: Overstock.com, the online seller of excess inventory, said the Securities and Exchange Commission did not plan to file a complaint after completing an investigation of the company and its officers. Overstock disclosed the inquiry in 2006, saying the S.E.C. was examining its accounting policies and its complaint against research company Gradient Analytics. Patrick Byrne, Overstocks chief executive, has accused hedge funds, analysts and financial journalists of spreading negative information about his company so that short-sellers can profit from a drop in its stock. The S.E.C. ended a related inquiry of Gradient last year and also declined to take action.

title: Mayweather Retires
description: There will, it seems, be no rematch for Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Oscar De La Hoya. Mayweather retired Friday, saying in a statement that these past few years have been extremely difficult for me to find the desire and joy to continue in the sport. Mayweather (39-0), the W.B.C. welterweight champion, said he had talked about retiring over the last two years, but subsequently rekindled his passion to compete. Now, after many sleepless nights and intense soul-searching, I realized I could no longer base my decision on anything but my own personal happiness, which I no longer could find.

title: An Artist Brings Religion Into His Work, in Big, Bold Style
description: Archie Rand is standing in a Brooklyn warehouse and surveying The 613, a vast artwork it has taken him five years to complete.

title: T-Mobile Sues Starbucks Over Hot Spots
description: T-Mobile USA sued Starbucks, saying the coffee chain breached a contract by allowing AT&T to supply in-store customers with free wireless Internet access using T-Mobiles lines and equipment. T-Mobile, which said it agreed to provide Wi-Fi service at Starbucks in 2002, accused the largest American coffee chain of secretly developing a plan to let AT&T provide free Internet service at more than 7,000 Starbucks stores in the United States. T-Mobile said it is bearing the cost and burden of the free Wi-Fi service offer because it provided equipment and technology at thousands of Starbucks stores. Valerie ONeil, a spokeswoman for Starbucks, did not return a voice-mail message left at her office seeking comment.

title: Harriet Johnson, 50, Activist for Disabled, Is Dead
description: Harriet McBryde Johnson, a feisty champion of the rights of the disabled who came to prominence after she challenged a Princeton professors contention that severely disabled newborns could ethically be euthanized, died on Wednesday at her home in Charleston, S.C. She was 50.

title: Film Notes
description: Adam Sandlers production company, Happy Madison, is branching into thrillers with a new division called Scary Madison, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The divisions first picture is Shortcut, about two brothers who find a neglected  and presumably frightening  route in their town. Not counting Happy Madisons latest movie, You Dont Mess With the Zohan, which stars Mr. Sandler and opened on Friday, the company has produced 18 films that have grossed more than $1.1 billion in ticket sales, according to Baseline, an entertainment database. ... Columbia Pictures and CBS Films will make a new version of My Fair Lady, the classic Lerner and Loewe musical, the companies announced on Friday. It will be produced by Duncan Kenworthy (Four Weddings and a Funeral) and Cameron Mackintosh (Cats, Les Misrables), who said in a statement that they would use the songs from the original Broadway show and shoot part of the film on location in London. Variety reported that the studios were in discussions with Keira Knightley to play Eliza Doolittle, but a Columbia spokesman declined to comment on casting.

title: Undefeated, Mayweather Retires From Boxing
description: There will, it seems, be no rematch for Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Oscar De La Hoya. Mayweather retired on Friday, saying in a statement, These past few years have been extremely difficult for me to find the desire and joy to continue in the sport.

title: The Card-Carrying Starbucks Fan
description: IN 1981, when American Airlines was struggling to differentiate itself in a newly deregulated industry, it invented the frequent flier mile. Ten years later, American Express responded to its own competitive crisis by introducing what we now know as Membership Rewards.

title: Modern Pieces, Classically Performed
description: Few pianists approach Philip Glasss music with the level of devotion and insight that Bruce Brubaker brings to it, precisely the reason he gets so much expressivity out of it. On Wednesday night at the Stone, a small experimental-music space on the Lower East Side, Mr. Brubaker performed two of Mr. Glasss major piano works as well as compositions by William Duckworth and Alvin Curran.

title: Photographer Cleared in Australia
description: The Australian police have dropped their investigation into the work of Bill Henson, whose photographs of naked children caused controversy after the authorities shut down an exhibition in Sydney last month, Bloomberg News reported. The New South Wales state police said in a statement on Friday that there is no reasonable prospect for a successful conviction. Mr. Hensons images captured headlines after officers shut down the exhibition, saying they had received complaints. Australias prime minister, Kevin Rudd, called the photos absolutely revolting, while more than 40 prominent people in the arts, including the actress Cate Blanchett, signed an open letter in support of Mr. Henson. The artist said in a statement that it had been profoundly humbling to witness the depth of support for his work in the last few weeks. It is reassuring to see existing laws, having been rigorously tested, still provide a framework in which debate and expression of ideas can occur, he added.

title: Hamilton Home Heads to a Greener Address
description: No matter that Alexander Hamiltons country home, the Grange, is 206 years old. Until now, it had been in a perfectly contemporary Manhattan real estate bind: not enough space.

title: International Agency Urges the Start of an Energy Revolution
description: BRUSSELS  The International Energy Agency, a group that advises industrialized countries, said Friday in a report that investments of at least $45 trillion might be needed over the next half-century to prevent energy shortages and greenhouse gas emissions from slowing economic growth.

title: Footnotes
description: Miriam Makeba, below, has canceled two American concerts this month because of a fall she sustained last week. The dates included the Detroit Festival of the Arts on Sunday and Celebrate Brooklyn on June 14. Ms. Makeba will be replaced at the Brooklyn show by Sibongile Khumalo, another South African singer. ... Playwrights Horizons has announced two new plays for its 2008-9 season. The Savannah Disputation by Evan Smith, to be directed by Walter Bobbie (Chicago), will feature Dana Ivey; and Inked Baby by Christina Anderson is a world premiere for the play and an Off Broadway debut for the writer. The theater company also announced that Michael Mayer (Spring Awakening) will direct the previously announced Theresa Rebeck satire Our House; Maura Tierney (ER) will star in Nicky Silvers play Three Changes; and Jonathan Groff will join Prayer for My Enemy.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on May 25, about alumni donating to Harvard, misstated a requirement for spending by foundations, and a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated which entities are covered by the requirement. Federal law requires private foundations to disburse 5 percent of their endowment a year, not 5 percent of their income. The requirement does not apply to charitable foundations.

title: Wholesale Inventories Grew Faster in April Than Forecasters Expected
description: American wholesalers inventories rose more than forecast in April, led by a surge in petroleum and metals that reflected rising commodity prices.

title: If Big Brown Wins, Racing Loses

Many people in horse racing are particularly excited because they see Big Brown as a savior of a moribund industry with image problems.

title: Vacations Are Good for You, Medically Speaking
description: GAS prices are going up, the economy is going down, and it seems hard to justify a vacation when many of us are glad just to have jobs. But now, more than ever, we need to take a break  a real break, not just a long weekend  from our stressed-out lives.

description: PERRIS, Calif.  As California faces one of its worst droughts in two decades, building projects are being curtailed for the first time under state law by the inability of developers to find long-term water supplies.
