description: One week after undergoing surgery to remove a malignant brain tumor, Senator Edward M. Kennedy was quietly released from a North Carolina hospital on Monday and was returning to his home in Hyannis Port, his aides said.

title: Bush Talks Up Dollar as He Heads to Europe
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush, departing Monday for a weeklong trip to Europe, promised to stress our nations commitment to a strong dollar  a signal that, amid soaring oil prices and worrisome inflation, the White House is joining with the Federal Reserve in calling for an end to the dollars slump.

title: Applying Iraqs Lessons in an Afghan Village
description: HAZARJOFT, Afghanistan  United States marines pushed the Taliban out of this village and the surrounding district in southern Helmand Province so quickly in recent weeks that they called the operation a catastrophic success.

title: King Coal Country Debates a Sacrilege, Gas Heat
description: POTTSVILLE, Pa.  Over the last 150 years, Schuylkill County has been famous for a rare hard coal called anthracite that fed the explosive growth of the East Coast during the Industrial Revolution, fostered the rise of the United Mine Workers union and powered many of the factories that supplied troops through both world wars.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Schedule information on Monday with a music review of a concert at the 3LD Art & Technology Center that featured Ballet Mcanique, by George Antheil, and that was presented in conjunction with Frequency Hopping, a play about Antheil and Hedy Lamarr, misstated the centers address. It is 80 Greenwich Street in Lower Manhattan (at Rector Street), not 80 Rector Street.

title: Following as Plots Thicken and Thicken
description: The beautiful crazy lady is the best part of Daniel Robertss Monsterface. Melanie (Sarah Grace Wilson), a New York actress, is young, delicate and prone to taking her clothes off in front of guests. She talks to an invisible turtle named Seymour. And the more bizarre her comments, the more she smiles like a perky cheerleader who has just been named homecoming queen.

title: Direct Advice Has Direct Effects on Improving Neonatal Survival
description: Four million babies a year die in their first month of life. Very few die in hospital incubators; most were born in huts to mothers helped only by relatives or a village midwife.

title: A Lighthearted Tale of Sex for Money
description: LOS ANGELES

title: France: Chirac Creates Foundation
description: Jacques Chirac, the former president of France, announced the creation of a nonprofit organization, the Chirac Foundation, to promote sustainable development and dialogue among cultures. The foundation will work to improve water supplies and provide better access to health care in poor countries, fight against deforestation and desertification, and save threatened languages and cultures.

title: East Coast Heat Wave Bakes Wide Area
description: The East Coast continued to bake on Tuesday with temperatures in the upper 90s for the fourth straight day, but weather forecasters say relief is on the way.

title: Outcomes: Tooth Loss Tied to Pregnancy
description: A new study suggests that the more babies a woman has, the more likely she is to lose teeth.

title: Bush, in German Visit, Will Discuss Iran With Merkel
description: BERLIN  When Chancellor Angela Merkel plays host to President Bush on Tuesday and Wednesday, it will be well away from the bright lights of this capital.

title: U.S. Troops Causing Instability, Irans Religious Leader Tells Iraqi Premier
description: TEHRAN  Irans supreme leader told Iraqs prime minister on Monday that the American forces in Iraq were the biggest obstacle to Iraqi stability.

title: With Fall Vote in View, Obama Assails McCain on Economy
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Senator Barack Obama, with the Democratic stage to himself for the first time, began a two-week assault on Senator John McCains economic policies in a series of battleground states on Monday, moving to focus on the ailing economy as the central theme of the general election campaign.

title: Plan to Cut Back Public Defenders Stirs Worry in Georgia
description: ATLANTA  The chief judge of the Fulton County Superior Court on Monday sharply criticized a state plan to lay off a large group of public defenders, saying it could cause a legal crisis.

title: Among Scientific Treasures, a Gem
description: One thing you can say about the copy of Nicolaus Copernicuss book De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium (On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres), on sale next week at Christies auction house, is that it looks and feels old.

title: The Great Seduction
description: The people who created this country built a moral structure around money. The Puritan legacy inhibited luxury and self-indulgence. Benjamin Franklin spread a practical gospel that emphasized hard work, temperance and frugality. Millions of parents, preachers, newspaper editors and teachers expounded the message. The result was quite remarkable.

title: Japanese Architect to Make American Debut
description: The University of California, Berkeley, Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive have unveiled the conceptual design for the first American project by the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. He has designed a three-story curvilinear arts complex, above, for the joint institution, in Berkeley, with a fluid steel interior and towering windows. Inside will be a grid of interlocking spaces with curved walls for exhibition galleries as well as two theaters, a cafe, a screening room, a library and a study center. The final design is expected to be ready by the end of 2009, and the museum hopes construction will be completed by 2013. Mr. Ito is known for dynamic experimental spaces in urban settings like the Sendai Mediathque in Sendai, Japan, and Tods Omotesando, a boutique and offices for a luxury footwear maker in Tokyo.

title: The Laws of the Universe (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Growth of Lush Fairways Has No Bounds
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As dusk fell, a restaurant-lined lane in Seouls Mapo district filled with customers. While many loosened their ties and bought a round, at Kwon Sung-woons place men took off their ties and prepared to play a round  of golf.

title: Pierces Road From Inglewood Could Hit Its Summit Nearby
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.  At 5:30 in the morning, Paul Pierce would peel himself out of bed, rub the sleep from his eyes, and hop in his beat-up, brown, two-door Datsun 210 hatchback. He would head over to Inglewood High, often stopping to pick up a couple of friends  one of whom would be unlucky enough to have to crouch down in the hatch. When they arrived at school, they were met by Scott Collins, a policeman and assistant basketball coach at the school.

title: Broadway Vets
description: Next season has already been shaping up with starry projects on Broadway: Katie Holmes and Daniel Radcliffe are already on their way. But how about some real veteran wattage? Jeremy Irons, left, last seen on Broadway in The Real Thing, which opened in 1984, and Joan Allen (The Heidi Chronicles, which opened in 1989) are planning to return in Impressionism, a new play by Michael Jacobs about the relationship between a photojournalist and a New York gallery owner. Mr. Jacobs had a play on Broadway in 1978, Cheaters, but has since written primarily for television. Jack OBrien is scheduled to direct the play, which is to open in spring 2009.

title: Super Bowl Ring in Hand, Strahan Says Hes Retiring
description: Michael Strahan, the longtime leader of the Giants defense, is retiring from the N.F.L., leaving his lone Super Bowl victory as the final game of a 15-year career.

title: New Storms Cause Flooding in Three States
description: CHICAGO  A stalled storm system poured heavy rain on parts of the Midwest on Monday, setting off severe flooding in Indiana, Iowa and Wisconsin, where already swollen rivers and lakes overflowed their banks, broke through dams and created havoc for thousands of residents.

title: In a Bronx Funeral Parlor, a Veterans War Memorial
description: The old marine was back on duty Thursday, standing guard over a military shrine in the Morris Park section of the Bronx.

title: Spanish Truckers Block Border
description: MADRID  Spanish truck drivers began a blockade of their countrys border with France on Monday, lining up their rigs and slowing them to a crawl to protest the cost of diesel fuel.

title: Another Scandalous Video, Another Apology
description: Amy Winehouse apologized on Monday for yet another offensive appearance in yet another videotape that surfaced over the weekend on the Web site for yet another British tabloid. In the video, posted on the News of the World site (notw.co.uk), Ms. Winehouse, above, is seen in a squalid room littered with drug paraphernalia and, at one point, singing a racist chant with a friend. In the brief chant, set to the tune of a childrens rhyme, Ms. Winehouse makes slurs about blacks and Asians, while her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, promises repeatedly that he is not filming the episode. Another video surfaced in January showing Ms. Winehouse, 24, apparently smoking crack. ... Mr. Fielder-Civil, 26, has pleaded guilty to assaulting a pub proprietor two years ago and then conspiring with the man to withdraw as a witness at the trial, Reuters reported. Mr. Fielder-Civil and three-co-defendants pleaded guilty last week; a court order that barred reporting the pleas was lifted Monday.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Monday about a temporary agreement by Hamburg, Germany, to incinerate the trash of Naples, Italy, referred incorrectly to Hamburgs political leadership. It is a coalition of the conservative Christian Democratic Union and the environmentally conscious German Green Party; it is not governed solely by the Green Party. (The Greens do control Hamburgs environmental waste policy.)

title: Gay Unions Shed Light on Gender in Marriage
description: For insights into healthy marriages, social scientists are looking in an unexpected place.

title: Showing the Patient the Door, Permanently
description: It wasnt the boy I had a problem with. It was his mother.

title: Promised Brooklyn Community Center May Not Open
description: In 2000, the New York City Housing Authority decided to tear down the playground at the Marcus Garvey housing project in East New York, Brooklyn. It was not very big or all that attractive. But it was a refuge where children played on two sets of jungle gyms, slides and a water sprinkler, next to a small grassy field.

title: Yahoo Shareholders Seek Repeal of Severance Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An employee severance plan put in place by Yahoo to protect workers after a merger with Microsoft should be rescinded immediately, according to a brief filed by plaintiffs in a shareholder lawsuit against Yahoo and its directors.

title: Menthol Cigarettes
description: To the Editor:

title: Disorder Magnifies Blood Clot Risk
description: When David Bloom, 39, went to Iraq in 2003 to cover the war for NBC News, his wife, Melanie, naturally feared for his safety. Would a bullet or a bomb claim him? A land mine? An ambush?

title: Will Peace Take Flight?
description: LATE last month, Israel announced that it had named the hoopoe as its national bird. The long-billed hoopoe, which has a punky orange crest tipped black, is barely mentioned in the Bible (as an unclean animal that may not be eaten) but it plays a role in rabbinic literature and in Islamic lore as well. It is celebrated, among other things, as the messenger that shuttles between King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba. It is in other words well suited to the symbolic burden the country has placed on it.

title: Survey of Israelis Attitudes Toward Politics Finds Disgust and a Growing Apathy
description: JERUSALEM  A third of Israelis expressed feelings of nausea, revulsion, depression or despair when asked what they felt or thought about the word politics, according to a new survey. Another third said they instinctively associated politics with corruption, betrayal or deceit.

title: How to Cope With Hard Times
description: For small businesses that are trying to ride out an uncertain economy, all solid suggestions about cutting costs, reducing the amount of time it takes to collect a receivable, or finding forgotten tax breaks are much needed.

title: Doctors Say Hospital Is Falling Victim to Its Own Real Estate Value
description: Doctors at a community hospital in Brooklyn that is part of a large system of hospitals say they are being squeezed out so the system can sell off property in popular neighborhoods.

title: More Money for Food Safety Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON  Two days after announcing a large-scale recall of raw tomatoes, the Bush administration asked Congress on Monday to give the Food and Drug Administration an additional $275 million in next years budget to help improve the safety of the nations food supply.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An art review on Friday about Framing a Century: Master Photographers, 1840-1940, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the surname of the curator who organized the exhibition. He is Malcolm Daniel, not Daniels.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Faulty Scaffold Repair Preceded 47-Floor Fall, Investigator Says
description: A device that holds a cable in place for a scaffold was installed improperly last year, three weeks before the scaffolding gave way and sent two window washers plunging 47 floors on the Upper East Side, a federal investigator said on Monday. One of the two men was killed in the fall.

title: Adding to a U.S. Legacy Defined by One Pass
description: The place of Eddie Lewis in the history of United States soccer is secure, frozen in a flash of his polished left foot. Lewis delivered a perfect cross to Landon Donovans forehead in a second-round game of the 2002 World Cup, and Donovan nodded the ball into Mexicos net for an insurance goal as the Americans advanced to the quarterfinals.

title: Times Vice President Is Appointed
description: The New York Times announced the appointment of Michael Valentine on Monday as vice president for human resources.

title: Film Notes
description: Brian De Palma will direct The Boston Stranglers, based on the book by Susan Kelly about the series of murders of young Boston women in the early 1960s and the man who confessed to the killings but later recanted, announced Gale Anne Hurd, the producer. Albert DeSalvo claimed in 1965 to have committed the Strangler killings but later said he was only seeking notoriety, and investigators have long doubted that Mr. DeSalvo committed the crimes. He was never charged for them and was killed in prison while serving a sentence for an unrelated rape conviction. ... Leonardo DiCaprio, above, will produce and star in Atari, about Nolan Bushnell, one of the two men who founded the Atari video game company in 1972, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

title: Doctors Miss Cultural Needs, Study Says
description: As researchers ponder growing evidence that blacks have worse outcomes than whites in the treatment of chronic disease, they often theorize that members of minorities suffer disproportionately from poor access to quality care. Now a new study of diabetes patients has found stark racial disparities even among patients treated by the same doctors.

title: $4.5 Million Water Bill for a New York Agency
description: One of the biggest water bill deadbeats in New York City is the Economic Development Corporation, according to an audit released by the city comptrollers office on Monday.

title: Virginia: Death Sentence Commuted
description: The life of a man who killed three people in November 1996 was spared by Gov. Tim Kaine, a day before the scheduled execution, on grounds that the inmate was mentally incompetent to understand his situation. In commuting the death sentence of Percy L. Walton, Governor Kaine said a new sentence of life in prison without the possibility of parole is now the only constitutionally appropriate court of action in view of Mr. Waltons continuing mental defectiveness. The defendant had just turned 18 when he shot three of his neighbors to death in Danville.

title: After 100 Years, Tribes Ancestors Head Home
description: A hushed group of people, nearly four dozen strong, slipped into the American Museum of Natural History early Monday, ahead of the crowds. Their cheeks were smeared with rust-colored dye, red and white woven bands encircled their heads, the men wore ceremonial vests and the women were wrapped in shawls, fringed with red.

title: Bryant in Need of Celtic-Like Embrace
description: BOSTON

title: Worries Mount as Farmers Push for Big Harvest
description: GRIFFIN, Ind.  In a year when global harvests need to be excellent to ease the threat of pervasive food shortages, evidence is mounting that they will be average at best. Some farmers are starting to fear disaster.

title: Obama, Adopting Economic Theme, Criticizes McCain
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  With the Democratic stage to himself for the first time, Senator Barack Obama opened a two-week tour of battleground states on Monday, attacking Senator John McCains economic policies and moving to focus on the ailing economy as the central theme of the general election campaign.

title: New Type of Paper Wont Let You Just Rip It Apart
description: This newspaper is printed on paper made from cellulose fibers obtained from wood pulp. The fibers are fairly large, on the order of tens of micrometers wide, and the resulting paper is fairly weak  pull on it and it tears easily.

title: Ranks of Underinsured Are Rising, Study Finds
description: The number of people in this country who have health insurance but not the ability to afford adequate medical care continues to climb.

title: McCain and Obama Trade Charges on Economy
description: With grim financial reports dominating the news, the presidential candidates are trading charges over economic policy in recent appearances and are offering sharply contrasting remedies for the countrys ailing economy.

title: Sunday TV: N.B.A. and the Rest
description: ABC easily dominated Sunday nights ratings with live coverage of the N.B.A. finals, and CBS was the second-most-watched network, leading early in the night with 60 Minutes and Million Dollar Password. According to Nielsens overnight estimates, those two CBS shows delivered 9.6 million viewers each at 7 and 8 p.m. No other program on Sunday had a larger audience except for ABCs basketball broadcast, which attracted well over 10 million viewers. Meanwhile, from 9 to 11 p.m., repeats of CBSs Cold Case (8.1 million) and The Unit (4.2 million) trailed just behind NBCs two-hour edition of Dateline (7.9 million). NBC finished third over all with four reruns of Most Outrageous Moments from 7 to 9, drawing an average of 5 million viewers. Fox was fourth with repeats of its animated comedy line-up. Among adults 18 to 49, Fox, NBC and CBS finished in a virtual three-way tie for second place behind ABC.

title: Return to Form Puts Wie Back in Open Field
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.  On the tee box of a par-3 near the end of a marathon day, Michelle Wie consulted with her caddie, Kenny Harms. She had 168 yards to the pin and a 7-iron in her hands.

title: Memo Pad
description: FARE INCREASE ROLLBACK Four major airlines all retreated on Monday from an across-the-board fare increase that United Airlines initiated over the weekend. Continental Airlines, American Airlines, Delta Airlines and United rescinded the increases, typically $20 on most round-trip tickets, which would have been the 17th fare increase this year. Neither Northwest Airlines nor US Airways had rescinded their increase on Monday, but they were expected to do so by Tuesday. The old-line carriers inability to make the latest fare increases stick could be the first sign that demand is softening, said Graeme Wallace, of the airfare tracker FareCompare.com

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,087 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Scorching Heat Blankets East Coast
description: Scorching heat and stifling humidity gripped much of the East Coast on Monday, with the National Weather Service issuing heat advisories as temperatures approached 100 degrees in many areas.

title: Chvez Goes Over the Line, and Realizes It
description: President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela started this month as the most prominent political supporter of Colombias largest rebel group and a fierce defender of his own overhaul of his nations intelligence services. But in the space of a few hours over the weekend, he confounded his critics by switching course on both contentious policies.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An obituary on Thursday about William E. Odom, a director of the National Security Agency in the Reagan administration, misstated his position under President Jimmy Carter. He worked for the National Security Council, not the National Security Agency.

title: A Picture of a Familys Tragicomic Tree
description: Every family has its oddball or two, and many can even lay claim to a bona fide black sheep. But none of the in-laws who turn up in The Framer, a new play by Edward Allan Baker, would be at home in the smiling happy-family photographs the picture framer of the title works on.

title: CSX Grasping at Straws to End Battle
description: Lou Dobbs, wearing an American flag pin in his left lapel, introduced a segment on his CNN program last week with his trademark outrage. Tonight, there is a new threat to national sovereignty and security: A foreign hedge fund trying to take control of CSX.

title: Gadfly, Contending Price Fixing, Sues OPEC
description: MIAMI  With Democrats in Congress demanding a get-tough-or-else approach to the oil industry, Larry Klayman decided hed had enough. It was time to call gasoline prices what he thinks they are  economic terrorism.

title: Judge Tells Ohio to Change Executions
description: Ohio must stop using a common combination of three chemicals to execute condemned inmates because they may produce excruciating pain, a state court judge there ruled Tuesday.

title: Share Sale by British Bank Draws 95% of Shareholders
description: LONDON  Royal Bank of Scotland said Monday that 95.1 percent of shareholders had subscribed to its record $23.5 billion rights issue  a level many analysts saw as in line with their expectations.

title: In Air Force Changes, Signs of an Overhaul
description: LANGLEY AIR FORCE BASE, Va.  Earlier this year, the Air Force unveiled an advertising campaign that sought to distinguish the service as being Above All  exceptional in its training, technology and war-fighting skills.

title: Playing a Leading Role in the Ruins of a Tornado
description: On May 23 the people of Greensburg, Kan., found themselves back where theyd been when life as they knew it ended: burrowed underground, wind and hail composing a raucous symphony above, a tornado headed their way.

title: Bush Orders Contractors to Vet Status of Workers
description: President Bush has ordered federal contractors to participate in the Department of Homeland Securitys electronic system for verifying the immigration status of their workers, greatly expanding the reach of the administrations crackdown on employers who hire illegal immigrants.

title: China: Beijing Bans Fireworks
description: The Beijing city government has banned fireworks for three months around the time of the Summer Olympics for safety reasons, according to a post on a government Web site. From July 1 until Oct. 8, fireworks dealers will have to suspend sales and lock existing stocks in special warehouses. The ban is among a host of restrictions that the Chinese government has imposed for the Olympics, which begin on Aug. 8.

title: Guilty Plea in Slaying of Officer
description: A retired city police officer pleaded guilty on Monday to fatally shooting a retired Port Authority officer in 2006, as part of a plea agreement that will send him to prison for 21 years, according to Staten Island prosecutors.

title: Lehman Posts Loss and Plans to Raise Capital
description: Richard S. Fuld tried for months to persuade Wall Street that Lehman Brothers, the investment bank he runs, could weather the storm in the financial markets. But by last Wednesday his time had run out: Confidence in Lehman seemed to be slipping away.

title: Woman a Homicide Victim, the Police Say
description: A preliminary examination by the Dallas County Medical Examiners Office has determined that the woman found dead last week with David Jacobs, a convicted steroids dealer who tied several N.F.L. players to performance-enhancing drugs, was a homicide victim, the police said. The woman, Amanda Jo Earhart-Savell, and Jacobs were found dead on Thursday at Jacobss home in Plano, Tex. Last week, a preliminary examination by the medical examiners office found that Jacobs had shot himself. The police have said that the deaths are consistent with a murder-suicide.

title: At Airports, Lines Made for Speed
description: The Transportation Security Administration is trying to speed up airport screening by asking passengers to choose a line based on their familiarity with checkpoint procedures. But human nature being what it is, this approach may hit its own snags: people typically opt for the shortest line, and all think they are experts.

title: Israeli Soldier, Held for 2 Years, Writes to Family
description: JERUSALEM  The family of Gilad Shalit, the Israeli corporal who was seized by Palestinian militants and taken to Gaza in June 2006, received a rare letter from him on Monday, apparently proving that he is still alive.

title: S. Korean Cabinet Offers to Quit After Beef Protests
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas entire cabinet offered to resign on Tuesday as President Lee Myung-bak struggled to find a breakthrough in the biggest political crisis to face his young government, one set off by fears that an agreement to reopen markets to American beef could expose the public to mad cow disease.

title: Report on City Police Shootings Urges More Use of Tasers Before Guns
description: Police recruits and veteran officers could benefit from more frequent firearms training and a wider use of Taser stun guns, according to a study of the New York Police Departments shooting habits released on Monday.

title: In a Sweltering City, Any Sliver of Shade Will Do
description: For working stiffs, the fun in the sun ended on Monday. After two days of toying with the stifling weather in shorts and T-shirts, they found the most mundane chores a challenge during record-high temperatures in the New York region.

title: Help the Parks
description: It is only June, but given a summer recess and the falls campaigning, the rest of the legislative year could well be wasted, and some good bills left to die, unless Congress starts working harder now.

title: A Balanchine Prodigal Who Inhabits the Journey
description: On Sunday afternoon, many in the New York City Ballet audience leapt to their feet to applaud Damian Woetzels performance of the title role in Balanchines ballet The Prodigal Son. Quite right, too. Mr. Woetzel is due to retire from dancing next week, and it seems that each performance he gives is greeted by a heightened intensity in the auditorium.

title: Return to Old Spy Rules Is Seen as Deadline Nears
description: WASHINGTON  With Congress at an impasse over the governments spy powers, Congressional and intelligence officials are bracing for the possibility that the government might have to revert to the old rules of terrorist surveillance, a situation that some officials predict could leave worrisome gaps in intelligence.

title: Net Providers to Block Sites With Child Sex
description: ALBANY  Verizon, Sprint and Time Warner Cable have agreed to purge their servers of Internet bulletin boards and Web sites nationwide that disseminate child pornography.

title: Broken Finger Wont Keep Scott Out
description: SAN DIEGO  Adam Scott, the No. 3 player in the world, who is grouped with No. 1 Tiger Woods and No. 2 Phil Mickelson in the first and second rounds of the United States Open, told U.S.G.A. officials he would be ready to go Thursday despite a broken pinkie.

title: Field Trips to Dark Reaches of the Soul
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The Pink Pony is a strip club here, across the street from the Banned Bookstore, the House of Leather and the Fantasy Shoppe. On the evening before 9/11 the club was visited by three men who may have been part of the terrorist plot. They stayed for hours, dropping several hundred dollars on drinks and lap dances and left behind a Koran.

title: British Bank Issues $23.5 Billion in Shares
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said Monday that 95.1 per cent of shareholders had subscribed to its record $23.5 billion rights issue  a level seen by many analysts as in line with their expectations.

title: Man Who Killed 7 in Tokyo Left Online Warnings
description: TOKYO  The final, chilling posting read, Its time.

title: The Claim: Ice Is Good for a Skin Burn
description: THE FACTS

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: International

title: Sabbatini Says He's Not Afraid to Face the Best
description: SAN DIEGO  The last time the high-octane talent that is Rory Sabbatini popped up on the radar screen this season was here at Torrey Pines Golf Course, where he finished third in the Buick Invitational, 10 strokes behind the winner, Tiger Woods.

title: Spread of Tuberculosis Seen Slowing Progress on AIDS
description: Inadequate attention to the spread of tuberculosis is undermining recent gains made against the virus that causes AIDS, United Nations officials said Monday.

title: Regimens: Wine May Help Keep Liver Healthy
description: Recent reports suggest that red wine is a potent force in increasing lifespan, and a new study offers still more good news for wine drinkers. A glass a day, whether white or red, may reduce the risk of developing the nations most common liver disorder, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

title: Smartphones Now Ringing for Women
description: If recent history is any guide, roughly a third of the people snapping up Apples new iPhone are likely to tote it in a purse.

title: Pacific-10 Commissioner to Announce His Retirement
description: Pacific-10 Commissioner Tom Hansen announced Monday that he would retire in July 2009, the second major change in college athletics leadership in less than a week.

title: Nickel and Diming, but Still Traveling
description: SUCCESSIVE fare increases, a sharp reduction in flights and seats, crammed planes, chronic delays and missed connections  all of these would seem to argue that business travel is falling.

title: Tallying the Toll on an Elder of the Sea
description: MILFORD, Conn.  Horseshoe crabs may look ancient and alien and battery-operated, they may look like Wilma Flintstones idea of a Roomba vacuum cleaner, yet to the sixth-grade students from Columbus School in nearby Bridgeport, the most outrageous thing about the bronze-helmeted creatures crawling clumsily along the beach was not their appearance but their size  or rather sizes.

title: Change of Control at the Los Angeles Times Magazine
description: The Los Angeles Times has made plans to transfer control of its monthly magazine from its newsroom to its business operations and to replace the magazines entire editorial staff, according to two executives at the newspaper.

title: Anticipating the Future to See the Present
description: Staring at a pattern meant to evoke an optical illusion is usually an act of idle curiosity, akin to palm reading or astrology. The dot disappears, or it doesnt. The silhouette of the dancer spins clockwise or counterclockwise. The three-dimensional face materializes or not, and the explanation always seems to have something to do with the eye or creativity or even personality.

title: For Clinton, Millions in Debt and Few Options
description: With her campaign now officially suspended, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is confronting still another challenge: whittling down what is believed to be the largest presidential campaign debt in history.

title: President of Indonesia Restricts Muslim Sect
description: MANIS LOR, Indonesia  President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono signed a decree on Monday ordering members of a minority Muslim sect to stop practicing their form of Islam or face arrest.

title: Midwest Braces for More Flooding
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Sodden communities in the upper Midwest braced for more flooding on Wednesday as rising rivers threatened to overcome levees protecting many downtown areas.

title: Kaiser Backs Microsoft Patient-Data Plan
description: Kaiser Permanente, the nations largest nonprofit health maintenance organization, is endorsing the drive toward consumer-controlled personal health records in a partnership with Microsoft.

title: Threatening Iran
description: Israeli leaders spent last week talking tough about Iran and threatening possible military action. The United States and the other major powers need to address Tehrans nuclear ambitions, but with more assertive diplomacy  including greater financial pressures  not more threats or war planning.

title: Gates Selects New Air Force Leaders
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced his new Air Force leadership team on Monday, tapping Michael B. Donley, a Pentagon administrator, to be the services next secretary and Gen. Norton A. Schwartz, who has been in charge of transportation for the Pentagon, to be chief of staff.

title: A Fierce Predator Makes a Home in the Suburbs
description: WEST GREENWICH, R.I.  Last summer, Kerry Beaudry heard yelping from her German shepherd, Holly, and went outside to investigate. What she found still gives her chills. A small, mangy creature was on top of Holly, digging its claws into the scruff of her neck and gnawing at her face.

title: The Summer Wind
description: Q. This came up when someone tried to talk me out of even looking at an apartment with a terrace in a high-rise building: Does it get windier the higher up you go? Or does it depend on the wind conditions in general and the arrangement of surrounding buildings?

title: Victim Testifies About Small Talk With Rapist and How She Escaped
description: As a man raped her, threw boiling water and bleach in her face and tossed her around like a rag doll, a woman testified on Monday, there were many moments when all she could do was scream or beg for mercy.

title: Spain, Like U.S., Grapples With Immigration
description: MADRID  With the United States riven by calls to legalize millions of illegal immigrants, Americans might consider the possible effects by looking at southern Europe, where illegal immigration has abounded and so have forgiveness plans.

title: More Girls, Little Ones, Try to Take Back the Multiplex
description: LOS ANGELES  Kit Kittredge: An American Girl has no sex and not much of a city.

title: The Unexamined Life? He Never Heard of It
description: It sometimes helps to remind myself that not everyone is like me, David Sedaris writes in his spotty new collection, When You Are Engulfed in Flames. Not everyone writes things down in a notebook and then transcribes them into a diary. Fewer still will take that diary, clean it up a bit, and read it in front of an audience.

title: Japan: Rampage Plans Online
description: In the hours before a 25-year-old man went on a rampage in central Tokyo on Sunday that left seven people dead, he posted a series of messages on an online bulletin board from his cellphone, the authorities said on Monday. The attacker, Tomohiro Kato, above, described his intention of using a vehicle and knife to kill people in the district of Akihabara. The first message to the thread was titled I will kill people in Akihabara. In later posts, Mr. Kato described leaving his home just west of Tokyo and worrying that rain might hamper his plans. The final post was at 12:10 p.m., and 20 minutes later he plowed a rental truck into a crowd of pedestrians before stabbing passers-by.

title: Activity in Saturn Ring May Provide Clues to Birth of Solar System
description: Among the rings of Saturn, the ones designated A, B, C, D, E and G are the good children, neat and tidy with nary an ice or dust particle out of place. F, on the other hand, the narrowest ring at less than 100 miles wide, is the family freak. It appears to have a core of material that is surrounded by spiraling braided streams.

title: Libertarians Choose Candidate for Fossella Seat
description: The Libertarian Party selected Susan Overeem on Monday night as the nominee for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island. She had nearly three times as many votes as the other Libertarian candidate, Francis M. Powers, the son of the Republican Party candidate, Francis H. Powers.

title: Saudi Arabia Calls for Summit on Energy Costs
description: Saudi Arabia, the worlds biggest oil exporter, said on Monday that it wanted to convene an energy summit of producers and consumers to focus on how to objectively deal with high prices.

title: Two Opinions of Desormeauxs Ride of Big Brown
description: After spending the past three weeks at Belmont Park, Big Brown returned Monday to the Aqueduct barn of his trainer, Rick Dutrow, according to Michael Iavarone, co-president of International Equine Acquisitions Holdings, which is part owner of the colt.

title: Link Between Signaling and Physiology in Birds May Be Two-Way Street
description: Sexual signaling in animals is generally considered a one-way street. That is, a physical characteristic that conveys information about an animals desirability takes a physiological toll, and thus keeps things honest  if the animal isnt up to it physiologically, it cant produce the signal.

title: Two Actors Unions Fight as One Tries for a Deal

title: Owens Will Be Tested for Drugs More Often

title: The Family That Drinks Together Bickers Together
description: The Cocktail Hour, A. R. Gurneys mild examination of an overprivileged family that fights domestic battles while downing drinks, must have seemed fairly thin when it had its premiere in 1988. Now, with so many real-life families struggling to fill the gas tank and pay the grocery bill, Mr. Gurneys story of a self-absorbed clan whose biggest problem is whether the maid can cook a roast is in danger of registering as just plain annoying.

title: At the Intersection of Styles, Taking Some Songs for a Ride
description: In a video clip available on YouTube, a young woman named Briana Cartwright appears on the stage of The Ellen DeGeneres Show dressed as the host. Ms. DeGeneres had recently been in a car accident and could not perform her signature dance, so she asked her employees to come out and entertain her viewers. For a minute and a half Ms. Cartwright, who was a producer on the show at the time, did just that, all liquid shoulders, slinky hips and high-fives to audience members, then merrily skipped off.

The newsman, Patrick Poivre dArvor, 60, known as PPDA, has been the anchor of the main news program at 8 p.m. on TF1, the countrys largest private broadcaster, since 1987, after years of similar work on the public broadcast station France 2. He will be replaced by Laurence Ferrari, 41, who is both glamorous and popular.

title: Stolen Artifacts Returned to Iraq
description: A cache of ancient artifacts stolen from the National Museum of Iraq during the American-led invasion in 2003 were returned to Iraqs Antiquities Ministry on Monday in a ceremony in Baghdad, Reuters reported. The items, 11 cylinder seals made from agate and alabaster between 3,000 and 2,000 B.C., were found in Philadelphia last month by American customs officials and turned over to the Iraqi embassy in Washington, a spokesman for the ministry said. Thousands of pieces were looted after the 2003 invasion, and Iraqi officials have blamed the pilfering on smugglers and occupying troops. The National Museum said that 15,000 items were stolen and that up to 6,000 have been returned. In April, Syria returned more than 700 stolen artifacts seized by its customs officers. This is only the start, Hoshyar Zebari, Iraqs foreign minister, said of the cylinders return. We hope to return more of these pieces in the near future. The National Museum remains closed to the public because of its poor condition and a lack of security.

description: Evolutions recipe for making a brain more complex has long seemed simple enough. Just increase the number of nerve cells, or neurons, and the interconnections between them. A human brain, for instance, is three times the volume of a chimpanzees.

title: Illinois: Yippie Leader Faces Charges
description: Dana Beal, a longtime Yippie leader, is facing money laundering charges and is being held in the Coles County Jail on bail of $250,000, a sheriffs department spokeswoman said. Further information about the charges was not yet public. Mr. Beal became a member of the Youth International Party, known as the Yippies, shortly after the group was founded in the 1960s by Abbie Hoffman and others. Since 1973 Mr. Beal and other Yippies have lived in a building on Bleecker Street in New York City that the group used as a headquarters.

Estelle Parsons will be stepping into the role currently being performed by Ms. Dunagan, and Molly Regan (The Crucible on Broadway) will be replacing Ms. Reed. Recently Jim True-Frost (The Wire), Robert Foxworth (recently on Broadway in Twelve Angry Men) and Frank Wood (Side Man) were announced as replacements for three of the male roles. All the replacements will begin on June 17. ... November, David Mamets satire of Oval Office machinations, with Nathan Lane, above, playing the president, will close July 13. title: Are Doctors Screwing Up Public Health?
description: Health work in poor countries looks easy  vaccinate the kids, treat malaria, prevent mother-to-child transmission of AIDS  and yet in fact its extraordinarily difficult and has often failed. Because of AIDS, life expectancy has fallen. A quarter more women die in childbirth now in Africa than in 1990. As for malaria, we dont even have a good sense of the scale of the challenge. We roll out multi-billion dollar anti-retroviral programs for AIDS, but we dont even deworm kids or iodize salt  two simple interventions that would raise school attendance, reduce malnutrition and anemia, and prevent cognitive impairment and even cretinism.

title: Meet the Intraterrestrials
description: Some weeks ago, I wrote about microbes in the air and their possible role in helping clouds form, in causing rain and in altering the chemistry of the high atmosphere. This week, I want to go in the opposite direction and plunge down into the earth. For many bacteria live deep in the oceans and deep in the earth, far from light, far from what we normally think of as good, comfortable places to live.   For example: the bottom of the Mariana Trench. This is a seam on the sea floor in the northwestern Pacific, not far from the island of Guam; it's where the Pacific plate is sliding under the Philippine plate. The ocean is deeper here than anywhere else in the world: the seabed is 11 kilometers (almost 7 miles) below the surface of the sea. Yet even here, where the pressure of the water would crush you or me, there are bacteria. Some of them won't grow at all unless the atmospheric pressure is at least 50 megapascals (around 7,000 pounds per square inch), and they grow better if the pressure is greater  70 megapascals (more than 10,000 pounds per square inch). For comparison, the pressure at sea level  the pressure we have evolved to bear  is 700 times less.   Then there are the "intraterrestrials"  the organisms that live in rocks deep in the earth, the creatures of the "deep subsurface biosphere." Bacteria have been found in rock samples taken several hundred meters below the sea floor, even when the sea floor itself is 4 kilometers (2.5 miles) below sea level.   We don't know how many organisms are living in this (to us) alien environment. But based on what's been found in rock samples so far, the numbers are likely to be gigantic. One recent study found between 1 million and 1 billion bacteria per gram of rock (a gram is 1/28 of an ounce). It may be that a large proportion  perhaps as many as a third  of all bacteria on Earth live in rocks below the floor of the sea. That would be a lot of bacteria.  Until recently, it was assumed that the chemical alteration and decomposition of rocks in the ocean crust was due purely to elemental forces  the circulation of seawater, the grinding of rocks against one another. But increasingly, intraterrestrial bacteria are suspected of making a contribution, too. Shards of volcanic glass from basaltic rocks hundreds of meters beneath the seabed show grooves and etchings that appear to have been made by bacteria.   Volcanic glass? When molten basaltic rock wells up from deep in the earth and meets cold water at the bottom of the ocean, the heat is quenched and the rock hardens. As it does so, it forms a characteristic shape known as a pillow basalt  for it looks as though someone has stacked up a pile of rocky pillows. (Every year, around 20 cubic kilometers -- around 5 cubic miles  of new basalt forms at the mid-ocean ridges  the places where the sea floor is spreading apart as tectonic plates move away from each other.) Glass forms when the rock cools so fast that crystals don't have time to take shape. Thus the edges and rims of pillow basalts are often highly glassy; indeed basaltic glass is an important component of the top layers of the oceanic crust.   Bacteria of the deep biosphere can't get energy directly from sunlight, but they can get energy from a surprising array of other sources, including iron, manganese, sulfur or nitrogen compounds, methane and hydrogen. Indeed, bacteria collected from the deep biosphere show an enormous diversity of metabolic activities. And in chiseling away at rocks, in leaching out minerals to consume, and by excreting waste products, they alter the chemical composition of rocks  and also the composition of the seawater that circulates through the pores and fractures in them. Perhaps  though no one yet knows for sure  they do so on a grand scale, contributing substantially to the composition of rocks and oceans. Experiments suggest that deep biosphere bacteria may accelerate the weathering of basalt rocks by a factor of six compared to physical or chemical forces, especially at the low temperatures that prevail in much of the seabed.  And here's something nifty. By altering the chemical composition of rocks, the bacteria may alter the magnetic properties of rocks as well.  Basaltic rocks newly arrived at the sea floor give off a strong magnetic signal. This is due to titanomagnetites  iron oxides that contain some titanium  that are present in the rocks. As a result, the mid-ocean ridges often feature a zone of high magnetization known as the central anomaly magnetization high. The strength of the magnetic signal fades as you move away from the newest rocks  as you move from the mid-ocean ridges towards the coasts. (The new rocks are gradually pulled away from the ridge by the spreading apart of the ocean plates; a rock's distance from the ridge is thus a reflection of its age.) Soon after basalts arrive at the sea floor, then, they lose some of their magnetism. Why?  A recent series of experiments that looked at the loss of magnetism of young basaltic rocks shows that bacteria may greatly accelerate the loss. Rock slices were kept for 355 days in vials of seawater with or without bacteria. The bacteria in question were strains of Desulfovibrio  bacteria that give off hydrogen sulfide much as we give off carbon dioxide. Hydrogen sulfide interacts with the iron in the rocks to form iron sulfide; in doing so, it destroys the magnetic signal. And after 355 days, the rocks kept with bacteria gave off a lower signal than the rocks kept in seawater alone. Bacteria, it seems, can efficiently reduce the magnetic signal of young rocks.  No one knows, yet, how significant such effects are. Moreover, we're only beginning to make an inventory of who's down there  the identity of most intraterrestrials remains mysterious. But given their vast numbers, and the range of their activities, these small organisms from the weird world of the rocks below the sea will probably turn out to have a big-time influence on the composition of the oceans and the rocks of the seabed.   **********  NOTES:  For bacteria of the Mariana Trench, see Kato, C., Li, L, Nogi, Y., Nakamura, Y., Tamaoka, J. and Horikoshi, K. 1998. "Extremely barophilic bacteria isolated from the Mariana Trench, Challenger Deep, at a depth of 11,000 meters." Applied and Environmental Microbiology 64: 1510-1513. For the term intraterrestrials, see Pedersen, K. 2000. "Exploration of deep intraterrestrial microbial life: current perspectives." FEMS Microbiology Letters 185: 9-16.   For bacteria in rock samples from deep below the seafloor, see D'Hondt, S. et al 2004. "Distributions of microbial activities in deep subseafloor sediments." Science 306: 2216-2221. For 1 million-1 billion bacteria per gram of rock, see Santelli, C. M. et al 2008. "Abundance and diversity of microbial life in ocean crust." Nature 453: 653-657. Estimates of the number of intraterrestrials varies; but all the evidence suggests that the numbers are likely to be enormous. See, for example, Schippers, A. et al 2005. "Prokaryotic cells of the deep sub-seafloor biosphere identified as living bacteria." Nature 433: 861-864.  For microbes and the weathering of volcanic glass, see Thorseth, I. H., Torsvik, T., Furnes, H. and Muehlenbachs, K. 1995. "Microbes play an important role in the alteration of oceanic crust." Chemical Geology 126: 137-146, and Fisk, M. R., Giovannoni, S. J. and Thorseth, I. H. 1998. "Alteration of oceanic volcanic glass: textural evidence of microbial activity." Science 281: 978-980.  For a selection of bacterial metabolic activities in the seabed, see table 1 of Edwards, K. J., Bach, W. and McCollom, T. M. 2005. "Geomicrobiology in oceanography: microbe-mineral interactions at and below the seafloor." Trends in Microbiology 13: 449-456. For bacteria increasing the rate of weathering, see Edwards, K. J., Bach, W., McCollom, T. M. and Rogers, D. R. 2004. "Neutrophilic iron-oxidizing bacteria in the ocean: their habitats, diversity, and roles in mineral deposition, rock alteration, and biomass production in the deep-sea." Geomicrobiology Journal 21: 393-404.   For bacteria reducing the magnetic signal of young basalts, see Carlut, J., Horen, H. and Janots, D. 2007. "Impact of micro-organisms activity on the natural remanent magnetization of the young oceanic crust." Earth and Planetary Science Letters 253: 497-506.   Many thanks to Julie Carlut, Katrina Edwards, Dan Haydon and Stephen Porder for insights, comments and suggestions.    ************  Editors' note: In an earlier version of this essay, "iron sulfide" was in one instance mistakenly referred to as "iron sulfur." It has been corrected.

description: SAN DIEGO  There was a time when the United States Open could not have seemed more aptly named, when the winners of the tournament were rarely non-American.

title: Overhaul Is Set for N.Y. Governors Police Unit
description: The state police unit that protects and travels with the governor will be overhauled in an effort to ensure that governors do not exert improper influence over the troopers or compromise their security decisions, one of several officials briefed on the changes said on Tuesday.

title: With One Eye on Gasoline and the Economy, Congress Keeps the Other on November
description: WASHINGTON  Congress is shifting quickly to a general election footing, with lawmakers of both parties intensifying efforts to exploit public alarm about gasoline prices and the economy as a way of making the political case for themselves and their respective White House contenders.

title: Philippine Television Crew Believed to Be Kidnapped
description: MANILA  A television news team from the Philippines largest network, including one of the countrys best-known journalists, was believed to have been abducted by members of the militant group Abu Sayyaf, officials said Tuesday.

title: The Explanation: Climb Here to Combat Malaria
description: During his psychiatric examination at Bellevue last week, Renaldo Clarke was asked a series of routine questions  routine, that is, if youve just scampered up the side of a building 746 feet tall.

title: A Missing Staple Puts Many a Maine Chowder Recipe in Jeopardy
description: CHEBEAGUE ISLAND, Me.  Few pantry items can inflame an entire island, let alone a region. But not many snack foods have a history and following like that of the Crown Pilot cracker.

title: Putting Meat Back in Its Place
description: LETS suppose youve decided to eat less meat, or are considering it. And lets ignore your reasons for doing so. They may be economic, ethical, altruistic, nutritional or even irrational. The arguments for eating less meat are myriad and well-publicized, but at the moment theyre irrelevant, because what I want to address here is (almost) purely pragmatic: How do you do it?

title: A Violinist With Stories to Share (and Sing)
description: One evening last month, the violinist Jenny Scheinman settled in for her customary early set at Barbs, the cozy Park Slope bar that has long been her second home. Though she has been heralded over the last five years as a venturesome improviser, her first number was a vocal feature, I Was Young When I Left Home, one of many traditional songs associated with the young Bob Dylan. Ms. Scheinman, cradling her violin in the crook of an elbow, sang in a clear, agreeable tone, with a hint of nasal twang.

title: To Save Fuel, Airlines Find No Speck Too Small
description: The nations airlines are scrutinizing every step of their operations, from the tarmac to the sky, and from the nose to the tail of their planes, searching for new ways to cut their soaring fuel bills.

title: Questions on U.S. Beef Remain
description: About 50 countries, including Korea, Taiwan and Japan the last of which accounted for 36 percent of American beef exports closed their doors to American beef after the first confirmed case of mad cow disease was found in Moses Lake, Wash., in December 2003.

title: Bank of America Sells Its Equity Brokerage
description: Bank of America is selling its prime brokerage operation to BNP Paribas for around $300 million after a six-month bidding process, according to people briefed on the deal.

title: In a New World, Less Can Mean More
description: CHEAPNESS has many manifestations. A perfect example is the 1950s monster movie cheapness that Frank Zappa once sang about, with creatures that looked like giant poodles and visible nylon strings attached to the jaw of a giant spider. I love that sort of cheepnis, as Zappa put it. Who doesnt? The schlock and the camp were appealing precisely because they were an affront to pomposity and pretension.

title: Austria: Ex-Captive No Longer in Coma
description: A 19-year-old Austrian woman, whose illness helped expose the secret of a 73-year-old man accused of locking several family members in a cellar for up to 24 years, has been revived from a medically induced coma, according to hospital officials. The woman, Kerstin Fritzl, is the eldest daughter of Elisabeth Fritzl, who the authorities say was imprisoned and raped by the man, Josef Fritzl, her father, bearing seven children. Mr. Fritzl freed his captives after taking Kerstin to the hospital.

title: Ban All Nuclear Weapons

title: Records Tumble and Sweaty New Yorkers Grumble as Heat Persists
description: New York is famous for its superlatives. On Tuesday, the city did not disappoint.

description: Anyone and Everyone, which looks at how various couples took the news that their child is gay, ultimately decides to be an advocacy film rather than a documentary. But before it does, it tells some truly moving stories of the power of parental love.

title: O.K., Dad, Just This Once You Can Play With Your Food
description: Though they may seem a bit  shall we say it?  corny, these corn holders in the shape of golf balls by Charcoal Companion are actually a practical gift for a golf-loving dad. They are easy to grip, and a set of eight is $9.99 from mortongolfsales.com.

Championship. Asked Tuesday if he had considered that possibility, Immelman quickly answered: No.

description: More than 100 people have been arrested in New York City this month as part of a continuing effort to crack down on buildings with outstanding fire code violations  everything from a Costco in Brooklyn to a Merrill Lynch in Manhattan to small auto repair shops in Queens and the Bronx.

It is 42 percent, not 48.

description: DENVER  Colorado experienced the nations largest rate of growth in impoverished children from 2000 to 2006, according to a study released Tuesday.

description: TOKYO  Japans salarymen, famous for their work ethic and their corporate loyalty, fueled this nations industrial rise. But more recently, they have borne the brunt of its economic decline, enduring lower wages, job insecurity and long hours of unpaid overtime.

description: A business owner who had pledged not to sell her property to make way for Columbia Universitys expansion has reached a deal with the university, Columbia officials said on Tuesday.

Kipkalya Kones, the roads minister, and Lorna Laboso, assistant minister for home affairs, both in the leading opposition party, were flying to a town west of Nairobi to oversee a local election.

description: Ohio must stop using a common combination of three chemicals to execute condemned inmates because they may produce excruciating pain, a state court judge there ruled Tuesday.

The Broadway belter Martin Vidnovic chose as his role model the now half-forgotten Italian tenor Sergio Franchi, whom he discovered while in high school in Virginia in the early 1960s.

title: Russia: Nickel Producers Profit Falls
description: OAO Norilsk Nickel, the worlds biggest producer of nickel and palladium, reported an unexpected decline in profit for 2007 after cutting almost $2 billion off the value of mining and power companies it bought last year. Net income fell 11 percent, to $5.32 billion, or $29.20 a share, from $5.97 billion, or $31.70 a share, a year earlier, said the company, which is based in Moscow.

title: How Many Goodly Creatures Are There on Mr. Herzogs Planet
description: Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable. In his documentary Encounters at the End of the World, this professional madman and restlessly curious filmmaker travels to the blinding white of the Antarctic, where he meets melancholic scientists, brooding journeymen and various poets of the soul who, ensconced in the American headquarters, McMurdo Station, have traveled so far beyond the familiar coordinates  so far beyond traditional cities, suburbs and banal existence  that they might as well be on another planet.

title: Scorpions for Breakfast and Snails for Dinner
description: IN Beijing, where my family lives, I once returned home from a restaurant with a doggy bag full of deep-fried scorpions. The next morning, I poured them instead of imported raisin bran into my 11-year-old sons cereal bowl. I wanted to freak him out. The scorpions were black and an inch long, with dagger tails.

title: Mexico: Antidrug Aids Strings Intact
description: A plan to help Mexico fight drug trafficking emerged from a House-Senate conference in Washington with controversial human rights conditions intact, although softened in response to objections from Mexican officials and the White House, officials said. The initiative will send $400 million to Mexico. Fifteen percent of the money will be conditioned on governments holding their security forces more accountable for abuses.

title: Fuel Protest Begins to Pinch in Spain
description: MADRID  The customer ordered a tortilla  a traditional Spanish potato omelet  but Graciela Gmez Torea, owner of the San Telmo cafeteria in Madrid, sadly shook her head.

description: SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill.  A senior sergeant complained that the attention to the ground wars in Iraq and Afghanistan had left the Air Force short of personnel.

Paulson Jr. left Goldman Sachs and joined the Bush administration hoping to use his expertise and contacts to ease economic tensions with China. His other goal was to stop Congress from passing legislation that might make tensions worse.

description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was gracious in her full-throated endorsement of Senator Barack Obama. But that does not mean all is forgiven by others in the Clinton universe.

description: CAIRO  Emad Refaat strode out of his workshop with purpose, his grease-covered hands pointing down the road even before he could see the road. Come here, he said, his voice strong with reassurance. Go to the light, make the first right. Thats Salah el-Din Street.

description: LOS ANGELES  The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California issued a water alert on Tuesday, asking communities to modernize and toughen their water conservation rules.

title: Austens Inspiration
description: A portrait of the man believed to have inspired the character of Mr. Darcy in Jane Austens Pride and Prejudice is going on sale for 50,000 (about $98,000) at an antiques fair in London, the BBC reported. Thomas Lefroy, right, born in Ireland, met Austen in 1796, when both were in their early 20s. They had a flirtation, but Lefroy, whose family was poor, married an heiress. The watercolor portrait, 3 inches by 1 1/4 inches, was painted in 1798 by George Engleheart, and will be on sale at the Grosvenor House Art & Antiques Fair, which runs Thursday to next Wednesday. ... Christies in New York will put hundreds of James Brown items up for auction on July 17, Reuters reported. The 320 lots in The James Brown Collection include a rhinestone Sex Machine belt buckle, handwritten lyrics, instruments and grooming items, and are estimated to take in about $1 million.

description: PARIS  The Spanish police on Tuesday arrested eight men suspected of giving financial and logistical support to a terrorist group in Algeria linked to Al Qaeda, Spains Interior Ministry said.

title: Fresh From the Fire, Dressed-Up Ciabattas
description: Jonathan and Nina White, who own Bobolink Dairy in Vernon, N.J., also bake breads in a wood-fired oven. Among them is a ciabatta thats about 20 inches long and paved with the dairys own Cheddar cheese, $5. Portions of it, warmed, make a sumptuous breakfast. With ham or bacon on top you have lunch. And thin toasted slices can be passed on a board with cocktails. Another option is the Whites duck fat and garlic ciabatta, also $5, to accompany soup or salad or to eat with cured meats.

title: When Golfs Past, Present and Future Met in Denver
description: It was a multigeneration conflict impossible to imagine in another sport: at the 1960 United States Open golf championship, three men who defined their eras in their sport battled one another nearly to the end of 72 holes on a course in Denver. Ben Hogan was 47, a savvy shotmaker ending his career; Arnold Palmer was 30 and about to be golfs populist king; and Jack Nicklaus was 20, a powerful amateur still at Ohio State.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about policy reversals by President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela mistranslated part of a nickname that critics use to describe his proposed intelligence agency reform, which they say will force people to spy on each other. As the article noted, the nickname, the Getsapo Law, is a play on the words Gestapo and sapo, which as slang means snitch. But sapo literally translates as toad  not frog.

The state-owned newspaper, The Herald, said the government would give amnesty to prisoners to open space in the jails for those convicted of political violence. The opposition, whose members are being jailed in large numbers, interpreted the plan as a signal for an intensified crackdown.

title: Technology and Food Yield Choice at Charity
description: With its airy dining room, round tables and sleek wood chairs that look like something from a SoHo showroom, the new St. Johns Bread and Life center in Bedford-Stuyvesant bears very little resemblance to the traditional soup kitchen.

title: John S. Zinsser Jr., 84, Book Popularizer, Is Dead
description: John S. Zinsser Jr., who as editor of Readers Digest Condensed Books in the 1960s, 70s and 80s made nearly 800 carefully crunched versions of popular books available to millions of readers, died on May 27 at his home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 84.

description: Eliot Asinof, whose journalistic re-creation of the 1919 Black Sox scandal, Eight Men Out, became a classic of both baseball literature and narrative nonfiction, died Tuesday in Hudson, N.Y. He was 88 and lived in Ancramdale, N.Y.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the defensive end Justin Tuck of the New York Giants in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday morning to unveil a sidewalk plaque commemorating the Giants historic win over the heavily favored New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLII.

description: LOS ANGELES  Strawberry Shortcake was having an identity crisis. The it doll and cartoon star of the 1980s was just not connecting with modern girls. Too candy-obsessed. Too ditzy. Too fond of wearing bloomers.

description: In the past 48 hours, Wall Street has issued a sobering message: The days of easy money from the Federal Reserve are nearly over.

description: The pesto lineup  basil, mint, cilantro, tomato  works overtime in summer, being slathered on chicken or fish for the grill, dolloped into cold soup or served as a dip or hors doeuvre spread. New to the American market are pumpkin seed pestos from Austria, the country that has already given us pumpkin seed oil for flavorful drizzling.

description: WASHINGTON  A Democratic proposal to impose heavier taxes on big oil companies stalled in the Senate on Tuesday as Republicans and Democrats offered different ideas on how to deal with soaring energy costs.

description: BAGHDAD  The leader of Saddam Husseins tribe was killed by a bomb on Tuesday, after he had spoken publicly in favor of reconciling with the government in Baghdad.

title: Second Date With a Little Black Dress
description: Deborah Voigt is finally putting on that little black dress.

title: A Stuntman Dies Making Woo Film
description: A 23-year-old stuntman died and six others were injured in a fire in Beijing while shooting a historical epic by the director John Woo, The Associated Press reported. The films crew and Chinese news media reported on Tuesday that the accident occurred on Monday morning while filming an action sequence for Red Cliff. A small boat was set ablaze and collided with a larger boat as the filmmakers had intended, but the fire quickly raged out of control and engulfed both craft. Mr. Woo, told of the news while promoting his film in Hong Kong, rushed back to Beijing, the crew said. Red Cliff, about a well-known battle in feudal China, has suffered casting changes and set problems since it started filming.

title: A Name Change in Philadelphia
description: Last year Live Nation, the giant concert promoter, renamed a handful of clubs and small theaters around the country to give them a unified brand: Fillmore, after Bill Grahams famous clubs in San Francisco and New York. In Philadelphia the Theater of the Living Arts became the Fillmore at the TLA, and in New York, Irving Plaza became the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza. The Philadelphia club has now reverted to its old name, but Live Nation said it had no plans to change the name of the New York club. Although Fillmore is a valuable and powerful brand, which we remain committed to, the company said in a statement, the fans in Philadelphia made it known to us that the Theater of the Living Arts was a more relevant name in their local community.

title: Dying in Detention
description: The government has a duty to provide decent, effective, timely medical care to people in its custody. That should be beyond debate, but not when the government in question is the Bush administration and the people in custody are illegal immigrants.

title: Even the Most Romantic of Poets Can Sometimes Be Awfully Hard of Heart
description: Once the world was whole, in Antiquity and the Middle Ages, Heinrich Heine wrote. There was still a unity in the world and there were complete poets. We rightfully honor these poets and take pleasure in their poetry; but any aping of their wholeness is a lie.

What remains of the original choreography, from different 19th-century versions, is debatable; its music, by Ludwig Minkus, is not much more than nicely dancey; its relationship to the Cervantes novel minimal; its Spanishness a matter of flourishing fans and wearing capes.

title: Channeling Noir, Dickens-Style
description: Last year Tree of Smoke, a sweeping novel by Denis Johnson, below, about the Vietnam War, won the National Book Award for fiction, and this year it was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. But Mr. Johnson is not resting easy. Beginning with its July issue, which arrives at newsstands on Friday, Playboy will publish his next novel, Nobody Move, in four monthly installments of 10,000 words each, to be written on deadline each month through the October issue. The magazine described Nobody Move as a hard-boiled noir in the style of Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett, but Mr. Johnson said he was also inspired by an earlier writer. Ive always admired Charles Dickens, who wrote big, involved novels in monthly installments, he said in a statement, and I wanted to find out what it was like. Its a little nerve-racking.

title: A Soulful Sojourn Backtracks to Voltage
description: On his last two albums, the recent Jim and Multiply in 2005, the British musician Jamie Lidell all but foreswore the cold, jagged electronic music with which he first made his name in favor of straightforward, classic soul. With his sheepish and gawky persona, Mr. Lidell seemed an unlikely candidate for such a switch, but thanks to his tender voice and taut, faithful arrangements, the results were astonishingly sincere and often great.

title: Indonesian Village Struggles With Ban on Muslim Sect
description: MANIS LOR, Indonesia  A large sign spans the road just outside the main mosque in this quiet, well-kept village in West Java here reading, in big red letters, Banned. Residents pass beneath the sign every day on their way to the market, work or school.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A brief report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about observations of Saturns F ring misidentified the journal in which the study appeared. It was in Nature, not Science.

title: U.S. News Plans to Publish Biweekly and Expand Consumer Focus
description: Critics have carped for some time that U.S. News & World Report had stopped being a newsweekly  that both news and weekly were questionable descriptions.

title: Brazil: Economic Growth Slows
description: Brazils economy grew 5.8 percent in the first quarter, powered by higher consumer spending that is stoking inflation and forcing the central bank to raise interest rates. The growth rate slowed from 6.2 percent in the last three months of 2007. Brazils statistics agency also reported that exports had fallen 2.14 percent from a year ago, their first quarterly decline since June 2006.

title: China Lets Towns Ruins Wash Away, in Effort to Avert Disaster Downriver
description: BEIJING  Low-lying areas in one of the towns most devastated by the May 12 earthquake were flooded Tuesday as a torrent of water was released from a dangerous lake formed by landslides, dislodging wrecked homes, cars and corpses.

title: Realitys Low Numbers
description: Reality television proved lackluster in the ratings on Monday as ABC and NBC struggled opposite mostly repeat fare on CBS and Fox. According to Nielsens estimates, Episode 2 of The Mole had the weakest ratings, drawing 4 million viewers for ABC at 10 p.m., following The Bachelorette from 8 to 10 (6.4 million). ABC finished fourth for the night, just behind NBC, which garnered similarly low ratings for American Gladiators at 8 (5.6 million) and the debut of the singing competition Nashville Star from 9 to 11 (6.6 million). CBS was the nights highest rated network with a lineup of mostly comedy repeats followed by a rerun of CSI: Miami (8.6 million), the 10 p.m. time-slot leader. Fox was in second place with repeats of Bones at 8 (7.3 million) and House at 9 (8 million). ... On Sunday two popular cable series made strong second-season premieres. At 9 p.m. the History Channels Ice Road Truckers garnered 3.9 million viewers, the highest rating ever for a premiere on that channel, and at 10 p.m. Lifetimes Army Wives delivered 4.5 million viewers, that channels largest audience in its 24-year history.

title: Energy Agency Reduces Forecast for Oil Demand
description: Global oil demand is expected to grow at a slower pace than previously expected this year as a result of record prices and shrinking subsidies in some emerging countries, a leading energy forecaster said on Tuesday.

title: Campaigns Collide Over McCain Remark
description: WASHINGTON  The war over the war exploded anew here on Wednesday. Advocates and spinmasters for both presumptive presidential nominees jumped into all-out battle after Senator John McCain, when asked whether he now had a better idea when American troops could return home from Iraq, replied, No, but thats not too important.

title: 2 New-Style Candidates Hit Old Notes on Economy
description: For all the efforts of Senators John McCain and Barack Obama to portray themselves as willing to break with party orthodoxy to get things done, the economic debate that opened their general election campaign this week previews a classic clash. It is a battle between Republican supply-side economics and a Democratic tradition that uses government levers to try to reduce inequality and spur the economy.

title: Indias Fiscal Gains Offset by Rising Prices
description: NEW DELHI  Since a low-key economic liberalizer named Manmohan Singh became prime minister four years ago, Indias economy has soared by nearly 9 percent a year on average and per capita income is nearly double that of a decade ago.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Apples new iPhone models misidentified the location of the headquarters of Gartner, a market research firm. It is based in Stamford, Conn., not San Jose, Calif. (Mike McGuire, a Gartner vice president who commented on Apples strategy, is based in San Jose.)

title: Hope and Doubt Greet Peace Deal in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Peace is no small feat in Somalia, and if the reaction to the accord struck on Monday night is any gauge, peace may still be a long way off.

description: SAN DIEGO  The atmosphere changed at Torrey Pines on Tuesday. description: BRUSSELS  Competition Commissioner Neelie Kroes of the European Union delivered an unusually blunt snub to Microsoft on Tuesday by recommending that businesses and governments use software based on open standards.

description: DETROIT The financier Kirk Kerkorian said Tuesday that he would increase his stake in Ford Motor Company to 5.5 percent after stockholders offered to sell him nearly half of the automakers outstanding shares.

description: Argentina suggests red meat on the grill. But in many of the malbecs we tasted I found hints of soy sauce, intriguing vegetal flavors and touches of spice. Then why not just add a splash of soy sauce to a green chimichurri?

title: A Far-Too-Dangerous Business
description: Something is very wrong with how buildings are going up in New York City. After 15 deaths of construction workers and bystanders this year, the city is just beginning to get serious about making construction safety a priority. It must do more to fix not just questionable equipment, but a broken system.

title: Vatican City: Focus on Islam Criticized
description: A senior Vatican official said that the West had become obsessed by Islam, to the detriment of other religions involved in interfaith dialogue. The Roman Catholic Church has to have regard for all religions, said the official, Cardinal Jean-Louis Tauran, the president of the Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue, in an interview posted on a Web site of The Holy Land Review, which is published by an American church organization.

title: Guilty Plea Given in Iraq Contract Fraud
description: WASHINGTON  A retired Army colonel who has been a focus of a wide-ranging criminal inquiry into contracting fraud in Iraq pleaded guilty on Tuesday to steering a military contract for warehouses in Iraq to a contractor for $4,000 and a vacation to Thailand.

title: Mets Bullpen to the Rescue in Delay
description: The Mets had an entertaining rain delay Tuesday night at Shea Stadium after the sixth inning of their game against the Diamondbacks. As Pedro Feliciano took the mound as the new relief pitcher for the Mets in the top of the seventh, the grounds crew was on the infield to smooth the dirt of the base paths with brooms.

title: New Faces on Fox News
description: Still seeking a new format for the 5 p.m. hour, the Fox News Channel will use a rotating series of people in that time slot, beginning next week with the conservative radio host Laura Ingraham, left, the channel announced on Tuesday. Fox appears to be grooming Ms. Ingraham, who often fills in for Bill OReilly, as a new host. According to the blog the Radio Equalizer, Ms. Ingraham took a sudden leave of absence from her nationally syndicated radio show last week, apparently because of a contract dispute. Other hosts will have trial runs after her in the weekday slot. Foxs schedule has been remarkably stable in recent years, helping it maintain consistently high ratings, but it has made several tweaks over the past year. In February it replaced John Gibson, the longtime host at 5 p.m., with an election-oriented show. In another change The Live Desk With Martha MacCallum at 1 p.m. will be expanded to two hours and add a co-host, Trace Gallagher. Fox has not determined the new role for E. D. Hill, the current 2 p.m. host.

description: The two heavyweights in Group A of the European Championship, the Czech Republic and Portugal, both looked good, rather than great, as they won their opening games.

title: In Germany, Bush Protests Lose Appeal
description: BERLIN  The young anarchists, middle-aged peace activists and established left-wing politicians here have at least one thing in common: none bothered to keep a six-year tradition alive by organizing a protest against President Bushs arrival here Tuesday.
