title: Kelly Declines to Testify
description: R. Kelly told the judge in his child-pornography trial on Tuesday that he did not plan to testify in his own defense, The Associated Press reported. After Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court in Chicago told Mr. Kelly he had a right to decline to testify, he leaned forward at the defense table with his hands folded and  speaking for the first time at the trial  responded, I decided not to testify. The defense rested its case on Monday, and the jury was not present to hear Mr. Kellys statement. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to charges that he videotaped himself having sex with an underage girl. Mr. Kelly and the woman, said to be the victim, who is now 23, have denied being on the tape. The judge said that closing arguments would probably begin on Thursday.

title: Bellevue Is Allowed to Medicate Suspect
description: A lawyer for a schizophrenic man accused of killing an Upper East Side psychotherapist tried three times on Tuesday morning to persuade his client to leave his holding cell for a hearing. Each time, the lawyer, Ben Bernstein, got little response from his client, David Tarloff.

title: 50 Cent Can't Sell Long Island Home
description: A judge has told 50 Cent, left, that he may not dispose of the Long Island property where a $2.4 million house, above, was destroyed by fire two weeks ago, The Associated Press reported. Justice Carol R. Edmead of State Supreme Court in Manhattan also ordered him to put insurance proceeds in a trust account pending the outcome of his dispute with his ex-girlfriend, Shaniqua Tompkins. Ms. Tompkins says 50 Cent, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, promised her a house a decade ago, but recently wanted to evict her and their 10-year-old son, Marquise, from the house in Dix Hills, on Long Island. A fire destroyed the house on May 30. Ms. Tompkins, Marquise and four others were treated for smoke inhalation.

description: A fire on the PATH train tracks near the Ninth Street station in Greenwich Village knocked out service between West 33rd Street in Manhattan and New Jersey on Tuesday, snarling the way home for tens of thousands of commuters on a hot and steamy day.

description: Forty years ago, the New York business magnates Laurence A. Tisch and Preston Robert Tisch capitalized on growing public health concerns over smoking by buying a cigarette company at a bargain price.

title: XTO Agrees to Buy Hunt Petroleum for $4.2 Billion
description: HOUSTON  XTO Energy agreed on Tuesday to buy the Hunt Petroleum Corporation for nearly $4.2 billion in cash and stock, adding some profitable oil and gas wells to its portfolio. But the deal is also adding fuel to the fire of a family feud embroiling the Texas dynasty founded by the legendary oilman H. L. Hunt.

title: Most Experts Foresee a Repeat, at Least, of 2007 Arctic Ice Loss
description: Fourteen research teams studying the impacts of warming on the Arctic Ocean have issued independent projections of how the sea ice will behave this summer, and 11 of them foresee an ice retreat at least as extraordinary as last years or even more dramatic. The other three groups that issued a numerical estimate see the ice extent heading back toward, but not equaling, the average minimum for summers since satellites began tracking the comings and goings of Arctic sea ice in 1979. Five other groups chose not to issue a numerical estimate.

description: Daniel W. Drezner, a political economist at Tufts University and a veteran blogger, has posted a provocative essay about public intellectuals on his site. He argues that contrary to what has become the conventional wisdom, there has not been a decline in the quality of American intellectual life from the postwar glory days of Lionel Trilling, Edmund Wilson, Mary McCarthy and others who constituted the circle now known as the New York Intellectuals. Drezner goes on to list a battalion of contemporary public intellectuals to prove his point, everyone from Barbara Ehrenreich to Tom Wolfe to Samuel Huntington.

I envision maybe a million micro-refineries, he says.  Newsweek

title: Godless
description: This Father's Day, one of most popular pastors in America will open his megachurch to homosexual dads, an event that would usually signal an extreme weather alert from old guard Republican evangelical leaders.  (Photo: Rick Warren. (Credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images for Meet the Press)) But by welcoming gay fathers into his Southern California flock, Rick Warren, author of the "The Purpose Driven Life," is not just living up to the highest standards of Christian fellowship, he's turning the page on a particularly embarrassing part of our politics.   Just to refresh: it was televangelist Pat Robertson who predicted "earthquakes, tornadoes and possibly even a meteor" would hit Orlando for inviting gays to Disney World, and Rev. John Hagee who blamed Hurricane Katrina on a vengeful God angered over a gay pride parade in New Orleans. And they did this even without Doppler radar.   The fact that these people were taken seriously about anything other than, say, what color socks to wear on bingo night, tells us something about how far we've strayed rom the pulpit into the town square.   Over the last 30 years, church and state have become far more entangled than any of our fair-minded founders and their better successors -- including some chiseled on Mount Rushmore -- envisioned.   The good tidings from Warren's Saddleback Church come at a time when Barack Obama has ditched his incendiary ex-preacher, and John McCain has separated himself from the apocalyptical Hagee.   It's a start, but how about a clean break? Let's go Godless for the rest of the campaign.  I know, it's not going to happen, with Obama courting evangelicals this week and McCain trying to figure what makes Catholics in the Rust Belt tick.   But for a moment, imagine no religion, as John Lennon sang.   Forty-eight years ago an Irish Catholic presidential candidate said this about a bedrock principle of his:  "I believe in an America where the separation of church and state is absolute."  And, "I believe in a president whose views on religion are his own private affair."  That was John F. Kennedy, of course, sounding light years removed from Mitt Romney, who declared this year that "freedom requires religion," and Mike Huckabee, who called himself a "Christian leader" and advocated amending the Constitution to follow Biblical principles. Both men are being touted as running mates for McCain.  "Where we are today is almost the antithesis of Kennedy's time," said David Domke, a professor of communications at the University of Washington and co-author, with Kevin Coe, of "The God Strategy: How Religion Became a Political Weapon in America."   Not so long ago, politicians could talk about national defense or currency fluctuations without having to mention Him. But since 1980, the total number of references to God in major presidential speeches has jumped 120 percent over the preceding half-century, Domke and Coe found.   "It's the verbal equivalent of an American flag lapel pin: few notice if you do it, but many notice if you don't," Domke and Coe wrote in a recent essay in Time. Domke, by the way, is no tweedy secularist; his wife is a Presbyterian minister.   Obama has been the more overtly God-centric candidate in this campaign, perhaps because of the whispers that falsely paint him as a Muslim, or interchangeable blondes on Fox News who interpret playful hand gestures with his spouse as "a terrorist fist jab," as E.D. Hill said on air.  At a meeting with prominent Christian leaders on Tuesday, Obama discussed his "personal journey of faith," as one participant recounted. That, alone, goes against Kennedy's dictum of keeping it private.   Teddy Roosevelt, a McCain hero, was prescient on this point as well. He argued against putting, "In God We Trust," on the currency in 1907, saying it cheapens the divine. "It not only does no good," he wrote, "but it does positive harm."  (Photo: Ted Haggard. (Credit: AP Photo/Erik Stenbakken, New Life Church)) To their credit, some ministers have learned from their fallen fellows of the cloth. Four years ago, Ted Haggard's phone number was on speed dial at the White House, and he regularly boasted of his political clout as head of the 30-million-member National Association of Evangelicals.   Then came his admission of patronizing a gay prostitute and buying crystal methamphetamine, a two-fer in the hypocrisy sweepstakes. It also made for one the strangest images on television -- a smiling Haggard in his S.U.V., with wife and kids, talking about meth and massages from a buff male escort.   On the plus side, Pastor Ted is now welcome at Rick Warren's church on Sunday.  Joel Osteen, the feel-good Texas optimist who is perhaps the nation's most popular minister, and Warren have both disavowed politics this year. They will not endorse a candidate, allow politics in the service, or issue thinly disguised election "guidelines," hint, hint.   Bless 'em.   Now let the politicians pick up the cue, following advice of one of Teddy Roosevelt's Rushmore face mates.  "Say nothing of my religion," said Thomas Jefferson. "It's known to my God and myself alone."  **********  POSTSCRIPT: Following news of the plan by gay fathers to attend Saddleback Church this coming Sunday, the church's pastor, Rev. Rick Warren, has issued a statement clarifying the church's role. "We did not invite this group, and I will not be meeting with them," he said, adding that he had a previous commitment and would not be in church on Sunday.

Klinsky, 52, runs a private equity company; the mother, Maureen Sherry, 44, left her job as a managing director for Bear Stearns to raise their four young children (two boys and two girls); and the dog, LuLu, is a soulful Lab mix rescued from a pound in Louisiana.

title: Harry Potter Prequel Goes for $61 a Word
description: An 800-word handwritten prequel to the Harry Potter series by J. K. Rowling was sold for nearly $49,000, or just over $61 a word, on Tuesday at an auction for charity in a London bookstore, The Associated Press reported. The story, on both sides of a sheet of A5 paper (about 5 7/8 by 8 1/4 inches), was auctioned at the flagship store of the Waterstones chain to benefit a dyslexia charity and the English branch of PEN, the writers association. In addition to Ms. Rowling, right, 12 writers and illustrators contributed short stories on cards, including the novelists Doris Lessing, Nick Hornby and Margaret Atwood and the playwright Tom Stoppard, whose mystery story sold for more than $7,000. Copies of the cards are on display in Waterstones stores and online at Waterstones.com, and will be collected into a book available in August.

title: Green Jackets, Not Gold Medals
description: The image of Tiger Woods standing on a podium with an Olympic gold medal around his neck probably inspires heavy breathing among golf officials and some Olympic executives, but the bet here is that we'll never see it , nor should we. The start of the United States Open today at Torrey Pines, with all the anticipation about Woods's return from knee surgery and his pairing with Phil Mickelson, is a perfect reminder that major championships provide the most valid and respected measuring sticks in golf, and that the renewed effort to make it an Olympic sport is a fool's errand.

description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown faced down a revolt within his governing Labor Party on Wednesday, winning a precariously narrow victory in the House of Commons for a measure that among other things would allow the authorities to hold terrorism suspects for up to 42 days without charges.

title: Interrogation for Profit
description: Congress is finally moving to ban one of the Bush administrations most blatant evasions of accountability in Iraq  the outsourcing of war detainees interrogation to mercenary private contractors.

title: An Imitator That Rivals the iPhone
description: The story so far: Apple introduced the iPhone a year ago, and has sold six million of them. Then on Monday, Apple unveiled an improved model that brings faster Internet, G.P.S. and a much lower price to an already well-designed device.

title: What Women Want (Maybe)
description: LADIES! Behold the splendor of the nude male form: sleek and powerful, a miracle of sculpted sinew, striding confidently across the sand or stretching out before you in ever-uncoiling glory.

title: Corrections
description: Sports

title: Nepal: Deposed King Leaves Palace
description: The worlds last Hindu king, Gyanendra of Nepal, turned in his scepter and bird-of-paradise plumed crown, and he announced that he would live as a commoner, accepting the will of the countrys new Maoist-led government. Nepal became a republic last month and Gyanendra, now known as Gyanendra Shah, had been given about two weeks to vacate the Narayanhiti Palace in Katmandu, the capital. He left for a smaller summer palace outside the capital. The palace is to be turned into a museum.

title: Credibility Gap?
description: The charges by a former N.B.A. referee that the league used its referees to manipulate the outcomes of games has rocked the sport and put the league on the defensive. Do you believe the charges, and if so, how serious a blow is it to the league's credibility. If you don't believe them, why not?

title: Bill to Extend Jobless Benefits Stalls in House
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Wednesday narrowly defeated a plan to provide added unemployment aid for Americans whose benefits are running out after Republicans, bolstered by a White House veto threat, opposed the measure.

title: Building a Better Ankle
description: Bionic ankles dominated the chatter coming from the latest annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, especially a study that followed more than 5,000 ankle-surgery patients in California over the course of 10 years, including those who have had complete ankle-joint replacement.

title: Video Draws Attention to Growing Violence Against Minorities in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Shamil U. Odamanov used to call his parents almost daily from Moscow, where he worked as a laborer after moving from his village in Russias North Caucasus region in search of a better job. Then, just over a year ago, the phone calls stopped.

title: Footnote
description: Alan Gilbert, who will take over as the music director of the New York Philharmonic in the 2009-10 season, has been named conductor laureate of the Royal Stockholm Philharmonic. He is the third person to hold the title in the 106-year history of the orchestra.

title: Unlike Others, U.S. Defends Freedom to Offend in Speech
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A couple of years ago, a Canadian magazine published an article arguing that the rise of Islam threatened Western values. The articles tone was mocking and biting, but it said nothing that conservative magazines and blogs in the United States do not say every day without fear of legal reprisal.

title: No Beating Basketball
description: With Tuesday nights television ratings again dominated by ABCs live coverage of the N.B.A. finals, Fox and CBS shared runner-up status: CBS was second in total viewers, Fox second among adults 18 to 49. Fox got a lift in that demographic from the nights highest-rated nonsports program, Hells Kitchen, at 9 p.m., which drew a solid if less impressive audience of 8.8 million total viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. Foxs Moment of Truth at 8 p.m. attracted 6 million. CBS, despite finishing virtually even with NBC for third place in the 18-to-49 set, fared consistently well in total viewers with reruns of NCIS at 8 (10 million) and Without a Trace at 10 (8.3 million), as well as 48 Hours Mystery at 9 (9.1 million). ABCs audience for the third game in the Los Angeles Lakers-Boston Celtics series appeared to exceed Sundays Game 2 ratings, which averaged 13.5 million viewers when Nielsens final ratings were released.

title: Harmonious Tension and Dueling Flaxen Locks
description: On Raising Sand (Rounder), the spooky, beautiful album they released last year, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss tilt toward each other from starkly different vantage points: heat-blistered arena rock (his) and coolly plaintive bluegrass (hers). Their material, scouted out by the producer T Bone Burnett, mines a deep, dark region of Americana somewhat familiar to them both. But their chemistry springs partly from contrast; even the most harmonious moments convey a subtle, fruitful tension.

title: Hedge Funds Can Vote at CSX Meeting
description: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that two hedge funds seeking to win a proxy fight at the CSX Corporation had violated securities laws by not disclosing their positions and intentions many months before they did.

title: At Practice, 2 Giants Are Conspicuous in Absence
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Giants took the field for the first time in the post-Michael Strahan era, it was the absence of two other stars that threatened the teams harmony and quickly dimmed its championship glow.

title: Four Years On, Clinging to Lower Status
description: Kathy Griffin returns for a fourth season of Kathy Griffin: My Life on the D-List, bearing an Emmy Award. Literally: she carries her 2007 trophy for outstanding reality program around her living room, musing, Winning the Emmy was great, but, hey, the statue doesnt pay the bills around here, honey.

title: Some Shark Populations Collapsing
description: Some shark populations in the Mediterranean Sea have completely collapsed, according to a new study, with numbers of five species declining by more than 96 percent over the past two centuries.

title: Until Sudden Death, an Immigrant Worker Toiled Six Days a Week
description: The routine never changed. Six days a week, Lauro Ortega shuttled from pit to pit, taking another construction job. At the end of each week, he sent more than half of his weekly salary of about $700 to his wife and two children in Ecuador. On Sunday, he went to church and prayed.

title: Tornado Kills 4 in Iowa Boy Scout Camp
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Four teenagers were killed and 48 people were injured when a tornado tore through a Boy Scout camp in western Iowa on Wednesday night, according to a spokeswoman for the Iowa Homeland Security Division and news agency and local newspaper reports.

title: White House Names 6 for Medal of Freedom
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Peter Pace, who was denied a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff a year ago because of the war in Iraq, will receive a Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nations highest civilian award, the White House announced on Wednesday.

title: East Meets West, and Elegantly Sits Down
description: The name of Doshi Leviens new sofa, My Beautiful Backside, might not sound as if it has genteel origins, but inspiration for it came from a painting we have in our studio that illustrates a maharani, or a princess sitting on the floor with a multitude of cushions, said Jonathan Levien. Mr. Levien, a designer based in London who created the piece with Nipa Doshi, his Indian-born partner, explained that it fuses an Indian way of sitting with the European typology of a sofa. Because the backrest is made up of cushions of varying sizes printed with metal foil patterns on the back, it is suited for placement in the middle of the floor, rather than against a wall. A prototype, on view at the Moroso showroom in SoHo, is $18,500. Production pieces, available late this fall, will start at $14,300. Moroso, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 334-7222 or www.morosousa.com.

title: Mets Alou Is Left Discouraged After Hurting His Calf Again
description: Moises Alou is injured yet again, and he is not sure how seriously. But Alou described himself as frustrated, disappointed and embarrassed by his frequent absences from the Mets lineup. Im not out yet, he said Wednesday, but Im pretty down.

title: Norway: New Rights Granted to Gays
description: The Parliament granted gay and lesbian couples the right to marry and to adopt children on an equal basis with heterosexual couples. The countrys new universal marriage act, which also allows lesbians to be artificially inseminated in Norwegian medical facilities, supersedes a domestic partnership policy. No longer will there be different classes of love, Erling Lae, the chief commissioner of Oslo, told an online newspaper minutes after the Parliaments 84-41 vote, adding that he now plans to marry his male companion of 26 years.

title: One Evening, Five Works for Final Leg of the Spring
description: Saving the worst for last, Series C of Marathon 2008, the final, frustrating collection of short plays produced by the Ensemble Studio Theater this spring, features a few good ideas, the occasional lovely phrase but not one completely satisfying work.

title: A Gardeners Purple Prose
description: There are many familiar pleasures in The Unlikely Lavender Queen: A Memoir of Unexpected Blossoming (Broadway Books, $23.95), which chronicles Jeannie Ralstons transformation from a proto-Carrie Bradshaw type into a lavender farmer in Texas. Ms. Ralston is a true New Yorker, the sort of changeling born elsewhere (in her case, Tennessee) who feels at home for the first time in Manhattan. But she falls in love with a handsome Texan who plucks her from her life as a freelance writer and parks her on 200 acres in Blanco, Tex., leaving her largely alone to build their dream house, as his work as a photographer requires months-long absences. She also raises two sons, and then fields of lavender, turning tiny Blanco into the states lavender capital. Whats unfamiliar is the resolution: After 10 years of finding her way in a foreign land, when her peripatetic husband wants to sell their home because land values have risen so much, she acquiesces. I realized I wanted a happy home, she writes, versus this particular home. Now they live in Mexico. Last week she admitted: Im not quite over the house, but I am over the lavender. Nonetheless, shell be reading this weekend in Blanco, at the Lavender Festival she started.

title: Lawmakers Seek to Close Foreign Lobbyist Loopholes
description: Loopholes that lobbyists for foreign clients sometimes use to keep their activities under wraps would be closed under legislation that two Democratic senators are expected to offer on Thursday.

title: The National Challenge: Finding Offense
description: While our friends across the pond battle it out in the European Championship, the U.S. team faces its own high-stakes international competition this Sunday, playing Barbados in the national team's first qualification match for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. And though we can (and often do) talk until we're blue in the face about soccer's growth in America, one fact remains: The U.S. attack needs a serious upgrade.

title: A Couple Grapple for Love, and Love of Achievement
description: LAS VEGAS  Friends say Patricia Miranda and Levi Weikel-Magden argue like an old married couple, but really, they argue more like what they are  married wrestlers with law degrees.

title: Safety Starts at the Top
description: Brookline, Mass.

title: Canada Offers an Apology for Native Students Abuse
description: OTTAWA  The government of Canada formally apologized on Wednesday to Native Canadians for forcing about 150,000 native children into government-financed residential schools where many suffered physical and sexual abuse.

title: Sprucing Up the Start Menu
description: Q. I have so many programs on my PC that it takes me forever to find them in the Windows XP All Programs menu. Is there a way to customize the order they appear?

title: On a Highway, Looking for the Exit to Fame
description: It takes more than a video camera and a good idea to make convincing reality television. That is abundantly clear in the first episode of The Road Hammers, an eight-part series that was broadcast in Canada last year and will be shown on the Great American Country channel beginning Thursday night. Hammers follows the members of the country band by the same name as they try to translate Canadian success  they are award winners and veterans of an earlier reality series there  into fame and fortune in Nashville.

title: Putting You Look Tired to Rest
description: IRY CHANG is sick of people telling her she looks exhausted. She gets enough sleep, but the dark circles under her eyes still elicit stares and make her look much older than her 25 years.

title: Popular Garca Just Cant Seem to Win the Big Ones
description: SAN DIEGO  Sergio Garcas winning smile was once the spark for a series of whimsical television beer commercials. A would-be king, Garca is still popular with golf galleries, and with his bright wardrobe he is easy to find on fairways and greens. A title contender in every tournament he enters, he remains ranked among the worlds golf elite.

title: The Plight of the Underinsured
description: It is well known, by now, that almost 50 million Americans lacked health insurance for all or part of last year. What is less well known is that 25 million Americans who did have health insurance often found it pitifully inadequate when a medical crisis hit. They were only marginally better off than those who had no coverage at all.

title: To Light Up New York, Wed Have to Run Hard!
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping High-End Resale
description: MICHAELS 1041 Madison Avenue, New York; michaelsconsignment.com.

title: Neil MacNeil, Among First of TV Reporters on Congress, Dies at 85
description: Neil MacNeil, who covered Congress for Time magazine through seven presidential administrations and was among televisions first Congressional correspondents, died Saturday in Bethesda, Md., where he made his home. He was 85.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Japans Upper House Censures Prime Minister
description: TOKYO  The opposition-controlled upper house of Parliament passed a nonbinding censure motion against Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda on Wednesday, the first against a prime minister in postwar Japan.

title: A Winning Formula Is Written for the Mets
description: More than a six-run homer, more than a couple of perfect games back to back, what the Mets need now is leadership, sweet leadership.

title: Iowa Flooding Prompts Evacuations
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  The supply of water in Cedar Rapids was dwindling and electricity was scarce and likely to be spotty for days after parts of the city were submerged by flooding from the Cedar River. A local hospital rushed to evacuate 176 patients.

title: Fish Got to Swim, Birds Got to Fly, Genres Got to Meld
description: Carnegie Hall is justly renowned for its splendid acoustics. Yet because the sound of Isaac Stern Auditorium, the halls principal performance space, is so warm, rich and present, using amplification there has typically been a challenge. Like a prickly diva, Ms. Carnegie recoils when microphones and speakers are set up on her stage.

title: No Time Off for Olbermann
description: Keith Olbermann, below, the host of Countdown on MSNBC, canceled his time off this week when it appeared likely that he would score a ratings victory over his competition at the Fox News Channel once last weeks numbers were tallied. Sure enough, with an average of 477,000 viewers in the 25-to-54 demographic, he beat Foxs OReilly Factor by 5,000, according to Nielsen  a first in the five-year history of Countdown. (As usual, however, Bill OReilly had about twice as many total viewers, and on the three days the two hosts went head to head the Fox host won among the demographic.) Hoping to win a second week, Mr. Olbermann, who has engaged in increasingly bitter mudslinging with Mr. OReilly, has delayed his vacation indefinitely. But on Monday Mr. OReilly was back on top, attracting 60,000 more 25-to-54 viewers than Mr. Olbermann. Mr. OReilly doesnt appear worried. He took a vacation day on Friday.

title: A 21st-Century Profile: Art for Arts Sake, and for the U.S. Economy, Too
description: If all the professional dancers in the United States stood shoulder to shoulder to form a single chorus line, it would stretch from 42nd Street for nearly the entire length of Manhattan. If every artist in Americas work force banded together, their ranks would be double the size of the United States Army. More Americans identify their primary occupation as artist than as lawyer, doctor, police officer or farm worker.

title: Second Thoughts on Pulling the Guard From the Border
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  Swooping low over the Mexican border in her Blackhawk helicopter, Chief Warrant Officer Christina Engh-Schappert of the Virginia National Guard spots ... nothing. No sign of the migrants who would congregate in the washes for the mad dash to the United States. No clusters of people hiding in the bushes. Nobody in the throes of dehydration and heat exhaustion.

title: American Aid Is Seized in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwean authorities confiscated a truck loaded with 20 tons of American food aid for poor schoolchildren and ordered that the wheat and pinto beans aboard be handed out to supporters of President Robert Mugabe at a political rally instead, the American ambassador said Wednesday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Wednesday about airlines efforts to save fuel misidentified the employer of the airline workers shown checking dirt cleaned from a jets engine. They work for Southwest Airlines, not Northwest Airlines.

title: Times Hires New Chief of the About Group
description: The New York Times Company announced on Wednesday the appointment of Cella M. Irvine as chief executive of the About Group, which includes About.com, the information and advice Web site.

title: India: Larger Bid for Esmark
description: Essar Steel Holdings, an Indian steel maker, plans to raise its bid for Esmark, a steel maker in West Virginia, by 12 percent to about $750 million to thwart a bid by Severstal of Russia. Essar intends to raise the bid to $19 a share, from $17 once the two companies sign a merger agreement, the company said. Essar also said it would negotiate a collective labor agreement with the United Steelworkers union.

title: Manslaughter Charge in Trench Collapse
description: The owner of a Brooklyn construction site where a day laborer died in March when earth and debris collapsed on him was charged with manslaughter on Wednesday. In announcing the indictment, at a time in which construction-related deaths in New York are running far ahead of last years pace, the authorities said that more construction-related prosecutions may be ahead.

title: Rough Events at Mexican Rodeos in U.S. Criticized
description: TURLOCK, Calif.  It always begins at noon in a dusty arena, with brisk salutes on the brims of glittering sombreros and mustachioed horsemen in three-piece suits.

title: Commodity Prices Show No Letup
description: CHICAGO  Commodity prices went wild on Wednesday, with the price of corn shooting through the $7 barrier for the first time, soybeans and wheat moving up sharply and oil jumping more than $5 a barrel.

title: Shaken Korean Leader Promises New Beginning
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-bak pledged a "new beginning" on Wednesday as he contemplated reorganizing his unpopular government, which has been shaken by the biggest anti-government demonstrations in two decades.

title: So Young, and So Gadgeted
description: EVERYONE knows that babies crawl before they walk, and that tricycles come before two-wheelers. But at what age should children get their first cellphone, laptop or virtual persona?

title: Chief Executive Resigns at Martha Stewart Living
description: The woman who kept Martha Stewarts company going while the homemaking doyenne served prison time stepped down on Wednesday, raising fresh questions about whether the company can find its way in a tough economy.

title: Petty Enterprises Sells Stake to an Equity Firm
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Outside investors have poured into Nascar in recent years, buying stakes in race teams eager for an influx of money as the cost of competition rises.

title: Obama Camp Courts Clinton Fund-Raisers
description: With Senator Barack Obamas campaign manager scheduled to meet Thursday with top fund-raisers for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in New York, there is resistance from at least some in her once-vaunted network to supporting Mr. Obama.

title: Lithuania Approves Guggenheim Project
description: The government of Lithuania approved construction of a new museum in Vilnius, its capital, on Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported. A joint project between Lithuania, the Guggenheim and the State Hermitage Museum in Russia, the museum will be designed by Zaha Hadid and is to open in 2013. This is an important project, in a move to attract tourists to Lithuania, Gediminas Kirkilas, the countrys prime minister, told reporters. It is also important to Lithuanias image. The estimated value of the project, shown above in a rendering, is $117 million, with the Lithuanian government to pay 10 to 15 percent of the total. The museum will build its own collection and display art from the Hermitage and the Guggenheim. Arturas Zuokas, a former mayor of Vilnius who is an organizer of the project, said the museum could draw 400,000 visitors a year, half of them from outside Lithuania.

title: Chief Judge Contributed to Racy Web Site
description: The chief judge of the federal appeals court in California, Alex Kozinski, has contributed to a Web site that featured sexually explicit materials, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday.

title: Yankees Veras Making the Most of His Chance
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Jos Veras visited Alcatraz on Wednesday, taking a morning boat ride to the island with Mariano Rivera and Edwar Ramrez, his teammates in the Yankees bullpen. They heard tales of Al Capone and Machine Gun Kelly and marveled at the hopelessness.

title: In Kentucky, Reinterpreting English Gardening for a Bluegrass Climate
description: ONCE a house is built and its interior decorated, it is pretty much finished unless the owner feels the need to add something new. A garden is different. Plants change, maturing into large and vibrant shapes or dying back. They cannot be ignored.

title: Robbins the Contrarian Will Now Bow, Thanks
description: You think you know me? No, you dont. The need to resist categorization goes deep in many of the greatest performing artists, and in many of the greatest creative artists too. Part of the fascination of the current Jerome Robbins Celebration from New York City Ballet is to see how hard he worked throughout his career to escape pigeonholing. I could do without the title of its latest program, Generation Next, but Im grateful for how well it demonstrates his resistance.

title: At Minicamp, 2 Giants Are Conspicuous by Their Absence
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Giants took the field for the first time in the post-Michael Strahan era, it was the absence of two other stars that threatened the teams harmony and quickly dimmed its championship glow.

title: Ultrathin Laptop Starts Up Quickly and Comes With a Brand Name That Gamers Love
description: The Voodoo PC brand, favored by gamers, and the brothers behind it, Rahul and Ravi Sood, did not disappear when it became part of Hewlett-Packard. The latest Voodoo is the ultrathin Envy 133, which will be in stores and on Hewlett-Packards Web site this month.

title: Putting the Riviera in the Rental
description: FOR many people, moving into a summer rental means throwing a sheet over the lumpy sofa or rushing out to the hardware store and stocking up on plastic tumblers and paper plates.

title: Charges in Death at Construction Site
description: Correction appended.

title: Honey, Can You Answer That? The Clock Radio Is Ringing
description: The iHome clock radio for the Apple iPhone has not changed radically from versions of the iHome for the iPod. They allowed you to insert the iPod into a dock built into the top of the clock radio for recharging and  here is the cool part  play the contents of the iPod through the clock radios speakers. Thanks to a set of adapters that comes with the new $150 iP99 model of the iHome, the iPhone as well as various versions of the iPod can be docked.

title: Big Browns Trainer Ready to Testify
description: Big Browns trainer, Rick Dutrow, said Wednesday that he intended to be prepared next week when he appears at a Congressional hearing examining safety issues in thoroughbred racing.

title: Modern Samples, Marked Down
description: Property, a SoHo store that sells modern furniture, will hold a floor sample sale from June 23 to 29. The prices of all pieces in the showroom will be reduced 20 to 60 percent, and orders for new furniture placed during the sale will be discounted 20 percent. Floor sample merchandise on sale includes a 94-inch-long 60s Cabinet in light-blue matte lacquer, similar to the one shown here ($4,780); the Urban sofa, upholstered in brown fabric ($5,765); the Eureka hanging chair, made of bamboo with a black seat cushion ($2,316); and the Trach chair, covered in gray and brown fabric ($2,190). Property, 14 Wooster Street (Canal Street), (917) 237-0123 or propertyfurniture.com.

title: Networks Firm Up Convention Lineups
description: Those political aficionados wondering whether Senator Barack Obama looks better from the right or left, take note: in August visitors to the official Web site of the Democratic National Convention will be able to choose from a menu of camera angles as they tune in live, high-definition video streamed from the party gathering in Denver.

title: With the Stroke of a Pen, a Popular Educational Toy That Helps Children Learn to Read Is Simplified
description: What if you could take the popular LeapPad educational toy and shrink it down into a pen? That pretty much sums up the Tag Reading System, available now for $50 from LeapFrog.

title: Bronx Produce Co-op Says Market May Leave the City
description: For 41 years a raucous, muscular ballet of men and trucks, shipping pallets and sweat has unfolded before dawn most days at the Hunts Point produce market in the South Bronx.

title: Irish to Vote on Complex European Union Treaty
description: DUBLIN  The final straw, said Dermot Gilmartin, was seeing an official struggle on television to answer questions about the topic of the hour: the European Unions Lisbon Treaty, which is being put to a referendum here on Thursday. Challenged on a technical point, the official sputtered, began frantically rifling through his papers and fell silent.

title: Claims May Be Bogus, but the Perception Is Real
description: Los Angeles

title: Bush Loyalist Fights Foes of No Child Law
description: NEWPORT, Ky.  Margaret Spellings is not running for office  at least, not yet. But in the waning days of the Bush presidency, she is running one last campaign.

title: Rebuilding New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: Sentences in Goya Theft
description: Two men who stole a valuable Goya painting are going to federal prison, The Associated Press reported. The men, Steven Lee Olson and Roman Szurko, stole Children With a Cart, above, from a transport truck in November 2006 as its drivers spent the night at a motel in Bartonsville, Pa. The work was on its way to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York from the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio. The painting, from 1778, was insured for $1 million. It was eventually returned undamaged to the Toledo museum. In United States District Court in Newark on Wednesday, Mr. Olson was sentenced to the maximum five-year term; the judge said he had led the theft and had an extensive criminal record. Mr. Szurko received a year and a day. Lawyers for the men have said they did not realize the painting was famous when they took it.

title: Grass, Simplified: Hire Someone
description: WARMER weather and longer days mean more time to spend out in the yard. But how do you want to spend that time: relaxing in a lawn chair, or walking behind a lawn mower?

title: A Recycled Pavilion, to Shelter Furniture, Friends or Ferraris
description: On Saturday, the gabled pavilion designed by the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban for Artek, a Finnish furniture manufacturer, will be auctioned at Sothebys for an estimated $800,000 to $1.2 million. The 120-foot-long portable pavilion is open at both ends and has walls, trusses and a roof made of recycled plastic and paper.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the horse trainer Warren A. Croll Jr. erroneously included a race among notable victories by his horse Holy Bull. The horse did not compete in the Jockey Club Gold Cup as a 3-year-old.

title: Texas Leader Vows to Rebuild Governors Mansion After Fire
description: HOUSTON  Gov. Rick Perry pledged Wednesday to rebuild the Governors Mansion, which was damaged by fire on Sunday, and expressed outrage that someone would set fire to such an important symbol of state history.

title: The Netherlands: Staples Sets Deal
description: Staples agreed to buy Corporate Express for 1.68 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after raising its offer three times, becoming the worlds largest direct distributor of office supplies to companies. Staples, which has more than 2,000 stores, will get operations that ship office supplies to companies in Europe, the United States and Canada and add markets in Australia and New Zealand. Staples said it would pay 9.25 euros a share for Corporate Express. The bid was 28 percent more than Stapless original offer made in February. The agreement scuttles a deal Corporate Express struck to acquire a French rival, Lyreco, last month.

title: David Mitton, a Creator of Thomas for TV, Dies at 69
description: David Mitton, a creator of the gentle childrens television series Thomas the Tank Engine and Friends, which evolved into an international hit and a merchandising juggernaut, died on May 16 in London. He was 69.

title: Tornado Hits Scout Scout Camp in Iowa, Killing 4
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  At least four people were killed and about 40 injured when a tornado tore through a Boy Scout camp in western Iowa on Wednesday night, a spokeswoman for the Iowa Homeland Security Division said.

title: Top Secret Files Left on British Train
description: LONDON  The police opened an investigation on Wednesday after secret intelligence assessments of Al Qaeda and Iraqs security forces were left on a commuter train.

title: Police Review Lab Work After Suicide of Scientist
description: New York State Police officials are notifying district attorneys across the state that evidence in criminal cases may have been compromised by a forensic scientist who committed suicide last month after auditors discovered that he had not followed proper procedures in some cases, officials said Tuesday.

title: Now Its Tomatoes
description: Last week, federal officials started alerting consumers to avoid certain raw tomatoes  red plums, red Romas and round reds  that may have infected scores of people with a rare type of salmonella. Many grocers and restaurants rushed to remove all tomatoes from their stock  an over-reaction, but an understandable one.

title: Reflecting, in a Place of Racial Tolerance, the Long Road Traveled, and to Come
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.

title: Palestinian Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Says Economy Was Weak in April and May
description: The economy sputtered along in May and the last weeks of April, as Americans spent less and overall growth stayed soft, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

title: Democrats Criticize McCain on Strategy in Iraq
description: PHILADELPHIA  The presidential campaigns clashed Wednesday over strategy in Iraq as advisers to Senator Barack Obama seized on remarks by Senator John McCain to accuse him of being insensitive to the sacrifices being made by American soldiers.

title: In Postwar Britain, the Grim Face of Victory
description: The historian David Kynastons Austerity Britain: 1945-1951 seems less a book than a scroll. You dont feel that youre turning pages so much as unrolling a single piece of parchment, with facts, figures and, most of all, people moving by in grand procession. There go Churchill, Keynes and other leading politicians and policymakers, also Kingsley Amis, Graham Greene, Isaiah Berlin, J. R. R. Tolkien, a dashing Dirk Bogarde, a young Bill Wyman, as well as dozens of unknowns who happened to keep a diary or utter an especially piquant remark.

title: Not a Planet, but a Plutoid
description: Pluto is still not a planet, but now it is a plutoid. Two years ago, the International Astronomical Union decreed that Pluto was no longer a planet, but a member of a new category known as dwarf planets, bodies that were large enough to be round, but which did not gravitationally dominate their orbital neighborhoods. On Wednesday, the union announced the creation of the term plutoid for a dwarf planet beyond the orbit of Neptune. There is only one plutoid other than Pluto: Eris, the sphere of rock and ice formerly nicknamed Xena that is slightly larger than Pluto.

title: Never Mind Third Hand High; Count the Clubs
description: There were several interesting deals during the open trial to pick the United States team for the World Mind Sports Games in Beijing. In the diagramed deal at the trial, which finished last Friday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., Michael Becker made a great defensive play that would have been missed by many.

title: Can Credit-Card Interest Be Deducted for a Home?
description: Q. If I take out a cash advance on a credit card to use toward a down payment on a home, is the interest I pay on the credit card deductible on my federal income tax return?

title: 6 Deaths in Brooklyn and Queens Are Attributed to Heat
description: Six people in New York City died because of exposure to the heat on Tuesday, the medical examiners office said on Wednesday.

title: The Gravity of Donaghys Accusations Is Unclear

title: A Life of Quality

title: Work at Ground Zero Site Is Behind Schedule
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday that it was running more than a month behind schedule in delivering the site of Tower 2 at the new World Trade Center to the developer, Silverstein Properties. The authority will pay Silverstein a $300,000 daily penalty, beginning July 1, until the site can be turned over fully excavated in August.

title: Be Old Money or Just Look Like It
description: AN arresting image in fashion, these last few weeks, was the wives from the Yearning for Zion polygamist ranch. It is a muscular look primed for cultural combat: identically starched high-collared, pastel box-pleat dresses with huge princess sleeves; shellacked, high, French-braided hair; and Oakley wraparound mercenary sunglasses. You could imagine them stalking out of the courthouse in a horizontal row, slow motion  la Reservoir Dogs, their brown oxfords hitting the ground to the drumbeat of In-a-Gadda-Da-Vida.

title: Correction

title: Britain: Better Late Than Never
description: Prince Charles paid off a 17th-century royal debt of about $900, but he steered clear of paying interest of more than $90,000. On a tour of Worcester, the heir to the throne made the payment of 453 pounds and three shillings, about $900 at present exchange rates, to settle a bill run up by King Charles II in preparation for what turned out to be a losing battle between his forces and Oliver Cromwells. The bill, owed to the Clothiers Company of Worcester for uniforms worn by the royalists in the battle, was left unpaid when Charles fled the country, and it remained unsettled after he returned to claim the throne in 1660. The prince said he was happy to pay the debt, but not the interest. I wasnt born yesterday, he said.

From my green perspective, part of me feels guilty about being such a major consumer.

title: HBO Mines the Web
description: Coming soon to HBO: programming from the creators of the comedy Web site Funny or Die (funnyordie.com), founded last year by the actor Will Ferrell, the writer and director Adam McKay and the writer Chris Henchy. HBO, under pressure to develop a new stable of hit shows, said on Wednesday that it was investing in the site, which is best known for The Landlord, a short video featuring an angry baby. This is HBOs first partnership with an Internet video site, and the investment is for somewhat less than $10 million, according to executives involved with the deal. Funny or Die will produce 10 half-hour shows for HBO. The Internet comedy we do is short-form. HBO gives us a longer-form opportunity, said Dick Glover, the chief executive of Funny or Die. Some of the shows may be episodic, others stand-alone, and the partnership may expand to include a live comedy tour.

A French-Algerian choreographer, Mr. Maalem was inspired by time spent in Lagos, Nigeria, for this work featuring 14 performers from Mali, Benin, Nigeria, Senegal, Togo and Mozambique. In his rendition of Sacre performed on Tuesday night the story of a pagan spring ritual is transported to modern Africa.

title: Tip of the Week: Thinking Green When You Print
description: Hate those printed Word documents that have a few lines spilling over onto the last page? You can save paper by going to Words Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the Shrink to Fit or Shrink One Page button, which has an icon showing multiple pages transforming onto one page. Word will automatically fiddle with the documents text size and spacing to get it all on a single page. But if the shrinkage messes up your formatting or looks too cramped, undo it by pressing Control-Z (Command-Z on a Mac), which reverses the process.

title: Illinois: Museum in Protected Park
description: The Chicago City Council approved a plan to let the Chicago Childrens Museum build a new home in Grant Park, a downtown park that is protected from development. Much of the museum would be underground. With a 33-to-16 vote, aldermen supported Mayor Richard M. Daley, an ardent promoter of the plan, bucking the opposition of the local alderman, Brendan Reilly, and the tradition of giving aldermen power over decisions in their own wards. They understood that the issue was bigger than any one ward, Mr. Daley said. It was about doing the right thing on behalf of all Chicago, especially the children. Mr. Reilly accused the Daley administration of securing the vote through arm-twisting and deal making.

The party had refused talks with the government until her release.

title: Mississippi: Workers End Hunger Strike
description: About two dozen guest workers from India who said they were victims of human trafficking at an oil rig construction company in Mississippi ended a hunger strike in Washington. The workers said the protest was to pressure the Justice Department to allow them to remain legally in the United States while their case is under investigation. They were brought to this country in 2006 and 2007 under temporary visas to work at Signal International, based in Pascagoula. Twenty workers fasted for varying periods over 29 days; five were hospitalized, said Stephen Boykewich of the New Orleans Workers Center for Racial Justice, which organized the protest. After a rally outside the department on Monday, justice officials agreed to meet with workers representatives.

She is "MVP toned and shaped...first-team upstairs in a form-fitting, sleeveless, scoop-neck white top" and a "jacked-up mini." Sports fans will recognize this greens report as the work of Dan Jenkins, who since his seminal golf novel, "Dead Solid Perfect" (1974), has explored the relationship between the gentleman's game, and, well, the gentleman's game. Brannon makes his approach and unfurls his best pick-up line: "Golf is my life -- how about you?"

In a week busy with new releases, Volume 28 of the pop compilation Now Thats What I Call Music!, with songs by Leona Lewis, Lil Wayne, Jordin Sparks, John Mayer and others, opened at No. 2 with reported sales of 185,000. Weezers self-titled album on Geffen bowed at No. 4 with 126,000; Journeys Revelation (Nomota), sold only at Wal-Mart, moved 105,000 to reach No. 5 in its first week. Ashantis new album, The Declaration (Universal Motown), is No. 6 with 86,000, and Jewels country album Perfectly Clear (Valory) is No. 8 with 48,000. Ushers Here I Stand (LaFace/Zomba), last weeks No. 1, fell two spots to No. 3 with 145,000, a 67 percent decrease.

title: Pure Tyranny
description: Righteous indignation is so easy, so pleasant, when you can sit back and fling it overseas.  I had that edifying experience on the D.C. Metro Wednesday morning, reading in the Times about the Muslim women in France who are going to cosmetic surgeons for hymen replacement surgery so that they can bleed as seeming virgins on their wedding nights.   It's a practice that has, apparently, become relatively common in the immigrant communities of Europe. But, of course, it seems like hair-raising news in a country like ours, where a young woman's right to do with her body as she sees fit has, for decades, been enshrined as perhaps the most essential part of her God-given human dignity.  As my 11-year-old says, Yeah, right.   Right after I finished reading the Times piece, I called the French Embassy to find out under what conditions French social security would pay for the hymen-restoration procedure. (It's "mostly done in private clinics and in most cases not covered by tax-financed insurance plans," said the Times article; "Oh la la!" said the receptionist to whom I relayed my query.)  I then started rifling through my desk. And there, beneath a report showing paid family leave to be on the decline, beneath a Newsweek article on a new children's book, "My Beautiful Mommy," that tells the story of a mom who becomes even prettier after a nose job and a tummy tuck, I found the story that the hymen news had immediately brought to mind.  It was also from The Times, from May 19, and featured 70-odd girls, of "early grade school to college" age, with their fathers, stepfathers and fathers-in-law-to-be, at the ninth annual, largely evangelical "Father-Daughter Purity Ball."   "The evening, which alternated between homemade Christian rituals and giddy dancing"  and which culminated, for at least one father and his daughters, with a dreamy walk in the night around a lake, "was a joyous public affirmation of the girls' sexual abstinence until they wed," said the Times article.   "From this, it's only a matter of degree to the man in Austria," I'd scribbled across the first page.  The "man in Austria," of course, was 73-year-old Josef Fritzl, who was around that time also making headlines after it was discovered that he had kept his daughter, Elisabeth, 42, locked up in a cellar for 24 years, during which time he'd raped her regularly, and had her bear him seven children.   ("It was a lovely idea for me, to have a proper family  down in the cellar, with a good wife and a couple of children," he said in his confession.)  Fritzl, a self-described "man of decency and good values," had imprisoned his daughter after she began staying out all night and drinking. "I had to create a place where I could keep Elisabeth by force if necessary, away from the outside world," he confessed.   "Fathers, our daughters are waiting for us," Randy Wilson, one of the ball's organizers, said at the Colorado Springs "Purity" event. "They are desperately waiting for us in a culture that lures them into the murky waters of exploitation. They need to be rescued by you, their dad."  I don't want to take this analogy too far. I don't mean to imply that there's any equivalency between Josef Fritzl's acts and the Purity Ball. Fritzl's actions were uniquely horrific, and I am not accusing the men who danced in Colorado Springs of any crimes. But there is nonetheless a kind of horror to their obsession with their daughters' sexuality. There is a dangerous boundary violation contained in their vow "before God to cover my daughter as her authority and protection in the area of purity." And there is even greater danger to the fact that this particular aspect of the nationwide "abstinence movement" has not been broadly denounced as the form of emotional violence against girls that it indisputably is.  Judith Lewis Herman, a clinical professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, whose work with and writings on incest victims in the 1980s revolutionized the understanding of the crime and its perpetrators, believes that incest, like rape generally, has to be viewed within a wider context of power relations. Incest, she says, is "an abuse of patriarchal power," a criminal perversion of fatherly control and influence. It is perpetrated, in many cases, by men who present themselves as the guardians of the moral order. And it isn't always physical; in her 1981 book (with Lisa Hirschman), "Father-Daughter Incest," she writes that the violation can be emotional, too, as when a "seductive father" oversteps his boundaries and goes places he never should in his daughter's head.   "Something I need from dad is affirmation, being told I'm beautiful," said 19-year-old Jordyn Wilson at the ball. "If we don't get it from home, we will go out to the culture and get it."  Sexual abuse  judging by statistics mostly based upon reports of incest  has greatly decreased in our country in recent years. From 1992 to 2003, substantiated cases went down 40 percent, according to the Crimes Against Children Research Center at the University of New Hampshire. Lisa Jones, a research professor at the center, says she thinks the impressive decrease isn't just due to changed reporting patterns or data collection methods. "We feel like it's very suggestive of a likelihood that there's a real decline," she said.  There are many possible reasons for this improvement. But one, I think, that has to be considered is that girls' and women's status has risen. Acceptance of sexual assault and insult has declined. In a world where girls and women are stronger, "abuses of patriarchal power" are less tolerable, acceptable, and possible.  Or should be.  In highly secular France, the reaction to the drama over young women's virginity playing out in Muslim communities has been public and profound. Justice Minister Rachida Dati recently had to fight off calls for her resignation after she upheld a ruling by a regional court that had annulled the marriage of two French Muslims because the bride turned out not to be a virgin.   Our condemnation of cultural practices and beliefs in our own country that violate girls' and young women's dignity and most intimate personal boundaries should be no less total. For, when it comes to female chastity, much of what passes for "protection" is nothing less than sick.

title: Pure Tyranny
description: Righteous indignation is so easy, so pleasant, when you can sit back and fling it overseas.

title: Screen Actors Guild Says Contract Talks May Extend Into July
description: Associated Press: The Screen Actors Guild said Thursday that talks with Hollywood studios could extend past the end of the current contract on June 30, but was willing to keep actors working without a deal.

title: Mud and Muck in Minnesota's Everglades of the North
description: IT was a Sunday morning at Bemidji Regional Airport in northern Minnesota, and our plane had just left the ground. The wings shuddered as we buzzed above a highway and banked right, climbing in the four-seat Cessna toward clouds and a view so flat the land looked concave.

title: Mixed Feelings as Change Overtakes 125th St.
description: It isnt news that just two or three years ago, Harlem had a paucity of bank branches, grocery stores and other basic amenities, or that now that more affluent people have started to move there, upscale shops and restaurants have followed.

title: In Eastern Iowa, the City That Would Never Flood Goes 12 Feet Under
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  They said this city would never flood. They talked about 1993, and 1966 and 1851, years when the Cedar River swelled and hissed but mostly stayed within its banks. They thought they were safe. They were wrong.

title: Rangers, and Some Drama, Are Headed to Shea
description: Only one of two teams yet to play the Mets at Shea Stadium, the Texas Rangers arrive on Friday with three intriguing story lines.

title: Footnotes
description: Pete Seeger, below, has been added to the lineup of Roots of American Music, the two-day series that closes the free Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. He will appear at 11 a.m. on Aug. 24, the second day of Roots, with his grandson Tao Rodriguez-Seeger and the blues singer Guy Davis, on a bill that also includes Patti Smith, Charlie Haden, the Knitters and the Music Makers Blues Revue. ... Martin I. Kagan has been named executive director of the Paul Taylor Dance Foundation. Mr. Kagan, 61, who has been the executive director of Opera America, managing director of the John Anson Ford Amphitheater in Los Angeles and general manager of Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., succeeds Wallace Chappell, who held the job for four years. ... The Lebanese-born author Rawi Hage has won the 100,000-euro ($154,240) International Impac Dublin Literary Award, billed as the worlds richest prize for a single work of fiction. He won for his debut novel, De Niros Game, about growing up in war-torn Beirut.

title: Like American, More Airlines Add Fees for Checking Luggage
description: For weeks, American Airlines stood alone in facing the ire of passengers over its decision to begin charging $15 to check the first bag. But it now has some company.

title: For Chinas Top Star, Record Is Lost and Challenge Grows
description: Dayron Robles of Cuba set a world record of 12.87 seconds in the 110-meter hurdles Thursday, eclipsing the mark previously held by Chinas most celebrated Olympic star and setting the stage for a potential upset in the countrys most eagerly awaited event at the Summer Games in Beijing.

title: 3rd Guilty Plea in Prostitution Ring
description: A 62-year-old former tax specialist who ran the high-priced online escort service that was patronized by Eliot Spitzer pleaded guilty on Thursday to federal prostitution and money laundering charges.

title: Obamas Campaign Opens a New Web Site to Strike Back at Dishonest Smears
description: KAUKAUNA, Wis.  Confronted with one of the trickiest problems in politics  when to ignore rumors and misrepresentations and when to risk giving them greater visibility by rebutting them  Senator Barack Obamas presidential campaign began to push back aggressively on Thursday against what it said were unfounded and potentially damaging reports.

title: This Land Is Her Land (and Her Artwork, Too)
description: To judge from the museum calendars of the last few seasons, the 70s were segregated by gender: large surveys of Robert Smithson and Gordon Matta-Clark at the Whitney and Richard Serra at the Museum of Modern Art; equally hefty exhibitions of feminist art across the river at P.S. 1 and the Brooklyn Museum. Whats missing is a sense of the decade as radical for male and female sculptors alike.

title: I Do? Oh, No. Not Here You Dont.
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  Thousands of gay and lesbian couples across California are expected to marry next week, when a State Supreme Court decision granting that right becomes official.

title: McCain and Obama Split on Justices Guantnamo Ruling
description: BOSTON  The presidential candidates took differing positions Thursday on the Supreme Court decision granting foreign terrorism suspects at Guantnamo Bay a right to challenge their detention in civilian courts. Senator John McCain expressed concern about the ruling, while Senator Barack Obama lauded it.

title: Deafening Howl, Then Deadly Chaos for Scouts
description: BLENCOE, Iowa  Just before the tornado hit, the Boy Scouts were gathering on the porch of a shelter, playing cards and waiting out what many of them thought was just a pelting rain. In a matter of moments, a scout leader, hearing a faint tornado siren, hurried them inside, and then, as he stared out the open door and saw the twister in the distance, ordered them to dive under tables, survivors said.

title: Art in Review
description: TOM SACHS

title: Unemployment Aid Extension Easily Passes House
description: WASHINGTON  The House took another step on Thursday in a running political fight over unemployment insurance by ignoring a veto threat from President Bush and easily approving an extension of benefits for idle workers whose aid is running out.

title: Something Lethal Lurks in the Rustling Trees
description: The knives had been out and sharpened long before M. Night Shyamalans latest movie, The Happening, opened on Friday. A fine craftsman with aspirations to the canon, this would-be auteur has, in the last few years, experienced a sensational fall from critical and commercial grace, partly through his own doing  by making bad movies and then, even after those movies failed, by continuing to feed his ego publicly  and partly through the entertainment media that, once they smell weakness, will always bite the hand they once slathered in drool.

title: Obama, Liberalism and the Challenge of Reform
description: Is Barack Obama really a force for change, or is he just a traditional Democrat with a patina of postpartisan rhetoric?

title: Music Writer Resigns
description: A music writer and columnist for The San Antonio Express-News resigned on Tuesday after the paper accused him of hiring a ghost writer to produce more than 100 articles since 2001, the paper reported. Ramiro Burr, 52, who had been writing for the paper for 15 years, stepped down as an ethics investigation was coming to a close. Ramiro caused The Express-News to unknowingly publish work under his name that was not, in fact, his own work, said Robert Rivard, the editor. Mr. Burr, whose writing was also syndicated in other newspapers, had contested the allegations but, calling it a difficult situation, told the paper in a statement, I may have been a little overzealous, or overreached in trying to be the best reporter/syndicated columnist I could be. He added, I sincerely apologize for breaking any rules.

title: How to Curb Big Builders Big Appetites
description: PRISCILLA ALMODOVAR, a tiny presence with a towering agenda, is describing the reception she received from some of New York Citys most aggressive  as in profit-conscious  real estate developers after she assumed control of the hitherto myopic New York State Housing Finance Agency during the reform groundswell that characterized the salad days of the Spitzer administration. Before that administration wilted.

title: A Bull Market Sees the Worst in Speculators
description: In Washington, financial speculators have fat targets on their backs.

title: Will the Real Tax-and-Spender Please Fess Up?
description: With the general election in full gear, Senator John McCain has stepped up efforts to paint his rival, Senator Barack Obama, as what he calls a traditional Democratic tax-and-spend liberal. On Tuesday, for instance, Mr. McCain, addressing a business gathering, accused Mr. Obama of wanting to enact the largest single tax increase since World War II.

title: Disputed Blast in Gaza Kills 5
description: JERUSALEM  A large explosion destroyed a residential building in the northern Gaza town of Beit Lahiya on Thursday, killing at least five Palestinians, among them several Hamas militants and a baby girl.

description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening, and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

description: Retail sales picked up last month as Americans received more than $50 billion in stimulus checks. Investors took the report as an encouraging sign for the resilience of the economy, even as some analysts wondered how long the uptick would last.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about severe weather in Iowa referred incorrectly to the president of the chamber of commerce of Cedar Rapids, who released a statement about bridge closings. The official, Lee R. Clancey, is a woman.

title: Moving, Roof, Walls and All
description: ROUGHLY 10,000 private homes are moved in the United States annually, according to the International Association of Structural Movers, the trade association for those who haul everything from houses to lighthouses. Now that doesnt mean that 10,000 people pack up their things and members of the movers group help them carry the boxes (though that would be nice). It means that the entire house is put on a truck or barge, then hauled to another site.

title: Another Great Start, Another Bad Finish
description: The Mets recent losses have come in a sickening loop, one in which the outcome is sensed before the rest of the grisly plot unfolds. One loss is barely distinguishable from the next because only the details  how many runners were left on base, which reliever failed  change from game to game.

title: Invitrogen to Buy Applied Biosystems for $6.7 Billion
description: Invitrogen, an acquisitive provider of cells, probes and chemicals used in life sciences research, has made its biggest purchase yet. It will pay $6.7 billion in cash and stock to buy Applied Biosystems, the company that provided most of the equipment used in the Human Genome Project but that has struggled to adjust since that project ended early in this decade.

description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon on Thursday sought to justify airstrikes that killed 11 Pakistani soldiers by releasing what it said was a videotape of part of the episode.

description: WASHINGTON  The tainted-tomato outbreak has spread to six more states, federal health officials said on Thursday, even as they acknowledged to lawmakers that they had yet to nail down major aspects of a food-safety plan released seven months ago.

title: Courage to Bear Witness to Mans Infinite Cruelties
description: A Promise to the Dead: The Exile Journey of Ariel Dorfman, the opening-night selection of this years Human Rights Watch International Film Festival, may not be the strongest of the programs 19 feature-length films, but its rambling portrait of Mr. Dorfman, the Chilean playwright (Death and the Maiden), novelist and essayist, is a profile in courage colored with the anxiety of a human rights activist faced with painful moral choices.

title: Mighty Climbers
description: United by blood, rope and a serious adrenaline addiction, Thomas and Alexander Huber run up rocks the way some of us run up credit cards  rapidly, fearlessly and with little regard for consequences.

description: AMAGASAKI, Japan  Japan, a country not known for its overweight people, has undertaken one of the most ambitious campaigns ever by a nation to slim down its citizenry.

title: Group Says Satellite Images Prove Rights Abuses in Ethiopia
description: Human rights advocates on Thursday said that Ethiopia has been committing crimes against humanity, including the torture, murder, rape, and forced eviction of civilians, in its crackdown on insurgents in the countrys isolated eastern Ogaden desert region.

title: Harlan Cleveland, Diplomat and Scholar, Dies at 90
description: Harlan Cleveland, a former president of the University of Hawaii and an American ambassador to NATO who pressed for nuclear arms control and strengthening of the United Nations, died May 30 near his home in Sterling, Va. He was 90.

title: With the Perfect Script, the Plot Thickens for the N.B.A.
description: Long before the buzzer sounded on the corrupt officiating career of Tim Donaghy, extraordinary notions of result-rigging occasionally took root in the minds of chagrined fans, in the stomachs of coaches dying a thousand playoff deaths and especially in the simple everyday language in and of the game.

title: Dance Competition Tops Ratings Contest
description: A two-hour episode of So You Think You Can Dance lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, as 8.8 million viewers tuned in to watch the dancers compete from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Although Fox led over all, CBS finished close behind, drawing the nights largest audience with a rerun of CSI: NY during the 10 p.m. hour (9.2 million). CBS earned lower ratings earlier in the night with The Price is Right at 8 (6.1 million) followed by a repeat of Criminal Minds at 9 (8.2 million). Despite trailing just behind CBS in total viewers, NBC won a solid second-place finish among adults 18 to 49 thanks to the strength in that demographic of Deal or No Deal from 8 to 9:30 (8.5 million) and the premiere of Celebrity Circus, which attracted just 6.5 million total viewers from 9:30 to 11. With mostly repeats, ABC finished a distant fourth.

title: Chinese Parents Call Off Quake Memorial After Official Warning
description: BEIJING  Parents who lost children in a particularly horrific school collapse during the May 12 earthquake in Sichuan Province scrapped their plan for a one-month mourning ceremony on Thursday after local officials warned them not to go through with it, two of the parents said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 4 about the Japanese baseball legend Sadaharu Oh misidentified the first Japanese native to go to the major leagues in the United States from the Pacific League in Japan. It was Masanori Murakami, in 1964  not Hideo Nomo, in 1995. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Thursday.

description: Quid Pro Quo hovers in a noir-shaded twilight zone where repressed memories, dreams, desire and guilt merge in an obsession with physical and emotional paralysis. The first feature written and directed by Carlos Brooks, this small, intensely acted film is a psychological detective story that suggests a boutique version of David Cronenbergs Crash or David Finchers Fight Club, but it eventually runs out of courage.

title: V.A. Ban on Voter Drives Is Criticized
description: Voting rights groups are criticizing the Department of Veterans Affairs for its decision to ban registration drives among the veterans living at federally run nursing homes, shelters for the homeless and rehabilitation centers across the country.

description: To the extent that the tenor saxophonist Kidd Jordan is known in the general jazz world, hes known as a New Orleans patriarch and educator. Dig deeper and you might also hear about his long, eclectic career as a sideman and his role in inspiring the formation of both the Dirty Dozen Brass Band and the World Saxophone Quartet. But Mr. Jordan, 73, has never made much of a dent as a solo artist, and he still doesnt have an entry in The Biographical Encyclopedia of Jazz (Oxford).

Britain: Wife of Failed Bomber Is Sentenced to 15 Years
description: A London judge sentenced the wife of one of four men convicted in an abortive plot to bomb London subway trains to 15 years in prison for failing to inform the police of her husbands plans. Yeshi Girma, 32, is the wife of Hussain Osman, who was sentenced to life imprisonment last year for his plan to set off a bomb in West London in July 2005. The failed attack came two weeks after attacks on Londons transit system killed 56 people, including the four bombers.

description: Representative Ron Paul announced on Thursday that he was legally suspending his Web-driven campaign for the Republican presidential nomination.

description: BRUSSELS  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates joined NATO defense ministers here Thursday in an effort to push forward a design for missile defenses that will protect all alliance nations from a potential Iranian ballistic missile attack.

title: Maple Man Has Ideas to Solve Baseballs Bat Problem
description: More than 100,000 pieces of wood hang on a Wall of Shame in the Original Maple Bat Corporations factory in Quebec. Sam Holman, the companys founder and the father of maple bats, said the remnants were put there because they were rejected for making bats.

title: The MetroCard Is the Medium, With No Particular Message
description: Andy Padre, a 40-year-old artist, once went through 35,000 staples in one week, creating massive lilies out of foam and wire that would hang, suspended, over a table at a wedding at the Waldorf-Astoria. While he was working a day job at Microsoft, he once spent several hours every day for a week neatly wrapping every object in his supervisors office in green tissue paper to surprise her upon her return from vacation.

title: Blast in Falluja Damages Sunni Partys Main Office
description: BAGHDAD  A leading Sunni political partys headquarters in western Iraq was blown up early Thursday morning, while in southern Iraq, where Shiite factions have been fighting one another, a powerful bomb was discovered on the road to an important Shiite shrine.

title: The Ghost of Jack Abramoff
description: Jack Abramoff must have been one heck of a lobbyist. He has not set foot on Capitol Hill in years yet is still a major player in everyday Congressional life.

description: BEIJING  Representatives of China and Taiwan agreed Friday to start weekend charter flights next month between the two sides, taking the first step toward establishing regular transportation links that could ease relations.

description: LOS ANGELES  It is one thing to disagree about politics with your spouse at a backyard barbecue. It is quite another to do it in front of the 38 million people of California, with apparent and abundant passion.

description: Trevor Wilkinson, the founder of TVR, the small British carmaker known for nimble little sports cars that early owners often assembled from a kit, died on June 6 in Minorca, Spain. He was 85.

description: CHICAGO  Commodity prices continued to rise on Thursday, with the price of corn remaining above $7 a bushel. Soybeans also moved higher.

title: Bond Star Is Injured
description: Daniel Craig, below, who plays James Bond, was sent to the hospital after suffering a minor hand injury while filming Quantum of Solace, the latest Bond movie, near London, The Associated Press reported. There was a minor incident on set, a spokesman for Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group said on Wednesday. He was back on the set within a matter of hours, and production went on. It was not the first accident thats occurred during the filming; stuntmen were injured in April while filming an action sequence in northern Italy. In other Bond-related news, Sean Connery will offer the first public glimpse of his memoir, Being a Scot, at the Edinburgh Book Festival on Aug. 25, his 78th birthday, The Associated Press reported. The book contains Mr. Connerys views on many aspects of Scottish culture and life, including sport, architecture and, of course, the Gothic tendency in Scots literature, said Catherine Lockerbie, the festivals director.
