title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a new product introduction by Apple Inc. misidentified the location of a market research firm that commented on the companys strategy, and a correction in this space on Wednesday misidentified the product being introduced. The company, Gartner, is based in Stamford, Conn., not San Jose, Calif., and Apple introduced its new iPhone models, not iPods.

title: The Cycle of Seasons Illuminated
description: I take no pleasure in dumping on a 25-year-old pseudo-experimental nature documentary, but neither did I find much to like in Blue Planet. Granted, there are dozens of lovely images to behold in this lush 35-millimeter tone (deaf) poem by the filmmaker Franco Piavoli: the fat fall of plump raindrops; a meadow sculptured by wind; workmen silhouetted at dusk; a scrawl of hieroglyphic sunlight along the surface of a pond, as if Mother Nature were setting out to one-up the painter Cy Twombly.

title: Hirst: A Throwaway
description: Chris Evans, a BBC pop D.J., accidentally discarded a signed Damien Hirst print while packing to move to a new home, the BBC reported. Mr. Evans, 42, told his listeners on Wednesday that the print, one of Mr. Hirsts early dot pictures, had ended up in a charity shop in a small town in Surrey, England, after some boxes were mixed up by his mover. The picture is worth thousands of pounds, Mr. Evans said. ... U2 is selling a painting by Jean-Michel Basquiat that has hung in its studio in Dublin since 1989, the BBC reported. The painting, Untitled (Pecho/Oreja), was made in 1983 and bought at a New York gallery in 1989 by the bands bassist, Adam Clayton. It will go up for auction at Sothebys in London on July 1 as part of a sale of contemporary art. Basquiat died in 1988.

title: Stuck in His Teams Undertow, Santana Sees Another Win Slip Away
description: Johan Santana and Dan Haren opposed each other Thursday for the second time in nearly six weeks. The first time, in Phoenix, Haren was sharper, but the Mets won. In the rematch, Santana dominated, but the Diamondbacks won, 5-4, in 10 innings.

title: Celtics Rally Puts Title Within Reach
description: LOS ANGELES  It took the Boston Celtics 21 years to get back to the N.B.A. finals. On Thursday night, they waited 44 minutes just to take a lead. Once they got it, they refused to let go, and now they stand one victory away from claiming the 17th championship in franchise history.

title: Stern Unconcerned About F.B.I. Inquiries of Bavetta
description: LOS ANGELES  Commissioner David Stern restated his unwavering support for his referees on Thursday and said he was not concerned that at least one referee, Dick Bavetta, had been the subject of inquiries by federal agents.

title: Moodys May Align Municipal Debt Ratings With Corporate
description: Criticized by states and cities for how it rates their bonds, Moodys Investors Service said on Thursday that it was considering rating municipal debt on the same scale it uses for corporate debt.

description: Less than three weeks after Macklowe Properties was forced to sell its trophy General Motors Building and three other Midtown Manhattan office towers to pay off its creditors, William S. Macklowe has replaced his father, Harry, as chairman and chief executive of the vastly diminished real estate portfolio, the company announced on Thursday.

title: Pakistan Angry as Strike by U.S. Kills 11 Soldiers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  American air and artillery strikes killed 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers during a clash with insurgents on the Afghan border on Tuesday night, a development that raised concerns about the already strained American relationship with Pakistan.

title: From the Elusiveness of Schizophrenia, New Clues to Treatment
description: The people who suffer from schizophrenia are hardly the only ones confounded by its symptoms. Scientists are baffled, too, and despite years of study theyve had little success in explaining how the disorder develops, in whom, and why.

title: Homeless but Hopeful
description: So earnest it hurts, Kicking It follows a half-dozen homeless men from around the globe as they ready for the fourth annual Homeless World Cup in Cape Town. Introduced and narrated by the actor Colin Farrell, who sports a thick brogue and thicker eyebrows and intones the thickest of schmaltz (from war-torn Afghanistan to the slums of Africa to the streets and fields of Dublin where even as a child I spent many o me years kickin a football around ...), the movie has its heart in the right place, if not its mind or muscles.

Under new management this year, the festival will feature concerts in new theaters and clubs and some curious and challenging double bills, like the pairing of Cecil Taylor and George Cables, pianists representing very different parts of the jazz spectrum. These are potentially exciting developments for a festival that has seemed stolid at times.

title: Vets Are Going Public

Starting things off is the long-anticipated New York production of Stephen Sondheim and John Weidmans musical Bounce, directed by John Doyle, followed by the latest from the monologist Mike Daisey, If You See Something Say Something; Danny Hoch, a hip-hop playwright, will perform a solo show, Taking Over; and George C. Wolfe, a former artistic director of the Public, will direct A Free Man of Color, John Guares epic about the Louisiana Purchase. Next comes another Public veteran, Tracey Scott Wilson, with The Good Negro, presented earlier as part of the Public Lab series. Then Christopher Durang returns to the Public with a new play, Why Torture Is Wrong, and the People Who Love Them. The downtown season concludes with Craig Lucass Singing Forest, directed by Bartlett Sher. The Public also announced that The Bacchae, with music by Philip Glass and directed by another former Public artistic director, JoAnne Akalaitis, will be a part of the 2009 Shakespeare in the Park season.

title: Zoning Rules Are Flouted by Architect, City Says
description: New York City announced fresh administrative charges on Thursday against a Brooklyn architect whose name has become identified both with the building boom that has transformed large swaths of the borough and with its many excesses.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Bad Cow Disease
description: Mary had a little lamb / And when she saw it sicken / She shipped it off to Packingtown / And now its labeled chicken.

title: Zimbabwe Detains Opposition Leaders
description: JOHANNESBURG  The standard-bearer for Zimbabwes opposition was twice detained by the police on Thursday, and one of his most important deputies was arrested to face treason charges. The events underscored the daunting obstacles to campaigning against President Robert Mugabe in the two weeks before a presidential runoff.

title: Web Tool to Track Con Ed Power Failures
description: When lights and air-conditioners went out in Yorkville and Bensonhurst during this weeks heat wave and thunderstorms, Consolidated Edison customers were able to track the utilitys efforts to restore power in real time online. That is, if they still had power (or a battery-powered laptop or other device).

title: Microsoft Said to End Talks With Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Talks between Yahoo and Microsoft have ended with the two companies unable to reach a deal, Yahoo said in a news release on Thursday.

title: Deadlock on Appeals Court Judges Ends
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee split largely along party lines as it voted 10 to 8 in favor of two nominees from Michigan to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati. The nominees, Helene N. White, a liberal Democratic candidate originally put forward by President Bill Clinton, and Raymond M. Kethledge, a conservative Republican chosen by the Bush White House, were part of a compromise effort to break a years-long deadlock involving candidates from Michigan for the federal appeals bench. But many committee Republicans said the White House should have sought agreement from Democrats for the confirmation of additional Republican candidates. All but one of the Republicans, Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, voted against Ms. Whites nomination, the key to the deal. The full Senate may take up the nomination before the July 4 recess.

title: Are Washington Insiders Necessary?
description: Both presidential candidates have now been bruised by talking the talk of reform while walking the walk of old Washington habits.

title: The Health of Hospitals in California, and in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Absence Could Prove Costly for Giants Burress
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants can fine receiver Plaxico Burress for refusing to take the field during minicamp, and at least one teammate is frustrated by his decision to negotiate a bigger contract by watching from the sideline.

title: U.S. Marshals Continue Search for Missing Trader
description: A manhunt continued on Thursday for a hedge fund manager who disappeared Monday hours before he was to have reported to prison to serve a 20-year federal sentence for conspiracy and fraud in a scheme to cheat investors out of $450 million.

title: The Cross-Country Currents in American Ballet
description: WASHINGTON  On paper the Ballet Across America season unfolding this week at the Kennedy Center is exciting, and it causes excitement in the theater too. On three triple-bill programs nine American companies are dancing one work apiece.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Bloomberg to Give Out $60 Million
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is funneling another enormous set of ostensibly anonymous grants to hundreds of arts and social services groups through the Carnegie Corporation, spreading them over the next two years as he begins establishing his own philanthropic foundation.

title: Justices Rule Terror Suspects Can Appeal in Civilian Courts
description: WASHINGTON  Foreign terrorism suspects held at the Guantnamo Bay naval base in Cuba have constitutional rights to challenge their detention there in United States courts, the Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, on Thursday in a historic decision on the balance between personal liberties and national security.

title: Seeking Free Home, Ex-Legislator Will Get a Prison Cell Instead
description: Calling her actions an outrageous breach of trust, a judge sentenced Diane M. Gordon, a former state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, to two to six years in prison on Thursday for offering to help a developer acquire city land if he would build her a house free.

title: Airline Economies: A Few Modest Proposals
description: Readers of nytimes.com were invited to suggest ways that airlines and passengers could deal with rising fuel prices. Here are some ideas from readers who identified themselves.

title: Vermont to Offer Fuel and Food Assistance
description: Vermont is creating a task force to help residents combat the high prices of gasoline, home heating oil and food, Gov. Jim Douglas announced on Thursday.

title: Mayo Looks to the Future as His Past Is Questioned
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  O. J. Mayo wore a sleeveless Knicks T-shirt soaked in sweat, and blue Knicks shorts and black N.B.A. socks into the media room at the team facility.

title: Bright Waters and an Old-Time Catskills Feel
description: WILD turkeys coursing through the backyard and coyotes howling at the full moon might be among the reasons to buy a second home in Livingston Manor, N.Y. But many weekenders are drawn to the town, which sits at the western edge of the Catskills, by its low-key, artistic temper.

title: Belgium: Gates Pushes NATO Missile Defense System
description: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates joined NATO defense ministers in an effort to push forward a design for missile defenses that would protect all alliance nations from a potential Iranian ballistic missile attack. A senior Defense Department official traveling with Mr. Gates said the United States would press alliance members to agree on options for a defensive system against short- and medium-range ballistic missiles. That future NATO missile defense system would cover territory across the southeastern rim of the alliance: Bulgaria, Greece, Romania and Turkey. Parts of those nations  including almost all of Turkey  would not be covered by a longer-range system that the United States hopes to install in Poland and the Czech Republic.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Schizophrenia
description: Dr. Jeffrey Lieberman is the chairman of the psychiatry department at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and director of the colleges Lieber Center for Schizophrenia Research. He was also a principal investigator in a federal study that compared the effectiveness of an older schizophrenia drug with newer, more expensive drugs. The large, multisite study found that the older drug was generally as effective as the newer ones.

title: Officials Find Expired Items at Drugstores in New York
description: Caveat emptor: When you go into a drugstore in New York City, its best to check the expiration date of common over-the-counter medications, which can be expired even at large national chains, a survey by the state attorney generals office has found.

title: Federal Agency Grounds Light Jet Used as Air Taxi
description: WASHINGTON  A week after both engines on a small jet became stuck at full power as the pilots were trying to land, the Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order Thursday grounding the planes of that model until the throttle controls can be inspected.

title: Cultivating Leisure
description: WHO Regina Regner, 64, a retired registered nurse, and her husband, David, 63, a pharmacist, from Sylvan Lake, Mich. WHAT 3-bedroom house WHERE Suttons Bay, Mich.

title: Caution: Contents Turn Angry When Shaken
description: Five years ago there was a movie about Dr. Bruce Banner, a scientist who, when agitated, turns large and green. It was called Hulk and it didnt do very well, either with critics or with the legions of comic-book fans expected to sacrifice a portion of their pocket money every summer to keep the movie studios afloat. Now Universal and Marvel, every bit as indomitable as their rampaging asparagus-colored intellectual property, have given the franchise another try.

title: Texas: Rare Beach Nesting for Turtle
description: For the first time since the 1930s, federal biologists confirmed that a leatherback sea turtle has nested on a Texas beach, at the Padre Island National Seashore near Corpus Christi. Last Friday, staff members conducting a beach patrol found turtle tracks and a few exposed eggs. They were thought at first to be those of a green turtle. But the eggs and the width of the tracks, more than six feet across, were later determined to be from a leatherback. The giant turtles, endangered around the world, have until now only been known to nest in three spots in the United States  with about three dozen females a year laying eggs on beaches along the east coast of Florida and slightly larger nesting populations in Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands.

title: National Red Cross Campaign Begins as a Logo on a Stock Car
description: IN a perfect world, donating blood would be purely an altruistic pursuit. In the real world, however, the American Red Cross is finding that a little corporate sponsorship  plus a few freebies  helps to coax people to roll up their sleeves.

title: In Rio Slum, Armed Militia Replaces Drug Gangs Criminality With Its Own
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  When several Brazilian journalists decided to go undercover here in May to report on life in one of the hundreds of slums that have sprouted up around Rio, they thought they had chosen carefully.

title: Correction: Rooms With a Viewfinder
description: The Away column last Friday, about the home of two photographers in Rensselaerville, N.Y., misspelled the surname of the chief curator of the International Center of Photography in Manhattan. He is Brian Wallis, not Wallace.

title: Britain: Lawmaker Quits Over Detention Bill
description: The Conservative Partys leading spokesman on security issues, David Davis, announced that he was quitting the House of Commons to protest the insidious, surreptitious and relentless erosion of fundamental British freedoms under the Labor government. Mr. Davis said he would run for the seat again and use the campaign to debate the governments plan to extend to 42 days the maximum period for which terrorist suspects can be detained before being charged. The measure was approved by the Commons on Wednesday.

title: Donors Press Karzai on Corruption
description: PARIS  The United States, Europe and more than 60 other countries and international institutions offered about $20 billion in aid for Afghanistan as part of a big donors conference here Thursday.

title: The Mingling of Dreams and Life
description: Max Kohn (Otto Tausig), the aging Lothario of Love Comes Lately, is very much like the movie itself: doddering and milquetoasty, but ultimately disarming. Blending three short stories by the Nobel laureate Isaac Bashevis Singer, the filmmaker Jan Schtte may well have made a minor classic for the retired-Jews-of-Miami set. In this admirably grown-up tale, with its keen sympathy for autumnal sentiments, he has, at the least, offered mellow counterprogramming to frivolous summer fare.

title: Iraq Seeks Shield Against Claims by Hussein Victims
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Iraqi foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari, said he would ask the United Nations Security Council on Friday to start exploring ways to protect his government from an avalanche of financial claims from people harmed by Saddam Husseins government.

title: Over a River and Into the Woodlands at the Delaware Water Gap
description: ON weekends all through summer, tens of thousands of motorists will find themselves slowing down as they cruise into the S-curves of Interstate 80 at the Delaware Water Gap. Hurrying west to the Poconos, east to the Jersey Shore or far afield to all the other familiar vacationlands, many may glance up, where the speed limit decreases from 65 miles per hour to 50, at the crazily piled rock of one of the Northeasts most interesting geological formations. But most will be only dimly aware that they are skirting one of the most used (though least heralded) sites of the National Park Service.

title: Aid Team Head Says Team Will Have Full Access in Myanmar
description: SINGAPORE, June 12, 2008 (AFP)  A team of aid experts from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the UN will have full access to parts of cyclone-devastated Myanmar, ASEAN's secretary general said Thursday.

title: Orchestral Performance of One Ring to Shrink Them All
description: The Ring Without Words has been one of Lorin Maazels showpieces since 1987, when he assembled this orchestral overview of Wagners four Ring operas for a recording project with the Berlin Philharmonic on Telarc Records. He has performed it in New York with the Pittsburgh Symphony (in 1990) and the New York Philharmonic (in 2000), and when the Philharmonic paid a rare visit to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, he offered it again as the sole work on the program.

title: On Further Review, That Game Was Badly Officiated
description: I watched Game 6 of the 2002 N.B.A. Western Conference finals Thursday in the hope of spotting any signals, winks, nods, smiles or arched eyebrows among the referees that would buttress the accusation by their felonious ex-colleague, Tim Donaghy, that two of them rigged their calls to help the Lakers beat the Kings and advance to a seventh game.

title: On His Birthday, Matsui Gives Yankees Reason to Party
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  When Hideki Matsui arrived at the Coliseum on Thursday, about 30 Japanese reporters greeted him in the parking lot with a strawberry shortcake for his 34th birthday. A few hours later, Matsui returned the favor with a perfect story line.

title: What Do the Simple Folk Do? They Toil and Sing
description: You can almost smell the heather in The Hired Man, a chamber musical at the 59E59 Theaters thats part of the Brits Off Broadway festival. Set in the rolling hills of Cumbria, this intimate show from the 1980s is a far cry from the bigger, better-known, Broadway-devouring British musicals of that era. No whirling turntable piled with flag-waving French students. No masked man scurrying around the smoky bowels of the Paris Opera, fiddling with the light fixtures. Just the small victories and bitter losses of simple folk set against the pleasures and pastimes of the country.

title: Depending on the Kindness of Strangers
description: Set between the devastation of a flood and the safety of a private swimming pool, Beauty in Trouble uses the changing moods of water as both metaphor and frame for the infinite adaptability of human emotions.

title: Staking Claim to a City, With Camera in Hand
description: The title Eminent Domain: Contemporary Photography and the City suggests a history of contested municipal development projects like the Atlantic and Hudson Yards. Instead, this show at the New York Public Library is about the photographers proprietary claim to the urban landscape. That claim was briefly threatened last year by a Bloomberg administration proposal that would have required a permit to film and take pictures in public places.

title: World-Weary Fantasy
description: Youre stifled by rather precarious aesthetics, one character says to another in Pere Portabellas Warsaw Bridge, a film from 1990 that begins a weeklong run at the Museum of Modern Art on Friday. Arent we all? For his part Mr. Portabella seems pretty comfortable with his aesthetic of narrative enigma, elegant camerawork and attractive people who speak in literary and intellectual riddles.

title: On Marthas Vineyard on a Budget. Seriously.
description: MARTHAS VINEYARD, the 100-square-mile triangle of an island off the coast of Cape Cod, has been a summer retreat for New England Brahmins since the 1800s, and has never shed its pricey and exclusive reputation.

title: Two Charged in Getting Drugs for Winehouse
description: The police in London have charged a man and a woman there with supplying drugs to the singer Amy Winehouse, The Associated Press reported. The charges stem from a video that appeared to show Ms. Winehouse smoking crack cocaine. John Blagrove and Cara Burton have been charged with conspiracy to supply cocaine and MDMA, also known as Ecstasy. They were released on bail Thursday and are due back in court on July 1. The police began investigating after pictures from the video were published in The Sun newspaper in January. Detectives say that Ms. Winehouse will not be charged in the case.

title: John Rauch, 80, Coach of Raiders and the Bills, Dies
description: John Rauch, who coached the Oakland Raiders in the second Super Bowl and was later O. J. Simpsons first coach in professional football, with the Buffalo Bills, died Tuesday at his home in Oldsmar, Fla., near Tampa. He was 80.

title: A Question Mark Looms Over 3 Expensive Projects
description: More than two years ago, the Bloomberg administration came up with an aggressively creative way to use tax-exempt bonds to finance two of the most expensive stadiums in the world, one for the Yankees in the Bronx and another for the Mets in Queens.

title: Justice 5, Brutality 4
description: For years, with the help of compliant Republicans and frightened Democrats in Congress, President Bush has denied the protections of justice, democracy and plain human decency to the hundreds of men that he decided to label unlawful enemy combatants and throw into never-ending detention.

title: Trading Pickles for Art Galleries
description: The warning from the National Trust for Historic Preservation that the Lower East Side is one of the 11 most endangered places in America seems fast food for thought. Hasnt that been the case ever since this sliver of Manhattan was laid bare more than a century ago as the crammed tenement haven for immigrants?

title: Europe to Investigate U.S. Exports of Biodiesel Fuel
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union on Thursday accused United States producers of biodiesel fuel of benefiting from subsidies that threaten to put European producers out of business.

title: Classroom Door Gives Immigrants an Entry to Society
description: FRANKFURT  The first four years after Sara Tahir moved to Germany, she barely left her home because she could not speak the language. I didnt want to take a single step without my husband, even to the gynecologist. He had to go with me and translate, she said, turning red with shame just at the memory.

title: A Dangerous Place
description: There is enormous confusion about what happened Tuesday night on Pakistans border with Afghanistan. Pakistani officials say that American air and artillery strikes killed 11 of their paramilitary troops, and some are angrily demanding an end to all military cooperation. The Bush administration says that American forces were firing in self-defense  against Taliban fighters crossing into Afghanistan  and made conflicting statements about whether any Pakistani troops had died.

title: Police: Robbers Used Craigslist
description: Trying to exploit the popularity of iPhones, four men used Craigslist to lure would-be buyers to Brooklyn and then robbed them at gunpoint, the police said on Thursday.

title: Global Image of U.S. Improves Slightly
description: PARIS  There is good news and bad news for President Bush as he pursues his valedictory tour of Europe this week, according to a new worldwide study by the Pew Global Attitudes Project. The image of the United States has improved slightly in many countries over the past year, the poll results show. But the new optimism appears to be driven largely by the fact that Mr. Bush will soon be leaving office.

title: M.L.B. Questioned Over 2004 Steroid Testing
description: A Congressional oversight committee Thursday submitted questions to Major League Baseball and its players union asking whether steroid testing was suspended during the 2004 season and, if so, why they did not tell Congress about it during a 2005 public hearing.

title: Darkness Was Muse for a Master of Light
description: The Starry Night, van Goghs hypnotic canvas from 1889, is one of the Museum of Modern Arts most popular paintings, attracting thousands of visitors every year since it entered the collection in 1941.

title: In Lehman Fallout, Two Stars Are Given Lesser Roles
description: After 10 nightmarish days inside the headquarters of Lehman Brothers, nerves on the 31st floor continued to fray. By Wednesday evening, the president and chief financial officer were out  a dramatic attempt by Richard S. Fuld Jr., Lehmans pugnacious chief executive, to restore confidence in his beleaguered bank and safeguard his own job.

title: A Packed Gallery, but No Masterpieces on First Day of Open
description: SAN DIEGO  Kevin Streelman, who made his first surprise visit to the top of the leader board at Torrey Pines Golf Course five months ago during the Buick Invitational, made his second appearance there on Thursday. Despite a bogey at his final hole, Streelman shot a three-under-par 68 to join Justin Hicks as the co-leader at the 108th United States Open.

title: Regrets Only
description: ELLEN ARCHER loves her weekend home in Sharon, Conn., savoring every moment spent within its 150-year-old walls. The house, a colonial-style from the mid-19th century, has three bedrooms and a screened-in porch and is on a road that time seems magnanimously to have forgotten.

title: Yanks Would Have Interest in Sabathia
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  A painful swing by the Cleveland Indians Vctor Martnez on Wednesday could have significant ramifications for the Yankees. An elbow injury to Martnez all but ended the Indians flickering playoff hopes, and will probably lead to a trade of the ace left-hander C. C. Sabathia.

title: Red Cross Reaches Out to Nascar
description: IN a perfect world, donating blood would be purely an altruistic pursuit. In the real world, however, the American Red Cross is finding that a little corporate sponsorship  plus a few freebies  helps to coax people to roll up their sleeves.

title: Talking to Dogs, Without a Word
description: This will be his earliest memory, The Story of Edgar Sawtelle says about its title character. Red light, morning light. High ceiling canted overhead. Lazy click of toenails on wood. Between the honey-colored slats of the crib a whiskery muzzle slides forward until its cheeks pull back and a row of dainty front teeth bare themselves in a ridiculous grin.

title: Ad Accord for Yahoo and Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsofts four-month-long courtship of Yahoo has finally thrown Yahoo into the arms of their biggest common rival, Google.

title: Most Charges Dropped in Building Climb
description: A grand jury has decided to dismiss criminal charges against Alain Robert, one of two men who climbed The New York Times Building last week, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorneys office said Thursday.

title: Closing Arguments in Kelly Trial
description: In closing arguments at R. Kellys child pornography trial in Chicago, prosecutors replayed the sex tape at the center of the case for jurors, telling them that the man in the video is Mr. Kelly, right, an R&B star, and that he controlled the encounter with the girl, who was as young as 13, The Associated Press reported. Were going to see his direction, Shauna Boliker, an assistant states attorney, told the jury. He is directing her to dance, where to stand, when to stop urinating, she said. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to 14 counts of child pornography. His lawyers have argued that the man in the video is not him and that the reported victim, now 23, has also denied that she is in the video. The prosecution has called 22 witnesses in the monthlong trial, including several relatives of the woman they identified as the girl in the video. The defense attorney, Sam Adam Jr., told jurors that charges against Mr. Kelly came about because people were trying to extort money from him. Thats what this is about, he said, money, money, money.

title: Media Charged With Sexism in Clinton Coverage
description: Angered by what they consider sexist news coverage of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, many women and erstwhile Clinton supporters are proposing boycotts of the cable networks, putting up videos on a Media Hall of Shame, starting a national conversation about sexism and pushing Mrs. Clintons rival, Senator Barack Obama, to address the matter.

title: Sunday in the Dark With Tony?
description: Really, we never learn. After a primary season that proved scientific polling has the precision of a coin toss, after years of losing 10 bucks in the office Oscar pool (darn you, documentary short subject), after Big Brown did whatever he did last week at the Belmont Stakes, you would think we would have come to our senses.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a Planet Green television series on the rebuilding of Greensburg, Kan., after a tornado destroyed most of it in May 2007 misstated the tornados speed. While its winds were estimated at 205 miles per hour, the tornado itself was estimated to have moved through the town at about 20 m.p.h., not 200 m.p.h.

title: Visualizing Schizophrenia
description: Paul Thompson is professor of neurology at the University of California, Los Angeles, and leads the research group at the schools Laboratory of Neuro Imaging. He uses imaging technology to map disease processes involving the human brain, carried out in collaboration with the National Institutes of Health and more than 40 laboratories around the world. A goal is to create disease-specific atlases of the brain that can aid in the diagnosis, treatment and possible prevention of illnesses like schizophrenia.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about a genetic abnormality that raises the risk of blood clots, referred incorrectly to federal legislation that protects against genetic discrimination. The law offers protection in employment and health insurance, but not life insurance. (Go to Article)

title: An Avant-Gardists Sparse Stories, in Film and Fragments
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Chantal Akerman is a hero of the avant-garde cinema. Her most famous film, Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai de Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles (1975), devotes more than three hours to observing a womans domestic routines before climaxing in, as accounts regularly put it, an act of shocking violence.

title: Japanese Culture, in Vivid Color
description: It was probably too much to expect the International Center of Photography to have two excellent group shows of contemporary art in a row. Not many New York museums, especially small ones, manage that regularly. Thus Heavy Light: Recent Photography and Video From Japan, coming after the dense, thought-provoking From the Archive, is just average, or a little less, by the centers own standards.

title: South Korea Seeks a Revised Beef Deal
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said Thursday that it would send its top trade negotiator to the United States to try to revise an agreement on American beef imports that has set off weeks of demonstrations against the government of President Lee Myung-bak.

title: Europe Accuses 2 Utilities of Price Fixing
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission on Thursday stepped up its campaign to increase competition in energy markets by charging the leading suppliers of natural gas in France and Germany with colluding to raise prices.

title: Brown Faces New Protests Over Terror Bill
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown faced down a revolt within his governing Labor Party on Wednesday, winning a precariously narrow victory in the House of Commons for a measure that among other things would allow the authorities to hold terrorism suspects for up to 42 days without charges.

title: Justices, 5-4, Back Detainee Appeals for Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday delivered its third consecutive rebuff to the Bush administrations handling of the detainees at Guantnamo Bay, ruling 5 to 4 that the prisoners there have a constitutional right to go to federal court to challenge their continued detention.

title: As Banks Shun Loans, Hedge Funds Move In
description: Companies traditionally get loans from banks, but with so many lenders stretched and with credit so tight these days, businesses are turning to what might seem like an unlikely source for cash: hedge funds.

title: Salmon Thats Good to Eat
description: To the Editor:

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,089 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: Texas Inmate Says Judge and Prosecutor Had Affair
description: HOUSTON  Lawyers for a Texas inmate facing execution next week filed court papers on Thursday accusing the judge at his double-murder trial of having an affair with the prosecutor.

title: Helping Jobless Youths
description: To the Editor:

title: Selected Studies: Schizophrenia
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Edwina Froehlich, 93, La Leche League Pioneer, Is Dead
description: Edwina Froehlich, who was inspired to help found La Leche League to support breast-feeding after being told at the age of 35 that she was too old to make breast milk for her baby, died Sunday in Arlington Heights, Ill. She was 93 and lived in Inverness, Ill.

title: Permafrost Makes the Heart Grow Stranger in a Haunted Snow Globe
description: After seeing My Winnipeg, Guy Maddins odd and touching tribute to his hometown, I was tempted to do some further research. A few minutes at Wikipedia or the official Web site of the province of Manitoba would surely clarify some of the curious claims Mr. Maddin, the only famous Winnipeg native I can name off the top of my head, makes about the city.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 77 Bowling Green
description: Location: Bowling Green, Ohio

title: Justin Hicks
description: An interview with Justin Hicks, who had one of the best rounds during the first day of the U.S. Open, courtesy of insidetheropes.com.

title: Larry Dorman: First Round Recap
description: The Times's Larry Dorman analyzes the first round, courtesy of insidetheropes.com.

title: Day One at the U.S. Open
description: Justin Hicks, who is ranked No. 722, emerged as the leader at the end of Day 1 at the U.S. Open.

title: Hartsburg to Coach Senators
description: UPDATE 5:15 PM  Here is the story on Hartsburgs hiring from the Ottawa Sun, which reported earlier this week that junior coach Peter DeBoer was about to be hired. Ooops.

title: Schizophrenia and the Brain
The Hunt: June 15, 2008
Celtics Storm Back in Game 4
description: Boston rallied from a 24-point deficit and beat the Los Angeles Lakers in Game 4.

title: Japanese Photography at the ICP
description: The International Center of Photographys show feels a bit phoned in but provides valuable glimpses of Japanese life. Roberta Smith reviews.

title: Another columnist wades in on Trumps Scotland woes
description: The bad reviews keep coming in from Donald Trumps appearance in Scotland to defend his plan to build a golf resort near Aberdeen. A Wall Street Journal column tries to explain why Scotland had turned on Trump. As The Donald is beginning to realize, its not his plans for a world-class golf course near Aberdeen that have incensed so many Scots  its him, according to writer Bill Coles in his entertaining piece, The Donald Dinna Ken the Scots.

title: In slumping Miami, international buyers are a top priority
description: Although hard data is scarce, Miami Realtor association C.E.O. Teresa King Kinney believes 40 percent of transactions in Miami these days involve an international buyer or seller.

title: Bonnaroo: Band List, Later on Thursday
description: MGMTNicole AtkinsGrupo FantasmaBattlesThe SwordThe Felice BrothersSoul Rebels Brass BandVampire WeekendLez ZeppelinDark Star OrchestraPorter-Batiste-Stoltz

title: Bonnaroo: No Need to Work This Crowd
description: Impassive hipster audiences can warp a band. Vampire Weekends guitarist and singer, Ezra Koenig, had to rethink his patter in the face of a Bonnaroo audience. He introduced A-Punk as a song good for dancing, and explained dancing: Its a form of exercise and its great. But Vampire Weekends upbeat pop songs, with their underpinnings of African triplets, had the crowd dancing from their first song. Later, he called for a singalong on One (Blakes Got a New Face), describing the process as if it were unfamiliar. He sang the line and the roar of the audience response nearly knocked the band over. He didnt ask for a louder one. But the bands drummer, Chris Tomson, was wearing a Phish T-shirt, and had attended the first Bonnaroo, Mr. Koenig said to a wave of applause. He also jokingly described Vampire Weekend as a jam band but with shorter songs  which paid off for the crowd, since to play a full-length set the band had to add some new ones.

title: Croatia Triumphs Over Complacent Germany
description: KLAGENFURT, Austria  Germany, the favorite in many experts' minds to win Euro 2008, is rocking. Croatia thought it could cause an upset here Thursday, and then proved it by winning on merit, 2-1. The reality was that Croatia had the better skills, with and without the ball, and ultimately the better match temperament.

title: Two Teams Desperate for a Win Settle for a Tie
description: Ivica Vastic slammed a penalty into the Polish goal with 15 seconds left, Thursday, to give Austria a 1-1 draw with Poland in Group B in Vienna.

title: The Guy Who Wears the Pants in the Family

title: Jarring Segue at 11

title: The Computer Age and Its Carbon Footprint

But think about it: Many of us in the developed world plug and unplug our cellphones, music players, printers and laptops from wall sockets several times a day. It turns out that these goods are responsible for a significant amount of the electricity that we use in homes and offices.

title: Sexism? Who, us?
description: The 2008 campaign has been a very disillusioning experience for a lot of people. You can make a very good case that Barack Obama was the right person for the Democrats to nominate, and Hillary Clinton the wrong choice. But the way we got there was terrible. The raw sexism, in all too many cases coming from alleged progressives  see above  was part of it. So, too, was the inability of many alleged progressives to see that the news media created the narrative of Hillary Clinton as race-baiter in much the same way that, 8 years ago, they created the narrative of Al Gore as congenital liar  by assembling a montage of quotes taken out of context and willfully misinterpreted.

She spends enough time in Paris to really know whats going on (check out her site: www.doriegreenspan.com), she knows how to eat, and her French is 10 times better than mine. So when shes there, and Im there, its a no-brainer. Fortunately, on this trip she was, and on the second-to-last night I was in town she took me to the much-heralded Les Papilles. (Its right around the corner from the Luxembourg Gardens at 30 rue Gay-Lussac; 011 33 1 43 25 20 79.)
