title: Microsofts Internal Letter about Yahoogle
description: In the wake of Yahoos decision to embrace a Google partnership in its ad search business, many have wondered what Microsoft will do next.

title: Iowa Flooding Disrupts Triathlon Qualifying
description: Severe flooding in Iowa has left organizers of the Hy-Vee Triathlon, the last leg of the Olympic qualifying process, scrambling to find a new location for the June 22 race. They believe they have found one, seven miles west of the original site in Des Moines.

title: The Shelf Life of the Roasted Bean
description: Ninth Street Espresso sells Stumptown coffee beans shipped in from the roaster in Portland, Ore., three times per week. Most small batch roasters believe in the mantra that fresher is better, and coffee is at its best when made from beans roasted no more than two weeks ago.

title: First Thoughts on Russert
description: The death of Tim Russert at age 58 is garnering the sorts of blog attention usually reserved for presidents and popes. Heres a quick roundup:

title: A Lawyer With Two Clients at Large
description: Robert G. Morvillo, one of the go-to members of the criminal bar, had some explaining to do this week when two of his law firms high-profile clients appeared to be flouting the criminal justice system.

title: Albany and Mayor at Odds Over Future of Off-Track Betting
description: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson and the leaders of the Legislature announced on Friday a deal under which New York State would take over the financially unprofitable Off-Track Betting operation from New York City, the biggest change in the governance of the state-regulated gambling entity since its creation of 1970. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg  who had moved to shut down the operation, saying that it was not profitable and that it was not in the citys interests to continue running it  said the deal was unfair to the city and immediately vowed to move forward with a plan to close all 71 O.T.B. outposts this weekend. The political dispute meant that the agencys future remained uncertain.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 13
description: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Events include the Puerto Rican Day parade, scorching temperatures, a new home for the Grange and more.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Swapland
description: The reason bartering can work in villages  including, during various periods, Greenwich Village, the Haight-Ashbury and Burning Man  is that village neighbors make and need comparable products. Some corn, some carpentry, an embroidered pillowcase, firewood, horseshoes, quilts. Marijuana. A bottle of water.

title: Brokaw To Host Sundays Meet the Press
description: One of the most pressing concerns for NBC News has swiftly been addressed: Tom Brokaw will anchor the Fathers Day edition of Meet the Press on Sunday.

title: Bloggingheads: Fallen Sports Idols
description: Bryan Curtis, left, of Play Magazine and sportswriter Robert Lipsyte explore how the sports media covers the personal lives of athletes.

title: Iowa Flooding Hits Shawn Johnsons Gym
description: Shawn Johnson, the world champion in the womens gymnastics all-around, had to pack up her things and flee her gym this week because of heavy flooding in Iowa.

title: Signs of Peace in Burundi
description: Burundians hope that recent developments may lead to peace in their country for the first time in 15 years.

title: Signs of Peace in Burundi
description: Burundians hope that recent developments may lead to peace in their country for the first time in 15 years.

title: Club vs. Country, Cavs-Style: LeBron Wins, Lithuanian Loses
description: More evidence that American clubs just dont get the whole playing-for-your-country thing: the Cleveland Cavaliers of the NBA announced today that they will not allow center Zydrunas Ilgauskas to play for the Lithuanian Olympic team at the Beijing Games this summer. The reason? Hes had injuries to his foot and lower back, and his contract is not fully insured.

title: American Album
description: Two preachers hope to save at least some of the souls who pass the strip of all-night waffle houses and gas stations in Breezewood, Pa.

title: Good to See You. Is It You?
description: Regarding full disclosure, dear reader, I feel I know you well enough by now to confide that, yes, it was at Yale that I myself learned what it means to be gay.

title: At the End of the Earth
description: One of the most forlorn countries in the world is Central African Republic, CAR. It is landlocked, desperately poor, and has always had awful leadership  and now it is destabilized by Darfur and by its own civil war. The world pretty much looks the other way: The World Bank has a huge office in China, which couldnt grow by less than 10 percent annually if it tried to, and has no office at all in CAR.

title: Yanks Play in Houston, Defying George Costanza
description: If you love baseball and Seinfeld, an Astros-Yankees matchup brings to mind a classic episode from 1995, when George Costanza parties with some bawdy Houston executives as they plan an interleague series.

title: Bonnaroo: An Extended Bass Solo
description: With a head on a swivel, we stepped out into the great heaving mass of possibilities at Bonnaroo. Here is what we, not the royal we, but me and my new 80,000 friends found.

title: Bonnaroo: M.I.As Last Gig Ever?
description: This is my last show, the rapper M.I.A. announced from the stage of That Tent, and Im glad Im spending it with all my hippies. If, as she announced at least three times, it was M.I.A.s last gig ever, she went out with a boom. The seismic riffs of her songs, which sound like theyre made on the worlds cheapest equipment, puffed bass notes at everyones chest, and M.I.A. was all of her interlocking selves: fighter, lover, immigrant, instigator, party girl.

title: Beijing Nightclubs
description: Images that capture the city and its nocturnal celebrators.

title: Bonnaroo: Respite in the New Orleans Tent
description: We were told not to miss Henry Butler, he of the psychotic, off-the-hook right hand. He was playing in the New Orleans tent, which was dark, dust-free and nearly people-free, which provided a respite to what was going on just outside. Mr. Butler is one of the most celebrated pianists in a town  New Orleans  that has its share. He can do anything and often does, opening with a riff on Debussy or at least what sounded like one, and then vamping his way into Let It Roll. His hands did very different things and then came together and did precisely the same thing, with sparks nearly coming out when his paws collided. I watched a kid next to me spaz out during one of his more remarkable riffs, clicked my tongue in judgment and then found myself doing something similar five minutes later. The guy can go.

title: Slimming Japan
description: Japan has undertaken one of the most ambitious campaigns ever by a nation to slim down its citizenry.

title: Womens Wrestling: Miranda Fails to Qualify for Beijing
description: LAS VEGAS  After Patricia Miranda lost Friday, after her wrestling career possibly ended along with her 2008 Olympic bid, she walked past a crowd of reporters toward a concrete wall deep in the Thomas & Mack Center. She knelt down, hands on knees, and leaned forward until her head rested on the concrete. A friend stood sentry, blocking Miranda from the outside world.

title: Bonnaroo: Exclamation Point Rock
description: Few bands are more precious than !!! (think chk, chk, chk by way of pronouncers.) The dance punk ensemble  three exclamation points and at least eight musicians, push the jungle sound through a psychedelic prism that, well, really had the kids freaking out  and yeah, a creaky old rocker who stopped by too. The deeper one went into the thicket of fans, the darker and more intense it got, until up by the stage a full-on rave seemed to be underway. These guys got it all: chops, mood and a frontman, Nic Offer, who actually looked pretty fine in a pair of Spandex-like shorts.

title: Judo: Getting to Beijing Is Easier Than Getting to Arena
description: LAS VEGAS  The United States best chance at an Olympic medal in judo clinched a spot in the Games without breaking a sweat Friday.

title: Bonnaroo: I Just Wanted to Know Where North Was
description: The number one most asked question today?

title: American Idol Producers Sued
description: The musicians union filed a federal lawsuit against the producers of American Idol on Thursday, claiming that its members had been underpaid because the shows live music was rerecorded for reruns, The Associated Press reported. The suit by the American Federation of Musicians contends that American Idol Productions and its subsidiary violated a collective bargaining agreement. According to court papers, the producers used different musicians to record new music for the season highlights show in 2007 and did not inform the union. The damages sought were unspecified.

title: China: More Antiterrorism Drills
description: The Chinese government began a final round of antiterrorism drills at various Olympic sites this week. The exercises include simulations of a chemical attack and of hijacking of athletes buses, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. At the beach volleyball ground in Chaoyang Park, firemen, police officers and other security workers evacuated 400 spectators in a simulated blast. The Olympics begin Aug. 8.

title: Iowas Disasters
description: The heaviest rains in Iowa this past week fell in the northern part of the state  a torrential downpour in many cases, following the third-wettest May on the books. That water has been draining out of fields  washing away soil and crops as it goes  and into the rivers, which in the eastern half of the state flow predominantly to the southeast. Des Moines, Iowa City and Cedar Rapids have all watched as floods have approached, but it has been impossible to turn them away. Cedar Rapids and Iowa City have been engulfed. Fifty-five of Iowas 99 counties have been declared a disaster.

title: A Primer for Young People Starting Their First Job
description: To the hundreds of thousands of young people who have landed entry-level jobs that come with health insurance and a retirement plan, I offer my congratulations. Things are tough out there right now, so you must be doing something right.

title: How to Get It Done
description: A BRILLIANT strategy, blockbuster product or breakthrough technology can put you on the competitive map, but only solid execution can keep you there, the lead article in the Harvard Business Review begins. You have to deliver on your intent. Unfortunately, the majority of companies arent very good at it, by their own admission.

title: Britain Strengthens Rules on Disclosure of Short Sales
description: LONDON  The British financial regulator introduced rules on Friday covering the disclosure of certain types of share bets  short-selling  that are aimed at protecting the integrity of the countrys financial market.

title: Northern Japan Quake Kills 2 and Injures Dozens
description: TOKYO  A powerful earthquake with a magnitude of 7.0 shook northern Japan on Saturday morning, killing two people and injuring dozens, the Japanese government said.

title: China Increases Lead as Biggest Carbon Dioxide Emitter
description: China has clearly overtaken the United States as the worlds leading emitter of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas produced by human activity, a new study has found, its emissions increasing 8 percent in 2007. The Chinese increase accounted for two-thirds of the growth in the years global greenhouse gas emissions, the study found.

title: Campaigns Unable to Agree on Series of Meetings
description: In almost every campaign appearance this week, Senator John McCain has been leaning on Senator Barack Obama to accept his offer to engage in a series of 10 one-on-one town-hall-style meetings, a format that worked well for Mr. McCain in the primaries.

title: Papa Was a Rolling Stone, and a Famous Disc Jockey
description: Anger, bitterness and ceaseless yearning course through the quest narrated and enacted by W. Allen Taylor in his one-man show at the Abrons Arts Center of the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side.

title: Star Shuns Emmys, Angering Producers
description: LOS ANGELES  Writers and producers for the ABC hit Greys Anatomy are fuming after one of the shows stars, Katherine Heigl, said this week that she had opted out of the Emmy race this year because she was not given good enough material to work with last season.

title: Courting Conflict
description: Judges must be impartial  in both appearance and reality  so federal law sensibly requires that they disqualify themselves from cases if they own stock in a company that is a party in the matter. It would be best if all judges ordered their investments to avoid conflicts. But the issue is most acute for Supreme Court justices, who cannot be replaced by another jurist. When Supreme Court justices recuse themselves, they risk altering important decisions and blocking the court from doing its job.

title: Afghanistan: More Aid Is Promised
description: At a two-day session of NATO defense ministers in Brussels, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pleaded with allies to fulfill pledges for troops, and they promised modest additions. The alliance has almost 53,000 troops in Afghanistan, but commanders want three more battalions and more trainers for Afghan forces. Mr. Gates said he told his counterparts that in May, for the first time, more coalition troops were killed in a months fighting in Afghanistan than in Iraq.

title: Legal Drugs Kill Far More Than Illegal, Florida Says
description: MIAMI  From Scarface to Miami Vice, Floridas drug problem has been portrayed as the story of a single narcotic: cocaine. But for Floridians, prescription drugs are increasingly a far more lethal habit.

title: An Iowa Towns Landmark, Leveled by Explosion, Is Rebuilt by Friendships
description: BALLTOWN, Iowa  The morning before Christmas 2007, an explosion rocked this village of 70 people on a bluff overlooking the Mississippi River, just north of Dubuque. Within minutes, Breitbachs Country Dining had burned to the ground.

title: Tim Russert, Meet the Press Host, Is Dead at 58
description: Tim Russert, a fixture in American homes on Sunday mornings and election nights since becoming moderator of Meet the Press nearly 17 years ago, died Friday after collapsing at the Washington bureau of NBC News. He was 58 and lived in Northwest Washington.

title: Rowing Is Invigorating (but Do Stay in the Boat)
description: I CROUCHED in the cockpit of a recreational scull, pulling on a pair of oars and going nowhere. It was an unseasonably warm Saturday morning on Sag Harbor Cove at the far eastern end of Long Island. The sky was blue, the waves were flat and my knees were bent as I tried to execute a rowing stroke with my back toward the bow.

title: For 3 Celtics, Parade Route Wouldnt Be Strange Path
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce and Ray Allen had just become teammates last summer when they were ushered onto one of Bostons famous duck boats and taken on a tour by Celtics Coach Doc Rivers.

title: California Braces for New Summer of Love
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The groom was shopping for the perfect diamond for his betrothed  the other groom. As Rey Almeida, a 47-year-old elementary school principal, perused the Equality Forever rings (a same-sex wedding special at 40 percent off if purchased from June 16 to June 26), he couldnt help reflecting on the symbolism.

title: N. Korea Yields Slightly on Abductions
description: TOKYO  North Korea said Friday that it would reopen an investigation into abductions of Japanese citizens, reversing its longstanding position that the issue had been settled.

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times listing on Friday about the 32nd American Crafts Festival misstated the location and this weekends dates. It is in Damrosch Park today, noon to 9 p.m., and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. It will also be held there next Saturday and Sunday. It is not at the Lincoln Center plazas on Sunday (nor was it held there on Friday).

title: A Ruling on the Rights of the Detained
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost in E-Mail, Tech Firms Face Self-Made Beast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The onslaught of cellphone calls and e-mail and instant messages is fracturing attention spans and hurting productivity. It is a common complaint. But now the very companies that helped create the flood are trying to mop it up.

title: Making City Buses Run Cleaner Yields a Big Bonus: Fewer Trips to the Gas Pump
description: When you buy 55 million gallons of diesel fuel a year to power some 5,000 buses, even small improvements in fuel efficiency can make a big difference.

title: A World of Competitions and Desires With No Exit
description: Blind Spot is something of a misnomer for the 2003 dance by Pavel Zustiak that opened at Performance Space 122 on Wednesday. What he offers is far more encompassing.

title: An Author Underwrites a Successful Track Program
description: NEW BERN, N.C.  At the convergence of the Trent and Neuse Rivers in the wetlands of eastern North Carolina sits this town of 29,000 people. It has been around for nearly 300 years, but has never had a reputation as a breeding ground for professional athletes. One of its proudest athletic achievements came last year, when the New Bern Bears defeated Charlotte Independence for the Class 4A high school state football championship, after which the town threw a parade.

title: U.S. Gets Modest NATO Accessions on Afghanistan
description: BRUSSELS  A two-day session of NATO defense ministers ended Friday after following a now-familiar script in the debate over Afghanistan: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates made a heartfelt plea for allies to fulfill pledges for troops. Allies promised modest additions.

title: Gas Prices and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Winehouse in Moscow
description: The troubled British singer Amy Winehouse performed for the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich and his girlfriend, the model Daria Zhukova, at the opening of an art gallery in Moscow on Thursday, the BBC reported. For the hourlong performance, which was watched by 300 people at the gallery, the Garage, Ms. Winehouse was paid a reported 1 million, about $1,950,000.

title: Corrections
description: Front Page

title: High End or Low, Ballparks Break Bank
description: An interesting problem is what to do with the words and numbers $2 billion. Hardly anyone really knows what they mean. One example, worth repeating, is that the difference between a million and a billion seconds is the difference between 11 days and 33 years. A thousand seconds is 16 minutes.

title: Woods Charges at U.S. Open, but He Has Company
description: SAN DIEGO  The misty fog that creeps ashore in the afternoons in coastal California occurs when cool ocean temperatures mix with heat on the land. So it was no surprise when the intense heat coming from the shots being hit and the putts being made at Torrey Pines Golf Course on Friday produced a brand of United States Open marine layer like none seen before.

title: Talks With U.S. on Security Pact Are at an Impasse, the Iraqi Prime Minister Says
description: BAGHDAD  Negotiations on a long-term security agreement with the United States are at a stalemate because of American demands that compromise Iraqs sovereignty, the Iraqi prime minister said Friday.

title: Disclosures Give Look at Candidates Personal Finances
description: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama released their Senate financial disclosure statements on Friday, revealing that Mr. McCain and his wife had at least $225,000 in credit card debt and that Mr. Obama and his wife had put more than $200,000 into college funds for their daughters.

title: Two Swiss Banks Agree to Settlement in Parmalat Case
description: UBS and the Credit Suisse Group, Switzerlands two largest banks, agreed to pay almost 357 million euros ($548 million) to settle all legal claims related to their role in financing Parmalat, the dairy company that collapsed five years ago in Italys biggest bankruptcy. UBS will pay more than 184 million euros and Credit Suisse will pay 172.5 million euros, Parmalat said in separate statements on Friday. Parmalats chief executive, Enrico Bondi, filed lawsuits against dozens of Parmalats banks, contending they helped hide the true state of the companys finances from investors. The banks did not acknowledge any wrongdoing.

title: The Recession in the Rearview Mirror
description: HOPES that the United States could avoid a recession were renewed this week by evidence that the governments rebate checks were stimulating spending, at least for now. But two recession indicators based on employment statistics offer evidence that a recession may have begun months ago.

title: Writers for a Fox Cartoon Walk Out
description: The writing staff of Sit Down, Shut Up, a Fox animated series about a high school scheduled to begin next spring, walked off the job on Wednesday. The writers, who had been working without a contract for weeks, expected to receive the benefits recently negotiated by the Writers Guild of America, but the studio producing the series, Sony Pictures Television, said that another union, the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, would have jurisdiction over the show instead. It was one of the first confrontations between writers and a studio since the crippling three-month writers strike was settled in February. We thought there would be no more shenanigans like this, said John Aboud, a writer for the series. He noted that the writers union contract had covered every Fox animated series since 1998. Sony said the production of its animated shows has been covered by agreements with the theatrical stage employees union for at least 10 years. The conflict has arisen because this is the first animated series Sony has produced for Fox.

title: Justices Come Under Election-Year Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  Thanks in no small part to Justice Antonin Scalias dire warning that granting Guantnamo detainees access to habeas corpus will almost certainly cause more Americans to be killed, the Supreme Court finds itself on the verge of becoming something that it has not been for many election cycles  a campaign issue.

title: Question of Bushs Legacy Lingers Over His Farewell Visits to European Capitals
description: PARIS  The final days of George Bushs presidency have never seemed more imminent as during his tour of Europes capitals, a farewell visit in which reminiscence, valediction and even eulogies have trailed him.

title: In France, Plans to Make a Bit More of the Bubbly
description: MAGNEUX, France  Jean-Michel Petit, a third-generation beet farmer in this village, yearns to trade his earthy roots for the sparkle of Champagne.

title: Green Thievery in the South Bronx
description: Many promises were made two years ago when the New York Yankees grabbed prime parkland in the South Bronx to build a new stadium. One of them, made by the city, was that residents would have better parks, soccer fields, tracks and ball courts to replace what was taken away. That has not yet happened  and it must.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about retail sales in May misstated the year-over-year sales trend. Sales were 2.5 percent higher than in May 2007  not lower. (The figures did extend a six-month downward trend in year-over-year sales growth when adjusted for inflation.)

title: A Fathers Tribute to Three Dead Daughters Is Restored
description: There were once  but far too briefly  three sisters from Jamaica, Queens.

title: No Problems Seen for Shuttle Landing
description: There was a flurry of activity on Friday morning aboard the space shuttle Discovery after astronauts noticed an object floating away from the orbiter and saw what appeared to be a small protrusion sticking out of its rudder.

title: The Search for a Missing Trader Goes Global
description: Is Samuel Israel III dead or alive?

title: Bending Gender Every Which Way
description: Its a mystery why sometimes a few people moving on a stage in apparently random patterns can look so right. In the first 10 seconds  maybe 5  of Dance by Neil Greenbergs Quartet With Three Gay Men, the oddly graceful, undulating movements of the four dancers, the jangly sounds of Zeena Parkinss score, and Michael Stillers clear, bright light have the immediate effect of a poem. Meaning is compressed and harbored, to be released in thrilling fragments, inconclusive and richly layered.

title: Social Bees Fluttering to Bachs Sonatas
description: The Czech choreographer Dusan Tynek is a bit of an anomaly nowadays: he makes dances, formal ones, set to Baroque music that burst with leaps, turns and lifts. A former competitive ballroom dancer, Mr. Tynek ended up at Bard College, where he studied with Aileen Passloff, and later went on to dance with the Merce Cunningham Repertory Understudy Group and Lucinda Childs. He has, in dance terms, been around the block.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sexism in Clinton Coverage? Issue Hits a Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Free 1,200 Inmates in Attack on Afghan Prison
description: In a brazen attack, Taliban fighters assaulted the main prison in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar on Friday night, blowing up the mud walls, killing 15 guards and freeing around 1,200 inmates. Among the escapees were about 350 Taliban members, including commanders, would-be suicide bombers and assassins, said Ahmed Wali Karzai, the head of Kandahars provincial council and a brother of President Hamid Karzai.

title: What Is Life Without a Tram? Residents Are Getting a Taste
description: They waited at the islands single subway stop as jam-packed cars  two, three, four of them  clacked by without a seat to spare. Then the grumbling began. The tram is always on time, said Sally Jenkyn Jones as she forced herself aboard an already brimming F train. This is always too packed.

title: Bloomberg Says Tax Rate on Property May Go Up
description: With the economy in the doldrums, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that the city might scrap a popular tax cut for homeowners in 2009  a step he previously said he would try to avoid.

title: Newspaper Advertising Takes Big Fall
description: Print advertising sales by American newspapers fell the most on record in the first quarter, tumbling 14 percent as the real estate and job markets shrank and business was lost to the Internet.

title: Candidates, Fly Away Home
description: The lifespan of a ladybug is four to six weeks.

title: Mets Add Trot Nixon in a Trade With Arizona
description: In what General Manager Omar Minaya described as a trade that improves the team and the clubhouse, the Mets acquired outfielder Trot Nixon from the Arizona Diamondbacks on Friday for cash or a player to be determined.

title: Tim Russert, 58, NBCs Face of Politics, Dies
description: Tim Russert, a fixture in American homes on Sunday mornings and election nights since becoming moderator of Meet the Press nearly 17 years ago, died Friday after collapsing at the Washington bureau of NBC News. He was 58 and lived in Northwest Washington.

title: R. Kelly Is Acquitted in Child Pornography Case
description: CHICAGO  It took more than six years for prosecutors to get the R&B star R. Kelly into court on charges of child pornography. It only took a few hours for a jury to declare him not guilty on all 14 counts.

title: Playground Rules: A Game N.B.A. Players Grasp
description: Los Angeles

title: Jeters Homer in Eighth Lifts Yankees
description: HOUSTON  For anybody who doubted the wisdom of making Joba Chamberlain a starter, the Yankees can point to Fridays game as the reason they did it.

title: Footnotes
description: Mary Higgins Clark is to receive the First Lady of Mystery Award at the International Mystery Writers Festival in Owensboro, Ky., on June 22. ... Warren Beatty received a lifetime achievement award from the American Film Institute at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles on Thursday.

title: The Greeting Card Business Adapts to Change
description: FATHERS DAY is Sunday, and many greeting cards that will be given out are likely to have been made by the American Greetings Corporation. Zev Weiss, the companys chief executive, says the holidays and annual events this time of year are important generators of revenue for the company, regardless of whether someone is looking for a card made of paper or a digital one to send by e-mail.

title: Pettitte Still Admired by Houston Fans
description: HOUSTON  When Andy Pettitte tried to park his car at Minute Maid Park on Friday, the attendant directed him to a different lot than the one he used when he played for the Astros from 2004 through 2006.

title: Ford Executives and Kerkorian Expected to Talk Next Week
description: DETROIT  The investor Kirk Kerkorian will meet with top executives at Ford next week as a way to show his support for management and its turnaround strategy, people with knowledge of the plans said Friday.

title: Winter Worries Come Early
description: IT may seem crazy to fret about winter, with summers official start just days away. Yet the rising price of winter is on my mind, as it is for many of us who heat our homes  most unfortunately  with oil.

title: Giuliani Plans to Aid Hopefuls, for His Share
description: WASHINGTON  With the Republican Party in need of money for the November elections, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has offered to appear at fund-raisers around the country for G.O.P. candidates. But there is a catch: He wants some cash out of the deal.

title: Greenspan Sees Light at the End of the Credit Tunnel
description: American financial markets, roiled by the collapse of the subprime-mortgage market, have shown a pronounced turnaround since March, Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Friday. The worst is over for the credit crisis, or will be soon, and there is now a reduced possibility of a deep recession, Mr. Greenspan said in remarks via satellite to a conference in Mexico City. His remarks echo the assessment of the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, who said this week that danger of a substantial downturn in the economy had receded.  Still, the persistent slump in the housing market is putting major downward pressure on the economy, said Greenspan, who served as Fed chairman from August 1987 to January 2006.

title: Flood Puts Triathlon Qualifier in Doubt
description: Even the selection of the United States Olympic team is being affected by the severe flooding in Iowa. Next weekends Hy-Vee Triathlon, the third and final qualification race to determine who goes to Beijing, has been washed out of its home at Grays Lake Park near downtown Des Moines and moved seven miles west.

title: National Politicians Sought Out the Crucial Russert Test
description: Through Republican revolution and Republican collapse, the rise and fall of the Houses Clinton and Bush, one war in Afghanistan and two in Iraq, Tim Russert remained a center of gravity in the national discourse every Sunday on Meet the Press.

title: Taking Out the Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a decision overturning rulings that denied asylum to three Guinean women who said they were victims of genital cutting misidentified the judge who wrote the opinion for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. It was Judge Chester J. Straub  not Judge Rosemary S. Pooler  who wrote that the court was deeply disturbed that the womens cases did not receive the type of careful analysis they were due, and who quoted from a State Department report that said women in Guinea often endured domestic violence and rape. And it was Judge Straub who used a political analogy to dismiss the argument that genital cutting was a one-time act of persecution. (Judge Straub also submitted his own concurring opinion.)

title: His Status Uncertain, Randolph Relaxes
description: The question was asked with a laugh, and Willie Randolph responded in kind.

title: Canada Orders the Recall of Some Rail Car Wheels
description: OTTAWA  For safety reasons, the Canadian government ordered the removal on Friday of about 10,000 wheels used on railroad freight cars operating throughout North America.

title: Access to Health Records
description: To the Editor:

title: An Oxford Appointment for Kevin Spacey
description: The actor Kevin Spacey, below, has been named Cameron Mackintosh visiting professor of contemporary theater at Oxfords St. Catherines College, The Associated Press reported on Friday. Mr. Spacey, who also serves as the artistic director of the Old Vic in London and has won two Academy Awards, succeeds Patrick Stewart. Stephen Sondheim, Alan Ayckbourn and Diana Rigg have also held the post. During his yearlong term Mr. Spacey will offer workshops, lectures and seminars.

title: A Buildings Commissioners Qualifications
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Men Shift From Friendly to Qualifier
description: CARSON, Calif.  In the past two and a half weeks, the United States mens soccer team has struggled against England, endured against Spain and battled against Argentina, the top team in the FIFA world rankings. But when World Cup qualifying opens Sunday, the United States opponent will be decidedly less glamorous.

title: Corrections
description: An article and headlines on Tuesday about an agreement by three Internet providers and the office of the New York attorney general under which the three companies will curb access to child pornography overstated the extent of one aspect of the agreement. The providers  Verizon, Sprint and Time Warner Cable  have agreed to purge Web sites that display child pornography and are hosted on the three companies servers. The agreement does not, however, prevent customers from accessing such sites on other servers not controlled by those companies.

title: City and Labor Leaders Reach Deal on Plan to Develop Willets Point
description: The Bloomberg administration has forged an unusual pact with labor leaders, promising that in exchange for their support of the citys ambitious plan to transform Willets Point, a 62-acre enclave of auto repair shops and cinder block sheds near Shea Stadium, the project will provide union jobs and good wages.

title: Metallica Says Its Sorry
description: In its latest cybercontroversy, the heavy-metal band Metallica apologized for asking several bloggers to remove their online reviews of its untitled coming record, The Guardian of London reported. The band upset fans by suing the file-sharing service Napster in 2000 and by removing its music from iTunes in 2003  a decision that was reversed in 2006  but says the removal of the reviews was orchestrated by its management company, Q Prime, without the bands permission. In a statement on Metallica.com, its Web site, the band described its own reaction to the move. Our response was WHY?!!!, the statement said. Why take down mostly positive reviews of the new material and prevent people from getting psyched about the next record ... that makes no sense to us! Links to the reviews are now available on the site.

title: Euro 2008, and the Joys of Being Stateside
description: Every four years, for three short and delightful weeks, I rediscover the pure joy of being a sports fan. I am nowhere near the Euro 2008 soccer tournament being played in Austria and Switzerland, and maybe thats why Im having such a wonderful time.

title: Senators Caught in Mortgage Fallout
description: When Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota wanted a mortgage for his beach house, he turned to a Washington insider, James A. Johnson, former head of Fannie Mae, the government mortgage giant, who then put the senator in touch with Angelo Mozilo, chief executive of the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial.

title: Stewart R. Mott, Longtime Patron of Liberal and Offbeat Causes, Dies at 70
description: Stewart R. Mott, a philanthropist whose gifts to progressive and sometimes offbeat causes were often upstaged by his eccentricities, like cultivating a large garden atop his Manhattan penthouse, complete with 460 plant species (including 17 types of radishes) and a chicken coop, died on Thursday night. He was 70 and had homes in North Salem, N.Y., and Bermuda.

title: Lost Baroque Work Is a Spectacle Again
description: ROME  Every afternoon at 5:30 sharp, the ta-da moment arrives at the Chiesa del Ges, the mother church of the Jesuit order.

title: Another Art Theft in So Paulo
description: Two Picasso prints were stolen by three armed robbers from a museum in So Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, The Associated Press reported. Along with the Picasso prints, Minotaur, Drinker and Women from 1933 and The Painter and the Model from 1963, the thieves took paintings by two Brazilian artists  Couple by Lasar Segall and Women in the Window, above, by Emiliano Di Cavalcanti  from the Pinacoteca do Estado museum. The works were estimated to be worth a combined $612,000. The robbers paid the museums entrance fee of $2.45 and then overpowered guards to take the framed works. In December another Picasso, Portrait of Suzanne Boch, and a painting by the Brazilian artist Candido Portinari were stolen from the So Paulo Museum of Art after men used a crowbar and car jack to force open the museums doors. The paintings from that robbery were later found leaning against a house on the outskirts of the city.

title: Some Cling to Hope for a Deal After Microsoft Discloses Details
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A day after Yahoo said it had ended talks with Microsoft and signed an advertising deal with Google, some of its shareholders were still holding on to hopes that some kind of marriage between Yahoo and Microsoft could be consummated.

title: Saatchi Taps Young Artists
description: The art collector Charles Saatchi was in a generous mood on Wednesday when he bought almost all the works by three young students from their final graduation exhibit at the Royal Academy Schools in London, The Times of London reported. The student artists are Carla Busuttil, 26; Angus Sanders-Dunnachie, 28; and Jill Mason, 33. Mr. Saatchis early purchases helped begin the careers of now-famous artists including Damien Hirst, Tracy Emin, Natasha Kissell and Jake and Dinos Chapman.

title: Wood Reinvents Himself as the Cubs Closer
description: CHICAGO  Kerry Wood was not asked to choose a song for his entrance into games as the closer for the Chicago Cubs. The Cubs play Welcome to the Jungle by Guns N Roses, but they selected it. Wood cited an antiquated sound system  weve got a couple of indoor-outdoor speakers, he said  while playfully saying there was no need to have a personally picked tune.

title: Ireland Derails a Bid to Recast Europes Rules
description: Europe was thrown into political turmoil on Friday by Irelands rejection of the Lisbon Treaty, a painstakingly negotiated blueprint for consolidating the European Unions power and streamlining its increasingly unwieldy bureaucracy.

title: A Tosca Who Comes Out to Meet the Audience
description: The stage at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, when Lorin Maazel and the New York Philharmonic gave a concert performance of Puccinis Tosca, looked as though it had been set up for a rock concert. Loudspeakers were everywhere.

title: At Even Par, Four Veterans Are Down but Not Out
description: SAN DIEGO  It is a foursome that has combined to win 4 major championships, 26 PGA Tour events and 32 European Tour tournaments. Geoff Ogilvy, Ernie Els, Luke Donald and Robert Allenby are tied at even par after two rounds of the 108th United States Open, and while each golfer feels as if the Torrey Pines Golf Course has beat him up for two days, each also feels quietly thankful.

title: George E. Moore, 88, Cancer Researcher, Is Dead
description: Dr. George E. Moore, a versatile cancer researcher who found an early association between chewing tobacco and mouth cancer while directing the Roswell Park Cancer Institute, a state-financed research center in Buffalo, died on May 19 in Evergreen, Colo. He was 88 and lived in Conifer, Colo.

title: Progress in Salmonella Investigation
description: Nine of the 228 people who have gotten sick from salmonella-tainted tomatoes ate at two restaurants in the same chain, a federal food official said. The official, David Acheson, the associate commissioner for foods at the Food and Drug Administration, did not name the chain or disclose the location of the restaurants. In a conference call with reporters, he said the agency was keeping the information confidential because the investigation was continuing. A spokeswoman for the Illinois Department of Public Health said the agency was looking at a cluster of cases in the Chicago area. The tainted raw tomatoes, which have sickened people in 23 states, most likely came from Mexico or central or southern Florida, Dr. Acheson said.

title: A Moment of Clarity in Baghdad
description: The disconnect between Washingtons stay-the-course Republicans  President Bush and Senator John McCain, in particular  and the Iraqi government has grown too wide to ignore. As the administration pushes for a legal agreement to extend the American military presence in Iraq, the Iraqis are pushing back. That is a positive sign.

title: South Korean Truckers Strike to Protest Rising Fuel Costs
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Thousands of South Korean truck drivers went on strike on Friday to protest rising fuel prices, threatening to paralyze the countrys ports and challenging the already unpopular government of President Lee Myung-bak.

title: Letters From Vermont
description: Despite the focus on the housing crisis, gasoline prices and the economy in general, the press has not done a good job capturing the intense economic anxiety  and even dread, in some cases  that has gripped tens of millions of working Americans, including many who consider themselves solidly middle class.

title: Top Opposition Official Still Missing in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  A high court judge in Zimbabwe on Friday ordered the police to produce Tendai Biti, the opposition partys secretary general and chief strategist, who was arrested Thursday the moment he re-entered the country and whose whereabouts has since remained a mystery.

title: Password Helps CBS
description: A special Thursday edition of Million Dollar Password gave CBS a ratings lift as 9.4 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen. That tally made it one of the nights most-watched programs, even with CBSs repeat of CSI at 9 (9.4 million) and ahead of the networks Swingtown at 10 (7 million). CBS earned a second-place finish for the night, trailing only ABC and its live broadcast of Game Four of the N.B.A championship series between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers. On par with earlier games in the series, Thursdays broadcast averaged 13.8 million viewers. Fox, in third place, edged past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49, thanks to So You Think You Can Dance at 9 (8 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, broadcasting a repeat of My Name Is Earl at 8 (3.3 million) followed by Last Comic Standing from 8:30 to 10 (4.1 million).

title: Tiny Town, Quaint House, Big Voices

Grant two years later. Nor is it very citylike by 21st-century standards, with its population of 515 or so nestled 8,500 feet high in the Rockies, a spectacular hours drive west of Denver.

But because of you, were not so bowled over by that sort of thing anymore.

The division serves more than 500,000 people through workers compensation. Express, based in St. Louis, said the deal would not add to earnings until 2009, and then only slightly. Express and companies like it operate drug plans for employers, unions and governments.

title: Mexico: Cuban Detainees Missing
description: Thirty-three Cubans who fled Cuba this month in motorboats were still missing the day after a Mexican government bus transporting them was stopped by armed men Thursday night. A half-dozen armed men in ski masks hijacked the bus, which also carried four Central Americans, and forced officials away at gunpoint in Chiapas. The Cubans had been detained in motorboats near Cancn on June 5. Immigration officials were transporting them to a detention center in Tapachula, on Mexicos southern border.

Maybe he was surprised that a huge majority of hands went up  or maybe not, since Bonnaroo is the life-affirming hippie festival, and Metallica songs just about always revolve around death: via electrocution (Ride the Lightning), addiction (Master of Puppets) or war (No Remorse). title: Bonnaroo: No More Films for Glen Hansard from Once

Sitting in the artist tent after a 90-minute set that landed nicely, he said its been a heady couple of weeks. When the band was in Louisville, word came that it was invited to hear Barack Obama speak. It was amazing, just like everything else that has been happening for us, he said. Mr. Hansard is contemplating a move to New York from Dublin. I dont really live anywhere right now, but Dublin is where I keep my stuff, he said. The band sold out Radio City Music Hall last month, and Mr. Hansard is continually amazed that people find his and Ms. Irglovas turn in Once riveting enough to stop them everywhere they go. Perhaps a bit more film work then? No, Im going to leave that alone, he said. I got lucky with the one I already did.
