description: Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. womens water polo team, which is favored to win the gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. Shell be writing occasional posts for the Rings blog in the buildup to the Olympics.

title: BMX: A New Day
description: The BMX racer Mike Day qualified for the Olympics today. He won the first two races of the first BMX Olympic Trials, held in Chula Vista, Calif., and placed second in another.

title: Bad free trade arguments
description: Supporters of free trade do not help their case when they accuse those who worry about trade impacts of forgetting about the good stuff, like exports and lower import prices. All they do is show that they dont understand textbook international economics  the very textbook economics on which the standard case for free trade is based.

title: Player Ratings: Red Bulls vs. D.C. United
description: The Red Bulls (4-4-3, 15 points) were at a soggy Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington Saturday night to play D.C. United (5-7-1, 16 points) after an eight-day break since their last game. Claudio Reyna and Juan Pablo ngel, the teams two designated players, both missed the game because of injuries. (They are also expected to miss the midweek game against New England.) Jozy Altidore will soon wear the yellow uniform of Villarreal of Spain, which left Coach Juan Carlos Osorio with few options other than John Wolyniec up front in a 4-5-1 formation. Seven mostly young Americans were in the Red Bulls uninspired and rudderless starting lineup.

title: Bonnaroo: Warmed Up for Pearl Jam
description: Jack Johnson is no slouch, having moved about 15 million copies of his various albums, but he had to notice that the space in front of him at the What Stage for his 7:30 pm set was filling up with a few more people than he might have expected. The rest of the Bonnaroo stages had closed down and there seemed to be massive anticipation for the Pearl Jam show tonight. It was if someone had lifted up one corner of the site and all the bodies slowly rolled down toward the What Stage. The reflexively mellow crowd seemed a bit amped, anxious to get a cherished spot, or at least a defendable space, for Pearl Jams set.

title: Bonnaroo: Ring of Fire
description: Late Saturday afternoon and gigantic black smoke rings more than 50 feet wide were floating over the Bonnaroo site, as if Godzilla was working a stogie just over the hill. As it turns out, Ken Smith of Muscle Shoals, Ala., had set up a liquid-fueled flame projector, a contraption that shoots a giant fireball into the air, which then leaves a legacy in the form of a smoke ring.

title: Mets
description: New York Mets vs. Arizona Diamondbacks

title: For a Wrestler Too Young and Another Too Old, a Night to Celebrate
description: LAS VEGAS  When Jake Deitchler won his final match on Saturday and qualified for the Olympics, he fell to his knees, extended both arms skyward and let loose a scream that echoed off the walls here at the Thomas & Mack Center.

title: Day Two at the United States Open
description: Stuart Appleby finished the day in first place.

title: Queens Man Obsessed With Trains Is Arrested Again
description: Darius McCollum knows the New York City Transit system well. Perhaps too well.

title: Mary Fan and Dean Kawamoto
description: Mary De Ming Fan and Dean Noboru Kawamoto were married on Thursday in the chambers of Judge John T. Noonan Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco. The bride had served as his law clerk from 2003 to 2004.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies last Sunday about the Mets lost opportunities in a 2-1 defeat to San Diego on June 7 misstated the number of runners they left on base in the game. It was 11  not 8, which was the number left on base in the six innings pitched by Cha Seung Baek of the Padres.

title: 1935: Ramos Gin Fizz
description: This recipe appeared in a letter to The Times, written by W. D. Rose. The original recipe called for rich milk, which I took to mean old-style milk with a layer of cream. So I replicated the milk with a mixture of whole milk and a dash of heavy cream.

title: The Business of Intelligence Gathering
description: AMERICA is ruled by an intelligence-industrial complex whose allegiance is not to the taxpaying public but to a cabal of private-sector contractors that have disgraced our national image and potentially compromised our national security for the sake of making profits.

title: A Bond Book From Bentley
description: HIGH BEAMS

title: Phoebe Connell, Jacob Danziger
description: Phoebe Day Connell and Jacob Klein Danziger were married on Saturday evening at Bear Flag Farm in Winters, Calif. The officiant was Kevin Reikes, an owner of the farm who was appointed a deputy civil marriage commissioner by Yolo County to perform the ceremony.

title: David Sedaris: Veracity vs. Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: An American Candidate With a Global Fan Club
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Darnton, Matthew Blodgett
description: Margaret Townsend Darnton, a daughter of Susan G. Darnton and Robert C. Darnton of Cambridge, Mass., was married on Saturday to Matthew Christopher Blodgett, a son of Diane S. Blodgett of St. Louis Park, Minn. The Rev. Anne Marie Richards, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: The Weapon of Rape
description: World leaders fight terrorism all the time, with summit meetings and sound bites and security initiatives. But they have studiously ignored one of the most common and brutal varieties of terrorism in the world today.

title: Up Front
description: Vanessa Grigoriadis has written many memorable articles (she won a National Magazine Award in 2007 for a profile of Karl Lagerfeld that appeared in New York magazine), but the one that may have been the most fun to work on was a Britney Spears cover story for Rolling Stone this year.

title: In Harmony With His Daughter, in Song and in the Dugout
description: THE day I auditioned for the New York City Gay Mens Chorus, I thought it would be fun for any number of reasons. Chief among them: Im a gay rights activist who loves to sing. But over the past three years, during which I have been the groups only female singing member, one reason more than any other has given it a special meaning. Surrounded by 249 talented men, I find myself remembering my favorite Irish tenor. My dad.

title: On Bench, Can Gets a Chance to Watch
description: HOUSTON  When the Yankees first used Robinson Can as a pinch-hitter this season, on April 14, he sat on the bench, studied other left-handed hitters, and smacked a go-ahead home run at Tampa Bay. That was in Cans mind on Saturday, when he watched the first seven innings of an 8-4 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: As a Father, I Was Hardly a Perfect Fit
description: DURING our weekly telephone call, my 10-year-old son told me he wanted a Yankees cap. Not just any Yankees cap; it had to be a fitted cap. Fitted caps dont have the little plastic adjuster on the back, he told me. All the pro players wear them.

title: Summer in the Caribbean
description: HOUSTON in summer can be a miserable place.

title: A Mixed Bag, With Inflation a Top Worry
description: It was a mixed week for the stock market, which was constrained by unfavorable economic reports but nonetheless had some pockets of strength.

title: Storms Cause Power Failures and Close Roads and Subways
description: Heavy storms disrupted subway service, flooded highways and caused power failures throughout the region on Saturday evening.

title: With the Passage of Years, a Coming Together
description: IT took dementia to finally bring me and my 86-year-old father together. A few months ago, I rather brazenly suggested that he and Marilyn, his partner of the last 20 years, separate to their respective families for the holidays. At his age, I thought, it might be one of the last times he could see many of his grandchildren together in one place. To my surprise, Marilyn agreed, and the following week he was dropped off with his small valise, for four days.

title: Correction: Fashion Designers Honor Their Own
description: An entry in the Evening Hours column last Sunday, about the New York City Outward Bound benefit on June 3, omitted the name of an honoree. Besides Louis V. Gerstner Jr., Tim Armstrong, second from right in the last picture, was also honored. The column also misidentified the educational affiliation for the Outward Bound graduates shown with Quemel Arroyo. They attend Washington Heights Expeditionary Learning School, not the Bronx Expeditionary Learning High School.

title: Oyster Bay Ordered to Permit Malls Construction
description: IN what could be a decisive moment in a seven-year legal battle over plans to build a luxury mall in Syosset, a Suffolk County judge has ordered the Town of Oyster Bay to immediately issue a permit that would allow construction to begin on a 39-acre former industrial site next to the Long Island Expressway.

title: 36 Hours in Vienna
description: THERE is new energy in Viennas imposing gorgeous streets. Where museum-worthy beauty may once have felt untouchable, there is a palpable sense of a city loosening up. Its alive in the reinvention of the gasthuser  the Austrian greasy spoons that haunt every corner  now taken over by young chefs reinvigorating menus. Its in the night life, which ranges from gritty to ber-designed lounges. Its in festivals like ImpulsTanz (www.impulstanz.com), the modern dance extravaganza that charms the city each summer, and will do so again this year from July 10 to Aug. 10.

title: On Cozy Streets, a Great Divide
description: FOR the first hour or so, the gathering of the Manhattan Beach Neighborhood Association on June 3 resembled any other such meeting. About 70 residents fidgeted and murmured in the auditorium of Public School 195, while a procession of local officials trooped up to the stage.

title: Two Styles of Dysfunctional Family. Which One Reassures?
description: From "August: Osage County," by Tracy Letts

title: The Gambler
description: There are only two kinds of gamblers: the lucky and the broke, says the compulsive wagerer at the center of Preston L. Allens casino noir All or Nothing. Known simply as P (protagonist? Preston?), hes been one or the other his entire adult life. A Miami school bus driver with a large family and an even larger jones, he squanders his paychecks and scrounges loose change from school bus seats, then loses it all at South Florida Indian casinos, mostly to slot machines, the crack cocaine of gambling. P is not above wishing for his young sons life-threatening allergic reactions, believing the child utters winning numbers while slipping toward a coma. He plays, he loses and, with the Sisyphean regularity of the certifiably insane, he returns to play again. Above all, he lies  to his wife, his bosses, his children, himself.

title: On a Parks Border, Fears of Long Shadows
description: SINCE its completion more than 30 years ago, Mount Sinai Medical Centers Annenberg Building, at 99th Street off Fifth Avenue, has been regarded by some people as the sore thumb of East Harlem, a 31-story black monolith that intrudes on the mostly pristine skyline on the northeast border of Central Park. But if a plan put forth by the medical center gains city approval, the Annenberg may be relieved of its pariah status, surpassed in height and maybe local resentment by a condo tower.

title: Agent of Reinvention (Sorry About That, Chief)
description: SO, the old turn-a-beloved-TV-show-into-a-hit-movie trick, eh?

title: Bottlemania
description: AN ALARM IN THE WOODS

title: 2008: Californiafied Ramos Gin Fizz
description: By Duggan McDonnell, of Cantina in San Francisco. McDonnell recommends a low-proof gin like Plymouth, as well as the most bitter orange marmalade you can find.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Rail roundup in some editions last Sunday about the search for answers after Big Browns failure at the Belmont Stakes misidentified a medical procedure that the horses handlers said they would have done to check for a breathing obstruction or internal bleeding. It was an endoscopic exam, not arthroscopic surgery.

title: Welcome to the Dollhouse
description: About a decade ago, when Dutch fashion was still something of an oxymoron, Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren could fit their dreams of becoming world famous designers into a shoe box.

title: Letters: The Lawyers Crusade (Continued)
description: I read with interest James Traubs article on the Pakistani lawyers movement (June 1). As a humble participant in the movement, I took exception to the comparison of our leader and guide Aitzaz Ahsan with Jawaharlal Nehru. While Nehru was called to the bar he did not make a living as a lawyer, partially because he didnt need to and partially because he was no good. Aitzaz on the other hand is nothing if not a great lawyer. If there is a silver-tongued barrister he reminds us of, it is Muhammad Ali Jinnah, held by many to be the greatest lawyer in the British Empire. Like Jinnah, Aitzaz is at the top of the legal game and a politician who uses mainly constitutional means to advance his cause. What is more, Aitzaz consciously emulates Jinnah in his measured, logical exposition of facts.

title: A Long Road to the Right Fit
description: PROFESSIONALLY, Carlos Vargas trains financial executives on managing mergers and developing investment strategies. Having such expertise didnt hurt when it came time for his own recent entrepreneurial move: the sale of his West Village co-op apartment.

title: Love at First Touch
description: The real hero of Katie Hafners book A Romance on Three Legs is not, as the subtitle suggests, the pianist Glenn Gould, or even the piano he was obsessed with, but a nearly blind man named Verne Edquist, who confirms that behind every great pianist is a great tuner.

title: Almighty Dollar
description: Now the child of scorn.

title: Angry Clinton Women  McCain?
description: TEN years ago John McCain had to apologize for regaling a Republican audience with a crude sexual joke about Hillary and Chelsea Clinton and Janet Reno. Last year he had to explain why he didnt so much as flinch when a supporter asked him on camera, How do we beat the bitch? But these days Mr. McCain just loves the women.

title: LieDate.Com
description: A few months ago, I met my boyfriend on JDate, a dating site for Jewish singles. He assumed I was Jewish, and I didnt correct him when I had the chance. Now Im afraid that if I tell him, hes going to dump me. What do I do? I really like this guy, but its getting weird. C.T., Brooklyn

title: A 3-Wheel Dream That Died at Takeoff
description: BUCKMINSTER FULLERs 1933 Dymaxion, a streamlined pod on three wheels, is one of the lovable oddballs in automotive history. Three were built, fawned over by the media and by celebrities, but the car pretty much disappeared after one crashed, killing the driver.

title: Lily Stockman, Peter Brooks
description: Isabel Robinson Stockman, a daughter of Lisa Russell Stockman and Robert Bernard Stockman of Princeton, N.J., was married at her familys farm there on Saturday afternoon to Lt. Peter Harrington Brooks, a son of Virginia Woodworth Brooks and Stephen Harrington Brooks of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Valerie Webster, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Think First, Bail Out Later
description: Boston

title: That Bag Is Suddenly $15 Heavier
description: ONCE upon a time, the music associated with air travel was the soaring theme from Rhapsody in Blue, which United Airlines licensed as its signature song in 1976.

title: A World of Curiosity
description: I WAS born in Boston and lived there for all of three weeks, until I was old enough to travel. My father had lined up a job in California with a military contractor. He was originally from Thailand and had come to the United States to go to graduate school. He arrived with a suitcase of pots and pans.

title: Where the Wild Things Came From
description: When my second-grade teacher was growing up during the Great Depression, she discovered what would become her favorite book at the Cleveland Heights Public Library. Unfortunately, by the time shed finished reading The Hobbit and persuaded her parents to buy her a copy, they couldnt find it in the bookstore. Undeterred, she checked out the librarys copy over and over again, determined to make one of her own by pecking out the entire text with two fingers on the familys manual typewriter. How many authors who write for adults can boast of having a reader so utterly devoted to their work?

title: The Power of the Powerless
description: There are not many countries whose stories are so intensely bound to the character of a single person, much less a person with no tangible power, not even the power to leave her house or receive a visitor or make a telephone call. Yet for nearly two decades, events in Myanmar (formerly Burma) have revolved around the condition, the policies and most of all the victimization of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, now 62, who has been held under house arrest for 12 of the past 18 years. Hers is a symbiotic power, as Justin Wintle describes it in his aptly titled Perfect Hostage, bestowed by the almost cartoonish thugs who have made her an outstanding example of the power of the powerless, in the words of the former Czech president Vaclav Havel.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An obituary last Sunday about the ABC Sports broadcaster Jim McKay misidentified the birthplace of David Berger, a weight lifter who was one of 11 members of the Israeli Olympic team killed by terrorists in 1972 in Munich, an episode Mr. McKay covered. Mr. Berger was born in Shaker Heights, Ohio; he was not Israeli-born.

title: Two Twosomes, Not a Script in Sight
description: THE improv duo of T J Jagodowski and David Pasquesi, better known as TJ and Dave, do not speak to each other on the day before a show. They think any sort of contact detracts from the spontaneity of the performance. Murray Nossel and Paul Browde, the two men in Two Men Talking, meanwhile, wont shut up. Before facing the audience, they confide intensely with each other for up to two hours (longer than the actual show), pouring out the thoughts and events of the day.

title: Report of Horse Deaths Creates More Questions
description: Over the past five years, 3,035 thoroughbreds, standardbreds and quarter horses have died at racing facilities, but not all of them on the racetrack or in racing-related accidents, according to statistics provided to a Congressional subcommittee by the Association of Racing Commissioners International.

title: Correction: The Wiki-Way to the Nomination
description: An article last Sunday about the importance of the Internet to Barack Obamas presidential campaign misstated a Web address for the campaign. It is my.barackobama.com.

title: Very Colorful Cynicism
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A listing of renovation tips with an article last Sunday about brokers who advise owners to keep resale in mind when renovating their apartments referred incompletely to the life span of prefinished floors. While laminated prefinished floors may indeed need to be replaced after being refinished only once or twice, a solid hardwood prefinished floor can stand up to just as many sandings as any other solid wood floor.

title: Its Zaragozas Turn to Make a Splash
description: UP to now, one could be forgiven for knowing next to nothing about the ancient Spanish city of Zaragoza, capital of Aragon and the countrys fifth largest metropolis. For some reason, its never had the same mystique as, say, Granada, Salamanca or Toledo. But that seems likely to change very soon.

title: Nixon Joins the Mets, Rejoining the Majors
description: Trot Nixon has spent the past three months with players who know nothing of winning a World Series, of playing in a rabid baseball town like Boston or of even playing in the major leagues.

title: Imprinted With Surrealisms Influence
description: Not only did Adolph Gottlieb make oil paintings that burn with calligraphic intensity, he was also good at printmaking. Fourteen of the Abstract Expressionists linocuts, lithographs and etchings can be seen in Adolph Gottlieb: Early Prints, a national touring exhibition at the Pollock-Krasner House in Springs.

title: Staying in the Apartment for an Extra Month
description: Q I live in a rent-regulated apartment in Brooklyn, which I rent on a yearly basis. I plan to vacate my apartment one month past the expiration of the lease because I am moving out of state. My landlord tells me to sign a lease for a whole year and to sign a letter saying I am responsible for rent if he is unable to replace me with another tenant. What should I do?

title: An Olympics to Make and a Promise to Keep
description: LAS VEGAS  After winning a Greco-Roman wrestling world title in 2002, Dremiel Byers celebrated like a man possessed.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Sports

title: Guiding Hands Help Immigrant Artists Connect
description: Something about the man in the banana costume appealed to Ricardo Miranda Ziga. Maybe it was the sign he wore that read, A banana from my country can travel easier than me. Maybe it was the fruit-wearers free-spiritedness as he paraded in his peel through public places. Or maybe it was the Latino roots they shared.

title: Letters | The Great Unknown
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bid for .400 Comes Out of Nowhere
description: CHICAGO  Chipper Jones is chasing the magically elusive .400 batting average, but he paused to remind everyone where the chase started. Not while Jones was in spring training with the Atlanta Braves and not during a secret batting practice, but way back. Years back, back home.

title: Finding Hes at Home in His Second Skin
description: DAD was always the silent type. Slipping home quietly after work every evening, he would let my sister and me take turns pulling the knot out of his tie. Then he tended to his menagerie, which consisted of either dogs, birds, chinchillas, iguanas or all of the above at any given time. Later, hed sip Bustelo espresso and watch old westerns. Ask him about those cinematic classics and he can still recite a few lines of dialogue with his Spanish drawl.

title: Literary Lion
description: Q: At the age of 82, you will be publishing your new collection of essays this week, which seems likely to confirm your reputation as one of Americas last public intellectuals. Why do you think that critics have traditionally praised your essays more than your fiction, which includes Burr,   Myra Breckinridge and 20 other novels? Thats because they dont know how to read. I cant name three first-rate literary critics in the   United States . Im told there are a few hidden away at universities, but they dont print them in The   New York Times .

title: The Late Dictator
description: Assassination has long been an appealing subject for male novelists. Geoffrey Households Rogue Male (1939), Richard Condons Manchurian Candidate (1959), Frederick Forsyths Day of the Jackal (1971), Don DeLillos Libra (1988) and James Ellroys American Tabloid (1995): all are fictions plotted by men about men plotting to murder other men.

title: Swapland
description: The reason bartering can work in villages  including, during various periods, Greenwich Village, the Haight-Ashbury and Burning Man  is that village neighbors make and need comparable products. Some corn, some carpentry, an embroidered pillowcase, firewood, horseshoes, quilts. Marijuana. A bottle of water.

title: Letter From Cairo
description: Cairo

title: Letter: How to Pick Asparagus
description: To the Editor: In the explorer column, On the Trail of a Sustainable Feast (June 1), the author states that Ana Stayton reached under a blueberry bush to yank a stray asparagus stem out of the ground for us to taste.

title: Bearing Bad News
description: In Steven Spielbergs Saving Private Ryan, soon after the re-creation of D-Day, attention turns stateside to a middle-aged woman washing dishes as a car approaches her home. The vehicle comes to a stop, and the woman  knowing what awaits  steps outside and onto her porch before falling to the ground, almost as if she were a soldier wounded in battle. Spielberg chooses to place the camera behind his actress and at somewhat of a distance; we do not see her face when she hears the news that three of her sons have been killed in combat. There is no audible dialogue, either. The power of the scene lies in its universality: a parent collapsing from an emotional anguish projected over a barren landscape.

title: The Other
description: No Escape from the Unhappiness Machine

title: In a Year Off the Beaten Path, a New Direction for Life
description: AT the end of my junior year in high school in Maryland, I realized I wasnt ready to apply to college or take the SAT. I wanted to postpone the whole application process and focus on my studies during senior year. A friend suggested a gap year  a year to pursue other interests  after high school.

title: Still the King, but Money Rules
description: The last few yards of stock-car racings Tobacco Road heritage were finally paved over last Wednesday when Petty Enterprises, a team dating from the start of Nascar in 1949, announced the sale of a majority interest to a private equity firm, Boston Ventures. Pressed for money and without a victory since 1999, Petty Enterprises needed capital to compete with the better-financed teams that now dominate.

title: Restrictions Reduce Horseshoe Crab Fishing
description: WESTHAMPTON DUNES

title: His Dad, the Worlds Darling
description: MY father was a saint. Everyone said so. His family. My mothers family. His business partners. His employees. Even his competitors.

title: A Case of Exploding Mangoes
description: There is something about these bloody squadron leaders that makes them think that if they lock you up in a cell, put their stinking mouth to your ear, and shout something about your mother, they can find all the answers. They are generally a sad lot, these leaders without any squadrons to lead. It's their own lack of leadership qualities that stops them mid-career, nowhere for them to go except from one training institute to another, permanent seconds in command to one commander or the other. You can tell them from their belts, loose and low, straining under the weight of their paunches. Or from their berets, so carefully positioned to hide that shiny bald patch. Schemes for part-time M.B.A.'s and a new life are trying hard to keep pace with missed promotions and pension plans.

title: Scraping the Sky, and Then Some
description: THE worlds population is expected to climb to nine billion by the middle of the century, from six and a half billion today, according to the United Nations, and a staggering number of those people are likely to be living in big cities.

title: DeMilles Close-Up
description: Simon Louvishs elegantly exhaustive study of Cecil Blount DeMille (1881-1959) carries the respectful if not necessarily reverent title Cecil B. DeMille: A Life in Art. It examines that life largely though not entirely through his 70 movies, completed during a 42-year career, from The Squaw Man in 1914 to The Ten Commandments in 1956, itself a remake of his own 1923 Ten Commandments. The Squaw Man was also remade as an early talkie in 1931, during a period in which all of Hollywood, and DeMille especially, was struggling, often pathetically and disastrously, to make sense and cinema out of the newfangled dimension of talk.

title: For 3 Days, 2 Jazz Festivals Will Go Head-to-Head
description: FOR 14 years, the jazz acts at the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah have been presented on two consecutive Saturdays at the end of July and the beginning of August. This year, they will be presented on three straight days, Aug. 1 to 3.

title: They Love (the New) Brooklyn
description: WHILE condominium developers across the country are trying to unload thousands of apartments that they cant sell, some builders in Brooklyn have found the real estate equivalent of a golden parachute. Having turned their new units into high-priced rentals, they have found a surprising number of eager takers.

title: Iowa River Falls, but Misery Isnt Over
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  As the waters of the Cedar River started to slowly recede in this city overnight, officials in other cities in Iowa were fighting untamed rivers.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in some copies of the baseball roundup in some editions last Sunday about the Giants 6-0 victory against the Nationals on June 7 misstated the number of runs Washington scored in losing six of seven games. It was 13  not 3, which was the total number of runs in the six losses.

title: A Graduate of Sha Na Na, Now a Linguistics Professor
description: Hempstead

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about the final efforts to prepare Big Brown for the Belmont Stakes referred incorrectly to his name. His only official name has been Big Brown; he was not named Boundary at birth. (Boundary is his sire.)

title: Up in Smoke
description: Even if you disregard the van Gogh cover sketch of a skeleton smoking a cigarette, its difficult to miss that When You Are Engulfed in Flames is a book about David Sedariss midlife crisis. He was in his 30s when he was discovered by Ira Glass of NPR, and ever since he has presented himself as a childish genius perpetually late to the literary scene and forever mini-crisis prone. Even as he was transformed into publishings Dave Matthews  with four best sellers, endless paid lecture opportunities and 30-city tours  its taken his 50th birthday to alert Peter Pan to the onset of maturity. Ive been around for nearly half a century, he moans, later adding, In another 25 years Ill be doddering, and 25 years after that Ill be one of the figures haunting my Paris bedroom. He tallies up the last 25 years, the prime of his life, and isnt impressed by the sum: How had 9,125 relatively uneventful days passed so quickly, he writes, and how can I keep it from happening again?

title: Tiny Town: Washington After a Fall
description: Washington  Did you hear about Tim Russert?

title: Into the Woods
description: In college, I had a friend named Kurt. A lot of people know someone like Kurt in college  brilliant, obsessive and kind of scary. He stayed up 72 hours reading Goethe. He filled a 50-page notebook with tiny scrawled notes about Henry James. (These werent class assignments.) He loved absolute principles and what he called the timeless. He railed against hypocrisy. He liked to stand outside fraternities and shout lines from Byron. When a poem offended him, he ate it  crumple, chew, swallow  and ended up with an intestinal blockage. My friends and I loved Kurt, and we worried about him.

title: A Year Reshapes Hamas and Gaza
description: GAZA  Cursing God in public here  a fairly common event in this benighted and besieged strip of Palestinian land  can now lead to prison. So can kissing in public. A judge ruled last week that a bank could not collect its contracted interest on a 10-year-old loan because Islam forbids charging interest.

title: Museum Repasts, From Snacks to Tea
description: THE majestic Charles II style manor house at Old Westbury Gardens, built from 1904 to 1906 for John S. and Margarita Grace Phipps and their four children, has been preserved as the family left it in 1958 after more than 50 years in residence. The ballroom has polished teak parquet floors and French doors opening onto a terrace with a sweeping view of the south lawn. A tea table in the chandeliered drawing room is set with the familys silver.

title: Two Bubbles, Two Paths
description: LATELY more and more people have been questioning the received wisdom about what a central bank should do when confronted by an asset price bubble. That piece of wisdom, shared by Alan Greenspan and Ben S. Bernanke, the former and present Federal Reserve chairmen, holds that deliberate bubble-bursting is something between impossible and dangerous  and thus best avoided. Instead, according to this view, the Fed should let bubbles burst of their own accord, and then be prepared to mop up after.

title: Tapped Out
description: To paraphrase an old axiom: You dont buy water, you only rent it. So why did Americans spend nearly $11 billion on bottled water in 2006, when we could have guzzled tap water at up to about one ten-thousandth the cost? The facile answer is marketing, marketing and more marketing, but Elizabeth Royte goes much deeper into the drink in Bottlemania: How Water Went on Sale and Why We Bought It, streaming trends cultural, economic, political and hydrological into an engaging investigation of an unexpectedly murky substance. Partway through her undoctrinaire book, Royte, a lifelong fan of tap water, refills her old plastic water bottle, reflecting that what once seemed so simple and natural, a drink of water, is neither. All my preconceptions about this most basic of beverages have been queered. And by the end of the book she will have discarded the old plastic bottle too, but not the tap.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Elnaz Menhaji, David Klotz
description: Elnaz Menhaji, a daughter of Badrolsadat Menhaji and Mohsen Menhaji of Greenvale, N.Y., was married on Friday to David Matthew Klotz, a son of Nancy H. Klotz and Lt. Gen. Frank G. Klotz of Bolling Air Force Base in Washington. Leslie Gross, the town clerk of North Hempstead, N.Y., officiated in her office there. On Sunday evening, Ahmad Pakzad is to lead a traditional Persian ceremony at the Westbury Manor, a caterer in Westbury, N.Y.

title: On the Big Stage, No Urge to Disturb
description: The word is that Broadway got hip this year.

title: To Curb Traffic on the Internet, Access Providers Consider Charging by the Gigabyte
description: Some people use the Internet simply to check e-mail and look up phone numbers. Others are online all day, downloading big video and music files.

title: Most Formidable Major Frustrates Golf's Greatest
description: For Tiger Woods, the United States Open has been the most difficult of the four major championships to win. If he were to stack his 13 majors as if they were poker chips, he has four Masters, three British Opens and four P.G.A. Championships, but only two Opens.

title: A Venerable Firm, at Least in Name
description: Thornberg & Forester may sound like a stodgy, corporate Wall Street firm thats been around for 100 years. In fact, its the concocted name of a year-old Manhattan design and communications group.

title: Senator Says Loan Favoritism Is Possible
description: Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, said Saturday that he would donate $10,500 to charity and refinance a property loan after suggestions that he and other prominent Washington figures received preferential treatment from Countrywide Financial Corporation.

title: Billionaires Go Shopping
description: THE moment of truth has arrived for 15 Central Park West, the limestone-clad retreat for the rich and very rich.

title: Thanks, Weird Al, You Model American
description: CAIRO  My son Nikolas will be 10 years old in August. He knows all about Ramadan and can walk into any mosque and tell the mihrab from the minbar. He is absolutely color blind to people and culture. Hes a child of the world, a kid who has spent eight years of his young life living first in Russia and then in Egypt.

title: Starting to Think Outside the Jar
description: WHEN it comes to innovations in everyday essentials, the glass is either half-empty or half-full.

title: Stephanie Denton, Zeno Baucus
description: Stephanie Maria Denton, the daughter of Linda L. Denton and Dr. Stephen L. Denton, both of Athens, Tenn., was married on Saturday evening in Big Sky, Mont., to Zeno Benjamin Baucus, the son of Ann Geracimos of Washington and Senator Max Baucus of Helena, Mont., and Washington. The Rev. Dave McConnell, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Big Sky Resort.

title: Croutons From My Father
description: Los Angeles

title: Dannielle Tegeder, Pablo Helguera
description: Dannielle Tegeder and Pablo Helguera are to be married on Sunday evening. The Rev. Mark W. Hummell, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate in Brooklyn.

title: Jennifer Baur, David Rooney
description: Jennifer Marie Baur, the daughter of Carolyn B. Baur and Michael P. Baur of Eatonton, Ga., was married on Friday evening to David Patrick Rooney, the son of Mary Ann and William F. Rooney of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Michael A. Carrano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine Church in Spring Lake.

title: The Conservator
description: When William F. Buckley Jr. died a few months ago, George F. Will, who dedicates One Mans America to him, became, perhaps, the rights most enduring elder statesman. Its a distinction hes worked assiduously to earn. Over the past three and a half decades, Will has been conservative in everything but his output, which includes several columns a week and regular appearances on Sunday television, along with a steady stream of books on subjects ranging from baseball to politics. But Will isnt noteworthy simply for his industry. As this droll and discerning examination of America reminds us, hes also been, and remains, the conscience of conservatism.

title: The Actor With Stardom in His Eyes
description: JAPANS most distinguished living actor, Tatsuya Nakadai, has made well over 100 movies, and hes still probably best known to American audiences for a role in which he is nearly unrecognizable. As Hidetora, the 80-something feudal patriarch of the Ichimonji clan in Akira Kurosawas Ran (1985), Mr. Nakadai  then in his early 50s  wore heavy makeup intended not only to age him but also to resemble a Noh mask. In an interview conducted three years ago for the Criterion DVD release of the film he said, They had to draw in every single wrinkle; the only parts of that face that were actually mine were the eyes.

title: When Young Was Old
description: Age can seem more a state of mind than a biological condition, particularly when it comes to presidents, who are often frozen in the images formed by history and legend. It is strange to think that Abraham Lincoln (52) and Franklin D. Roosevelt (51), who sagaciously guided the nation through times of unparalleled crisis, were both younger when they assumed office than George W. Bush (54) was when he did. Strange, too, that Andrew Jackson, the swashbuckling Hero of New Orleans and the embodiment of a new spirit of backwoods populism, began his first term at age 61, making him one of our older presidents, and positively ancient in his own day, when life expectancy for white males was below 40.

title: Examining Obamas Call for Scrutiny of Trade Deals
description: As he campaigns against what he describes as unfair foreign trade deals, Senator Barack Obama, the presumptive Democratic nominee, often singles out Japan and especially South Korea for criticism. Both countries, he complains, have erected all kinds of restrictions and barriers to shut out American products, including beef and automobiles.

title: Rival Turns Up the Heat on Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The pressure on President Pervez Musharraf to resign escalated Saturday after a senior leader in the civilian government suggested to a large outdoor rally here that Mr. Musharraf should be hanged.

title: When You Are Engulfed in Flames
description: It's Catching

title: After a Final Bow, Continuing a Legacy of Change
description: WHEN Damian Woetzel takes his final bow on Wednesday as a principal dancer for New York City Ballet, balletomanes everywhere will grieve. But as so often of late, City Ballets loss is the fields gain.

title: Adding Hamlet to Characters Within
description: MICHAEL STUHLBARG spoke so softly at times in this interview that the recording of it had to be played back at maximum volume, and even then some words registered barely above a whisper. The conversational voice of the man is in stark contrast to the speech of the actor.

title: Letters | Campaign Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: THE BOND ERA: Ian Flemings James Bond novels werent immediately popular with American readers. The first Bond title, Casino Royale, appeared here in 1954, early in Eisenhowers presidency, and didnt make much of a dent. Casino Royale took a beating in the Book Review. Our critic, Anthony Boucher, liked the novels opening baccarat scene but not much else. He complained that Fleming leads the weary reader through a set of tough clichs to an ending which surprises no one save Operative 007.

title: Accessorize Like an Ascetic
description: Your luggage or your wallet.

title: The Man for a New Sudan
description: When Roger Winters single-engine Cessna Caravan touched down near the Sudanese town of Abyei on Easter morning, a crowd of desperate men swamped the plane. Some came running over the rough red airstrip. Others crammed into a microbus that barreled toward the 65-year-old Winter as he climbed down the planes silver ladder. Some Sudanese call Winter uncle; others call him commander. On this day, angry and anxious, the people of Abyei wanted Winters help in averting a return to civil war between the predominantly Arab north and the black south  a decades-long conflict, claiming more than two million dead, that Winter helped to end with his work on the Comprehensive Peace Agreement of 2005.

title: Agee Unfettered
description: On May 16, 1955, James Agee, 45, died of a heart attack in a New York City taxicab while on the way to his doctors office. Elegized by the critic Dwight Macdonald as a literary James Dean, he left behind an idiosyncratic nonfiction classic called Let Us Now Praise Famous Men along with one of those myths for hard-living and intemperate genius that are far more alluring to young writers than the idea that they are going to spend their working lives alone in a room, hoping that something interesting will happen on the blank screen in front of them. (There are days when more interesting things happen on a widget assembly line.)

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio referred incorrectly to a military officer portrayed in Valkyrie, a planned film from United Artists (of which MGM is part-owner) about a plot against Hitler during World War II. While that officer, Col. Claus Graf Schenk von Stauffenberg, was in the German Army, he was not a member of the Nazi party.

title: Sarah Lucas and Jonathon Kass
description: WHAT works professionally can sometimes wreak havoc on ones personal life. As a policy analyst and legislative aide to a city councilman in Washington, Jonathon Kass habitually studies issues from all angles.

title: Correction: Running in Circles Over Carbon
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about cutting carbon dioxide emissions at coal-fired electric plants may have left an incorrect impression that a white plume shown rising from a cooling tower at one such plant was an example of greenhouse gases being discharged. The plume consisted of water vapor. (Carbon dioxide, which would be emitted from the plants smokestack shown at right, is colorless.)

title: Chasing the Golden Dream
description: An article last Sunday about Debbie Capozzi of Bayport, who will compete in sailing in the Olympics this summer, misidentified the location of Old Dominion University, where she was on the sailing team. It is Norfolk, Va., not Richmond.

title: Correction: Surfs Up, Channel Surfers
description: Two television listings last Sunday in the special Emmys section gave outdated broadcast dates. After the section went to press, Fox announced that Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles would begin Sept. 8, not Aug. 11, and Fringe would begin Sept. 9, not Aug. 26.

title: New Laws Try to Keep Swimmers Safe
description: WHEN the Township of West Caldwell, N.J., took on a major renovation at its Westville Avenue community pool five years ago, one news article was fresh in officials minds.

title: School Buys 42 Pianos, Steinways, That Is
description: IN its bid to become an all-Steinway school, the Conservatory of Music at Purchase College has bought a staggering number of grand pianos made by the esteemed 155-year-old manufacturer. The purchase of 42 pianos  20 of them seven-foot-long Model B grand pianos  was one of the largest acquisitions of Model Bs in Steinways history for student practice rooms, said Sally Coveleskie, national director of institutional sales for Steinway & Sons.

title: Letters | Double Your Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: Good (for) Shabbat
description: The old ads for Levys rye bread (You dont have to be Jewish to love Levys) apply to the traditional Friday night dinner as well: You dont have to be Jewish to love a good Shabbat special. Observant Jews start their day of rest the evening before, and a typical takeout chicken meal has evolved to meet their needs. But others are likely to appreciate these Shabbat specials as a great way to end a hectic week (and a solid value too).

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: After 10 Years, Tract Wins Protective Status
description: THE decade-long efforts of a homeowners group, town officials in Cortlandt and a developer have finally resulted in the preservation of one of the last large unprotected tracts of open space in the county.

title: Person-to-Person Loans
description: HOMEOWNERS who are having trouble borrowing against their house are starting to look to an interesting new source for cash: strangers.

title: Glass Ceiling, Meet Sisterhood
description: THE women are gathered for a celebratory dinner. The wine flows freely, as does the talk. Of the fickleness of men, the pleasures of sex, the price of achievement. Fashion is touched upon briefly  one woman boasts dreamily of a particularly extravagant gown made of eight layers of silk  but, oddly enough, the subject of shoes never once arises.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions last Sunday about the United States gymnastics championships misstated the age, in some copies, of a top competitor, Nastia Liukin. She is 18, not 19.

title: Homeowners Fight Back as Market Cools Off
description: JOSEPH ELLIOTT has been the tax assessor for Ocean City since 2003. In his five-year tenure, he has already overseen the reassessments of all 18,934 properties in this shore community  twice. And going a third round in the not too distant future is a distinct possibility.

title: Cheryl Liebman, Keith Guliner
description: Cheryl Jan Liebman and Keith Adam Guliner were married Saturday evening at the summer home of the brides parents in East Hampton, N.Y. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated.

title: Angela Campbell, Ethan Powell
description: Angela Brucia Campbell, the daughter of Margaret A. Brucia and James E. Campbell Jr. of Huntington, N.Y., was married on Saturday afternoon to Ethan Andrew Powell, the son of Andrea M. Powell and Wayne M. Powell of Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. David Robb performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Universalist Church in New York, where he is an assistant minister.

title: In the E-Mail Relay, Not Every Handoff Is Smooth
description: FOR centuries, letter writers have wondered whether their missives safely reach the hands of their intended recipients. I know not whether this will ever come to your hands or miscarry, opened a typical one in 1625, from Roger White in the Netherlands, who was writing to friends at Plymouth colony.

title: An Eccentric but Loving Man Had a Side No One Knew
description: PEOPLE often referred to my father as a character. For one thing, he had two first names. When my parents went to court to shorten our last name from Glovinski to Glovin, he told the judge, Id like to also change my first name from Max to Fred.

title: When Gas Prices Lead to Roads Less Traveled
description: What price would gasoline have to reach before it caused you to make a big change? Some people have already crossed that barrier. According to a survey by the NPD Group, a research firm, rising fuel prices have caused a small percentage of drivers to buy a more efficient vehicle or to move closer to their work.

title: Teenage Agenda
description: The mind of a teenage boy is not an easy place to inhabit. Philip Roth examined the exhausting mental  not to mention physical  work of existing in a perpetual state of heat; J. D. Salinger described the panicked resistance to entering the adult world of phonies; and, more recently, J. K. Rowling explored the frightening black magic of a changing body. The latest bulletin arrives from a 25-year-old Welsh writer, Joe Dunthorne, whose precocious talents and cheerful fondness for the teenage male are showcased in Submarine, his first novel.

title: Randolph Remains Seemingly Unfazed by Talk of Firing
description: Willie Randolph hardly knew him when he added Jerry Manuel to his coaching staff in 2004, before his first season as manager. If Randolph were to be fired, though, Manuel would be asked to take over. Manuel would love to manage in the major leagues again, but this is not how he wants to get that chance.

title: Letters: Rewarding Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Shows Optimism on Iraq Deal
description: PARIS  President Bush expressed confidence on Saturday that the United States and Iraq would agree on a new security arrangement this year, even though his strongest ally in Iraq, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, declared the negotiations at an impasse the previous day.

title: Think the Gender War Is Over? Think Again
description: San Francisco

title: Turbans Make Targets, Some Sikhs Find
description: Woodbridge

title: Free and Flush, Russians Eager to Roam Abroad
description: ANTALYA, Turkey  Yelena Kasyanova booked her trip at a local travel agency in about as much time it takes to drop by the market for a few groceries. She was soon lounging here by the Mediterranean, a working-class anybody from an anyplace deep in Russia, a child of the Soviet era who still remembers the humiliating strictures that once made it difficult to obtain a passport, let alone a plane ticket.

title: Maligned Buses, Beloved Trees, Perilous Crossings
description: Chinatown Buses: Criticized but Vital

title: Elizabeth Willett, Lee Falls
description: Elizabeth Le Baron Willett, the daughter of Elizabeth W. Willett and J. Jackson Willett III of Ruxton, Md., was married in Baltimore on Saturday evening to Henry Lee Falls III, the son of Betty C. Falls and Mr. Falls Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Sandra L. Lawrence, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer, where she is associate rector.

title: Welcoming a Car You Can Park on a Dime
description: NESTLED between an enormous Mitsubishi and a sprawling Jeep Liberty, the tiny red Smart car sits like a nub of jam between two slabs of cake. A stump of an automobile, a squat, friendly two-seater less than nine feet long, it fits, fuel-efficiently, in the half-spaces outside its owners apartment building on West 81st Street near Columbus Avenue.

title: Tokyo: Kanehara
description: It takes no effort to find good food in Tokyo. From the corner noodle shop and the humble 7-Eleven to deluxe sushi counters and Michelin-starred bistros, Japans capital offers great cuisine.

title: Musician, Sim. Albums, No.
description: A NUMBER of notable concerts of Brazilian music around the world this year, including one by Joo Gilberto next Sunday at Carnegie Hall as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, are being advertised with the line 50 Years of Bossa Nova. Mr. Gilberto is considered by many to have defined the musical form, which was embraced internationally and has never really gone away in Brazil. Yet Mr. Gilbertos first three albums, some of the best music of the 20th century, have largely been unavailable.

title: Approve This Deal, or Else
description: BOWING to shareholder pressure, directors at Washington Mutual, the nations largest savings and loan, stripped Kerry K. Killinger, chairman and chief executive of the company, of his chairmanship on June 2. The board said it would appoint an independent chairman by July 1, and it instituted a majority voting standard for future director elections.

title: Williss Decline: Was It Foreseeable?
description: Things have not turned out as planned in Detroit. In a major off-season trade, the Tigers landed the prized young stars Miguel Cabrera and Dontrelle Willis.

title: Georgia Close, Benjamin Spencer
description: Dr. Georgia Molly Close, a daughter of Leslie Rose Close and the artist Chuck Close of Bridgehampton, N.Y., was married there on Saturday evening to Dr. Benjamin Alan Spencer, a son of Susan K. Spencer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Anthony R. Spencer of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa S. Greene, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Tradition, and a Number of Twists
description: SOMETIMES we diners are so busy searching for the next new thing that we forget why we like some of the old, taking for granted their familiar, comfy-slippers appeal.

title: Falcon Cam
description: TELEVISION monitors rarely make New Yorkers pause, but in the marbled lobby of 55 Water Street, an insurance company worker named Katherine Stronk was transfixed recently by the image on the screen of four peregrine falcons in their nest on the buildings 14th floor.

title: By Caring for Animals, Foundation Helps Their Human Owners
description: Windsor

title: Signs of Progress in Cleanup After Storm Lashing
description: Maplewood

title: Darwinists for Jesus
description: In 1981, Michael Dowd would have counted himself among the millions of conservative Christians who blame Charles Darwins theory of evolution and the idea of a godless, purposeless universe for the moral decline of society. That year, as a freshman at Evangel University in Springfield, Mo., Dowd felt a rush of indignant anger in biology class when the professor held up a textbook that taught evolution. As he stormed out of the classroom, Dowd could not have imagined that he would come to view evolution as a spiritually inspiring idea that religion must embrace.

title: Brew Tour, From Kettle to Keg
description: People want things fresh and local, Joe Mendyka said, citing farmers markets and the Slow Food movement as examples, while pouring a short glass of pale ale for one of two visitors to the Thomas Hooker brewerys Saturday afternoon tour. Thomas Hooker, a resurrection of the Trout Brook brand, moved to Bloomfield in 2007.

title: The Love Song of R. Buckminster Fuller
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: Sloe Gin Is Back, but Hold the Fizz
description: IT hasnt been easy, in America, to love sloe gin. Once a barmans delicacy, both here and abroad, the gin-based liqueur  which takes its name and bittersweet flavor from the infusion of sloe berries, the purplish fruit of a wild shrub native to England  suffered a long, painful decline in the United States, when the import market dried up. American distillers filled the gap with mass-produced imitations that, according to the author and bartender Toby Cecchini, evoke grenadine spiked with grain alcohol.

title: Kathy Griffin Just Cant Shut Up
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Field of Facial Hair Helps a Place in Baseball History
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  Have you heard the one about Albert Einstein, Charles Bronson and John Holmes walking into a bar? It sounds like the beginning of a bad joke, but not to some of the workers at the Elysian Cafe on Washington Street. On Tuesday, the cafe will conduct a charity mustache competition with categories like scholarly (Einstein), vigilante (Bronson) and adult film star (Holmes).

title: Lakers Struggles in the Finals Put the Focus on Bryants Leadership
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  The Los Angeles Lakers may be down to their final game, and so naturally the conversation has swerved back to where it began, to Kobe Bryant.

title: Alexandra Melby, Andrew Farnum
description: Alexandra Tripp Melby and Andrew Lawrence Farnum were married in Washington on Saturday. The Rev. Scott A. Benhase performed the ceremony at St. Albans Episcopal Church, where he is the rector.

title: That Pesky Plant Returns in a Vibrant Little Shop
description: Audrey doesnt want much from life. Poor, dear, blond, bosomy Audrey, with her nasal New York accent and her perpetual black eye courtesy of her sadistic boyfriend, just wants a little tract house like everybody elses in an ordinary development.

title: Living Reminders of Africas Colonial Past in Namibia
description: IT was getting toward evening in Swakopmund, on the desert coast of Namibia, and at Kikis Pub just off Kaiser-Wilhelm-Strasse, the Pilsener was starting to flow. Swiveling on a stool with a stein of Hansa Draft in his fist, a stout fellow in safari shorts and with gray mutton-chop whiskers was chatting emphatically in German with the young bartender. Waitresses bearing the days catch moved through the room, its walls decorated with colonial-era German maps of Africa and sepia-tinted photos of Schutztruppe (German protection force) soldiers riding camels through the bush.

title: 2008 Tony Award Winners
description: A complete list of winners of 2008 Tony Awards (denoted with a *), with links to the original New York Times reviews. The list will be updated during the evening as the awards are announced.

title: Major Barbara
description: In 1980, Barbara Walters was about to report that Ronald Reagan had selected George H. W. Bush as his running mate when another reporter at another network beat her to it. Walters says she nearly went crazy after losing the scoop of the whole convention. Her colleague George Will simply looked at her with disdain and declared, Its only television, Barbara.

title: The C.I.A. and Contractors
description: To the Editor:

title: Silence Is Golden. Or Not.
description: I am a physician. A 30-year-old woman, a student at a local school, came for an initial visit. Her condition was unremarkable. A few weeks later the administrator of her school, a longstanding patient, mentioned how impressive it is that this woman continues to study despite having terminal cancer. The school even held a fund-raiser to help with her medical bills. I said nothing, but must I let the school know that she does not have cancer? May I confront her about this?  NAME WITHHELD

title: Fast Finish and Controversy at Womens Championship
description: The manner in which the United States womens champion was crowned last month raises questions about the process.

title: Want to See All of France? Rail Europes New Pass Helps
description: Paris not enough for you? Want to eat strudel in Strasbourg, sip wine in Bordeaux or sunbathe on the Riviera, but youre feeling hemmed in by a tight budget? Now theres a way to visit all of France without breaking the bank. Anywhere Anytime France, Rail Europes first prepaid electronic ticketing system, is for Francophiles on a budget who would like to visit more than two French cities by train. After an initial purchase of $199, travelers can buy an unlimited number of $50 train tickets. All accommodations are in first class. To sign up, visit raileurope.com to set up an account and purchase tickets, which can be printed out later at ticket offices or self-service kiosks in French train stations. There are a few caveats: to get the $50 rate, travelers must purchase all their trips at the same time (subsequent trips will cost $70), and all travel must be completed within 30 days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Praise for a Horse Who Lost

title: House Wont Sell? Turn It Into a B&B
description: Ridgefield, Conn.

title: When Old Money Marries New Media
description: MELISSA C. MORRIS was weighing her words carefully. The society wife, whose two-and-half-year-old blog about her rarefied life has garnered a devoted and growing readership, wanted to be sure nothing she said could be taken the wrong way. Over espresso at a restaurant near her Manhattan apartment, she said that, on the Internet and in life, I focus on the positive. I like to keep things lighthearted.

title: Malthus Redux: Is Doomsday Upon Us, Again?
description: During the last American food-and-gas-price crisis, in the 1970s, one of my colleagues on the Berkeley student newspaper told me that he and his semi-communal housemates had taken a vote. Theyd calculated they could afford meat or coffee. They chose coffee.

title: The Intel Investigation
description: It certainly took its time. But the Federal Trade Commissions decision to open a formal antitrust investigation of Intel is very welcome.

title: A Sportscaster Revealed a Dictators Human Side
description: In the summer of 1991, ABC Sports packed a 423-foot cargo ship with 15 mobile units, 40 cameras, 20 miles of cable, 50 videotape machines, 5 satellite dishes and enough food to feed 350 people for three weeks, and shipped it to Havana to cover the most important sporting event to take place in Cuba  the Pan American Games.

title: New Take on a Prostate Drug, and a New Debate
description: For the first time, leading prostate cancer specialists say, they have a drug that can significantly cut mens risk of developing the disease, dropping the incidence by 30 percent.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Site for Boutique Hotels Widens Scope
description: Mr. and Mrs. Smith, a London-based travel publisher and hotel reservations service that specializes in boutique hotels, has recently extended its collection of over 400 properties in Britain, Europe, Southeast Asia, Africa, Australia, South America and the Caribbean to include selections in the United States.

title: A Victory for Tenants
description: OFF the construction-choked streets of Manhattan, tenants are in court fighting condominium developers, in search of justice  or at least a bigger settlement.

title: Letters: 31 Summer Destinations
description: To the Editor: Of the 31 places to go in the United States  The 31 Places to Go This Summer (June 1), you had only one attraction in the Southeast: Myrtle Beach, S.C.

title: A New-Old Pony Enters the Corral
description: SPIKING gasoline prices, tighter emissions standards, a grim economic outlook  does this sound familiar?  all conspired to doom the original Dodge Challenger to an early expiration date.

title: Cowboys Ware Fulfills a Challenge for Fatherhood
description: SOUTHLAKE, Tex.  DeMarcus Ware cradled his 3-month-old daughter, smoothing her plentiful black hair, tickling her tummy, kissing her cheeks.

title: Old Farming Habits Leave Uzbekistan a Legacy of Salt
description: KHUJAYLI, Uzbekistan  Salt crunches underfoot like frosty soil on this bare stretch of land in western Uzbekistan.

title: Correction: Public Theaters Dreamer in Chief
description: An article last Sunday about Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, misstated the position that his colleague Mara Manus held while at the Ford Foundation. She was a program officer for economic development, not a fund-raiser.

title: Theyre Drawn Back, Once Again, by Stickball
description: Yiggy showed up early, carrying the mop and broom handles he keeps in his closet back home. Barry Heyman, 63, arrived soon afterward, bearing a large black and white photograph of the eighth-grade class of 1958. David Sternthal, 63, the blurry one in the photo because he jerked when the boy next to him pinched him in the behind, brought his video camera.

title: Editors Choice
description: WHILE THEY SLEPT: An Inquiry Into the Murder of a Family, by Kathryn Harrison. (Random House, $25.) Harrisons account brings moral clarity to the dark fate of the family of Jody Gilley, who was 16 when she survived a rampage by her brother in 1984.

title: Mugabe Vows to Go to War Before Ceding Post
description: JOHANNESBURG  The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, sounding ever more pugnacious, said Saturday that he was prepared to go to war if he lost a runoff election to the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai on June 27.

title: Shuttle Returns Safely After a 14-Day Mission
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Discovery rolled to a stop here on Saturday morning, bringing a 14-day mission to the International Space Station to a close.

title: A Father to One Thousand Hits
description: I had made the drive so many times that I wasnt even conscious of it anymore. Philadelphia to Teaneck, N.J., became a Star Trek teleporter from Center City to 619 Cadmus Court. All I knew was I ended up home.

title: Indian to the Core, and an Oligarch
description: Mumbai

description: It all started with cards.

title: Sara Schoenfeld, Marc Wein
description: Sara Rachelle Stiefel Schoenfeld, the daughter of Leanna Stiefel and Dr. Melvyn Schoenfeld of New York, was married on Saturday to Marc Nathan Wein, the son of Wendy S. Wein and Dr. Richard B. Wein of Cheshire, Conn. Rabbi Howard S. Herman officiated at the Seymour St. John Chapel of Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, Conn.

title: Giants Manning Calmly Returns to the Stage
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: The Taste of Flowers
description: MY favorite French bakery, Madeleine Patisserie, is a quiet oasis on West 23rd Street near Seventh Avenue. Stopping in for Earl Grey tea with soy milk and the best raspberry Parisian macaroons in or out of Paris, I sit by the window, and watch the comings and goings on the street.

title: Air India Has a Sale, Weather Permitting
description: In this age of ever-rising airfares, heres a last-minute deal that stands out (even if it does mean dodging monsoons): Air Indias One Price India sale. The sale, which ends Friday, is offering round-trip tickets from Kennedy or Newark airports in the New York area to Chhatrapati Shivaji Airport in Mumbai, and to over 40 other destinations in India served by the carrier, set at $549 (for departures Aug. 19 to Sept. 18); $599 (for departures Aug. 1 to 18 and Sept. 19 to Oct. 31); and $704 (for departures July 14 to 31). To get this rate, travelers must leave New York from Sunday through Thursday and return Monday through Friday (weekend departures are available for an additional $50). Taxes and fees are not included. Passengers must also travel during monsoon season (roughly June through September), unless they are flying in October (www.airindia.com).

title: Chaser of Beer, Rock or Bebop With Your Bach?
description: YOU might not expect to find a polished young ensemble like the Parker String Quartet playing music by Beethoven, Bartok and Ligeti  or collaborating with ensembles like Las Rubias del Norte, which specializes in Latin American folk music  in the no-frills back room of a Brooklyn bar. But the group spent this season as the resident quartet at Barbs, a Park Slope bar that regularly presents classical performers in a schedule otherwise devoted to jazz, pop and world music.

title: Paperback Row
description: DIVISADERO, by Michael Ondaatje. (Vintage International, $13.95.) This novel by the author of The English Patient braids together three stories full of parallels and resonances. On a Northern California farm, two girls grow up with their father and an adopted farmhand whose love for one of the sisters leads to an act of violence with lasting consequences. She becomes a literary historian obsessed by a French poet who vanished mysteriously. And she moves to the French countryside, where she falls in love with a guitar-playing Gypsy who turns out to be the poets more-or-less adopted son. Our reviewer, Erica Wagner, found the book initially hard to follow, but concluded, Give in to Ondaatje and his language will seduce you.

title: Fuel Thoughts
description: Between Lowell and Lawrence, Mass., last Tuesday mid-afternoon, the temperature reached 102 degrees. By the time I got to Boothbay Harbor, Me., the thermometer had dropped 40 degrees. To my surprise, the price of fuel had dropped too. In my experience, gas is always more expensive where youre going than where youre coming from, unless youre going to Indiana. At stations along the secondary roads in New York State, diesel fuel, which is what my pickup takes, was over $5 a gallon. In Boothbay Harbor, it was $4.79, and the lobster rolls were cheaper too.

Even though Im halfway through life, a little part of me still dreads Fathers Day  the holiday when, it seemed back then, everyone was celebrating exactly what I didnt have.

My sturdy 7-year-olds horrifying case was considered mild, but if an infant or young toddler caught such a disease from an older child in the play group, the results could be tragic.

Cooke lived in this country for sixty-seven years, producing a body of work of unrivaled perceptiveness, affectionateness, and elegance. One of his books, published in 1952, was titled One Man's America. The title of the book you are holding is one man's homage to Cooke.

title: Father Knows Pets
description: When my kids started clamoring for a pet, I was strategically indifferent. I grew up in Miami, in a house with more pets than kids, and while I believed that there was an emotional benefit to the dogs, the cats, the birds, the fish and the mice, I wasnt going to admit it, because then Id have to think through the practicalities: health, space, food, waste. My wife, who also grew up in Miami, also with pets, readily admitted the benefits and started thinking through the practicalities. She concluded that a cat was problematic. She told the kids. They cried. They promised that theyd do all the cat-related jobs. Enough, I said. They fell silent, which meant only that I heard the noise of the clock ticking. The countdown to cat had begun.

title: Foreclosures and the Election

Like so many other problems, the foreclosure crisis will be dumped on the next president and the next Congress.

title: Atlantic City Oddity: A Hotel, but No Casino
description: The Water Club, a Signature Hotel by Borgata, which is opening this month in Atlantic City, deserves its name. The club, a 43-story hotel, has five pools (three indoor, two outdoor) and ocean or bay views from all 800 rooms, each with big glass-enclosed showers with waterfall showerheads. The Water Club, the first luxury hotel in Atlantic City that doesnt have a casino, also features a two-story, 36,000-square-foot spa called Immersion (get it?) and a lobby where water flows across a curved wall, along with a reflecting pool. For those who do not want to swim or soak, they can shop (the Shoppes at the Water Club include La Perla, which sells lingerie, and Hearts on Fire, which sells diamonds), or attend meetings (there is 18,000 square feet of meeting space). Nightly rates start at $299 (www.thewaterclubatborgata.com).

title: Angle of Repose
description: Seen in profile, perched on a hillside overlooking the ocean in Southern California, this house looks almost birdlike, with outstretched wings and a long tail. The wings turn out to be the upswept roof of the main living areas, and the tail is the roof of a long passage that leads from the front door. Though the roof lines are entirely functional, for the houses architect, Tom Kundig, the avian analogy is an apt one. Kundig, a partner in the Seattle firm Olson Sundberg Kundig Allen, says that he wanted the house to be a small building that landed lightly on the landscape, much like the raptors he had seen hovering over the hills.

For the sake of the environment, she dutifully lugged them back and forth from the grocery store every week. Cutting out disposable paper cartons, she reasoned, meant saving trees and reducing waste.

title: Checking Baggage? Not at These Prices
description: FIRST came the liquids and gels crackdown, sending road warriors to their corner drugstores in search of that ever-elusive three-ounce bottle of contact-lens solution. Then came tighter weight restrictions for checked baggage, causing logjams at airport check-in desks as vacationers promptly unzipped their suitcases, transferring shoes and other heavy items into carry-ons in an effort to lighten their checked luggage.

title: Gay Couples Find Marriage Is a Mixed Bag
description: BOSTON  Four years after Massachusetts became the first state to allow gay couples to marry, there have been blissful unions, painful divorces and everything in between.

title: Letters: Banksable
description: While not always a fan of Ms. Banks, I have a newfound respect for her business acumen after reading Lynn Hirschbergs profile of her (June 1). She has created a Tyra Market that is both profitable and marketable.

title: Messages of Exhortation, Counsel and Congratulation
description: President Bush, addressing students at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., last month, said a bit wistfully that it would be the last commencement address of his presidency. Mr. Bush has seemed to enjoy the campus speeches each spring, often bantering with cadets at military academies. But he has also used them to speak patriotically about his goals in Iraq.

title: When Dads Were Models for All of Us
description: Long ago, I grew up with three dads: my own and two neighbors who had enough left over after dealing with their own kids to feel like dads to us as well. They lived in split-level houses next to one another that they bought around 1953 for about $30,000 at 39, 35 and 31 Tanners Road in Great Neck. Back then, they were too busy with the grand and quotidian duties of fatherhood to meditate too much about it. So, on Fathers Day 2008, a respectful salute to fatherhood before play dates, before anything 24/7, or 2.0.

title: Upon This Rock, a Church of Cracks
description: THE hole in the back of St. Brigids Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, big enough to walk through, is nailed over with blue plywood now. The tall arched window frames along the side, where construction workers smashed the old painted-glass windows on a day almost two years ago when it seemed the whole building would be razed, are covered in plexiglass.

description: SEVEN years ago, Casey J. Pedrick arrived in New York to join her future husband, Steven Jackson. At that point, permanently relocating to the city was not an option. I am a suburban girl, she declared.

title: The Watch List
description: On Saturday night, Braves fans had their first look at the teams top pitching prospect, Charlie Morton, below, who was called up to fill in for the injured starter Tom Glavine. The 24-year-old Morton struggled earlier in his minor league career, but he improved at the end of last season and continued his solid play in the Arizona Fall League, going 4-1 with a 2.57 earned run average. This season, he has done better, going 4-2 with a 2.05 E.R.A. for Class AAA Richmond. He earned the win in his debut, a 9-4 victory against the Angels. He allowed three runs in six innings, striking out four.

title: Out of This World, Catchy or Good for Driving
description: After a decade-long hiatus, Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth has gotten back together with two of her Free Kitten band mates, Julie Cafritz and Yoshimi P-We. The product of their reunion is Inherit (Ecstatic Peace), a blurry, rowdy guitar fest that Ms. Gordon says was influenced by the freak folk movement in western Massachusetts. We made this album because we were bored, she said, and also because Julie has two kids and needed to get out of the house. Inherit was released last month, and though the bands in no rush to go on a formal tour, Ms. Gordon did allude to secret shows. In addition to recording, Ms. Gordon, 55, has been collaborating on Sensational Fix, a traveling exhibition of works by visual artists, filmmakers and others who have worked with Sonic Youth that opens on Tuesday in St. Nazaire, in western France. While in New York City this spring to attend an exhibition at KS Art organized by Thurston Moore, her husband and Sonic Youth band mate, Ms. Gordon spoke by phone with Winter Miller about what shes listening to now.

title: Figuring Marlene Dumas
description: MARLENE DUMASS STUDIO occupies an underheated, underfurnished ground-floor apartment on the southern side of Amsterdam. As she sat at her worktable one evening in late March, emptying a bottle of white wine and picking at a plate of almond pastries, she offered an image of contented Bohemianism. Beside her, a red vase held a bouquet of dead white tulips, and beyond an unusually tall window, dusk was gathering in a garden densely overgrown with weeds.

Mr. Boyd, a retired telephone worker, nodded and walked through, but there was no exchange of pleasantries, no neighborly chitchat.

title: Bonnaroo: A Word About Access
description: People refer to Bonnaroo as a small town and, like every village, it has its hierarchy, in this case, one defined by wrist bands and badges. We do, in fact, need your stinkin badges. To have access at Bonnaroo means not having to endure the brutal bathroom lines, enjoying hospitality while others plop in dust, and in general, to want for not much. The press credentials I had helped me get up close at many stages, including right up on top of the My Morning Jacket show. But last night, the Pearl Jam stage locked up early and I was banished to a far hill, where Eddie Vedder,was a dot on the stage and a broadcast presence on the big video screens.

title: Bonnaroo: Eddie Vedder Sings with Jack Johnson
description: Eddie Vedder knows a Jack Johnson song: Constellations, a romantic ballad about lying down under the stars. He came out to sing it with Mr. Johnson, who was playing the big What stage before Pearl Jams set there tonight. Mr. Johnson is ubiquitous at festivals this summer, and its easy to see why. His songs are catchy, relaxed and full of kindly sentiments. They vamp along like jam-band tunes, but also have pop choruses. Mr. Johnson has an amiable, Everyman voice  like a latter-day Steve Miller  that puts his tunes within just about anybodys singalong capability. In addition, his entire touring operation seeks to make a minimal environmental impact.

title: Bonnaroo: Calling for Change
description: If there are any Republicans performing at Bonnaroo, theyre keeping quiet about it. In the meantime, performers that sing about politics, like Pearl Jam and the multicultural Los Angeles groove band Ozomatli, are putting out election-year messages, and bands that generally dont are subtly or unsubtly stumping for Barack Obama. During Pearl Jams exhilarating set, Eddie Vedder, Pearl Jams leader, did not mention Mr. Obamas name, but made heartfelt speeches calling for change, and for an encore he sang No More, with the chorus no more war.
