Yet Detroiters also have been waiting nearly a year to see Mr. Obama, who has not appeared in the city since last July, when he received thunderous applause during an N.A.A.C.P. candidate forum despite being considered a long shot to become the Democratic nominee. He did not campaign in the state before the primary and his name did not even appear on Michigans ballot, after party leaders moved up the date in violation of Democratic National Committee rules.

description: Willie Randolph wheeled his suitcase through the Mets clubhouse at 10:20 a.m., said, Wake up, Johnny, to a sleepy-looking John Maine lounging on a couch and proceeded to his office. It is still his office, by the way, with it looking more and more likely that Randolph will accompany the team on their flight Sunday night to California. Barring a complete and total disaster during Sundays doubleheader, of course, because in the Mets bizarre game-by-game, minute-by-minute world, their plans can change with little notice.

title: Le Mans, les mains and Fernando speaks at Technocenter
description: I can sigh relief today. The lede of one of my stories about Le Mans came true: The top three finishers at Le Mans were Audis and Peugeots. Furthermore, my decision to go not to Le Mans but to the celebration of the 10th anniversary of the Renault Technocenter paid off. I didnt have to write the story about Jacques Villeneuve winning the Triple Crown  as he finished only second in Le Mans  and I did manage to speak to Fernando Alonso. I have put up a recording of that interview, and I was particularly interested in what he said about why he attacked so hard  and blew it  at the Canadian Grand Prix. I liked that response  it reminded me of the kind of thing you might have heard fromGilles Villeneuve. But youll have to listen to the end of my Alonso interview to hear it.

title: Bonnaroo: The Warriors Stick Around
description: The Friday and Saturday overload is over. Sunday is for what Aimee Mann just called the Bonnaroo warriors, in it to the end. Death Cab for Cutie and the Robert Plant-Alison Krauss collaboration are worth sticking around for, and so was Orchestra Baobab, a Senegalese band in love with Afro-Caribbean music Baobab formed in 1970, before Senegalese rock found a more nationalistic style with mbalax, Baobabs rhythms have a Caribbean liltCuban and Jamaicanwhile its vocals are African and its guitarist, Barthelemy Attisso, is quietly startling. His leads have some blues, some jazz, some surf-guitar reverb and tremolo and a supple touch thats unmistakably African. No wonder groups audience, which would barely have filled a club as the band started, multiplied across the field before the end of the set.

title: Bonnaroo: Kanye Goes On Late. Really Late.

title: Bonnaroo: Same Set, Different Sound
description: I had seen Robert Plant and Alison Krauss performing their duets with T-Bone Burnett leading their Raising Sand Revue band in New York, at WaMu Theater, the night before I left for Bonnaroo. It was a memorable concert: hazy with smoke and reverb, full of mystery and melancholy. And I was curious to see how such eerie, pristine music would survive daylight, a standing audience and the bleary day-four Bonnaroo crowd. It did, by turning everything inside out. The set list was virtually the same, the effect entirely different. The Raising Sand album was conceived and partly recorded in nearby Nashville, representing Mr. Plants discovery of, as he bluntly put it, Americas white songwriters. And behind the grief and solitude in many of the songs, it turned out, was a core of tenacity.

title: Five Words to Communicate Brand
description: The Webby Awards, honoring excellence on the Internet, were announced last week. And after I recovered from not being nominated, I spent some time browsing the list of acceptance speeches, which adhered to an interesting format. The winners had to accept their awards using no more than five words. The most successful of these speeches are terrific examples of branding. For example, Stephen Colbert, the winner of the Webby person of the year award, simply accepted with Me. Me. Me. Me. Me.

title: Golf Can Extend Your Life, Study Says
description: Golf is good for your health and can extend your life by five years, according to a recently released Swedish medical study. And better golfers seem to live the longest. Data collected from 300,000 Swedish golfers showed that the death rate in golfers was significantly lower than it was for the rest of the population. The lowest death rates were reported among those with the lowest golf handicap. Researchers reasoned that because the game is good for you, playing it more often (typical behavior for better golfers) yields even more benefit.

description: OTTAWA  Imagine if Fox bought up all the rights to Take Me Out to the Ballgame and decreed it would be heard only on its own broadcasts. title: Karzai Threatens to Send Soldiers Into Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan threatened on Sunday to send soldiers into Pakistan to fight militant groups operating in the border areas to attack Afghanistan. His comments, made at a news conference in Kabul, Afghanistan, are likely to worsen tensions between the countries, just days after American forces in Afghanistan killed 11 Pakistani soldiers on the border while pursuing militants.

title: Gay Marriages Begin in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With a series of simple I dos, gay and lesbian couples across California inaugurated the states court-sanctioned and potentially short-lived experiment with same-sex marriage on Monday, the first of what are expected to be a crush of such unions in coming weeks.

title: A Young Man From Omaha, Who May Perfectly Represent Brooklyn
description: Moments before Yosef Abrahamson, 16, accepted an award for the essay hed written in a competition sponsored by the Police Athletic League, an officer approached him to complain about his fedora. The hat, an essential wardrobe item for Hasidic men, was gaudy, the policeman told him, and whats with all these kids today and their nose rings and their attitudes. A second police officer, overhearing the conversation, came over to steer away the first one, who reappeared a few minutes later to apologize. Hed never seen a Hasidic Jew, he told Yosef.

title: At the Box Office, Hulks More Incredible
description: The Incredible Hulk, above, an attempt by Marvel Entertainment Inc. and Universal Pictures to give fans of the Hulk comic books and television series a better movie than the disappointing 2003 Ang Lee film Hulk, shows early signs of faring better. The newest version, starring Edward Norton as Bruce Banner, a scientist who turns into a giant green beast when his blood pressure soars, was the top box-office draw over the weekend, making $54.5 million in its first week in theaters. It was a tight race for the No. 2 spot this weekend, between the new M. Night Shyamalan thriller The Happening (Fox), starring Mark Wahlberg, and last weeks No. 1 movie, Kung Fu Panda, featuring the voice of Jack Black. This animated comedy from DreamWorks Animation and Paramount took in $34.3 million over the weekend for a cumulative gross of $118 million in two weeks out, according to Media by Numbers, a box-office tracking firm. The Happening made $30.5 million in its first weekend. In fourth place was You Dont Mess With the Zohan (Sony) starring Adam Sandler, which made $16.4 million for the weekend and $68.8 million to date, and following in fifth place was Paramounts Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, which took in $13.5 million, for a total of $275.3 million in box office since it opened on May 23.

title: Can We Talk? Lively Musical Conversations, With a Contemporary Slant

But for their final concert of the season at Zankel Hall on Friday night, the musicians chose the pieces and, always a delicate matter, decided who should play what part in each work. Every piece chosen explored the concept of concertato, the musical equivalent of a conversation in a lively, eclectic social setting: a boisterous pub, perhaps, as the program note suggested.

description: SAN DIEGO  The United States Open playoff between Rocco Mediate and Tiger Woods on Monday will not be match play, but as an 18-hole, head-to-head contest, there is still room for gamesmanship.

title: Truffle Hound and Trusty Snoop Unearth Grim Secrets
description: Ruth Rendell published From Doon With Death, the first of her Chief Inspector Wexford novels, in 1964. So it is not surprising that the old boy finds himself in codgerly company these days. Ms. Rendell has ghoulish fun with the assorted elderly, eccentric characters who bedevil him in Not in the Flesh, which is only the third of her Wexford books to appear in this present century.

title: Woods Forces a Playoff With a Dramatic Birdie on 18
description: SAN DIEGO  Tiger Woods, facing defeat in the 108th United States Open, summoned one more dramatic shot Sunday  a birdie putt from 15 feet to tie Rocco Mediate at one-under-par 283 and send the Open into a playoff Monday for the first time since 2001 at Southern Hills.

title: In Iraqs South, a Mission Has Dual Aims
description: BAGHDAD  In an operation with military and political objectives, the Iraqi Army continued to assemble troops in and around the southern city of Amara on Sunday.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The DealBook column on Tuesday, about efforts by the railroad company CSX to keep a British private equity fund from winning control of some of its board seats, misstated the relationship of Representative Corrine Brown, a Florida Democrat who has spoken out on CSXs behalf, to Edward Waters College in Jacksonville, Fla. Ms. Brown received an honorary degree from and has close ties to the college, which received $25,000 from CSX and $1 million from its chief executive, but it is not her alma mater.

title: After a Feud and 2 Deaths, Soldiers Families Torn
description: Capt. Phillip Esposito and Staff Sgt. Alberto Martinez went to war together, two very different soldiers from the same New York National Guard unit. After five months in Iraq, a bombing sent both men back home, one in a coffin, the other in handcuffs, a suspect in his murder.

title: Yanks Lose Their Ace and Eye Another
description: HOUSTON  The Yankees season changed irreversibly on Sunday. Chien-Ming Wangs season is in jeopardy with a serious injury to his right foot, and C. C. Sabathia instantly became a very important name in the Yankees universe.

title: NBC Universal Brings Oxygen Into the Fold
description: NBC Universal spent almost a billion dollars buying the Oxygen cable channel last year. Now its busy making it a member of the family.

title: United States Wins by Record Margin in Cup Qualifier
description: CARSON, Calif.  Freddy Adu was asked after practice last week if he could pick out Barbados, the United States first opponent in qualifying for the 2010 World Cup, on an atlas.

title: Footnotes
description: Primary Stages has announced the cast of Buffalo Gal, the new comedy by A. R. Gurney that will be the first production in the companys 2008-9 season. The six-member cast will include Susan Sullivan, known mostly for her television appearances on Falcon Crest, Dharma & Greg and other shows; Mark Blum (Twelve Angry Men) and Carmen M. Herlihy (The Piano Teacher). Performances start July 22 for a limited run through August 30 at 59E59 Theaters. ... One World Symphony (oneworldsymphony.org) will present semistaged performances of Richard Strausss Ariadne Auf Naxos, on June 27 at St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights and again on June 29 at the Ansche Chesed Synagogue, 251 West 100th Street, Manhattan. Both performances will start at 8 p.m. Tickets are $30 to $40.

title: MySpace Might Have Friends, but It Wants Ad Money
description: When the News Corporation added MySpace to its portfolio nearly three years ago, it expected that if its base of 16 million users kept growing  and each user kept adding friends, sharing photos and swapping flirty messages  the advertising dollars would roll in.

title: Separate Bloomsdays for Theater and Radio
description: For nearly three decades theatergoers, literature lovers and admirers of Irish culture have traveled to Symphony Space or tuned in to WBAI on June 16 in order to watch or listen to actors honor the life of James Joyce and interpret his novel Ulysses, one of the most celebrated and recondite books of the 20th century.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on the Square Feet pages on June 4 about a mixed-income residential development planned on the site of a former state mental hospital in southwestern Boston referred imprecisely to the organization that runs a nearby nature preserve. Although the area is indeed overseen by the Audubon Society, it is the Massachusetts Audubon Society, not the National Audubon Society. (The two groups are not affiliated.)

title: Officials Fear Bomb Design Went to Others
description: WASHINGTON  Four years after Abdul Qadeer Khan, the leader of the worlds largest black market in nuclear technology, was put under house arrest and his operation declared shattered, international inspectors and Western officials are confronting a new mystery, this time over who may have received blueprints for a sophisticated and compact nuclear weapon found on his networks computers.

title: The Forest Premeditated: Illusions of Wildness in a Botanical Garden
description: Before Sunday it was possible to enter the conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden, look out a window resembling the one Charles Darwin once gazed from at Down House in Kent, England, and see a lush overgrowth of petals and leaves, exuberant in its variety and density. Now that view is gone (unless, presumably, you travel to Kent). The Botanical Garden has dispersed the plantings, along with the stagecraft of labels and frames, and replaced David Kohns smartly mounted exhibition, Darwins Garden, with another temporary horticultural display.

title: The Massachusetts Model
description: Massachusettss pioneering plan to provide universal health coverage is off to a good start and is heartening evidence that national health care reform may be possible if sufficient skill and determination are applied to forge a political consensus.

title: Valentine Vester, Jerusalem Hotelier, Is Dead at 96
description: PARIS  Valentine Vester, a Yorkshire homemaker who went to Jordanian Jerusalem in 1963 to take over a little hotel, the American Colony, and turned it into one of the citys finest, died on Sunday morning at her home in the hotel. She was 96.

title: Pot Dealers Washed Up in an Unchic Beach Town
description: For a long time it has been hard to know what Weeds, the Showtime series starring Mary Louise Parker as a widowed suburban drug dealer, actually stands for but too easy to see what it is against.

title: Lack of Care in Detention
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Opera to Host New York City Ballet
description: New York City Ballet will become the first non-French dance company to perform at the Opera Bastille in September, when the Paris Opera presents the ballet company in the French capital for the first time since 1965. The engagement marks the first time that Peter Martins, City Ballets ballet master in chief, and Gerard Mortier, director of the Paris National Opera and the soon-to-be general manager and artistic director of New York City Opera, will work together. City Ballet will perform Sept. 9 through 21 at the Bastille, the modern opera house that opened in 1989. Highlights will include a joint performance by the Paris Opera Ballet and City Ballet at the Palais Garnier on Sept. 18 and will feature two Gallic hallmarks of City Ballet history  Apollo, which Balanchine choreographed and gave its first performance in Paris in 1928, and Symphony in C, which was originally titled Le Palais de Cristal and was created at the Palais Garnier in 1947. Mr. Martins said his company will present 18 ballets that will pay tribute to Balanchine and Jerome Robbinss long associations with Paris, as well as ballets by Mr. Martins and Christopher Wheeldon. We have a whole different repertoire and a whole different take on dance, Mr. Martins said. The season is made possible through joint financing by Paris National Opera, City Ballet, and the American Friends of the Paris Opera and Ballet.

title: In a Changing World of News, an Elegy for Copy Editors
description: I went to the Newseum, a shiny new building in Washington that news companies and foundations have erected as a shrine to their industry. Since its my industry, too, I thought a museum, where sacred relics and texts have been placed safely in the equivalent of a big glass jar, might make me hopeful about the future.

title: No Rushing Talks on Pact With U.S., Iraqis Say
description: BAGHDAD  Discussions among Iraqi politicians on the countrys long-term security agreement with the United States were under way over the weekend, but it will take many weeks and more likely months before the agreement is completed, people close to the negotiations said.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted June 6 to 11 with 1,062 adults throughout the state. Of those, 931 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: Gunther Stent, an Early Researcher in Molecular Biology, Is Dead at 84
description: Gunther Stent, one of the original thinkers in the field of molecular biology, whose research wrestled with and validated the breakthrough discovery of the structure of DNA, died Thursday near his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 84.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on May 29 about a decline in liquefied natural gas imports misstated the name of the energy consulting firm that employs Nikos Tsafos, an analyst who commented on shrinking supplies. It is PFC Energy, not PCF Energy.

title: Recalling Russert as Political Operative in New York
description: WASHINGTON  For most of Washington, Tim Russert was known as the successful moderator of Meet the Press on NBC and a premier chronicler of the presidential campaign. His accomplishments and status could be measured in the flood of tributes that poured in from his colleagues, competitors and the people he covered.

title: Offer Says, This Buds for InBev
description: InBev, the worlds biggest brewer, started to build an argument Sunday for its $65-a-share offer to acquire Anheuser-Busch, saying it was based on the Budweiser makers current assets and business.

title: As Open Goes Public, Many Players Do, Too
description: It is midafternoon on a Friday, and the fairways and greens of the Blue Hill Golf Course 30 miles north of New York City are alive with golfers. In their faces, you see excitement, even glee. It is an 80-degree June day, and cars are streaming up the driveway to Blue Hills century-old stone clubhouse.

title: The Rays Are Putting Their Dismal Past in the Past
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Rays have been surprisingly successful this season, feisty upstarts who have provided a series of eye-popping highlights. One dynamic moment came Friday night, when Cliff Floyd stole second base in an interleague game against the Florida Marlins.

title: 3 Dead and 5 Hurt in Queens Blaze That Forces Victims to Jump
description: Three people died and five others were injured, two critically, when a fire ripped through a three-story brick building in Queens on Sunday morning and forced people to jump from their windows, police and fire officials said.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Tonys Spread the Glory Around
description: Reflecting an eclectic Broadway season, the 62nd Annual Tony Awards crowned a salsa-flavored musical written by a theater novice, a nostalgic glamorous revival, a sweeping melodrama from a writer making his Broadway debut, and the revival of a 60s sex farce.

title: The Secret to Success in Publishing: Bash Bush, With Nods to a Classic
description: The manuscript  unsolicited and addressed simply to Editor in Chief, Little, Brown  arrived at its destination in a clear envelope, which was very clever, said Geoff Shandler, the Little, Brown editor in chief who received the package. Without opening it, I could see some of the cover image they had designed.

title: The Jerome Robbins Touch: Playful as a Somersault or Ethereal as Glass
description: As part of its ongoing Jerome Robbins Celebration, New York City Ballet unveiled another homage to the choreographer in Bach to Glass: A Musical Odyssey II. (Between the Bach and the Glass comes Alban Berg.) As theme programs go, its a good one, even if the second half, at least on Saturday afternoon, doesnt have a chance of competing with the first.

title: Rogue Computers Used in Ad Fraud
description: The bane of online advertisers is click fraud, in which people or computers click on ads solely to generate a payment.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Carnival Cruise Lines, Miami, named two agencies owned by Havas to handle its account, with spending estimated at $70 million to $80 million. Arnold Worldwide, Boston, will handle the creative duties as well as direct marketing, design and digital assignments. The Boston office of MPG will handle the media planning and buying duties. Cooper DDB, Coral Gables, Fla., part of the DDB Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, had handled the bulk of the account.

title: In Poll, Taxes and the Economy Are New Yorkers Top Worries
description: Gov. David A. Paterson, elevated unexpectedly to the job three months ago, has won the support of nearly half of New Yorkers, according to a New York Times poll. But many of those surveyed are increasingly worried about the economy and taxes and uncertain about the governors ability to address those problems.

title: Rice Says Houses Hurt Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Sunday that thousands of housing units that Israel is building on captured land were harming peace talks with the Palestinians. She also said she could not understand why Israel was still blocking three Fulbright grantees from leaving Gaza.

description: WASHINGTON  By Friday evening, the checkpoints were gone from the Trinidad neighborhood, leaving residents to ponder the citys actions after nearly a week of intense police attention.

title: How Angel of Sichuan Saved School in Quake
description: SANGZAO, China  The students lined up row by row on the outdoor basketball courts of Sangzao Middle School in the minutes after the earthquake. When the head count was complete, their fate was clear: all 2,323 were alive.

title: Remote Clicks That Do More Than Just Change Channels
description: AN ambitious effort to take interactive television into American homes is expanding after a test of the system began at a single station last month.

description: Let the conversation begin is how Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the 2008 presidential campaign. As that conversation now continues without her, it plainly will be different from what American voters have grown accustomed to.

title: Officiating Crew Is a Focus After Assignment of Bavetta
description: LOS ANGELES  The N.B.A.s officiating controversy crept back into the finals on Sunday, before the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers ever took the court. Dick Bavetta, who was a subject of inquiries by federal agents last summer, was the lead referee for Game 5 at Staples Center.

title: After 15 Years, Hints of Peace in Burundi
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  The hills around town do not ring with gunfire anymore. Terrified civilians have stopped trudging down muddy paths seeking shelter. Areas that had been cut off for years because of fighting are finally opening up. And a cautious optimism seems to be spreading across the land.

title: Queens Man Is Found Shot to Death in His Car
description: A Queens man was found shot in the head in the front seat of his car early Sunday morning in Jamaica by a woman who said she had been passed out in the back seat, the police said.

title: A Delegator, Obama Picks When to Take Reins
description: WASHINGTON  In the months leading up to Senator Barack Obamas big loss in the Pennsylvania primary, he was a detached manager: around, but not meddling. Rarely on early-morning conference calls with his senior advisers, he delegated most decisions to others and did not immerse himself in all of the nuts and bolts of running for president.

title: In Praise of Being Cut Off
description: About a quarter-century ago, I was in West Beirut at the Commodore Hotel, once described as a functioning telex machine surrounded by 500 broken toilets. You lined up to use the telex. There was a war on in a divided city. There was also plenty of Black Label.

title: Lakers Say It Isnt Over; Last Word to Be in Boston
description: LOS ANGELES  Nine bright gold banners are stretched in three neat rows high above the south end of Staples Center, a reminder of past glory and present goals. On Sunday night, that loose quilt of championship dreams looked like one big security blanket to the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Obama Calls for More Responsibility From Black Fathers
description: CHICAGO  Addressing a packed congregation at one of the citys largest black churches, Senator Barack Obama on Sunday invoked his own absent father to deliver a sharp message to black men, saying we need fathers to recognize that responsibility doesnt just end at conception.

title: Kosovos New Constitution Takes Effect
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  This former Serbian provinces new Constitution came into force on Sunday, an important milestone on its path toward full-fledged statehood. But a dispute over who has authority threatens to destabilize the newborn country and to plunge the Balkans into crisis.

description: THE HOLD STEADY

title: Awaiting a Big Blue Box and an Altered World
description: When she moved to her apartment five years ago, Perian Carsons small corner of Red Hook in Brooklyn looked much different. An abandoned Civil War-era warehouse sat a few blocks away on Van Brunt Street. Nearby, along the cobblestones on Beard Street, she could see the remnants of the old Todd Shipyards, where ships were repaired in a massive graving dock.

title: Slocum Hits His Shots for a Final-Round 65
description: Heath Slocum shot a six-under-par 65 on Sunday at Torrey Pines Golf Course, the best round in a United States Open since Vijay Singh shot 63 in the second round in 2003. Slocum, 34, who had never made an Open cut before, called it one of the best rounds he had ever played.

title: JPMorgans Stately Old Logo Returns for Institutional Business
description: On the first weekend in June, JPMorgan Chase began phasing out the Bear Stearns name  beginning with the Midtown Manhattan headquarters of the firm it acquired May 31.

title: A Theater Moves, Again
description: The site of a new home planned for the Theater for a New Audience in the BAM Cultural District in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has shifted yet again, officials involved in the project said over the weekend. In 2004 the city announced that the theater, an itinerant Off Broadway institution known for innovative productions of Shakespearean and classical drama, would get a permanent home opposite the Brooklyn Academy of Music at the intersection of Flatbush and Lafayette Avenues. Then in 2006 the city relocated the theater across the street, to the corner of Ashland Place and Lafayette Avenue, as the site was reconceived as a kind of public gateway to the cultural district. Now the city has moved the theater to the north to make way for a private developers tower that will be largely residential. While the theater will remain on the same lot between Lafayette Avenue and Fulton Street, it will face Ashland, not the corner. Jeffrey Horowitz, the theaters founder, said that he was not deflated. You have to swing with the punches, he said. Its not as wonderful as being on the corner, but its great to have your theater and be in a cultural district, and were going to make it work. Three years ago the city unveiled a design for a glass and stainless steel building designed by Hugh Hardy and Frank Gehry to house the theater. Mr. Horowitz said that $44 million of the theaters $48.5 million cost had been raised, and that the essential elements of the design had not changed. The building will have a 299-seat theater, a rehearsal room and a studio that will seat 50.

title: EMIs New Boss Sees Cracks in Music World
description: One evening last autumn a group of about 10 artist managers, including representatives for the pop stars Kylie Minogue and Robbie Williams as well as an executive who oversees the Beatles catalog, clustered around a table in an executive dining room at the London headquarters of EMI. The purpose was to size up the new boss, Guy Hands, and discuss the future of the record business.

title: A Treasure Travels, Inconspicuously
description: They didnt exactly hire two guys with a truck to secretly move one of the worlds largest and most valuable coin collections over the weekend in Manhattan. But they did use five standard-issue moving vans.

title: With Shares Battered, A.I.G. Ousts Leader
description: For the second time in three years, the board at American International Group, the giant insurance company, replaced its chief executive Sunday in the wake of its falling stock price and regulatory concerns about its accounting.

title: With Tim Russerts Death, NBC News Must Replace a Man of Many Roles
description: The sudden death of Tim Russert has left the management of NBC News, for the moment at least, at a loss to contemplate how to replace him.

title: Jackson May Head to Las Vegas Strip
description: Michael Jackson, below, may be next to follow the well-worn trail of pop star footsteps that leads to the Las Vegas strip, where Celine Dion, Elton John and others have taken up residence at various times. Mr. Jackson, who has had a seemingly endless series of financial troubles over the past few years, including a recent threat of foreclosure at his Neverland Ranch in California, is considering a long term Las Vegas engagement as part of a plan to repay a $23 million debt to Colony Capital, the private equity group that recently bought the loan on Neverland, Reuters reported. Colony owns the Las Vegas Hilton, and is a major shareholder in the Station Casinos chain. There is no deal yet and the possible Las Vegas engagement is one of several repayment options Mr. Jackson and Colony are considering. Mr. Jackson, who was acquitted of child molestation charges in 2005, has been reclusive ever since (O.K., before too), living in Ireland, Dubai and Bahrain at various times. He is now reportedly living in Pahrump, Nev., about 60 miles from Las Vegas.

title: An Emotional Urge to Get Up and Gro
description: An energetic new campaign that urges consumers to go outdoors and get their hands dirty looks and sounds as if it could be promoting brands like Gore-Tex, Jeep, North Face, Range Rover or Patagonia.

title: Stance on Same-Sex Marriage Brings Surprises for Paterson
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Patersons decision to direct state agencies to recognize marriages of same-sex couples elevated his status in the eyes of many gays and lesbians to something of a celebrity.

title: The Associated Press to Set Guidelines for Using Its Articles in Blogs
description: The Associated Press, one of the nations largest news organizations, said that it will, for the first time, attempt to define clear standards as to how much of its articles and broadcasts bloggers and Web sites can excerpt without infringing on The A.P.s copyright.

From their suites, they watched as their $138 million investment had another bullpen implosion, started a stirring-if-unsuccessful comeback and, eventually, split a doubleheader.

description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  At around 3 a.m. Sunday at the 2008 Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, Phil Lesh and Friends were harmonizing on Sugaree, a song by Mr. Leshs band mate in the Grateful Dead, Jerry Garcia. The Icelandic art-rock band Sigur Ros had just finished a set that deployed a horn section, a tootling pennywhistle, a group of female drummers singing la-las and a confetti drop along with its usual elegiac anthems.

title: Pop Veterans Still Pumping Anti-Charisma
description: Donald Fagen and Walter Becker seem like the kind of late-1960s hypercerebral born-cynical East Coast hipsters who are often found valorizing authenticity in aesthetic expression. You know: collectors of pre-war blues 78s, memorizers of outdated jazz argot.

title: Late Deal Pulls OTB From Brink of Shutdown
description: Confusion and discord gave way to handshakes on Sunday as Gov. David A. Paterson and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg agreed on a deal authorizing the state to take over the citys Off-Track Betting Corporation while still granting the city a share of gambling revenues.

title: Dianne Bullis Snyder: A Wife, a Mother, a Doer
description: Nothing was handed to Dianne Bullis Snyder; she made things happen. She worked her way through college, waiting on tables, planning on a career teaching disabled children. When she ran out of money a few credits short of a degree, she became a flight attendant instead. She was raising her children, Leland and Blakeslee, while flying coast to coast two weeks a month  and while her husband, John Snyder, worked a job that rarely brought him home for dinner. Leaving for a trip, she would post life lessons on her childrens doors. Dont wait for tragedy, say it today, one of them read. I love you and Im glad youre alive. She made quilts, taught herself French, timed the cookies to come out of the oven as the children arrived home from school. She was the glue in a network of 50 first cousins. In 1999, to reduce Johns commute, the family moved to Westport, Mass., from Connecticut. Dianne began flying out of Boston and thinking about finally getting her degree and teaching. She died on American Airlines Flight 11 on Sept. 11, 2001, at age 42. Things were settling out, John Snyder said. It just seemed like we were turning that corner. She would have gone back to school.

title: The Heir Up There
description: THE appointment of Gen. Norton A. Schwartz as the chief of staff of the Air Force last week is a historic first, one that could serve as inspiration for people who share his underprivileged background. General Schwartz is, you see, a cargo pilot.

title: Correction
description: A June 7 Editorial Observer about European concerns over rising protectionism in the United States misidentified the European Unions trade commissioner. He is Peter Mandelson, not Mandelstam.

title: Another Chance for the Senate
description: Given a chance to do something important about global warming, the Senate fell flat on its face earlier this month when it could not even produce enough votes to have a good debate. It can begin to redeem itself, by approving a bill to extend vital tax credits for renewable fuel sources like wind and solar power.

title: In Midwest Floods, a Broad Threat to Crops
description: NEWHALL, Iowa  Here, in some of the best soil in the world, the stunted stalks of Dave Timmermans newly planted corn are wilting in what sometimes look more like rice paddies than the plains, the sunshine glinting off of pools of collected water. Although time is running out, he has yet to plant all of his soybean crop because the waterlogged soil cannot support his footsteps, much less heavy machinery.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A music review on Friday about the tenor saxophonist Kidd Jordan, who performed in the Vision Festival at the Clemente Soto Vlez Cultural Center on the Lower East Side, misstated his age. He is 73, not 78.

title: En Route to Scotland
description: New York theatergoers have become rather used to hits from the annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe coming to New York. Black Watch, which will return to St. Anns Warehouse for a second run in October, is a noteworthy recent example. But 59E59 Theaters annually offers a chance to look at some shows heading in the other direction. The lineup for this years East to Edinburgh festival, running July 8 to 27, will include the erotic dance-theater piece The Judgment of Paris, choreographed and directed by Austin McCormick, which was staged in Brooklyn last month. Judgment, presented by Company XIV, was inspired by the Greek myth of what was probably the first ever beauty contest. (The aftermath was not pretty. It led to the Trojan War.) Also on the schedule is Queen of Wyoming, a play with music written and performed by the singer-songwriter Maggie Simpson and based on her experience as a fourth-generation member of a political family in Wyoming. Details will be available later this week at easttoedinburgh.com.

title: Looking Ahead

title: Equal Parenting: Divide and Conquer
description: So much of the conversation here the past few days has been about couples who divide household chores. It brings to mind a memory about how things probably shouldn't work.  When my firstborn was an infant and I was in the middle of a sleep-deprived, hormone-fueled meltdown, my husband, Bruce, made some comment, probably benign, about how having a baby means having no time for yourself. I took this as a declaration of war. I stormed off to make a very detailed chart of how much time each of us spent with our son, as well as how much time we each spent working, doing family-related errands and being alone. Then I flung the chart at him. It actually made me feel a little better, but it didn't measurably fix anything.    The power of lists depends on how you use them. And the discomfort so many of us feel about the approach of many couples in this article, I think, is a fear of my first kind of list. The kind that is built on resentment and that creates obligation.  "They divide a the laundry into, 'You have to do the colored, and I have to do the white'?" Nicholas Bakalar wrote on this blog.   "These are two grown-ups talking? Sounds like a pair of 8-year-olds arguing over whose turn it is to walk the dog."  And a reader named Dee echoed that sentiment, writing, "Keeping score is a relationship killer, especially if you are in it for the long run."  But what I realized during the months I spent with these couples is that they didn't use their lists (mental or physical) this way. Instead of creating bickering, their lists ended it. They decided what stuff went in whose basket of responsibility, and they trusted their partners to do what was in his or her bucket. They also learned to keep their mouths shut if something wasn't done exactly "my way." Then they forgot about it. It was taken care of. They had a lot of conversation upfront, yes, but they eliminated even more conversation down the road.  And to those posters who asked, "Well, what if someone has a bad day or is sick or just plain tired?" Common sense says you pick up the slack for your partner, no? Again, I don't live this life, I am just reporting on it, but these were not militant households here. Yes, they adapt to circumstance.  This isn't for everyone. I'd feel ridiculous dividing laundry into darks and whites. But it seems to work for Marc and Amy, which means that in their house it's a good idea. And that's the entire point here. Not that everyone keep charts or lists or does things the way any one of these couples do. But rather that we should all take some more time to think about how the division of labor evolved in our own relationship and decide in a focused and deliberate way whether or it exists because it make sense for us, or because it just kind of worked out that way. To each his own. But make sure you know what your own really is.

The airlift became a turning point in the cold war, when the West pushed back against the Soviet Unions quest for dominance in central Europe. title: Principal Dancer to Leave American Ballet Theater
description: Gather your Giselles while you may: American Ballet Theater announced Monday that Nina Ananiashvili would retire from the company after its 2009 summer season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Ms. Ananiashvili, right, who has been a principal dancer with the company since 1993, has appeared in Swan Lake and Don Quixote during its current season and is scheduled to dance in Giselle on July 7. Ms. Ananiashvili, who was born in Tbilisi, Georgia, was appointed artistic director of the State Ballet of Georgia in 2004, and in recent years she has led it on international tours, including a visit to the Brooklyn Academy of Music this spring. Her husband, Gregory Vashadze, said in an e-mail message to a Ballet Theater publicist that it had become more difficult for Ms. Ananiashvili to travel overseas with their young daughter for the several months required for her to appear with the American company. The theaters statement said that she planned to continue performing with the State Ballet of Georgia and to make guest appearances with other companies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Connections column on May 27, about the concept of cultural property, misstated some aspects of the case of Kennewick Man, a 9,200-year-old skeleton found in Washington State in 1996 and claimed by local Indian tribes under the provisions of the 1990 Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act. The skeleton is among the oldest found in North America, not the oldest. While Indians, with the support of the government, did initially block complete scientific examination of the skeleton, in 2004, after several years of litigation, scientists prevailed and continued their work; thus the Indians did not ultimately prevent a complete examination. In 1998, the Army Corps of Engineers, with the help of helicopters and barges, buried the Kennewick site under tons of rocks and soil; the corps did not bulldoze the site.

title: Zimbabwe: Opposition Official Still Held Without Charge
description: Four days after Tendai Biti, the chief strategist and secretary general of Zimbabwes main opposition party, was arrested, authorities still had not formally charged him. They also did not bring him before a judge on Monday, despite a High Court order issued Saturday to do so, said an opposition spokesman, Nelson Chamisa. The police have said Mr. Biti will be charged with treason, based on statements in a document that the opposition says is forged.

Other winces may soon follow from directors and organizers of tournaments that were expecting Woods, the No. 1 golfer in the world, to be working his magic at their events.

title: New Leader for Art Society
description: Vin Cipolla will succeed Kent L. Barwick as president of the Municipal Art Society of New York, Philip K. Howard, the societys chairman, announced on Monday. Mr. Cipolla is currently the president and chief executive of the National Park Foundation and a former executive vice president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. Mr. Cipolla will assume his position with the society in early 2009, society officials said. He previously served for nine years as chairman of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, overseeing the development of the organizations new waterfront museum. The nonprofit Municipal Art Society strives to promote excellence in urban design and planning, contemporary architecture, historic preservation and public art in New York City. Mr. Barwick, who last year announced his intention to step down, will take a one-year sabbatical before returning to the society as president emeritus. He served as executive director from 1969 to 1975 and president from 1983 to 1995, and returned as president in 1999. He has also served as president of the New York State Historical Association, chairman of New York Citys Landmarks Preservation Commission and director of the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Sudan: Security Council Rebuke
description: The United Nations Security Council adopted a unanimous statement calling on the Sudanese government to cooperate with the International Criminal Court in bringing to trial people charged with war crimes in Darfur. The statement, the Councils first such rebuke of Sudan in three years, slightly diluted an initial version by dropping the names of two Sudanese officials who have been indicted.

title: A Knuckleballer Is Waiting to Rise
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I. He accepts that all he can do is aim at his catchers face mask, throw as slowly as he can and hope for the best.

title: Now, Tenement Museum Reflects Irish Immigration
description: A wake was probably held on April 21, 1869, in a cramped walk-up at 97 Orchard Street. A 5-month-old girl, Agnes Moore, had died that morning of malnutrition. Her Irish immigrant parents, Joseph and Bridget, may have invited the German immigrant neighbors in the building and some co-workers from the saloons and restaurants where Mr. Moore worked to visit and mourn, as well as the Catholic priest who had baptized Agnes.

title: Brown Says Europe Will Tighten Iran Sanctions
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced Monday that Britain and the European Union would freeze the overseas assets of Irans largest commercial bank, joining the United States in intensifying financial pressure against Iran over its refusal to address international concern over its nuclear activities.

title: Churches Off Limits to Angels Demons
description: In the continuing battle between Dan Brown and the Roman Catholic Church, this round goes to the church. Two years after Vatican officials urged a boycott of the film The Da Vinci Code, based on Mr. Browns blockbuster novel, the Rome diocese said Monday that two churches had been declared off limits to film crews for Angels & Demons, the Da Vinci Code prequel, The Associated Press reported. Msgr. Marco Fibbi, a spokesman for the diocese, said that the film does not conform to our views and treats religious issues in a way that contrasts with common religious sentiment. Permission to film inside Santa Maria del Popolo, above, and Santa Maria della Vittoria, both in central Rome, was denied in 2007, but the situation did not become crucial until now because production of the movie was delayed by the writers strike. Angels & Demons reunites the director of The Da Vinci Code, Ron Howard, and its star, Tom Hanks, with Mr. Hanks reprising his role as the Harvard symbologist Robert Langdon in a story that involves a papal conclave, the cult of the Illuminati and a high-tech threat to the Vatican. Mr. Brown, an executive producer of both films, published Angels & Demons three years before The Da Vinci Code. This is a prequel to The Da Vinci Code, and its clear that the theme is similar, Monsignor Fibbi said. The ban will not stop crews from filming the exteriors of the churches.

title: In the Art of a DNA Graph, the Colors of Uniqueness
description: What is black and white and red all over? Heres a hint: It is not the newspaper, at least not in this instance.

title: When Shops Keep Doors Agape, Think of Cold Air at $140 a Barrel
description: Not for the first time, Jo Gangemi felt anger well up as she passed a clothing store on Prince Street the other day. There this shop was, with its air-conditioning on high and its front doors wide open, the cold pouring wastefully, senselessly  outrageously  onto the sidewalk. Like so many other stores on blisteringly hot days.

title: Mets Put Him In. Is He Ready to Play?
description: The Mets have a board at the entrance to their clubhouse that lists the starting lineup for every game. The players names, written on strips of laminated paper, are slipped in and out before each game. But its a wonder that someone bothers to remove David Wrights name at all.

title: Walter Netsch, Architect, Dies at 88
description: Walter Netsch, an architect who employed stubbornly individualistic theories to create the ethereal chapel at the United States Air Force Academy as well as bold, modernist conglomerations that repulsed some and enthralled others, died on Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 88.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary on June 1 about Jordan M. Wright, a collector of political memorabilia, using information from his family, referred incorrectly to his marital status. He was estranged from his wife, Pamala Plummer Wright; they were not divorced.

title: Despite Cross-Links, Diversity of Spirit in a Sampler of Ballet Troupes
description: WASHINGTON  Theres every likelihood that the Kennedy Centers first Ballet Across America festival  seven performances, nine companies, nine ballets, three programs that closed Sunday  will cause new cross-fertilization in American ballet. Artistic directors were in conversation with one another; dancers watched other companies keenly; foyer conversation was animated.

title: Public Housing Residents Face Loss of Their Community Centers
description: The community center at Parkside Houses, a public housing complex in the Bronx, has one floor, four rooms and many uses.

title: Bloombergs Popularity Survives Darkening Mood of City, Poll Finds
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg remains as popular as ever, despite an overwhelming consensus that his administration should have done more to ensure the safety of construction sites and an overall sense that the city is headed down the wrong path, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: Deciphering Relationships (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hazards: Golf Carts Get Around, and Injuries Rise
description: As golf carts zip their way off the golf course and into places like national parks, college campuses and gated communities, the number of people hurt in them has more than doubled, researchers say.

title: Helpful Bacteria May Hide in Appendix
description: Everyone is born with one, but no one knows what its for. The human appendix is a small dead-end tube connected to the cecum, or ascending colon, one section of the large intestine. Everyone lives happily with it until it becomes painfully inflamed, when the only treatment is to remove it surgically.

title: How Close McCain Is to Bush Depends on the Issue
description: WASHINGTON  The Democrats like to say that electing Senator John McCain would usher in the third term of George W. Bush, and they do not mean it as a compliment. The Republicans counter that calling the senator McBush is political spin and that Mr. McCain is his own man.

title: Feints, Uppercuts and Button Mashing
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, is one of the most recognizable faces in American culture. A brilliant, gregarious and loquacious man with a violent criminal past, he is one of the best in the world at what he does for a living, which is attract attention.

title: McClatchy Plans to Cut 1,400 Newspaper Jobs
description: The McClatchy Company, one of the nations biggest newspaper chains, said Monday that it would cut its work force by 10 percent, or around 1,400 people, after having already eliminated about 2,000 jobs over 18 months.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Midwest Floods, a Threat to Crops
description: NEWHALL, Iowa  Here, in some of the best soil in the world, the stunted stalks of Dave Timmermans newly planted corn are wilting in what sometimes look more like rice paddies than the plains, the sunshine glinting off of pools of collected water. Although time is running out, he has yet to plant all of his soybean crop because the waterlogged soil cannot support his footsteps, much less heavy machinery.

title: International Court Says It May Discard First Case
description: PARIS  Judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague warned Monday that they might throw out their very first case because of doubts that a fair trial was possible. The long-awaited trial was to begin next week.

title: In a Restaurant Row, Drive-Through Charity
description: MUMBAI, India  The golden Honda pulled over to the curb alongside the restaurant on a quiet afternoon last week. A window rolled down. A 100-rupee note, worth about $2.30, popped out, courtesy of a woman in a head scarf who would identify herself only as Mrs. Abbas. Then, as quietly as it came, the car sped away.

title: Rice Visit Signals Support for Power Deal in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made a surprise visit to Lebanon on Monday, the first by a senior American official since an agreement last month that handed decisive new powers to Hezbollah, the militant Shiite group that the United States considers a terrorist organization.

title: South Korea: U.S. Talks On Again
description: Trade envoys from South Korea and the United States broke off talks in Washington, then agreed to resume them, on revising a pact on American beef imports that has pushed President Lee Myung-bak's government into a political crisis, officials said. Kim Jong-Hoon, South Korea's trade minister, was scheduled to fly home after two days of talks ended without an agreement. But South Korea's foreign ministry said he had decided to remain for more discussions.

title: Rent Board Gives Landlords and Tenants a Chance to Vent
description: Seven score and eight years ago, when he was stumping for the Republican presidential nomination, Abraham Lincoln wowed the crowd in the Great Hall at Cooper Union in the East Village. Historians consider it a decisive moment.

title: Taliban Fighters Infiltrate Area Near Southern Afghan City
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Hundreds of Taliban fighters have swarmed into a strategically important district just outside Kandahar, the biggest city in southern Afghanistan, apparently in a push for control just days after 400 Taliban members escaped in a spectacular breakout from the Kandahar prison, officials said Monday.

title: Gore Endorses Obama as a Solver of Problems
description: DETROIT  Former Vice President Al Gore made his debut appearance in the presidential campaign here Monday evening, offering a vigorous endorsement of Senator Barack Obama and urging Democrats to keep in mind the consequences of not taking the general election with grave seriousness.

title: Brazil Arrests Police Officer in Crackdown on Militia
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A police officer accused of leading a local militia that the police said had tortured four people, including two journalists, for more than six hours here last month turned himself in on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: Metro

title: You Still Fly Commercial? Thats So Down-Market
description: WE are developing in this country an upstairs-downstairs air transportation system. Downstairs is the commercial airline industry  constricting, retrenching, ever more expensive to fly and struggling for survival.

title: After 19 Extra Holes, Woods Captures U.S. Open
description: SAN DIEGO  He has won four Masters titles, the first one by 12 strokes. He has won three United States Opens, the first by 15 strokes. He has won three British Opens, the first by eight strokes. He has won four P.G.A. Championships, one of them by five strokes.

title: Tony Schwartz, Father of Daisy Ad for the Johnson Campaign, Dies at 84
description: Tony Schwartz, a self-taught, sought-after and highly reclusive media consultant who helped create what is generally considered to be the most famous political ad to appear on television, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: The Philharmonic, Just on a More Human Scale
description: Like their colleagues in the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, the musicians of the New York Philharmonic regularly set out in small groups to play chamber music. It makes sense: in the Mets case, it gets the players out of the pit and into view, and for the Philharmonic, it gives audiences a sense of the individual players who are normally seen as parts of a vast musical machine.

title: For NBC, U.S. Open Is One-Man Show
description: NBCs decision to show the United States Open broadcasts in prime time last weekend must have come with the underlying desire that Tiger Woods be in the running. His knee surgery in April surely gave NBC executives agita, but his ability to play, then beat Rocco Mediate in sudden death on Monday, was redeemed by terrific viewership on Sunday night, peaking with a huge 13.5 preliminary rating with Woodss tying birdie at 18.

title: Prosecutors Said to Consider Charges in Bear Funds Case
description: Federal prosecutors expect to charge the managers of two Bear Stearns hedge funds that collapsed a year ago with securities fraud, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

title: Another Imprisoned Woman Is Found, This Time in Italy
description: ROME  The discovery of a woman on Friday who the authorities say was kept in a locked room in her familys home for 18 years has Italians pondering the similarities with the widely publicized abuse cases that have shaken Austria in recent years.

title: Winehouse in Hospital
description: Amy Winehouse was taken to a hospital in London on Monday after she briefly fainted and was kept from falling by an assistant, her publicist Tracey Miller said. She quickly recovered and her father, Mitch, took her to hospital as a precaution, Ms. Miller said. Doctors are unsure of the cause of the incident, and Amy is currently undergoing tests. Ms. Winehouse, the 24-year-old British singer, only recently began performing again after leaving drug rehabilitation.

title: Another Bad Deal for Baghdad
description: WITH only perfunctory debate, the Bush administration is pressuring a divided Iraqi government to approve a security agreement that could haunt Washingtons relations with Baghdad for years to come. The strategic alliance that President Bush is proposing eerily resembles, in spirit and in letter, a failed 1930 treaty between Britain and Iraq that prompted a nationalist eruption in Baghdad, a pro-Nazi military coup and a pogrom that foreshadowed the elimination of Baghdads ancient Jewish community.

title: Weighing Nondrug Options for A.D.H.D.
description: About 2.5 million children in the United States take stimulant drugs for attention and hyperactivity problems. But concerns about side effects have prompted many parents to look elsewhere: as many as two-thirds of children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., have used some form of alternative treatment.

title: Stan Winston, 62, Special-Effects Artist, Dies
description: Stan Winston, the Oscar-winning special-effects artist who created the animatronic dinosaurs in Jurassic Park, the slimy 14-foot alien queen in Aliens and the liquid-metal assassin in Terminator 2, died Sunday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 62.

title: Tributes to Tim Russert: A Few Drops From the Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Penalty Set for Law Firm, but Not a Trial
description: The best-known shareholder law firm in the country agreed on Monday to pay $75 million to dodge a criminal trial, ending a seven-year investigation that tarnished the professions image.

title: The Web Time Forgot
description: MONS, Belgium  On a fog-drizzled Monday afternoon, this fading medieval city feels like a forgotten place. Apart from the obligatory Gothic cathedral, there is not much to see here except for a tiny storefront museum called the Mundaneum, tucked down a narrow street in the northeast corner of town. It feels like a fittingly secluded home for the legacy of one of technologys lost pioneers: Paul Otlet.

title: Young American Indians Find Their Voice in Poetry
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  The memories of long summers spent on Navajo land as a little boy have stayed with Nolan Eskeets, like the words his grandfather spoke from his deathbed.

title: Frog Keeps Its Claws Hidden Until Needed
description: David C. Blackburn, an evolutionary biologist at Harvard who studies frogs, knew there was something different about the specimen he encountered one day while doing fieldwork in Cameroon. Not surprisingly, it kicked its hind legs wildly when he picked it up. But then Dr. Blackburn noticed that his arm had been clawed. I got a real nasty scratch, he said.

title: The Frozen Gaze
description: Rocco Mediates head swiveled about as he walked up the fairway of the sudden-death hole of the U.S. Open on Monday. Somebody would catch his attention, and his eyes would dart over and hed wave or make a crack. Tiger Woodss gaze, on the other hand, remained fixed on the ground, a few feet ahead of his steps. He was, as always, locked in, focused and self-contained.

title: Leader of the Pack
description: Vineyard Haven, Mass.

title: French Truckers Protest Fuel Prices
description: PARIS  After weeks of protests across Europe, French truckers attempted to block roads across the country on Monday to demand government measures to offset the soaring price of diesel fuel.

title: Index Ranks Pharmaceutical Groups According to Third World Outreach
description: An unusual ranking of pharmaceutical companies is being unveiled this week. It evaluates them by how easy they make it for patients in poor countries to get drugs and vaccines.

title: South Korea Continues Beef Talks With U.S.
description: SEOUL  U.S. and South Korean trade envoys broke off and then agreed to resume talks on revising a beef import accord that has pushed President Lee Myung-baks government into political crisis, officials said Monday.

title: City Council Shuns Bottles in Favor of Water From Tap
description: The City Council has become the latest government agency to take a stand against bottled water.

title: A Plague on Their House Brought On by a Black Bird
description: All the characters in The Raven wear traditional Chinese costumes. All the characters in The Raven have Italian names.

title: Old-Line Taliban Commander Is Face of Rising Afghan Threat
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attack was little reported at the time. A suicide bombing on March 3 killed two NATO soldiers and two Afghan civilians and wounded 19 others in an American military base.

title: The Man in the Room
description: Washington

title: Basketball Trounces the Tony Awards
description: One year after earning its smallest television audience on record, the broadcast of the Tony Awards appeared to fare no better in the ratings on Sunday. According to Nielsens overnight estimates, CBSs presentation of the awards show from 8 to 11 p.m. attracted 6.2 million viewers, even with Nielsens preliminary estimates a year ago but just slightly more than last years final tally, issued a day later, of 5.7 million. CBS ended the night mired in third place. ABC easily finished first as its live coverage of Game 5 of the National Basketball Association championship series averaged well over 13.5 million viewers in preliminary estimates of the 9-to-11 time slots. NBC ranked second, leading early in the night with the conclusion of its all-day coverage of the final round of the U.S. Open golf championship, which averaged just under 14 million viewers from 7 to 9. A Saturday Night Live special honoring the work of Mike Myers drew 4.6 million viewers to NBC from 9 to 11. Fox, with a lineup of reruns, finished in fourth place in total viewers but third among adults 18 to 49, ahead of CBS.

title: After 75 Years, the Working Poor Still Struggle for a Fair Wage
description: At the height of the Great Depression, industry convinced President Franklin Roosevelt and Congress to enact a law allowing companies to collude to drive up prices. To balance out this giveaway to big business, the law gave workers something that they had long been fighting for: the first federal minimum wage.

title: A Bounty of Midsize Planets Is Reported
description: There is a lot of new territory out there in the cosmos, but nothing you would want to pitch camp on  yet.

title: Authorities Say Hedge Fund Manager Is on the Run
description: Federal authorities say they believe that Samuel Israel III, the hedge fund manager convicted of defrauding investors out of about $450 million, is alive and on the run.

title: On the Stump, for Consumers
description: WHILE the long primary campaign may have exhausted candidates and voters alike, Madison Avenue is busy rolling out politically themed ads, sometimes lifting incidents straight from the campaign trail.

title: At Lehman, a Reminder of Loss
description: The chief executive of Lehman Brothers, Richard S. Fuld Jr., stepped up to the microphone on Monday morning.

title: A Better System for Young Offenders
description: The New York City courts that process arrested adults have long been open seven days a week. But until just recently, the courts that process arrested children were closed on weekends, making it necessary for children taken into custody to be detained for 48 hours or even longer before seeing a judge.

title: Court to Hear Challenge From Muslims Held After 9/11
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether top government officials can be sued for damages by the Muslim men who were rounded up and imprisoned under harsh conditions in the immediate aftermath of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Barclays Considering Share Issue
description: PARIS  Shares of Barclays, the British bank, soared as much as 11 percent Monday after the lender said it was considering a plan to sell new shares.

title: A Town That Looked at Leaving the Floodplain but Stayed On
description: CHELSEA, Iowa  This is not the first time this tiny city in a valley of rolling hills 70 miles northeast of Des Moines has been mostly under water, as it is now, a soaking casualty of the swollen Iowa River, the Otter Creek and this endlessly wet spring.

title: In Defense Policy, France Turns to U.S. and Europe
description: PARIS  In its first new national defense policy in 14 years, France has decided that its security lies within Europe and NATO, establishing a significant shift from the countrys longstanding notions of moral and military self-sufficiency.

title: A Search for Answers in Russerts Death
description: Given the great strides that have been made in preventing and treating heart disease, what explains Tim Russerts sudden death last week at 58 from a heart attack?

title: $14 Billion in Deals Precede Trade Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Leading businesses in China and the United States, seeking to overcome mutual suspicion of foreign investment, announced $14 billion in new business deals on Monday, on the eve of high-level economic talks to ease tensions between the two countries.

title: Despite Irish Vote, the Euro Remains Strong
description: FRANKFURT  Irelands rejection of the Lisbon Treaty has plunged Europe into a familiar bout of hand-wringing about the future of its grand experiment in political and economic integration.

title: Food Revolution That Starts With Rice
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Many a professor dreams of revolution. But Norman T. Uphoff, working in a leafy corner of the Cornell University campus, is leading an inconspicuous one centered on solving the global food crisis. The secret, he says, is a new way of growing rice.

title: New A.I.G. Chief Plans to Reach Out to Investors
description: The new chief executive of American International Group, the giant insurance company, promised on Monday to review all of A.I.G.s businesses before meeting with investors, probably after Labor Day.

title: Aging: Cue the Lights and Help Dementia
description: Researchers who put brighter lights into nursing homes have found that residents with dementia appear to suffer fewer symptoms.

title: Ex-Convict Sings Odes to Street Life Strewn With Hope
description: A few minutes into his set at the Apollo Theater on Friday night, Lyfe Jennings stopped his band and said, Lets take em back to 19  dramatic pause  Hold up, I was in prison. It was 2004 he was going for, the year when he released his often excellent platinum-selling debut album, Lyfe 268-192 (Columbia), two years after a long stretch behind bars. Stick Up Kid was one of its great songs, a dark chronicle of misspent youth, but the version he proceeded to deliver was vibrant and energetic; in places, the crowd drowned him out completely in singalong, as if it were a particularly inspirational gospel number.

title: F.C.C. Chief Backs Satellite Radio Merger
description: WASHINGTON  The long-running government review of the proposed merger of the nations two satellite radio companies took an important step forward on Monday when the head of the Federal Communications Commission announced he would circulate a plan this week to approve the deal.

title: Bowing Out: Opponents to Moving the Barnes
description: Officials in Montgomery County, Pa.  home to the Barnes Foundation and its world-class painting collection  decided on Monday not to appeal a judges decision to deny new hearings to reconsider a 2004 ruling to move the collection from its home to downtown Philadelphia. Lawyers for the government of Montgomery County, where the Barnes has been since its founding in the late 1920s, appeared before the judge, Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans Court, in March to request that he reopen the case. Judge Otts 2004 ruling permitted the foundation, which has struggled financially, to bypass the charter and bylaws of its founder, Albert C. Barnes, who stipulated that no picture in his collection could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built for it in Merion. The judge said at the time that he considered the move to a downtown location the only viable alternative to save the Barnes from bankruptcy. But opponents contend that the collections financial troubles have been overstated and that new ways to raise money to prevent a move have emerged.  James R. Matthews, chairman of the Montgomery County Commissioners, said in a statement that he believed the county had exhausted any real chance of overturning Judge Otts decision.

title: After One Wall Fell, Before New Ones Rose
description: The title of Derek Chollet and James Goldgeiers new book, America Between the Wars: From 11/9 to 9/11, is a clever one, using the fall of the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9, 1989, and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, as bookends for a period during which, the authors argue, the ideas and dynamics that characterize the current era took shape. It was during this decade, they say, that the consequences of the end of the cold war first unfurled, including the economic, political, and security challenges created by globalization; the rise of nonstate actors; the threat of weapons of mass destruction; the dangers that emanate from weak or failing states; the possibilities and limits of international institutions; and questions about whether and how to use Americas preponderant power to meet global responsibilities. In addition, they contend, the debates that raged both between and within the Republican and Democratic Parties during the 1990s shaped their respective responses to 9/11  and still influence their foreign policy choices today.

title: China Still Lags Behind U.S. in Influence, Survey Shows
description: SHANGHAI  Despite Chinas remarkable economic rise, and its efforts to spread its influence in Asia through what is known as soft power, the country still lags far behind the United States in that sphere, according to a survey to be released Tuesday.

title: Wang to Miss at Least 10 Weeks for Yankees
description: Two summers ago, when the Yankees lost two starting outfielders to serious injuries, Brian Cashman knew he needed replacements. Other teams also knew it, and gave him trade proposals designed for the desperate shopper. The Kansas City Royals, for example, offered the aging outfielder Reggie Sanders for the top pitching prospect Phil Hughes.

title: After Months of Wavering, Resolution
description: Anaheim, Calif.

title: In Search of the Education President
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Juries Become Latest Abortion Battlefield
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Opponents of Dr. George Tiller and his clinic here, one of the nations few providers of late-term abortions, have tried many ways to stop him over three decades. They have held protests, lobbied lawmakers and complained persistently to state regulators and prosecutors. There have also been several acts of violence, including one in which Dr. Tiller was shot in both arms.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Sunday with an article in some editions about an interview that the ABC Sports commentator Jim McKay had in Cuba with Fidel Castro in 1991 misidentified the pitch that the men were shown discussing. It is a knuckleball, not a curveball.

title: Paterson Has More Surgery on His Left Eye
description: ALBANY  For the second time in less than a month, Gov. David A. Paterson had emergency eye surgery on Monday to relieve a painful build-up of fluid in his left eye caused by glaucoma, his office said in a statement.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,093 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

description: Anaheim, Calif.

title: Spanish Firms Bid for Utility Hits a Hurdle
description: ALBANY  An administrative law judge advised state regulators on Monday to block a Spanish energy conglomerates bid to buy Energy East, a Maine-based utility with operations in four states, including New York, citing anticompetitive concerns.

title: The Genocide Continues
description: Despite the dispatch of United Nations peacekeepers to Darfur and the issuing of international arrest warrants for leaders of the genocide, the killing goes on. So does the burning of villages, the bombing of schools and the systematic rape of women and girls. And it will continue until the Security Council shows the will to stop it.

title: Woman Pleads Not Guilty in Internet Suicide
description: LOS ANGELES  A Missouri woman accused of posing as a teenage boy on the Internet and harassing a 13-year-old girl who later committed suicide, pleaded not guilty in a federal court here Monday morning to charges of Internet fraud and conspiracy to inflict emotional distress.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews conducted statewide from June 6 through 11 and included 444 adults in New York City. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: Date Seed of Masada Is Oldest Ever to Sprout
description: Scientists in Israel have confirmed that an ancient date palm seed retrieved from the rubble of Masada and successfully germinated is about 2,000 years old. That makes it the oldest seed ever to sprout, beating the previous well-documented record holder, a lotus found in a dry lakebed in China, by about 700 years.

title: Chilling a Deal for Bud
description: They call him The Fourth.

title: Stay of Execution Is Rejected in Texas
description: HOUSTON  The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals on Monday denied a stay of execution for a death row inmate whose lawyers last week accused the judge at his 1990 trial of having an affair with the prosecutor.

title: The Best of YouTube: Los Angeles, 1984
description: The 1984 Los Angeles Olympics are remembered for an American gold rush, caused by a Soviet-bloc boycott and home-field advantage. Americans won 83 gold medals, the most by any nation at any Games.

title: Chinese Company Gains Olympic Webcast Rights
description: The Chinese Web portal Sohu.com Inc. announced Monday that it has signed an agreement with the Internet arm of CCTV, the Chinese state television network, granting it official rights to webcast the Beijing Olympic Games, including the opening and closing ceremonies as well as all athletic competitions.

title: McCain and Bush on the Issues
description: On a variety of issues Senator John McCain is similar to President Bush, but on other issues he has strikingly different views.

description: The following is the prepared text of Senator John McCains speech about energy and climate change in Houston, as provided by his presidential campaign.

description: A look at a four-bedroom semi-detached house in the Crouch End neighborhood of London.

title: $850,000 Homes
description: Properties on the market in Maine, Arizona and Wisconsin.

title: Private Equity Goes to the Bank
description: Washington Mutual and National City, two big banks, both turned to buyout funds for their recent equity infusions. Investment Dealers Digest suggests that private equity may find more opportunities in the financial sector, especially at small and midsize banks at the regional and community levels.
