description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Apples Next Product Rollout
Varolii Pulls Plug on I.P.O.
description: Varolii Corporation, a Seattle-based provider of interactive customer communications software, has withdrawn its initial public offering, citing difficult market conditions.

title: Loews Scores Coveted One-Letter Ticker
description: Loews Corporation, the conglomerate run by the billionaire Tisch family, on Monday said it will change its New York Stock Exchange trading symbol to L from LTR, joining a handful of large companies to carry a coveted single-letter ticker.

title: Funambol Bags $12.5 Million
description: Funambol has raised $12.5 million in venture funding to fuel its open-source mobile messaging software business, VentureBeat reported.

title: Landrys Agrees to Buyout by Founder
description: The founder and chief executive of the Landrys Restaurants chain, Tilman Fertitta, has reached an agreement with his board to take the company private for about $415 million, pending shareholder approval.

title: Apollo Finds Exit From Hughes in Spac Deal
description: Apollo Management is selling Hughes Telematics, which makes automotive information systems, to Polaris Acquisition Corporation, a special-purpose acquisition company formed by two financiers who have advised Apollo on prior investments.

title: Cirque du Soleil Says Its Not For Sale
description: Are Middle Eastern investors hoping to snag Cirque du Soleil, the high-flying, internationally known circus act? And would such a deal even make sense? These questions were in the air after a British newspaper reported the company had received a takeover approach worth nearly $2 billion from Dubais investment arm. Soon after, Cirque du Soleil denied it was on the block.

title: Socit Gnrale Inks Alliance With Rockefeller Financial
description: Socit Gnrale, the French bank, and wealth management company Rockefeller Financial Services announced a global alliance on Tuesday in the private banking sector.

title: A $1 Billion I.P.O. for Glorious Properties?
description: Glorious Property Holdings, a real estate developer in nine Chinese cities, may raise as much as $1.1 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported, citing an e-mail sent to fund managers Tuesday.

title: Chinas Everbright Bank Files for I.P.O.
description: Everbright Bank of China said Monday it had applied to Chinas securities regulator for a long-planned initial public offering. The move comes as investment sentiment in the countrys main exchange is facing poor conditions after recent heavy losses, Reuters wrote.

title: Carlyle and TPG May Bid for Cavalli in Second Round, Report Says
description: The Carlyle Group, TPG and Candover are likely to bid in the second round of the auction of Italian fashion house Roberto Cavalli set for mid-July, Reuters reported.

title: Metropark Decides to Go Public
description: Metropark, a fashion-conscious retailer focused on the 20 to 35 year-old demographic, believes that its market segment is underserved and, as such, has filed to raise $100 million in an initial public offering.

title: Quadrangle Picks Up Greenfield Online for $426 Millon
description: The Quadrangle Group has signed a deal to buy Internet surveying firm Greenfield Online for $426 million in cash.

title: Cameron Health Gets $51.5 Million Injection
description: Cameron Health, a San Clemente, Calif.-based maker of implantable devices for treatment of cardiac disorders, has raised around $51.5 million in Series E funding, peHub reported, citing a regulatory filing.

title: Judge Urges Regulators to Vote Against Utility Deal
description: A New York administrative law judge recommended on Monday that state regulators disapprove Iberdrolas $4.5 billion takeover of U.S. utility Energy East, saying the deal is not in the publics best interest.

title: Gardening Start-Up Aims to Make Thumbs Greener
description: Plant Sense, a technology start-up that helps gardening enthusiasts take soil readings and decide what to plant there, has raised $3.5 million in a Series A round, The Deal.com reported.

title: A Stiff Fine, but No Trial, for Milberg
description: The best-known shareholder law firm in the country agreed on Monday to pay $75 million to dodge a criminal trial, ending a seven-year investigation that tarnished the professions image.

title: After 38 Years, Soul Train Gets New Owner
description: People who think of Soul Train as an artifact from 1970s television may be surprised to learn that the 38-year-old song-and-dance show was never canceled. Although no new episodes are produced, it lives on in reruns that showcase the taste-making music, hairstyles and fashions of decades past.

title: New A.I.G. Chief Plans to Reach Out to Investors
description: The new chief executive of American International Group, the giant insurance company, promised on Monday to review all of A.I.G.s businesses before meeting with investors, probably after Labor Day.

title: Yahoo Shareholder Proposes Compromise on Icahn Slate
description: Dissident Yahoo investor Eric Jackson urged fellow shareholders on Monday to vote for a board comprising five existing directors and four nominees from billionaire investor Carl C. Icahns slate.

title: CSX Urges Shareholders Reject Dissident Slate

title: Equal Parenting: Whats in a Last Name?
description: One surprise while writing this article was how most of the women had taken their husband's last name. While that is clearly the norm in the country as a whole, I would have guessed that this subgroup, which had made equal sharing their priority, would be more likely to keep the name they were born with or create something hyphenated with their spouse.  Of the three dozen or so couples I interviewed for the article, however, only about 10 of the women kept their names and only one, a lesbian couple, hyphenated theirs. Names are intimate and personal reflections of how we present ourselves to the world, and the decisions of these couples make clear, in the words of Amy Vachon, how "there is no perfect choice."   Changing your name feels unequal, she says. Not changing it means not being seen by the world as an automatic unit. Hyphenating works, at least for a generation, but can be long and cumbersome. Using one name for work and another at home means never remembering who you are. Giving baby boys Dad's last name and baby girls Mom's last name? He taking her name? Creating something new from scratch? All possible and all with their own complications.    Amy changed her name because the one she had when she met Marc wasn't actually hers. She had been married before, at 20, and hadn't thought about any other option then. By the time she divorced, she felt more like her married name than her birth name (I just can't use the term "maiden name" with a straight face, folks), and when she married Marc, she couldn't see entering that marriage with her ex-husband's name. So she became Vachon and thought of it as practical rather than unequal. (She also happens to like the name. For those who have asked, it's pronounced Vah-shon.)  As for me, my byline was Belkin long before I met my husband. My boys both have Belkin as their middle name, so that at any important legal occasion in their lives they will remember where they came from. And I added my married name as a third name to my passport and driver's license and such because I never wanted to be standing outside an emergency-room door trying to prove my kinship to my husband or child inside. (Yes, I tend to worry about these things, and yes, they were more of an issue 20 years ago than they are now, because a potpourri of choices has become more common.)  A reader asked a question along these lines this week that I would love to throw out here for conversation. The couples she knows who are hyphenated, she says, seem, at least from her vantage point, to share parenting more equally. Her theory is that the conversation and compromise that lead a couple to hyphenate probably also make them more purposeful about sharing other things. As far as I know there are no studies of this question (if there are, please let me know), but your thoughts from the real world would be welcome.

title: Darwinmania!
description: The party is about to begin.  (Photo: Charles Darwin. (Richard Milner/European Pressphoto Agency)) In a week or so, the trumpets will sound, heralding the start of 18 months of non-stop festivities in honor of Charles Darwin. July 1, 2008, is the 150th anniversary of the first announcement of his discovery of natural selection, the main driving force of evolution. Since 2009 is the 200th anniversary of Darwin's birth (Feb. 12), as well as being the 150th anniversary of the publication of his masterpiece, "On the Origin of Species" (Nov. 24), the extravaganza is set to continue until the end of next year. Get ready for Darwin hats, t-shirts, action figures, naturally selected fireworks and evolving chocolates. Oh, and lots of books and speeches.  But hold on. Does he deserve all this? He wasn't, after all, the first person to suggest that evolution happens. For example, his grandfather, Erasmus Darwin, speculated about it towards the end of the 18th century; at the beginning of the 19th, the great French naturalist Jean-Baptiste Lamarck made a strong case for it. Lamarck, however, failed to be generally persuasive because he didn't have a plausible mechanism  he could see that evolution takes place, but he didn't know how. That had to wait until the discovery of natural selection.   Natural selection is what we normally think of as Darwin's big idea. Yet he wasn't the first to discover that, either. At least two others  a doctor called William Wells, and a writer called Patrick Matthew  discovered it years before Darwin did. Wells described it (admittedly briefly) in 1818, when Darwin was just 9; Matthew did so in 1831, the year that Darwin set off on board HMS Beagle for what became a five-year voyage around the world.   It was a few months after returning from this voyage that Darwin first began to consider seriously the possibility of evolution, or the "transmutation of species." At this time he knew nothing of Wells's and Matthew's accounts of natural selection; indeed, both accounts languished in obscurity until after the "Origin" was published. (After the "Origin" appeared, Matthew wrote to a magazine to draw attention to his statements on the subject; he then proceeded to put "Discoverer of the Principle of Natural Selection" on the title pages of his books. This annoyed Darwin.)  By 1858, Darwin had spent more than 20 years studying plants and animals and thinking about evolution. He had filled notebook after notebook with his thoughts on how evolution works; he had, in 1844, written a short manuscript on the subject that was to be published in the event of his untimely death; and he had discussed evolution with a few close friends. But he had published nothing. (He had, however, published books on several other subjects, including an exhaustive study of barnacles, both living and extinct.) Then, in June of that year, Darwin received a package from a young man named Alfred Russel Wallace; in the package, Wallace enclosed a brief manuscript in which he outlined the principle of evolution by natural selection.   What happened next is famous in the history of biology. On July 1, 1858, Wallace's manuscript, as well as a couple of short statements on natural selection by Darwin (a segment of the 1844 manuscript, and part of a letter he'd written in 1857), were read at a meeting of the Linnean Society in London. The meeting had been organized by some of Darwin's scientific friends to establish his priority in the discovery.  Of the material presented that night, the manuscript by Wallace is, in some respects, the more impressive: it is clearer and more accessible. Yet it is Darwin we celebrate; it is Darwin who, like a god in a temple, sits in white marble and presides over the main hall at the Natural History Museum in London. Why?  The reason is the "Origin." Without the publication of the "Origin" the following year, the meeting at the Linnean Society could well have passed unnoticed, the Darwin-Wallace statements going the same way as those by Matthew and Wells. Indeed, the meeting had so little impact at the time that, at the end of the year, the president of the Linnean Society said, "The year which has passed has not, indeed, been marked by any of those striking discoveries which at once revolutionize, so to speak, the department of science on which they bear."   This is one of my all-time favorite quotations (and I am fond of using it) because it shows how, at the time, little significance was attached to the Linnean Society meeting. We see that meeting as important now because of what happened next: it galvanized Darwin into writing and publishing the "Origin."  And the "Origin" changed everything. Before the "Origin," the diversity of life could only be catalogued and described; afterwards, it could be explained and understood. Before the "Origin," species were generally seen as fixed entities, the special creations of a deity; afterwards, they became connected together on a great family tree that stretches back, across billions of years, to the dawn of life. Perhaps most importantly, the "Origin" changed our view of ourselves. It made us as much a part of nature as hummingbirds and bumblebees (or humble-bees, as Darwin called them); we, too, acquired a family tree with a host of remarkable and distinguished ancestors.  The reason the "Origin" was so powerful, compelling and persuasive, the reason Darwin succeeded while his predecessors failed, is that in it he does not just describe how evolution by natural selection works. He presents an enormous body of evidence culled from every field of biology then known. He discusses subjects as diverse as pigeon breeding in Ancient Egypt, the rudimentary eyes of cave fish, the nest-building instincts of honeybees, the evolving size of gooseberries (they've been getting bigger), wingless beetles on the island of Madeira and algae in New Zealand. One moment, he's considering fossil animals like brachiopods (which had hinged shells like clams, but with a different axis of symmetry); the next, he's discussing the accessibility of nectar in clover flowers to different species of bee.   At the same time, he uses every form of evidence at his disposal: he observes, argues, compares, infers and describes the results of experiments he has read about, or in many cases, personally conducted. For example, one of Darwin's observations is that the inhabitants of islands resemble  but differ subtly from  those of the nearest continents. So: birds and bushes on islands off the coast of South America resemble South American birds and bushes; islands near Africa are populated by recognizably African forms.  He argues that the reason for this is that new islands become colonized by beings from the nearest continents, and that the new inhabitants then begin evolving independently. He then asks: can animals and plants from the continents get to new islands, especially those that are far out at sea? To investigate this, he conducts experiments to see how long seeds from different plants can remain immersed in saltwater and still begin to grow. In short, he tests his reasoning over and over again.  He is also, in some respects, surprisingly far-seeing. The "Origin" does not just expound natural selection. It contains a wealth of additional ideas and hypotheses, some of which Darwin went on to elaborate in other books. Among them: sexual selection. This is the idea  and it remained controversial until recently  that males in many species are burdened with showy ornaments like enormous tails because the females of their species have, by repeatedly picking the showiest males as their mates, caused them to evolve them that way.  This is not to say that the "Origin" is flawless, or that Darwin was right in every respect. It isn't, and he wasn't. Nor is the book a definitive account of how evolution works. It wasn't even definitive in his lifetime: he published six editions, revising, sometimes heavily, from one to the next. (In the third edition, which appeared in 1861, he introduced a historical sketch in which he discusses his precursors, including Matthew and Wells.) Yet his knowledge of the natural world is so immense, and the scrutiny to which he subjects his ideas is so thorough and scrupulous, that the "Origin" presents a grand new vision of the world. A vision that, as far as possible given the knowledge available at the time, he worked out in every detail. A vision that changed the world forever.  Let's party!  **********  NOTES:  The historical events described here can be found in any biography of Darwin; I drew on Janet Browne's -- Knopf, in two volumes, "Voyaging" (1995) and "The Power of Place" (2002). The anecdote of Matthew annoying Darwin can be found on page 109 of "The Power of Place"; the quotation from the president of the Linnean Society can be found on page 42 of the same volume.   Many thanks to Dan Haydon, Horace Judson, Gideon Lichfield, Dmitri Petrov, Elizabeth Pisani and, especially, Jonathan Swire, for insights, comments, arguments and suggestions.

title: The New Beijing Subway: Suddenly, A Pretty Good Ride
description: Some readers of my recent ode to the Beijing taxi wondered why, in the name of efficiency and environmental responsibility, I dont just take the subway. I do, often, but heres one reason I dont enjoy it: To get from my home to just about any place of importance, I must change trains twice. One of those switches is tolerably annoying, but the other involves going outdoors, hiking up and down two escalators and 198 stairs, passing through endless dank and dreary corridors, and adding seven minutes of walking to a journey that can consume an hour. Whoever designed this system did not have convenience in mind.

Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts pantheon of humor. The center announced on Tuesday that Mr. Carlin would receive this years Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, an award whose previous winners include Richard Pryor, Whoopi Goldberg, Lily Tomlin and Steve Martin. title: A Swiss Orchestra Rebounds From Loss
description: After losing support from the Swiss bank UBS last fall, the UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra has raised about $1.4 million to continue its operations. Half the money came from public funds and the rest from foundations and private individuals, the festivals founder and director, Martin Engstrom, said on Tuesday. UBS, which had invested nearly $10 million a year in the orchestra, has transferred its support to a rival Swiss festival in Lucerne. The orchestra still needs to raise about $720,000 to support its orchestra and chamber music activities, Mr. Engstrom said. The Verbier orchestra, a training ensemble based at the Verbier Festival in Switzerland, was founded by the bank and the festival in 2000. After this summer it will stop using UBS in its name. It consists of musicians under 30 who are coached by principal players from the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.

title: A Two-Man, One-Woman Crime Wave

Thats the problem with the underbelly: Let the characters you find there sound too smart or talk too poetically and theyre not believable. And Mr. Fitzgerald makes his job doubly difficult with the format he chooses. The tale is told as a montage of monologues, with the characters rarely interacting.

title: Ex-Officer Acquitted in Death of Immigrant in Westchester
description: A former Mount Kisco police officer was acquitted of all charges on Tuesday in the death of an illegal immigrant from Guatemala, ending a case that roiled the Westchester County suburbs a year ago.

title: Study Finds Little Benefit in New SAT
description: The revamped SAT, expanded three years ago to include a writing test, predicts college success no better than the old test, and not quite as well as a students high school grades, according to studies released Tuesday by the College Board, which owns the test.

title: Celtics Show That Bryant Is No Jordan
description: Boston

title: Dominance Struggles That Dont Include Men
description: Four Women and a Waitress, a lopsided program of two one-acts  Edward Allan Bakers blue-collar drama Rosemary With Ginger and August Strindbergs psychological sketch The Stronger  starts with a fizzle and ends with a bang.

title: Campaigns in a Skirmish Over Terrorism and Law
description: A sharp debate over terrorism, security and the rule of law broke out on Tuesday as the campaigns of Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama exchanged pointed salvos over who could best keep the nation safe.

title: Investors Seek Asian Options to Costly China
description: HANOI  Canon is no longer building or expanding factories in China, but the company is doubling its work force at a printer factory outside Hanoi to 8,000.

title: American President Pleads Guilty to Hopeless Idealism
description: LONDON

title: Mississippi Washes Over Illinois Levees
description: CANTON, Mo.  The Mississippi River washed over two levees in western Illinois early Wednesday, forcing people out of their homes, destroying countless acres of crops, and bringing the number of levees that have given way to the river this week to nearly 20.

title: Ballet Theaters Revised Beauty Spotlights a Very Busy Prince
description: Of the 19th-century classics that dominate todays ballet repertory, The Sleeping Beauty is the most multilayered, the most abundant in telling detail, the most blessed with a score of miraculous eloquence. Which is why its the hardest to bring off in the theater. No production has ever been flawless (starting with the 1890 original, which made all sorts of nips and tucks and at least one reordering of the score).

title: New Mets Manager Mixes Intellect With Fire
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Standing a few feet from his soon-to-be office at Shea Stadium, Jerry Manuel was talking excitedly Saturday evening about a package he received in the mail. A copy of One Mans America: The Pleasures and Provocations of Our Singular Nation, the latest book by the columnist and author George F. Will, had just arrived, and Manuel was eager to start reading.

title: A Garlic Festival Without a Single Clove
description: ID rather have an ounce of garlic than a pound of truffles, my father often said, setting the tone for garlic worship in our family.

title: More Medical Tests for Amy Winehouse
description: On the celebrity blotter: The British singer Amy Winehouse remained in a London hospital on Tuesday after collapsing at her North London home on Monday, the Associated Press reported. A spokesman for Ms. Winehouse said that initial tests were inconclusive and more would be performed. ... An unidentified photographer who pressed charges against Britney Spears for running over his foot was found to be at fault himself and prosecutors will not pursue the case, according to The Associated Press. Joseph D. Shidler, a Los Angeles County deputy district attorney, wrote on Friday that based on police records and videotape of the incident last year, the only way the victims foot could have been where the video indicates it to be was by the victim placing it in that location.

title: At Social Site, Only the Businesslike Need Apply
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For a Web site, it could hardly look less exciting. Its pages are heavy with text, much of it a flat blue, and there are few photos and absolutely no videos.

title: Central Park Loses Dozens of Its Trees in Big Storm
description: It would be a sad census in any case, but the tally of trees lost in Central Park to high winds during the storm on June 10 comes with particular ill grace in the middle of the Million Trees NYC campaign.

title: Burmese Endure in Spite of Junta, Aid Workers Say
description: YANGON, Myanmar  More than six weeks have passed since Cyclone Nargis swept through the Irrawaddy Delta in southern Myanmar, leaving a trail of flattened villages and broken lives and arousing international sympathy that turned to anguish as the military government obstructed foreign aid.

title: More Illegal Crossings Are Criminal Cases, Group Says
description: Criminal prosecutions of immigrants by federal authorities surged to a record high in March, as immigration cases accounted for the majority  57 percent  of all new federal criminal cases brought nationwide that month, according to a report published Tuesday by a nonpartisan research group.

title: Flooding in Southern China Claims Scores of Victims
description: SHANGHAI  Torrential rains that have caused some of the worst flooding in 50 years and killed scores of people continued to batter a huge swath of southern China on Tuesday near one of the biggest manufacturing zones in the country.

description: Dennis Weatherstone, who helped usher in a new era of banking during the early 1990s as chairman and chief executive at J. P. Morgan, died Friday near his home in Darien, Conn. He was 77.

title: Taliban Fighters Infiltrate Area Near Southern Afghan City
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Afghan families continued to flee the Argandab District in southern Afghanistan on Tuesday as Taliban fighters and NATO and Afghan forces prepared to battle over the strategic region.

description: To the Editor:

title: Northwest Plans More Fleet Cutbacks
description: Northwest Airlines said Tuesday that it planned to eliminate more planes from its fleet, including Boeing, Airbus and McDonnell Douglas jets, by the end of December, its second cut in capacity this year.

title: New Jerseys Office Developers See a Few Bright Spots
description: Last month, a developer began resurrecting the skeleton of Parsippany  a steel frame for an office building that was started in the late 1980s but never finished after a recession hit. And some real estate professionals instantly perceived this as a possible harbinger of resurgence for the office market in New Jersey.

title: Energy Costs Help Push Inflation Higher in Britain
description: LONDON  Inflation in Britain accelerated to the highest level in more than 10 years in May, further tying the hands of policy makers grappling with a slowing economy.

title: New Florida Rules Return More Than 115,000 Ex-Offenders to Voting Rolls
description: MIAMI  Gov. Charlie Crist announced on Tuesday that 115,232 Florida felons had regained their voting rights since new rules took effect last April, but 80 percent of the states disenfranchised ex-offenders remain off the rolls.

title: Bronze Eagles Owe Survival to Drug Dealer
description: When the price of scrap metal rises, the parks and cemeteries of the world are mined by thieves. Statues are decapitated and delimbed, hacksawed into pieces that can be carried off and sold for their weight, not their grace. One ages bronzed glories have often become the phone wires or car bushings of the next.

title: Blessings and Anguish for Pastors in California
description: Some clergy members in California spent Tuesday officiating at same-sex weddings made legal by a State Supreme Court ruling that took effect on Monday night. Others spent the day speaking out against same-sex marriage.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Saturday about efforts to cut down on information overload in the workplace, using data from the research firm Basex, gave an incorrect estimate in some editions for the annual cost of unnecessary interruptions at work. It is $650 billion  not million.

title: Big Banks Sued Over Sewer Bonds
description: A man in Jefferson County, Ala., has sued JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Keegan and 10 other banks, advisers and insurers, claiming their work on county bond transactions saddled residents with soaring sewer bills.

title: British Free a Cleric Linked to bin Laden and Wanted in Jordan
description: A London-based Muslim cleric who was known as Osama bin Ladens spiritual leader in Europe was released under severe restrictions on Tuesday, after a court decision that blocked his deportation to Jordan.

title: Chimps Sex Calls May Reflect Calculation
description: Intricate as the mating dance may be among people, for other primates like chimpanzees and baboons it is even more complicated. This is evident from the work of researchers who report that the distinctive calls made by female chimpanzees during sex are part of a sophisticated social calculation.

title: Workshop on Preparing for Calamities Focuses on the Flu
description: Be afraid, be very afraid. There is no telling what the next disaster will be. Another terrorist attack? A steam pipe explosion like the one that shut down several blocks of Lexington Avenue a year ago? Or perhaps a pandemic flu that would cripple New York Citys economy by making people afraid to go to work or ride on subways and buses?

title: After Attacks, Michelle Obama Looks for a New Introduction
description: Michelle Obamas eyes flicker tentatively even as she offers a trained smile. As her campaign plane arcs over the Flathead Range in Montana, she is asked to consider her complicated public image.

title: Mets End the Suspense for Randolph
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  It started out as a great story, the quintessential New York story, in fact. Back in 2004, Willie Randolph, the African-American manager from Brooklyn, teamed up with Omar Minaya, the Hispanic general manager from Queens, and together they vowed to bring a World Series championship to the team each rooted for as a child.

title: Pakistani Fury Over Airstrikes Imperils Training
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military is so angry over the American airstrikes here last week that it is threatening to postpone or cancel an American program to train a paramilitary force in counterinsurgency for combating Islamist militants, two Pakistani government officials said.

title: Crude? So What? These Characters Still Find Work in Ads
description: THE characters on the Fox television series Family Guy make tasteless jokes about sex, AIDS, religion and bodily functions, purposely offending just about every group of people you could name.

title: Workers of an Extreme World, One Beyond Classes
description: Right away there are gripes to be had with Black Gold, a new reality series about oil-rig workers in West Texas that arrives at a moment when their employers are enriching themselves at the spigot of the boom. The show, starting Wednesday on TruTV, refrains from mining the dramatic potential of bad weather, a neglect that would hardly bear remarking if Black Gold did not come from the workshop of Thom Beers, the genre-defining producer and creator of severity-virility-unendurable-hardship-wearing-six-parkas-and-still-layering-extreme-sleet TV.

title: Notes Show Confusion on Interrogation Methods
description: WASHINGTON  When military officers at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, struggled in the fall of 2002 to find ways to get terrorism suspects to talk, they turned to the one agency that had spent several months experimenting with the limits of physical and psychological pressure: the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Minnesota Woos Coen Brothers Film
description: New Yorkers may be blas or hostile when it comes to film crews in their streets, but other places are willing to pay for the privilege. When Ethan and Joel Coen, coming off their best-picture Oscar for No Country for Old Men, were deciding between locations in Wisconsin and Minnesota for their next film, A Serious Man, Minnesota lawmakers came up with $500,000 to induce them to shoot in Minneapolis and St. Paul, The Associated Press reported. The Coen brothers  Ethan, above left, and Joel, right  are Minnesota natives.

title: Drivers Turning to Lower-Grade Gas
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  As the price of fuel continues to climb, more drivers are trying to save 20 or so cents a gallon by using regular or midgrade gasoline, even when their owners manuals recommend premium.

title: Shadows Grow Across One of Africas Bright Lights
description: DAKAR, Senegal  From the air, this sprawling city looks like a metropolis on the move, a buzzing quadrilateral jutting into the Atlantic. Cars speed along a supple, newly reconstructed four-lane highway that hugs the rugged coastline. Cranes dot the seaside, building luxury hotels and conference centers, as investors from Dubai revamp the citys port, hoping to transform it into a high-tech regional hub.

title: In Hard Times, the Truck Stop Offers a Place to Pray
description: BREEZEWOOD, Pa.  More than six million souls pass through this quarter-mile strip of all-night waffle houses and gas stations each year. The Rev. Shannon Rust hopes to save at least a few of them.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of a Former Official Linked to Abramoff
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned the conviction of a former Bush administration official caught up in a lobbying scandal, finding that part of the prosecutions case was faulty and that the trial judge was wrong to exclude expert testimony for the defense.

title: Canadian Court Hears Appeal of BCE Buyout
description: The Supreme Court of Canada reserved judgment on the Bell Canada leveraged buyout case after hearing about three hours of arguments on Tuesday.

title: Report Sees Cost in Some Academic Gains
description: A new study argues that the nations focus on helping students who are furthest behind may have produced a Robin Hood effect, yielding steady academic gains for low-achieving students in recent years at the expense of top students.

title: Cablevision Buys Sundance
description: The future of the Sundance Channel is being defined this week after Cablevision closed a deal to acquire it. Rainbow Media Holdings, a subsidiary of Cablevision, said on Tuesday that it had completed the acquisition of Sundance from NBC Universal, CBS and Robert Redford for $496 million. On Wednesday, Rainbow executives are scheduled to meet Sundance employees in New York. Rainbow officials plan to announce a new structure for the channel that is meant to unify it with Rainbows other cable entities, including IFC, according to two people involved in the negotiations who spoke on condition of anonymity because the announcements had not been made. Sundance and IFC both showcase independent films, and some analysts have speculated that Cablevision may try to merge the two channels, although this weeks announcement is expected to keep the brands separate.

title: Cyd Charisse, 86, Silken Dancer of Movies, Dies
description: Cyd Charisse, the leggy beauty whose balletic grace made her a memorable partner for Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly in classic MGM musicals like Singin in the Rain, The Band Wagon and Brigadoon, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was believed to be 86.

title: Black Humor, Pageantry and Absurdity for Lunch
description: In the pressurized, volatile world of Wall Street, that finicky beast hope might die and be reborn untold times in a single trading session. Its the ideal setting, in other words, in which to hold a funeral for optimism, and on Monday the Doorknob Company obliged, during a brief lunchtime performance in Bowling Green Park. No word yet on whether it subsequently held a resurrection ceremony.

title: Randolph Says He Is Stunned by Mets Firing
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Willie Randolph, fired as manager of the Mets in the early hours of the morning Tuesday, said he was stunned by the decision to let him go nearly three months into another disappointing season.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the efforts of opponents of abortion to petition for grand jury investigations of abortion providers misstated, in some editions, the surname of an opponent of pornography who used a similar tactic. He is Phillip Cosby, not Crosby.

title: Despite Leaks Online and File Sharing, Lil Waynes New CD Is a Hit
description: In a year when album sales have fallen by another 11 percent after years of declines, the ailing record labels received good news Wednesday: Tha Carter III (Cash Money/Universal Mo- town), the new album by the rapper Lil Wayne, looks to be a rare blockbuster hit.

title: Senator Viewed Mortgage Treatment as a Courtesy
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut said Tuesday that he was aware that Countrywide Financial Corporation had assigned him to a V.I.P. program in 2003 when he refinanced mortgages on his homes in Connecticut and Washington but that he and his wife assumed that it was more of a courtesy thing.

title: Worlds Refugee Count in 2007 Exceeded 11 Million, U.N. Says
description: GENEVA  The number of refugees crossing borders to escape conflict and persecution increased last year, and threatens to continue to grow because of factors like climate change and scarce resources, the United Nations refugee agency warned Tuesday.

title: Austria: $21.5 Million Awarded in Fire
description: The Austrian authorities have awarded $21.5 million to the families of people caught in a deadly fire in November 2000 at the Kaprun ski resort. A cable car transporting skiers to the Kitzsteinhorn glacier caught fire in a tunnel, leading to the deaths of 155 people, among them Austrians, Germans, Japanese and Americans. Only 12 people survived. Relatives of victims will share the money, Austrias compensation commission said.

title: Reruns Fuel TV Ratings
description: Reruns ruled the ratings once again on Monday, as Fox and CBS finished first and second for the night over all. According to Nielsens estimates, repeats of CBSs Two and a Half Men and Foxs House led the night, with the half-hour CBS sitcom drawing 8.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. and the Fox medical drama averaging 8.6 million viewers over the 9 p.m. hour. Fox edged past CBS for first place by winning the 8 p.m. time slot with a rerun of Bones (7 million). CBS led the 10 p.m. hour with a repeat of CSI: Miami (8 million). ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for third place over all. ABC earned decent ratings for The Bachelorette at 9 (6.9 million), but trailed with a Bachelorette special at 8 (5.9 million) and especially with The Mole at 10 (3.9 million). NBC broadcast American Gladiators at 8 (5.1 million), followed by Nashville Star from 9 to 10:30 (6.1 million), with a short edition of Dateline afterward (4.7 million).

title: Sudan: Darfur Groups Urge U.N. Action
description: Representatives of about 15 groups focused on the crisis in Darfur met with the United Nations Security Council, urging it to add muscle to its many statements condemning Sudan. Mia Farrow, the public face of the group Dream for Darfur, said after the meeting that Sudan, backed by China, had blocked the deployment of enough peacekeeping troops by insisting that they all come from African nations.

title: Horsemen Make Move to Stay Ahead of Congress
description: The Thoroughbred Safety Committee recommended Tuesday that steroids and toe grabs be banned and that new rules be implemented on the use of whips.

title: Mourning After Queens Fire, and Searching for Cause in Makeup Artists Death
description: All day on Tuesday, the phones were ringing in Orlando Tobns office in Jackson Heights, Queens. The callers were actors and others in the movie industry saddened to hear of the death of Flor Marina Sandoval, a makeup artist killed on Sunday when a suspicious fire engulfed her home.

title: Detroits Shrinking Sales Take a Toll on Dealerships
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  In the glory days of Detroit carmakers in the 1960s, Leonard J. Immke Jr. used to sell 200 new Buicks a month from his vast downtown showroom here filled with gleaming Electras, Rivieras and Skylarks.

title: Whips and Scorns of Time, Stinging All They Touch
description: There is one breathtakingly poignant moment in the flat-footed Hamlet that opened Tuesday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Its the sad spectacle of seeing a human mind genuinely oerthrown, of someone losing his hold on reality so completely that you gasp in pity and terror and think, That could be me someday.

description: A study to be released on Wednesday finds that advertisements appearing in traditional media like television are still much more likely to have made a positive impression with consumers than ads running in digital media.

title: How Fast Is Too Fast?

title: Beauty and Soul

Ill let you be the judge. The issue will be on newsstands in Europe next Thursday, and after in the States. Steven Meisel did the fashion pictures, about 100 in all, and I think they are some of the best hes done. They are crazily, softly beautiful, plainly the work of someone who knows women and fashion, has looked at both a long time, and when I spoke to Meisel the other dayfor a piece in the Times tomorrowI admitted I didnt recognize Tyra Banks in one of the portraits. description: To the Editor:

title: For a Hockey Players Workouts Off the Ice, Go Straight to the Videocam
description: Within the first few minutes of MVP, a new drama  and I use that term as one might call Big Mommas House a film  a young woman barely out of her teens is straddling a guy upstairs during a party at her parents Disney World castle of a house, and making royal demands: You work for me now. Take your pants off.

title: What to Ask About Foot and Ankle Pain
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening, and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions that Dr. Robert B. Anderson, chief of foot and ankle surgery at Carolinas Medical Center in Charlotte, N.C., and president-elect of the American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society, suggests you might ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

title: Taking On McCain for a Comment on the War
description: The political action committees of the liberal political group MoveOn and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees together paid more than $500,000 to run this advertisement this week in Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, and on CNN and MSNBC.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on June 7 about Senator Barack Obamas stance on an undivided Jerusalem misstated his position. He said in an interview on CNN that a return to separate Israeli- and Arab-controlled sectors, the situation prevailing before 1967, would be very difficult to execute. He did not say that about maintaining an undivided Jerusalem.

title: Your Web Site, Free and Easy
description: Q. I need to make a quick Web site  is there any downside to using one of the free site-creation services instead of finding a Web host and getting someone to design the pages?

title: Woods to Have Knee Surgery, Ending His Season
description: A 2008 golf season that many believed would be Tiger Woodss best has instead become his briefest. Two days after his epic victory in the 108th United States Open, Woods announced that he would have surgery to repair damage to the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee and would miss the rest of the season.

title: Russerts Son Sounds a Theme of Unity at Funeral
description: WASHINGTON  In death, Tim Russert did on Wednesday what no living journalist has accomplished this campaign season: he got Barack Obama and John McCain to sit together and talk, quietly.

title: Bad Day in the Rose Garden
description: Its very easy, in our chaotic world, to lose track. Did you know, for instance, that ER is still on television? That The Phantom of the Opera is still on Broadway? That Hugh Hefner is still dating?

title: Idea of Offshore Drilling Seems to Be Spreading
description: MIAMI  Gov. Charlie Crist stepped on the third rail of Florida politics this week when he abandoned his opposition to drilling offshore for oil and natural gas. But surprise, surprise, he did not die.

title: Keeping the Water Pure Is Suddenly in Demand
description: LOS ANGELES

title: H.P. to Reorganize Its Printing Division
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hewlett-Packard on Wednesday said it would reorganize its printing division, the companys crown jewel, to try to accelerate the growth of its corporate and consumer printing services businesses.

title: No Longer the Capital, but a Global Destination
description: BONN, Germany  Someone forgot to turn out the lights in Bonn.

title: In Dutchess County, a Wine Merchants Renovated Home
description: PINE PLAINS, N.Y.

title: Fallout From Bad Loans Rocks Regional Banks
description: In Ohio, the Panic of 1907 drove the Fifth National Bank into the arms of the Third National Bank, creating the singularly named Fifth Third Bank of Cincinnati.

title: Britain: Chief Out at Woolworths
description: Woolworths Group, the British retailer, said its chief executive, Trevor Bish-Jones, would leave after six years in the position. The timing of the departure was the boards decision, the chairman, Richard North, said during a conference call. Woolworths also reported a decline in sales and announced the sale of four stores for 25.5 million ($49.8 million). Sales have fallen for four consecutive years at Woolworths stores open at least 12 months. Mr. Bish-Jones, left, will stay in his post for three months while a successor is sought, Woolworths said.

title: Her Feminine Mystique
description: Because the archetypal women in Daphne Guinnesss short film, The Phenomenology of Body, revolve on turntables, it is somehow easier to think of her as a D.J. than as a director. Because the chic images she assembled appear in some sense random, it seems appropriate to think of her as more a sampler than any kind of auteur. And because the story depicting women through the ages is, as its creator points out, not exactly linear and only accidentally feminist, it is easy to see in it hints of autobiography, the personal history of a slightly anachronistic sort of being, less actor than spectator, a woman upon whom the events of life impress themselves.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Calendar listing on Wednesday about a tasting of spirits, many of them organic, at Counter, 105 First Avenue (Sixth Street), misstated its date. The tasting will be on Saturday, not Friday, from noon to 4 p.m.

title: Taiwans Leader Outlines His Policy Toward China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan called on Wednesday for a rapid expansion of economic relations between Taiwan and mainland China over the next year or two that would go far beyond the weekend charter flights and increased tourism announced last Friday.

title: When the American Dream Gets Lost in a Giant Storm
description: Lois Weaver is a playful pixie of performance art. When, at the start of Miss America, she approaches the front of the audience from the back row, clambering over people and snapping pictures of them, she conveys a delightful sense of mischief. Offering mild recriminations (You never told me that you dont really love anyone, You never told me that you romanticize poverty), she is a Park Avenue Kaye Ballard in a tiara, bob wig, black dress and a matronly knee-length coat. Onstage she joins Peggy Shaw  a frequent partner of Ms. Weavers since 1981 in the Split Britches troupe  who suggests a Bill Irwin clown in her jaunty loose-fitting suit with pants too short.

title: Morgan Stanley Reports 58% Decrease in Profit
description: The investment bank Morgan Stanley, with its core securities trading business continuing to reel from the tight credit market, reported a 58 percent decrease in net profit on Wednesday.

title: Art Pranksters Punished
description: The cost of superimposing a nuclear mushroom cloud on a television weather report in the Czech Republic: 50,000 koruna, or about $3,210. That was the fine meted out on Wednesday to each of three artists who hacked into a broadcast of Czech Televisions CT2 channel for 39 seconds last June, Agence France-Presse reported. Seven members of the Ztohoven art collective were acquitted of charges of scaremongering in March, a decision that prosecutors have appealed. The artists have said they were trying to draw attention to the networks failure to carry out its public broadcasting mission.

title: The Catch Phrase Is  La Carte as Airlines Push Additional Fees
description: Airlines are adding fees and surcharges on top of rising fares. They would like travelers to embrace them as  la carte pricing.

title: Russia in Quarterfinals
description: Russia defeated Sweden, 2-0, on Wednesday in Innsbruck, Austria, to secure the final spot in the quarterfinals of the European Championship.

title: On a June Day in Philadelphia, a Bit of October Was in the Air
description: Philadelphia

title: Obamas Campaign Tightens Control of Image and Access
description: At a rally for Senator Barack Obama in Detroit on Monday, two Muslim women said they were prohibited from sitting behind the candidate because they were wearing head scarves and campaign volunteers did not want them to appear with him in news photographs or live television coverage.

title: Con Ed Urged to Improve Its Response to Gas Leaks
description: State investigators looking into a fatal gas explosion in November in Queens suggested on Wednesday ways that Consolidated Edison and the New York City Fire Department can better coordinate their response to gas leaks.

title: Standards of Free Speech, in the U.S. and Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ankle: The Last Frontier in Replaceable Body Parts
description: Dr. John G. Kennedy, assistant professor of orthopedic surgery at Weill Medical College of Cornell University, is clinical director of the running clinic in the gait laboratory at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. He is a specialist in sports medicine of the lower limb.

title: Similar End, but Different Reaction From Bryant
description: BOSTON  Kobe Bryants 12-month journey began with anger and frustration and ended with anger and frustration, although he seemed to enjoy the ride well enough.

title: U.S. Blames Shiite Leader for Deadly Baghdad Blast
description: BAGHDAD  The American military on Wednesday blamed a Shiite militia leader for detonating a car bomb that killed 63 people in a Shiite district a day earlier, saying he had intended to set off sectarian violence against Sunnis returning to the area as security improved.

title: Tons of PCBs May Come Calling at a Down-at-the-Heels Texas City
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex.  This downtrodden chemical town on the Gulf of Mexico has no shortage of nicknames: Cancer Alley, the Armpit of Texas, Ring of Fire.

title: Realizing a Dream Deferred
description: SOME architects  seething with frustration as the spires they once imagined springing from their pencils vanish in the daily grind of the pencil sharpener  wait their whole lives to work on one dream project.

title: Abu Sayyaf Releases News Crew in Philippines
description: MANILA  Abu Sayyaf militants have released members of a news team they abducted in the southern Philippines last week, among them one of the countrys best-known television journalists, officials said Wednesday.

title: Dearth of Ships Delays Drilling of Offshore Oil
description: As President Bush calls for repealing a ban on drilling off most of the coast of the United States, a shortage of ships used for deep-water offshore drilling promises to impede any rapid turnaround in oil exploration and supply.

title: High-Profile Lineup for Atlantic Theater
description: The Atlantic Theater Company has announced its 2008-9 season, and look whos back: John Gallagher Jr., Martin McDonagh and Ethan Coen. Mr. Gallagher (who won a Tony for featured actor in Spring Awakening, which moved uptown from the Atlantic) will be starring in Beau Willimons new play, Farragut North, which had been rumored to be associated with Second Stage and then Broadway, as well as with Mike Nichols and Jake Gyllenhaal. It is scheduled to open under Doug Hughess direction in October. Along with the Druid Theater in Galway, Ireland, the Atlantic will produce a revival of Mr. McDonaghs play The Cripple of Inishmaan, first seen in New York at the Public Theater in 1998. Garry Hynes, who directed Mr. McDonaghs Beauty Queen of Leenane in 1998 at the Atlantic (and later on Broadway, where it won a Tony), will be directing this revival. Finally, Mr. Coen, whose Almost an Evening opened at the theater in January, is back with a new work, Offices, which will be directed by the Atlantics artistic director, Neil Pepe. At the Atlantics Stage 2 theater, David Pittu, who was nominated for acting Tonys the last two years, will perform his own work, Whats That Smell: The Music of Jacob Sterling.

title: Selected Studies: Foot and Ankle Pain
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Shorn Under a Good Sign
description: IF you pay attention as you rush through the streets, you will find constant inspiration in the hilariously ambitious, unintentionally poetic signage on the awnings and doors of small, scrappy businesses. Many of our citys best signs come from nail or beauty salons. Diva Nails, Salon Mingle, Skillz, Confetti of Nail. Chinatown, near the Manhattan Bridge, has one of my favorites: Amy Artistic Hair, written in dingy pink. Simple, sweet, weird. I love it.

title: U.S. and China Agree to Ease Foreign Investment
description: WASHINGTON  China and the United States, concluding two days of high-level economic talks, announced Wednesday that they would step up their cooperation on energy and the environment and also try to negotiate a new treaty to ban discriminatory practices that block foreign investments in both countries.

title: Shopping for Dishware With Sarah Cihat
description: WHEN shes not busy at her kiln, Sarah Cihat, a ceramist based in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, can often be found in thrift stores, scavenging for piles of plates. Ms. Cihat is the designer of Rehabilitated Dishware  old ceramic dishes given new life with fresh patterns and glazing  as well as her own line of porcelain bowls, cups and vases made from scratch.

title: Testing and Learning
description: To get the well-educated, highly skilled workers that the country needs, states must strengthen public school curriculums, especially in math and science. States also need to adopt high-quality tests that show how students are performing from year to year.

title: Lifted by Win, Mets Hope Rut Leaves With Manager
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Less than 48 hours after their manager had left town, the Mets packed their belongings late Wednesday night hoping they had also left behind something else: the aimless, indifferent baseball team they'd been the first 2 months of the season.

title: Center of the Universe (in the Auction World)
description: New York was the center of the Copernican universe on Tuesday when a first edition of his De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium (On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres) sold at auction to a commercial buyer in Britain for more than $2.2 million, nearly double Christies high estimate of $1.2 million. The 1543 edition, in which Copernicus put forth his theory that the Earth rotates around the Sun, was among 300 books from the collection of Richard Green, a retired physician and amateur astronomer, which fetched just more than $11 million, a Christies spokeswoman said. An 1878 directory for the worlds first commercial telephone system, published in New Haven, sold for $170,500 to a private buyer in the United States.

title: Crisis and Renewal
description: Buenos Aires

title: NATO and Afghan Troops Clash With Taliban
description: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan  Using helicopter gunships, NATO and Afghan forces battled Taliban insurgents on Wednesday in this strategic district just a few miles north of the city of Kandahar.

title: For Your Distorted Pleasure
description: THE affair was bizarre, even by the often loopy standards of a fashion show: art world notables sauntering down a makeshift runway wearing bulbous protuberances and looking like nothing so much as strolling egg cartons with most of their produce intact.

title: Michelle Obama Shows Her Warmer Side on The View
description: First, she had to unclench her fist.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture credit on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about a subtle image makeover for Michelle Obama misspelled part of the name of the agency that provided the photograph. The picture of Mrs. Obama at the University of Chicago Medical Center was from Heidi Zeiger Photography, not Zeigler.

title: Judge Gives a Victory to Tree Sitters in Berkeley Oaks
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  A group of protesters who have occupied a stand of coastal oaks at the University of California, Berkeley, for 19 months claimed victory on Wednesday when a Superior Court judge ruled that a university project on the site must be temporarily delayed to address lingering concerns about the project.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about President Bushs weeklong visit to Europe misstated the response to the foreign policy issues on his agenda. While there had been some expectation of disagreements, administration officials said they did indeed make progress in several areas; it was not a visit that featured confrontations over a variety of issues.

title: Cant Place the Phone Number? Perhaps the Face Rings a Bell
description: G.E. is taking caller ID to a new level with a home phone that shows you not only who is calling, but also what the person looks like.

title: Three Lives Inspire the Portrayal of a Complex Artist
description: This was the first place I came, Mercedes Ruehl says, looking around the small white pentagonal chapel that Louise Nevelson designed for St. Peters Church in Midtown Manhattan. She is describing how she prepared to portray Nevelson onstage in Edward Albees Occupant.

title: Comfortable Seating From Japanese Forests
description: Piave, a surprisingly comfortable chair manufactured by a Japanese company called Hida Sangyo, was created by Enzo Mari, an Italian designer. Part of a line of knotty-looking wood pieces, it is made from sugi, or Cryptomeria japonica, an elegant cedarlike evergreen. (One landscape designer, Tanya Kelley of Newport, R.I., described the trees as the Chanel of evergreens: theyre terribly chic.) Sugi was planted en masse in Japan after World War II, and now the forests need thinning; Hida has built an eco-friendly business on making sweetly simple furniture from the stuff. Because the wood is soft like pine, it is compressed until sturdy and dense, then molded into gently rounded forms that hold the human shape in a salubrious manner. Piave is $870, and made to order through Ameico.com.

title: The Latest Contender in the Lightweight Category
description: The MSI U100 Wind is the latest ultra-light laptop made for office work, Web browsing and portability. The Wind, not to be confused with another light, atmospherically themed laptop, from Apple, stands for Wi-Fi Network Device. It is 10 inches long and about an inch thick.

title: At 91, He Isnt Ready for the Last Dance Just Yet
description: GARRISON, N.Y.

title: Hearst Chief Executive Resigns Over Policy Differences With Family Trust
description: The Hearst Corporation announced on Wednesday the unexpected resignation of its president and chief executive, Victor F. Ganzi, citing unspecified irreconcilable policy differences with the Hearst family trust that owns the company.

title: Lil Waynes New CD Breaks One Million in Sales
description: As expected, Lil Wayne easily topped the Billboard album chart this week, selling just over one million copies of his new CD, Tha Carter III (Cash Money/Universal), according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the first time an album sold more than a million copies in one week since 50 Cents Massacre three years ago. (Kanye West came close: His Graduation moved 957,000 in its first week last September.) Definition of Real (Slip-N-Slide), the new album by the Florida rapper Plies, had a respectable debut, reaching No. 2 with 215,000 in sales. Three more albums opened further down the Top 10: N.E.R.D.s Seeing Sounds (Star Trak/Interscope) was No. 7 with 80,000 in sales; Alanis Morissettes Flavours of Entanglement (Warner Brothers) was No. 8 with 70,000; and My Morning Jacket moved 49,000 copies of Evil Urges (ATO) to reach No. 9. Last weeks best seller, Disturbeds Indestructible (Reprise), dropped to No. 4 with 102,000.

title: In Massachusetts, Diamonds for Once Outscore No-Trump
description: The trial to select the United States senior team for the first World Mind Sports Games in Beijing in October started on Monday and will end Thursday, in Sturbridge, Mass.

title: Illness Will Keep Dutrow From Attending Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Rick Dutrow, Big Browns trainer and the man who put the use of steroids in horse racing front and center with his colts bid for a Triple Crown, is ill and will not testify as expected Thursday before a Congressional subcommittee examining drug use and fatalities in the sport.

title: Israel Open to Deal With Lebanon on Land
description: JERUSALEM  Israel offered on Wednesday to start direct peace talks with Lebanon, saying all issues would be negotiable, including a tiny piece of Israeli-held land on the countries border that Israel has long argued does not belong to Lebanon but that the Lebanese say is theirs.

title: Think of It as Adding an Extra Room Onto Your TiVo
description: One of the problems with digital video recorders like TiVo is that they eventually run out of room to record. And if you change out the internal hard drive to upgrade, you lose your library of programming.

title: Chemical Maker Files Suit to Block Its $10.6 Billion Merger
description: Hexion Specialty Chemicals, a chemical maker owned by the buyout firm Apollo Management, sued the Huntsman Corporation on Wednesday to end their $10.6 billion merger, dragging one of the few remaining giant deals of last year into court.

title: Tales of Summer Heat Along With Thoughts of Cooler Times
description: Cole Porters Too Darn Hot opposite Billy Barness barroom torch song, Something Cool: Sheera Ben-David, a theatrically savvy performer with a strong, steady voice, places these standards side by side in her seasonal cabaret show, Come Summer, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: Getting Hooked on Human Power
description: As the cost of gas sinks fishing plans for some power-boaters, paddlers reap the benefits -- they get more fishing hot spots unreachable by motorboat and foot. And dont think the good news extends just to canoers. Kayak fishing  during which one casts, reels and chills from the sea-level cockpit  is on the rise. Joe Cambria, the editor of Kayak Fisherman magazine, says that 1 of every 10 kayaks bought in 1998 was used for fishing; today, half of all purchased kayaks see some angling action. "Kayaks allow you to get to spots you cant reach by boat or even by foot, and its like fishing from a lounge chair," says Cambria. Compared to canoes, kayaks are faster, lighter and less prone to wind effects, and Cambria says that many new kayak designs add stability, reducing the chances of tipping. (Unless you catch the really big one.)

title: Testing Linux With a Live CD
description: Q. I am interested in putting Linux on an old computer, but not sure whether it is easy enough to use yet. I have heard you can test it without installing it. How?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about a museum in Belgium devoted to the Mundaneum, an early concept of a worldwide information and communication network, misstated the year the Nazis marched on Belgium. It was 1940, not 1939.

title: An Ordinary-Looking Bunch, Reflecting the Random Activities of Others
description: Periodically one of the nine dancers in Maguy Marins Umwelt steps from the forest of standing mirrors assembled onstage to peer at the audience. The lights grow bright overhead (though the numbingly loud score doesnt let up) so that these confrontations seem somehow out of time, like those moments when you remember something important: a lost lover, the immutability of death, yourself.

title: Grocery Shopping Made Easy
description: On The Jetsons, when George got hungry, he just pushed a couple of buttons on the Food-a-Rac-a-Cycle on the kitchen counter. In seconds, a freshly synthesized meal appeared on a plate, prepared to his exact specifications.

title: Think of Your Poor Feet
description: The average person walks the equivalent of three times around the Earth in a lifetime. That is enormous wear and tear on the 26 bones, 33 joints and more than 100 tendons, ligaments and muscles that make up the foot.

title: Recalling the 80s? Try Selective Memory
description: THE signs of gentrification in the East Village are unmistakable: luxury co-ops, chic bistros, even a branch of Chase Manhattan where the Second Avenue Deli once stood. But one stretch of bohemia has yet to fall to luxurys wrecking ball  namely, St. Marks Place, presided over since 1975 by its patron-saint store, Trash & Vaudeville.

title: Most Doctors Arent Using Electronic Health Records
description: A government-sponsored survey of the use of computerized patient records by doctors points to two seemingly contradictory conclusions, and a health care system at odds with itself.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the acquittal of a former Mount Kisco, N.Y., police officer in the death of an illegal immigrant misidentified the municipality that is six miles from Bedford, N.Y., where the immigrant, Rene Javier Perez, was found dying by the side of a road. It is Mount Kisco, not Mount Vernon.

title: Strengthening Extremists
description: GAZA

title: An Unlikely Antagonist in the Detainees Corner
description: When he speaks publicly, Lt. Cmdr. William C. Kuebler, a military lawyer for a Guantnamo detainee, is careful to say his remarks do not reflect the views of the Pentagon.

title: Paper Mill Playhouse Is Bought by Town
description: The township of Millburn, N.J., has agreed to buy the land and buildings of the Paper Mill Playhouse for $9 million and rent them to the theater, which is recovering from a near-fatal financial crisis. The Millburn Township Committee voted unanimously on Tuesday to approve the purchase, which will help the theater pay off a $3.5 million bank loan it took out last year; close this years deficit; provide working capital; and beef up a newly created endowment. The theaters debt should be cleared by the end of July, said Mark W. Jones, executive director of the Paper Mill. The theater will hold a 75-year lease, with the rent for the first two years set at $1, then growing until it eventually equals 1 percent of the theaters annual operating income. (Its current budget is $18.6 million.) In the 11th year of the lease, the theater has an option to buy back the land. As landlord, the township has no say over management of the theater, only the use of the property, Mr. Jones said.

title: F.D.A. Says Source of Tainted Tomatoes May Stay a Mystery
description: The Food and Drug Administration may never be able to pinpoint the origin of salmonella-tainted tomatoes that have sickened hundreds of people, an agency official said Wednesday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief report in the Vital Signs column on Tuesday about the body types of people imprisoned for violent crime referred incompletely to the academic affiliation for one researcher. While Jeffery T. Walker is indeed with the University of Arkansas, he is at the campus in Little Rock, not the flagship campus in Fayetteville.

title: India: Military Evacuates Flood Victims
description: The Indian Army and Air Force were called in to evacuate people threatened by floodwaters after days of monsoon rains in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country. More than 300,000 people have lost their homes, according to a Reuters report from Bhubaneswar, the capital of Orissa State, which is among the hardest hit. Reuters said the stranded residents were scattered among relief camps and improvised shelters. Electricity was cut off in parts of the affected area, and some roads and rail lines were flooded.

title: South African Leader Visits Mugabe Amid Election Turmoil
description: JOHANNESBURG  With Zimbabwes runoff election only nine days away, President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, the regions most powerful nation, met on Wednesday with Zimbabwes strongman, President Robert Mugabe, as a rising chorus of voices warned that a fair vote could be impossible.

title: Back a Bill, Then Throw It Under a Bus? It Happens
description: ALBANY  Once again, Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor of New York City, has been frustrated by the mysterious ways of the capital.

title: Why the Squint Is Endangered
description: WHEN Wimbledon begins later this month, chances are that the majority of competitors wont be wearing sunglasses. After all, London summers are often soggy. But what about at the United States Open, or the Australian Open, where the sun shines in full force? Even there, the pros will be squinting. Its recreational players who appear to be starting a trend.

title: The Big Pander to Big Oil
description: It was almost inevitable that a combination of $4-a-gallon gas, public anxiety and politicians eager to win votes or repair legacies would produce political pandering on an epic scale. So it has, the latest instance being President Bushs decision to ask Congress to end the federal ban on offshore oil and gas drilling along much of Americas continental shelf.

title: Talent Draws a Crowd
description: Americas Got Talent lifted NBC on Tuesday, as 12.8 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. for that talent shows third-season premiere, according to Nielsens estimates. The show drew 13 million for its 2007 premiere, but faced new competition this time. The final game of the National Basketball Associations championship series led the nights ratings with estimates indicating that it earned an audience somewhere between Game 4 on Thursday (13.8 million) and Game 5 on Sunday (17.4 million). At 9 p.m. Foxs Hells Kitchen drew a modest 8.2 million total viewers, but was runner-up to basketball for the nights highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. For the night, Fox tied NBC for second place in that demographic. CBS finished fourth over all with a three-hour special, AFIs 10 Top 10 (5.5 million).

title: Abu Sayyaf Militants Free Kidnapped News Crew in Philippines
description: MANILA  Abu Sayyaf militants have released members of a news team they abducted last week in the southern Philippines, among them one of the countrys best-known television journalists, officials said Wednesday.

title: China Cracks Down on Drug Companies
description: BEIJING  Chinese officials said Wednesday that licenses had been revoked for three drugmakers, including one that sent human growth hormone to the United States, and that they had punished 125 other companies, mostly pharmacies, for making, selling or distributing performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Bernazard Finds Himself in Middle of Mets Turmoil
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Mets had just started taking batting practice Wednesday evening, and Tony Bernazard, the teams vice president for development, was standing about 20 feet behind the cage. Alfredo Griffin, the Los Angeles Angels first-base coach and Bernazards teammate on the 1987 Oakland Athletics, ran over and pumped his hand. Off to the side, Carlos Beltrn, limbering up, offered a smile and slapped Bernazard on the shoulder.

title: One-Stop Redecorating, From Design to Finishing Touch
description: On Saturday, Ethan Allen, the famously American furniture maker and retailer (think of brown bedroom sets), is opening a 30,000-square-foot store next to Bloomingdales on Third Avenue. The furniture is not all brown, or especially American in its styling  at least, not the way youd imagine. Nor is the space just a store: like the companys flagship in Danbury, Conn., and, indeed, its 289 other locations around the country, the new Ethan Allen Design Center here aims to be one-stop shopping for anyone looking to redecorate a space.

title: Some Farmers Devastated by Flooding; Others Brace for What Might Come
description: CANTON, Mo.  Looking out from the highest hill in this town, it suddenly seemed that there were two rivers: the Mississippi, of course, and now a new river, a nameless renegade that had appeared out of nowhere on Wednesday when the Mississippis waters broke over a levee near the tiny hamlet of Meyer, Ill., and surged over tens of thousands of acres of farm fields.

title: Out of a Pocket, a Video Camera Filled With Tricks in High Definition
description: Sanyos Xacti HD1000 was one of the first compact cameras to shoot high-definition video. The latest in the line, the HD1010, includes a slow-motion mode and a slick face-tracking feature.

title: After Being Displaced by Flooding, Top U.S. Gymnast Springs Back for Trials
description: PHILADELPHIA  When the floodwaters rose in Iowa last week and the bloated Raccoon River filled Chows Gymnastics and Dance Institute with water that was knee deep, Shawn Johnson suddenly was a gymnast with no gym.

title: Anxiety Grows in West Over Firefighting Efforts
description: SAN DIEGO  As fire season arrives in the West, there are growing doubts about the regions ability to attack the kind of sweeping blazes that devastated parts of California last year.

title: Pedaling Smarter, Not Harder
description: "Most cyclists think that you have to train on hills to be competitive in road races, which typically feature multiple vertiginous, lung-busting climbs. Not Christian Vande Velde, who's expected to be selected next month for the United States road racing team for the Summer Olympics in Beijing," Gretchen Reynolds writes in The Times today. Vande Velde and his coaches have developed innovative training techniques, nutritional plans and strategies, and they share with readers a few clues for riding faster, longer and smarter.

title: Russia: Four Charged in Killing of Journalist
description: Prosecutors in Moscow formally charged four men in the killing of Anna Politkovskaya, the crusading opposition journalist who was gunned down in 2006, but the person suspected of shooting her remains at large. Three of the men were accused of involvement in the killing while the fourth, a former officer of the F.S.B., a successor to the K.G.B., was charged with abuse of office related to the inquiry, officials said. The authorities last month formally charged the suspected gunman, Rustam Makhmudov, a 34-year-old Chechen, and are searching for him. In August 2007, 10 people were arrested in the case, but some have been released.

title: New Challenges for European Unions Next Presidency After the Defeat in Ireland
description: PARIS  The European Union, it seems, just will not take no for an answer.

title: As Poles Balk, U.S. Eyes Lithuania as Site for Missile Shield

They worked at the local lumber mill, where a seemingly endless supply of timber from the mountains kept saws whirring. The show, co-sponsored by the Furniture Society, includes stools made of foam, a lounge that resembles desert dunes and a chair, left, that appears to have been made with green xylophone mallets, aptly named Suspended Chaos. It would have been hard to tell it was a chair without the catalog, so a reporter called the designer, Chris Holden, to see what had provoked him to create such an uncomfortable-looking piece.

Court Offers Homeowners

It's one of the enduring institutions in our country, and I think we take some comfort in that." All due respect to Bob, but the only thing that hasn't changed about baseball over the last 50 years is the wistful musings of baby boomers.

title: Argentina: Embattled President Addresses Supporters
description: Argentinas embattled president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, addressed thousands of supporters at a rally in Buenos Aires, two days after her economic policies prompted nationwide protests. Despite concerns that the rally would heighten tensions, the event was peaceful. The president, who has been struggling to quell a revolt by farmers over higher export taxes she imposed in March, did not expand on a plan announced Tuesday to let Congress debate the tax increases. But she defended her move to raise taxes and redistribute wealth to the poor, and called on farmers to end their strikes. I did not take this decision to hurt anybody, she said. This was not against anybody, but it was so that all Argentines could live better.

The dumping of red Gatorade on his bewildered coach. At 31 by 54 inches, and 18 inches high, the table is big enough for a small crowd and is water resistant, so it can be left out in the rain. Sea Levels Rose Faster Than Estimated
description: The oceans have been growing warmer and sea levels have been rising at a faster rate than previously estimated, researchers reported. A review of millions of measurements over the past four decades revealed a subtle error, they said; after correcting it, they found that sea levels rose two inches from 1961 to 2003  about 50 percent greater than previous estimates. Experts familiar with the work said the finding, published in the journal Nature, added credence to computer simulations predicting centuries of rising seas from human-caused global warming.

A breeze cast a quiet spell over the crowd gathered outdoors at the Hispanic Society of America on Audubon Terrace in Upper Manhattan. And as soon as Mr. Galvn appeared on the unadorned black stage, he fit right in. As a flamenco dancer, he is full of purity, almost shockingly so.

Laziness, paranoia and pedantry may also have something to do with the failure to hire black models for shows and magazine features in any meaningful number, but, hey, thats just a guess.

title: CORRECTIONS

A Public Service Commission policy discourages any one company from simultaneously owning generation, transmission and distribution facilities, but there is no state law preventing such an arrangement.

The Golden Calf, above, with the artist, will be part of a two-day auction of works made by Mr. Hirst in the last two years, Sothebys announced on Thursday. In addition to the bull, the auctions on Sept. 15 and 16 will include some of his new paintings, drawings and sculptures. This is the second time Sothebys has held an all-Hirst auction. In 2004 it sold the contents of the Pharmacy, his defunct Notting Hill restaurant, which included Hirst-designed ashtrays and bar stools, as well as his paintings, for $20 million. Last summer Mr. Hirsts human skull cast in platinum and covered with 8,601 diamonds was said to have been sold to an investment group for $100 million.
