title: Brooklyn Gains TKTS
description: A new TKTS discount tickets booth is opening on July 10 in Brooklyn. The booth, operated by the Theater Development Fund, will be in the MetroTech Center in downtown Brooklyn at the corner of Jay Street and Myrtle Avenue. For the most part, it will operate like the two other TKTS booths in Times Square and at the South Street Seaport, except that it will also sell tickets to Brooklyn arts events, like productions at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The renovated TKTS booth in Times Square is scheduled to open later this summer.

title: A.M.D. and Its War With Intel
description: A few weeks ago, Stephen Labaton of The New York Times broke the news that the Federal Trade Commission had decided to open a formal antitrust investigation into Intel, the worlds dominant maker of microprocessors. Subpoenas had gone out not just to Intel, but to many of the computer manufacturers who rely on Intel chips. The investigation, as Mr. Labaton wrote, was going to revolve around accusations that Intels pricing is intended to maintain a near monopoly on the microprocessor market.

title: Michael Shernoff, 57, Gay-Health Therapist, Is Dead

title: Fox Takes Thursday
description: On a low-rated Thursday of almost-summer television, Fox came away as the most-watched network, thanks to its game show Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader? (7.8 million viewers, winning the 8 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsens estimates) followed by a results edition of So You Think You Can Dance (8.8 million, winning the 9 p.m. slot). CBS finished second for the night, broadcasting comedy repeats during the 8 oclock hour, a CSI rerun at 9 and Swingtown at 10, which managed to win its time slot despite an audience of just 6.1 million viewers. Also at 10, NBCs Fear Itself drew only 4.7 million viewers, as did NBCs 90-minute episode of Last Comic Standing, from 8:30 to 10. NBC finished in third place over all. ABC was fourth with a rerun of Ugly Betty at 8 (3.1 million) followed by a two-hour Greys Anatomy repeat from 9 to 11 (3.2 million).

title: Oils Perspective on Whats Behind the Energy Crisis

title: Hewitt D. Crane, 81, Early Computer Engineer, Is Dead
description: Hewitt D. Crane, who was instrumental in the design and construction of the first commercial computer to automate checking accounts, died on Tuesday at his home in Portola Valley, Calif., not far from Ridge Vineyards, which he helped found. He was 81.

title: Corrections

title: Owner and Trainer Cry Foul Over Horses Positive Test

Larry Jones, who trained the late filly Eight Belles, and Jim Squires, the breeder of 2001 Kentucky Derby winner Monarchos, were notified on Tuesday that Stones River had tested positive for illegal levels of clenbuterol, a bronchodilator that helps burn fat and promote muscle growth, after a race on June 8 at Delaware Park.

title: The Court and Workers
description: The Supreme Court under Chief Justice John Roberts quickly carved out a reputation for being reflexively pro-business. On Thursday, however, it issued a good ruling in favor of workers suing for age discrimination, the latest of several pro-worker decisions. The ruling is an encouraging sign that the court may be evolving in its approach to cases brought by workers who have been treated unfairly.

title: Fake Gems, Genuine Appeal
description: MANUFACTURED diamonds have become as pure and nearly as big as the finest specimens hauled out of the ground, Ulrich Boser reports in Smithsonian magazine (smithsonianmag.com). title: The Zany Spirit of Shaw, Adapted Into Operas
description: George Bernard Shaw wrote his short, fanciful play The Dark Lady of the Sonnets for a performance in 1910 in support of establishing a national theater to honor Shakespeare. Here Shaw puts a royal twist into the mystery surrounding these love poems: To whom were they directed? In another short work, Passion, Poison and Petrifaction, or the Fatal Gazogene, Shaw gleefully skewers the murderous mayhem and convoluted plot turns of Shakespearean drama.

title: Dealing With More Than Just Olympic Trials
description: PHILADELPHIA  There were so many times, too many to count, that Darling Hill wanted to quit gymnastics. Times when she would stand beneath the uneven bars and cry with fear. Times when she would hide beneath her bedcovers, wishing that she could skip practice.

description: MY younger son is already lobbying for his present when he graduates from elementary school  in 2009.

title: R.E.M.: The Histories and Commentaries
description: Michael Stipe, lead singer of R.E.M., spent a great deal of time explicating on Thursday night, good-naturedly turning Madison Square Garden into a lecture hall. This, he said of Disturbance at the Heron House, from 1987, is my rewriting of the novel Animal Farm. Ignoreland, from 1992, was his barely adult reaction to the Iran-Contra scandal. And Man-Sized Wreath, from this years album Accelerate(Warner Brothers), was inspired, he said, by the day in 2004 when, met by several hundred protesters, President Bush visited  or, in Mr. Stipes description, desecrated  the grave of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

The Ford Motor Company said on Friday that it would delay introducing its new pickup, a vehicle critical to its plan to become profitable, and that it would probably lose money for a fourth consecutive year in 2009 because of a precipitous drop in demand for large vehicles.

Roosevelt Park from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. The roster of players also includes the English soccer players Steve McManaman and Robbie Fowler, and the N.B.A. players Jason Kidd, Baron Davis, Raja Bell, Leandro Barbosa and David Lee.

More broadly, I argue that when American politicians compete to be pro-Israeli, they too often line up behind the one that oppresses Palestinians on the West Bank and not enough behind the one of Israeli human rights groups, historians and journalists that fights relentlessly for fairness for those same Palestinians. I would love to see American politicians showing up not only at Aipac but also at BTselem.

description: THE Lower East Side of Manhattan is being SoHo-fied. (Or is it Chelsea-fied?) Concrete floors are being poured next to Chinatown fish stalls. title: Installations Worthy of the Name
description: Installation art is all about the manipulation of scale and sensibility. The size of the installation is crucial, either occupying most of a gallery to impress at first sight, or radically scaled down so as to invite inspection and enable viewers to focus on the artists command of detail. Sensibility is a lot more complicated. The theme or subject of the installation must be sufficiently familiar to allow quick recognition, but also witty or intriguing enough to excite curiosity. The choice of materials helps, preferably something unusual that does not commonly belong in a gallery.

title: Night Moves
description: Is it dangerous to lark in Central Park at night? Not really, Marie Winn says in Central Park in the Dark. The precinct enjoys the citys lowest crime rate, she writes. This may be true on a per acre basis (not per capita), but still, it wasnt until the author came to know the park extremely well that her fear of the night receded, though it never disappeared completely. Familiarity breeds content.

title: The Pixar Touch
description: Still another film was in Pixar's pipeline during the making of A Bug's Life. Talk of a sequel to Toy Story began around a month after Toy Story opened, when Catmull, Lasseter, and Guggenheim visited Joe Roth, Katzenberg's successor as chairman of Walt Disney Studios. Roth was pleased and embraced the idea.

title: Editors Choice

title: The Devil Wears Nada

Even if she werent about to bare her thighs, along with everything else, this wouldnt seem to be a great idea. But its all too indicative of how her night is going to go  and of Aprils judgment, or lack thereof. Shes also a single mother who has strapped her 3-year-old daughter into the car to take her to work. Within a couple of pages, April pulls a U-turn, with predictable results for her thighs.

Avocational or school choruses, which account for most choruses in the United States, are reluctant to tackle music they fear will be overly complex, he says. Music publishers fear contemporary works will be too atonal to sell.

title: A Green Coal Baron?
description: When I met with Jim Rogers one day this spring, he tossed back two double espressos in a single hour. A charming and natty 60-year-old, Rogers is the chief executive of the electric company Duke Energy. But he has none of the macho, cowboy stolidity you might expect in an energy C.E.O. Instead, he lives to brainstorm. He spends more than half his time on the road, a perennial fixture at wonky gatherings like the Davos World Economic Forum and the Clinton Global Initiative, corralling clean energy thinkers and listening eagerly to their ideas. The day we met, he was brimming with enthusiasm for a new approach to solar power. Solar is currently too expensive to make economic sense, according to Rogers, because the cost to put panels on a roof is greater than what a household would save on electricity. But what if Duke bought panels en masse, driving the price down, and installed them itself  free?

title: International Touch Lines
description: A few years ago I spent a semester teaching American history and English in Erbil, the capital of the Kurdistan region of Iraq. The campus of the university where I taught has both a basketball court and a soccer field. The court was always empty, but the dirt field, with lines barely visible and netless goals, was frequently filled with players in mismatched jerseys and winter jackets who lacked for nothing in confidence or joy. Soccer is a sport Ive enjoyed all my life, and the many invitations I received to play on that field made me feel welcome, not only at the university but in that part of the world. So last summer, when I returned to the region, I suspected it wouldnt be long before the games began again.

title: Hertz Changes Way it Charges for Gas
description: On July 1, Hertz (www.hertz.com) will introduce a new refueling program. Instead of its current practice of charging about $7.50 a gallon to refuel a returned car with less than a full tank of gas, it will charge a one-time fee of $6.99, plus the average price per gallon locally, as determined by the Oil Price Information Service. To calculate the rate, Hertz will take the average price charged by the three gas stations closest to the facility where the car is being returned. Hertz has also revamped its fuel-purchase option. Those who opt to pay for Hertz-provided gas upfront will also pay the local market rates minus a small amount (about 15 cents a gallon).

A new pitching coach, Dan Warthen, will oversee Pelfreys start against the Colorado Rockies on Sunday, and it is the first time Pelfrey has worked with anyone at the major league level other than Rick Peterson, who was fired Tuesday.

title: The Greed Beat
description: As I finished Joe Noceras Good Guys and Bad Guys  a collection of his best business writing over the last quarter-century  I found myself wishing hed waited a year to publish it. Or maybe just six months. Because by then Nocera would certainly have trained his no-nonsense eye and deceptively simple writing style on the kind of scandal it seems he was born to chronicle: the subprime mortgage disaster. Peopled as it is with so many scoundrels and fools  and even a few good guys  the subprime story is precisely the sort of economic morality tale that Nocera has excelled at telling for so long, with himself cast as the stern schoolmaster.

title: Central Park in the Dark
description: The first time I walked through the Ramble at night I was terrified. I had been there in the daytime often enough; that thirty-seven-acre wilderness in the heart of Central Park is where I first became a birdwatcher. But the very features that enchanted me by day  the winding paths, the thicket of trees blocking out the city in all directions, the rock formations cropping up out of nowhere, the secret coves, the rustic bridges and sylvan streams  all looked grotesque and menacing in the darkness. A shadow looming up ahead brought back a scary illustration from my childhood fairy-tale book, the silhouette of a horrible, grinning witch about to seize innocent children just like me! And those rustlings to the right of the path and the small, throaty growls from the bushes near the Lake  was I imagining them?

title: Not My Fault
description: Although secrecy and loyalty have been bywords of the Bush White House, its officials have been improbably loose-lipped upon leaving office, particularly in the memoirs they have written. So far, there have been exposs from Paul ONeill (Bushs former Treasury secretary), Richard Clarke (his onetime counterterrorism czar), David Kuo (deputy director of the White Houses faith-based initiative), L. Paul Bremer III (the former top civilian in Iraq) and the foreign-policy hands John Bolton and Douglas J. Feith. Each of these books has been a record, to some extent, of disillusionment, and all have excited a good deal of attention. But perhaps none have had the force of What Happened, the new memoir by Bushs former press secretary, Scott McClellan, which has zoomed to the top of the best-seller lists (including the Book Reviews) and brought fresh scrutiny to an administration that had been all but invisible during this election season.

title: New Cruise Ship to Feature Aquatheater

The 5,400-passenger Oasis will also introduce some first-time-at-sea amenities. Its Boardwalk neighborhood, a family-friendly area with casual restaurants, a candy shop and fortune telling and temporary tattoo parlors, will feature a carousel and an Aquatheater. The theater, home of the largest pool at sea, will offer fountain shows with music, lights and high-diving aerial performances, and will seat 600. Two rock-climbing walls, as well as private deck seating, will overlook the performance space. Another neighborhood called Central Park will feature a football-field-sized open-air space with tropical vegetation (www.oasisoftheseas.com).

title: Alexis Scott, Michael Faber
description: Alexis Joanna Scott, a daughter of Joanna Colleto Scott and Hal S. Scott of Cambridge, Mass., was married on Saturday on the Massachusetts island of Marthas Vineyard to Michael Bach Faber, a son of Susan Bach Faber and Richard A. Faber of Memphis. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Federated Church in Edgartown.

title: Correction: Malthus Redux
description: An article last Sunday about the population theory of Thomas Malthus, a British economist and demographer at the turn of the 19th century, misstated the population of Africa. The estimated population last year was about 944 million people, not 770 million.

title: A World of Censorship, With Sounds to Jog By
description: Nas

title: New-Age Mutant Ninja Wagons
description: MUTATIONS drive evolution. Say youre born with six toes on each foot around the time that an epidemic of the Five Toed Virus sweeps the planet and wreaks havoc on the normal-footed populace. From then on, you and the other six-toed people will have the upper hand, and your offspring will wonder how anyone got by with only five little piggies on each foot.

title: A Cornucopia of Produce
description: In 1969, Joe Smiths parents decided to buy an old roadside farm stand on Allaire Road in Wall. Since then, the surrounding landscape has changed and farmland has been developed into tracts of homes, schools and soccer fields. Smiths Farm Market still remains, as timeless as the classic apple pies it sells.

title: For a Good Retirement, Find Work. Good Luck.
description: Bill Neugent, an engineer in McLean, Va., is doing his bit to ease the looming generational financial squeeze as the nations 75 million baby boomers begin to retire. Hes working longer.

title: Finding Solutions, Together
description: SCARSDALE

title: Food Stamps Buy Less; Families Are Hit Hard
description: Making ends meet on food stamps has never been easy for Cassandra Johnson, but since food prices began their steep climb earlier this year, she has had to develop new survival strategies.

title: When Walking the Course Is a Courageous Act
description: There has been a lot of talk in the last week about courage in golf, much said about guts and resolve, about physical and mental toughness and fortitude.

title: Hoboken Weathers the Market
description: HOBOKEN was often held up as the prime example of the booming real estate market, and now it appears that the city is showing that it can hold its own in a down market, too.

title: Two Republican Contenders Whose Similarities Are Mostly Skin Deep
description: WASHINGTON  They are war heroes with the injuries to show for it. They are known for hurricane tempers and caustic wit. They are among the oldest men to seek the presidency.

title: Editors Note
description: The Central Intelligence Agency asked The New York Times not to publish the name of Deuce Martinez, an interrogator who questioned Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and other high-level Al Qaeda prisoners, saying that to identify Mr. Martinez would invade his privacy and put him at risk of retaliation from terrorists or harassment from critics of the agency.

title: And the Band Honked On
description: THE classroom filled with the sounds of a band struggling to be born, a cacophony of squealing and buzzing. Middle school students in a working-class Brooklyn neighborhood were trying to produce the note F.

title: Family Meal
description: For my sister, Mary, who has lived in a Maryland institution for the mentally retarded since she was 8, theres no hiding the fact that food is central. When she is eating, food appears to be the focus of her attention. She doesnt like to be distracted from it by conversations, let alone by dramatic events. In anticipating the birthday lunches my parents planned for her on her yearly two-hour visits to their summer rental in Bronxville, N.Y., to which she was accompanied by an attendant, she would always reel off the menu she was expecting. This meal never varied throughout her teens and remained unchanged as she passed through her 20s, 30s, 40s and 50s: chicken salad, tomatoes, rolls with butter, iced tea, ice cream and cake. Each summer, she would mention the food within moments of arriving. Mary has a way of speaking that can almost be like singing or intoning, with each syllable given enormous weight. This menu always sounded particularly emphatic. During the chicken-salad course, she would mention a few times that ice cream and cake were coming.

title: Sea of Trash
description: Off Gore Point, where tide rips collide, the rolling swells rear up and steepen into whitecaps. Quiet with concentration, Chris Pallister decelerates from 15 knots to 8, strains to peer through a windshield blurry with spray, tightens his grip on the wheel and, like a skier negotiating moguls, coaxes his home-built boat, the Opus  aptly named for a comic-strip penguin  through the chaos of waves. Our progress becomes a series of concussions punctuated by troughs of anxious calm. In this it resembles the rest of Pallisters life.

title: Juliet Eilperin, Andrew Light Jr.
description: Juliet Eilperin and Andrew Ronald Light Jr. were married on Saturday in Washington. Stephen F. Eilperin, the brides father, a senior judge of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated at the Swedish Embassy.

title: An ME Hotel to Open in Barcelona
description: ME by Meli (www.mebymelia.com), a hotel line that integrates modern design and fusion cuisine, will add a fourth property to its roster on July 22: the ME Barcelona. This will be the second ME property in Spain, following the opening of the ME Madrid in October 2006. The ME Barcelona is in the Innovation District, a waterfront business park that houses about 200 international companies  many of them technology-related  and is near the convention center. Highlights of the 259-room hotel include the 24th-floor restaurant, Dos Cielos, which has 360-degree views of the mountains and the Mediterranean (a rooftop garden will provide the restaurant with fresh herbs and other ingredients). There is also a pool on the sixth-floor terrace, along with two night life spots: the Chocolate Bar and the Penthouse Pool Lounge. Nightly rates start at 200 euros, or about $322 at $1.61 to the euro.

title: An Increasing Appeal of Starting a Business
description: FOR many female entrepreneurs, necessity is the mother of their venture. Take Carla Schneider, 40, of Orange, whose product, the WubbaNub, a silicon pacifier with a small stuffed animal attached, has been used in neonatal intensive care units and by mothers of fussy babies around the country.

title: The Lying Dutchman
description: In the late 1930s and early 40s, a middling Dutch painter of old-fashioned taste, Han van Meegeren, made several pictures in the style of Vermeer (1632-75), with the object of passing them off as originals. It was a smart choice  only a tiny number of Vermeers (three dozen) were thought to exist, and the passion among collectors to own one was intense. But still, why should any artist want to hide his own name and talent behind that of another? Why, that is, become a forger? These are questions Edward Dolnick tries to answer in The Forgers Spell.

title: Web Access on the Dash
description: THE Dash G.P.S. unit that went on sale in March was notable for one eye-popping feature: it transmits the position and speed of the car to a network that shares real-time reports of traffic tie-ups with other Dash owners.

title: The Demography of Death
description: IN a bustling neighborhood defined by crowded apartments and shops stacked on top of one another like intricate mah-jongg tiles, a traditional funeral home bearing the name Gerard J. Neufeld sits on a patch of freshly cut lawn. But despite the neat appearance of the two-story brick house, with its sloping roof and its chimney, it is one of the few survivors in a diminishing world.

title: Strawberry Fields, Wherever
description: If you had a craving for strawberries in season and a willingness to travel about 80 miles from New York City, you could have gone north last Sunday to the Beacon Strawberry Festival on the banks of the Hudson River, or east to Mattitucks, not far from the Long Island Sound. Which one to choose?

title: Pantsuits and the Presidency
description: SOME supporters of Hillary Clinton believe that sexism colored news coverage of her presidential campaign. The Times reported in a front-page article on June 13 that many are proposing boycotts of cable news networks and that a Media Hall of Shame has been created by the National Organization for Women.

title: When the Comedy Is Lost in Translation
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Datebook
description: SONOMA WINE COUNTRY

title: Shallow Graves
description: Still writing against the grain, Ruth Rendell opens her 21st Inspector Wexford mystery, NOT IN THE FLESH (Crown, $25.95), with a rustic English scene featuring a truffle hound named Honey who leads her master to a fragrant growth of fungi buried in Old Grimbles Field. Since this author has neither taste nor time for sentimentality, the mood is abruptly shattered when Honey digs up a skeleton and the picturesque countryman whips out his cellphone to call the police.

title: Party Titans, Updating Discos Sound
description: SOMETIMES you instantly know you have a hit on your hands. And sometimes it takes you a few years to realize it, because you mistakenly assume that your lone collaborator hates the song. In 2004 Andy Butler persuaded his friend Antony, the otherworldly singer of Antony and the Johnsons, to record a dance track he had written called Blind.

title: Bakeries Where Cake Is a Many-Layered Thing
description: IN the red, white and blue time between Flag Day and the Fourth of July, is there any dessert more all-American than a big frosted layer cake?

title: Katharine Shaughnessy, Eric Southard
description: Katharine Meghan Shaughnessy, the daughter of Judith and Bernard Shaughnessy of Garden City, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Eric Donnelly Southard, the son of Christina and Melville Southard Jr. of Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. James W. Adelmann, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Garden City Community Church.

title: Inching Along on a Master Plan for Jamesport
description: RIVERHEAD

title: Hold the Private Contractors in Iraq Accountable
description: To the Editor:

title: Cost
description: Her memory was gone.

title: Lauren Mara, Steven Chaput
description: Lauren Ann Mara, a daughter of Denise and John Mara of Harrison, N.Y., was married on Friday evening to Steven Robert Chaput, a son of Nancy and Dr. Christopher Chaput of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Daniel OReilly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

title: Mr. Bush, Lead or Leave
description: Two years ago, President Bush declared that America was addicted to oil, and, by gosh, he was going to do something about it. Well, now he has. Now we have the new Bush energy plan: Get more addicted to oil.

title: Are Small-Cap Stocks Signaling a Recovery?
description: IN times of economic uncertainty, investors dont usually flock to volatile assets like small-company stocks. Instead, they tend to favor havens like bonds or shares of stable, industry-leading blue-chip companies.

title: Letters
description: Too, Too Casual

title: The List, Where Intent Meets Action
description: IN our house, the tenuous relationship between word and deed begins at the top of the cellar stairs. Thats because theres a list there, tacked to the wall years ago when we took up residence. Replace basement windows. Pour concrete floor. Repair rotten step. Install shelving. Though nothing but a few words on a scrap of paper, that inventory is a place where an idea became an intention and the intention, a word. And when the word was written down, I was sure it would be the first step toward materiality.

title: Trading Compost for Condos
description: SOUTHAMPTON

title: A Fine Day for Music, No Matter Your Taste
description: For unsuspecting visitors to Governors Island on Saturday, there perhaps to see the Federal-style brick buildings or other relics of the islands military past, something was out of whack. Sharing the normally staid grounds were roving brigades of teenagers and young adults, some in torn black T-shirts and plaid pants, others festooned with piercings and tattoos. They were there to listen to bands like Hipster Holocaust, Beatdown Brigade and Reagan Youth.

title: Some Severance Deals at Utility Required Silence
description: ALBANY  At least 19 employees who have resigned in recent years from the New York Power Authority, the sprawling and politically powerful state-owned utility, were required to keep secret the circumstances of their departures in order to obtain severance pay or benefits, according to a review by The New York Times.

title: Battlegrounds
description: For the last six months, several writers from around the country have filed occasional dispatches on the presidential primaries for the Op-Ed page. Well, the primaries are now over. Here, then, are final reports from our correspondents.

title: Correction: The Love Song of R. Buckminster Fuller
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about R. Buckminster Fuller misspelled the given name of the former assistant curator of Mr. Fullers archive at Stanford. It is Hsiao-Yun Chu, not Hisiao-yun.

title: Abigail Freireich, Mark Weinsier
description: Abigail Suzanne Freireich, a daughter of Nancy Freireich and Paul Freireich of New York, is to be married Sunday to Mark Everett Weinsier, the son of Laurie Sherer Weinsier of Marietta, Ga., and Steven Weinsier of Plantation, Fla. Rabbi Jessica Zimmerman will officiate at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Buildings Auction Ends Feud
description: A RUN-DOWN five-story brick tenement building at 79 Horatio Street, between Washington and Greenwich Streets, will probably generate plenty of buzz when it hits the auction block this summer.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: Im the Designer. My Clients the Autocrat.
description: FOUR months ago the architect Daniel Libeskind declared publicly that architects should think long and hard before working in China, adding, I wont work for totalitarian regimes. His remarks raised hackles in his profession, with some architects accusing him of hypocrisy because his own firm had recently broken ground on a project in Hong Kong.

title: In Fertile India, Growth Outstrips Agriculture
description: JALANDHAR, India  With the right technology and policies, India could help feed the world. Instead, it can barely feed itself.

title: Im Richard the Ad Exec, Ill Be Your Waiter Today
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Breaking Down Barriers to Get Parents Involved
description: NORWALK

title: Beth Davidson, Clifford Lopate
description: Rabbi Beth Dina Davidson and Clifford Lopate are to be married on Sunday in Manchester, N.H. Rabbi SueAnn Wasserman is to officiate at Temple Adath Yeshurun, where the bride is the rabbi.

title: At the End of a Leash, a Surprise
description: IN a standoff with a white Chihuahua, Radar, a sleek, 3-year-old feline resident of the Upper West Side, stood serenely at attention. Beneath a canopy of trees on Columbus Avenue, near the American Museum of Natural History, he waited in his yellow harness (size: extra small) as the Chihuahua sniffed him out. Upon realizing that this creature was not one of its own, the dog leapt backward in yelping horror, and Radar, aloof, continued on his walk.

title: Keep the Rejection Letters
description: I WAS born in Iran and attended a boarding school in Switzerland when I was 13. At 16, I enrolled in M.I.T. and graduated with bachelors and masters degrees in engineering. Afterward, I went to Stanford business school. I graduated in 1980.

title: Rite of Summer Turns a Little Serious
description: The Mermaid Parade in Coney Island on Saturday had its usual array of sequined mermaid tails, long trains of fish netting, tiny clamshell bikinis and strategically placed plastic swordfish. But this years celebration also included a large number of performers with a cause.

title: Shannon Martin, Landon Nordeman
description: Mary Shannon Martin and Landon Nordeman were married on Saturday at St. Andrews Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Charles H. Clark, an Episcopal priest and the former rector of St. Pauls School, from which the bridegroom graduated, performed the ceremony.

title: The Shootout Over Hidden Meanings in a Video Game
description: If theres a subject thats as contentious as war itself, it might be a video game about war.

title: Do as I Say, Not as They Do
description: A friend insists that her children address all adults by last name and courtesy title (Mr. Smith, Mrs. Jones). But quite a few of her female friends, including myself, didnt change our names when we got married, which means her children call us by our childrens surnames instead of our own. She says she is raising her children with proper manners. I think they should ask what wed like to be called. Who is correct? Julie Atkinson, Redwood City, Calif.

title: The New Trophy Home, Small and Ecological
description: For the high-profile crowd that turned out to celebrate a new home in Venice, Calif., the attraction wasnt just the company and the architectural detail. The house boasted the builders equivalent of a three-star Michelin rating: a LEED platinum certificate.

title: Love, Honor, Leave No Carbon Footprint
description: STAYING in a treehouse in Africa, an igloo in Switzerland or a hut in the Amazon may not sound like the perfect honeymoon to everyone, yet these days many newlywed couples are choosing a bed draped with mosquito netting over one dotted with rose petals, shunning the more traditional romantic resorts for retreats that are environmentally friendly.

title: Staying in the Comfort Zone
description: NEARLY two years ago, Lana Walsh helped her future husband, Marco Tartaglia, choose his bachelor pad at the Zephyr Lofts condominium in Jersey City, just over the Hoboken line. She joined him soon afterward. They knew they wouldnt be living there long.

title: Courtland Wood, Trey Colantonio
description: Courtland Wallace Wood, the daughter of Cynthia McNair Wood and Stephen W. Wood of West Simsbury, Conn., was married on Saturday to Second Lt. Donald Francis Colantonio III, a son of Paige S. Colantonio and Mr. Colantonio Jr. of Simsbury. The Rev. Joseph L. Pace, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Johns Church in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Call for Change Ignored, Levees Remain Patchy
description: CANTON, Mo.  The levees along the Mississippi River offer a patchwork of unpredictable protections. Some are tall and earthen, others aging and sandy, and many along its tributaries uncataloged by federal officials.

title: Depleted in Dairyland
description: Shorewood, Wis.

title: See the Economy Through the Eyes of Its C.E.O.s
description: Did you recently let out a sigh of relief because you escaped the ax? Not so fast. According to a new survey of chief executives, a little over 30 percent expect their United States employment to decline in the next six months.

title: Remembering a Father, Adored but Distant
description: The Ties That Bind a Father and Son

title: Healed, Seal Returns to Hamptons Waters
description: HAMPTON BAYS

title: Paperback Row
description: NEW ENGLAND WHITE, by Stephen L. Carter. (Vintage, $14.95.) Carter, who teaches at Yale Law School and is the author of The Emperor of Ocean Park as well as several works of nonfiction, combines mystery, academic satire and reporting on the lifestyles of the black upper class in this stylishly written novel. The wife of the black president of a university much like Yale, herself a divinity school dean, investigates the death of her former lover, an economist who was collecting evidence about a 30-year-old murder that threatened powerful politicians  including her husbands college roommate, now the president of the United States.

title: Condos at Pedigree Prices
description: TENANTS at the Apthorp, the elegant full-block complex built by the Astor family for the New York elite, were amused at the high prices listed by the owners when they filed preliminary plans last year to convert its 163 apartments to condominiums.

title: Grand Central Sunspots
description: Grand Central Sunspots

title: Nothing Sells Like Celebrity
description: EARLY last year, marketing executives at Totes Isotoner, a Cincinnati company that had spent the previous 30 years churning out a reliable lineup of humble umbrellas, crowded around a computer and listened to a teenage singer from Barbados named Rihanna breeze through a tune titled, appropriately, Umbrella.

title: Paul Hamm Among Two to Win Olympic Berths
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Paul Hamm was named to the United States Olympic gymnastics team Saturday, he stood at the center of the Wachovia Center, the site of the trials, and waved to the cheering crowd.

title: Navigating the Road to Budget Harmony
description: THE deal hammered out in the past week that all but ensured passage of Gov. Jon S. Corzines $32.9 billion budget was born of negotiations that began in earnest two months ago and the bitter budget debate that raged in New Jersey two years ago.

title: Irena Budimova, Peter Shiba
description: Irena Budimova and Peter Kazumi Shiba were married yesterday evening at the Paauilo Kongoji Mission in Paauilo, Hawaii. Koga Miyazaki, a Buddhist priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Brooklyn for Sale
description: THERE was a time, decades ago, when Steve Hindys friends couldnt believe what he and his partner wanted to call their new business. Brooklyn Brewery? Why, people wondered, would you name a beer after that place?

title: Orthodox Jews Request Divides a Resort Village
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH

title: Firing Back at Gay Bashers, Bawdily
description: ENJOYING cocktails after a fatiguing rehearsal for Bashd, a gay rap opera, Chris Craddock and Nathan Cuckow, the shows Canadian writers and actors, recalled an evening nearly a year ago. Having just performed at the New York International Fringe Festival, they were strolling down a Greenwich Village street when, Mr. Cuckow said, a young man passed them and hissed an anti-gay slur.

title: 36 Hours in Mumbai
description: ITS the Jazz Age again in Mumbai. The populous metropolis is bursting with stock-market money, a shimmering art scene has a growing global presence, and young people are exploiting their newfound freedoms in dim bars until the wee hours. Indeed, in the citys more rarefied circles, Champagne is sipped every night and everyone knows everyone, darling. But large swaths of Mumbai, the former Bombay, remain immune to the homogeneity of global glamour. Behind the bustling boulevards are nameless alleys where coconuts are sold, haircuts are given and the citys frenetic traffic occasionally comes to a honking halt because of a scampering goat.

title: Katherine Pushkar, Eric Barrow
description: Katherine Pushkar, an editor at The New York Post, and Eric Barrow, an editor at The New York Daily News, were married on Saturday at Christ Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Agency Sees Theft Risk for ID Card in Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  Social Security officials, concerned about the risk of identity theft, are calling for immediate action to remove Social Security numbers from the Medicare cards used by millions of Americans.

title: One Mall, Two Realities. The Builders Is Winning.
description: Oyster Bay

title: Eleanor and Francis
description: In the early 1970s, newly flush with earnings from The Godfather, the director Francis Ford Coppola and his wife, Eleanor  an artist, shy on the surface but not to be underestimated  went house-hunting in Napa Valley. They wanted a place outside of chilly San Francisco where their three kids could play. Also, Francis hoped to grow grapes, maybe make a little wine. On a lark, the real estate agent took them to see a grand old estate that was up for sale. The huge Victorian house had an octagonal lookout tower; there was a perfect oak tree, and the surrounding vineyards dated back nearly a century. It looked like a movie set! We were enthralled. Thus writes Eleanor in these winning and quietly provocative if, by definition, highly selective notebook musings on her life and marriage.

title: Jakarta: Jalan Surabaya
description: If you want to buy a bit of Indonesias future, go to one of Jakartas many malls. If you want to hold on to a piece of its past, come to Jalan Surabaya.

title: Quote, Unquote
description: To the Editor:

title: Reminders of Paris in Londons Truly English Food
description: WHAT are great restaurants for? At worst, theyre a seated passeggiata, where the in-crowd asserts its in-ness, the would-bes try to, and the innocent come to gawp and glut. At best, they nourish the soul. Ideally, they start doing it once you walk through the door and continue long after youve left.

title: Veterans Rebut Swift Boat Charges Against Kerry in Answer to Challenge
description: For most people, Swift boat has become a political verb, a synonym for the kind of attack that helped destroy the presidential campaign of Senator John Kerry in 2004.

title: A Circle of Women, Discovered on a Stoop
description: WITH its faded painterly cover, Kingfishers Catch Fire caught my eye.

title: One Mistake Unravels Solid Start for Giese
description: A Yankees starter pitched well again Saturday, but for the second game in a row, a younger Cincinnati Reds starter proved too much for the Yankees to handle.

title: Letters | Dont Meet the Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: A Quest That Brought Lady Liberty Closer
description: Jersey City

title: Rural Legacy
description: MALVERNE

title: Michelle Mead and John Armor
description: WHEN Michelle Mead met John Armor in 1972, she was in a Baltimore courtroom accusing her husband of assault and battery, and Mr. Armor, her husbands defense lawyer, was cross-examining her.

title: Robbed of His Sight, a Car Owner Maintains His Vision
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J.  A crew chief named Jay Blake folds his white cane into four pieces and shoves it in his back pocket when he works on his dragster. He is blind, but he knows his way around an engine. His hands are callused, his fingernails greasy.

title: Letter: The Canals of Venice
description: To the Editor: As a marine geochemist studying the Venice lagoon, I was entertained and slightly horrified by David Kocieniewskis recent article On the Grand Canal  in a Kayak (June 1). After a couple of trips to the local hospital to be treated for bacterial infections, and with knowledge of the contaminants found in those waters, I can make some recommendations to those who are daft or intrepid enough to try it.

title: The New Pariahs?
description: No country is wholly free of anti-immigrant prejudice, whether it is the United States, where illegal immigration was a hot-button issue in the Republican primaries, or post-apartheid South Africa, where economic migrants were recently burned to death. But in many Western European countries today, something new and insidious seems to be happening. The familiar old arguments against immigrants  that they are criminals, that their culture makes them a bad fit, that they take jobs from natives  are mutating into an anti-Islamic bias that is becoming institutionalized in the continents otherwise ordinary politics.

title: Getting to the Grass Roots
description: Chillicothe, Ohio

title: Neuro-Liberalism
description: George Lakoff wants to save his country. In a series of books, Lakoff, a linguist and cognitive scientist at the University of California, Berkeley, has explained how the right wins and keeps power: by framing issues and controlling minds. His latest book, The Political Mind, grounds his critique and his agenda in neuroscience. Lakoff proposes to beat conservatives at their own game. Democracy is too important to leave the shaping of the brains of Americans to authoritarians, he argues. But shaping brains is a treacherous business. Its hard to manipulate voters and still be a democrat.

title: To Help Those on the Lowest Rungs
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale of Farm to Developer Is Under Way
description: BALDWIN PLACE

title: Caitlin Boyle, Curtis Ellis
description: Caitlin Antisdale Boyle and Curtis Cleland Ellis were married on Saturday at Dudley Farm, a house museum in Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Michael Maslowsky, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Network Nation
description: The chatter these days is that the Republicans are a party that has run out of ideas. The Soviet Union is long gone; welfare has been reformed; market logics have permeated almost every aspect of our lives (eBay, anyone?). The truth is that the triumph of conservative ideas may present a political problem for the ailing Republicans, but the party thats truly lacking in new ideas is my own, the resurgent Democrats.

title: Letters: The Architecture Issue
description: The architecture-themed issue, The Next City (June 8), was a wonderful exploration of how todays cutting-edge architectural firms, like OMA and MVRDV, are exploding the boundaries of conventional architecture. However, I would have liked to have seen perspectives from landscape architects, or what some refer to as landscape urbanism. Even architects like Rem Koolhaas, Bernard Tschumi and Stan Allen are turning toward landscape architecture to infuse and renew their own architectural-design strategies. Planning cities by single buildings was, and continues to be, a shortsighted strategy. To truly design our urban centers, we must now think of the city as a landscape of infrastructure (transportation, utilities) and systems (ecological, social, institutional).

title: Renewal Leases and Landlords Obligations
description: Q How many days before a lease expires does a landlord have to send a tenant a renewal lease?

title: In Confronting the Foreclosure Crisis, a Bill Strikes a Balance
description: The bill that Gov. David A. Paterson and leaders of the State Legislature announced last week to address the subprime lending and foreclosure crisis was, for Albany, that rarest of things  an effective compromise.

title: Soft-Core Auteur Turns Attention to Radicals
description: AT its peak in the 1960s the brand of kinky soft-core erotica known as pinku eiga, or pink film, accounted for half of all movie production in Japan. Most pink-film directors were anonymous journeymen, but the industry nurtured its share of eccentric talents. Among the most talented and eccentric was Koji Wakamatsu, a gonzo auteur with a knack for eyebrow-raising titles (Go, Go Second Time Virgin, Violated Women in White) whose most interesting films owe as much to Karl Marx as to the Marquis de Sade.

title: Letter: Food and Baseball
description: To the Editor: Peter Meehans article Buy Me Some Sushi and Baby Back Ribs (June 8) was interesting to read, but as a fan who has attended games for over 50 years in about a dozen ballparks (sadly some of them long gone), I have never once considered the food quality as key to having an enjoyable time.

title: U.S. Women Triumph in South Korea
description: Angela Hucles scored the games only goal in second-half injury time as the United States womens national team defeated Canada, 1-0, to win the Peace Queen Cup on Saturday in Suwon, South Korea.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: COMEDY

title: Pathways to the Spirit World
description: Try to keep in mind, as you wander among the sculptures in Embodying the Sacred in Yoruba Art, the Newark Museums lovely, revelatory show of African art, that many of these objects were never intended to be on public view. The idea, instead, was that they be placed on an altar in a private space and worshipped.

title: How Big a Payday for the Pay Consultants?
description: THE credit crisis, rising oil prices and the economy may dominate headlines, but excessive executive pay still makes shareholders boil. With the proxy season pretty much over  and with John McCain and Barack Obama both making compensation a campaign issue  lets see where investors stand in the battle to rein in outsized pay.

title: Maria Glover, Derek Ho
description: Julie Maria Glover, the daughter of Julie M. Glover and Eugene B. Glover of Maryville, Tenn., was married on Saturday in Washington to Derek Tam Ho, the son of Josephine Tam Ho and Robert P. Ho of Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. Samuel L. Wood officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension and St. Agnes, where he is curate.

title: With N.H.L. Draft Over, the Heavy Lifting Begins
description: Summertime for 29 N.H.L. general managers is about making repairs, stocking talent and telling themselves and their fans that they were not that far from competing for the Stanley Cup.

title: Low-Cost Film With Friends in High Places
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Correction: On the Trail of a Sustainable Feast in Sonoma
description: The Explorer column on June 1, about a tour of sustainable-agriculture farms in Sonoma County, Calif., overstated one growers contribution to the regions production of olive oil. The McEvoy Ranch was among the first to plant olive varietals from Tuscany in Northern California; it did not introduce Tuscan methods of olive oil production to the region.

title: Meredith Klein, Ryan Buckley
description: Meredith Nancy Klein and Ryan William Buckley were married on Saturday in Chatham, Mass. Rabbi H. Hirsch Cohen officiated at the Chatham Bars Inn.

title: That Summer in Maine
description: Theres a pitch-perfect passage late in Roxana Robinsons new novel in which the director of a rehab program meets with the relatives of a heroin addict to prepare them for an intervention. Their task, he explains, is not to judge the young man, whose habit has become life-threatening.  What were here to do is offer support. He paused. And love. The word: it sizzled in the silence like a live wire, electric, dangerous. Love was not a word their family used. It was not a word they would tolerate from a stranger.

title: Real W.M.D.s
description: Any new entry in the crowded field of books on the 1962 Cuban missile crisis must pass an immediate test: Is it just another recapitulation, or does it increase our net understanding of this seminal cold war event? By focusing on the activities of the American, Soviet and Cuban militaries during those tense October days, Michael Dobbss One Minute to Midnight passes this test with flying colors. The result is a book with sobering new information about the worlds only superpower nuclear confrontation  as well as contemporary relevance.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about Robert I. Toll, chief executive of Toll Brothers, described the companys new C.E.O. bonus plan incorrectly. The plan results in a bonus only if certain company and individual performance criteria are met; it does not ensure that Mr. Toll receives a bonus.

title: An Aching Reporter Feels the Pain of a Predraft Workout
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The sweat cascaded off my nose, fatigue ambushed my body, and my hamstrings pounded. After just 15 minutes, my jump shot became less reliable than the town drunk and I received the ultimate backdoor insult from a former N.B.A. All-Star, B. J. Armstrong, who happened to be my workout partner.

title: Correction: Buy Me Some Sushi and Baby Back Ribs
description: An article on June 8 about the new food choices at major league ballparks misstated the location of the tavern McNallys, an outpost of which is on Ashburn Alley at Citizens Bank Park, home of the Philadelphia Phillies. It is in Chestnut Hill; it is not in Germantown.

title: Sick Days
description: In her second year of college, the poet Sarah Manguso developed a neurological disease so uncommon it doesnt even have a real name. The autoimmune condition, a rarer form of the already rare Guillain-Barr syndrome, is known as chronic idiopathic demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy, and it took more than four years to run its course. For several of them, Manguso had to undergo periodic treatments in which her plasma was completely removed and replaced. The treatments worked, but sometimes only for a few days. Later, she moved to steroid treatments, which restored a degree of physical well-being but created complicated side effects.

title: Goya Framed by His City, Madrid
description: MANY painters seem indelibly linked to the cities in which they lived and worked, like Canaletto and Venice or Vermeer of Delft. But paintings are portable and, a few centuries on, can often be dispersed far and wide, which is why one quarter of Vermeers output can be seen today in a 10-block stretch of Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Success Story 2
description: Great paradigm-shifting narratives  entrepreneurs seeing clarity where others saw only fog  often have a feeling of manifest destiny about them. Whats striking about David A. Prices history of Pixar, the computer animation studio behind Toy Story, The Incredibles and other movies, is how provisional it all seemed in the moment, how key players at important junctures didnt really understand what they were doing even as they were doing it. But they kept working because of a sixth sense that something would eventually happen.

title: With Friends Like Angelo . . .

title: The Avant Gardener
description: For a first-time visitor, Brussels can be a dreary city. Follow the old towns meanderings past Gothic squares and gargoyle-laden monuments, and you will invariably come to rows of unyielding, unapologetically functional buildings that house much of Europes bureaucracy. Add to that gray skies and frequent drizzle, and the picture can become less than cheery. No wonder that passers-by often stop in their tracks when they come across Daniel Osts Art Nouveau storefront on the Rue Royale: his floral emporium feels like a breath of fresh  and beautifully perfumed  air.

title: Dominating Nadal Stirs Rare Wimbledon Debate

But courtside, as the coaches and the agents looked on in the June gloom, the chatter turned to the favorite for the mens title.

The climax was in 2005, when the increase was 15.7 percent, putting home prices at more than double their 1995 level. Except for the early years after World War II and during the great inflation of the 1970s, home prices in the United States had never doubled in the short space of 10 years.

description: Cheo Feliciano, a singer who helped define salsas golden age, celebrated what he cheerfully called the first 50 years of his career at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, joined by collaborators and admirers.

title: To Make a Stir at City Hall, Make an Appointment
description: The group scrambled under the portico at the top of the steps outside City Hall, seeking shelter from the rain. Paul Nagle, communications director for Councilman Alan J. Gerson, checked his cellphone for the time  10:18 a.m.  and turned to the reporters gathered to cover the first of two back-to-back news conferences on the steps.

title: In Rift Among Dentist Groups, a Tale of Political Clout
description: This is a parable about power and money and fear and influence and secrecy  in other words, about how a bill becomes law in Albany.

title: 2 Named to Womens Team, Meaning More Trials Remain
description: PHILADELPHIA  It came as no surprise Sunday when Shawn Johnson and Nastia Liukin were named to the United States Olympic womens gymnastics team. For about the past year, it had been a foregone conclusion that Johnson and Liukin, two of the worlds best gymnasts, would be going to Beijing.

title: Agreements Are Elusive at Oil Talks in Saudi Arabia
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  A hastily convened global energy summit meeting led by Saudi Arabia ended largely in disagreement on Sunday, with only a modest pledge of increased production by the Saudis and no resolution on what other practical steps should be taken to ease the crisis over soaring oil prices.

title: Big Browns Owners Say Stable Will Go Steroid Free
description: The owners of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner Big Brown, saying they want to lead the way to the elimination of performance-enhancing drugs in horse racing, announced Sunday that they would immediately begin withdrawing all steroids and any unnecessary medications from their horses.

title: This Time, Cink Beats the Field, Not Himself
description: CROMWELL, Conn.  As the sky faded to a menacing gray, Stewart Cink was the lone splash of color at the 13th hole. His stunningly yellow shirt, better suited to the glorious sunshine that bathed the Travelers Championship until Sunday morning, stood out in the darkened afternoon when his game did not.

title: Major Economic Reports for the Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS The economic spotlight will be on the Federal Open Market Committee, which will meet Wednesday to make a decision on interest rates.

title: Tweeners Tune In
description: Camp Rock, Disneys latest made-for-television musical, kept millions of tween viewers on the couch over the weekend, drawing an average of 8.9 million to the Disney Channel on Friday night and 3.6 million to ABC on Saturday night. The Disney Channel premiere was the most popular show on television on Friday and ranked as cables top-rated entertainment telecast of the year. But it did not reach the heights of the reigning tween musical, High School Musical 2. Disney had high hopes for Camp Rock, which stars the Jonas Brothers and the teenage singer Demi Lovato. In addition to the broadcast premiere on Saturday, it was shown on the ABC Family channel Sunday night and will be streamed on Disney.com beginning Monday.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An art review on June 13 about Heavy Light: Recent Photography and Video From Japan, at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, misidentified the source of comments by the photographer Makato Aida in the exhibitions catalog. They are from a condensed interview with Masayuki Yoshinaga, another photographer in the exhibition; Mr. Aida did not forgo the catalog interview.

title: Someone Elses Alex
description: The people at MoveOn.org have a new Iraq ad that is, if they do say so themselves, their most effective ever. Then again, for the group that brought us the General Petraeus or General Betray Us? ad last September, that might not be saying much.

title: Philadelphia Set to Honor Darwin and Evolution
description: PHILADELPHIA  In the long-running culture war between evolution and creationism, Philadelphia is firing the latest shot.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Arthur Galston, Agent Orange Researcher, Is Dead at 88
description: Arthur W. Galston, a Yale plant biologist who did early research that helped lead to the herbicide Agent Orange, then helped raise awareness of the militarys use of it in Vietnam in the 1960s and its devastating effects on river ecosystems, died on June 15 in Hamden, Conn. He was 88.

title: For Tom Petty Fans, the True Sound of Vinyl, Also Captured on a CD
description: The vinyl version of the new album from Mudcrutch, the recently reunited band from the early 70s that features Tom Petty, comes with a CD that buyers can play in their cars or rip to make MP3 files. Those who do will notice that it is abnormally quiet  and that the CD holder instructs listeners to play it on a good stereo and turn it up.

title: Doubts in South Korea Halt Deal to Restart U.S. Beef Imports
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Beef imports from the United States will not resume soon, officials said Sunday, after a new import deal failed to quell South Koreans concerns about mad cow disease and their policy grievances with President Lee Myung-bak.

title: Increase in Charitable Giving Dampened by Signs of Belt-Tightening
description: Despite a host of troubling economic signals, charitable giving rose slightly last year, according to estimates from the Giving USA Foundation. But there are signs that those trends could give way to a decline this year.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, auctions of four-week bills and two-year notes on Tuesday and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.

title: Bollywood Goes to Hollywood, Seeking Bargains
description: NEW DELHI  Hollywood loves to show outside investors just how the movie business really works. But some of the people behind Bollywood in India believe they have something to teach Hollywood about making movies.

title: Obama Camp Closely Linked With Ethanol
description: When VeraSun Energy inaugurated a new ethanol processing plant last summer in Charles City, Iowa, some of that industrys most prominent boosters showed up. Leaders of the National Corn Growers Association and the Renewable Fuels Association, for instance, came to help cut the ribbon  and so did Senator Barack Obama.

title: Madagascar in the Lion House
description: New York City is rich in dioramas, the most famous being the beloved trompe loeil landscapes at the American Museum of Natural History. Now the city is considerably richer.

title: Loosen Up, Youve Got a Friend on the First Tee
description: There was the guy who split the seat of his pants on the first tee. Bill Hancock quietly mended the breach, and stifled the embarrassment, with the safety pins he always keeps handy.

title: In a Box Office Battle, a Spy Beats a Guru
description: LOS ANGELES  In a comedy slugfest at the weekend movie box office, Steve Carell and Get Smart knocked out Mike Myers and The Love Guru, though intense competition among a continuing series of comic films could leave everyone looking a little bruised before the summer is over.

title: In Iowa, Lifes Possessions Become Debris Piles on the Curb
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Alice and Jon Galvin had waited patiently for the day that the water would recede and this flood-ravaged city would drop its barricades and let them go home again, only to find that there is no going home again.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the first round of the N.H.L. draft misidentified the teams that drafted Alex Pietrangelo and Luke Schenn. Pietrangelo was selected fourth by the St. Louis Blues, not the Toronto Maple Leafs. Schenn was selected next by Toronto, not by the Columbus Blue Jackets. The article also misstated the outcome of a trade between the Maple Leafs and the Islanders. The Maple Leafs gained the fifth pick of the first round from the Islanders, not the fourth pick.

title: The N.H.R.A. Races on After a Drivers Death
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J.  Tim Wilkerson had a trophy under his arm, but he had no desire to celebrate having the fastest funny car on the drag strip. His friend Scott Kalitta was dead, and Wilkerson wore a weary, forced smile during a round of photographs.

title: Ad Leaders See Webs Threat and Promise
description: CANNES, France  The growing advertising ambitions of technology powerhouses like Google and Microsoft are creating alarm in the executive suites of ad agencies.

title: Treaty on Ice
description: Washington

title: Wont You Be My Neighbor?
description: Brighton, N.Y.

title: Town in India Rocks (No Use to Wonder Why, Babe)
description: SHILLONG, India  Lou Majaw wore his signature skin-tight, cutoff short-shorts. His long gray hair hung like dirty threads around his face. Eyes closed in prayer, a guitar cupped in arms, he strummed the chords to Blowin in the Wind.

title: Flip-Flops Are Looking Like a Hot Summer Trend
description: This presidential election year may prove better than most at allowing a candidate to survive charges of flip-flopping. And Senators Barack Obama and John McCain seem to have set out to test their luck.

title: Philanthropist Giving Millions to Two Schools of Journalism
description: Leonard Tow is betting $8 million that universities can figure out the future of newspapers.

title: Ensuring It Still Feels Like the Old Ball Game
description: OMAHA  People always ask Lambert Bartak about the time an umpire tossed him from a baseball game, a dubious distinction for an organist.

title: No Planes, Ms. Earhart, but There Is a Trapeze
description: Amelia Earhart, the first woman to fly across the Atlantic, disappeared in 1937 during an attempt to pilot her plane around the world. She remains an object of fascination for many, including Julie Ludwick, a choreographer whose company Fly-by-Night Dance Theater specializes in aerial work. In The Amelia Project, Phase II, told in eight sections, Ms. Ludwick aims to pay homage to Earharts achievements.

title: For Rent-Stabilized Tenants, Increases Raise Fear
description: The rent is getting so hard to pay that Maricela Soto can barely afford her favorite green bell peppers at the supermarket. Soon, she said in Spanish, Im just going to have start eating chicken and forget about the rest.

title: Council Victory in Queens Energizes Republican Party
description: When the numbers were finally and officially tallied a little over a week ago, Anthony Como had won a special election for a City Council seat by a mere 41 votes. Mr. Comos razor-thin victory in a four-candidate race is not only a triumph for him, but also a victory that brings bragging rights for the Queens County Republican Partys leadership.

title: Women in Drug Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: To Ease Gas Prices, Obama Eyes Speculators
description: Senator Barack Obama on Sunday proposed tightening the regulation of oil speculators in an effort to ease record high gasoline prices and address one of Americans top concerns.

title: 2 Killed in Lebanon Clashes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At least two people were killed and 24 wounded as supporters and opponents of the pro-Western government clashed Sunday in northern Lebanon, security officials said.

title: New Outreach to Blacks as Border Patrol Grows
description: MEMPHIS  Nearly 1,500 miles from his post at the Mexican border, Cyril V. Atherton, a Border Patrol agent, embarked on one of his trickiest missions.

title: Thats Some Cheeky Shaman in the Aisles
description: Jim James, the lead singer of My Morning Jacket, couldnt decide whether Radio City Music Hall was a cathedral or a playground on Friday night. A handful of songs into the bands triumphant sold-out concert, he pronounced the building one of the most spiritual places on earth, sounding awe-struck. A few songs after that he was bolting up a stairway along the halls perimeter, stopping short of the balcony to strike a heroic pose.

title: JVC Jazz Festival in Review
description: TRIBE

title: Papers Facing Worst Year for Ad Revenue
description: For newspapers, the news has swiftly gone from bad to worse. This year is taking shape as their worst on record, with a double-digit drop in advertising revenue, raising serious questions about the survival of some papers and the solvency of their parent companies.

title: Theater Notes
description: Bill T. Jones, below, the Tony-winning choreographer of Spring Awakening, is back at work in the theater as the choreographer and director of Fela!, a musical based on the life of the Nigerian Afrobeat musician and political activist Fela Anikulapo-Kuti (or Fela Kuti, as he is widely known). The show features a book by Mr. Jones and Jim Lewis (Chronicle of a Death Foretold on Broadway) and music by Mr. Kuti, who died of AIDS in 1997. It will run Off Broadway at 37 Arts from July 29 to Sept. 21. ... Arias With a Twist, the collaboration between the puppeteer Basil Twist and the drag performer Joey Arias, has been extended at the Here Arts Center through Aug. 31. The run had been scheduled to end July 13. ... The Goodman Theater in Chicago has announced that Jeff Daniels (Blackbird) and Rachel York (Dirty Rotten Scoundrels) will star in the world premiere of Turn of the Century, a new musical directed by Tommy Tune with a book by Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, the writing team behind Jersey Boys. Previews begin Sept. 19. ... The New York Neo-Futurists will present a special Gay Pride edition of their weekly show Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind, June 27-29. The new version, Too Much Pride Makes the Baby Go Gay, will include the usual 30 plays in 60 minutes. Details are at nynf.org. ... Eddie Mekka, who played Carmine Ragusa on the sitcom Laverne & Shirley from 1976 to 1983, will take over in the solo show My Mothers Italian, My Fathers Jewish and Im in Therapy beginning July 15 (ItalianJewishTherapy.com).

title: Bad Medical News for Amy Winehouse
description: The troubled singer Amy Winehouse, right, has early stage emphysema as a result of smoking crack cocaine and cigarettes and may need an oxygen mask to breathe if she cannot stop, her father told a British newspaper, The Sunday Mirror, in an interview. Ms. Winehouse, 24, was taken to the hospital last Monday after a collapse and underwent tests last week. The doctors have told her if she goes back to smoking drugs it wont just ruin her voice, it will kill her, her father, Mitch Winehouse, said. Mr. Winehouse, who said his daughter also had an irregular heartbeat, added that focusing on her work has sometimes helped her to stay away from drugs, and that had she not performed recently in Moscow and Portugal, she could have been dead by now. Ms. Winehouse is scheduled to sing on Friday at a London concert celebrating the 90th birthday of Nelson Mandela and also plans to take part in the Glastonbury music festival on Saturday.

title: ABC Moves to Expand Its Reach on Video Web Sites
description: SAN FRANCISCO  ABC, the stingiest of the major television networks when it comes to syndicating its programs across the Web, is loosening up a little.

title: Uniting Neighbors, in Fun and Sorrow
description: There are buildings in New York where residents typically exchange little more than token pursed smiles every time they find themselves on the elevator at the same time, lest anyone suffer the imposition of an unwelcome friendly overture. Then there are the buildings where the lobby is a great sinkhole of sociability, a liminal space where 20 or 40 minutes of time vanish in pleasantries and catching up and invitations to dinner parties that require no more of a commute than an elevator ride or a walk down the hall.

title: Labor Needs to Improve Conditions for Nonunion Workers, Official Warns
description: Ed Ott, the executive director of the New York City Central Labor Council, an umbrella group for the citys labor unions, has an unexpected and unnerving warning for New Yorks more than one million union members.

title: Dutiful Grandsons Down Yonder in the Paw-Paw Patch
description: Perhaps youre one of those people who have long lamented, If only Weekend at Bernies had been funnier and had starred actors with some chemistry. Your wait is over.

title: More Money Trouble for Ed McMahon
description: Financial troubles continue to mount for Ed McMahon, below, the erstwhile sidekick to Johnny Carson and the former host of Star Search. Citibank has filed a lawsuit against him in Los Angeles County Superior Court seeking to recoup almost $200,000 in outstanding debt, The Associated Press reported. Earlier this month The Wall Street Journal reported that Mr. McMahon, 85, was $644,000 behind in payments on $4.8 million in mortgage loans on his six-bedroom home in Beverly Hills and faced foreclosure on the property. Mr. McMahon and his wife, Pamela, appeared on Larry King Live and discussed their financial problems, attributing them to a poor economy as well as Mr. McMahons inability to work since he broke his neck 18 months ago.

title: Reporters Say Networks Put Wars on Back Burner
description: Getting a story on the evening news isnt easy for any correspondent. And for reporters in Iraq and Afghanistan, it is especially hard, according to Lara Logan, the chief foreign correspondent for CBS News. So she has devised a solution when she is talking to the network.

title: Live Music Thrives as CDs Fade
description: A little over a week ago, Patterson Hood, a guitarist and singer in the Drive-By Truckers, stood in front of a sleepy but amped noon crowd at Bonnaroo, the music festival in Manchester, Tenn., explaining profanely that it was time to, um, wake up. As he kicked into The Righteous Path, a song from the groups new-ish record Brighter Than Creations Dark, it was if the space in front of him was filled with sunburned bobble-heads, each bouncing in unison to every word: Trying to hold steady on the righteous path, 80 miles an hour with a worn-out map.

title: A Bunny, Too, Can Strut and Fret Upon This Stage
description: Whats up with the guy in the rabbit suit?

title: New CDs
description: ALEJANDRO ESCOVEDO

title: Years Later, Climatologist Renews His Call for Action
description: Twenty years ago Monday, James E. Hansen, a climate scientist at NASA, shook Washington and the world by telling a sweating crowd at a Senate hearing during a stifling heat wave that he was 99 percent certain that humans were already warming the climate.

title: Mad Dash of Bikers Leaves Island in Its Dust
description: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man  Halfway down the suburban road that descends Bray Hill, past the traffic lights, between the elementary school and rows of homes with families relaxing in their front yards, there is a barely perceptible bump.

title: The New Fight for Financial News
description: TORONTO  For years, the Thomson Corporation was the information giant that rarely talked about its own business.

title: The Cure Mopes Through Town With Songs of Love, Endings and War
description: Theres no question that Robert Smith has one of rocks most irritating voices. Its quavery and strangled, yelpy when he raises it and morose when he doesnt, the voice of a hypersensitive high-school poet who cherishes his own wounded feelings. But if that voice were any less irritating, his songs for the Cure wouldnt be anywhere near as durable.

title: Looted Antiquities Returned to Iraq
description: Almost 2,500 ancient artifacts that had been looted from archaeological sites and from Baghdads national museum during the American-led invasion in 2003 and were recently seized by Jordanian border officials were returned on Sunday, Reuters reported. Maha al-Khatib, Jordans tourism minister, presented the pieces  including coins, necklaces, ancient scrolls and ceramic pots  to Mohammed al-Uraibi, Iraqs antiquities minister, at a ceremony in Amman, Jordan. One of the most valuable of the pieces is an ivory relief from the first millennium B.C. that came from the ancient Assyrian city of Nimrud. Mr. Uraibi said 15,000 items were stolen during the looting in 2003, and about 8,500 have been returned.

title: Doubting Case, a Prosecutor Helped the Defense
description: The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, had a problem. The murder convictions of two men in one of his offices big cases  the 1990 shooting of a bouncer outside the Palladium nightclub  had been called into question by a stream of new evidence.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A report in some editions of the Sports Briefing column on Friday about the United States Olympic mens basketball team misspelled the surname of a player who withdrew from consideration for the team and misspelled the surname of the managing director of USA Basketball. The player is Amare Stoudemire, not Stoudamire, and the managing director is Jerry Colangelo, not Colangleo.

title: Making Progress on Pensions as the Session Draws to a Close
description: ALBANY  Heading into the last day of the legislative session on Monday, Gov. David A. Paterson and lawmakers are close to agreement on a series of changes aimed at preventing abuses of the state pension system, people involved in the negotiations said.

title: Going Back to Bruckner for a Formidable Finale
description: Lorin Maazel will end his next season with the New York Philharmonic, his seventh and last as music director, with a series of blockbuster programs: much the way he ended this season, in fact. In recent weeks there were Mahlers Ninth Symphony; Mr. Maazels own orchestral distillation of Wagners Ring cycle; a concert presentation of Puccinis Tosca; and finally, on Friday and Saturday, Bruckners Eighth Symphony.

title: The Mets Math: 2 Stars, 6 Encores, 50,000 in Park
description: The speculation that 100,000 people, maybe even 150,000, might turn up for the Metropolitan Operas concert in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Friday night may have been strategic hype from the companys media-savvy general manager, Peter Gelb. Still, Mr. Gelb promised a big show, and this concert, featuring operas starriest married couple, the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna, was certainly that.

description: To the Editor:
