description: Metro

title: Heroes Who Drink Milk and Know Their Xbox
description: One of the enduring attractions of comic books and graphic novels is the ease with which they explain the universe. Evil is identifiable, external and fairly simple to vanquish with the application of the appropriate superpowers. And sometimes, as in the case of ABC Familys new comic-based series The Middleman, evil is downright funny.

title: Couples Downfall Is Culminating in Sentencing in Long Island Slavery Case
description: MUTTONTOWN, N.Y.  With their courtship complete and their arranged marriage only a few weeks old, Mahender and Varsha Sabhnani set out for New York from India in 1981, leaving behind their wealthy families and households with live-in servants.

title: Fashion on the Fairway, With Function in Mind
description: A few weeks ago, we offered some tips on mens golf fashion. In advance of this weeks United States Womens Open, the L.P.G.A. Tour players Morgan Pressel and Christina Kim discussed what they wear on the golf course.

title: An Unlikely Promoter Drives Nokias Push in Hollywood
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.  Tero Ojanpera is an unlikely media entrepreneur. Mr. Ojanpera, a veteran Nokia executive, is not a fan of American Idol, although he says he enjoys it from time to time. And when he tried to watch a recent episode of Hannah Montana, one of his sons switched the channel.

title: Rudolph J. Vecoli, Scholar of Immigration, Is Dead at 81
description: Rudolph J. Vecoli, an Italian-American historian whose searching chronicles of the American immigrant experience gave a new view of what immigrants kept and left behind, died on June 17 in St. Louis Park, Minn. He was 81 and lived in St. Paul.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: AbelsonTaylor, Chicago, promoted three employees and hired two. Julie Anne Lewis, copywriter, becomes senior copywriter. And Pearl Ochoa and Julia Thiel, art directors, become senior art directors. The new employees are Tony Pope, senior copywriter, who had been senior copywriter at Goble & Associates, Chicago, and Kevin Tran, art director, who worked most recently as a freelance.

title: Flying High
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Tuesday about business deals announced on the eve of trade talks between the United States and China misstated the name of the school where the top Chinese delegate to the talks, Vice Premier Wang Qishan, was educated. It is Northwest University, in his native Shanxi Province  not Northwestern University.

title: ABC and Writers Skirmish Over After-Hours E-Mail
description: BlackBerrys blur the lines between work and play. A recent dispute at ABC News asked: at what point does checking e-mail after hours constitute working overtime?

title: What Time Is It? Time to Go Outdoors.
description: A campaign from Timex is trying to be as big as all outdoors.

title: The Case for Mining Law Reform
description: On June 17, the generally conservative commissioners of Lincoln County, New Mexico, terrified by the prospect of a big gold mining operation in the nearby Capitan Mountains, asked the Senate to amend the 1872 mining law to give local officials some say in the matter. Two days later, Representative Ral Grijalva of Arizona urged the secretary of the interior to take emergency measures to protect lands adjacent to the Grand Canyon from uranium mining. And the day after that, three Western governors added their voices to the reform chorus.

title: From Afghanistan, NATO Shells Militants in Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO forces in Afghanistan shelled guerrillas in Pakistan in two separate episodes on Sunday, as escalating insurgent violence appeared to be eroding the alliances restraint along the border.

title: Mugabe Rival Quits Zimbabwe Runoff, Citing Attacks
description: JOHANNESBURG  The leader of Zimbabwes opposition party withdrew Sunday from a presidential runoff, just five days before it was to be held, saying he could neither participate in this violent, illegitimate sham of an election process, nor ask his voters to risk their lives in the face of threats from forces backing President Robert Mugabe.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the songwriter-singer Tony Joe White, who will perform at Joes Pub on Wednesday, misidentified an artist who recorded his Rainy Night in Georgia. It was Brook Benton, not Gladys Knight. (She recorded Midnight Train to Georgia, by Jim Weatherly.)

title: For One Night, a Feeling of Caramoor on the Seine
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  Almost as soon as American music was weaned of its early dependency on German models it developed an adolescent crush on France. George Gershwin, of course, celebrated the allure of Paris. The relationship was consummated by the influential pedagogue Nadia Boulanger and her distinguished line of American students, chief among them Aaron Copland.

title: The Misfits on Block
description: A film of Marilyn Monroe on the set of The Misfits, her last completed movie, brought $60,000 at an auction of cinema memorabilia held by Juliens Auctions at Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino in Las Vegas on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. The 47-minute film, On the Set With The Misfits, was shot by Stanley Floyd Kilarr, an extra in the movie, and includes candid bits with Monroe, above in a still from the movie, Clark Gable, Montgomery Clift and the director John Huston. The auction also included a disco ball from Saturday Night Fever, an original script of The Godfather signed by Marlon Brando, and Alfred Hitchcocks drivers license. (It went for $8,000.)

title: Census Damage Control
description: Preparations for the 2010 census are a shambles.

title: A Musical Daisy Chain Leads Up to Balanchine
description: The new program that entered City Ballets repertory on Friday and Saturday evenings features four ballets whose greatest common factor is that they were all choreographed by Balanchine. Since they are so unalike, that itself is a real fascination.

title: Lottery Numbers
Big Paycheck or Service? Students Are Put to Test
description: A prominent education professor at Harvard has begun leading reflection seminars at three highly selective colleges, which he hopes will push undergraduates to think more deeply about the connection between their educations and aspirations.

title: Bright Spots on a Rainy Day
description: In the wacky category of Yankees highlights Sunday, Jason Giambi stole a base and Andy Pettitte was knocked off the pitching mound by a gust of wind during a rain-delayed 4-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Yankee Stadium.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article Saturday about Steven, Mark and Diana Lopez, siblings who qualified for the Olympics in tae kwon do, misstated the origins of karate. It is a Japanese martial art, not a Korean martial art like tae kwon do.

title: Bruno, N.Y. Senate Majority Leader, Wont Seek Re-Election
description: Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, the New York States highest-ranking Republican, said Monday evening that he would step down at the end of his term in December.

description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Despair in a Venezuelan Prison, Strains of Hope From a Music Program
description: LOS TEQUES, Venezuela  When Nurul Asyiqin Ahmad was taken seven months ago to her cell at the National Institute of Feminine Orientation, a prison perched on a hill in this city of slums on the outskirts of Caracas, learning how to play Beethoven was one of the last things on her mind.

title: More Time Spent With Online Videos
description: Compared with previous years, the number of Internet users who watched videos on YouTube and other Web sites has risen only slightly. The overall number crept to about 135 million in April from 132 million in May 2007, according to comScore, an online measurement firm.

description: To the Editor:

title: Old World Lesson for the New N.B.A.
description: Brandon Jennings smiled Sunday afternoon when someone suggested that he might be considered a trendsetter.

title: In Algeria, a Tug of War for Young Minds
description: ALGIERS  First, Abdel Malek Outass teachers taught him to write math equations in Arabic, and embrace Islam and the Arab world. Then they told him to write in Latin letters that are no longer branded unpatriotic, and open his mind to the West.

title: Once an Internet Giant, InfoSpace Dismantles Itself
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A couple of weeks ago, the handful of people who were still trying to use InfoSpace.com to look up phone numbers and addresses started finding themselves on the homepage of SuperPages, the business-listings site owned by a Verizon spinoff.

title: Another Female Suicide Bomber Strikes Iraqi Province, Killing 15 Near Courthouse
description: BAGHDAD  The latest in a wave of female suicide bombers killed 15 people and wounded more than 40 others on Sunday near a heavily fortified courthouse and government outpost in central Baquba, Iraqi security officials said. Seven of the dead and 10 of the wounded were Iraqi police officers.

title: Soggy Cleanup in Cedar Rapids
description: As the floodwaters slowly recede, residents find that going home is only one step toward recovery.

title: NASAs Hansen: Humans Still Loading Climate Dice
description: [UPDATED 6/23, 9:30 a.m.] Twenty years ago today, James E. Hansen testified before the Senate Energy Committee  in a room kept intentionally warm by committee staff  that the atmospheric buildup of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases from burning fossil fuels and forests was already perceptibly influencing Earths climate.

title: Meet the Starter
description: Bill Pennington meets the club's starter and learns the etiquette of beginning a round.

title: Bob Feller: Lots of Words, Plus a Ride to the Airport
description: If you spend two hours interviewing the Hall of Fame pitcher Bob Feller, you are bound to get some terrific stories and some saucy opinions. When I spoke with Feller last week for a story about the 1939 All-Star Game in todays paper, he delivered. He gave me priceless anecdotes and blunt comments.

Talk to the Newsroom:
Richard W. Stevenson, Political Editor
description: Richard W. Stevenson, political editor and deputy Washington bureau chief, answered questions from readers June 23-27, 2008. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

description: Location: Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: George Carlin, 1937-2008

Among other confusions, many are wondering how Mr. Russert could have passed a recent stress test, as well as other evaluations, and still have succumbed to sudden cardiac death.

title: Early Into the Summer Season, Notable Ratings Dips For Broadcasters
description: The broadcast networks are experiencing a sluggish start to the summer season, TV Week reports:

title: Big Box on The Sopranos
description: The Associated Press: A a 30-disc box set with every episode of the HBO series The Sopranos weighs in at nearly 10 pounds. Itll go on sale Nov. 11 with a list price of $399.99, HBO Video said Monday.

title: Should Shows Label Embedded TV Ads More Clearly?
description: U.S. regulators are expected to take the first step this week that could rein in advertisers growing use of product placements on television shows, sources tell Reuters.

title: Residents Return to Cedar Rapids
description: Sidewalks in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, are piled high with ruined belongings as residents return to confront the flood damage and the cleanup.

title: The South Street Seaports Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: An Author Enters a Fray
description: The prizewinning British author Ian McEwan has caused a minor uproar by saying that he despised Islamism because of its intolerance of homosexuality and its limits on womens freedom, The Telegraph of London reported. Mr. McEwan, right, known for his many novels including Enduring Love and Atonement, made the comments to the Italian newspaper Corriere Della Sera while defending his friend the writer Martin Amis from charges of racism. Mr. Amis has written that people who look as though they are from the Middle East should be strip-searched and possibly deported. Mr. McEwan said, As soon as a writer expresses an opinion against Islamism, immediately someone on the left leaps to his feet and claims that because the majority of Muslims are dark skinned, he who criticizes it is racist. He added: This is logically absurd and morally unacceptable. Martin is not a racist. And I myself despise Islamism, because it wants to create a society that I detest, based on religious belief, on a text, on lack of freedom for women, intolerance towards homosexuality and so on  we know it well. He called fundamentalist Christians with similar views equally absurd, though at least they are not trying to kill people. Mr. McEwans words drew criticism from the Muslim Council of Britain.

title: Court Voids Finding on Guantnamo Detainee
description: In the first civilian judicial review of the governments evidence for holding any of the Guantnamo Bay detainees, a federal appeals court has ordered that one of them be released or given a new military hearing.

title: Dody Goodman, 93, Television Actress, Dies
description: Dody Goodman, an actress who combined a dancers grace, a strawberry blond mane and exquisitely timed scatter-brained humor to create television legends, first as a fey foil to Jack Paar and later on the soap-opera parody Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, died Sunday in Englewood, N. J. She was 93, older than she often said.

title: Prognosis: Diabetes and Depression Track Each Other
description: Depressed people may have an increased risk of Type 2 diabetes, and those with diabetes may be at increased risk for depression. A study published on June 18 in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggests a new level of complexity in the relationship between the disorders.

title: More Closing Doors
description: Regional theaters arent the only cultural places falling on hard times. Codys Bookstore in Berkeley, Calif., a literary lighthouse for more than 50 years, closed for good on Friday. Yohan Inc., a Japanese distributor and retailer, bought the store in 2005, and Hirosho Kagawa, Yohans president, said in a statement posted on the bookstores Web site, codysbooks.com: Unfortunately, my current business is not strong enough or rich enough to support Codys. Of course, the store has been suffering from low sales and the deficit exceeds our ability to service it. During the 1960s the bookstore was an outpost of the Free Speech Movement. Mr. Kagawa was one of the many writers and readers who fell in love with the store. This is a heartbreaking moment, he said, adding, It means so much to me and I apologize to the people who have supported Codys for not being able to keep this landmark independent bookstore open.

title: Democrats in Senate Seek to Block Deals for Iraqi Oil
description: A group of Democratic senators led by Charles E. Schumer of New York is appealing to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to block a set of contentious no-bid oil contracts that Iraq has decided to award to the Western oil giants Exxon Mobil, Shell, Total and BP.

title: A Seductive Urban Sound Hushes Carnegie Hall
description: Bossa nova, the quietly revolutionary Brazilian music that Joo Gilberto introduced 50 years ago, quickly became associated with the sunswept beaches and sweeping mountain vistas of Rio de Janeiro in songs like Garota de Ipanema (The Girl From Ipanema) and Corcovado. Yet in the hands of Mr. Gilberto, who returned to Carnegie Hall for a JVC Jazz Festival concert on Sunday night, it is also very clearly an urban music, working its subtleties within confined spaces and rigid limitations, like an apartment dweller intent on not disturbing neighbors.

title: Calls From Crocodile Eggs Serve as Alerts
description: Babies make a lot of noise when they leave the womb, crying and otherwise carrying on.

title: Top Senator in New York Wont Seek Re-election
description: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader and New York States highest-ranking Republican, said Monday evening that he would not seek re-election in November, after a 32-year career in the Senate.

title: Technology Leaders Favor Online ID Card Over Passwords
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft, Google and PayPal, a unit of eBay, are among the founders of an industry organization that hopes to solve the problem of password overload among computer users.

title: Hacking Case Jolts Affluent California High School
description: RANCHO SANTA MARGARITA, Calif.  As their classmates at Tesoro High School here donned caps and gowns a few nights ago, two seniors were caught up in a much harsher transition into adulthood, far from the graduation festivities.

title: New DVDs: The Furies and Solo Sunny
description: THE FURIES

title: On Coachs Turf, Lagat Aims for Olympic Gold
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Sunset last Monday seemed to bring a perfect ending to a perfect day in what so far had been a perfect year. Bernard Lagat had just finished a nine-mile trail run as his coach, James Li, followed along on a bike. They had escaped the desert heat of Arizona for cool shade to train for the Olympic track and field trials. Then the evening calm was shattered, along with two windows of the rental car in which they had ridden.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: National

title: Washington Post Editor to Step Aside
description: Leonard Downie Jr. will step down after 17 years as the top editor of The Washington Post, he told his newsroom staff on Monday, making way for a generational transition under a new publisher, Katharine Weymouth, at a time of financial and technological strain for newspapers.

title: Two Quarterbacks, All Business on the Field, Share Wisdom
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.  In the cafeteria at the headquarters of MasterCard on Monday morning, Peyton and Archie Manning were the hottest items on the menu.

title: Wounds You Cant See
description: The U.S. has been at war for years now, but ordinary Americans have never been asked to step up and make the kind of sacrifices that wars have historically required.

title: Chorus Swells: Closed Doors Save Energy
description: Certain issues strike especially powerful chords among New Yorkers, and one of them is many stores wasteful habit of leaving their front doors wide open while they run their air-conditioners at full blast.

title: Confronting Inflation, on Separate Continents
description: FRANKFURT  In the view of a central banker, the worst thing about skyrocketing food and energy prices is not their rise, but that most people think higher prices are here to stay.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An obituary on Friday about Bert Shepard, who pitched in the major leagues after losing a leg in World War II, misstated his relationship to Betty Shepard. She was not his wife at the time of his death; they were divorced.

title: Mediate Gets a Greeting Thats Fit for a Champion
description: BARRINGTON, R.I.  The phone rang Monday morning, and Rocco Mediate fumbled for the receiver. On the other end was an unfamiliar voice, informing him that his driver was downstairs waiting. What time is it? Mediate said. And where are we?

title: A Bonfire Returns as Heartburn
description: Almost exactly a year ago, Tom Wolfe, the author of The Bonfire of the Vanities, was wandering the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Dressed in his trademark white suit, he darted around traders and whisked past trading booths, shaking hands and waving, just before the market was about to open.

title: Last Train to Cross Connecticut Drawbridge
description: In Amtraks Northeast Corridor, the railroads weakest link  a 90-year-old drawbridge across the Thames River in eastern Connecticut  was scheduled to carry its last train on Monday evening, as a four-day, round-the-clock marathon to replace the span was to begin.

title: Government Study Criticizes Bush Administrations Measures of Progress in Iraq
description: Beyond the declines in overall violence in Iraq, several crucial measures the Bush administration uses to demonstrate economic, political and security progress are either incorrect or far more mixed than the administration has acknowledged, according to a report released Monday by the Government Accountability Office.

title: American Envoy Is Linked to Arms Deal Cover-Up
description: WASHINGTON  An American ambassador helped cover up the illegal Chinese origins of ammunition that a Pentagon contractor bought to supply Afghan security forces, according to testimony gathered by Congressional investigators.

title: Officials Reject Report of Pregnancy Pact
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass.  The mayor of this seaside city said Monday that there was no independent evidence that a group of high school girls here had made a pact to become pregnant and raise their babies together, as a magazine reported last week.

title: Tropical Diseases Add to Burden Among the Poor in the U.S.
description: Ailments of poverty, including some tropical diseases much more common in poor countries, are a burden in several regions of the United States, a new analysis finds.

title: U.S. Womens Soccer Coach Names Her Olympians
description: When Pia Sundhage was hired as coach of the United States womens national team seven months ago, her to-do list included taking the team back to the top of the soccer world, preparing it to defend its Olympic gold medal, and altering the chemistry and composition of the roster.

title: Columbia Professor in Noose Case Is Fired on Plagiarism Charges
description: The Columbia University professor who gained widespread attention last fall after a noose was found hanging on her office door was fired on Monday after months of wrangling over charges that she plagiarized the work of two former students and a former colleague.

title: Nasty Noises
description: Q. Is there a name and an explanation for the nails on a chalkboard reaction?

title: Dan Brown Tourists: Next Stop, Rome?
description: ROME  As Tom Hanks, Ron Howard and the rest of the cast and crew of Angels and Demons wrap up filming, the Dan Brown effect is on many minds here.

title: New York Sees Big Potential in a New Wave of Chinese Tourists
description: New York looks a lot like Shanghai, said Fu Jiang Li, 47, as he studied the bronze peace sculpture with its knotted gun barrel on United Nations Plaza. He should know, because thats where hes from. But China has only one Shanghai  and America has so many big, modern cities.

title: Registry for Lobbyists Is Greeted Coolly
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission on Monday opened its voluntary registry for the thousands of lobbyists and special interest organizations operating in Brussels, aiming to shed more light on a group that seeks to influence regulations on everything from computer software to greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Germany: Calls to Remove U.S. Arms
description: Social Democrats, who share in Germanys governing coalition, and opposition parties called on the United States to remove all nuclear weapons stored in military bases in the country after a report found that security and safety standards at most sites for nuclear weapons in Europe fall well short of Pentagon requirements. The report was commissioned by the United States Air Force. The Pentagon said it planned to close some sites, but declined to identify them.

title: From a Prominent Death, Some Painful Truths
description: Apart from its sadness, Tim Russerts death this month at 58 was deeply unsettling to many people who, like him, had been earnestly following their doctors advice on drugs, diet and exercise in hopes of avoiding a heart attack.

title: Rights Groups Assail U.S. for Withholding Aid to Haiti, Citing Political Motives
description: An array of human rights groups has strongly criticized the United States government, saying it withheld money meant to provide clean drinking water to Haiti as leverage for political change in the country.

description: I AM not in the business of dispensing advice, but here is some nevertheless:

title: Leadership Void Seen in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan is in a leaderless drift four months after elections, according to Western diplomats and military officials, Pakistani politicians and Afghan officials who are increasingly worried that no one is really in charge.

title: Agreements Elusive at Oil Meeting; Price Moderates
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  A hastily convened global energy summit meeting led by Saudi Arabia ended largely in disagreement on Sunday, with only a modest pledge of increased production by the Saudis and no resolution on what other practical steps should be taken to ease the crisis over soaring oil prices.

title: Chinas Visa Policy Threatens Olympics Tourism
description: BEIJING  The plush lobby of Beijings Kerry Center Hotel is usually crowded with foreign guests, many of them listening to jazz and sipping martinis in Centro, the hotels fashionable bar, or lining up for taxis after dinner at the Horizon restaurant.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A music column and headlines on Monday about the Metropolitan Operas concert in Prospect Park on Friday night, featuring Angela Gheorghiu and Roberto Alagna, misstated the number of encores they performed. It was seven, not six. The column also misspelled the title of one encore piece, which was repeated. It is Granada, not Grenada.

description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The death of Tim Russert of NBC News this month quickly became a top article on the nations biggest news sites.

title: Court Overturns Guantnamo Hearing
description: After the first court review of the basis for holding a Guantnamo detainee, the federal appeals court in Washington has overturned the Pentagons decision and ordered that the man be released or given a new military hearing.

title: Some Doubts Upon Entering a New Carboniferous Era
description: Has any phrase in the English language ever spread more quickly than carbon footprint? There are contenders  hanging chad, for instance  but they dont reflect the potential revolution in consciousness that carbon footprint suggests. After all, carbon footprint captures something weve never really had a simple phrase for before: the measurable totality of your environmental impact, or, to put it more simply, what your way of life actually costs the planet. Carbon footprint is to your physical being what soul is to your spiritual being.

title: Achieving Wellness, Whatever That Is
description: There are so few good belly laughs in health care these days. What a pity I am likely to be the only person on the planet to enjoy the guffaw-laden, if slightly unnerving, experience of reading Dr. Nancy Snyderman and Dr. Nortin Hadlers new books in tandem, taking careful notes.

title: Firefighters Start to Gain in Northern California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Firefighters began to gain an upper hand on some of the hundreds of fires that erupted across Northern California over the weekend.

title: A Theater Goes Dark
description: In 2005 Minneapoliss inventive Thtre de la Jeune Lune won the special Tony award for the nations best regional playhouse. Now it is closing its theater and selling off its building to pay off a $1 million debt. After much soul searching and extensive fund-raising and debt management efforts, we have determined it to be the only prudent and fiscally responsible choice, Dominique Serrand, the artistic director, wrote in a letter posted its Web site, jeunelune.org. Mr. Serrand helped found the theater in 1978, and it traveled between the United States and France before it bought the Allied Van Lines building in Minneapoliss warehouse district in 1992. The board voted over the weekend to close on July 31.

title: A Master of Words, Including Some You Cant Use in a Headline
description: Stand-up comedy in America is not, for the most part, a long-lived profession. Comics burn out, go stale, lose their edge. Some, like Lenny Bruce and Richard Pryor, almost literally consume themselves. Others, like Steve Martin, prudently retire from the stage at the top of their form and then find other things to do. And a few old-timers, like Don Rickles, have turned themselves into living museums, doing a kind of humor that commemorates its own borscht belt roots.

title: Footnotes
description: Apparently not everything that happens in Las Vegas stays in Las Vegas. The 25th annual MTV Video Music Awards will be held in Los Angeles on Sept. 7. ... The original cast recording of The Hired Man, part of the current Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, will be on sale at the theater starting Tuesday. The show continues through June 29 (britsoffbroadway.com). ... The comedian Don Reed will present his autobiographical solo show East 14th: True Tales of a Reluctant Player, about growing up in Oakland, Calif., in the 1970s. Previews start at New World Stages Thursday (East14th.com). ... After a successful run at the Piccolo Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., last month, Silence of Lucky, the comedian David Lee Nelsons solo show of monologues and video, will run at the 78th Street Theater Lab on Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m. between July 13 and 28 (smarttix.com). ... The architects Zaha Hadid and Ben van Berkel will each design a pavilion for the 100th anniversary of Daniel Burnhams influential Plan of Chicago in the citys Millennium Park next year.

title: Cameras Emerge as a Tool in a Conflict Over Land
description: KHIRBET SUSIYA, West Bank  The conflict between Arabs and Jews over grazing land and water wells in the ancient, arid hills south of Hebron in the West Bank has a distinctly biblical feel, like the flimsy tent encampments and dank caves in which some local Palestinian farming families dwell.

title: To Avoid Student Turnover, Parents Get Rent Help
description: FLINT, Mich.  Because he has moved so often, 9-year-old Richard Kennedy has already attended four different schools in Flint. In his mothers latest rental house the other day, he described how it felt to enter an unfamiliar classroom.

title: Safety: Deaths Soar After Repeal of Helmet Law
description: In 2003, Pennsylvania legislators repealed a law requiring motorcycle riders to wear helmets. Researchers who studied deaths and injuries over the next two years say that decision had lethal, and expensive, consequences.

title: Whats Obscene? Google Could Have an Answer
description: Judges and jurors who must decide whether sexually explicit material is obscene are asked to use a local yardstick: does the material violate community standards?

title: Dia Art Foundation Names a Curator as Its Next Director
description: After two years of flux, the Dia Art Foundation said on Monday that it had hired a prominent contemporary-art curator, Philippe Vergne, deputy director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, as its director.

title: M.T.A. Cuts Delay Some Big Projects Until 2010
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority released a cascade of grim financial assessments on Monday that mean delays in subway station renovations and other major improvements, as well as possible cutbacks in service and increases in fares and tolls.

title: Kidnappers Release Greek Industrialist After Ransom Is Paid
description: ATHENS  A Greek industrialist who was kidnapped at gunpoint two weeks ago has been freed unharmed after his family paid an unspecified sum in ransom.

description: To the Editor:

title: Two U.S. Soldiers Killed by Gunman, but Details Are Disputed
description: BAGHDAD  A security guard for an Iraqi politician grabbed his Kalashnikov automatic rifle and opened fire on at least a half-dozen American soldiers, killing two of them, during a meeting with Iraqi officials in a village southeast of Baghdad on Monday, an Iraqi Interior Ministry official said.

title: Built to Order: Myanmars New Capital Isolates and Insulates Junta
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  The bamboo forests and sugar cane fields that once covered the gently sloping hills here have been replaced by hulking government buildings, roads so long and straight they resemble runways and a vast construction site marked by a sign: Parliament zone. Do not enter.

title: Conflict With Farmers Takes Toll on Argentina
description: ROSARIO, Argentina  Country roads and highways swelled with trucks bearing grains and gasoline over the weekend, as Argentinas farmers cleared the highways after lifting their fourth strike in three months.

title: After Rose and Beasley, Plenty of Questions to Choose From
description: The N.B.A. holds its draft in a Manhattan theater, a setting that evokes drama, colorful characters and wily plot twists. It is, in the best of years, a night of exultation and exclamation marks. This is not one of those years.

title: A One-Time Tax Break Saved 843 U.S. Corporations $265 Billion
description: More than 840 of the largest American corporations reaped a $265 billion windfall thanks to a one-time tax break aimed at bringing home profits stashed overseas, according to recent government data.

title: A Familiar Tale of a Man Losing Himself in the Wild
description: In April 1992 a young man named Christopher Johnson McCandless left civilization for the Alaskan wilderness, determined to live off the land and kill the false being within. Several months later hunters found his corpse and a note, saying: SOS. I need your help. I am injured, near death and too weak to hike out of here. He was dead at 24.

title: Small Towns in Illinois and Missouri Await Rivers Crest
description: GRAFTON, Ill.  Residents in cities and towns north of St. Louis continued battling floodwaters Monday as forecasters warned that the Mississippi River would remain near its current peak levels through much of the week.

title: Lawyer Says N.B.A. Is Trying to Intimidate Donaghy
description: The N.B.A.s attempt to recoup nearly $1.4 million in restitution from the disgraced referee Tim Donaghy is a transparent attempt at witness intimidation, his lawyer said Monday.

title: Lottery Numbers
M.P.G. Can Mislead When Searching for Fuel Efficiency
description: In an era of climate change and expensive gasoline, a vehicles fuel efficiency, measured in miles per gallon, is an increasingly important factor to consider when shopping for a car.

title: Justices Take Case on Navy Use of Sonar
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday stepped into a long-running environmental dispute over the impact on whales and other marine mammals of Navy training exercises off Southern California.

title: Memo Pad
description: UNITED ADDS MINIMUM STAY RULES  United Airlines says it will put minimum stay restrictions on almost all its coach fares, for travel starting Oct. 6. The move comes two months after United said it would add Saturday night stay requirements on 65 percent of its routes, and as other airlines are generally reintroducing minimum stay and Saturday night stay rules that were largely discarded in 2001 because of competition from low-cost airlines. In general, said a United spokeswoman, Robin Urbanski, the lower the fare, the higher the minimum stay requirement. For some of the lowest fares in some markets, a combined Saturday and Sunday night stay will be required. Minimum stay requirements have generally been used by airlines to discourage business travelers from buying the cheapest fares.

title: School Is Out, and Nutrition Takes a Hike
description: As my 9-year-old daughter began summer day camp last week, we talked about swimming rules, sunscreen and ... cheese fries.

title: Federer Wins Like Clockwork, but Others Face Sterner Test
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The clock on the new Centre Court scoreboard is digital, but the schedule is the same. On Monday at 1 p.m. sharp, the crowd begins to applaud. Moments later, Roger Federer walks onto the meticulously kept rectangle of English lawn that he has made his own over the last five years, and another Wimbledon is under way.

title: Death Row Inmates Case Gets 3rd Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to have a third look at the case of a death row inmate in Tennessee, this time to consider whether he has forfeited the opportunity to argue that prosecutors withheld evidence important to his defense.

title: Waste Firms Set Merger for $6 Billion
description: Republic Services said on Monday that it would acquire Allied Waste Industries for $6.07 billion in stock, uniting two of the largest companies in the waste disposal industry.

title: G.M. Offers Deals to Cut Overstock
description: DETROIT  General Motors, which has struggled to stop depending on big discounts to draw in customers, is pulling the sale banners out again.

title: Doctors Say Medication Is Overused in Dementia
description: Ramona Lamascola thought she was losing her 88-year-old mother to dementia. Instead, she was losing her to overmedication.

title: McCain Proposes a $300 Million Prize for a Next-Generation Car Battery
description: FRESNO, Calif.  In the 18th century the British offered a 20,000 prize to anyone who figured out how to calculate longitude. More recently, Netflix offered a million dollars for improving movie recommendations on its Web site. Now Senator John McCain is suggesting a new national prize: He said here Monday that if elected president he would offer $300 million to anyone who could build a better car battery.

title: George Carlin Didnt Shun School That Ejected Him
description: George Carlin, who died on Sunday at age 71, is not the most famous graduate of Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx. That honor would probably go to either Martin Scorsese or Regis Philbin.

title: Alaska: Energy Rebate Is Proposed
description: Gov. Sarah Palin wants to dip into the states budget, overflowing with oil-tax revenue, and give every Alaskan a $1,200 rebate to offset rising household energy costs. Ms. Palin, a Republican, said the rebate would cost $729 million in the fiscal year that begins July 1. Every man, woman and child who has lived legally in the state for more than 180 days would qualify for the payment. The states Department of Revenue estimates that record crude oil prices could pump $14 billion into states coffers in the coming fiscal year, $7 billion more than needed to meet current spending requirements. Ms. Palins deputy press secretary, Sharon Leighow, said the bill was likely to face opposition in the Legislature, which must approve the spending. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: Hopes for Survivors Fading at Sunken Philippine Ferry
description: MANILA  Rescuers failed on Monday to find signs of life in a capsized ferry that held more than 800 passengers and crew members when a typhoon struck on Saturday.

title: Dying Is Hard. Comedy Is Harder.
description: THE honest truth is, for a comedian, even death is just a premise to make jokes about. I know this because I was on the phone with George Carlin nine days ago and we were making some death jokes. We were talking about Tim Russert and Bo Diddley and George said: I feel safe for a while. There will probably be a break before they come after the next one. I always like to fly on an airline right after theyve had a crash. It improves your odds.

title: The Bush Paradox
description: Lets go back and consider how the world looked in the winter of 2006-2007. Iraq was in free fall, with horrific massacres and ethnic cleansing that sent a steady stream of bad news across the world media. The American public delivered a stunning electoral judgment against the Iraq war, the Republican Party and President Bush.

title: The Times and I.H.T. Study Web Merger
description: PARIS  The New York Times Company is developing plans to merge the Web site of the International Herald Tribune with that of The New York Times, in a bid to expand their global reach and deepen their appeal to advertisers.

title: Survey Shows U.S. Religious Tolerance
description: Although a majority of Americans say religion is very important to them, nearly three-quarters of them say they believe that many faiths besides their own can lead to salvation, according to a survey by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

title: Fred Wilpon Discusses the Dismissal of Randolph
description: As speculation about Willie Randolphs job status as manager of the Mets simmered for weeks, Fred Wilpon, the teams owner, declined to comment. But one week after Randolphs dismissal, Wilpon finally spoke about the decision.

title: Canada: Suspect in Terror Plot Tried to Ship Detonators, Prosecutors Say
description: A man charged with participating in planning terrorist attacks in Britain hoped to use an internal courier service of Canadas Department of Foreign Affairs to send remote bomb detonators to England, prosecutors said at the opening of his trial in Ottawa. The man, Momin Khawaja, a former software developer at the department, also used the departments computers to exchange messages about the detonators and a bomb plot with fellow conspirators in Britain, prosecutors said. Mr. Khawaja, a Canadian, is charged with plotting to bomb various sites in Britain.

title: Microbes Eating Away at Pieces of History
description: At Angkor Wat, the dancers feet are crumbling.

title: Woman Is Killed When Truck Hits Bus in Chinatown
description: The green street sign says, Welcome to Manhattan, but drivers coming off the Manhattan Bridge usually have no trouble knowing precisely where they are.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Because of an editing error, the Shortcuts column on Saturday, about gifts for graduates, misstated the sales of a popular gift, the Dr. Seuss book Oh, the Places Youll Go! It sells several hundred thousand copies a year, not several hundred thousand dollars worth of copies. The column also misstated the rate of sales growth for the book. Sales, which have been increasing steadily, rose by 10 percent this year, not by 10 percent each year since it was published in 1990.

title: Football Talk Soon Turns to Race on Imuss Show
description: The radio host Don Imus, fired by CBS last year for referring to the Rutgers womens basketball team as nappy-headed hos, waded into racially treacherous waters again on his new radio program Monday morning, in a brief exchange about a suspended professional football player, Adam Jones.

description: While a lot of attention has been paid in recent weeks to the fees that struggling airlines are adding to ticket prices, car rental companies have been quietly doing the same thing.

title: With New Sorter, the Worms Go in, the Worms Go Out
description: Sorting worms is not necessarily anyones idea of a good time. But its something that happens a lot in laboratories devoted to the study of C. elegans, the tiny nematode that serves as a model organism in so many fields of research.

title: Macedonian Murder Suspect Dead in Cell
description: PRAGUE  A Macedonian journalist who wrote vivid accounts of the grisly murders of three cleaning women was found dead in his cell on Monday after the police arrested him on suspicion that he was the killer.

title: Death Creates More Turmoil in S.I. Congressional Race
description: The death on Sunday of Francis H. Powers, the man selected by Republican leaders on Staten Island as their candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella, has once again plunged party leaders on Staten Island into uncertainty.

title: The Olympics Compete
description: NBCs coverage of the United States Olympic Trials gave the network a boost in the ratings on Sunday, making it No. 1 for the night among adults 18 to 49. But that was not enough to pull NBC ahead among total viewers. According to Nielsens estimates, the womens gymnastics contenders put NBC in the lead in the 18-to-49 demographic during the 7 and 8 p.m. hours despite averaging only a modest total audience of 6.2 million. That tally fell short of CBSs programming in those time slots: 60 Minutes (8.9 million) followed by Million Dollar Password (8.3 million), helped CBS edge past NBC for the night in total viewers. NBCs Dateline ranked first during the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with 8.2 million viewers, outpacing CBSs repeats of Criminal Minds (7.3 million) and The Unit (6.9 million). ABC finished third for the night with a lineup of all repeats. Fox was fourth, although it fared particularly well with the 18-to-49 set. Foxs Family Guy rerun at 9 earned the nights highest ratings in that age group but just 5.5 million total viewers.

Arrested by the police in Serbia on June 11, Mr. Zupljanin declined to enter a plea. He was indicted on seven counts of war crimes and six of crimes against humanity, accused of murder, torture, unlawful detention, forcible deportation, the destruction of villages and political, racial and religious persecution. Mr. Zupljanin, 56, sat mostly stoically as the charges were read out, apart from an occasional sigh and shake of his head.

title: California: Shootout on Freeway
description: A gun battle on the Riverside Freeway in Orange County left a suspect dead and a woman caught in the crossfire wounded, an Anaheim Police Department official said. The shootout followed a chase along the freeway, also known as California Route 91, around midnight after police officers spotted the car of a 40-year-old man wanted after he fled the scene of a shooting of a police officer at an Anaheim hotel on Sunday morning. Sgt. Rick Martinez said two officers had responded to a call about a man exposing himself to guests from the window of his room at a Best Western hotel about a mile from Disneyland. When the officers arrived, the man, who was not identified, was getting into a car. Shots were fired, and one officer was shot in the thigh. The suspect was next seen driving on the freeway about midnight Sunday. While chased by the police, he crashed and ran from his car, Sergeant Martinez said, then exchanged shots with officers and was killed. A woman who was in a nearby car was wounded in the elbow and lower abdomen, the officer said; she was expected to be released from a hospital. EDWARD WYATT

title: Praise for a Restoration

Winfried Brenne and Franz Jaschke, both of Berlin, are the first recipients of the Knoll Modernism Prize, established to recognize architects and designers who rejuvenate Modern structures. The pair re-exposed elements of the 1928-30 ADGB Trade Union School in Bernau, Germany, that were hidden or removed during the East German era, like glass brick, stainless steel and the original bright red color of the steel framing. The jury was led by Barry Bergdoll, chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, and included the architectural historians Kenneth Frampton, Jean-Louis Cohen and Dietrich Neumann. The prize consists of a $10,000 honorarium and a limited-edition chair made by Knoll.

description: Charles Wadsworth, the director of Spoleto Festival USAs chamber music series for more than 30 years, has announced that he will retire in 2009, ArtsJournal reported. Mr. Wadsworth, who turns 80 this year, has organized music for the festival for 50 consecutive seasons, beginning with Gian Carlo Menottis Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. We will miss Charles and look forward to celebrating his birthday and his tremendous artistic contributions, said Paula Edwards, a spokeswoman for the American festival.

title: New Allegations Revive an Italian Mystery of the 1980s
description: ROME  On June 22, 1983, Emanuela Orlandi, 15, was walking home in central Rome from a music lesson when she vanished.

title: Bipartisan Group to Speak Out on Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of 200 former government officials, retired generals and religious leaders plans to issue a statement on Wednesday calling for a presidential order to outlaw some interrogation and detention practices used by the Bush administration over the last six years.

title: In Cairo or Queens, Its Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: Theres Lots of Rough at Womens Open, but the Greens Get Most of the Attention
description: EDINA, Minn.  The 16th green at Interlachen Country Club is typical of this Donald Ross-designed course  pitched toward the fairway and as slick as linoleum.

title: Congo: Former Warlords Trial Halted
description: Lawyers at the International Criminal Court in The Hague fought over the possible release of Thomas Lubanga, a former warlord in Congo, whose trial on war crimes charges has been halted. Judges at the court warned last week that they might have to free Mr. Lubanga, who is charged with recruiting child soldiers during militia violence in 2002-3, because of errors by the prosecution involving the withholding of evidence. At the heart of the dispute is whether judges and defense lawyers will be allowed to evaluate about 200 confidential United Nations documents obtained by the prosecution. In an attempt to have the trial resumed, the United Nations legal office, which had refused to release the documents, sent a letter saying the three judges could privately read them under United Nations supervision but could not take notes. The judges said they would rule in the case next week.

title: NYSE Buys 25% of Qatar Securities Market
description: LONDON  NYSE Euronext agreed on Tuesday to buy a 25 percent stake in the Qatar securities market, gaining a lead in the race against its British and German rivals to become a truly global stock exchange at a time when growth has slowed in their home markets.

title: Boy George Denied U.S. Visa for Tour
description: Boy George, below, has canceled his American summer tour after being denied a visa by the United States because he is facing trial in London in the fall, his management said in a statement. He had been scheduled to show up in New York in August for the Department of Sanitations annual family day. (Boy George cleaned the streets for five days in 2006 as court-ordered community service after falsely reporting a break-in to his New York home. He wanted to give a concert for department workers.) The statement said that Boy George was devastated and that George is astounded at the decision and is having lawyers here in the States look at it in the hope that someone will change their mind. Boy George, whose real name is George ODowd, is facing trial in November on a charge of falsely imprisoning a man. The statement said, George has not been convicted of anything in London, and there is a presumption in the Western world of innocence until proven guilty.

title: At 32, Davenport Still Has Enough to Survive on the Graveyard Court
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Lindsay Davenports welcome-back present at Wimbledon was a first-round match on the Graveyard, otherwise known as Court 2.

title: Coldplays Strong Sales Buck Industry Trend
description: Near the beginning of Coldplays free concert at Madison Square Garden on Monday night to promote its new album, Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends, Chris Martin, the lead singer, joked with the crowd: I understand there have been some complaints about the ticket price. The roar of 11,500 fans suggested they were quite happy.

title: Americas Next Chapter
description: Kittredge, Colo.

title: Consumer Confidence Declines to a 16-Year Low
description: Consumer confidence dropped to its lowest point in 16 years in June while home values fell in 20 metropolitan areas across the country, according to two economic reports released Tuesday.

title: Casting a Wider Net
description: Several leading lights of the Internet world believe that access to broadband is a civil right, like water, roads and sewage treatment, and have renewed their call for making such access a national priority. To further their goal, they have introduced a Web site, internetforeveryone.org.

title: A Kingpin of State Politics Bids Adieu to a Stage He Relished
description: ALBANY  Like any good showman, Joseph L. Bruno knows how to leave his audience wanting more.

title: Two Romeos in a Modern Tragedy
description: Those familiar with Manhattan gay culture may not find a lot of new ground in Bashd!, billed as a gay rap opera, other than the novelty of a story recited entirely in verse and set to electronic rhythms and samples. Certainly not in the sexual explicitness of its lyrics, its nightclub argot or its star-crossed Romeo and Romeo narrative. But such an audience should be impressed by the passion of its convictions.

title: Let It Be
description: We read the news today  actually a couple of days ago  that representatives of the Beatles are in talks to develop a Beatles-themed video game. The commercial logic is impeccable. Guitar Hero, a video game that allows you to play along with a rock band, has been a huge, unexpected hit, and a video game based on the Beatles would be a way to introduce their music to an audience whose parents had not yet been born when the band first came to America.

title: Near Tie in Prime Time
description: In a low-rated Monday night of network television, filled mostly with summer repeats and reality fare, CBS, ABC and Fox finished in a virtual dead heat for first place in the prime-time ratings. CBS eked out a victory as the most-watched network, according to Nielsens estimates, earning the nights top ratings at 9 with a rerun of Two and a Half Men, which attracted nine million viewers. CBS also led during the 10 oclock hour with a repeat of CSI: Miami (8.2 million), which easily outpaced ABCs struggling reality show The Mole (4.1 million). During the 8 and 9 oclock hours, ABCs two-hour installment of The Bachelorette averaged a competitive 7.5 million viewers, leading during both time slots among adults 18 to 49. ABC and CBS tied for first place for the night in that demographic, just slightly ahead of Fox, which broadcast repeats of Bones (6.4 million) at 8 and House (7.4 million) at 9. NBC was a distant fourth for the night, drawing 4.9 million viewers for American Gladiators at 8, followed by Nashville Star (6.1 million) from 9 to 11.

title: Hot and Complicated: Thai in the Village
description: PORK on Fire. This contender for spiciest dish in the city should draw heat-seeking chowhounds to Rhong-Tiam, a restaurant that opened in Greenwich Village in March. But the timid shouldnt be turned off: Rhong-Tiam also explores the complexities of Thai dishes that have nothing to do with heat.

title: U.S. High Tech Said to Slip
description: The United States may be synonymous with the high-tech revolution, but it is in danger of losing its high-tech edge, according to Cybercities 2008, a report released Tuesday by AeA, a technology industry trade association.

title: The More Things Change in Albany
description: Joseph Bruno, the powerful leader of the New York State Senate, surprised nearly everyone this week, announcing suddenly that he will not seek re-election. It is hard to know what that means for Mr. Bruno, who at age 79 is facing a federal investigation of his outside businesses, or for the Republicans slim Senate majority. We hope that politicians in Albany  from both parties  will capitalize on this shift to finally clean up one of the most dysfunctional and expensive state governments in the country.

title: Croque-Monsieur
description: Adapted from Bar Boulud

title: House Votes to Block Cut in Doctors Medicare Fees
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill to prevent a 10 percent cut in Medicare payments to doctors that was scheduled to take effect July 1.

title: More Phony Myths
description: WASHINGTON

title: Cartagena Limeade
description: Adapted from the Charleston Santa Teresa, Cartagena, Colombia

title: Approval Is Near for Bill to Help U.S. Homeowners
description: WASHINGTON  With sinking home values continuing to drag down the economy, Congress is poised to approve a huge package of housing legislation, including a refinancing program aimed at rescuing hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure and the most sweeping government overhaul of mortgage financing since the New Deal.

title: Churros at Home, Without the Deep-Fryer
description: Fresh, warm churros dusted with sugar are an irresistible treat on village plazas in Spain, near the zcalos of Mexican towns, and, increasingly, in restaurants like Pamplona and Bar Jamn in New York, and even in some subway stations here.

title: Clinton Returns to the Warm Embrace of Her Day Job
description: WASHINGTON  If Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was seeking solace from the heartache of a bruising, losing campaign, she came to the right place on Tuesday.

title: An Italian Red, for Hot-Weather Sipping
description: Think of summer wine and white and ros come to mind. But in Milan this year, an unusual red wine, Anthos, has become popular. It is made from the brachetto grape of Piedmont, which is usually turned into a fairly sweet sparkling wine.

title: A Musician Who Mixes and Matches
description: Herbie Hancock was in good form as a host at Carnegie Hall on Monday night: gregarious, generous, unassuming, charming. And as a pianist he produced moments of typically ingenious effervescence. His problems arose in other areas, like concept and organization. But those things are crucial, and so the concert, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, felt glib and undernourished. It should have been a lot better than it was.

title: Showdown on South Street
description: A VISIT to the former Fulton Fish Market in Lower Manhattan on Sunday will be a little like watching a boxing match with a culinary twist.

title: Add a Splash of Ad-Lib
description: HERES how I learned to make cocktails. Some years ago, I discovered mojitos, which I liked a lot, at least when they were made well. But they varied wildly when I ordered them in bars and restaurants. So I began tinkering at home and found my way: dark rum, a little simple syrup (half water, half sugar, heated until the sugar melts), loads of lime, not much mint. No club soda (a weakening aberration, even if its correct). No muddling (too much work, too showy, and I dont even like the sound of the word). No white rum (unconventional, but I like rum with flavor).

title: Rosenberg Case Materials Are Closer to Publication
description: The trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, that touchstone of atomic espionage, is a case that launched a thousand doctorates and enough historical texts to make a library groan. Now, however, the 50-year-old record may grow even more complex: on Monday, the federal government, in an unusual move, consented to release most of the secret grand jury testimony taken in the case.

title: Keeping Things Artful While Picking Up the Tempo
description: For a few expectant moments on June 17, the four members of Sigur Ros stood in a corridor of the Museum of Modern Art, near the entrance of an Olafur Eliasson exhibition called Take Your Time. They were about to play a concert in the museums lobby, where hundreds of fans crowded before a makeshift stage. The show had sold out almost instantly, prompting much complaining (and some price gouging) online.

title: Bid for Australian Energy Company Turns Hostile
description: PARIS  The BG Group, the British gas utility, took its $13 billion bid for Origin Energy, the Australian energy company, directly to shareholders on Tuesday, saying Origin was overplaying its hand by demanding a larger takeover offer.

title: A Monet Sets a Record: $80.4 Million
description: LONDON  The summer auction season here began at Christies on Tuesday night when a standing-room-only crowd of dealers, collectors and art lovers came from all over the world to watch and bid on one of the largest London sales the auction house has held. Early in the evening a record price for a Monet, $80.4 million, was set for one of the rarest of his waterlilies.

title: Walsh Ready for Backlash From Draft
description: Donnie Walsh will make his first Knicks draft pick on Thursday night, then brace himself for the inevitable backlash. Booing draft picks is, after all, a time-honored Madison Square Garden tradition.

title: Evangelical Leader Attacks Obama on Religious Views
description: Just days after Senator Barack Obama met quietly with religious leaders, including the son of the Rev. Billy Graham, another of the evangelical movements most prominent names, James C. Dobson, has sharply attacked Mr. Obama, accusing him of having a fruitcake interpretation of the Constitution and twisting the meaning of both the Old and New Testaments.

title: Service With a Wink to a Japanese Fad
description: Culver City, Calif.

title: Truck Was Unsafe, Crash Inquiry Finds
description: The dump truck that crashed into a bus in Chinatown on Monday, killing one person and injuring four others, was not safe to drive, according to the authorities.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the hiring of a new director for the Dia Art Foundation, Philippe Vergne, the deputy director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, misstated the current title of a former Walker director whom Mr. Vergne was said to have been a candidate to replace when she resigned last year. The former director, Kathy Halbreich, is associate director of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, not an associate curator.

title: Hell Hold His Breath Until You Call Him a Man
description: Spending 80 minutes with Alby Cutrera (Matt McGrath), the insufferable protagonist of Full Grown Men, a serious road comedy about arrested development, is excruciating enough. But it is hard to imagine why any sane woman would actually marry and have a child with this unemployed 35-year-old cartoonist, who has the emotional maturity of a 10-year-old.

title: In Overhaul, Disney.com Seeks a Path to More Fun
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company, concerned that its main Web site is not entertaining enough, is moving once again to overhaul Disney.com.

title: Japanese Warship Visits Chinese Port
description: SHANGHAI  A Japanese destroyer docked at a heavily guarded naval base in Guangdong Province on Tuesday for a five-day port call, the first by a warship from Japan in China since World War II.

title: Footnotes
description: The comedian George Carlin, who died on Sunday, will posthumously receive the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Reuters reported. Mr. Carlin was named the winner last week. ... The Golden Globe winner and Emmy Award nominee Dylan McDermott (The Practice) has joined the cast of Playwrights Horizons first production of 2008-9, Three Changes. The new play, by Nicky Silver, begins previews on Aug. 22. ... The Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center on Long Island celebrates its 10th-anniversary season with performances by Gilberto Gil, Kathleen Battle, Herbie Hancock, K. D. Lang, Pilobolus Dance Theater and New York City Opera (whbpac.org). ... Brian Wilson  is joining Jimmy Buffett, Trey Anastasio, the Black Crowes, and Stephen Marley and Damian Marley at the Newport Folk Festival in August. ... Smithsonian magazine has picked Sept. 27 for its Museum Day, when participating museums and cultural institutions around the country drop admission fees for the magazines readers and Smithsonian.com visitors who present a special admission card. ... Eleven fans of the 1990s sci-fi television series Babylon 5 chipped in to buy a prosthetic mask worn by the actor Andreas Katsulas in his role as the exiled alien ambassador GKar. They bought it on eBay and then donated it to the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens. ... The Tony-nominated performance artist Justin Bond will perform his show Lustre at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side for four nights starting on Thursday (henrystreet.org/arts).

title: South Korea Warns Against Further Beef Protests
description: SEOUL  President Lee Myung-bak, attempting to reassert his authority after weeks of demonstrations against his decision to resume imports of American beef, said Tuesday that his government would not tolerate further violent protests.

title: Holding Back Young Students: Is Program a Gift or a Stigma?
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.  With the increasing emphasis on standardized testing over the past decade, large urban school systems have famously declared an end to so-called social promotion among youngsters lacking basic skills. Last year, New York flunked 6 percent of its first graders, and Chicago 7.7 percent.

title: Housing Aid Bill Passes Senate Test
description: WASHINGTON  A bill aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure cleared an important test vote in the Senate on Tuesday, raising the prospects for final passage of an aid bill by mid-summer.

title: Efforts to Slow Defense Industrys Brain Drain
description: When Paul G. Kaminski completed his graduate work in 1971 with degrees from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford, he started building advanced airplanes for the Air Force. By the time he stopped several decades later, he had played a pivotal role in producing a flock of new weapons, including radar-evading stealth aircraft.

title: Baghdad Blast Kills Four Americans
description: BAGHDAD  American soldiers and civilians had a surprise for the Sadr City District Council on Tuesday, and gathered in the office of its acting chairman to make the presentation just before the weekly meeting.

title: The Station That Dared to Defend Carlins 7 Words Looks Back
description: As the encomiums for George Carlin have rolled in from stand-up legends, celebrities and scholars, his death at 71 has also been noted at a diminutive, iconic and iconoclastic radio station in Manhattan, WBAI-FM.

title: Italy Gives Cultural Diversity a Lukewarm Embrace
description: ROME  An exhibition of art from India was being installed here the other morning, at the Luigi Pigorini Museum of Prehistory and Ethnography. Beyond the mah-jongg, Chinese music and Andean ritual dancing displays, Putli Ganju; Juliette Fatima Imam; and Juliettes mother, Philomina Tirkey Imam, were hanging their paintings of animals and fish.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A chart on Sunday with the continuation of a front-page article about the C.I.A.s secret interrogation program misidentified the Pakistan cities where two major Al Qaeda figures, Abu Zubaydah and Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, were captured. As the article correctly noted, Mr. Zubaydah was captured in Faisalabad, not Rawalpindi, and Mr. Mohammed was captured in Rawalpindi, not Karachi. The chart also misstated the year of Mr. Mohammeds capture. As the article also correctly noted, he was captured in March 2003, not 2002.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about stream restoration misspelled the surname of a researcher. She is Dorothy Merritts, not Merrits. And the picture credit misstated the surname of the photographer. He is Robert Walter, not Walker.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Slow-Food Fest

title: A Curmudgeon Leaves Millions to Poor Children of Panama, and the Battles Begin
description: PANAMA  In life, Wilson C. Lucom was not exactly child friendly. The gruff octogenarian never had children himself and was not especially close to the offspring of his third wife, Hilda, either. When he opened his ample checkbook, friends say, it was more likely to finance a conservative political cause than to help underprivileged youths.

title: Cherry Crush
description: Time: 5 minutes

title: As Bats Shatter, Baseball Considers New Rules
description: Bat makers, beware. The future of maple bats was discussed by baseballs safety and health advisory committee on Tuesday, and the dialogue could lead to more stringent qualifications for companies seeking approval to make major league bats.

title: MoveOns Alex Ad: More From the Torrent
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in Kentucky Kills 5 Co-Workers
description: HENDERSON, Ky.  A man who worked at a Henderson plastics company called his girlfriend from the plant about two hours before he fatally shot five people and then killed himself and told her that he was going to kill his supervisor, police officials said at a news conference on Wednesday.

title: Portrait of a Haunted Artist Who Befriended Giant Spiders
description: From an art historical perspective, the work of Louise Bourgeois effects a startling synthesis of traditions. In the 1930s Ms. Bourgeois fell in with the Paris Surrealists, and their touch (totemic, irrational, biomorphic, uncanny) can be felt on her sculptures, installations and drawings to this day. Other Modernist influences  the elemental rigor of Brancusi, the archaic vigor of Picasso  fused, in the postwar era, with her experiments in unorthodox materials and techniques (fabrics, knitting) and disquieting new forms (distorted anatomies, giant spiders) in sync with emerging ideas of the body, gender and sexuality.

title: Taking Ownership of Iraq?
description: Having recently returned from Egypt, I have the Suez Canal on my mind. And looking at Iraq from Cairo, the thought occurred to me that maybe the Iraqis have just crossed the Suez Canal. If so, thats good news.

title: City Proposes More Regulations to Improve Construction Safety
description: WASHINGTON  New York City officials announced a new seven-point plan on Tuesday that they said would increase safety at tower crane construction sites by strengthening inspections and requiring safety reviews each time a crane passes from one owner or operator to the next.

title: Albanian Custom Fades: Woman as Family Man
description: KRUJE, Albania  Pashe Keqi recalled the day nearly 60 years ago when she decided to become a man. She chopped off her long black curls, traded in her dress for her fathers baggy trousers, armed herself with a hunting rifle and vowed to forsake marriage, children and sex.

title: Ally Warns Outsiders Not to Push Zimbabwe
description: Despite an increasingly thunderous chorus of complaints that Zimbabwes presidential runoff election will be neither free nor fair, the African National Congress, South Africas governing party, rejected outside diplomatic intervention on Tuesday, arguing that any attempts by outside players to impose regime change will merely deepen the crisis.

title: Beer Lovers Make Room for Brews Worth a Wait
description: WHEN Matthew VandenBerghe brings home his favorite beers, he doesnt make room for them in the fridge. He takes them to his beer cellar.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Tuesday about the closing of the Thtre de la Jeune Lune in Minneapolis referred incorrectly to the artistic director, who commented on the closing in a letter posted on the theaters Web site. The artistic director, Dominique Serrand, is a man.

title: Investor, a Socialite, Is Charged With Fraud
description: An Italian businessman who was accused last year by the entrepreneur Ron Burkle of misusing more than $1 million he had put up for investments was arrested on Tuesday and charged with fraud and money laundering.

title: Dutrow Faces Steroid Ban
description: A horse trained by Rick Dutrow that finished second in a $100,000 stakes race at Churchill Downs the day before Big Brown won the Kentucky Derby has tested positive for twice the allowable level of clenbuterol that helps burn fat and promote muscle growth, according to Kentucky racing officials.

title: Religion and Its Role Are in Dispute at the Service Academies
description: Three years after a scandal at the Air Force Academy over the evangelizing of cadets by Christian staff and faculty members, students and staff at West Point and the Naval Academy are complaining that their schools, too, have pushed religion on cadets and midshipmen.

title: Fuel Prices Shift Math for Life in Far Suburbs
description: ELIZABETH, Colo.  Suddenly, the economics of American suburban life are under assault as skyrocketing energy prices inflate the costs of reaching, heating and cooling homes on the distant edges of metropolitan areas.

title: New Charges for 2 Accused of Embezzling Council Funds
description: A scheme by two City Council aides to embezzle money from a charity financed by their bosss discretionary awards of city money was more widespread than an earlier indictment had alleged, federal prosecutors charged on Tuesday.

title: Suspects in Kennedy Plot Extradited From Trinidad
description: Three men who face terrorism-related charges in connection with a plot to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport were extradited from Trinidad on Tuesday night.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A picture on Friday with an article about Europes carbon-trading market may have left an incorrect impression that the smog shown obscuring the Eiffel Tower was caused by emissions of carbon dioxide. While smog and carbon dioxide emissions share a common source in automotive and industrial use of fossil fuels, smog results from a combination of ground-level ozone and hydrocarbon particulates, not from carbon dioxide.

title: Britain: Ad Companys Sales Growth Slows
description: The WPP Group, an advertising company, said sales growth slowed in the first five months of the year as business in Western Europe continued to lag behind other regions. Sales excluding acquisitions and currency swings climbed 4.5 percent, WPP said. On that basis a year earlier, sales grew 5.2 percent, the company said at the time. Advertising spending in Western Europe has been hurt as soaring energy prices sapped households buying power and companies lowered marketing expenses. WPP said sales in Continental Europe had grown less than in Asia, Latin America, Africa and Eastern Europe. Stock in WPP, which is based in London, fell 3.7 percent.

title: U.S. to Take North Korea Off Terror List
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government announced on Thursday that North Korea will hand over a declaration of its nuclear program and that, if the information is verified to be accurate, the United States would then remove North Korea from a list of state sponsors of terrorism and end some economic sanctions against it.

title: No. 1 Faux Pas in Washington? Candor, Perhaps
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  It was the journalist Michael Kinsley who changed Washingtons understanding of gaffes with his observation that they occur not when people lie, but when they say what they really think.

title: Audit Says Follow-Up on Buildings Is Lacking
description: The citys Department of Buildings, which has already been the object of intense scrutiny over fatal construction accidents and accusations of corruption, is facing more criticism.

title: An Honor That Bush Is Unlikely to Embrace
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Reagan has his highways. Lincoln has his memorial. Washington has the capital (and a state, too). But President Bush may soon be the sole president to have a memorial named after him that you can contribute to from the bathroom.

title: As the Levees Fail, Time for Tough Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Awarded Contract, Unaware of Dealers Past
description: WASHINGTON  When the Army last year awarded a contract worth up to nearly $300 million to a tiny Miami Beach munitions dealer to supply ammunition to Afghanistans security forces, it overlooked a very checkered past.

title: The Pulse of Summer: Blender Drinks Are Back
description: YOU may regard the electric blender as a helpful household appliance. For your bartender, it is a tool straight from the devil.

title: Richard J. Koke, Visionary Curator of New Yorks History, Dies at 91
description: Richard J. Koke, who as curator of the New-York Historical Society for nearly 40 years organized much of the institutions transformation from a repository of documents and artworks into a space where visitors come face to face with relics of New York City and its place in American history, died on May 28 in Plattsburgh, N.Y. He was 91 and lived in Peru, N.Y.

title: Revival of 70s Play
description: Ntozake Shanges play For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf ran on Broadway in 1976 and toured the country. Now Whoopi Goldberg is bringing a new version, with added material written by Ms. Shange, to Circle in the Square Theater. Choreographed by Hinton Battle and directed by Shirley Jo Finney, For Colored Girls is scheduled to open in September with the Grammy-winning singer-songwriter India.Arie.

title: A Love Without End in a World Beyond Time
description: American Ballet Theaters production of La Bayadre, choreographed by Natalia Makarova, can leave you feeling as if youve stumbled, perhaps after a few drinks, onto a dusty old movie set. Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom comes to mind, though no one in the ballet, alas, has his still-beating heart pulled from his chest.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Tuesday about the use of antipsychotic drugs in dementia patients misspelled the names of two drugs in a different class, sometimes used to treat the symptoms of Alzheimers and Parkinsons diseases. They are Exelon and Namenda, not Exalon and Menamda.

title: Service From Google Gives Crucial Data to Ad Buyers
description: In announcing a new service for media buyers on Tuesday, Google said that its Ad Planner was meant to make life easier for the people whose job it is to identify Web sites where their clients messages will have the most impact.

description: AMMAN, Jordan

description: WHAT is it about root beer?
