title: Sonny Okosuns, 61, Musician With Message, Is Dead
description: Sonny Okosuns, a Nigerian singer and musician who achieved international stature by aiming his music  a catchy, rock-inflected cocktail of funk, reggae, Afrobeat and more  at human-rights abuses, died on May 24 in Washington. He was 61.

title: Lottery Numbers
What You Get for ... $1 Million
description: Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Auctions Are Aiding Sales in a Weakened Market
description: It has been 15 years since real estate auctions held by property developers have been commonplace, but in the current torpid real estate market, theyre starting to re-emerge in cities throughout the country.

title: Illinois to Sue Countrywide
description: The Illinois attorney general is suing Countrywide Financial, the troubled mortgage lender, and Angelo R. Mozilo, its chief executive, contending that the company and its executives defrauded borrowers in the state by selling them costly and defective loans that quickly went into foreclosure.

title: More German Troops to Afghanistan
description: BERLIN  Under pressure from NATO, Germany announced Tuesday that it would increase the number of soldiers available for duty in Afghanistan by almost one-third to 4,500, but that it would maintain its policy of keeping the bulk of them away from the relatively violent southern provinces.

title: Smoke at Post Office
description: Firefighters responded on Tuesday night to reports of smoke coming out of the James A. Farley Post Office building, on Eighth Avenue across from Madison Square Garden.

title: A Hockey Team Built on Showmanship Is Sidelined Indefinitely
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Looking back on the whole marvelous caper, the high point was not so much the playoff runs or the bewildered crowds or even all those underdressed Texas sweethearts shivering around the hockey rink glass. No, the high point was probably Guaranteed Fight Night.

title: Medicare Savings vs. the Lobbyists
description: To cut costs and reduce fraud in one corner of the sprawling Medicare program, Congress called for competitive bidding on medical equipment that is provided to elderly and disabled Americans and set a sensible schedule for phasing in the program. Demonstration projects were held, the results looked promising, and last year Medicare received competitive bids from companies to supply equipment in 10 metropolitan areas.

title: Congress Looks for a Culprit for Rising Oil Prices
description: With Americans growing angrier by the day about high gasoline prices, nobody can accuse Congress of turning a deaf ear.

title: White House Refused to Open Pollutants E-Mail
description: The White House in December refused to accept the Environmental Protection Agencys conclusion that greenhouse gases are pollutants that must be controlled, telling agency officials that an e-mail message containing the document would not be opened, senior E.P.A. officials said last week.

title: Citigroup Considers Repealing a Pledge, and the Slogan With It
description: LAST year Citigroup made a promise to millions of people who flex its credit cards: A deal is a deal. The slogan was used to trumpet an announcement that the financial giant would no longer reserve the right to raise interest rates on cards at any time, for any reason.

title: Pirates Pound Yankees With 19 Hits
description: PITTSBURGH  Joe Girardi tries hard to stay optimistic and project confidence in all of his players. But there are games that try him, and Tuesdays was one of them.

title: Wright Accepts the Order to Take a Night Off
description: David Wrights first game on the bench this season proved to be the perfect night for some time off.

description: International

title: Woods Has Successful Surgery
description: Reconstructive surgery to repair a torn anterior cruciate ligament in Tiger Woodss left knee was successful and the long-term prognosis is for a full recovery, one of Woodss doctors who performed the operation said Tuesday after the procedure in Park City, Utah.

title: Longtime Art in America Editor Steps Down
description: After more than three decades as the editor of Art in America magazine, Elizabeth C. Baker, a powerful voice in the contemporary-art world, is stepping down, the magazine said on Tuesday. The change comes shortly after a shake-up in the magazines ownership. Peter M. Brant, a newsprint magnate and art collector, took over Brant Publications, the magazines publisher, in January after buying out the 50 percent stake owned by his former wife, Sandra Brant. Mr. Brant appointed Fabien Baron and Glenn OBrien as joint editorial directors of Art in America and the companys two other publications, Interview and The Magazine Antiques. Ms. Baker, known as Betsy, took over the magazine in 1974. Under her leadership Art in America grew from a bimonthly publication with a circulation of around 45,000 to a monthly with a circulation of more than 75,000, featuring the writing of many influential critics. Marcia E. Vetrocq, who joined Art in America in 1998 as a senior editor, will take over as editor. Ms. Baker will become editor at large in charge of special projects, which will include book publishing and Web site development.

title: South Korea: Tougher Line on Protests
description: President Lee Myung-bak, trying to reassert his authority after weeks of demonstrations against his decision in April to resume imports of American beef, said his government would not tolerate further violent protests. The government must deal sternly with illegal and violent protests, as well as rallies that challenge the states system, Mr. Lee said at a cabinet meeting. His comments contrasted with the low-key, apologetic stance he had taken in recent weeks. The demonstrations led Mr. Lee, who took office in late February, to ask Washington to revise the original agreement on beef. In a new accord unveiled on Saturday, the United States agreed to export beef only from cattle younger than 30 months, to allay South Koreans fears of mad cow disease. Protest organizers vowed to keep rallying until Mr. Lee agreed to a complete renegotiation of the pact.

title: Diabetes Cases Increase 15 Percent in 2 Years
description: The number of Americans with diabetes increased by 15 percent in two years to 24 million, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. About 8 percent of the population now has the disease, mainly Type 2 diabetes, which is linked to obesity and sedentary living, the agency said in a report using data from 2007. A quarter of people ages 60 and older had diabetes, the agency said. The number of people worldwide with diabetes will double to 366 million by 2030, according to the World Health Organization, which calls the disease an epidemic. Most people with diabetes have resistance to insulin, which the body uses to convert blood sugar to energy. The C.D.C. report was its first update of the prevalence of diabetes since 2005, when it reported that about 21 million Americans had the disease.

title: The Petro-Manipulators
description: Anyone who lived on the West Coast during the phony energy crisis of 2000 and 2001 cannot help thinking of Texas and two of its worst products  Enron and a politician not named George Bush  as gas creeps up toward $5 a gallon this summer.   What happened during the great energy heist at the start of the new century was like an extended bad dream, part "Twilight Zone" and part "Chinatown," the extraordinary 1974 film about water manipulation and long-buried secrets.   The price of energy spiked  tenfold, a hundredfold  despite low demand. Californians became the most efficient users of power in the nation, and still suffered through dozens of rolling blackouts. None of it added up.   And into the worst energy crisis since the Arab oil embargo of 1973 came Vice President Dick Cheney, blasting conservation as a sissy virtue and saying the nation needed to build a new power plant every week for the next 20 years.   The administration's neglect was breathtaking, a harbinger of what was to come when a natural disaster, Hurricane Katrina, would do to Louisiana what a man-made disaster had done to California. We now know, of course, that the problem eight years ago was caused by manipulation by Enron and other speculators who gamed a faulty system, sticking it to Grandma Millie while laughing at how easy it was to rob 40 million people.   Now consider the present dilemma: oil doubling over the last year, gas at $4.50 a gallon in places and the oversized influence of speculators in a market where few used to tread. Big investors are free to run up oil futures contracts thanks in part to former Senator Phil Gramm. He is the Texas Republican who co-sponsored the so-called Enron loophole in 2000 at the behest of what was later found to be one of the nation's biggest criminal enterprises.   Enron may be gone, but its legacy lingers in the work done by politicians who did its bidding. And Gramm, who once told corporate contributors, "I have the most reliable friend you can have in American politics, and that's ready money," is now the chief economic adviser to Senator John McCain.   Gramm's role in helping to unleash energy speculators has been well-documented in recent months, and Senator Barack Obama has made an issue of it. Both Obama and McCain have called for closing the loophole. But just how big a role that kind of global gambling plays in the overheated commodities market is only now coming to light.   Testifying before the Senate on Wednesday, the ever-knowledgeable Daniel Yergin blamed speculation for part of the run-up. Yergin, an author and the chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, pointed to numerous other causes, as have other experts.  But he also noted that 2007 may have been the peak year for oil demand in the United States. In other words, the world's largest energy consumer has reached the height of its gluttony, and will be using less oil from here on out.   Keep that in mind when thinking of the parallel to California. Less demand from the biggest consumer, yet record high prices. Why? Yes, tight supply during the end stages of the 200-year reign of fossil fuels, higher use by China and India, and global troubles all contribute to the bloat of oil prices.   But market manipulation seems obvious.  Over the last five years, investment in index funds tied to commodities like energy and food has gone from $13 billion to $260 billion. At the same time, the prices of those commodities have risen 200 percent.   Take away the excess speculators who are in the market purely for the ride, and oil prices could drop by half. That's the view of Michael W. Masters, a hedge fund manager who's been advising Congress this year.   "There are no lines at the gas pumps and there is plenty of food on the shelves," said Masters, whose testimony has been widely discussed in financial circles but rarely in the political realm. What has changed, he said, is the presence of big speculators making futures bets.  "If Wall Street concocted a scheme whereby investors bought large amounts of pharmaceutical drugs and medical devices in order to profit from the resulting increase in price, making these essential items unaffordable to sick and dying people, society would be justly outraged," he said.   This testimony came before a committee chaired by Senator Joseph Lieberman, the former Democratic vice presidential candidate who is now one of John McCain's biggest boosters. If you want to see the effects of McCain's top financial adviser, look no further than the hearing run by McCain's top ally in the Senate.   With five months to go, it looks like energy will dominate the presidential campaign. Nutty ideas will abound, from the gas tax holiday to $300 million prizes for wonder batteries.   And just as in California eight years ago, the oil industry's most devoted politicians will use this troubled time to advance a tired agenda  more drilling for the last of the nation's oil, in distant, fragile corners of the earth.   If nothing else, we should remember the lesson from that debacle: When something smells this bad, look for rotten fish as well.

title: Hermitage Says to Turn It Down
description: Ears arent the only items that may suffer from blaring rock music. The preliminary results of a Russian study by scientists at the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg found that rock concerts by the Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney and others in the adjacent Winter Square have affected their collections over the past three years, The Independent of London reported. The research, now being examined by the Grabar Art Restoration Institute in Moscow, showed that every 10 concerts above 82 decibels added an extra year to the age of a work because of vibrations. After a 2004 McCartney concert shook the windows of the Hermitage, the museum asked the Stones last year to keep the sound level below 85 decibels to protect works by the likes of Czanne and Matisse in the palaces nearby wings.

title: A Spanish-Modern Mashup in Los Angeles
description: WHEN it comes to architecture, Los Angeles can sometimes seem like a battlefield of styles. Mixed into the mishmash of nondescript buildings that dominate the city are a large number of houses with distinct characters and little apparent interest in getting along  in particular the bright white Spanish-style villas that overtook the town early last century, and the earnest early Modernist boxes that followed a decade or so later. These two domestic forms have been dueling it out for nearly a century.

title: Activists Warned on Olympic Protests
description: SHANGHAI  In the latest sign of efforts to prevent dissent during the Beijing Olympics, political activists in Shanghai say they have been warned against expressing their opinions, speaking with foreigners or visiting Beijing until after the Games.

title: Brooklyn Blog Helps Lead to Drug Raid
description: Most neighborhoods in Brooklyn have at least one blog  and in some places, there seems to be one in every house, every bedroom  but not many read like BayRidgeTalk.com, where the subjects over the last year or two veered away from apartment sales and plumbing tips and block parties and sounded more like rat-a-tat police reports.

title: Another Anchor Fired
description: Six months ago KYW-TV, the CBS affiliate in Philadelphia, fired its newscaster Alycia Lane, above with her former co-anchor, Larry Mendte, after she was arrested for reportedly hitting a New York City police officer. Now the station has dismissed Mr. Mendte, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The F.B.I. has been investigating Mr. Mendte, seizing his computer to determine if he illegally broke into Ms. Lanes e-mail account and forwarded its contents to news organizations. A statement from KYW said that Mr. Mendtes termination was based on an independent investigation conducted by CBS.

title: Why Obama Should Visit a Mosque
description: ISTANBUL

title: Mississippis Misplaced Priorities
description: Congress is finally asking hard questions about Mississippis handling of $5 billion in emergency federal aid that was supposed to help victims of Hurricane Katrina.

title: A Hedge Fund and Its Nonprofit Twin
description: Christopher Cooper-Hohn and his wife, Jamie, follow a simple economic formula: he makes money, and she gives it away.

title: State Bill Expands Pool of Possible 9/11 Benefit Recipients
description: Even as New York City battles thousands of ground zero workers over their health claims in federal court, New York State is making more workers eligible for health care benefits.

title: Zimbabweans Make Plea for Help as Runoff Nears
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  As Zimbabwes neighbors urged it to postpone this weeks presidential runoff, hundreds of beaten, newly homeless Zimbabweans gathered Wednesday outside the South African Embassy here in a desperate bid for help during the electoral crisis.

title: Snuggling Up to the Bundlers
description: In his self-serving retreat from the spending restraints of public financing, Senator Barack Obama hailed his formidable Internet army of small donors as a new kind of politics. Maybe so. But just in case, the senator is not about to neglect the old politics of special-interest money bundlers in his presidential campaign.

title: New York Grit, With Flat-Screen TVs
description: The red brick building at 113 Jane Street in the West Village, with its lighthouselike corner tower and storied history (it sheltered the surviving crew of the Titanic), is about to get a new life  in stages.

title: A Warehouse Sale for Italian Luxury Linens
description: Nancy Koltes at Home, a company that sells Italian cotton bed and bath linens, will have its first warehouse sale starting July 10. Selected items, reduced 25 to 80 percent, include Dot Embroidery shams (about $50, marked down from $68), left, and duvets ($130 in full/queen size, reduced from $175); Hotel sheet sets ($150 in queen size, marked down from $300); and Ikebana bath sheets with floral embroidery ($69, reduced from $138). Through Aug. 10 at Nancy Koltes at Home, 31 Spring Street (Mott Street), (212) 219-2271 or nancykoltesathome.com.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in the Currents column last Thursday about a new line of furniture from Hida Sangyo, a Japanese company, misstated the name and price of the chair pictured. It is called Piave, not Po, and it sells for $870, not $770.

title: Running Into the Past
description: PORTLAND - Twenty-eight years ago, when the United States Olympic track and field trials were last held at Hayward Field on the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, earning one of the three slots on the American team was the equivalent of a mayoral candidate in Baltimore winning the Democratic primary. Just as the victorious politician was a shoo-in in the general election, the winning athlete had already proved herself among the best in the world. Now that the trials have returned to Eugene, by contrast, America has long since ceded domination of distance running to the Africans. And in events where American athletes still flourish -- the sprints and jumps -- doping has all but destroyed public confidence. In 2008, most elite American track-and-field performers are thrilled to get to the point where theyre suspected of juicing.

title: Sorenstam Welcomes All Aboard at the Open
description: EDINA, Minn.  Finding Annika Sorenstam on the back nine at Interlachen Country Club is a snap. Just look for the largest crowd.

title: Impasse in India on Nuclear Pact With the U.S.
description: NEW DELHI  Indias governing party and its communist allies failed again to agree on the terms of a nuclear agreement with the United States on Wednesday, dimming prospects for the deal.

title: Sacred Songs Sell, Drawing Attention to Their Source
description: HEILIGENKREUZ, Austria  As noon draws near, the monks glide into the church, their white cowls billowing behind them. They line up in silence, facing each other in long choir stalls. Wood carvings of saints peer down on them from the austere Romanesque nave.

title: Down With Helvetica: Design Your Own Font
description: WHEN Spike Gjerde started to build a new restaurant in an old mill in Baltimore, he did not want a slick menu with crisp, perfect letters. Were all totally about salvage and reuse, he said. The menu had to reflect the restaurants goal: presenting local ingredients in a rough-hewn complex that once cast the 36-inch-wide columns that support the dome of the United States Capitol.

title: For One Night in Central Park, Two Orchestras for the Price of None
description: The Metropolitan Opera may have dropped its commitment to presenting a concert tour of parks throughout the boroughs of New York this summer. But not the New York Philharmonic, which began its 43rd season of these popular free programs with a concert on Tuesday night on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

title: Huge Meteor Strike Explains Marss Shape, Reports Say
description: The lopsided shape of Mars may well be a result of a cataclysmic impact of a Pluto-size meteor billions of years ago, three teams of scientists are reporting. That would suggest that the lowlands of Marss northern hemisphere are a single gigantic impact crater, the largest crater in the solar system.

title: Fed Shifts Its Concern to Inflation
description: The Federal Reserves policy makers ratcheted up their worries about inflation on Wednesday without abandoning their view that the American economy is weak.

title: Taking Lessons, and Confidence, From the Water
description: She had rowed a boat, in the East River. She had learned to swim. She had eaten an oyster; it was gross, yes, but it was a challenge, and she had met that challenge. And now, in a final rite of passage, she was at the helm of the Lettie G. Howard, the historic 125-foot schooner that is her schools classroom-on-the-Hudson.

title: Suggested Read: The Rookie Life
description: Itll be years before we can declare with full-throated authority the winners and losers of tonights draft, yet one thing is already certain: the lives of the lottery picks will change fully and immediately. Basketball executives can only hope that their draft pick manages the transition as well as Amare Stoudemire, whose background didnt exactly portend smooth sailing. Stoudemire entered the 2002 draft straight out of high school (he attended a handful of them) and with a mom who had been in and out of jail.

title: In Milan, All Masculinity, No Pretense
description: MILAN

title: The Ball Bounces Ivanovics Way
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It has been a heady month for Ana Ivanovic, who rose to No. 1 and won her first Grand Slam singles title at the French Open. But an unseeded Frenchwoman, Nathalie Dechy, came within an inch or two of ruining Ivanovics Wimbledon on Wednesday before the Serbian star prevailed, 6-7 (2), 7-6 (3), 10-8.

title: Gene Testing Questioned by Regulators
description: Regulators are cracking down on companies that sell genetic tests directly to consumers, threatening to crimp the growth of one of the hottest sectors of the biotechnology industry.

title: Push in Bronx for H.I.V. Test for All
description: The New York City health department plans to announce on Thursday an ambitious three-year effort to give an H.I.V. test to every adult living in the Bronx, which has a far higher death rate from AIDS than any other borough. The campaign will begin with a push to make the voluntary testing routine in emergency rooms and storefront clinics, where city officials say that cumbersome consent procedures required by state law have deterred doctors from offering the tests.

title: Corrections
description: A bibliographical note on Wednesday with the Books of The Times review, about a translation of Albert Camuss notebooks, misstated part of the title and the years the notebooks cover. The title is Notebooks 1951-1959, not 1951-58.

title: Afghans See Pakistan Role in Karzai Plot
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government for the first time publicly accused the Pakistani intelligence service on Wednesday of organizing the failed plot to assassinate President Hamid Karzai at a parade in Kabul in April.

title: Coming Soon to YouTube: My Face-Lift
description: LAST September, Michelle Wilder left Dr. Emil W. Chynn of Park Avenue Laser armed with the usual postoperative fare: eyedrops, sunglasses and a pair of prescription-free contact lenses. And oh, yes: a DVD of her Lasek surgery, so she could experience from the confines of her own home the joy of watching the doctor scrape her eyeballs.

title: Safin Ousts Third-Seeded Djokovic
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Did Marat Safin really once hate grass-court tennis with all his Russian soul?

title: A Forecast of Violence in a Neighbor of Chechnya
description: MOSCOW  Though violence in Chechnya has decreased markedly in recent years, fighting between Muslim insurgents and Russian troops threatens to engulf a neighboring region, a human rights group said in a report released Wednesday.

title: Colorful and Well Connected, a Laptop That Stands Out
description: Its summer, so why shouldnt ones laptop match ones hot-pink bikini? Dells Studio line comes in seven colors and offers some impressive computing power inside.

title: Provence in a Plant: Just Inhale
description: AN herb that smells as good as lavender simply has to be grown, even though its not a native plant. I feel a little guilty saying this, because lately I have been so vigilant about planting natives, to feed the insects and birds that evolved with them. But lavender, which hails from the Mediterranean  as do oregano, bay, thyme, rosemary and so many other herbs  is one of those fragrant plants that settle in your soul.

title: United We Campaign
description: Hillary Clinton is so united!

title: City Unveils Final Plan on First Slice of the High Line
description: City officials and the Friends of the High Line presented the final design on Wednesday for the first phase of the High Line, the $170 million park that is under construction on the West Side of Manhattan and has been called one of New York Citys more distinctive public projects.

title: Hundreds Seized in Sweep Against Child Prostitution
description: Twenty-one sexually exploited children have been saved from the streets, and 389 people arrested on charges of trafficking children for prostitution, in what the Federal Bureau of Investigation calls the largest such multistate sweep ever, officials said Wednesday.

title: The Right Mulch for Any Occasion
description: Q. I want to add mulch to my flower beds, but Im confused by all the choices. What kind is best?

title: Exploring What Lies Beyond Manifest Destiny
description: Confined at its birth to the area east of the Mississippi River, by 1867 the United States reached all the way to the Bering Strait. Never has a nation grown so large so quickly.

title: Home and Garden Advice, and a Little Music Besides
description: While Amazons Kindle seems to have grabbed the most attention lately, there are plenty of electronic book readers out there that are worth a quick look  or read.

title: Much Left Undone, Again, as Session Ends in Albany
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson took one more chance this week to distance himself from the strategy of his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, the man he ran alongside nearly two years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about The Shack, a Christian-themed novel by William P. Young that has become a surprise best seller, misidentified a Web site of the publisher, Windblown Media, where the book can be purchased. It is theshackbook.com.

title: Hollywood Braces for an Actors Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  Labor unrest continues to dominate the landscape in Hollywood, and the possibility of a strike by actors has large movie studios planning to shut down production after Monday and has television studios rushing to complete episodes of series scheduled to return in the fall or January.

title: Donaghy Is Not Responsible for Costs of N.B.A.s Inquiry
description: A federal judge said Wednesday that the disgraced referee Tim Donaghy will most likely not have to reimburse the N.B.A. for the cost of its internal investigation into betting by referees.

title: Hoboken, an Economic Success That Cant Pass a Budget
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Europe Plans New Push to Cut Mobile Charges
description: BERLIN  The European Commission, having capped roaming fees on international mobile phone calls, plans a new move to lower cellphone charges that could result in even greater savings for European consumers.

title: Girl Gone Wild, Idaho Style
description: MaryJane Butters (born Mary Jane) was once a single mother of two and a forest ranger, among other tough jobs. She is now an organic farmer, a grandmother and an activist, living on a farm in Northern Idaho.

title: Mind the Gap: A Button Too Far
description: GOLDILOCKS had nothing on Tommy Fazio.

title: Low Maintenance, and Its a Bargain
description: When Jeremy Cole, a London designer, was last interviewed in this section, he had just introduced a gold version of his Aloe lamps, which ranged in price from $4,430 to $37,500.

title: Rhythm in His Hips, Technology on His Mind
description: Gilberto Gils show at the Nokia Theater on Tuesday night started with his bands arrangement of the famous Nokia cellphone ring tone. If corporate mediation of cultural events puts you on edge, hearing that particular melody in that particular place might make you especially nervous.

title: Obama and Clinton in Talks to Unify Party
description: WASHINGTON  With the help of one of Washingtons best-connected lawyers, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are negotiating a thicket of complicated issues, like how to repay Mrs. Clintons campaign debt and her role at the Democratic convention. The talks come as they try to leave behind their intense rivalry and work out a plan to cooperate this fall.

title: In Zimbabwe, Doctors Document the Horror
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Just Another Jelly Bean
description: Easter may be long gone, but the Jelly Belly Candy Company is still producing jelly beans, 300,000 pounds a day.

title: Manager Moves on After Ejection
description: A day after being ejected from Tuesdays game by the home plate umpire, Brian Runge, during a dispute about balls and strikes, Jerry Manuel said he was not carrying any grudges.

title: Suit Claims a Warhol Is Not, Well, a Warhol
description: The title, 315 Johns, sounds less like the name of an artwork than a headline describing a prostitution bust. But in the second volume of the catalogue raisonn enumerating the works of Andy Warhol, it is listed as a 1967 Warhol creation: a series of silk-screens made from a photograph of the artist John Chamberlain and arranged in a heroic grid.

title: Close by: Another World
description: The Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park has seen better days. Erected in 1923 by the philanthropist Elkan Naumburg, who had presented free symphonic concerts in the park since 1905, the handsome limestone structure has fallen into neglect. After repairing the half-dome roof in 2005, the Parks Department has gone no further to restore this once vital landmark to its former elegance.

title: Anheuser to Reject InBev Offer
description: The board of Anheuser-Busch is planning to reject this week an unsolicited $46.4 billion takeover bid from InBev, a rival brewery based in Belgium, people close to the American company said on Wednesday.

title: Correction: An Olympic Cyclists Levelheaded Advice
description: An article last Thursday about training advice from Christian Vande Velde, an Olympic cyclist, referred incorrectly to the technique he uses during five-minute sequences in which he tries to push his pedals as hard as possible while the wheels turn slowly. He drops into what is known as a big gear, not a low gear.

title: Lincoln Trove to Move
description: One of the largest museums dedicated to Abraham Lincoln is closing its doors on Monday and giving away its $20 million collection, The Civil War News reported. The Lincoln Museum collection in Fort Wayne, Ind., includes more than 18,000 books and pamphlets; 7,000 prints; 5,000 photographs; 350 documents signed by Lincoln, including one of 13 copies of the 13th Amendment he signed; and thousands of newspaper clippings and Lincoln-related items. The Lincoln Financial Foundation, which runs the museums, intends to donate the collection to one or more of the nations major nonprofit institutions specializing in Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War, and to digitize documents to make them more accessible for next years Lincoln Bicentennial, a spokesman said. The Library of Congress, the National Museum of American History, Fords Theater and President Lincolns Cottage have formed a partnership to try to buy the collection, The Washington Post reported.

title: Ex-Big Board Chairman Wins Round in Pay Fight
description: On Wall Street, there are stars that fade and stars that fight. Richard A. Grasso is one of the latter.

title: Weighing New Candidates for Fossellas House Seat
description: Following the death of their candidate for Congress, Republican leaders on Staten Island and in Brooklyn are turning their attention in earnest  once again  to finding potential candidates to run for the seat. And they say they will probably reach a decision by the weekend.

title: Pakistani Taliban Say They Killed 28 Men From Peace Group
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The bodies of 28 members of a government-sponsored peace committee were found dumped on a road near the tribal area of South Waziristan on Wednesday, Pakistan officials said. The Pakistani Taliban said the men were killed because they supported the government, according to a Taliban statement made to a local journalist.

title: Judge Rejects Bid to Let Police Check Immigration Status
description: LOS ANGELES  A Superior Court judge on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit seeking to end a longstanding police policy that prohibits officers from initiating contact with people for the sole purpose of learning their immigration status.

title: Lehrer Back on Camera
description: Jim Lehrer plans to return to the anchor desk at The NewsHour on PBS on Thursday, after being absent since late April while recuperating from aortic valve replacement surgery. The NewsHour said Mr. Lehrer, 74, planned to anchor the nightly newscast two or three evenings a week before eventually returning to a full-time schedule. He is also planning to anchor PBSs live coverage of the Democratic and Republican conventions later in the summer. Mr. Lehrer has been an anchor on NewsHour and its predecessor, The MacNeil/Lehrer Report, since 1975.

title: N.B.A. Draft Puts Mayo in Customary Spotlight
description: O. J. Mayo has been a magnet for publicity and controversy since age 14, so it seems only natural that he is now a central figure in what may be the N.B.A.s wildest draft night in years.

title: The Spanish Connection: Dealing in Charm or Fire
description: The allusions flew fast and furious at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, as Ballet Biarritz performed two works by its director, Thierry Malandain. The company is the final feature of the French Collection festival, but  mon Dieu!  Mr. Malandains gaze is on Spain in both pieces.

title: 8 Civilians Killed in 2 Disputed Attacks, Iraq Says
description: BAGHDAD  American soldiers fatally shot three Iraqi bank employees Wednesday as their car passed a convoy near Baghdad International Airport, according to an Interior Ministry official and Yarmouk Hospital, where the bodies were brought.

title: More Delays for Cameras in Subways
description: Aging fiber-optic cable in Brooklyn and Queens has become the latest obstacle to a planned high-tech system of surveillance cameras meant to safeguard the subway and commuter railroads, according to Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials.

title: Extra Work Pays Off for Manuel and Mets
description: Jerry Manuel, a week into his stint as the Mets interim manager, continued searching Wednesday for some trick, some ploy to snap his sluggish team out of its funk. Three hours before the Mets tried to keep the Seattle Mariners, the worst team in baseball, from sweeping them at home, he ordered his players to take stretching exercises as a team.

title: New G.O.P. Leader Says Mayor Has Pledged Support
description: ALBANY  The State Legislatures newly installed Republican leader said on Wednesday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would back the Republican Partys efforts to defend its thin majority in the State Senate.

title: Sentences Reduced for Adelphia Founder and Son
description: The prison sentences of John J. Rigas, the founder of Adelphia Communications, and his son Timothy were reduced by three years each on Tuesday after an appeals court overturned a count of bank fraud.

title: In Pittsburgh, Posada Takes in All Things Clemente
description: PITTSBURGH  Jorge Posada is a five-time All-Star, but this week he is an awestruck fan. The Yankees are playing in Pittsburgh, where Roberto Clemente starred for the Pirates, and Clemente is a hero to Posada.

title: Books, Not Bombs
description: AMMAN, Jordan

title: Leonid Hurwicz, Nobel Economist, Dies at 90
description: Leonid Hurwicz, who shared the Nobel Prize in economics last year for his work on mechanism design theory, which helps explain the interaction among individuals, markets and institutions, died Tuesday. He was 90 and lived in Minneapolis.

title: From Campaign 2.0 to Governing 2.0
description: Much has been made this year of how the presidential candidates have expanded their use of the Internet, particularly for raising money, organizing supporters and sharing videos.

title: Profit Expands for BlackBerry Maker
description: OTTAWA  Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, said on Wednesday that its first quarter profit was more than double that of last year. But the result fell short of analysts estimates, causing the companys shares to fall in after-hours trading.

title: Soccer and N.B.A. Stars Play for Kicks and a Good Cause
description: Of course Baron Davis had played soccer before  he was in seventh grade at the time. And of course he had a game plan for Wednesday nights pickup soccer match.

title: Justices Cut Damages Award in Exxon Valdez Spill
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday reduced what had once been a $5 billion punitive damages award against ExxonMobil to about $500 million. The ruling essentially concluded a legal saga that started when the Exxon Valdez, a supertanker, struck a reef and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Prince William Sound in Alaska in 1989.

title: At a Last Party, Real Estate Claims the Night
description: LAST week, a memorial of sorts was held in the former New York home of Pat and William F. Buckley Jr.

title: When Your Camera Knows Where You Are
description: Any sufficiently advanced memory card, Arthur C. Clarke once didnt write, is indistinguishable from magic.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Death Penalty for Child Rape
description: WASHINGTON  The death penalty is unconstitutional as a punishment for the rape of a child, a sharply divided Supreme Court ruled Wednesday.

title: Lee Is Focus of Trade Talk by the Knicks
description: After early speculation that the Knicks might move up in Thursdays draft, the latest indications are that the team is in discussions to move down.

title: House Votes to Expand Civil Rights for Disabled
description: WASHINGTON  The House passed a major civil rights bill on Wednesday that would expand protections for people with disabilities and overturn several Supreme Court decisions issued in the last decade.

title: In Alaska, Rage and Sorrow Over Decision
description: When the Exxon Valdez ran aground in 1989, Andrew Wills was a successful herring fisherman in Alaska and the owner of three canneries.

title: Turkey Scores Late Again, but Not Late Enough
description: BASEL, Switzerland  This time, when it counted most, Turkey made its late comeback a little too early.

title: Castillos Contract Looms Over Mets
description: The $25 million second baseman, Luis Castillo, has the tools of his trade sitting on a chair in front of his Mets locker. There is a jar of heating ointment, an Ace bandage, a roll of black tape, a roll of white tape and a pair of surgical gloves. Castillo uses those materials to treat and wrap his injured left leg.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on May 20 about the arrest of a foster mother in Harlem accused of accidentally killing a 6-year-old girl by placing a fentanyl pain patch on her neck referred incompletely to the basis for determining dosage and referred incorrectly to fentanyls effect on respiratory function. Along with the patients weight, the dosage is generally based on his or her tolerance to opiates and body fat content. Slowed breathing is a side effect of the drug, not the mechanism by which it relieves pain. This correction was delayed for research.

title: Dancer on the Block
description: When the Impressionist and modern art auctions continued in London on Wednesday night at Sothebys, it was a far more modest affair than Christies blockbuster auction the previous evening, which saw a record price of $80.4 million for one of Monets late waterlilies. Of the 55 works offered Wednesday, the standout was probably Dancer, right, a 1915 painting by Gino Severini. Four telephone bidders vied for the painting, and it ended up selling to one for $29.6 million, far above the high estimate of $19.8 million and a record at auction for the artist. The previous record for a Severini, $3.6 million, was set in 1990 at Sothebys in New York for Sea=Dancer. The painting sold Wednesday dates from the end of Mr. Severinis Futurist period and was later acquired by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, where it hung from 1944 until 1988, when it was deaccessioned. An unidentified collector who had owned the painting ever since was the seller.

title: Laptop Searches in Airports Draw Fire at Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Advocacy groups and some legal experts told Congress on Wednesday that it was unreasonable for federal officials to search the laptops of United States citizens when they re-enter the country from traveling abroad.

title: Complaints Against New York Judges Reach a High, but Fewer Merit Investigations
description: A record number of complaints were filed against New York State judges in 2007, according to a report by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. But the number of complaints that warranted a full investigation during that time was lower than it had been in a decade, the report said.

title: Working Alone in a Group
description: MY book proposal was not writing itself. It was half-done, and the stack of research in the corner was growing tall enough to topple. Because it was the only project, among several, without a deadline, it always seemed to fall off the to-do list entirely.

title: Sales of New Homes Decline a Fifth Time in Six Months
description: Sales of new homes fell again in May, the fifth decline in six months, as buyers stayed on the sidelines despite lower prices.

title: Strong Economy and Labor Shortages Are Luring Polish Immigrants Back Home
description: WARSAW  For a long time, Germany has been good to Katarzyna, a 28-year-old Polish woman who works in a pharmacy in Frankfurt during the day and cleans houses in the evenings.

title: MasterCard Will Pay $1.8 Billion to American Express
description: MasterCard Worldwide agreed on Wednesday to pay $1.8 billion to its credit card rival American Express to settle claims related to a 2004 antitrust lawsuit.

title: Rain Heightens Worries Along the Mississippi
description: CLARKSVILLE, Mo.  A storm that federal forecasters had expected would quietly pass through here instead brought about six inches of rain in places along the Mississippi River overnight Tuesday, dashing expectations that the worst of the flooding was over.

title: Acquittal in Case of Winehouses Husband
description: Blake Fielder-Civil, the husband of the singer Amy Winehouse, got into a barroom fight in 2006 and beat up a pub manager, James King. Though he has admitted he offered Mr. King $400,000 to keep quiet about the incident, a British court acquitted Mr. King on Wednesday of obstructing justice by taking a bribe, The Associated Press reported. Mr. King, who ended up with a broken cheekbone, said he had been intimidated into dropping assault charges. Mr. Fielder-Civil and three others face jail terms when they are sentenced.

title: Nissan and Others Add Factories in Emerging Markets
description: ORAGADAM, India  On a dusty sun-baked field, in a ceremony presided over by a chanting Brahmin priest tossing water and rice, the Japanese carmaker Nissan Motor made a bold step into the Indian auto market.

title: New iPod, New AV Cable
description: Q. I cant select the TV Out menu option on my new iPod when I have it connected to my television with an iPod video cable. Is there some other setting I need to adjust so I can play videos from my iPod on the TV screen?

title: Maryland: Mayor Speaks on Case
description: Mayor Sheila Dixon of Baltimore criticized state prosecutors and the news media in her first comments since acknowledging she had been in a relationship with a major developer whose projects she supported as City Council president. The news media have acted as judge and jury, even though she has not been charged, and the Office of the State Prosecutor has leaked information, Ms. Dixon said, but she is forbidden to respond publicly because of the two-year investigation into city spending practices. Ms. Dixon, a Democrat, issued a statement Monday confirming that she had been in a personal relationship in late 2003 and early 2004 with Ronald H. Lipscomb, a developer who owns Doracon Contracting. Prosecutors said they were investigating possible bribery, perjury and misconduct in office. The authorities raided Ms. Dixons home last week and seized numerous boxes, and a grand jury began hearing testimony this week.

title: South Korea Lifts Ban on U.S. Beef
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea lifted an import ban on American beef on Thursday, despite an overnight protest in which thousands of people rallied in central Seoul to protest the government move and the police fired water cannons and detained at least 120 protesters.

title: Study Shows Problems With Olympic-Style Tests
description: Athletes who want to cheat by injecting themselves with a performance-enhancing drug that boosts their blood cell count can do so with little risk of getting caught, a new study indicates, possibly exposing another flaw in what is regarded as the worlds toughest anti-doping program.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Michael Shernoff, a gay psychotherapist who wrote widely on the emotional toll of AIDS on gay men, misstated the diagnosis he received in 1982. Although he wrote that he learned that year that he had tested positive for the human immunodeficiency virus, a virus was not established as the cause of AIDS until 1983, and the term H.I.V. did not come into use for a few more years. His precise diagnosis in 1982 remains unclear.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the comic actress Dody Goodman misspelled the surname of the host of The Tonight Show who had her as a regular guest. He was Jack Paar, not Parr.

title: Applicant Checks May Dig Deep
description: BUYING a condo or co-op, or even renting an apartment, can be arduous, and most applicants understand that part of the process may involve being investigated by a board or a management company.

title: On-Screen Forecast: Hazy
description: If its summer on network television, somebody is probably being humiliated.

title: A Chance for the Everglades
description: The languishing effort to revive and restore the Everglades  one of the most ambitious environmental initiatives on the planet  received an unexpected and potentially spectacular boost on Tuesday when Gov. Charlie Crist announced that Florida had agreed in principle to buy 187,000 acres of farmland from the United States Sugar Corporation, the states (and the nations) largest sugar-cane producer.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about Jordans return of looted antiquities to Iraq misspelled the name of the ancient Assyrian city from which one of the most valuable pieces came. It was Nimrud, not Nimrod.

title: Tip of the Week: Previewing Search Results
description: Sometimes in your Google search results its hard to tell from just the text link and description if the Web pages have the information you actually want. The Google Preview browser extension adds a small thumbnail image of each hit on your results page to help you see what youre getting before you click the link. Versions are available for Firefox and Internet Explorer at www.googlepreview.com, and despite the name Google Preview also works with Yahoo search results.

title: Filmmaker Says Distributor Failed Him

title: Some Questions About Those Commitment Letters

InBev will now have to decide whether it will launch a consent solicitation to remove all of the Anheuser directors. This can be done at any time. Alternatively, at the request of 25% of Anheusers shareholders a special meeting of Anheuser shareholders can be held. So, InBev can also go this route and remove the Anheuser directors at the special meeting if they can get enough shareholder support for it to be called. I suspect that if InBev does attempt to remove and replace the Anheuser directors, InBev will arrange a consent solicitation rather than attempting to call a special meeting: it is quicker.

title: Q&A: Scalia's Gauntlet
description: The Supreme Court's decision today declaring the District of Columbia's ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.   Steve Wermiel is adjunct professor and associate director of the Marshall-Brennan Constitutional Literacy Project at the American University Washington College of Law.     Q. In Slate, Dahlia Lithwick refers to what she called your "rather brilliant observation" asking why none of the dissenters in today's decision cautioned the majority that it "will almost certainly cause more Americans to be killed." Can you explain more?    A. Use of that phrase is partly serious and partly flip. Justice Scalia used those words (hence the quotation marks) in a very strident dissent on June 12 when the Supreme Court ruled that Guantanamo Bay detainees have a right to go to federal court to challenge their detentions. My initial point is that it seems appropriate for the justices Scalia was criticizing in the detainees' case to throw that line back at him when he has written a decision that will facilitate the possession of handguns by individuals.  Answering on a more serious (perhaps less flip) level, whether it is individuals shooting others in self-defense or those committing crimes having easier access to weapons, it does seem likely that more people may be killed using handguns as a result of the newly declared Second Amendment right. At the very least, it seems more likely that people will die from the constitutional right to own firearms than from the constitutional right of an enemy terrorist to challenge his detention in federal court.

title: Q&A: The Ratifiers and the Second Amendment
description: The Supreme Court's decision today declaring the District of Columbia's ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.   Brian Frye, a lawyer in New York, is the author of "The Peculiar Story of United States vs. Miller," an article published in the New York University Journal of Law & Liberty, Vol. 2, 2007.  Q. What was your reaction to today's Court decision, based on what you know about the history of the Second Amendment?   A. I am not an authority on the ratification and early history of the Second Amendment, so I will refrain from commenting on the Court's opinion and dissents in that respect. That said, it does seem that the Court's opinion overemphasizes the role that personal self-defense played in ratification. It is probably true that a common-law right to own weapons for self-defense existed at ratification.   But the prefatory clause suggests that the need for collective self-defense through the militia, rather than individual self-defense, prompted ratification of the Second Amendment. Of course, it appears that the ratifiers assumed that the Constitution guarantees common-law rights as well as specifically enumerated rights. So while they may not have understood the Second Amendment right to directly guarantee the right to own weapons for self-defense, they would have understood it as consistent with that right.   Q. How do you see today's decision in the context of the last big Second Amendment case before the court, in the 1939 Miller decision, which more or less allowed states and localities to adopt gun control measures?  A. The Court affirms the D.C. Circuit's holding that the Second Amendment, under Miller, guarantees a right to own weapons "in common use at the time," which now includes handguns. I would suggest that the Miller holding is more closely tied to militia service. I suspect that a slightly more accurate characterization would be that Miller held the Second Amendment guarantees a right to own a weapon suitable for militia service, in order to ensure that members of the unorganized militia are familiar with the use of such weapons and possess then in the event militia service becomes necessary. I'm not really qualified to say what sort of  weapons are suitable for militia service, but it is certainly conceivable that long guns are suitable and handguns are not.  Q. Why do you think it has taken the Court so long -- the last decision was almost 70 years ago -- to rule on a Second Amendment case?  A. I suspect that the Court has taken a long time to hear a Second Amendment case because the constitutional validity of gun control laws was a controversial question lacking a burning need for resolution. Miller provided a workable resolution, effectively  permitting state and local gun control based on state and local preferences. Gun owners are politically powerful. Accordingly, they are rarely the target of unreasonable regulations. Perhaps the District of Columbia regulation was sufficiently unreasonable that the Court felt obliged to step in.

title: Q&A: Jack Rakove on Heller and History
description: The Supreme Court's decision today declaring the District of Columbia's ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.   Jack N. Rakove, a professor of history, American studies and political science at Stanford University, won a Pulitzer prize for "Original Meanings: Politics and Ideas in the Making of the Constitution." He was the lead author of a historians' amicus brief written in support of the District of Columbia's position.   Q. In reading the Heller decision today, what leaps out at you?   A. The two main opinions differ enormously in how they think about which elements of history help most in understanding the original meaning of the Second Amendment. Justice Scalia's opinion has remarkably little to say about the drafting of the Amendment or the constitutional debates of 1787-1789. By contrast, Justice Stevens' dissent focuses tightly on the immediate context within which the value of "a well-regulated militia" and "the right of the people to keep and bear arms" were actually discussed.   Scalia replies that "It is dubious to rely on such history to interpret a text that was widely understood to codify a pre-existing right, rather than to fashion a new one." Scalia similarly claims that "most [Americans] thought" the right was "even more important for self-defense and hunting" than it was as an antidote to the danger of a standing army. Scalia's history depends on a deep background understanding of the right that presumes its content and purpose were only slightly affected by the events of the Revolution or the distinct way in which the Militia Clauses of Article I, Section 8, of the Constitution became controversial during the ratification debates of 1787-1788.   Stevens's history, by contrast, says that the true (and really the only) subject under active debate when the Amendment was framed was the militia. The legal rights of individual Americans to own and use firearms remained a matter of state and local regulation, it suggests, and no one at the time understood that the adoption of the Amendment would modify their authority in any way.    Scalia's historical basis for asserting that his interpretation was the one that was "widely understood" at the time remains unclear. The best-known statement of an avowedly individual right to own and use firearms came in a document issued by the minority Anti-Federalist delegates to the Pennsylvania ratification convention. Their "Dissent" was issued early in the ratification campaign, and could have become a rallying point for the Constitution's critics. Instead the "Dissent" quickly became an object of Federalist ridicule precisely because its idea of protecting a right to "hunt and fowl" seemed too trivial to merit constitutional recognition. Thereafter the discussion of the right to keep and bear arms was concerned almost exclusively with the militia, which is why I continue to find Scalia's argument historically deficient  Q. How sweeping is the ruling?   A. As an endorsement of the "individual right" view of the Amendment, the decision is about as sweeping as it could be. Never one for understatement when it comes to castigating his fellow Justices, Scalia minces no words in endorsing an unequivocal interpretation of the essentially private activities the Amendment was meant to protect.   But because today's ruling is so open-ended, even vague when it comes to laying down the appropriate standards for regulation, it will be years before the impact of the decision will be known. By then, the composition of the Court will have changed, and a Court that could toss aside the 1939 precedent of the Miller case so casually might follow suit with Heller as well.  Q. Why has it taken so long for the Court to take up a Second Amendment case?  A. Controversy over the meaning of the Second Amendment is a relatively modern phenomenon. It took the transformation of the National Rifle Association from an organization primarily concerned with promoting the safe and skillful use of guns into an active advocacy group bent on opposing all forms of firearm regulation to give the Second Amendment any salience in constitutional debate.   At that point, it became something of a touchstone issue for conservative legal activists and some federal judges with impeccable right-wing credentials, like Laurence Silberman of the D.C. Circuit. A handful of cases and opinions endorsing the individual right interpretation and challenging the conventional view of the Miller case created enough dissonance within the federal judiciary to make it possible for the Supreme Court to take on the issue.   But of course, the fact that today's opinion took the predictable 5-4 form of so many other issues of recent years could not possibly mean that the political preferences of the Justices had anything to do with the outcome. Heaven forfend!

title: Of Mice and Women
description: I spent last week at M.I.T.  You don't know me well enough to know how funny that statement is.  I am someone, you see, who dropped science after 9th grade. Who dropped math after 10th. Who studied an accumulated 18 years of foreign languages, but has never set foot in a lab.  So it was an education. To put it mildly. But, predictably enough, I probably didn't get out of my week-long science course precisely what I was supposed to be taking in.  I was attending a journalism workshop called "Frontiers of Brain Science." The other participants were all real science writers, people who don't have to rack their brains to remember the meaning of the word "ion."  I was there because I thought that, given the fact that I am writing a book on children's mental health issues (yes, I know I promised never to bring that up again), I ought to know a little more about the brain.  What I hadn't realized is that "brain science" is far from synonymous with psychiatry. Locating, identifying, computationally modeling "qualia"  what we might call subjective experience  remains to this day the elusive final frontier of neuroscience.  (Though it can be done: one of the most fascinating things I learned, last week, is that you can actually see, via a visual representation of the electrical activity of a rat's brain, what it is "thinking." You can recognize a recurrent pattern of mental activity  what it looks like in the rat's brain when the rat is running through a maze and what it looks like when the creature is thinking over the sequence afterward, as rats apparently do. "These animals are three- to six-months-old and their experiences are only what we've given them," Matt Wilson, a professor in M.I.T.'s department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, told us. In other words, scientists can read rats' minds because they know what they put in them.)   At M.I.T., I learned a great deal about neurons, dendrites, action potentials, the localization of function, visual perception and transcranial magnetic stimulation.   I learned that you can make a mouse "depressed" by dunking it repeatedly in cold water, by giving it electrical shocks over and over again, by subjecting it to "chronic forced swimming," or making it experience "social defeat," by putting a mean mouse in its cage. The latter method is the best way to test antidepressants, because after such a negative social experience it takes a mouse three weeks of drug therapy to recover, an interval that neatly parallels the amount of time antidepressants take to reach their optimal effectiveness in humans.   But let's move on.  I also learned a great many things about my own brain at M.I.T.   I learned that I can take copious notes without understanding a word.   I learned that I can take copious notes while falling asleep.  I learned that I can jerk myself out of sleep by attempting to translate my notes into French. (If you don't know a word, just add an "e" at the end.)  I learned that I can take copious notes on paper while writing utterly unrelated notes on the inside of my hand.  And I learned that, no matter where I go, no matter what I learn or try to do, my mind always runs along the same old grooves, much like a rat that has been trained, all its pitiable life, to run one eternal maze. And that all the thoughts in my own one-track rat-trap of a mind lead back to  Hillary Clinton.  Here's how:  At M.I.T., we were mostly spoken to by men, various kinds of men, of different ages and with different speaking styles, and we interacted with them with typical reportorial formality. Some were more popular with us than others; some were more engaged with us than others. Some spoke right over our heads; some reached even me with perfect clarity.  Something very different happened, however, on the two occasions when we were spoken to by women. The atmosphere in the room changed. We all became more familiar. We asked more questions. We interrupted more. We made sounds of assent or dissent; we questioned methods, concepts, base assumptions. It was as though, with the women, the boundaries dissolved. We were all immediately drawn into relationships.  How much of this had to do with the fact that the women tended to speak more relationally ("I think," "I feel"), I don't know. I don't know if it was created by the fact that the women  to varying degrees  turned the story of their work into personal narratives.  I know that there was no conscious desire on anyone's part to talk back to them or treat them with less respect. But one woman in particular, Rebecca Saxe, a young, dynamic professor of neurobiology at M.I.T. who gave a riveting presentation on social cognition  "how we reason about the desires and intentions that motivate others' actions"  was interrupted so much by her super-engaged audience that she didn't have time to get through essential portions of her talk.   I did not ask questions of this amazing young woman. I was struck, once again, with one of my crippling bouts of shyness, and besides that, I was too busy writing down her every word and wondering why on earth I had never taken science and whether my daughters might attend M.I.T.   Maybe I could send them to do summer study, I thought. (Once they'd both learned their multiplication tables, of course.) Maybe I should sport little wire glasses and wear my hair in a long braid. Or buy Birkenstocks.  "What did you think?" I breathed to a fellow female fellow, as we filed out of the classroom for lunch.   "I have a crush on her," she said. The women around us made approving noises.  "It was her passion and energy and approach that was infectious," she later explained in an e-mail. "I really had an emotional reaction to her, and found myself day dreaming about being her friend."  What is this thing we so often do, when confronted with an impressive woman? Why do they, in particular, set off such a Pavlovian rush of emotion? Why, for women in particular, do they set off this me/not me engagement, this game of my friend/not my friend, this eternal, sometimes infernal play of positive or negative mirroring?  Men do a version of this with women, too  though I think it plays out more in terms of validates me/doesn't validate me, which may amount, in slightly altered form, to much the same thing. I don't see them doing it with other men. I don't hear of men getting "crushes" on other men because they're impressed with them. They don't seem to get so flooded with the desire to be them, to try on their skins; they don't appear to be constantly testing their identities against another man's example, calling into question, at the drop of a hat, their clothing style or hair or general sense of being in the world.  My husband, Max, has no interest in spectator sports. But he can survive office conversations about the Washington Redskins without feeling that his very selfhood as a man has been called into question. The fact that Barack Obama is barely seeing his children this year is not setting off a cultural conversation on modern working fatherhood. I don't think that any man, in the Clinton years, felt personally implicated, defined or not-defined as husbands and fathers, by Bill's intimate affairs.   Which brings me back to Hillary.  I have long been convinced that the heart of the endless cultural brouhaha about Hillary turns around this me/not me business, the fact that her face, her life, her choices, her style have had, for some reason, to serve as a funhouse mirror for millions of American women (and men).  One of the biggest criticisms of her in the race for the Democratic nomination was that she entered it as a wife-of; and, like Geraldine Ferraro before her, that "of-ness" proved toxic. Yet the main relationship that defined her, I believe, was not the one she had with Bill, but with individual members of the public. She set off a firestorm of neuronal activity in the social cognition center of the national brain. Conscious or not.
