description: With a legal deadline four days away, city officials brokered a deal on Thursday night on a $59.1 billion budget that would preserve a popular tax cut for homeowners and a $400 rebate and add $129 million in education spending to what had originally been proposed.

title: InBevs Bid for Anheuser Turns Hostile
description: Directors of the American brewing company, Anheuser-Busch, rejected an offer from the rival brewery, InBev of Belgium, on Thursday, as InBev decided take its takeover bid directly to shareholders.

title: Cannibal Witches on the Prowl
description: Its not the water that menaces in Wicked Lake, an inept, nasty and absolutely irredeemable entry in the stale torture-porn subgenre of horror that more often than not features bloodthirsty clans residing in the backwoods. The lake serves only as a skinny-dipping site for four vacationing lesbians, who eventually reveal themselves as more villainous than the assorted deranged males who follow them to a secluded cabin, where at midnight they transform into some sort of cannibal witches. (That this is someones idea of female empowerment is by far the most frightening thing about the film, besides, perhaps, the universally atrocious acting.)

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: In May, Housing Market Rallied With Small Gain
description: The ailing housing market got a bit of a bump last month, as steadily falling home prices led to a small increase in sales, a realty group said Thursday.

title: Justices Rule for Individual Gun Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday embraced the long-disputed view that the Second Amendment protects an individual right to own a gun for personal use, ruling 5 to 4 that there is a constitutional right to keep a loaded handgun at home for self-defense.

title: Mr. Ravitch to the Rescue?
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that runs the citys subways, buses and commuter trains, has warned that it is so far in the red that it may have to raise fares, trim service, defer repairs and cut major projects.

title: Baby on Board for NBC
description: The premiere of The Baby Borrowers, a new reality series in which teenage couples learn firsthand about parenting in an intense three-week child-sharing experiment, gave NBC a boost on Wednesday, when the network was runner-up in the nights 18-to-49 ratings demographic. According to Nielsens estimates, Baby Borrowers delivered the nights second-highest ratings in that category, with 7.8 million viewers at 9. It was also NBCs best-rated hour of programming on Wednesday, better than Deal or No Deal at 8 (6.6 million) and Celebrity Circus at 10 (5.7 million). Fox led the night over all with the top-rated show, So You Think You Can Dance, which averaged 8.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. ABC and CBS ranked third and fourth, respectively, in the 18-to-49 set.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Request for a Fast Decision on Gases
description: A federal appeals court in Washington unanimously rejected the petition by a group of states and environmental organizations to force a speedy decision on whether and how to regulate heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide. In the wake of a 2007 Supreme Court decision in the case brought by these states and environmental groups, the Environmental Protection Agency concluded that such gases were pollutants requiring regulation. When the agency forwarded its finding to the White House, it was told that the e-mail would not be opened. That finding remains in limbo, as does a draft E.P.A. regulation setting emission standards for motor vehicles. A less direct draft rule, which outlines the issues involved in regulation, is due soon, an agency spokesman said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Federal Reserves decision to keep interest rates unchanged included an outdated statement from the Fed on the status of the economy. The article quoted from an earlier Fed statement, issued April 30, rather than the June 25 statement, the text of which accompanied the article. The text can also be found at nytimes.com/business.

title: Union Says It and Con Edison Are Far Apart on Contract
description: Consolidated Edison and the union that represents nearly 9,000 of its workers appear to be making little headway in negotiations to renew their four-year contract before its expiration at 12:01 a.m. on Sunday.

title: The Sams Club Agenda
description: Among the many dark tidings for American conservatism, there is one genuine bright spot. Over the past five years, a group of young and unpredictable rightward-leaning writers has emerged on the scene.

title: What to Ask About Vasectomy
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Lottery Numbers
Friends Recall a Young Peacemaker and Aspiring Lawyer
description: Aaliyah Clark and Chole Toppin tied a handful of balloons to the rusted old gate. Some were purple and heart-shaped. Some said, I Love You or Friends Forever. A figurine of Betty Boop hung beneath another, attached to its string.

title: At Open, Some Stars Struggle on Deceptively Soft Greens
description: EDINA, Minn.  Lorena Ochoa, annoyed at being three over par and still awaiting her first birdie after 13 holes, spied a leader board teeming with red numbers. The names mixed the familiar (Laura Davies, Helen Alfredsson) and the unknown (Ji Young Oh of South Korea). Even the amateur Mara Jos Uribe, the bubbly Colombian playing in the same group with Ochoa, was three under.

title: Earmarks Persist in Spending Bills for 2009
description: WASHINGTON  Despite a pledge by Congressional leaders to reduce pork-barrel projects, new information shows that both the number and amount of earmarks have increased in several spending bills now making their way through Congress.

title: Two Testify on Memo Spelling Out Interrogation
description: WASHINGTON  Two Bush administration lawyers who provided important legal justification for harsh interrogation methods that critics denounce as torture made a rare public appearance on Thursday to defend their actions.

title: Gay Has His Sights on Olympic Trials and a Formidable Opponent
description: EUGENE, Ore.  An absent persons shadow will loom large over the mens 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials  Usain Bolt of Jamaica, who set a startling world record of 9.72 seconds at the Reebok Grand Prix meet in New York on May 31.

title: Record Wool Price Set in Australia
description: An Indian fabric maker paid nearly $250,000, a record price, for a 200-pound bale of exceptionally high grade wool at an auction Thursday in Australia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the arrest of the Italian businessman Raffaello Follieri on charges of fraud and money laundering misstated his investment relationship with the Yucaipa Companies, the private equity firm controlled by Ron Burkle. Yucaipa put up more than $55 million in a joint venture with Mr. Follieris company, the Follieri Group  not in the company itself.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: When a Done Deal Unravels
description: Peter Huntsman, the chief executive of Huntsman Chemical, thought he had a solid deal. When some on Wall Street showed their doubts, he bet millions they were wrong.

title: Golden Newies
description: Here is information about the recordings mentioned:

title: Umpire Suspended for Manuel Bump
description: Brian Runge, the umpire who bumped Mets Manager Jerry Manuel during an on-field argument Tuesday night, has been suspended one game, the commissioners office announced.

title: Senate Passes Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Fourth of July fireworks came early on Capitol Hill.

title: New York Asian Film Festival 2008
description: Back for its seventh year, the New York Asian Film Festival is known for its disdain of art house movies and its feverish support of Asian popular cinema, particularly in its more disreputable and blood-splattered variations.

title: The Day Robert Mugabe Was Greeted at City Hall
description: Foreign leaders arent routinely honored with receptions at New Yorks City Hall. In the last two decades, as best as we can tell, only two Africans have received this red-carpet treatment.

title: Government Seeks Dismissal of End-of-World Suit Against Collider
description: Calling its claims overly speculative and not credible, and saying that it is too late anyway, lawyers for the federal government argued this week that a so-called doomsday suit intended to prevent the startup of a the worlds most powerful particle accelerator should be thrown out of court.

title: In a World Left Silent, One Heart Beeps
description: The first 40 minutes or so of Wall-E  in which barely any dialogue is spoken, and almost no human figures appear on screen  is a cinematic poem of such wit and beauty that its darker implications may take a while to sink in. The scene is an intricately rendered city, bristling with skyscrapers but bereft of any inhabitants apart from a battered, industrious robot and his loyal cockroach sidekick. Hazy, dust-filtered sunlight illuminates a landscape of eerie, post-apocalyptic silence. This is a world without people, you might say without animation, though it teems with evidence of past life.

title: A Second Woof
description: John Grogan, the author of the 2005 man-and-his-dog best seller Marley & Me, is writing a prequel called The Longest Trip Home, HarperCollins announced. On sale in October, this memoir will recount the childhood days of Mr. Grogan, above with his dog Gracie. It is part of a Grogan-fest this year that includes a childrens book, A Very Marley Christmas, and a film adaptation of Marley & Me, starring Owen Wilson, Jennifer Aniston and oh, yes, a dog.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about marketplaces opening near the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan misstated the starting time of a one-day food market called the New Amsterdam Public that will be held on Sunday. It will open at 11 a.m., not 10, and close at 4 p.m.

title: A Whirling, Digitized Ride on a Small Celluloid Raft
description: The filmmaker Ken Jacobs calls his new feature-length movie Razzle Dazzle, and boy, he isnt kidding. Subjecting a minute-long film made by Thomas Edison in 1903 to a kaleidoscopic array of digital distortions, effects, filters and montage techniques, Mr. Jacobs, one of Americas most esteemed avant-garde filmmakers, has orchestrated a scintillating tour de force.

title: The Sex and the Fury, French Aristocracy Style
description: The first time you see the courtesan called La Vellini, shes stretched out on a divan and wearing a smile, or perhaps a scowl. Its hard to tell with this woman, whose lips restlessly tremble and twist with rage and pleasure. Shes dressed like the supine subject of Goyas painting The Clothed Maja, which, like its sister image, The Nude Maja, was condemned as indecent by the Spanish Inquisition. To look at the figure on screen writhing like a pampered cat is to understand why those paintings made some observers uneasy.

title: A Company Computer and Questions About E-Mail Privacy
description: When he was fired, Scott Sidell was angry enough. Then he found out that his former employer was reading his personal Yahoo e-mail messages, after he had left the company.

title: Branching Out in Bilbao
description: Government officials in Bilbao, Spain, have proposed that a new branch of the Guggenheim Museum there be built in the countryside, beyond the citys outskirts, Reuters reported. Jos Luis Bilbao, who leads the Vizcaya provincial government, said that local officials could finance the project, to be built in a nature reserve. Juan Ignaco Vidarte, director general of the Bilbao Guggenheim, known for its twisting, titanium-clad building designed by Frank Gehry, said the new branch would link art with the notion of environmental sustainability. He did not say who would design the building or when it would open. In New York, Betsy Ennis, a spokeswoman for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, said it had reviewed an initial proposal from the Guggenheim Bilbao for the new satellite museum and would analyze its programming, architecture, operations and budget issues over the next few months.

title: Truce Is Strained as Militants Launch Rockets and Israel Keeps Goods Out of Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  A barely week-old truce between Israel and the Hamas rulers of Gaza frayed further on Thursday when Palestinian militants launched two rockets against Israel, and Israel prevented goods from entering Gaza for a second day.

title: Moving to Stravinsky, Debussy and Winehouse
description: As a dancer, Nicholas Leichter is one of the best New York has to offer. His impulse to move springs from a deep place untainted by superfluous details. But in his ensemble dances Mr. Leichter is just part of the group, and this is where the trouble begins: his astounding natural ability never manages to translate to the rest of his cast.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Guide to Viewing the Waterfalls
description: The New York City Waterfalls, Olafur Eliassons work of public art, will be even more public than The Gates were. After all, you had to go to Central Park to see The Gates.

title: Waits Plague Transfers of Children to Relatives Care
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md.  When child welfare officials in Washington removed five young children from their parents home in May, relatives in this Washington suburb quickly stepped in, offering to share guardianship.

title: The Sad, Proud Elegies Start in Brunos District
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  On Tuesday evening, as the State Senate rose in the Capitol in Albany to applaud Joseph L. Bruno, a few middle-aged men gathered at the Park Lane Tobacconist here in downtown Saratoga Springs, smoking cigars the size of bratwursts as the sun sank in the sky.

title: With Trade, the Nets Rebuilding Is Official
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It might have been the 2008 edition of the N.B.A. draft, but 2010 seemed to be the year on everyones mind in the Nets camp Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a political crisis in Argentina caused by a tax dispute between the government and farmers misidentified the capital of Santa Fe province, a major agricultural region. It is Santa Fe, not Rosario.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Google Tries Tighter Aim for Web Ads
description: Google, with its deep reservoir of data about online behavior gathered by tracking hundreds of millions of computers, is for the first time testing ways to use some of that data to aim ads at Web users.

title: The Myths and Realities of a Vasectomy
description: Dr. Marc Goldstein is director of the Center for Male Reproductive Medicine and Microsurgery at Cornell University Weill Medical College. Dr. Goldstein was one of the first surgeons to introduce no-scalpel vasectomies in the United States and remains a leader in research in the field of male contraception and fertility.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a report by the inspector general of the Justice Department on the departments use of political or ideological factors in hiring mistakenly conflated the cases of two rejected job applicants mentioned in the report (but not named in the article). One was described in the report as having worked for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton; the other was described as having a MySpace page with an unflattering cartoon about President Bush. They were not the same person.

title: Allegations in Russia Could Hurt BP Venture
description: BPs grasp on its extensive oil assets in Russia became more tenuous Thursday after its Russian partners said that a general shareholders meeting for a joint venture had been held in violation of Russian law.

title: Job-Seeking Baby Boomers
description: To the Editor:

title: Cascades, Sing the City Energetic
description: When Walt Whitman crossed the East River on the Brooklyn Ferry, the sheer ecstasy of the trip made him see the future. It was us, the coming generations of urban dwellers who would draw the same energy he did from his wonderful town and its waterways.

title: For Obama, a Pragmatists Shift Toward the Center
description: Barack Obama has taken a stroll this week away from traditional liberal political positions, his path toward the political center marked by artful leaps and turns.

title: Dashing Spain Transcends Its Anguish
description: This is something that has not happened in 24 years, most of them frustrating. Spains national team  La Seleccin  has disappointed so often, so graphically, so diversely. But on Thursday came the biggest win in a generation.

title: Ed Arno, Cartoonist of New Yorker Whimsy, Is Dead at 92
description: Ed Arno, whose sketchy, casually rendered cartoons on topics domestic and cosmic appeared regularly in The New Yorker for more than 30 years, died on May 27. He was 92.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Tigers No Longer Looking Back
description: DETROIT  Todd Jones, the Tigers closer, put on a shaggy wig and a Magglio Ordez jersey and took a bat to the tarp-covered infield during a rain-delayed game at Comerica Park.

title: Council Seeks Harsher Penalty in Urban Climbs
description: The death-defying climbers who scale New York Citys skyscrapers shut down entire blocks, tie up dozens of police officers and risk the safety of bystanders below. And for that, the city slaps some of them with the equivalent of a parking ticket.

title: Reflections Through a Surrealistic Eye: Dal and the Camera
description: Nearly 80 years on, the famous image from Un Chien Andalou, which Salvador Dal and his art-school friend Luis Buuel cobbled together in Paris in April 1929, remains one of the most shocking in all cinema. A womans face fills the screen. A mans left hand widens the lids of her left eye; his right begins to draw a straight razor across it. Then there is, as it were, a jump cut. The razor slices through the eye of a dead cow and gelatinous ooze tumbles forth. Yick, and whew.

title: For Love of the Game
description: On Sept. 1, 2006, two dozen of Americas top-ranked high school basketball players converged on Rucker Park in Harlem for an unprecedented event. Regardless of age, experience or sneaker-company affiliation, these athletes would play for no other reason than love of the game.

title: Lock and Load
description: Thirty-thousand Americans are killed by guns every year  on the job, walking to school, at the shopping mall. The Supreme Court on Thursday all but ensured that even more Americans will die senselessly with its wrongheaded and dangerous ruling striking down key parts of the District of Columbias gun-control law.

title: Complex Ties Lead Ally Not to Condemn Mugabe
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Robert Mugabes enforcers had already begun to rampage across Zimbabwe, beating his political opponents, when television cameras captured a startling image of Mr. Mugabe holding hands with the smiling South African president, Thabo Mbeki, a professed champion of African democracy.

title: Footnotes
description: Eli Broad, below, the philanthropist whose donations to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art helped it to build one of the largest contemporary-art institutions in the country, is stepping down from a formal role on the museums board, the museum announced on Wednesday. Mr. Broad will serve as a life trustee, a nonvoting member of the museums board. Christopher V. Walker, a former vice chairman and chairman of the museums finance committee, also stepped down from its board. ... Adriane Lenox, who won a Tony for her work in John Patrick Shanleys Doubt: A Parable in 2005, will lead the cast of Lynn Nottages Ruined, about a businesswoman dealing with strife in Congo, at the Manhattan Theater Club next season. The play will have its premiere this fall at the Goodman Theater in Chicago.

title: Philippines: Typhoon Toll May Exceed 1,300
description: The death toll from Typhoon Fengshen could reach more than 1,300, including the passengers and the crew of a ferry that capsized Saturday in the storm, officials said. As many as 809 people on the ferry are thought to have died. Divers continued to search the boat, where hundreds of bodies are believed to be trapped, as villagers, left, prayed for the victims during a Mass on Sibuyan Island. Apart from the ferry disaster, officials raised the death toll to 498.

title: Post-Spitzer, a New Breed of Reformer
description: No one is dusting off those valiant titles once bestowed on Eliot Spitzer, honorifics like The Enforcer and Sheriff of Wall Street. But slowly, even a bit gently, Mr. Spitzers successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry.

title: CBS to Appeal Military Court Ruling on Haditha Interview
description: A First Amendment case has escalated between CBS News and a military court over a 60 Minutes report about an attack at Haditha, Iraq.

title: H.I.V. and Aids Diagnoses Rise in Men Who Have Sex With Men
description: Diagnoses of H.I.V. and AIDS in men who have sex with men rose significantly from 2001 to 2006, while declining in other demographic groups, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. The increase in infection rates was especially high among males ages 13 to 24, with an annual increase of 12.4 percent, compared with 1.5 percent for men over all. The annual increase was higher still among young African-American men who have sex with men, nearly 15 percent. Its a grim report, said Dr. Ronald Stall, an epidemiologist and professor of public health at the University of Pittsburgh. It means roughly speaking that about half of the American AIDS epidemic is occurring among a few percent of the adult population. And the terrible trends were seeing among white gay men are even amplified further among minority men.

title: Citing Need for Assessments, U.S. Freezes Solar Energy Projects
description: DENVER  Faced with a surge in the number of proposed solar power plants, the federal government has placed a moratorium on new solar projects on public land until it studies their environmental impact, which is expected to take about two years.

title: Bruise-Inducing Games: Young Sadists at Play
description: With an actress as extremely gorgeous as Meital Dohan and a script that requires her to thrash around in ways most often seen in straight-to-video steamers, you would think that Stitching would be heating up the Wild Project theater to the boiling point.

title: Dipping Into Many Modes
description: An old Indian legend tells of how, after several years of intense meditation, the Buddhist monk Bodhidharma began to grow sleepy. His goal being spiritual awakening, this just wouldnt do, so he removed his eyelids and flung them to the ground. From the spot where they landed grew the first tea leaves.

title: Alkaline Soil Sample From Mars Reveals Presence of Nutrients for Plants to Grow
description: Stick an asparagus plant in a pot full of Martian soil, and the asparagus might grow happily, scientists announced Thursday.

title: Mexico: 14 Men to Be Compensated for Vasectomies
description: Officials of Guerrero State have agreed to pay $3,400 each to 14 indigenous men who were coerced into having vasectomies a decade ago. The men will also get water storage tanks and cement to build new homes, Luis Barrera Rios, the state health secretary, told The Associated Press. During a visit to the village of El Camalote in 1998, health workers demanded that men with more than four children be sterilized, the National Human Rights Commission said last year in a report. The men said state workers had promised them new homes and scholarships for their children if they underwent the procedure.

title: Obama Gives $2,300 for Clinton Debt
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama said on Thursday that he had written a personal check of $2,300 to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a good-will gesture intended to nudge his top donors to help ease Mrs. Clintons campaign debt and help the two Democrats move beyond their rivalry to focus on the fall contest.

title: An Inexhaustible Energy Source: Heated Words. But Can It Be Tapped?
description: WASHINGTON  Fourth of July fireworks came early on Capitol Hill.

title: Take Out the Trash Precisely, Now. Its the Law.
description: WHITEHAVEN, England  The citizens of Whitehaven try, really they do. They separate out their cans, their paper, their cardboard and their glass, and they recycle them all. They compost. They jump up and down on their trash to cram it into their government-issued garbage cans, and they put the trash out for collection at exactly 7 a.m., twice a month.

title: A Grim Image of Politics in Zimbabwe Emerges
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe As President Robert Mugabe defied intensifying international condemnation to insist that Fridays presidential runoff would proceed, a picture was emerging on Thursday of the circumstances under which Zimbabweans would be forced to go to the polls, and what they might face if they resisted.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,098 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: Fuels on the Hill
description: Congress has always had a soft spot for experts who tell members what they want to hear, whether its supply-side economists declaring that tax cuts increase revenue or climate-change skeptics insisting that global warming is a myth.

title: Legal Loophole Allows Taxpayer to Profit From False Filing
description: In 2004, city investigators discovered that the owner of a parking garage in Lower Manhattan had cheated the city out of roughly $210,000 in property taxes over seven years.

title: Muslim Supporters Shouldnt Be a Political Liability
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding a Comfort Zone With Bach and Beethoven
description: John Kamitsuka takes a modest approach to the piano that, depending on what you want from a public piano recital, can be either endearing or frustrating. He is not a pianist who likes to show off his instruments power or, for that matter, the more fiery aspects of piano technique. And when he plays pieces that require such things, his readings can seem distant and cautious. But in music that thrives on a focused, intimate sound and clean articulation, he is often interesting and original.

title: Supreme Court Strikes Down Millionaires Amendment
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday struck down a law meant to level the financial playing field when rich candidates pay for their own political campaigns.

title: On eBay, Bride Finds Sponsor for a Wedding
description: The eBay auction to be a bridesmaid in Kelly Grays wedding is officially over, but the surprises keep coming.

title: Philippines Toll Could Reach 1,300
description: MANILA  The death toll from Typhoon Fengshen, the storm that battered the Philippines last week, could reach 1,300 if the missing passengers and crew of a capsized ferry are included, officials said Thursday.

title: Housecleaning on a Grand Scale
description: Collectors are always on the lookout for works that have not recently been for sale in galleries or at the auction houses.

title: Settling Inquiry, Anheuser Drops Caffeinated Brews
description: Anheuser-Busch has agreed to stop selling caffeinated alcoholic drinks to settle complaints that it was misrepresenting the beverages and marketing them to minors.

title: Fast Field in 100 Stands in Way of Felixs Pursuit of 4 Gold Medals
description: EUGENE, Ore.  When Allyson Felix folds her long legs into the starting blocks in the first round of the 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials Friday, she will feel a little more at home than usual.

title: Ex-Leader of Bus Drivers Union Is Sentenced in Bribery Case
description: The former president of a union representing 15,000 New York City school bus drivers was sentenced on Thursday to four years and nine months in federal prison after pleading guilty to extortion and receiving bribes in a Mafia-controlled racketeering conspiracy.

title: The Knicks Look Abroad and Hope for the Best
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Phase III of Donnie Walshs rebuilding project went into effect Thursday night. Charged with the task of orchestrating the ramshackle Knicks first draft on his watch, Walsh reached overseas for the newest piece of the franchise.

title: Jury Convicts Motorist of Causing Train Crash
description: LOS ANGELES  The man who caused a catastrophic train crash that killed 11 people and injured scores of others was convicted on Thursday of 11 counts of first-degree murder and may face the death penalty.

title: Corrections
description: Business Day

title: A Trip Through the Revolving Doors of Perception
description: Paul McCarthy fans are in for a shock. They will find almost nothing of what this Los Angeles master of transgressive provocation is famous for in Central Symmetrical Rotation Movement: Three Installations, Two Films at the Whitney Museum of American Art. No psychotic clowning, no scatological food play, no pornographic vaudeville, no raunchy political satire, no gross self-abnegation.

title: Not Your Mothers Original-Cast Albums
description: A surge of oxygen pours through the original cast albums of In the Heights and Passing Strange, two musicals that have shown Broadway how to revitalize a somnolent form this season.

title: Black Hills Rail Line, on Spoked Wheels Instead of Steel
description: THE Lakota called the incongruous patch of low mountains erupting from the prairies of southwestern South Dakota Paha Sapa  Black Hills  for the dark drapes of ponderosa pine that decorated the gray granite slopes. To the Indians they were sacred. Then prospectors discovered gold, the United States Army took over, and miners, railroad men and settlers dug, drilled and dynamited. Despite these scars  and this judgment might not pass muster with the Lakota who knew them first  the Black Hills remain downright stunning.

title: The North Korea Deal
description: For six years, President Bush rejected any serious diplomacy with North Korea. That obstinacy made the world a more dangerous place. While he was refusing to talk, Pyongyang made more fuel for more weapons and tested a nuclear device. Now that American diplomats finally have been freed to negotiate, there is a chance that North Korea can be persuaded to give up its weapons. That would make the world a safer place.

title: Throwing a Line
description: WHO Mickey Youmans, 58, an executive of Farmers Almanac TV, and his wife, Annette, 45, an executive assistant in fuel marketing, from Savannah, Ga. WHAT 3-bedroom cottage WHERE Topton, N.C.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Tuesday with an article about the 1960 World Series between the Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates misstated the name of the building at the University of Pittsburgh where home plate from Forbes Field is embedded in the floor. It is Posvar Hall, not Posner Hall.

title: One Gloomy Family
description: Leave it to the Irish to turn misery and recrimination into an art form. In Red Roses and Petrol, a soused, post-funeral postmortem on a dysfunctional Dublin family, the misery seeps from the screen in cold, damp waves; by the end youll be grabbing for the bottle yourself.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Movie Listings Highlight: Brigadoon
description: To find Brigadoon, it seems, you must move backward. Thats what the director Vincente Minnelli and the cinematographer Joseph Ruttenberg did for MGMs Brigadoon. First they shot the discovery scene as a clear view of a village nestled in a valley and then pumped in fog to cover it over. Finally they projected the sequence in reverse, and Brigadoon emerged magically from the Highland mists for its one day every 100 years.

title: The Kid Keeps Himself in the Picture
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  There is a slight paunch and a tilt in his gait, the result of all the knee surgeries that serve as penance for all the years he spent as a major league catcher. But Gary Carter, even at 54, has the same camera-ready smile, the same golly-gee enthusiasm that he carried into rookie ball after graduating from  where else?  Sunny Hills High School.

title: A Gambler Goes to Sin City in Search of Atonement
description: If the title Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas didnt already belong to Hunter S. Thompson, it would perfectly fit Peter Tolans viciously funny satire, Finding Amanda. Set mostly in Sin City, it offers a through-the-looking-glass vision of confused Americans losing their already shaky bearings in the worlds gaudiest honky-tonk.

title: How Well Will Budweiser Travel?
description: FRANKFURT

title: Things to Know if Youre Considering a Vasectomy
description: Dr. Edmund Sabanegh Jr., is director of the Center for Male Fertility at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, where he has counseled hundreds of men about vasectomies. He offers a checklist of five things every man should know before deciding to have a vasectomy.

title: Gifted Programs: The Teachers Union Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Brain Lies to You
description: FALSE beliefs are everywhere. Eighteen percent of Americans think the sun revolves around the earth, one poll has found. Thus it seems slightly less egregious that, according to another poll, 10 percent of us think that Senator Barack Obama, a Christian, is instead a Muslim. The Obama campaign has created a Web site to dispel misinformation. But this effort may be more difficult than it seems, thanks to the quirky way in which our brains store memories  and mislead us along the way.

title: Another Yahoo Overhaul as It Tries to Right Itself
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  Under pressure from many shareholders for its poor performance and for its failure to complete a deal with Microsoft, Yahoo is doing something it has done several times before: reorganizing itself.

title: Win One, Lose One for Dallas Museum
description: LONDON Now that Christies has celebrated one astronomical sale this week  a 1919 Monet waterlily painting that went for a record-breaking $80.4 million  it is gearing up for another.

title: Call It Disneys Food Kingdom
description: WHEN our children were 4 and 6, the idea of taking them to Disney World for part of spring vacation was under consideration. For about five minutes. Instead, we booked a trip to Rome, Naples and Sicily.

title: Microsoft Seeks Path Beyond Gatess Legacy
description: Bill Gates is retiring, sort of. He is still only 52, and he is going off to spend more time guiding the worlds richest philanthropy, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. He will still be Microsofts chairman and largest shareholder, but Friday is his last day as a full-time worker at the software giant, marking the unofficial end of his career as a business leader.

title: Doctors Face Payment Cuts for Patients on Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  Doctors face a 10 percent cut in Medicare payments next week, following the Senates failure on Thursday to take up legislation that would have averted the cuts.

title: Guitar Music, Chatty Players, No Dress Code
description: The summer procession of institutes and festivals at Mannes College the New School for Music reached its guitar installment, formally called the New York Guitar Seminar, on Wednesday evening.

title: Man, 39, Charged in Fatal Stabbing of Girl, 15
description: A 39-year-old man who has been charged with the fatal stabbing of a 15-year-old girl on Wednesday night told police officers that he was acting in self-defense, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Thursday.

title: Vasectomy: Safe, Simple and Little Used
description: A tiny puncture and a little snip, done under local anesthetic  thats essentially all there is to a vasectomy.

title: U.S. Inquiry Into Funding by Council Is to End Soon
description: A federal investigation into the City Councils appropriation of funds to fictitious groups should conclude within 90 days, a prosecutor said on Thursday.

title: When an Eloquent Voice Was Stilled in Hollywood
description: Peter Askins stirring documentary Trumbo gives you reasons to cheer but also to weep. It makes you lament the decline of the kind of language brandished with Shakespearean eloquence by Dalton Trumbo, the blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter, in his witty, impassioned letters excerpted in the movie.

title: Phillips, New to Mets, Knows Opponent Well
description: PITTSBURGH  When he learned Wednesday that he was the newest member of the Mets, Andy Phillips had no hint he would head right back to Yankee Stadium. He had just been there last weekend, with the Cincinnati Reds, and used to play home games there for the Yankees.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: The Adventures of Georgia, Queen of the Desert Painting
description: It has been a big year for art onstage, with the revival of Stephen Sondheims Sunday in the Park With George and Mercedes Ruehl as Louise Nevelson in Edward Albees Occupant. Now comes the eager, animated actress-playwright Natalie Mosco tackling Georgia OKeeffe, perhaps Americas first female superstar painter.

title: 3 U.S. Marines and More than 30 Iraqis Die in 2 Bomb Attacks
Better Rail Service
description: To the Editor:

title: From Rucker Park Documentary to Top of the N.B.A. Draft
description: On a muggy September day in 2006, Kevin Love became Kevlar, Jerryd Bayless got a name (Pay Up) to rhyme with his game (shifty layups) and Michael Beasley nearly tore the rims down at Manhattans most legendary outdoor court.

title: Our Corner of the American Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Bus-Stop Dispute Ends With Girl Dead
description: It began shortly before 10 on Wednesday night with an accusation that a woman had cut in line while waiting for a bus in Queens. It ended less than an hour and a few miles later with a 15-year-old girl lying mortally wounded on the sidewalk.

title: Hunting With Hounds
description: To the Editor:

title: Gun-Control Supporters Show Outrage
description: Gun-control advocates across the country reacted with shock and outrage at the Supreme Courts decision to strike down the District of Columbias ban on handguns today, saying the ruling would threaten gun-control measures in other states.

title: Early Exits for Roddick and Sharapova
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Another historically bad day for American tennis ended with Andy Roddick demonstrating much better touch in the Wimbledon interview room than he had on Centre Court, where he was eliminated in the second round by Janko Tipsarevic of Serbia.

title: On the Summer Menu: Light Musical Fare, Served With a Few Wry Asides
description: No sooner had the British conductor Bramwell Tovey kicked off the New York Philharmonics annual tour of the citys parks with a festive program in Central Park on Tuesday night than he led the players back to Avery Fisher Hall for the first of this years Summertime Classics concerts on Wednesday.

title: Dancing to Aspen
description: Damian Woetzel, who retired last week from the New York City Ballet after 23 years, has been named the 2008 Harman-Eisner Artist in Residence at the Aspen Institute. Mr. Woetzel will begin his tenure there this summer, taking part in leadership forums, an idea festival and a symposium on Tibet. (He has a masters in public administration from the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard and is a charter member of the Young Leaders Forum of the National Committee on United States-China Relations.) Mr. Woetzel, 41, is also the artistic director of the Vail International Dance Festival, which runs from July 27 to Aug. 10 this year.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Kermit Love, a costume designer and a creator, with Jim Henson, of Sesame Street characters including Big Bird, misstated Mr. Hensons role in starting Sesame Street. The show was created by a team put together by the Childrens Television Workshop, now called Sesame Workshop; Mr. Henson was not the creator.

title: A Pep Talk at Chrysler, Hailing Its Hero of the 80s
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  For one afternoon at least, it was like the good old days again at Chrysler.

title: 'Idol' Tryouts in Puerto Rico
description: American Idol will conduct auditions for its eighth season in San Juan, P.R., and seven other cities; this is only the second time that the singing competition has gone outside the continental United States in its search for contestants. (Auditions were conducted in Hawaii in Season 3.) The auditions will begin on July 17 at the Cow Palace in San Francisco and continue in Louisville, Ky., on July 21; Phoenix on July 25; Salt Lake City on July 29; San Juan on Aug. 2; Kansas City, Mo., on Aug. 8; Jacksonville, Fla., on Aug. 13; and East Rutherford, N.J., on Aug. 19. The auditions are open to men and women ages 16 to 28 as of July 15 who are eligible to work in the United States; full regulations and details are available at AmericanIdol.com.

title: Survey of Teachers Shows Dissatisfaction With Klein
description: A school year that began with a choreographed show of harmony between New York Citys schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, and the president of its teachers union, Randi Weingarten, ended on Thursday in discord, with the release of a survey in which thousands of the citys teachers voiced strong disapproval of Mr. Kleins leadership.

title: Raw Materials of a Life, Revealed by Sculpture
description: Spirals abound in Louise Bourgeoiss art. She says they make her think of control and freedom, and of strangling someone. So its perfect that her retrospective, seen in London and Paris, is now in the looping rotunda of the Guggenheim Museum. It looks great there, clean but organic  fecund, tumid, enwrapping  and unclassically classical.

title: Iran Fights Scourge of Addiction in Plain View, Stressing Treatment
description: TEHRAN  Ali blew out a candle on a small round cake. More than 200 people cheered, celebrating the first anniversary of his becoming drug-free.

title: Kauai Lagoons and Derbyshire
description: Kauai Lagoons

title: Trying to Find the Right Balance for the Seaport
description: For a relatively long moment in the late 1970s and early 80s, Boston was pretty hot. Between the Preppy Handbook (which came out in 1980), the hit television series Cheers  (which premiered in 1982) and Steves Ice Cream (which originated in Boston and helped begin the national craze for fancy ice cream), all things Brahmin and baked-beany felt of-the-moment, if not exactly chic. Possibly the country was enjoying some kind of a post-bicentennial afterglow, leaving behind the messiness of the 70s (and all that cinematic urban decay) for the kind of wholesome Americana vibe that Boston always captured so well.

title: In the Metal Recycling Business, Its Loud, Dirty and Suddenly Lucrative
description: Bob Rommeney steered his flatbed truck into a scrap-metal recycling plant in Brooklyn and unloaded two battered cars that had been wrecked days earlier at Riverhead Raceway on Long Island.

title: All About Families, Generation After Generation
description: IT was clear from the day he got his drivers license where Louis Cerone was going to hang out at the Jersey Shore.

title: Clooney Offers Actors a Pre-emptive Strike
description: George Clooney, below, is offering some proposals aimed at breaking the negotiating standoff between the Screen Actors Guild and movie and television production companies: among them, annual pay reviews to be personally overseen by stars like Tom Hanks and Jack Nicholson and a substantial increase in the dues that high-earning actors pay the union. Mr. Clooney floated the ideas in a public statement on Thursday. The actors current contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers expires on Monday night, and talks have been stalled for weeks. Im not the brightest bulb out there, Mr. Clooneys statement said, inviting fresh thinking from anyone who has a better idea. His proposals involve creating a panel of high earners  10 people that studio heads dont often say no to  to seek an annual adjustment in actors pay based on information compiled by SAG and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists, another actors union. He also suggested that actors, whose dues are now calculated on only their first $1 million in earnings, agree to eliminate the cap and pay $6,000 on each $1 million they earn, without limit. That could go a long way in helping pensions and health care, Mr. Clooney said.

title: Correction: On Marthas Vineyard on a Budget. Seriously.
description: An article on June 13 about Marthas Vineyard on a budget misstated the price for one adult round trip on the Vineyard Fast Ferry over Memorial Day weekend. The round-trip fare was $86.50, which included fuel surcharges and port and security fees; not $94.50. (See www.vineyardfastferry.com for current fares.)

title: Coming Next, Court Fights on Guns in Cities
description: WASHINGTON  The individual right to bear arms identified by the Supreme Court on Thursday will have little practical impact in most of the country, legal experts said, though Washingtons comprehensive ban on handguns used for self-defense in the home will have to be revised, and similar laws in several cities are also vulnerable.

title: A Diplomatic Success That Defies the Critics
description: WASHINGTON  North Koreas declaration of its nuclear activities is a triumph of the sort of diplomacy  complicated, plodding, often frustrating  that President Bush and his aides once eschewed as American weakness.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a series of exhibitions in Philadelphia about evolution gave an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for a woman shown looking at an exhibit at the University of Pennsylvania. She is Bonnie Grant  not Bonnie Squires, a friend of Ms. Grants.

title: An Ex-mas Feast
description: Now that my eldest sister, Maisha, was twelve, none of us knew how to relate to her anymore. She had never forgiven our parents for not being rich enough to send her to school. She had been behaving like a cat that was going feral: she came home less and less frequently, staying only to change her clothes and give me some money to pass on to our parents. When home, she avoided them as best she could, as if their presence reminded her of too many things in our lives that needed money. Though she would snap at Baba occasionally, she never said anything to Mama. Sometimes Mama went out of her way to provoke her. "Malaya! Whore! You don't even have breasts yet!" she'd say. Maisha would ignore her.

title: A Close-Knit Trio Turns Itself Into a Quartet for a Night
description: Since officially declaring bandhood around the turn of the millennium, the Bad Plus has convincingly modeled a closed society. Its members  the pianist Ethan Iverson, the bassist Reid Anderson and the drummer David King  all hail from the upper Midwest, where they first played together as teenagers. Their chemistry is reactive but stable, and their methods dont avail much room for outside contributions.

title: Rikers Guards Accused of Passing Contraband to Inmate
description: Two Rikers Island correction officers were fired on Wednesday after they were accused of smuggling marijuana, alcohol and tobacco to an inmate who is awaiting trial in the death of a police officer last July, officials said.

title: China Says It Opposes Politicizing Olympics
description: SHANGHAI  After months of warning other countries not to politicize the summer Olympic Games in Beijing, China has come under criticism from the International Olympic Committee for doing just that.

title: You Talkin to Me, Boys? (Bang-Bang, My Pretties)
description: The money shot in Wanted, its pice-de-special-effects-rsistance and reason for green-lighted being, appears in the opening minutes of this noisy, ultraviolent shoot-em-up with Angelina Jolie, her many tattoos and some guys. A man has soared onto the roof of a high-rise where he has laid a handful of others to waste. Suddenly the camera cuts to his face as a bullet exits his forehead in slow motion, his skin stretching forward as the projectile tears through it, going straight for the camera and our already numbed skulls.

title: Giants to Charge Seat License Fees for New Stadium
description: Less than five months after winning the Super Bowl, the Giants said Thursday that they would charge their fans one-time fees, called personal seat licenses, for every seat in the stadium that they were building with the Jets.

title: Suit Claims UBS Misled Investors
description: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has sued UBS on the grounds of fraud, saying that the firm misled clients when it sold them auction-rate securities and that it pushed the increasingly risky instruments on individual investors to reduce its own potential losses.

title: Selected Studies: Vasectomy
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Mayo Shows That He Was Made for New York
description: Fifteen minutes into the conversation, you begin to wish that O. J. Mayo were being drafted by your N.B.A. team. Especially if your team is the hapless Knicks, a franchise lost in darkness that has not had a great point guard in more than three decades. They incurred the wrath of fans Thursday by making Danilo Gallinari of Italy their No. 1 pick, passing up D. J. Augustin of Texas and Eric Gordon of Indiana.

title: New Flavors for Addresses on the Web Are on the Way
description: PARIS  Move over .com and .org. Get ready for a nearly infinite variety of new Web addresses ending in words like .perfume, .sports and .paris.

title: Gloom Descends Over Wall Street Again
description: Once more, gloom is descending over Wall Street.

title: Corrections: The Harbor View Hotel & Resort and Azulera Resort Village
description: A report in the Breaking Ground column last Friday about the Harbor View Hotel & Resort in Edgartown, Mass., using information from a representative of the developer, referred incorrectly to several phases of construction at the site.

title: Mother of 2 Killed at Y.M.C.A. Pool
description: A 31-year-old woman was shot and killed at a Y.M.C.A. pool in Montclair, N.J., on Thursday night by the father of her two children, officials said, as her son and daughter and dozens of other children and parents watched from a few feet away.

title: Retirees Find the Time May Be Right to Buy
description: THE euphoria is past. The era of rampant house flipping is gone. What was once a seemingly unstoppable climb in home prices has given way to a plunge in value in many areas.

title: N.B.A. Draft and 2 Trades Change Outlook in East
description: An N.B.A. draft that promised wild twists, trades and misdirection instead unfolded with an almost predictable rhythm Thursday evening.

title: Bush Rebuffs Hard-Liners to Ease North Korean Curbs
description: WASHINGTON  Two days ago, during an off-the-record session with a group of foreign policy experts, Vice President Dick Cheney got a question he did not want to answer. Mr. Vice President, asked one of them, I understand that on Wednesday or Thursday, we are going to de-list North Korea from the terrorism blacklist. Could you please set the context for this decision?

title: Wicked Witch Bounces in Like a Bohemian Big Sister
description: When you are as closely identified with a role as Idina Menzel is with Elphaba, the Wicked Witch of the West in the Broadway musical Wicked, how do you step out of it into a concert without alienating your fans (in her case mostly girls and young women) who expect her to be a version of Elphaba? That was the question Ms. Menzel wrestled with in her eccentric concert on Wednesday evening at Town Hall, where she appeared with a drum-heavy rock quartet and two backup singers.

title: With 3 You Get Egg Roll and a Side of Adventure
description: Three Delivery is a great-looking new prime-time cartoon on the Nicktoons network. Set in Chinatown in San Francisco, it features three young orphans who save the world nightly while delivering food for their adoptive Nanas restaurant, Wus Garden. The action takes place after dark, and the animation is a riot of reds, greens and yellows: neon signs, rampaging dragons, rivers of hot-and-sour soup.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Scientist, Claiming Bias, Sues U.S. Over Revoked Clearance
description: PITTSBURGH  An Egyptian-born nuclear physicist who worked in a government-financed laboratory here for 18 years filed a lawsuit on Thursday saying the Energy Department had revoked his security clearance because of his ethnicity, his Muslim faith and comments he made criticizing the war in Iraq.

title: Justices, Ruling 5-4, Endorse Personal Right to Own Gun
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday embraced the long-disputed view that the Second Amendment protects an individual right to own a gun for personal use, ruling 5 to 4 that there is a constitutional right to keep a loaded handgun at home for self-defense.

title: Vic Hershkowitz, Dominant Handball Star, Dies at 89
description: Vic Hershkowitz, a New York City fireman who learned handball on the playgrounds of Brooklyn and was considered by many to be the sports most brilliant player, died Monday in Plantation, Fla. He was 89 and lived in Davie, Fla.

title: Marching Noisily Toward Late Middle Age
description: As increasing numbers of baby boomers march noisily into late middle age and early dinners, the wrinkly romance (a genre generally ignored by youth-obsessed Hollywood unless the wrinkles belong to Diane Keaton and Jack Nicholson) could become a multiplex staple. Look out for softer popcorn and larger subtitles.

title: London Exchange Plans New Trading System
description: London Stock Exchange Group, seeking to regain a leading role, said on Thursday that it would create a pan-European trading system in partnership with Lehman Brothers.

title: Foreign Investment in City Is Growing, Report Finds
description: More than one-tenth of all the goods and services produced in New York City and 1 of every 20 jobs are supplied by companies controlled by foreign investors, according to a report scheduled to be released on Friday by the Partnership for New York City.

title: U.S. Beef to Reach South Korean Markets Next Week
description: SEOUL -- Thousands of tons of American beef, held for months in South Korean warehouses because of concerns about mad cow disease, will be released to the markets next week, officials said on Thursday.

title: Corrections
H.I.V. Diagnosis Rates Continue to Rise Among Young Men, African-Americans
description: Diagnoses of H.I.V. and AIDS in men who have sex with men rose significantly between 2001 and 2006 while declining in other demographic groups, the federal Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday.

title: DDT on Ice
description: It has been getting ever harder to pretend that Antarctica is a pristine place. We like to think of it as being scoured clean by hostile winds and extreme cold. But more and more, Antarctica, like the Arctic, shows the lasting scars of human negligence.

title: Oooooh, Canada
description: LATE last Saturday evening, La Ronde, an amusement park thats just a stones throw from downtown Montreal on an island in the St. Lawrence River, seemed an unlikely venue for a world-class competition. Teenagers with the giggles and other signs of roller-coaster overexposure contemplated yet another ride on the Super Mange or Le Monstre. Younger children, slowed by too much barbe  papa (cotton candy) and poutine (that Qubcois concoction of French fries, cheese curds and gravy), were willed along by weary parents. The occasional large Fred Flintstone or Scooby-Doo plush doll appeared among the midway crowd, bounty from booths like Frappez la Taupe (Whack the Mole) and Roul-Boul (a form of skeeball).

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Corrections
description: The Big City column on June 16, about the Abrahamson family, African-American Hasidic Jews who moved from Omaha to Brooklyn, included an erroneous distinction from the family matriarch about her family. The Abrahamsons were not in fact the only Hasids in Omaha when they lived there.

title: Water, Soap and Open Air
description: SUMMER means the beach, the sand, the sun, the pool  factors that prompt many second-home owners to think about installing an outdoor shower. Whether the goal is to wash off the ocean brine after a swim, to prep for the pool before you jump in, or to serenely bathe au naturel outdoors, an exterior shower can be a beautiful thing. But building and maintaining one takes planning.

title: Europe Tells Airlines to Pay for Emissions
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union reached a landmark agreement Thursday to cap emissions from aircraft, raising the stakes in an increasingly ferocious battle with the United States over how to regulate global greenhouse gases.

title: As Africas Horrors Rage, Suffer the Little Children
description: Its Christmastime in Kenya in An Ex-Mas Feast, the first short story in Uwem Akpans startling debut collection, Say Youre One of Them. The narrator is Jigana, an 8-year-old boy. His 12-year-old sister is a prostitute, which makes her Jiganas most fortunate family member by a long shot. His 10-year-old sister wants to follow the older girls example. There are also 2-year-old twins and a baby whos used as a prop for begging. The familys most precious Christmas gift is a container of sniffable glue.

title: Twenty Five Years Later, Dave Righettis No-Hitter
description: It was a warm holiday afternoon nearly 25 years ago, a perfect day for July 4th baseball. For the Yankees Dave Righetti, it was also a perfect day to pitch a no-hitter against the Boston Red Sox. On that afternoon, Righetti whiffed Wade Boggs, flung his arms in the air and celebrated his doodle of a day at Yankee Stadium.

title: Fridays Link: The Illustrated Work-Life
description: I have been spending some time over at Ribbon Farm, the blog of Venkatesh Rao, who brings fresh insights to the discussion on work-life balance through whimsical and thoughtful drawings like the one above. The drawing comes fairly close to what my blurry work-life looks like most weeks, though I still aim for at least a day or two a week that look like the Sunday on Mr. Raos then drawing (though not necessarily on a weekend).

title: Now That Europe has Capped Airline Emissions, Will America Follow?
description: With the EU capping emissions on intercontinental flights, American airlines might be forced out of Europe if they fail to comply. (Daniel Munoz/Reuters)

title: Donadoni Out for Italy; Lippi Back In
description: Four days. Four days is all it took Italian soccer officials to banish Roberto Donadoni and replace him as national team coach with  Marcello Lippi.

title: Personal Seat Licenses: Jets to Giants, You First
description: The Giants and the Jets are sharing in all aspects of their new stadium.

title: Euro 2008: Spain vs. Russia
description: Spain beat Russia, advancing to the finals of the 2008 European Soccer Championships.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 63 Washington
description: Location: Seattle.

What an Insult
description: More of your user-generated comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: A weekly roundup of the latest from the T Web site
description: With her penchant for armor and feathers, the fashion muse Daphne Guinness has been to known to turn heads. But in her short film The Phenomenology of Body, the beer heiress cum director puts the politics of fashion on display. Taking the viewer through a revolving journey of how clothes have defined, constricted and liberated women throughout history, Guinness presents a stark catalog of vintage, new and costume pieces. The result, a spare and thoughtful voyage set to Great Release by LCD Soundsystem, reveals both the warrior and swan in Guinness. T: Online unveils  the exclusive short here.

title: Jesus Held Hostage
description: For some reason this story from earlier this year eluded Laugh Lines, until now. From a local TV news station in Michigan:

title: Part-Time Pickups
description: Pontiac has announced it will begin selling the Holden Ute, a car-based pickup much like the sporty haulers that Americans had known years earlier as the Chevrolet El Camino and Ford Ranchero.

title: AniBoom.com Draws $10 Million
description: AniBoom.com has raised $10 million in funding led by venture capital firm Draper Fisher, Reuters reported. The Internet site allows animators to create and share their work.

title: Middle Eastern and Asian Investors Flock Into U.S. and European Property
description: A wave of capital from the Middle East and Asia could be on its way into the ailing U.S. and European property markets, as a weak dollar and falling asset prices lure sovereign wealth funds and institutional investors.

title: Duke Energy Acquires Catamount in $320 Million Deal
description: In a privately negotiated deal, Diamond Castle Holdings has sold Catamount Energy to Duke Energy for $320 million including debt.

title: KSG Raises $194 Million in I.P.O.
description: KSK Energy has completed an initial public offering to raise $194 million just four months after fixing the price at the bottom of the indicated range, Finance Asia reported.

title: News Corp. Could Bid for European Pay TV Players
description: The News Corporation may bid for two major pay-TV players, Germanys Premiere and Spains Digital+, in a move that could give more responsibility to James Murdoch, son of News Corp. chief Rupert Murdoch, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.

title: Asia Deal-Making Rises in 1st Half of 2008
description: Mergers and acquisitions across Asia are headed to mark an 8.7 percent rise to $362 billion in volume for the first half of 2008, after accelerating in the second quarter, according to preliminary data from Thomson Reuters.

title: Virgin Green Fund Raises $199 Million
description: Virgin Groups first green investment fund has attracted the interest of such maiden investors Wolverhampton City Council and Calpers, The Financial Times reported.

title: Microsoft Said to Find Deal for Powerset
description: Microsoft has agreed to buy Silicon Valley semantic search engine Powerset, Venture Beat reported. The acquisition price is rumored to be slightly more than $100 million with an announcement expected in July.

title: Are Spacs Back in Fashion?
description: Navios Maritime Acquisitions $220 million initial public offering this week could be an indication that special purpose acquisition companies are back in favor, The Daily Deal reported.

title: Everbright in Shanghai I.P.O.
description: Everbright Securities is gearing up for an initial public offering to sell as many as 520 million shares in Shanghai.

title: National Australia Bank Eyeing HBOS Unit
description: National Australia Bank may bid for HBOSs Australian unit, Bloomberg reported citing people with knowledge of the matter.

title: China South Locomotive May Roll With I.P.O.
description: China South Locomotive & Rolling Stock may sell a 30 percent stake in a Shanghai initial public offering to help fund nearly 9 billion yuan ($1.3 billion) of projects, Bloomberg reported citing a company filing.

title: Judge Rejects Hedge Funds Attempts to Block Candover-Expro Deal
description: Britains High Court has rejected a last-gasp effort mounted by a group of hedge funds to block Candovers 1.8 billion pound bid for oil services group Expro, The Telegraph reported.

title: GMR Takes Half of InterGen for $1.1 Billion
description: GMR Infrastructure has bought 50 percent of InterGen from AIG Highstar for an equity value of $1.1 billion. The deal marks the largest ever acquisition of a global energy utility by an Indian company, Finance Asia reported.

title: Stray Questions for: Mary Jo Salter
description: Mary Jo Salter is the author of A Phone Call to the Future: New and Selected Poems. She is a professor in the writing seminars at Johns Hopkins University.

title: Bank of America to Cut 7,500 Jobs After Countrywide Deal
description: Bank of America on Thursday said it expects to eliminate about 7,500 jobs over the next two years after it completes its acquisition of Countrywide Financial, the largest U.S. mortgage lender.

title: Apollo Has Cut 1,500 Jobs at U.K.s Countrywide
description: Apollo Management has slashed more than 1,500 jobs at Countrywide since buying the British company at last years market peak, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Bradford & Bingley Shareholders Up in Arms but Cowdery Remains Resolute
description: Bradford & Bingley investors are clamoring for an urgent clarification of the agreement between the lender and Texas Pacific Group because of growing fears that the private equity firms deal would make it almost impossible for the company to negotiate with other bidders.

title: America  An Iraqis First Impression
description: Suadad al-Salhy is an Iraqi reporter who recently joined The New York Times in Iraq. In May she was one of five Iraqi journalists who visited the United States on a reporting tour organized by the State Department to learn about How Americas Middle East Policy is Formulated.

title: Cadence May Have to Raise Bid for Mentor, Analysts Say
description: Earlier this month, Mentor Graphics rejected an unsolicited $1.6 billion takeover bid from Cadence Design Systems Inc. Analysts now say Cadence will have to up the ante in order to succeed in buying the rival chip design software maker, The Daily Deal reported.

title: For Smaller U.S. Banks, Risk Management Might Become Easier
description: The majority of U.S. banks would have the option to adopt alternative risk-based capital adequacy rules based on the Basel II accords, under a proposal agreed to by a top U.S. banking regulator, Reuters reported.

title: Spoleto Italy: The Menottis Are History
description: SPOLETO, Italy  Menotti? Menotti who?

title: As Markets Plunge, Deal-Making Plummets
description: Gloom has descended over Wall Street once again. While the price of oil is rising, the health of the financial sector is flagging, taking yet another heavy toll on the markets.

title: Im In Like With You Pulls in $1.5 Million Round
description: Social-network-turned-gaming-site Im In Like With You has raised $1.5 million of venture funding led by Spark Capital, CNet News reported.

title: He Says That to All the Possible Running Mates
description: CINCINNATI  You are a (comparatively) young Republican making a name for yourself, and your name keeps cropping up on media lists of potential running mates for Senator John McCain. But with the McCain campaign playing its cards so close to the vest, it can be maddeningly hard to figure out where you stand.

title: Another Yahoo Overhaul as It Tries to Right Itself
description: Under pressure from many shareholders for its poor performance and for its failure to complete a deal with Microsoft, Yahoo is doing something it has done several times before: reorganizing itself.

title: Letters: Anonymous Sources and the Apostate Column
description: Re Culling the Anonymous Sources (June 8 ) : I believe the problem with accountability of anonymous statements can be solved with a simple baseball-like statistic. Reporters and their editors should carry a believability average  some ratio of proved true, still unknown truth, proved false  whereby anonymous statements are reviewed multiple times after those statements were published.If individual writers and editors had individual ratings attached to them, the public would be better informed about anonymous sources while those reporters and editors would have to think harder about what to publish because their entire decision-making history would be on the line.Scott KaczmarekSeattle, June 8, 2008

title: Your Sisters Dress

Last evening, a beautiful Paris sort of evening, Mr. Alloux and I were on our way to Dries Van Notens show in the 15th, at the site of a former slaughter house for horses. Our destination prompted a culinary discussion (in my limited French) about the differences between horse and beef. Mr. Alloux said that horse meat was once a commonplace in France and that, in terms of taste, you could barely distinguish it from beef. He asked me if horse was ever popular in the States, and I replied that it may have been at one time in some places but that we Americans tended to keep Nelly in the barn.

In another, a Thomas Jefferson statue bound for Monticello. And down a hallway, an early version of a sitting James Madison that will one day join a statue of his wife, Dolley Madison, and take up residence outside their historic home at Montpelier.

title: Man Sentenced for Plundering Body Parts
description: A New Jersey dentist, Michael Mastromarino, 44, was sentenced to 18 to 54 years in prison on Friday after pleading guilty to being the mastermind behind a multimillion-dollar enterprise that harvested tissue and body parts from funeral homes and sold them for use in transplants and medical research. Among the bodies plundered was that of Alistair Cooke, the British journalist and former host of Masterpiece Theater. Mr. Mastromarino, 44, had pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on March 18 to numerous charges of enterprise corruption, reckless endangerment and body stealing. He admitted leading a harvesting operation that sold hundreds, perhaps thousands, of bone fragments and bits of flesh from people who had never given their consent to being donors. The body parts were sold to tissue processors around the country, and eventually to medical companies for use in surgical transplants like bone and skin grafts.
