title: Andy Grove Offers an Energy Solution
description: Andrew S. Grove, Intels former chairman and chief executive, is wading into the energy debate, arguing that Americas national goal of energy independence is misguided. He reasons that a more sensible approach for both environmental and political reasons would be shifting to a goal of energy resilience.

title: Carey and Chris
description: Chris Balogh met Carey Migliaccio while on tour with rock bands in Aruba. Three years later, he gave up his life on the road, for her.

title: Carey and Chris
description: Chris Balogh met Carey Migliaccio while on tour with rock bands in Aruba. Three years later, he gave up his life on the road, for her.

title: Gunnin' for That #1 Spot
description: A documentary features several N.B.A. draft picks participating in a tournament for high school players in Rucker Park in Harlem.

title: The Return of Kei Igawa. Believe It.
description: The Yankees lost by 15-6 in Game 1 of the doubleheader, but they have the solution. Get ready, folks, for Sidney Ponson and the return of Kei Igawa.

title: Smiling Through
description: Who decided that its variety thats the spice of life?

title: The Disconnect Between Doctors and Patients
description: The Well blog has been busy the past week with comments from patients frustrated with their doctors, and doctors frustrated with their patients.

title: Looking at the Heart
description: An example of the images generated by CTA. Narrated by Dr. Harvey Hecht of The Lenox Hill Heart and Vascular Institute of New York.

title: Countdown to Sundays Final: Get Soccer Fever in Berlin
description: by Kimberly Bradley

title: McCain Doubts Forums Chances
description: Senator John McCain said Friday that he thought it was unlikely that he would get the one-on-one, town-hall-style meetings he had been asking Senator Barack Obama to hold with him during the summer.

title: Violence and the Vote
description: Thousands of Zimbabweans have been beaten or displaced from their homes in election-related violence.

title: Prefer to Sit by the Window, Aisle or ATM?
description: Weekend Update: If you read this post earlier, you might want to return to its comments, where Ms. Maynard will be addressing them all weekend.The modern airplane creates a new geographical dimension, Wendell Wilkie declared in 1943 after returning from the world tour he conducted as an envoy for President Franklin D. Roosevelt. There are no distant places any longer: the world is small and the world is one.

title: Church Has Outside Chance of Playing This Weekend
description: Ryan Church could rejoin the Mets as soon as Saturday if he felt well after playing the outfield Friday night in Class A Brooklyns game against Aberdeen. He went 0 for 3 and played seven innings in right field. But Manager Jerry Manuel said Church, on the disabled list since June 6 because of post-concussion symptoms, would have only an outside chance of playing this weekend. If hes not quite ready, Sunday could be a good day for him, could be, Manuel said. That would be kind of pushing it anyway. Manuel said Church would definitely not start Saturday, when Andy Pettitte, a left-hander, is scheduled to pitch. Church went 3 for 3 and played right field Thursday for Brooklyn but the Mets recommended he play another game before evaluating him.

title: Montreal International Jazz Festival
description: Concerts by Montreal native Leonard Cohen served as a prelude to the 2008 festival which began Thursday.

title: U.S. Track Trials: Perfect Weather for a Heptathlete
description: EUGENE, Ore.  The organizers of the United States track and field Olympic trials have been fretting this week about a coming heat wave, which threatens to bring this weekends temperatures into the 90s.

title: A Fearful Day in Zimbabwe
description: Portraits of Zimbabweans outside the capital. With President Robert Mugabe the sole candidate, many voted only out of fear. Ink-stained fingers are proof of voting.

title: Paris: Showing Off
description: The French are feeling as economically pinched as Americans, but I get the sense they are busting to look fashionable. Ive noticed it all day as I go around to shows and look at people on the streets. Heading to Montmartre, I saw a young woman20s, thin, medium heightin a pair of slim gray shorts that ended mid-thigh, a loose navy popover top, and a classic pair of black stilettos. Super chic. Ive seen slim-fitting shorts with a sailor front, worn with chunky black sandals and a cream silk blouse. The look is tailored and sexy. And there are lots of women in mini skirts; this afternoon I saw a woman in a flaring navy cotton skirt with a red and white striped polo shirt. The best-looking dress at the moment seems to be a dark tunic. Ive noticed a lot of the guys in the front row also wearing shorts, especially as a kind of nerd school-boy uniform with knee socks and maybe a pastel vest and a tie. And its a little surprising how many shows have hatsthe porkpie, the scarecrow, the snap-brim. Shades of next summer

title: A Team-Record 9 R.B.I. Leaves the Enigmatic Delgado Just Happy
description: Carlos Delgados first home run Friday afternoon would have been good enough, a grand slam that landed in the nether reaches of the stands in right-center at Yankee Stadium, a few rows below the video board that displayed his smiling face.

title: Walking, Falling and Bouncing Through a Mysterious America
description: LENOX, Mass.  There has been plenty of anticipation for Mark Morriss new Romeo and Juliet, opening at Bard Summerscape in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., on July 4. Nonetheless, many dance fans didnt even know that this week Mr. Morris was presenting another world premiere.

title: In a Virtual Galaxy, Assembly Is Required
description: Most video games can be likened to a theme park. The fun, like a roller coasters, has been entirely created by a team of professionals, and the players then progress through each loop, each dip, each turn in a way that has been meticulously designed to produce a specific effect. Books and films tell stories in a similar way.

title: Number of Salmonella Illnesses Grows
description: The number of reported illnesses from the salmonella outbreak associated with raw tomatoes has risen to 810 cases in 36 states and the District of Columbia, federal officials said. Investigators are also looking into other ingredients that could be the source of the outbreak, although it remains most closely linked with tomatoes, said Dr. Patricia Griffin of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Ransom Frees Lawmakers Kin in Mexico
description: A Mexican citizen who is a distant relative of a prominent congressman from Texas was kidnapped last week in Ciudad Jurez, Mexico, and then released within three days after the victims immediate family paid ransom of $32,000.

title: Class-Action Lawyer Gets 5 Years in Bribery Case
description: Richard F. Scruggs, whose successful battle against the tobacco industry in the 1990s made him one of the countrys best-known plaintiffs lawyers, was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison for conspiring to bribe a judge.

title: A Goya Downgraded
description: The Prado Museum in Madrid said on Thursday that El Coloso, right, the oil painting of a looming giant long attributed to Francisco de Goya, was probably painted by an assistant. The authenticity of the painting, which was created during Napoleons occupation of Spain, had been disputed by a Goya specialist at the museum, Manuela Mena, The Independent of London reported. Stylistically, it is completely alien to Goya, said Ms. Mena. The person who painted the bulls in El Coloso knew nothing about the anatomy of a bull, which Goya knew everything about. Jos Luis Dez, a curator at the Prado, also claims that initials at the bottom corner of the work belong to Asensio Juli, Goyas assistant, The Telegraph reported. The painting has been omitted from Goya in Times of War, a special exhibition commemorating the bicentennial of the start of the Spanish War of Independence, which runs through July 13.

title: For Now, Ponson Fits Into Yankees Puzzle
description: The new savior was sitting beside the entrance to the Yankees clubhouse. The pitcher who was charged with making sure that Friday was not a total waste for the Yankees was waiting for his teammates to shower and dress. Sidney Ponson, the accidental Yankee, was actually smiling.

title: Scientist Is Paid Millions by U.S. in Anthrax Suit
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department announced Friday that it would pay $4.6 million to settle a lawsuit filed by Steven J. Hatfill, a former Army biodefense researcher intensively investigated as a person of interest in the deadly anthrax letters of 2001.

title: Lottery Numbers
Working Together, Obama and Clinton Try to Show Unity
description: UNITY, N.H.  Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton set off on their maiden political voyage on Friday, trading their rivalry from the presidential primary battle for a newfound display of harmony intended to set a fresh tone for any Democrats still harboring bitterness from their grueling duel.

title: Face to Face: A Council of Online Gamers
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  This city near the top of the world has a distinguished history of hosting summit meetings. Presidents, prime ministers and premiers have come here to discuss their differences and chart earths future.

title: Senate Democrats Attack Republicans on Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats moved swiftly on Friday to assail Republican senators for voting against a major Medicare bill and said the Republicans should be held responsible for a 10 percent cut in payments to doctors that takes effect next week.

title: Royalty Bill Moves Forward
description: Musicians, singers and record companies seeking more radio royalties won an initial victory in Congress on Thursday. The House Subcommittee on Courts, the Internet and Intellectual Property passed the Performance Rights Act, which would reverse terrestrial radios exemption from paying royalties to the performers of sound recordings, which satellite and Internet radio stations are required to pay. The measure still faces opposition in the House and in the Senate, which is considering its own version.

title: Fox Tops Slow Night
description: Fox ranked No. 1 in the ratings on a slow summer Thursday of network television, as So You Think You Can Dance led the night over all with 8.6 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The 9 p.m. dance competition followed Foxs 8 p.m. game show, Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? (6.9 million), which edged past CBSs rerun of Million Dollar Password (6.8 million) to win its time slot. CBS finished second for the night, attracting 7.2 million viewers at 9 for a CSI repeat and 5.7 million for Swingtown at 10. NBC was third, with Last Comic Standing from 8 to 10 (5.3 million) followed by Fear Itself (4.5 million). ABC earned a fourth-place finish with reruns of Ugly Betty at 8 (3.5 million) and Greys Anatomy at 9 (3.4 million). At 10, the first part of Hopkins, ABCs six-part documentary filmed inside the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, led its time slot by a slim margin with 5.8 million viewers.

title: North Koreas Intent in Razing Tower Is Unclear
description: TOKYO  International television crews were invited to reclusive North Korea on Friday to witness the destruction of the cooling tower at the countrys main nuclear weapons plant. Viewers around the world later watched the most visible symbol of the Norths nuclear ambitions collapse in a cloud of shattered concrete.

title: Albanys Latest Haul
description: The New York State Legislature passed more than 800 bills in the session that ended this week. Some were merely elaborate press releases  especially those that passed only one house but can still be waved proudly at this years voters as proof of statesmanship. Others were favors  somebody wanted the deposit on beer kegs reduced from $75 to $50, and it was done. And a few were actually worthwhile.

title: Saxophone Leaps Over Wall of Funk
description: Joshua Redman is a saxophonist of such intelligence and energy that you could probably place him in any musical setting, and he would find a way to make himself at home. Sitting in with the trio Soulive on Thursday night for a JVC Jazz Festival performance at Le Poisson Rouge, he did just that.

title: Oil Hits New High as Dow Flirts With Bear Territory
description: The bear peeked out of its cave on Friday.

title: Gazprom Investors Elect an Ex-Prime Minister
description: The revolving door between politics and business in Russia spun on Friday as Gazprom shareholders elected former prime minister Viktor A. Zubkov as chairman of the board, replacing Dmitri A. Medvedev, who stepped down after he succeeded Vladimir V. Putin as president. The companys chief executive, Aleksei B. Miller, retained his position. Also at the meeting, Gazprom floated a proposal to expand its retail business in Western Europe with a chain of natural gas fueling stations for passenger cars.

title: For Gay, a Defeat Is Followed by a Tuneup
description: EUGENE, Ore.  An absent persons shadow will loom large over the mens 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials  Usain Bolt of Jamaica, who set a startling world record of 9.72 seconds at the Reebok Grand Prix meet in New York on May 31.

title: Russian Shift: A European Charm Campaign
description: KHANTY-MANSIYSK, Russia  The food was nouvelle cuisine, the wine was French and the coffee was served on a terrace with a spectacular view of the Siberian countryside. At his first summit meeting with the European Union, the new Russian president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, dispensed with the aggressive rhetoric of his predecessor, Vladimir V. Putin, and tried a new tactic on the Europeans: being nice to them.

title: Mexico Accepts Anti-Narcotics Aid From U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY  With a deadly drug war spreading around the country, beleaguered Mexican officials on Friday welcomed $400 million in anti-narcotics assistance in a bill that was given final Congressional approval in Washington on Thursday night.

title: Unity Is Crowded
description: Unity, N.H.

title: Laughter From the Assembly Line
description: Factory, a new series beginning on Sunday, is the first original comedy from Spike TV, which makes no effort in expanding its brand. Happen on it serendipitously and you would think, I must be watching Spike, the television network for men with 40-inch waists and wives theyd like to stick in a witness protection program.

title: Citing Weather Forecast, U.S. Postpones Transfer of Authority for Anbar Security to Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  As funerals were held on Friday near the site of a suicide bombing in Anbar Province the day before, the American military delayed plans to transfer authority over security in the province to Iraqi forces. The final death toll in the suicide bombing was placed at 20.

title: Charles Parkhurst, Who Tracked Down Looted Art, Dies at 95
description: Charles Parkhurst, a museum director in Baltimore and Washington and one of the monuments men, an Allied Forces team that chased down leads, pried open crates and snooped around museums, salt mines and castles in search of art stolen by the Nazis during World War II, died on Wednesday at his home in Amherst, Mass. He was 95.

title: Travelers Face Deep Flight Cuts by Summers End
description: With summer barely under way, it may seem too early for travelers to start thinking about Labor Day. But that is when significant cuts in the airlines fleets and schedules will begin taking effect, making for a particularly jarring end to summer.

title: Goldman Sachs Sees More Pain for Home Builders
description: Higher refinancing costs may leave American home builders, including D. R. Horton and Lennar, the two largest, with negative cash flow in 2009, according to a report by Goldman Sachs. Goldman changed its neutral rating on homebuilders to cautious. Goldman holds at least $15 million of D. R. Hortons debt, according to the report.

title: Challenges to Bans on Handguns Begin
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Using the new judicial muscle provided by the Supreme Courts affirmation of the right to bear arms, the National Rifle Association and another pro-gun group sued San Francisco and its housing authority on Friday to invalidate a ban on handguns in public housing.

title: Hoping the Upswing Is Nigh
description: DONT worry! All the bad news about the economy is actually good news, Kiplingers Personal Finance says as part of a package of articles highlighted on its cover with the headline: Market Update: For Stocks, the Worst Is Over.

title: The Leadership to Battle Religious Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief of 9/11 Health Programs Gains Support
description: Labor leaders, business executives and members of New Yorks Congressional delegation say they fear that the federal governments health programs for ground zero workers will be endangered if Dr. John Howard, who has coordinated those programs since 2006, ends his term as scheduled on July 5.

title: Bollywood Flavors Opening of Spoleto
description: SPOLETO, Italy  A cast member of Padmavati, the opening-night production at the Festival of Two Worlds here on Friday, ambled slowly up a narrow and steep street on her way to the theater. She was plenty early and plenty wrinkled, even without makeup.

title: To Build a Young-Adult Crowd, ABC Family Gets More Physical
description: LOS ANGELES  The Secret Life of the American Teenager, a coming cable drama, opens with a 15-year-old getting pregnant at band camp. Subsequent scenes depict two teenagers, each asking adults for free condoms.

title: Prosecutors Play Down Donaghys Help
description: Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, has overstated the extent of his cooperation with the government, federal prosecutors said in a court filing Friday. But the prosecutors did not specifically refute any of the recent charges Donaghy made about N.B.A. officiating.

title: Experts to Discuss One Puzzling Autism Case, as a Second Case Has Arisen
description: Federal health officials on Sunday will call together some of the worlds leading experts on an obscure disease to discuss the controversial case of a 9-year-old girl from Athens, Ga., who became autistic after receiving numerous vaccinations.

title: Off the Fire Escape Is in Play
description: The police will close off three side streets next weekend in Manhattan to serve as the asphalt playing fields for what East Harlem graybeards are hailing as the world series of stickball. Thats right, no more cheese-it-the-cops moments. In the old days, stickball was a deliciously intrusive blight on urban order, powered by three-sewer home-run blasts soaring above dangerous traffic intersections. Now the series players  more than a few in their 60s  apply for permits.

title: Calculating the Worth of East River Waterfalls
description: Amid all the hoopla over Olafur Eliassons New York City Waterfalls, which opened on Thursday along the East River, one might think the city was in for a windfall.

title: North Korea Destroys Tower at Nuclear Site
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a gesture demonstrating its commitment to halt its nuclear weapons program, North Korea blew up the most prominent symbol of its plutonium production Friday.

title: The Courts Landmark Ruling on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Want to Play Handball? Better Not Forget Your Ego
description: Around the Coney Island handball courts, the handball mecca of New York City, there was the usual thwock of rubber balls against concrete walls, sneakers sliding on sun-baked courts and raspy trash being talked among the players, many of whom had deep tans, taut bodies and egos big enough to play great playground handball.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A entry in the Whats on Today television highlights on Friday for 20/20 on ABC, using information from the network, gave outdated information on segments about FitFlops sandals and a deadly love triangle. After the section went to press, they were pulled from the program. (Go to Article)

title: Dutrow Says Drug Violation Is Overblown
description: Concerned that he has been unfairly labeled a cheat, Rick Dutrow, the trainer of Big Brown, said Friday that his latest drug offense had been overblown and insisted that he did not purposely break any rules.

title: Spate of Changes in Airline Industry Heightens the Need to Plan Ahead
description: Planning to fly this fall? Better have a backup plan.

title: A Small Slam Appears Beatable, but ...
description: The diagramed deal is from the final of the Reisinger Knockout Teams, played on May 23 at the Edgar Kaplan Eastern States Regional in New York. The winners were Richard DeMartino of Riverside, Conn.; William Ehlers of Jersey City; and John Fout, Michael Kopera, John Ramos and John Rengstorff of New York.

title: Floodwaters Threaten 100 Homes as a Levee Falters in Eastern Missouri
description: WINFIELD, Mo.  The Pin Oak levee, the last remaining barrier between about 100 homes here and the lakelike Mississippi River, finally gave way before dawn Friday. But the fight to save those homes continued into the evening as the authorities coordinated an effort to wall them off with a new sand-filled barricade.

title: Footnotes
description: Nelson Mandela, below, celebrated his 90th birthday on Friday in London with a concert in Hyde Park to support his global campaign to fight AIDS. Proceeds from the show will go to 46664, the charity named after Mr. Mandelas prison number and dedicated to raising awareness of the H.I.V./AIDS epidemic. Mr. Mandela turns 90 on July 18. Video of the concert, which was scheduled to include performances by Amy Winehouse, Josh Groban and the Soweto Gospel Choir among others, is available at 46664.com. ... New York Theater Workshop has announced its 2008-9 season, which will include new works by Peter Brook, Michael Weller and Naomi Wallace. The company also announced the inaugural season of Off Again, a series of concert versions of revivals of Off Broadway musicals. Proposed shows include Iphigenia in Concert, by Peter Link; Promenade, written by Maria Irene Fornes, with music by Al Carmines; and The Waves, written by Lisa Peterson, with music by David Bucknam.

title: Revisiting a Debut Album and Its Semi-Confessions
description: Back in the early 1990s, Liz Phair was hanging out with indie-rockers in Chicago and quietly writing songs on her own. The ones she released on her 1993 debut album, Exile in Guyville (ATO), spoke so frankly that the album sold half a million copies and has just been re-released. Ms. Phair, 41, and her band have done four sold-out concerts, playing it from start to finish, including two New York shows at the Hiro Ballroom. Fifteen years seems like a minute, she said.

title: Nice Spot to Eat After Golf, but Women Are Barred
description: PHOENIX  When the men of the Phoenix Country Club saw their feeding ways in peril, they did not tarry. Some sent nasty e-mail messages, hectored players on the fairway and, for good measure, urinated on a fellow club members pecan tree.

title: Fitch Weighs Lower Rating for Wachovia
description: Fitch Ratings may lower the credit ratings of Wachovia, the bank that ousted its chief executive after greater-than-expected mortgage losses. In a report Friday, Fitch said that Wachovia, based in Charlotte, N.C., increased its loan loss reserve by $2 billion as of March 31, which represented only about 1.2 percent of the banks $170 billion mortgage portfolio. About 70 percent of Wachovias mortgages are option adjustable-rate mortgages that let borrowers skip part of their payment and add the sum to their principal. The company declined to comment.

title: Venture Investors Wrap Up an Unusually Bleak Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  So far this has been a challenging year for companies hoping to go public. But it has been even rougher on venture capitalists who were hoping to get a big payday from such an offering.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,105 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: The Europeans Step Up
description: It has been nearly two years since the United Nations ordered Iran to stop enriching uranium. Tehran continues to defy that order, and its scientists are getting closer to mastering a process that is the hardest part of building a nuclear weapon. So we welcome the European Unions decision  after much foot-dragging  to impose new sanctions on Iran that go beyond what the United Nations Security Council has mandated.

title: Economy Can Wait; Stimulate Your Savings
description: ITS one of those classic ant-versus-grasshopper financial decisions, and millions of Americans are facing it.

title: Im So Old, (Insert Punch Line)
description: John McCain, when I was born, you were nearly six years older than my mother. Now, seven years into her retirement, you want a new job: the hardest job in the world. Wow!

title: Yankees and Mets Two Games Are Miles Apart
description: The Mets arrived at Yankee Stadium in full uniform Friday morning, like the varsity busing to meet a rival across town. If schoolyard rules had really applied, the game would have been over in the top of the eighth inning, by virtue of the 10-run rule. There was, after all, another game to play.

title: China Is Just One Market for Travel Expansion
description: Ctrip.com, a nine-year-old online travel agency based in Shanghai, and traded on the Nasdaq, introduced an English-language Web site this year that offers the companys leisure and business travel services within China. Last month, it began selling packages for the Beijing Summer Olympics with air transportation from the United States.

title: In a Collection of Memorabilia, Politics at Its Most Boisterous
description: One of the great unanswerable questions of the exuberant exhibition Campaigning for President: New York and the American Election, which opened this week at the Museum of the City of New York, concerns a handsome 1888 ceramic chamber pot that sports an elegant monogram intertwining the initials of Grover Cleveland and Allen G. Thurman. If this vessel was ever used, was it out of support for these Democratic Party candidates, or the opposite?

title: Its Nice to Be Rich
description: Millionaires are already wildly overrepresented in Congress. The Supreme Court gave a big boost to rich candidates this week by striking down the millionaires amendment, which was designed to help level the playing field for candidates running against wealthy opponents.

title: With Elbow Grease and an Artists Eye, a Sculpture in Harlem Regains Its Luster
description: When the artist Richard Hunt conceived Harlem Hybrid, a welded bronze sculpture on a traffic island at West 125th Street, he intended for it to blend in with its surroundings: the triangular plaza it sat on, the church across the street, the street itself.

title: An Angel Rides in to Preserve a Family (and India)
description: What happens when a rich, single-minded businessman is ordered to take care of four children he is responsible for orphaning? God himself (Rishi Kapoor, in a white suit with a Nehru collar) sends help: a mischievous angel, who bikes to earth on a rainbow to save the day, Mary Poppins-style. (And, yes, Virginia, there are dolphins in heaven.)

title: Frost/Nixon Film to Open Festival
description: The movie version of Frost/Nixon, the acclaimed play by Peter Morgan, will open the London Film Festival in October, BBC News reported. The movie, directed by Ron Howard, reconstructs interviews between former President Richard Nixon, played by Frank Langella, and the British journalist David Frost, played by Michael Sheen, that were shown on television in 1977. Both actors are reprising their stage roles for the film. The annual film festival, now in its 52nd year, runs from Oct. 15 through Oct. 30. The movie also stars Kevin Bacon, Oliver Platt and Sam Rockwell. The play, which opened in London in 2006, later came to Broadway and earned three Tony nominations in 2007.

title: With Wireless Network, City Agencies Have More Eyes in More Places
description: Rigor mortis had set in by the time Joseph Mauro, a supervisor with the Department of Sanitation, drove by a dead opossum on Park Drive East in the Kew Gardens Hills section of Queens.

title: McCain Pitches a Bipartisan Plan for Achieving Energy Security
description: This advertisement for Senator John McCain, the presumed Republican nominee, will be going on the air in key closely contested states and on national cable television. Titled Purpose, it runs for 30 seconds.

title: World Stocks Sag as Oil Price Surges
description: LONDON  Oil reached $142 a barrel, a record high, and world stock indexes declined as Wall Street braced for markets to open a day after a painful 300-point plunge in the Dow.

title: A Candidate Runs to a G.O.P. Chorus of Dont
description: ATLANTA  He has been called a spoiler. A would-be Ralph Nader. A thorn in the side of Senator John McCain and the Republican establishment.

title: Serbs Choose New Premier for Coalition
description: PRAGUE  Serbias finance minister, Mirko Cvetkovic, was nominated on Friday to become prime minister of a new pro-European coalition government.

title: Fox News Finds Its Rivals Closing In
description: When prime-time cable news ratings for the second quarter of 2008 are officially released next week, they will show that Fox News reclaimed the top spot among viewers in their mid-20s through mid-50s, those of greatest interest to news advertisers, according to estimates from Nielsen Media Research.

title: Battered by Oil, Dow Touches Bear Territory
description: After eight brutal months on Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average finally made it official: Blue-chip stocks have stumbled into bear territory.

title: The Odds Are as Big as Their Dreams
description: Michael Rodgers came from California to New York City last month to defy the odds of making a living as an actor, not to defy death by pedaling a secondhand bicycle through Midtown traffic.

title: By Adding Yi, Nets Hope to Expand Their Market
description: Yi Jianlian was about 7,000 miles away when he made the move from Milwaukee to New Jersey. As he trained with the Chinese Olympic basketball team, the Nets made a three-player trade with the Milwaukee Bucks on Thursday afternoon, before the N.B.A. draft, acquiring the 7-foot Yi and putting him in the spotlight on the East Coast.

title: Baltimore Woman, Subject of 05 Article, Is Found Dead
description: BALTIMORE  The troubled stepdaughter of a former city police commissioner was found strangled here on Friday morning.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Thursday about Ira Tucker, the innovative lead singer of the Dixie Hummingbirds gospel quartet, misstated his relationship to two survivors. Sundray Tucker and Lynda Laurence are his daughters, not his sisters. The obituary also paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Anthony Heilbut, an expert on gospel music, about Mr. Tuckers standing in the genre. Mr. Heilbut said Mr. Tucker was the presiding intelligence of gospel quartet music, a subgenre  not of gospel music over all.

title: Some Crinoline and an Accordion Too
description: RedShift Dance unites two choreographers, Kelly Hayes and Katy Orthwein, who met as teenagers while dancing at Joseph Holmes Chicago Dance Theater. For the companys new evening of dances, first presented at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night, the artists have split their program, Tell Her/To Stay, in half.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about the CSX Corporations annual shareholder meeting in New Orleans referred incorrectly to the location of the meeting. It has been held in various sites in CSXs 23-state territory, including the Greenbrier, a resort in West Virginia, but it has not usually been held there.

title: Rested Martnez Labors Through a Weary Start
description: Pedro Martnez is prone to embellishing every now and again, but there was no denying his displeasure Friday night after his dismal start against the Yankees. Between innings, he sat silently and slumped in the dugout. After the Yankees thrashed him for six runs in their 9-0 victory against the Mets, Martnez spoke to reporters with his arms folded across his chest and a blank expression on his face.

title: Not in Lead, Sorenstam Is Still Star of Open
description: EDINA, Minn.  Before thunderstorms rolled across Interlachen Country Club and delayed second-round play at the United States Womens Open, Annika Sorenstam strode up the 18th fairway in sunshine to a standing ovation from fans packed into the grandstands. She waved in thanks for the gesture, as much an acknowledgment of lifetime achievement as for the chance at an eagle that she just had given herself.

title: Dark Knight Pays Tribute
description: The closing credits of The Dark Knight, the highly anticipated sequel to Batman Begins, include a tribute to Heath Ledger, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ledger, who plays the Joker in the film, directed by Christopher Nolan, died of an accidental overdose of prescription drugs in January. The tribute, which also acknowledges the death of Conway Wickliffe, a special-effects technician who was killed in September in an accident, reads, In memory of our friends Heath Ledger & Conway Wickliffe. The film opens July 18.

title: Unlikely Allies on a Former Wedge Issue
description: During his years as the attorney general of Virginia, Mark Earley periodically visited his states prisons. In a very real way, he was looking at the human consequences of his career as a public servant, the men and women jailed for fixed, lengthy sentences without parole under laws Mr. Earley had endorsed. Not surprisingly, many inmates pulled back a few steps when introduced to their visitor.

title: A Witness to Polands History, Now Its Diplomatic Voice
description: GDANSK, Poland

title: Why Some Succeed Wildly

The real estate company Alexico Group, which also developed the Mark Hotel, said a design would be released in the fall. The tower is to rise at the intersection of Leonard and Church Streets, and the sculpture will be fully integrated into the architecture. Mr. Kapoor, who was born in India and lives in London, is known for vast public sculptures like Sky Mirror, a convex stainless steel reflecting sculpture that was installed at Rockefeller Center two years ago. Herzog & de Meurons many projects include the new national stadium for the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing, the Tate Modern museum complex in a former power station at Bankside in London, and an expansion of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

title: An Interview With President Ali Abdullah Saleh
description: Yemen, in the southern corner of the Arabian peninsula, is facing security threats on several fronts. An uprising by northern rebels belonging to the Zaydi branch of Islam reached the outskirts of the capital last month. Al Qaeda's Yemeni branch claimed several attacks on foreign embassies and other targets in recent weeks. The past year has also seen riots and demonstrations across the south, which was a separate country until 1990. The current discontent, some say, has its roots in unresolved conflicts dating back to 1962, when a revolution toppled north Yemen's ancient system of religious rule and the country's modern history began. Robert F. Worth, the Times's Beirut bureau chief, interviewed Yemeni president Ali Abdullah Saleh earlier this month in the capital, Sana. The president spoke in Arabic; this transcript is a translation.

As the French biologist Jacques Monod once said, What is true for E. coli is true for the elephant.

Buses have video screens, Wi-Fi service and power outlets. Customers board in New York outside Penn Station and in Toronto at the Royal York Hotel. Walk-up tickets cost $85 (one way), and the better deals (the earlier the reservation, the lower the price) are available at www.greyhound.com.

Gore certainly did not attend that academy, and yet he feels comfortable defaming McCain by implying that he did not suffer in the P.O.W. camp. title: Choux City
description: I fell for choux paste, a k a cream-puff dough, early in my cooking career. At one of my first restaurant jobs, creating pretty slices for our cheese-plate service left the kitchen with countless dismal little ends of cheese. (We cooks called them cheese butts.) Choux (pronounced SHOO) paste proved the perfect home for the orphaned bits of Boucheron, Roquefort and cheddar. The cheeses would be stirred into the paste, which then was shaped into neat quenelles and fried into beignets; crisp on the exterior, oozy and fragrant on the interior. From near garbage came near perfection, all thanks to a strange, decidedly old-fashioned dough.

His 73 strikeouts in 297 at-bats were high, but his on-base plus slugging percentage was over 1.000 against both lefties and righties. Fully clothed among them stood some relics of Olympics past: Scott Goldblatt, who won a gold medal in the 2004 Games, wore an aqua sport coat and a striped tie and was doing on-air commentary for Swimnetwork.com; Mel Stewart, who won two golds and a bronze in 1992, wore the same goofy get-up, working as Goldblatts sidekick. Meanwhile, Dara Torres, who won the first of her nine Olympic medals in 1984, a year before Michael Phelps was born, stripped off her baggy T-shirt and sweat pants, revealing a breathtaking body in a magenta Speedo. She pulled on a cap marked with her initials and prepared to swim. Torres is now 41 and the mother of a 2-year-old daughter, Tessa Grace. She broke her first of three world records in 1982, at 14, and she has retired from swimming and come back three times, her latest effort built on an obsessive attention to her aging body.

Many thought that bad genes would eventually explain the spike, but Weinstock didnt buy it. In areas where fewer than two generations ago the I.B.D. incidence might have been as low as 1 in 10,000, it was now 1 in 250. A defective gene couldnt spread that quickly, he reasoned. It had to be something in the environment. But what? Stumped, Weinstock tried turning the question around. Instead of asking what triggered I.B.D., he asked what, before the 20th century, protected against it?

Although Strausss new novel, More Than It Hurts You, is set in present-day Long Island, where he grew up, this is no retreat into a safer territory and time. title: No Babies?
description: IT WAS A SPECTACULAR LATE-MAY AFTERNOON IN SOUTHERN ITALY,but the streets of Laviano  a gloriously situated hamlet ranged across a few folds in the mountains of the Campania region  were deserted. There were no day-trippers from Naples, no tourists to take in the views up the steep slopes, the olive trees on terraces, the ruins of the 11th-century fortress with wild poppies spotting its grassy flanks like flecks of blood. And there were no locals in sight either. The town has housing enough to support a population of 3,000, but fewer than 1,600 live here, and every year the number drops. Rocco Falivena, Lavianos 56-year-old mayor, strolled down the middle of the street, outlining for me the towns demographics and explaining why, although the place is more than a thousand years old, its buildings all look so new. In 1980 an earthquake struck, taking out nearly every structure and killing 300 people, including Falivenas own parents. Then from tragedy arose the scent of possibility, of a future. Money came from the national government in Rome, and from former residents who had emigrated to the U.S. and elsewhere. The locals found jobs rebuilding their town. But when the construction ended, so did the work, and the exodus of residents continued as before.

title: Giambi Goes From .150 Hitter to Possible All-Star
description: When Jason Giambi was hitting .150 in early May, the lowest average in the major leagues, he said Yankees Manager Joe Girardi and Kevin Long, the batting coach, kept him from plummeting into a mental funk.Those were the two guys that really kept my head on straight and didnt let the human emotion get in the way where you look up at the board and you go, Im hitting .150, Giambi recalled.Since then, Giambi is hitting .322 and seems look a good bet to be picked for the All-Star team and perhaps compete in the Home Run Derby. I asked Giambi about those possibilities for Sundays Times and he used words like cool and awesome to describe how he would feel if he was selected.As Giambis average deteriorated, he said that Long had told him to stop worrying about statistics. Instead, Long told Giambi to analyze each individual at-bat.At the end of the game, wed go in there and wed line them up, Giambi said. He would be like, Awesome, three out of four at-bats, a line drive or a hard-hit ball. Thats how we were breaking it down. He was like: Look at it, youre doing great. I know the numbers dont show it, but you are. He told me to just keep doing the same things and Id start to get out of this.Long was right. Giambi, who seemed lost in May, is a productive hitter again.

description: OMAHA  The high-tech swimsuits are the ultimate cover-up, if you ask Gary Hall Jr., and not because the full-body versions leave little skin exposed. The more talk there is about how the suits are driving this years record-breaking spree, the less discussion there is of doping.

description: Oh, dear. I have the same feeling one gets when grading final exams: the students have missed the point so badly it must be my fault.

description: Colombia hardly constitutes a general election battleground. Neither does France nor Jordan. But Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are heading to those countries and others because votes can be won there.

description: Scenes from Sunday's gay pride parade on Fifth Avenue in New York.

description: Thayer Evans recently caught up with Jamarkus McFarland, a 6-foot-3, 285-pound defensive tackle who is rated by many as the top defensive recruit in the country.

title: U.S. Track Trials: At Age 40, Vaulter Is Returning to Olympics after 12 Years
description: EUGENE, Ore.  In the previous two United States Olympic trials, Jeff Hartwig was on the painful end of the quirks of the pole vault. He failed to clear a single height in 2000, when he was the dominant force in the sport, and he failed again in 2004.

title: Better Know an N.H.L. Rival: The K.H.L.
description: With the July 1 free agent deadline almost upon us, itd be a good idea to bone up on the Continental Hockey League teams youre going to be hearing a lot about once the offers start flying. Below, we present a capsule summary of each of the KHLs 24 clubs, so you can memorize where they are, who theyve got, and which nefts  the suffix for oil companies, very important on the local level  are doing the bankrolling.

title: Fox Ramps Up Marketing For Fringe
description: TV Week: The out-of-the-box marketing campaign for the Fox drama Fringe continues this week, as Fox begins unleashing paid media in 10 major markets, as well as a nationwide online campaign. description: The popular radio show Car Talk is finally being adapted for television. An animated spinoff, Click & Clacks As the Wrench Turns, will debut June 9 on PBS, Elizabeth Jensen reports.

title: U.S. Swimming Trials: Rival Pushes Phelps to World Record in 400 I.M.
description: OMAHA  For as long as he can remember, Ryan Lochte has played Lil Wayne to Michael Phelpss Jay-Z in the 400-meter individual medley. For all his immense talent, Lochte has been unable to unseat the king, Phelps, who has owned the world record in the event since 2002.

title: Final Hours of Florent
description: Florent, a restaurant that helped transform Manhattans meatpacking district, closed after more than two decades in business.

title: U.S. Track Trials: Gay Runs Wind-Aided 9.68 to Win 100 Meters
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Because of a stiff tailwind, Tyson Gay did not shatter the limits of human possibility with his astounding time of 9.68 in the 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials on Sunday.

title: Sam H.F.J. Manekshaw Dies at 94; Key to Indias Victory in 1971 War
description: Field Marshal Sam Hormusji Framji Jamshedji Manekshaw, Indias best-known soldier and the architect of the countrys victory in the 1971 war with Pakistan that gave birth to Bangladesh, died in Wellington, India, on Friday. He was 94.

title: The Winehouse Punch
description: Amy Winehouse  performed for a crowd of about 80,000 on Saturday at the Glastonbury Music Festival in England, and there was just one small problem: She appeared to punch a fan during the show, the BBC reported. Video of the incident, which is widely available on the Web, does not indicate a clear cause of the altercation, though witnesses said a fan tried to grab her. By Sunday the police had received no complaints of assault and said there would be no further investigation. It was a busy weekend for Ms. Winehouse, a woman who was in the hospital a week ago. On Friday she appeared at a concert in Hyde Park in London to celebrate the 90th birthday of Nelson Mandela.

title: Prez Shows His Good Side, Which Is Bad for the Yanks
description: Hardly anyone dominates left-handed hitters quite like Oliver Prez, but then again, hardly anyone does most things like him. These truths confronted Joe Girardi on Sunday morning as he filled out the Yankees lineup card. He chose to sit Bobby Abreu, Robinson Can and Jason Giambi, all lefties, while preparing for  maybe expecting  Prezs quirkiness to reveal itself, as it often does, through command problems and a lack of focus.

title: 6 Killed and 3 Are Injured as Copters Collide
description: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz.  Two medical helicopters collided on Sunday as one was taking off and the other landing, killing at least six people and critically injuring three others, officials said.

title: In a Dry Spell This Season, Kurt Busch Benefits From the Rain and Wins a Race
description: LOUDON, N.H.  Kurt Busch won a Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday even though he was not sitting in his stock car at the time. A tarpaulin covered his blue Dodge, which was parked on pit road and had a part ominously dangling from the bottom.

title: A Master of Nonchalance in Control of His Illusions
description: When the artist formerly known as Frdric Gafner changed his name to Foofwa dImobilit in the mid-1990s, it seemed both the gesture of a surrealist and irritatingly pretentious. But when he returned last week to New York after several years, things had changed.

title: Malaysia Opposition Leader Accused of Sodomizing Aide
description: Anwar Ibrahim, the leader of Malaysias resurgent political opposition, took refuge on Sunday in the Turkish Embassy in the capital, Kuala Lumpur, saying he feared for his security after an aide accused him of participating in homosexual acts.

title: Group Suggests an Exchange to Trade Internet Capacity
description: PARIS  There are exchanges where you can buy and sell stocks, futures, pork bellies, wine and even pollution allowances.

title: Ferrying From Manhattan to Bare It All on the Beach
description: SANDY HOOK, N.J.  In honor of Nude Recreation Week, traditionally celebrated after July 4, join us on the Wall Street ferry SeaStreak as it makes its twice-daily run to Gunnison Beach, the busiest clothing-optional recreation area in the nation, devotees say.

title: Thinking the Unthinkable: A World Without Nuclear Weapons
description: When Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev talked at the 1986 Reykjavik summit about giving up all of their nuclear weapons within a decade, it was dismissed as a trick or more frightening proof that the American president was out of touch with strategic realities. The deal fell apart over Mr. Reagans refusal to limit testing of a missile defense program that was notional then and is still.

description: It is safe to speculate that at some point in his young life, the Scottish historian Niall Ferguson happened upon the documentaries of the art critic Robert Hughes and believed he had found his destiny.

title: Israels Diplomatic Offensive
description: Few countries can afford the luxury of limiting their diplomacy to friendly countries and peace-loving parties. National security often requires negotiating with dangerous enemies. Fortunately, Israels prime minister, Ehud Olmert, is now displaying a clearer grasp of such realities than President Bush has mustered.

description: Pasadena, Calif.

title: Online Tunes, in Service to Africa
description: The music business is known for supporting causes with events like the Live Aid and Live Earth concerts, which generate lots of money and publicity for a relatively short time. But on Monday (RED), a nonprofit organization that arranges for companies to contribute a share of profits on certain products to fight AIDS in Africa, is starting a digital music service for that purpose, and it plans to operate for the long haul. The new venture has already arranged to release new songs from U2, Bob Dylan, Elvis Costello, Elton John, Emmylou Harris and Death Cab for Cutie.

Seven states  Arizona, California, Georgia, Illinois, Louisiana, Mississippi and Rhode Island  had delinquency rates of 4 to 5 percent, not 5 to 6 percent. Two states, Indiana and Ohio, had delinquency rates of 5 to 6 percent, not over 6 percent. A corrected version can be found at nytimes.com/business.

title: A Hurdler Lives Up to Her Name
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Queen Quedith Earth Harrison did not expect to jump an 11th barrier in the womens 400-meter hurdles at the Olympic track and field trials, especially one that was human.

title: Expanding Democracy in Florida
description: Among the worlds democracies, the United States is uniquely unforgiving in denying ex-offenders the right to vote. Nowhere is the problem worse than in Florida, where criminal justice experts estimate that as many as 950,000 felons are barred from the voting booth.

title: In Italy, Eroica Energizes a Frail Fixture of Period Music
description: SPOLETO, Italy  The stooped figure, his head topped with a shock of white hair, made his way slowly out onto the stage of a toy-size theater on Sunday as muses gazed down from the frescoed ceiling.

title: 15-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot in Harlem
description: A 15-year-old boy was killed early Sunday by what appeared to be a stray bullet while walking with a friend in Harlem, the police said.

title: For a Good Cause: Bits and Pieces and Company Depth
description: As a benefit for its Dancers Emergency Fund, New York City Ballet on Friday presented a one-time-only galalike event, Dancers Choice. It fell to a principal, Jonathan Stafford, to be the dancer who chose. Apart from selecting material from a repertory that contains (he told us) 238 ballets, he came up with a number of novelties. These included new and unfamiliar casts in known works, excerpts of dances unseen in several seasons, and the world premiere of a ballet choreographed and composed by a pair of 27-year-old company members.

title: Anglican Conservatives, Rebelling on Gays, Will Form New Power Bloc
description: JERUSALEM  Anglican conservatives, frustrated by the continuing stalemate over homosexuality in the Anglican Communion, declared Sunday that they would defy historic lines of authority and create a new power bloc within the communion led by a council predominantly of African archbishops.

title: Beloved Pets, Displaced by Floodwaters, Find Temporary Shelter in Iowa
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  As floodwaters began to rise this spring, forcing thousands from their homes, Sgt. Kent Choate oversaw one of the larger evacuation efforts, providing shelter to hundreds of animals whose owners had been displaced.

title: A Long Way to Catch the Yanks (and the Phils)
description: There are millions of New Yorkers who refer to the Mets as the second baseball team in a two-team city, from teachers to actuaries to pharmacists. They are probably Yankees fans or truthful fans. The Yankees have a history that dwarfs the Mets history, and they have routinely been the better club across the past 16 seasons.

title: Commanding a Role for Women in the Military
description: WASHINGTON  For more than a decade, Lt. Gen. Ann E. Dunwoody has delighted in leaping through the doors of military planes and plunging into the night with a parachute on her back.

description: On the Internet, theres an answer to every question  even how are marshmallows made? and how do toilets work? The Web site HowStuffWorks wants to remind television viewers and Web visitors that it knows how.

description: Alice Dye, the wife of the famed golf architect Pete Dye and the author of the 2004 book From Birdies to Bunkers, has been a tireless and prominent advocate of the game for decades. title: McCain Gets Praise, Not Backing, From Grahams
description: Senator John McCain, who has had trouble courting faith-based voters, went to the mountaintop on Sunday  Billy Grahams Blue Ridge mountaintop retreat in western North Carolina, that is  and met with the evangelist and his son the Rev. Franklin Graham for a private, 45-minute conversation.

title: U.S. Advised Iraqi Ministry on Oil Deals
description: A group of American advisers led by a small State Department team played an integral part in drawing up contracts between the Iraqi government and five major Western oil companies to develop some of the largest fields in Iraq, American officials say.

title: Sweet-Talking a Crowd With Flirting and Flowers
description: Only thing I can do is be myself, Al Green told the Carnegie Hall audience at his JVC Jazz Festival concert on Friday night. Fans know that. An Al Green concert is a free-form excursion, a hodgepodge of virtuosity, teasing, flirting, preaching, making faces, dancing, flinging red roses and coaching audience participation. Sometimes he tosses the show away, doing more smiling than singing. And sometimes he displays the voice and presence that make him one of souls greatest singers.

title: Mugabe Is Sworn In to Sixth Term After Victory in One-Candidate Runoff
description: JOHANNESBURG  Robert Mugabe, the runaway winner in a one-horse race, was quickly inaugurated Sunday as president of Zimbabwe after a runoff election on Friday. His opponent had already dropped out because state-sponsored enforcers were beating and killing his followers.

title: Artists Daughter-in-Law Accused of Theft
description: The daughter-in-law of the Op Art pioneer Victor Vasarely has surrendered her French passport after being accused of stealing artwork from a storage site in Chicago that was being rented by a dealer, Agence France-Presse reported. The artists daughter-in-law, Michle Taburno-Vasarely, said the paintings that she was trying to take belonged to her and that she feared that the gallery owner, Thomas Monahan, was planning to steal them from her. Mr. Monahan said he had indeed been storing thousands of pieces for Ms. Taburno-Vasarely but became concerned about how she had obtained them when he heard of an inquiry now under way in France. He said his lawyer had advised him to hold on to the works until rightful ownership could be established. Prosecutors asked a county judge to postpone Ms. Taburno-Vasarelys case until July 16 and said they intended to seek a grand jury indictment on felony theft charges. She was arrested on June 22 when the authorities discovered her trying to move the bubble-wrapped paintings from Mr. Monahans unit into an adjacent one. She was released on a $125,000 bond two days later. Mr. Vasarely died in 1997.

title: In China, Jeers and Cheers for Kung Fu Panda
description: Sometimes it is important to take a political stand. And sometimes it is just fun to watch a cartoon panda trying to do kung fu.

description: WIMBLEDON, England  Crack! went one racket as Radek Stepanek slammed it against a chair Saturday evening. Crack! went a second racket a few moments later.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising column on June 12, about two television shows in which the sponsors are integral to the shows content, misspelled the given name of a host of one program and misstated her background. She is Shanon Cook, not Shannon. And she is a host and contributing reporter on CNN; she is not an actress.

title: With Skirts of Crinoline and an Accordion Too
description: RedShift Dance unites two choreographers, Kelly Hayes and Katy Orthwein, who met as teenagers while dancing at Joseph Holmes Chicago Dance Theater. For the companys new evening of dances, first presented at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night, the artists have split their program, Tell Her/To Stay, in half.

title: Presidential Campaign Turns Personal
description: WASHINGTON  The presidential campaign turned personal on Monday as John McCains camp offered an unusually sharp and vigorous defense against attacks on the relevance of his military experience to national leadership, and as Senator Barack Obama attacked head-on the persistent rumors that his loyalties to the country are doubtful.

title: So, How Would You Like Your Culture Clash? Joke-Filled or Sugar-Glazed?
description: CHICAGO  Tracy Lettss Pulitzer-and-everything-else-winning August: Osage County is a full theatrical meal, a nine-course tasting menu of family angst. His new play, Superior Donuts, which opened Saturday at the Steppenwolf Theater here, is a much less ambitious repast. It has a lot in common with the deep-fried breakfast food of the title. Its insubstantial and sweet, with virtually no nutritional value.

title: Chinese Riot Over Handling of Girls Killing
description: BEIJING  Thousands of people have rioted in a county in southwest China, setting fire to government buildings and overturning cars in angry protests over the official handling of the death of a local teenage girl, according to a human rights group, state news media and videotapes of the events.

title: Falling Prices Grip Major Stock Markets Around the World
description: FRANKFURT  As the United States markets edge toward bear territory, losing nearly 20 percent of their value from last falls peak, investors might wonder where they can turn for relief.

title: Jagr Wants to Stay a Ranger, but He Has a World of Options
description: With the free-agency signing period to begin Tuesday, the drama surrounding the future of Rangers right wing Jaromir Jagr has only deepened.

title: Siemens Is Said to Be Preparing to Cut More Than 17,000 Jobs
description: PARIS  Siemens, the German engineering and electronics company, plans to cut 17,200 mostly white-collar jobs as it reorganizes to reduce its cost base, a person who has been briefed on the plans said on Sunday.

title: Amid U.S. Policy Disputes, Qaeda Grows in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  Late last year, top Bush administration officials decided to take a step they had long resisted. They drafted a secret plan to make it easier for the Pentagons Special Operations forces to launch missions into the snow-capped mountains of Pakistan to capture or kill top leaders of Al Qaeda.

title: Friends Reunited at a Wedding on Maines Rocky Coast, Dashed Hopes All Around
description: One of the rich, adrift Yale chums in Galt Niederhoffers second novel never quite managed to apply to film school after graduation. But he did buy expensive screenwriting software, read part of its manual and write an unfinished script about a clique of college friends who reunite at a funeral. This little self-referential nugget is nicely buried in The Romantics, Ms. Niederhoffers book about a clique of college friends reuniting at a wedding.

title: A Team, and a Country, Finally Unite as One
description: With his strawberry-blond locks and fair cheeks, Fernando Torres of Spain does not look like the grim, physical forward who could bedevil mighty Germany.

title: Cabarets Non-Sinatra
description: Un-Frank-like, meaning not in the Sinatra manner, said Tom Wopat, describing his approach to Thats Life on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. Swinging lightly and joking his way through the 1966 hit that Frank Sinatra turned into a vocal punching bag, Mr. Wopat treated it as an offhanded sparring match between the urge to triumph and the impulse to throw in the towel. Thats alliteration, he joked, after singing the lines, Ive been a puppet, a pirate, a pauper, a poet, a pawn and a king.

title: Nine-Game Test Awaits the Yankees
description: The schedule says the Texas Rangers will make their only appearance at Yankee Stadium this week, but that is not exactly accurate. A chunk of the Rangers lineup will probably come back next month for the All-Star Game.

title: Little Movies, Big Problems
description: Hollywood is having a good-to-great summer. Box office is marginally up  mostly on the strength of increased ticket prices, but still, theres over $4.52 billion already in the bank this year, according to Media by Numbers. The big studios  the sworn enemy of moviegoing snobs  have used great casting, like Robert Downey Jr. in Iron Man, Steve Carell in Get Smart, filmmaking innovation in Pixars Wall-E and Wanted and smart retreading in Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull and Sex and the City to leave both audiences and the people in the studio corner office happy.

title: Celebrating Female Composers (Without Polemics)
description: During a panel presented recently at the National Performing Arts Convention in Denver, the American Music Center and the American Composers Forum reported preliminary findings from Taking Note, a survey of American composers. The study was undertaken to help those organizations better serve their constituencies. According to its findings, the average American composer is a highly educated 45-year-old white male.

title: Jozef Szajna, 86, Writer of Quiet Protest in Poland, Dies
description: Jozef Szajna, a Polish playwright, set designer and theater director who through often nearly wordless productions evoked the beastliness of humanity, the suffocation of individuality and the oppressiveness of dictatorship  gaining acclaim even during the Communist era  died on Tuesday in Warsaw. He was 86.

title: A Game Changer Left Unchanged by the Game
description: LUFKIN, Tex.  After sitting through a lesson in a college algebra class, Jamarkus McFarland trotted out to a tan sports utility vehicle driven by his mother.

title: Intels Dominance Is Challenged by a Low-Power Upstart
description: SAN DIEGO  From mainframes to minicomputers and then PCs, each new computing generation has displaced its predecessor by reaching a broader audience and costing far less. And each time, the dominant company in one generation loses control in the next.

title: Israel Agrees to Exchange Prisoners for Dead Soldiers
description: JERUSALEM  Israels government voted Sunday to trade one of the most notorious convicts in its prisons, a Lebanese murderer, for the bodies of two Israeli soldiers whose cross-border capture led to and partly motivated its monthlong war with the Lebanese militia Hezbollah in summer 2006.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Business Marketing Association presented the Best in Show Award at the 26th annual New York Ace Awards ceremony to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, for the blade center integrated marketing campaign, created for I.B.M. BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, won in the corporate brand category, for the ecomagination campaign for General Electric. Merkley & Partners, also part of Omnicom, won in the rich media online ad category, for AXA Equitable. And Summit Marketing won in the promotional materials and/or product service catalog category, for Coca-Cola.

description: LOS ANGELES  Google is experimenting with a new method of distributing original material on the Web, and some Hollywood film financiers are betting millions that the company will succeed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Thursday about a speech by President Bush at a fund-raising event for the Michigan Republican Party misspelled the surname of the cleric who delivered the invocation at the event. He is Rabbi E. B. Freedman, not Friedman.

title: South Korea Cracks Down on Suspected Protest Organizers
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The police on Monday raided the offices of two civic groups accused of leading weeks of protests against American beef imports. The raids followed government warnings that it would get tough on the demonstrations.

title: The Tombstones Have It
description: Performances presented by Danspace Project take place in St. Marks Church: the tombstones in the entryway to St. Marks Church, with their poignantly terse testaments to brief lives, are reminder enough. But once inside, both audiences and artists tend to regard the church as a neutral, if atmospheric, theatrical space.

title: Love Guru, Panned in U.S., Heads to India
description: Whats worse: that the new Mike Myers movie, The Love Guru, satirizes Indians and mocks Hinduism, or that it is just not funny?

title: Rookie Wins on European Tour
description: The Spanish rookie Pablo Larrazabal won the French Open for his first European Tour victory, closing with a four-under 67 to beat Colin Montgomerie by four strokes at Versailles. Larrazabal, who had to play two qualifying rounds, finished at 15-under 269.

title: Pakistani Forces Appear to Push Back Militants
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani paramilitary forces pushed fighters belonging to an Islamic militant group farther from Peshawar on Sunday and destroyed unoccupied bases and houses belonging to members of the group. But the militants leader appeared to remain unscathed.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  The government of President Lee Myung-bak sealed off major rallying points in central Seoul on Sunday after hundreds of citizens and police officers were injured during a protest against United States beef imports.

The photograph of workers searching the rubble of the twin towers was by Ruth Fremson of The New York Times, not by Tyler Hicks of The Times.

title: Trying to Keep His Home, Guardsman Loses His Life
description: Gloria Hedges walked out into the hot, muggy morning air last Thursday and made her way, as if against her will, around the corner to Liberty Avenue, the main strip in South Ozone Park, Queens. She trudged into a corner bodega looking for candles, then headed to the supermarket, where she finally found some among the mops and liquid cleaners. When she paid, she asked for a few pieces of tape from the cashier, then headed to the cab stand where the man she loved used to work. She asked the dispatcher what he thought: better inside or out?

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of four-week and one-year bills on Tuesday.

description: After clashes with entrenched interest groups over education, firehouse closings and other knotty issues, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is seeking to bring his business-minded, results-based approach to an especially challenging constituency: the elderly.

description: The very future of how we consume media rests on the movie star shoulders of Will Smith. That is Hollywood hyperbole  but it contains a speck of truth.

description: SEATTLE  In Ballard, a quiet neighborhood not far from the waterfront where many of its residents once worked, I found a replica of an Icelandic badstofa.

But even after graduation on Thursday, one more job remained for the high schools college counselor and principal: hound their students to make sure they have completed every last task to enroll in their college classes in the fall.

description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi government officials on Sunday criticized the American military for two recent attacks in which soldiers killed people who the government said were civilians.

description: BANGKOK  At least 29 countries have sharply curbed food exports in recent months, to ensure that their own people have enough to eat, at affordable prices.

description: Comic-book collectors like their numbers. They know that the first issue of X-Men, which introduced Marvels mutant superheroes, was published in 1963 and had a cover price of 12 cents. They also know that today a copy of that issue, in near mint condition, is worth $16,500. (Parents, take note.)

title: The Choice They Made
description: Half a century ago the philosopher Leo Strauss remarked that the passage in which the Declaration of Independence proclaims its self-evident truths has frequently been quoted, but, by its weight and its elevation, it is made immune to the degrading effects of the excessive familiarity which breeds contempt and of misuse which breeds disgust.

title: Closing Time at a Diner That Never Closed

title: Chicago Shows, Going and Coming
description: Adding Machine, the musical adaptation of Elmer Rices bleak 1923 play, presented in New York by the Next Theater Company, is to close on July 20 after 16 previews and 149 regular performances at the Minetta Lane Theater. The production, with a score by Joshua Schmidt and a libretto by Jason Loewith and Mr. Schmidt, was well received by New York critics after a successful run in Chicago, where it won a Joseph Jefferson Award for best new musical. Another new show from that city is on its way to New York. Beginning July 9, Theater Ooblecks production of The Strangerer, by Mickle Maher, will be presented off Broadway at the Barrow Street Theater with the four-member Chicago cast intact. A political satire, Mr. Mahers play mashes together an unlikely combination: the works of Albert Camus (of The Stranger fame) and a George W. Bush-John Kerry presidential debate of 2004. The political rivals grapple with many questions, including the moral implications of murdering the debates moderator, Jim Lehrer.

The film, scheduled for a September release, stars George Clooney and Brad Pitt, who won best actor in Venice last year for his role in The Assassination of Jesse James. Mr. Wenders, 62, began his career as a film critic but went on to direct such films as Paris, Texas (1984) and Wings of Desire (1987). Another of his films, The State of Things, won the Golden Lion at Venice in 1982.

title: The Robot Rules
description: Disney-Pixar had a good day on Friday, when the animated feature Wall-E earned an estimated $23.1 million at the box office, breaking a record for the most lucrative opening day for a G-rated film. (Finding Nemo, which made $20.2 million on its first day in 2003, was the previous record holder, Variety reported. Andrew Stanton is the screenwriter-director behind both films.) It is hardly surprising, then, that Wall-E, the story of a lonely robot charged with clearing the earth of trash discarded by humans while also seeking love, was the top draw for the weekend, taking in $62.5 million, according to the box office tracking company Media by Numbers. Universals new action film Wanted, based on the comic strip by Mark Millar and starring Angelina Jolie, James McAvoy and Morgan Freeman, came in second, earning $51.1 million for its first weekend. Third was last weeks No. 1, the Steve Carell spy comedy Get Smart (Warner Brothers), which made $20 million in its second week, for a cumulative $77.3 million. The Paramount-DreamWorks animation movie Kung Fu Panda earned $11.7 million, enough for fourth place. That movie, about a panda named Po, voiced by Jack Black, who dreams of becoming a kung fu master, has made $179.3 million in four weeks. Rounding out the Top 5 was The Incredible Hulk, from Marvel and Universal Pictures, which earned $9.2 million, for a total of $115.5 million in three weeks.

The Tragic End of Bushs North Korea Policy, an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal, was his elegy for one of the first major foreign policy shifts of George W. Bushs presidency:

title: No G.O.P. Consensus on Fossella Replacement

title: U.S. Swimming Trials: Two World Records in Less Than Two Minutes
description: OMAHA  For about two minutes, Hayley McGregory was on the top of the world. Swimming in the second-to-last heat of the preliminaries for the 100-meter backstroke at the United States Olympic Trials, McGregory, a 22-year-old from Texas, clocked a 59.15 to break the world record by .06 seconds.

title: An Underdog Challenges Speedo
description: OMAHA  In 1992, Roque Santos made the Olympic team as a decided underdog, handing the world-record holder Mike Barrowman his first defeat in the 200-meter breaststroke in three and a half years at the United States Swimming trials. Sixteen years later, he is at these trials, reprising his role as the earnest long shot.

title: CBS Completes CNet Acquisition
description: Television and radio station operator CBS Corporation said Monday that it completed its acquisition of CNet Networks, the Associated Press reports.

title: U.S. Track Trials: 800 Meters  the Beautiful Race
description: EUGENE, Ore.  The 800 meters is one of the beautiful races in track and field. In the shorter races (100, 200 and 400), one mistake usually means defeat. In the next-longest Olympic race, the 1,500, there is enough time and distance to overcome some mistakes.

title: NBC Escapes a Ratings Inferno
description: Ten Scariest Escapes from Death lifted NBCs Dateline to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday among adults 18 to 49, though the network finished second in total viewers. [A promo for the show promised, People trapped in burning planes, sinking ships, a roaring avalanche, skydiving accidents  and each one is caught on tape. You cant help but ask, How could anyone survive that?!]

description: Psychology | Havent much of a clue? Guess again. Researchers have found that the average of first and second guesses is more accurate than either guess on its own. But its best to solicit other views, a la The Wisdom of Crowds: more heads are far better than one.  Economist

title: Paris Mens Shows | Video Round-up
description: As the Paris mens shows wind down to a close, its time for a mens wear video retrospective courtesy of Suzy Menkes, a T columnist and one of our favorite colleagues over at the International Herald Tribune. The clips feature candid interviews with style guydols like Tom Ford (he confirms he is dressing Daniel Craig in the next James Bond installment!), Paul Smith (he plays peek-a-boo behind a pair of bright green shoes!), Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce (they describe Naomi Campbell as being like a little sister!), Bottega Venetas Tomas Maier (he says the key look in a mens wardrobe is the jacket!), and, er, Fergie? Check out that clip, if for nothing else, to see Fergie call Menkes a goddess and confess to always loving the fetching IHT fashion editor. Suzylicious!

title: Photo Album: Managing My Hives
description: A beekeeper never really knows whats going on inside a hive until she takes a look. You can see bees coming and going, and you can observe a funnel of activity at the entrance and assume the worst (bees have a natural swarming instinct, often expressed as a small tornado of swirling bees at the front of the hive, which can presage a mass exodus). Are they ready to swarm because of cramped quarters from bulging frames of honey? No way to know until you take a look.

title: Poets in the Cave
description: Poetry doesnt matter to most people, and one guy you can blame is Plato. Reality, for Plato, was a perfect world of ideas, writes Jay Parini. Artistic representations of nature were thus at several removes from the ideal, hence suspicious. Poets have been back on their heels ever since.  Chronicle Review

title: G.E. Foundation Gives $17.9 Million to Schools
description: The G.E. Foundation, the philanthropic arm of General Electric, will give a $17.9 million grant to benefit New Yorks public schools, officials announced Monday. The grant is largest single corporate donation made to the Fund for Public Schools, a private group that raises money for the Education Department.The money will be distributed to roughly 10 middle schools in northern Manhattan, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said during a press conference at St. Nicholas Park Plaza to announce the grant.

title: A Bon Jovi Concert (With a Slip-Up Over Troubled Waters)
description: Updated, 6:49 p.m. | The rock band Bon Jovi will give a free concert on July 12 to as many as 60,000 people on the Great Lawn of Central Park in honor of Major League Baseballs 79th All-Star Game, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced at a news conference on Monday afternoon. The humorous highlight of the news conference occurred when the bands lead singer, Jon Bon Jovi, teased the mayor for mispronouncing Art Garfunkels name. (Mr. Bloomberg, citing previous performances on the lawn, had referred to Simon and Garfinkel.)

title: Cast Your Vote for Week 10
description: Where will I go during Week 10 of my Grand Tour? Readers sent in more than 170 recommendations, and whittling those down to three was far from easy, especially when everywhere sounded so enticing. Vienna, wrote Janice, is the epicenter for modern Western culture. Ibiza is like the Cabo of Europe times 100, cheered Eric. And Kosovo is super-cheap, but still sophisticated and fun, said a reader named Texas.

title: Go Forth and Get It On

title: Would You Buy an Electric Car Now?
description: In February, I wrote about researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory who proposed sucking carbon dioxide out of the air and turning it into gasoline as one way to battle global warming and find a new energy source. That prompted vehement e-mail messages from some readers who felt that I was being irresponsible in suggesting that gasoline could have a long-term future, and that to raise that possibility drew attention from electric cars, which they said was the real solution.

title: An Uncommon Thread, Part One
description: Its been more than 25 years since I ventured out on my creative walkabout as a songwriter. While traveling these songlines, I have had  and hope to continue to have  the good fortune to work with a number of truly gifted and inspiring men and women. One thing I have found in all of these artists, no matter how green or how legendary they appeared to be, is an uncommon thread, common to all of us, a strange strand of tribal D.N.A. living in our veins that connects us to each other. We experience the rush of taking something that has been hidden from the world and then we bring it back into the light to be seen and heard.
